title: SILICONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain from a land sale of $7,215,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $424,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective August 17.

title: Kurt Weill Conference
description: The Yale Music Library and the Kurt Weill Foundation for Music will sponsor an International Conference on Kurt Weill Nov. 2 to Nov. 5 at Yale University in New Haven. There will be performances of much of Weill's surviving European concert music and an exhibition of Weill material including manuscripts of his American works. A feature of the conference will be screenings of three rare films with scores by Weill. For information call 873-1465

title: The Marine Band Arrives
description: They practiced and practiced but, somehow, the members of the United States Marine Band never got to Carnegie Hall.

title: CHEMICAL BARRED AS PESTICIDE, BUT SAFETY RULES ARE BLOCKED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, after a 10-year fight over the issue, today banned most agricultural uses of ethylene dibromide, a chemical known to cause cancer. It is used both as a pesticide and a gasoline additive.

title: Wranglers, Blitz Trade Franchises
description: The Chicago Blitz and the Arizona Wranglers of the United States Football League announced today that they have traded franchises, including the rosters of players.

title: NIGERIANS ASSESS ELECTION FAIRNESS
description: Since early August more than 40,000 Nigerians have run for 1,913 offices on the presidential, gubernatorial, senatorial, congressional and state assembly levels.

title: Everyone's Pick
description: Nebraska's powerful offense has made such an impression upon the nation's coaches, writers and broadcasters that the Cornhuskers were a unanimous choice as the No. 1 team in both the United Press International and Associated Press polls this week.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture credit was omitted Thursday under a front-page photograph of Yuri V. Andropov. It was by Gamma-Liaison/Laurent Maous.

title: CHIEF OF HAWAII INVESTMENT FIRM JAILED IN $1.2 MILLION FRAUD
description: A few months ago Ronald Ray Rewald was spending up to $250,000 a month on polo, ranches and a million-dollar home. He is now in state prison awaiting trial on charges of defrauding investors of up to $12 million.

title: 2 Coast Policemen Held In Attempted Murder
description: A judge ordered two suspended city police officers today to stand trial on charges they attempted to murder a woman for a $100,000 insurance policy.

title:
GOING OUT GUIDE;
HAVEN
description: Snug Harbor is celebrating this year its 150th birthday as a refuge, first for elderly and ill seamen and, since 1976, for those in search of arts and culture or just a beautiful area in which to wander about. Snug Harbor covers 80 acres dotted with 26 buildings, columned and other, reminiscent of old college-campus elegance laid out on attractive grounds. It is on Staten Island's north shore, at 914 Richmond Terrace, two miles west of the ferry terminal in the Livingston area that overlooks the Kill van Kull.

title: Poetry Prize Awarded
description: Philip Booth, a professor of English at Syracuse University, has won the $10,000 fellowship of the Academy of American Poets for ''distinguished poetic achievement.'' Mr. Booth is the 45th recipient of the award, whose past recipients include Robert Frost, Ezra Pound, William Carlos Williams, Marianne Moore and Elizabeth Bishop.

title: CHAMBER OF COMMERCE IS BUDGETING
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce, the country's largest spokesman for business, which is a front-row critic of overspending by the Government, has begun to practice what it has long preached from its neo-classical limestone bastion overlooking the White House: living within its means.

title: 'ERENDIRA,' A GIRL, A GRANDMOTHER AND A LIBERATOR
description: Once upon a time, in a vast, otherwise empty desert, there is a great house filled with paper flowers and enough inflammable bric-a-brac to satisfy several generations of antique dealers. Here, with their pet ostrich, live a pretty, solemn-faced slavey named Erendira and her Gorgon of a grandmother, an imperious lady whose house and manners deny the destitution all around them.

title: Raymond Lester, Built ModelofNew YorkCity
description: Raymond A. Lester, whose company built the $600,000 scale model of New York City for the 1964-65 World's Fair, died of a heart attack Thursday at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: CBS and Coke Deny Rumors

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday misstated the size of the work force designated to operate the Department of Education in a budgetary emergency. It would consist of 18 officials and their personal secretaries.

title: U.S. ASSERTS SYRIA STILL REJECTS ROLE BY U.N. IN LEBANON
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz failed yesterday to persuade Syria's Foreign Minister to drop his Government's refusal to agree to United Nations observers to police the cease-fire in Lebanon, a senior State Department official said.

title: GAS STATIONS AND JOBS VANISH AS OIL COMPANIES REALIGN MARKET
description: Bethel Finnesend answered the phone at her service station several weeks ago with her usual greeting: ''Good morning. Harvey's Mobil.''

title: Two-Hand Sets Returning Briefly
description: When New York University resumes its varsity basketball program on Nov. 26 against City College at the Coles Sports and Recreation Center, alumni of both colleges should feel twinges of nostalgia during a pregame contest between former stars from both the Violets and the Beavers.

title: STOPGAP FEDERAL MONEY BILL IS VOTED
description: Congress approached the new fiscal year with unaccustomed discipline today, swiftly approving a 40-day stopgap spending bill needed to keep the Government operating after midnight.

title: PLAN TO PURIFY UPPER HUDSON WATERS
description: The Hudson River, flowing from Lake Tear of the Clouds in the Adirondacks to a deep-cleft valley that leads it past New York City to the Atlantic Ocean, is one of the most beautiful rivers in the world. But its looks are deceiving. Beneath its surface are highly toxic substances, polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

title: A LOVE-HATE AFFAIR ON LAKE ONTARIO
description: You can still go to the old places here - those saloons with their separate gentlemen's and ladies' entrances, where the endless glasses of draft beer come in even numbers. ''Each drinker is an island unto himself,'' said a patron of the Wheatsheaf, founded in 1849 and Toronto's oldest bar. ''Ontario may be the Scotland that was.''

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1983
description: International

title: Promoters in Accord
description: Just minutes after a jury had reached a verdict following a 10-week trial in the dispute between Don King and Butch Lewis over their rival contracts with Greg Page, the top-ranked heavyweight contender, King and Lewis reached an out-of-court settlement Thursday night. The agreement recognizes the King contract but requires him to pay Lewis $200,000.

title: THE RIGHTERS' BLOC
description: It seemed all right to me, but it was all left to him.

title: THE MAGIC OF 'CHORUS LINE' NO. 3,389
description: The only sad thing about a great night in the theater is its evanescence. When it's over, it's over. You can remember the performance forever, of course. But you can't re-create that virgin sensation - that almost numbing exhilaration - of witnessing something new and different and exciting in the theater for the very first time.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: THE FALTERING SALES AT AIRBUS
description: The day before Japan Air Lines announced it was buying nine new Boeing 767 airliners for $560 million, there were already long faces at Airbus Industrie headquarters in Toulouse.

title: Weaver Stops Ward in 9th
description: Mike Weaver, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, knocked out Stan Ward in the ninth round of their scheduled 15-round non-title bout at The Forum tonight.

title: MIDCON OIL & GAS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,981,495 from the sale of petroleum and natural gas interests and a gain of $1,409,857 from the sale of fixed assets.

title: Democrats See Deception
description: Democrats began a modest radio campaign today that seeks to associate record Federal budget deficits with the Reagan Administration.

title: SCHAGRIN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELEPHONE UNITS SEEK NEW RATES
description: The new access charges that will be added to all telephone bills starting Jan. 1 will be lower than expected for some customers, according to rate requests filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect the merger with Chemical Data Systems, Inc. on May 31, 1983.

title: Records for Kidnapping Trial Of Providence Mayor Sealed
description: A judge has sealed the records of the pending kidnapping and assault trial of Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. after a defense lawyer said he feared ''the case would be tried in the newspaper.''

title: Staff Director of Panel To Study Crime Quits
description: The executive director of the President's Commission on Organized Crime has resigned, the Justice Deparment announced today. He had reportedly had conflicts with the commission's chairman, Federal Circuit Judge Irving R. Kaufman of New York.

title: TAKEOVER BID HELPED STOCKS
description: Investors did not have to look much past takeover targets to find the stock market stars of the third quarter. Market strength or industry fundamentals played second fiddle to the bidding wars.

title: NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Your Money; Reducing Cost Of Insuring Car
description: WHEN measured against the rise in overall consumer prices in recent years, automobile insurance has been a relatively good buy for some time. But this pattern has reversed itself in the last year or so and the outlook for 1984 is that automobile insurance premiums will advance faster than prices in general.

title: Jerseyans to Vote On Park Bonds
description: Voters will be asked to approve a $135 million recreational-land bond issue and a change in spending plans for a 1981 water bond issue under legislation signed by Governor Kean.

title: FIRST REPUBLIC CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to June 30

PATENTS;
Building Blocks Made From Soil
description: Harry C. Sangree, now a graduate student at the Columbia University Business School, realized some years ago, while on volunteer work in Zaire, that there was a need for cheap building materials in such countries. This week he was granted patent 4,406,606 for apparatus to make building blocks from soil.

title: WORK IGNORED FOR 200 YEARS
description: ''Alcina,'' which Handel's librettist adapted from Ariosto's 16th-century epic poem ''Orlando Furioso,'' was first performed at Covent Garden in London in 1735 with the famous castrato Carestini as Ruggiero.

title: An Expensive Way to Save on Lunch
description: For most of its 37 years, all that America's school lunch program asked of its participants was honesty. Parents applying for free or reduced-price lunches for their children were asked only to declare their incomes. Usually they were taken at their word, but a school principal who distrusted that word could seek verification.

title: Weight Problem
description: Pete Johnson , the fullback who has returned to the Cincinnati Bengals after a four-game suspension, is bigger than he was before the suspension - too big, in fact. According to Coach Forrest Gregg, Johnson weighs 272 pounds, 17 over his ideal playing weight of 255, and that excess weight and a pulled calf muscle will keep him out of the lineup for at least three weeks. Gregg said that Ross Browner, a defensive end who had also been suspended by Commissioner Pete Rozelle for involvement with drugs, reported in playing condition and will be used in tomorrow's game against the Baltimore Colts. . . . Another of the four players suspended, the cornerback Greg Stemrick, has been activated by New Orleans for the game against Miami.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A MOVE TO EVICT AIDS PHYSICIAN FOUGHT BY STATE
description: The state said yesterday that it was suing a cooperative apartment house in Greenwich Village, charging that the tenants illegally tried to evict a physician because he treated patients afflicted with AIDS.

title: Power of Perseverance
description: Jon English , the Tulane quarterback who had been declared ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, won a new court order yesterday that clears the way for him to play today against Vanderbilt. English, the son of the Tulane coach, Wally English, won the order from Louisiana's Fourth Circuit Court of Appeal a day after a lower court judge had withdrawn an earlier order that had allowed English to appear in the first four games.

title: U.S. EASING LIMITS ON BANK RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS
description: In another step toward the total deregulation of the banking industry, Federal regulators decided today to make two high-interest types of accounts more accessible to depositors.

title: Boxer in Hospital After Forum Bout
description: Gino Perez, knocked out in the seventh round of a lightweight bout at the Felt Forum last night, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital with a head injury.

title: Primefax Accords
description: Primefax Inc. announced the signing of agreements with the General Electric Company, Montgomery Ward & Company and the RCA Service Company under which they will test the Primefax television repair information system at nearly 80 service centers nationwide this year.

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. Net income for the latest quarter reflects an unspecified amount of investment tax credits. Year-ago net income figures are restated to reflect an extraordinary credit for book purposes for the first three quarters of 1982.

title: ENCOURAGING STEP TOWARD HOUSING THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: More Transfers Barred In St. Louis School Plan
description: A Federal appeals court today granted a request by state officials for a halt in transfers of black students from the city to mostly white suburban schools under a voluntary desegregation plan.

title: MUBARAK URGES ALL FORCES TO LEAVE LEBANON
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, meeting with President Reagan, said today that a breakthrough in Lebanon could come only after the ''complete withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign forces'' from the area.

title: Bridge: United States Still in the Lead At the World Team Tourney
description: The leading contenders for the two available semifinal positions ran into difficulty in the 11th round of world team championship qualifying play here Friday night. The United States team still held a strong first-place lead at the end of the round, but New Zealand replaced Pakistan in second place.

title: T I M E -DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $956,000 for the quarter and $3,500,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $143,000 from discontinued operations. d-Comparable year figures were not available because the company changed its year-end date from December 31 to June 30 in 1982.

title: Colt Stirs Up Dreams
description: Hope, at the race track, is a 2-year-old colt who has not done anything wrong yet. It is the hope shared by everyone who owns, trains, breeds, grooms or bets on horses: The colt could be the next thoroughbred deity, a champion among champions, the real thing.

title: John V. Lindsay Jr. Is Given 6 Months
description: John V. Lindsay Jr., son of the former Mayor of New York, was sentenced today to six months in jail on his guilty plea to one count of selling cocaine to an undercover police officer.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to July 3
description: b-Net income which includes an extraordinary credit of $82,000.

title: AMERICAN MEDI-DENT reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK IS GIVEN $25 MILLION TO AID URBAN REBUILDING
description: New York City was awarded nearly $25 million by the Federal Government today for 10 urban development projects in the five boroughs.

title: BILINGUAL HORIZON
description: To the Editor:

title: Where's the Fire?
description: Westbound motorists on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway inched along for miles yesterday morning because a flooded area near Queens Boulevard was forcing three lanes of traffic to merge into one.

title: GOVERNMENT EXAGGERATION CHARGED IN TRIAL OF LAB OFFICIALS
description: Defense attorneys for Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories argued today that the Government had relied on propaganda and exaggerated reports of conditions at one of the nation's largest animal-testing laboratories in trying to prove that company officials had falsified test data.

title: Simpson Gets His Wish
description: Two days after he announced he was quitting as Transit Authority president, John D. Simpson forlornly watched the arrival of a gleaming new subway car from Japan.

title: Growing Diamonds
description: Seven Russians were granted a patent this week for a method of growing diamonds.

title: FINLAND, IN BETWEEN
description: President Mauno Koivisto of Finland, who will soon conclude a United States tour, must have been the least troublesome foreign visitor President Reagan has received so far. He neither sought aid nor offered advice on how America ought to conduct its policy.

title: MEGAVERDICTS' THREAT TO MEDIA IS NO MYTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Sees Job Change
description: Frank Howard intimated yesterday that he did not expect to be rehired as manager of the Mets but would probablybe offered another job in the organization.

title: AN ERA ENDS FOR MCCANNS ON WOR
description: The story of the McCanns in broadcasting began one day in the 1920's when a man with a powerful jaw and fierce dark eyes first sat behind a microphone in a studio of radio station WOR. Its end came one day last month when his granddaughter bid farewell to the family's listeners for the last time.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1983.

title: SANITAS SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the quarter and $2,470,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and $867,000 for the year.

title: Clifford Evans, 68, Executive At RKO Broadcasting Corp.
description: Clifford Evans, vice president and Washington news bureau director of the RKO General Broadcasting Corporation, died here Thursday after suffering a pulmonary aneurysm. He was 68 years old.

title: Lukas Charged By U.S. Officials
description: D. Wayne Lukas, one of the nation's top trainers of race horses, was among eight people charged with harboring illegal aliens at a thoroughbred training facility, Federal authorities say.

title: PENN'S PASSING ROUTS COLUMBIA, 35-10
description: The latest New York football team to move to Giants Stadium was probably wondering if tonight's trip was necessary.

title: POLITICAL COLUMNIST FOR 50 YEARS
description: Roscoe Drummond, a reporter-editor and syndicated columnist for more than 50 years who covered Presidents from Calvin Coolidge to Ronald Reagan, died yesterday at the Tenacre Foundation in Princeton, N.J. He was 81 years old and had lived at the Tenacre, a Christian Science nursing home, since he was injured in an auto accident in 1981.

title: SYRIANS REDEPLOY SOME PALESTINIANS
description: The Syrians have withdrawn many of the Palestinian guerrillas who were fighting alongside the Druse in the Shuf Mountains southeast of Beirut and are preventing more guerrillas from going to the area, according to Western military sources.

title: Terms of a Ban
description: When Mayor Koch announced on Wednesday that no city business could be conducted in clubs that discriminate, the categories of bias he listed were ''race, creed, color, national origin, sex, age, marital status, sexual orientation, affectional preference or disability.''

title: Apple Planning To Aid Customers
description: Apple Computer Inc. has agreed to help hundreds of customers who bought Apple machines at discounts from a retailer that has since filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws and can not deliver its orders.

title: SHIP'S OVERHAUL REVIVING SPIRITS ON JERSEY DOCKS
description: The Navy oiler Kalamazoo and her crew of 417 arrived at the shipyards here today, and with her came renewed hope for the economy of this mile-square Hudson County city.

title: Bic Profit Rises 35%
description: Bic Multinational, makers of disposable pens, cigarette lighters and razors, said today that its worldwide profit jumped 35 percent in the first six months of 1982 to 175 million francs, or about $21.8 million. Revenue rose 11 percent, to 2.7 billion francs - about $337 million. Bic attributed the strong performance in the first six months to its overseas subsidiaries and the appreciation of the dollar and other currencies.

title: Syracuse U. Strips Man of Doctorate
description: For the second time in its 113-year history, Syracuse University has stripped a graduate degree from a former student, a university spokesman, Lois Applegate, said today.

title: New-Home Sales Fall By 5.1%
description: Sales of new single-family houses fell by 5.1 percent in August, the second consecutive monthly decline, the Government said today.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUY AMERICAN: THE COMPETITION ISN'T ALWAYS FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: RATES OF EXCHANGE. By Malcolm To Laugh and to Sigh Bradbury. 310 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: A RADIO NETWORK THAT READS TO THOSE WHO CAN'T
description: ''In Touch helped bring me back to life,'' said Henriette Jones, a former Staten Island schoolteacher who was severely depressed after losing her sight. ''I felt without being able to read you can't live. But now I don't feel 73 and blind, and I can take part in any discussion.''

title:
Patents;
A System To Confuse Radar
description: A ROCKET deception system, which scatters clouds of material to protect aircraft from radar tracking devices, was patented this week for the Army. Thin metallic strips, or chaff, can be distributed to make false signals that would confuse an enemy as to the presence of a helicopter or other craft.

title: MUSIC: A NEW 'ALCINA' BY CITY OPERA
description: The New York City Opera took a fling with the theatrical avant-garde Thursday night, presenting Andrei Serban's relentlessly novel version of Handel's ''Alcina.'' The evening, though a trial of patience in many ways, was redeemed by stirring singing by Carol Vaness as the cruel enchantress Alcina and by a supporting cast that could not always meet Handel's fierce demands but came through with honor.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 25
RCA in Pact With Comsat
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said it had reached an agreement touse an advanced satellite distribution system, using a K-Band satellite, to deliver network programming to affiliates of the RCA Corporation's NBC Television Network. The company, known as Comsat, said the 10-year contract starts early next year and is expected to yield revenues of ''several hundred million dollars.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ireland Ties Series
description: Matt Doyle, a Californian playing for Ireland, gave his country a 1-1 tie with the United States in Davis Cup play today when he upset Eliot Teltscher, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4. Earlier, John McEnroe defeated Sean Sorensen of Ireland, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2.

title: PALMER TOPS YANKS AND GAINS A SPLIT
description: After nearly 18 seasons, most of them illustrious, with the Baltimore Orioles, Jim Palmer is on the verge of leaving the team. And if he goes, he will likely depart as an expendable pitcher.

title: Unwelcome Statistic
description: While winding down his 23d and final season with the Boston Red Sox, Carl Yastrzemski may not be leading the league in any statistical categories.

title: Ethiopia Rebels Issue Claim
description: Guerrillas of the Tigre Peoples Liberation Front, fighting Ethiopia for the independence of the northern province, said today that they recently overran an Ethiopian Army position, killing 90 Government soldiers. The claim was made by the organization's office in Somalia and broadcast on the Mogadishu radio, which was monitored here.

title: Soviet Calls for Warmth In Relations With China
description: The Soviet Union, a week before its next round of talks with China, has called for improved relations between the two countries and congratulated the Chinese people on the 34th anniversary of Communist rule.

title: ACCLAIMED FOR WAR REPORTING
description: Alan Moorehead, a distinguished World War II correspondent for The Daily Express of London, whose dispatches appeared from the Western Desert of Africa to the beaches of Normandy, and who later became a popular author of acclaimed works of history, biography and reportage, died of a stroke in London Thursday, his family reported. He was 73 years old.

title: One Killed and 26 Hurt In Marseilles Explosion
description: One man was killed and 26 people were injured today when a bomb destroyed the American, Soviet and Algerian pavilions at an international trade fair in Marseilles.

title: DR. G. ARNOLD CRONK
description: Dr. G. Arnold Cronk, retired vice president of the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation of Raritan, N.J., died Wednesday at the Medical Center of Princeton, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PILOTS URGE END TO THE BOYCOTT OF SOVIET FLIGHTS
description: The international pilots' union called yesterday for an early suspension, starting Monday, of the boycott on flights to Moscow it imposed in retaliation for the downing of a Korean Air Lines jet by a Soviet fighter.

title: 2 SUSPECTS SOUGHT IN FARM SLAYINGS
description: The parents of a man being sought for questioning in the slayings of two bank officers on a foreclosed farm made a televised plea today for their son and grandson to give themselves up.

title: PRICES PAID FARMERS DOWN 1.4%
description: Prices that farmers get for their raw products fell 1.4 percent in September after posting a significant gain in August, the Agriculture Department said today. But they remained seven-tenths of 1 percent higher than a year ago.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD GRIDLOCK
description: Blocked traffic is not the only kind of gridlock in New York City. Far more serious is neighborhood gridlock. For despite news reports of planned buildings and rehabilitations, little happens. Few buildings go up; few come down. Almost no one moves out of Manhattan rental apartments; thus, few can move in. The one constant change is deterioration: Much of New York gets a little worse - rental apartments, parks and public buildings. The exception to deterioration has been the quarters of the rich, who pay handsomely for their comfort.

title: N.B.A. Referees Without Contract
description: With negotiations at an impasse, the National Basketball Association will open its training camp for referees tonight at the Island Inn in Westbury, L.I., with what Russell T. Granik, the league's general counsel, termed ''temporary replacements.''

title: Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporatioin said its surveillance radar division had been awarded a $480.5 million contract by the Federal Aviation Administration for 137 radar systems that will be delivered over a five-year period beginning in 1986. The company said 23 of the radars are for Department of Defense installations. The airport radars, which are designed to operate 24 hours a day without full-time maintenance personnel, are part of a $10 billion program to modernize the United States air traffic control and air navigation system.

title: A New Year Ignored
description: When he was running for President, Ronald Reagan promised to balance the budget by the end of fiscal 1983. Fiscal 1983 ran out at midnight last night and he didn't even come close. Nor will he balance it in the new fiscal year, or the next one, the one after that, or in any year in the forseeable future.

title: LEVERAGED BUYOUT OF TICORA AGREED ON
description: A group of investors, including the American Can Company, through its Associated Madison Companies subsidiary, announced yesterday that it had agreed to a leveraged buyout of the Ticor Corporation and its subsidiaries from the Southern Pacific Company for $271.3 million. Ticor's Constellation Insurance Company was not included in the deal.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32.

title: Ethics Rule Asked In 'Courtesy' Case
description: State Senator Gerald Cardinale asked the Senate Ethics Committee today to conduct a hearing to determine whether he is in a conflict of interest for his attempts to block the reappointment of Judge Sylvia B. Pressler to the State Superior Court.

title: RUTGERS CONFIDENT AGAINST PENN STATE
description: Kenny Jackson can see it in their eyes: The way opponents now look at Penn State has changed, said the Nittany Lions' leading receiver. Thus it will be that Rutgers thinks it has a chance to beat the defending national champions today at Giants Stadium.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $540,000 for the quarter and $1,077,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $261,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net loss after a loss of $4,546,000 from discontinued operations. Results are restated to reflect a change of fiscal year from December to June.

title: MODERN HUNGARIAN VERSION OF BALZAC'S 'LOST ILLUSIONS'
description: The Hungarian director Gyula Gazdag has transposed the middle section of Balzac's ''Lost Illusions'' from Paris in the mid-19th century to the Budapest of 1968, though he might just as well have moved it to the moon. If the purpose of this feat of gamesmanship is to demonstrate the universality of ''Lost Illusions,'' it might as readily have been accomplished in the book's natural time and place as in this updated setting.

title: THEATER ZONE: PAPCACEA OR PROBLEM
description: The debate over a new development plan for the Broadway theater district is, in reality, less a debate over how to preserve old buildings than how to keep them filled up.

title: COURT DENIES DELOREAN ACCESS TO FEDERAL FILES
description: By a unanimous decision, a Federal appeals court today overturned a lower court ruling that had granted John Z. DeLorean access to Government files in preparing his courtroom defense against drug trafficking charges. It was a heavy setback for Mr. DeLorean's defense.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid August 1. Corrected from Friday's editions.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $2.3 billion in the financial week that ended Sept. 21.

title: Seafirst Sells Seattle Building
description: Seafirst Bank said that it had sold its headquarters building here for $123.3 million, but a bank spokesman said the sale had nothing to do with the bank's financial problems.

title: INDEX OF ECONOMY DOWN FOR AUGUGST
description: The Government's principal gauge for forecasting the economy's short-term prospects turned downward last month for the first time in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MOZAMBIQUE OUSTS JOBLESS FROM CITIES
description: Mozambique is forcibly resettling its urban unemployed, often using employed city residents to denounce those who have been living in cities as parasites.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $653,000.

title: DR. JESSE A. TOLMACH
description: Dr. Jesse A. Tolmach, a former chief of dermatology at Beth Israel Hospital, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: BAN ON ROUGHNECK IS LIFTED
description: The day before its championship game between Toronto and Tulsa, controversy developed within the North American Soccer League. Howard Samuels, the league president, overruled his executive director of operations and allowed a suspended Tulsa player to be reinstated for Saturday's Soccer Bowl-83.

title: CONNECTICUT TURNS OFF TAP FOR 19-YEAR OLDS
description: William Krassner is planning to put in a new jukebox, with jazz instead of rock-and-roll. Tom DeFilippo will serve nonalcoholic beer in mugs to spare underage drinkers embarrassment. Gary Galett is serving full meals instead of light snacks.

title: U.S. TO EVALUATE SHOREHAM PLAN
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it would undertake a full-scale evaluation of the emergency-evacuation plan written by the Long Island Lighting Company for its Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: KEEPING HIGH WATTAGE
description: Once again the President has not fired James Watt. I marvel at his endurance. The President's endurance, that is; not James Watt's. What I marvel at about James Watt is his ingenuity in finding new ways to stimulate demand for having him out of his job as Secretary of the Interior.

title: DEADLOCK CLOUDS FATE OF U.S. RIGHTS AGENCY
description: Statutory authority for the United States Commission on Civil Rights is expiring, with Congress and the White House at a standoff in their effort to reach a compromise on the future of the agency and President Reagan's three nominees.

title: BRUINS DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders closed out their exhibition season tonight with a 6-1 loss to the Bruins at Boston Garden, finishing their preseason with a record of 4-3-2.

title: Gerryduck in Louisiana
description: For the first time since the Voting Rights Act was passed in 1965, a Federal court has struck down a congressional redistricting plan after the Justice Department had approved it. Last week's ruling by three judges in New Orleans should serve as a call for more vigilance by those who enforce the civil rights laws.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SNUBBED: DECAFFINATED COFFEE
description: Manhattan's better restaurants, where dinner for two can easily cost $150, spare no expense to serve the finest food on the best china in the most opulent surroundings. The silver is imported from France; the china is by Villeroy & Boch; fresh flowers are arranged every other day.

title: ALASKA GOVERNOR CLEARED IN OIL LEASE INQUIRY
description: The special prosecutor appointed by Gov. Bill Sheffield to investigate conflict-of-interest charges against him said today that he had found no evidence of wrongdoing by the Governor or his aides. But the special prosecutor, Frederic C. Tausend, chided the Governor for what he termed ''insensitivity to the appearance of impropriety.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We now urge everyone involved to join us in our attempt to create an atmosphere of international cooperation to put the sorrow of this tragedy behind us and to collectively insure measures are adopted that will guarantee this kind of incident will never again occur.'' - The international pilots union, calling for an early end to the boycott of flights to the Soviet Union. (5:6.)

title: Assault Complaint Cites 2 Jets
description: A 21-year-old man filed a complaint in Manhattan today against Mark Gastineau and Ken O'Brien of the Jets stemming from an early-morning fight at Studio 54, the police said.

title: Funds Gap Cited at I.M.F.
description: Better means of coping with the global debt crisis, including potentially greater availability of funds, have grown out of the 38th joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which ended here today. Both the I.M.F. managing director, Jacques de Larosi ere, and the World Bank's president, A. W. Clausen, said in closing comments that the job was now to translate into action the political will shown here by most of the 146 governments in attendance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1983
description: The Economy

title: FRANCE IS SAID TO DELAY DELIVERY OF 5 JETS TO IRAQ
description: Intelligence sources in the United States and other Atlantic alliance nations report that, because of international pressure, France is delaying the delivery to Iraq of five Super Etendard fighters capable of firing Exocet missiles. The reason for the pressure, they said, is a fear that, if the missiles were used against Iranian oil installations, Iran would close the Persian Gulf to oil traffic.

title: INVERNESS PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: ECONOMIC DISASTER
description: In recent days, I have attended meetings of Commonwealth finance ministers as well as the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, where we have addressed major questions involving the world financial and banking system. I believe that the Administration, and Congress, are treading a dangerous path in failing to face up to the imminent threat of disaster that hangs over the world economy.

title: U.S. GRANTS BRAZIL AND MEXICO AID
description: The Reagan Administration went ahead today with a plan to provide trade assistance to Brazil and Mexico despite a Congressional subcommittee's unanimous appeal for delay.

title: House Restricts Salvador Aid
description: The House passed legislation today extending restrictions on military aid to El Salvador for another year.

title: Animal Water Valve
description: An animal bite valve is designed to allow pigs, sheep, dogs and primates to get water.

title: 2 TESTIFY YOUTH BOASTED OF KILLING BOY WITH CAR
description: Two cellmates of Gerald T. Gerlock Jr. testified today that he had boasted of intentionally ''flattening'' a 7-year-old Hispanic boy with his car and discussed his system of earning ''points'' for hitting Puerto Ricans.

title: 'LONELY LADY,' FROM A ROBBINS NOVEL
description: Pia Zadora plays an ambitious creature who marries a very successful older man, then claws her way to the top of the movie business in ''The Lonely Lady,'' which opened yesterday at the Rivoli. ''The Lonely Lady,'' based on one of Harold Robbins's later and lesser novels, follows the career of Jerilee Randall, an aspiring writer, as she pursues her muse. Winning an award while in high school - the trophy looks like an Oscar that's been left out in the sun too long - she states her credo: ''I always try to make at least one of my characters honest and open and worried about some important issue.'' Naturally, with an attitude like that, she goes far.

title: Small Strides
description: Because he has been associated with the franchise for 44 years, it was not surprising that Herb Stein rejoiced the other day when the Minnesota Twins passed the California Angels to take over fourth place in the American League Western Division.

title: QUARTERBACK'S HARSH LESSON
description: Romie Mayfield received one line in a recent issue of The Sporting News, under a catch-all column, ''College Football Notebook'':

title: BRIEFING
description: Less Fat for Advisers

title: Caracas Gets Debt Deferral
description: Venezuela's creditor banks will extend for 30 days an agreement deferring principal debt repayments that ran out today, bankers said.

title: Chacon Loses Round
description: Rejecting arguments that the World Boxing Council had illegally prevented the boxer Bobby Chacon from practicing his profession by stripping him of his super-featherweight title, a California judge has refused to order the W.B.C. to reinstate the fighter. In his ruling, Judge John L. Cole of Superior Court in Los Angeles held that Chacon could perform as a professional boxer with or without the title. The complicated civil action, which is now expected to go to trial in December, arose last May when, the W.B.C. contends, Chacon broke a contract with the promoter Don King to fight the W.B.C.'s approved challenger, Hector Camacho , and accepted a better offer to fight Cornelius Boza-Edwards .

title: Sunny's Halo Is Syndicated
description: Sunny's Halo, the 1983 Kentucky Derby winner with earnings of $1.2 million, has been syndicated for $7 million to stand at Domino Stud in Lexington beginning in mid-December.

title: ENDORSEMENT SET BY WOMEN'S GROUP
description: Judy Goldsmith, head of the National Organization for Women, said today that NOW would for the first time endorse a Presidential candidate. The group will also ask each Presidential candidate to pledge to name a woman as his running mate in 1984, she said.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BUDGET DEFICITS EFFECTS DEBATE IS INTENSIFYING
description: As the 1983 fiscal year comes to an end with the biggest Federal budget deficit ever, the Reagan Administration is intensifying the debate about how harmful or benign deficits may be.

title: House Votes to Tighten Nuclear Export Controls
description: The House today narrowly approved a measure to tighten controls on the export of nuclear technology to countries that have not accepted international safeguards against the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: M
description: Melber Chambers, for more than 35 years a partner in the New York City law firm of Sage Gray Todd & Sims and a former president and director of the Correctional Association of New York, died Wednesday at his Manhattan home. He was 82 years old.

title: An 'Incident' Reported At Launching in Soviet
description: A recent Soviet attempt to launch three astronauts into space went amiss but there were apparently no casualties, a United States Government source said today.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Rohatyn Renamed
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday announced the reappointment of Felix G. Rohatyn to a third term as chairman of the New York State Municipal Assistance Corporation, and said he had asked Mr. Rohatyn to ''begin charting a new role for the agency.''

title: ISRAELI FAILS IN BID TO BRING LABORITES INTO CABINET
description: Efforts to form a Government of national unity based on the Likud bloc and the Labor Party broke down today, and the Prime Minister-designate, Yitzhak Shamir, said he would try to put together a Cabinet from the current governing coalition.

title: Italian Prices Increase
description: Italian consumer prices rose 1.3 percent in September from August and were up 13.6 percent from September 1982, the State Statistical Institute reported today. The rise compares with a four-tenths of 1 percent monthly increase in August, when the year-to-year rise in the cost of living registered 13.7 percent.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHIEF JUSTICE OF PHILIPPINES QUITS PANEL STUDYING AQUINO'S KILLING
description: The Chief Justice of the Philippines resigned today as head of the presidential commission of inquiry into the murder of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Rambling Willie Loses in Farewell
description: Rambling Willie finished second in the final race of his pacing career tonight at Sportsman's Park, but the crowd of 13,611 that attended his official retirement party wasn't disappointed.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
Gambling Charges Denied
description: Carl J. Civella, a reputed leader in organized crime here, has pleaded not guilty to Federal charges that he and five other people operated illegal gambling activities. Mr. Civella appeared before Magistrate Calvin K. Hamilton on Thursday to plead to the charges that he and five others operated a gambling enterprise from November 1981 to April 1982 in Missouri and Kansas and used telephones in interstate commerce in taking bets on sports events.

title: CHILE'S INITIATIVES TO REACTIVATE ITS ECONOMY AND DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Boeing Changes
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said it plans to modernize 10 of its 16 Boeing 747 aircraft and speed up the delivery of a previously ordered Boeing 747-300 by 16 months, in a deal worth $200 million.

title: Miss Crafter Has 70 at San Jose
description: - Jane Crafter of Australia shot a three-under-par 70 to take a one- stroke lead today over Patty Sheehan, the defending champion, before rains halted play in the first round of the $175,000 San Jose Classic.

title: Technology and Trekking
description: From the canyons of Wall Street to the headwaters of the Amazon seems a natural leap to Grant G. Behrman, an investment banker with Morgan Stanley & Company. He is leading the Explorers Club expedition that left Manhattan recently to study and live among the Waorani tribe of eastern Ecuador for two months.

title: Jarreau Concerts Delayed
description: Al Jarreau's concerts at Radio City Music Hall next Thursday, Friday and Saturday have been postponed because of illness, and will be rescheduled. Information about ticket refunds is available from Radio City Music Hall, 757-3100, or at the place of purchase.

title: Chicago Mayor Backed By Court on Dismissals
description: Mayor Harold Washington was within his rights to dismiss 734 city employees in an effort to balance the city budget, a judge has ruled.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: AT some stereo and audio shops that sell high-priced equipment, customers are being asked to pay a fee for advice on what to buy. At least one bicycle shop also has such a charge and Potamkin Cadillac is charging $10 for a price quote by mail.

title: Advisory Panel of 8 Experts Backs Plan for Small Missile
description: An advisory group of experts has recommended going ahead with research and development of a new, smaller intercontinental nuclear missile for deployment in 1992, the Pentagon announced today.

title: British Envoy's Home In Coast Rica Attacked
description: Nine men dressed in military fatiques attacked the British Ambassador's residence but were repelled by civil guards firing machine guns, a police spokesman said.

title: DODGERS CAPTURE TITLE
description: The Dodgers clinched the National League West title tonight when Atlanta lost to San Diego. Los Angeles later defeated San Francisco, 4-3, to stretch its lead to four games.

title: CONTINENTAL REAFFIRMS PLANS TO FLY
description: Executives of Continental Air Lines said here today that passenger response remained strong in the face of a strike called for Saturday by pilots and flight attendants and that more than enough air crews would be on hand to fly the carrier's new schedules.

title: HLH PETROLEUM CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income which includes a gain of $2,682,390.

title: THE NEW SHAPES IN FURS
description: Luxury furriers, whose customers usually plan their wardrobes early, say they have had a brisk two weeks, particularly in the upper price brackets. Alixandre reports that it sold a $95,000 sable coat. Ben Kahn made a sale furriers dream about: a man bought two coats for himself and four for his fiancee, for a total of $100,000. Then Maximilian topped it by selling two Russian lynx coats, each at $200,000, in two days.

title: Man Dies in Car Crash In Tunnel to Brooklyn
description: One man died and five people were injured late last night after a driver drove the wrong way down a Manhattan-bound lane of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel at high speed and ran into oncoming traffic, Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority officials said.

title: Letter: On Teaching in English Keep Bilingual Education Flexible To the Editor:
description: Your editorial ''Si Quiere Promover English'' (Sept. 13), makes an argument against bilingual education, not on the basis of reasonable argument, logic or information, but on the basis of culturalist and political assumptions.

title: Bejart Program Changed
description: Changes in today's matinee program for the Bejart Ballet at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, have been announced. The matinee will include ''Seven Greek Dances,'' ''Concerto in Re,'' and ''The Rite of Spring,'' instead of ''Wien, Wein, nur du Allein,'' which will be performed this evening as scheduled.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rick Middleton , the smooth-skating wing of the Boston Bruins, has signed a four-year contract extension through 1989 that reportedly raised his salary from $225,000 to $300,000 a year. . . . The Giants have listed Billy Campfield, who has been returning kickoffs this year, as doubtful for tomorrow's game with San Diego. He has not practiced all week because of back spasms. . . . Ed Sherod, the guard placed on waivers by the Knicks earlier this week, went unclaimed and has been re-sgned by the Knicks. . . . Darwin Cook, the Nets guard who is a free agent, has begun negotiations with three other teams.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in 1983 and a 10 percent stock dividend in 1982.

title: New Analysis
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt gets little defense here for his verbal blunders, but on the strength of both his power as the West's landlord and his peformance in office, he retains widespread support in the region from Democrats and Republicans alike. Despite the criticism, there have been no calls for his resignation among major political figures in the West. Indeed, some even suggest that the severe slump in the region's mining and mineral exploration industries has strengthened Mr. Watt's Western base.

title: INTEREST RATE WAR STARTS IN NEW YORK
description: A major interest rate war broke out in New York City yesterday on the eve of the long-awaited deregulation of bank certificates of deposit today.

title: MRS. GANDHI, ON U.N. VISIIT, FINDS TIME FOR 'LA BOHEME' AND OLD FRIENDS
description: Indira Gandhi journeyed halfway around the world this week to discuss nuclear disarmament and the problems of the Third World at the United Nations, but she also bought books at Scribner's, attended ''La Boh eme'' at the Metropolitan Opera and talked with old friends about her father and her life as a politician.

title: POLE, AT THE U.N., SAYS U.S. CRUSADES AGAINST WARSAW
description: The Polish head of state, Henryk Jablonski, today defended his Government's policy toward the banned Solidarity trade union and accused the United States of leading a Western campaign aimed at destabilizing Poland.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington Talk page article yesterday on the Heritage Foundation misidentified Lewis E. Lehrman. A former chairman and president of the Rite-Aid Corporation, he is national chairman of Citzens for America, a Washington-based group that seeks to support policies of economic growth.

title: Italian Ship Is Reported Afire, But Doubts Are Then Raised
description: An Israeli radio operator said today that he had picked up distress signals from an Italian vessel that had collided with a Soviet ship in the Mediterranean, but Lloyd's of London and Italian authorities were unable to confirm the report.

title: NAVY TO CLEAR RECORDS OF 3,000 FOR DRUG USE
description: The records of about 3,000 Navy personnel disciplined because of reported drug use will be cleared because of problems with the tests that implicated them, the Navy has announced.

title: RECLAIMING A PIECE OF THE PAST
description: ROXBURY STATION is a stop off Route 67 in a quiet town of 1,500 people in Litchfield County. But for a short time, beginning in the 1800's, it was a boom town known as Chalybes.

title: SERIES IS FOCUSING ON ISSUE OF VIOLENCE
description: FOR its third yearly forum, the county's Department of Community Mental Health has focused on the issue of violence.

title: SHARING A PROFIT AND A RISK
description: FOR anyone fortunate enough to have a substantial income, small private real

title: SHIPMENT OF ATOM FUEL FROM UPSTATE DUE TO START
description: Shipments of hundreds of truckloads of highly radioactive spent nuclear fuel are expected to begin soon from a defunct waste-reprocessing plant at West Valley, N.Y., back to reactors in Rochester, N.Y., and in New Jersey, Wisconsin and Illinois.

title:
LEISURE;
AN INDOOR MUSHROOM CROP EXTENDS THE HARVEST SEASON;
description: Carolyn Jabs is a freelance writer.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant Maine Will Vote on Moose
description: ON Nov. 8, Maine's voters, in what has been described as the first such referendum on big- game hunting in this country, will decide whether the state will end its recently reinstituted moose-hunting seasons.

title: No Headline
description: 2,000 Greet Coetzee With Hero's Welcome

title: Quisenberry Gets 2 Saves in Sweep
description: Dan Quisenberry saved both games of a doubleheader today, as the Kansas City Royals defeated the Oakland A's, 4-1 and 7-3. The Royals' reliever extended his major league single-season saves record to 45.

title: HOSPITALS TRYING TO GET RID OF 'LOSERS'
description: RAHWAY LAST month, 12 of the 215 doctors at Rahway Hospital received notices that, during July, the hospital had lost a significant amount of money on some of their patients. Enclosed were computer printouts listing each doctor's ''losers'' and a memo from Dr. Ernest Geenberg, president of the medical staff.

title: Taxing Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Korean Fete Clouded By Downing of Plane
description: Solemn reminders of the Korean Air Lines tragedy punctuated a colorful and festive procession down Broadway yesterday afternoon as New Yorkers of Korean origin celebrated their traditional harvest festival and mourned the 269 people killed when the plane was shot down by the Soviet Union a month ago.

title: INTERNSHIPS OFFER STUDENTS VARIETY OF WORK EXPERIENCES
description: ''THE great difficulty in education,'' George Santayana said, ''is to get experience from ideas.'' But many corporations, colleges and universities in the county are helping students gain such experience through internship and cooperative- education programs.

title: Temple Falls, 18-15, To Boston College
description: Steve Strachan scored on a 4-yard sweep with 3 minutes 8 seconds to play, and Boston College (4-1) held off a late Temple drive for an 18-15 victory today at Franklin Field.

title: WEINBERGER MEETS ZIA AND AFGHAN REFUGEES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger met with Afghan refugees near the border with Afghanistan today and later met with Pakistani leaders ''to convince them that we are strong and reliable allies.''

title: DEMOCRATS BAR ACTION IN HOUSE ON IMMIGRATION
description: House Democratic leaders have blocked a sweeping revision of immigration law, which the Administration has supported, out of fear that President Reagan would score a political coup by vetoing it.

title: DARIEN'S 'CAMELOT' IS BEAUTIFULLY SUNG
description: ''CAMELOT'' does not need a multi-million dollar mounting. In 1960, the musical was produced for $700,000 - at the time, a record- breaking cost. By highlighting the human elements of a real legend for our times, the production now at the Darien Dinner Theater was put together for less than $50,000, and comes up a winner.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The name of the violinist James Buswell was misspelled in an article last week on the 1983-84 music season. Mr. Buswell will appear in a recital to be presented Feb. 28 by the Civic Music Association of Bergen County at Orrie de Nooyer High School in Hackensack.

title: Mary Hughes Is Bride Of James B. Barnes
description: Mary Patricia Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hughes of Millbrook, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Bradford Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Barnes of Short Hills, N.J. Msgr. Thomas Matthew Reardon performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Butler Memorial Chapel at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: PROPOSED TAX RULES PERIL GIFTS OF SCENIC LAND
description: The Montana Land Reliance had promises from four landowners before May that 32,000 acres of prime scenic and agricultural property would be preserved from development. Then the Internal Revenue Service proposed rules to govern such agreements, and all four plans fell through.

title: TWO KINDS OF REVOLUTION
description: REFLECTIONS OF A NEOCONSERVATIVE

title: PALMER SQUARE PLAN FACES COURT FIGHT
description: PRINCETON THE FIRST major phase of the $65 million renovation and expansion of Palmer Square here faces a court challenge over air rights.

title: MONDALE-GLENN CHOICE SPLITS UNIONISTS IN POLL
description: Rank-and-file union members are about evenly divided in their support for Walter F. Mondale and John Glenn, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: RACE TO GAIN BRANCA'S ASSEMBLY SEAT
description: MOUNT VERNON GREGORY P. YOUNG, the incumbent Democratic legislator who represents Mount Vernon on the County Board of Legislators, was passed over as his party's choice in the new ''minority legislative district,'' the 13th, in favor of Ernest D. Davis, a black candidate. At the time, Mr. Young says, he felt convinced that he was ''going into semiretirement from politics.''

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: For those of us who see modern Chinese history in terms of isolation, Yin Cheng-Zong comes as something of a surprise. This 42-year-old pianist from China gave his first New York recital in Carnegie Hall Wednesday, and in the process showed a superior command not only of his instrument but of his musical materials.

title: PESTICIDE RULES CHALLENGED
description: TRENTON BACKED by environmentalists and the state's Public Advocate, State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, Democrat of Elizabeth, has charged that the new pesticide-control regulations of the state's Department of Environmental Protection are dangerous and place economic interests above public health.

title: A MOVE TO STEM LIABILITY CASES
description: WASHINGTON BEFORE Joyce Bichler was even born, she became the victim of a defective product. While pregnant, her mother took a drug, diethylstilbestrol, or DES, to prevent miscarriage. Instead of protecting Joyce, however, the drug damaged her. She later developed cervical and vaginal cancer and when she was 17 years old, surgeons treated the cancer by removing her reproductive organs and most of her vagina.

title: HAWAII WELFARE CHIEF SPARED TIME IN OWN JAIL
description: Franklin Y. K. Sunn, Hawaii's top welfare officer, surrendered to the United States Marshal's office today to be jailed on a contempt-of-court charge, but the judge changed his mind and Mr. Sunn was freed several hours later.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE DEMANDS OF HIGH-TECH LAWYERING
description: ^Roy N. Freed, a Boston attorney, writes frequently on legal questions related to high technology and is founder of the Computer Law Association. ^By ROY N. FREED ^c.1983 N.Y. Times News Service Picture a scenario along the following lines. The head of computer operations at a major research hospital is shocked to learn that a group of ''hackers'' in Podunk has got into its computer system, destroyed records of many years of research work done under a grant from a medical device manufacturer and apparently rummaged around in patients' records besides. The story hits the national press. In an atmosphere of great public embarrassment, the hospital's president calls in its eminent, gray-haired legal counsel. He is asked for guidance on how to bolster the institution's reputation by teaching the hackers a lesson, and to fend off lawsuits by the manufacturer whose research money is at stake, by patients whose privacy is invaded and by the supplier of the systems security software program, whose reputation is besmirched. If you think that this story is fanciful, reread your newspapers of recent months. And think how much the hospital will have to pay for the complex legal assistance such a situation demands. Will it get its money's worth? Much depends on the care with which it chooses its legal counsel and the extent to which its attorneys have educated themselves in the intricacies of high technology. Not many decades ago, such questions were unimagined, because most corporate legal matters were much simpler than they are today.

title: AT HOME IN PROVENCE
description: The flaxen-haired hostess at Le Mandarin restaurant in Saint-Remy-de- Provence recommends, after a spicy chicken dish in the Vietnamese manner, beignets, the dessert of her native Brittany. She explains her move south to this venerable town of 8,000 simply. ''It is the sun that brings all of us here.''

title: STATE STRESSING EDUCATION FOR AGE OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: IT IS said that the technological revolution sweeping the world - a revolution in which New Jersey hopes to play a significant role - will alter life more radically and more rapidly than the Industrial Revolution, which shaped today's socioeconomic patterns.

title: Renting Abroad
description: To the Editor: Pleased as I was to read the articles extolling the special joys of self-catering holidays abroad (''Renting a Cottage Abroad,'' Travel, Aug. 7), I was disappointed to find no mention of Germany where, twice in the past three years, we have greatly enjoyed renting a Ferienwoh

title: No Headline
description: Linda Perrin Taber Wed

title: Football Giants' Latter-Day Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Changes in Medicare Seek to Control Costs
description: In an effort to control the rising cost of medical care, the Federal Government today put into effect a new system setting in advance what Medicare will pay a hospital to treat various ailments.

title: FOUR FEDERAL AGENCIES CLASH OVER PORT RULES
description: In a rare legal clash between Government departments, two Cabinet members have opposed the Justice Department and an independent Federal agency in a maritime dispute.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: DOGS OF DISTINCTION

title: IN THE SPIRIT OF VOLTAIRE
description: ARISTOTLE TO ZOOS

title: DESPITE RISE IN AIDS, OFFICIALS ARE ENCOURAGED
description: The New York City Health Department says that although there has been an increase in reported new cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, the monthly average is less than officials expected.

title: Lee McGraw Weds in Jersey
description: Marjorie Lee McGraw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. McGraw of Essex Fells, N.J., and Osterville, Mass., was married yesterday to Matthew E. Lewicki, son of Margaret H. Lewicki of Union, N.J., and the late Matthew E. Lewicki. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. David St. George, assisted by the Rev. Harry B. Whitley, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Essex Fells.

title: MOZAMBIQUE ACCUSES PRETORIA ON REBELS
description: The revolutionary Government of President Samora Machel continues to express interest in an arrangement on mutual security with white-ruled South Africa, but officials here assert that Pretoria's cross-border assistance to right-wing insurgents has actually been increased.

title: Mononucleosis Virus Is Linked to a Cancer
description: The same virus that causes mononucleosis may also be responsible for a rare kind of brain cancer that has shown up among victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, researchers say.

title: THE WORLD
description: Hessians PutKohl in a Bind

title: BLAKE TAKES OVER AFTER POLITICAL EXILE
description: ''WE GOT 10 princes and one king who has no muscle,'' said William M. Blake, the Babylon Republican leader, who is expected to be elected the new ''king'' - Suffolk County Republican chairman - tomorrow.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SOME DOUBTS AMONG RUSSIANS ON DOWNING OF JET
description: A month after a Soviet jet fighter shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 over Sakhalin island, the incident has maintained a surprising momentum here, despite Kremlin efforts to switch public attention back to the ''military threat'' posed by the United States.

title: Dining Aloft
description: To the Editor: Being a devout vege

title: FOR CHILD ACTORS, AN ERA OF CHANGE
description: Andrea Darvi is the author of ''Pretty Babies: An Insider's Look at the World of the Hollywood Child Star,'' to be published Oct. 31 by McGraw-Hill.

title: UNION BLANKS IRVINGTON
description: Keith Peace rushed 19 times for 154 yards and 2 touchdowns to lift formidable Union to a 29-0 victory over Irvington yesterday in Irvington.

title: LATIN UNREST IS CALLED THREAT TO WORLD PEACE
description: Nearly nine months ago, the Foreign Ministers of Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela met to begin a process they hoped would lead to a rapid quelling of violence in Central America.

title: No Headline
description: -RENEWAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No gifts, no pans, no pots, no toasters. Just rates.'' - Matthew Kissner, a Citibank vice president.(45:3)

title: BRYANT SHUT OUT BY MONROE, 20-0
description: Heavy rains forced the cancellation of two Public Schools Athletic League games yesterday, but at Flushing Memorial Athletic Field in Queens, the only washout was James Monore's 20-0 victory over Bryant.

title: DONNA L. LEAHY IS A BRIDE
description: Donna L. Leahy, daughter of Mrs. Harrison J. O'Connor of Falmouth, Me., and T. Donald Leahy of Boxborough, Mass., was married yesterday to Walter Dillingham Wick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Arms Wick Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the cemremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. Mrs. Wicks is the manager and buyer for Streets & Co., a New York women's clothing store in New York.

title: WORKS OF STATE RESIDENTS SHINE IN 3 SHOWS
description: WHERE art is concerned, it looks as though Connecticut is getting ready to secede.

title: ; THE INDUSTRIAL POLICY DEBATE
U.S. Plans Technology Center
description: Harvard University has been selected over two other colleges for a $7.7 million dollar technology center designed to improve the teaching of mathematics and sciences in the United States.

title: SCHOOLS REACT TO FOOTBALL DEATH
description: year-old football player, whose deteriorating heart condition had escaped detection by Yonkers High School, touched off sweeping disciplinary actions last week by an angry Superintendent of Schools.

title: STRIKE FAILS TO END CONTINENTAL'S FLIGHTS
description: Striking pilots and flight crews kept some Continental Air Lines planes on the ground today and delayed others but, with most of its flights in the air and on time, the airline maintained, ''We're still flying.''

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: use this Knowing Your Fiddlesticks

title: INTERNATIONAL FARE IN NEW MILFORD
description: SOME restaurants do not fade away, they move away. If they are like Fern's, they rejuvenate at their new site. This perky restaurant was once located in a small storefront on a street with limited parking in Fairfield. It is now in New Milford in a rambling old white-frame house with green trim and ample parking lot.

title: Boy, 12, Charged in Murder
description: A 12-year-old boy has been arrested and charged with second-degree murder and illegal weapons possession in the stabbing death of Jerry Emmanual, also 12, of 241 Lenox Road, Brooklyn, Friday afternoon while walking home from Lefferts Junior High School in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The boy, who was arrested Friday night but not identified because of his age, was released in his parents' custody, to reappear in Brooklyn Family Court Oct. 7, the police said.

title: WELFARE SUPPORTERS EVICTED FROM PENNSYLVANIA'S CAPITOL
description: About 25 people who had been protesting changes in the state's welfare law by camping in the Capitol rotunda since Sept. 19 were evicted this afternoon by security officers and the State Police.

title: TESTAMENT TO A LOST PEOPLE
description: Herbert Mitgang is cultural correspondent of The New York Times. By Herbert Mitgang VEN NOW, LONG AFTERward, the faces haunt him. The eyes of the children, black in the hollow sockets of the faces, stare into the camera. The children's faces have a waiting look, almost too patient for their age, as if hoping for a game, a meal, a lost youth. Adult minds form these children's thoughts, and the eyes seem to look at some distant horizon beyond fear, beyond resignation.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE

title: FIGURE IN AQUINO CASE SAID TO BLAME COMMUNISTS
description: The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that it had a witness who would testify that the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines ordered the killing of opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: THE STUBBORN, LOVEABLE RICH
description: OLD MONEY

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA UPSET BY SOUTH CAROLINA, 38-14
description: Thomas Dendy ran for two touchdowns, and South Carolina (3-2) turned three fourth-quarter turnovers into scores to upset Southern California, 38-14, tonight. Southern California fell to 1-2-1, its worst start since 1962.

title: LED A TOP SWEET-SOUND BAND
description: Freddy Martin, who led a big band for more than 50 years and who helped establish the ''sweet'' jazz sound, died Friday in Newport Beach, Calif., where he lived. He was 76 years old.

title: ELABORATE, AND SERIOUSLY CHINESE
description: CHOPSTICKS is Great Neck's newest entry on the list of fancy Chinese restaurants, and it has become enormously popular. It is elaborately done, with a greenhouse lounge area and, in a series of subterranean dining rooms, has undulating, gilded wall panels.

title: Mayer Roberts and William C. Baker Are Married
description: Mayer Martin Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Martin of Lakeland, Fla., and William Clayton Baker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin May Baker of Baltimore, Md., were married yeserday at the home of the bridegroom's parents by the Rev. Richard H. Baker, an Episcopal priest, who is the bridegroom's first cousin.

title: Belize
description: To the Editor: I am not sure what ''L.H.'' means in the Q & A column (Travel, Aug. 21) by expressing his wish to ''explore'' Belize. Belize is such a small country (174 miles at its longest point, 68 miles at its widest), that he may be misled.

title: SETTLEMENTS ARE REACHED IN SUITS OVER DIOXIN POLLUTION IN MISSOURI
description: Four victims of dioxin exposure will receive $2.68 million to settle lawsuits concerning the spraying of contaminated waste oil at Missouri horse arenas 12 years ago.

title: AUTUMN IN VERMONT
description: Manchester and Dorset, a town and a village five miles apart in southwest Vermont, together provide an assortment of activities for the fall visitor. Good food, shopping, cultural events and sports facilities are available against a backdrop of the natural beauty of autumnal Vermont.

title: AS BOYCOTTS END, SOVIET FLIGHTS RETURN TO NORMAL
description: Airline connections between the Soviet Union and the West have begun to return to normal as Western governments, labor unions and pilots' associations end a patchwork of boycotts imposed in the aftermath of the Soviet downing of a South Korean airliner.

title: TRAINS KILL 2 AMTRAK WORKERS
description: Two workers were killed and another is presumed dead after two separate accidents early yesterday in which trains slammed into members of track crews in Kearny, N.J., and in Newark, officials said.

title: FOR HOPEFULS, IT'S TIME TO TURN GUNS ON EACH OTHER
description: The battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination has entered a more combative phase as the competitors aim at one another the kind of criticisms formerly reserved for their common enemy, President Reagan.

title: IN ASHEVILLE, THE HOMESPUN LINGERS ON
description: CECILY DEEGAN McMILLAN, who lives in Frogmore, S.C., is working on a book about Elizabeth Sherman Cameron's friendship with Henry Adams. By CECILY DEEGAN McMILLAN

title: BESTSELLERS
description: FICTION

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO ATTRACT BIRDS TO YOUR GARDEN
description: MOST gardeners enjoy having birds in their gardens. Birds add color, activity and music to the garden at any time of the year. In addition, birds are beneficial in that many species devour insect pests that would otherwise damage the plants in the garden.

title: 10 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 10 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: NEW DRIVE READY FOR ISLAND TV STATION
description: THE way television covers the news on Long Island has changed in recent months, but the new programming can be seen by only a limited number of viewers on the Island. And that is one reason why a local broadcast-advocacy group contends that Long Island needs a conventional commercial television station of its own.

title:
WHAT'S HAPPENING IN CANADIAN BUSINESS;
UNFETTERING THE FOREIGN BANKS
description: Later this month, a Parliamentary finance committee will recommend whether the Canadian Government should allow foreign banks to expand, a move that has upset some Canadian bankers.

title: Miss O'Neil, Peter M. Lee, Market Traders, Are Wed
description: Maureen Regina O'Neil, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. I. Frank Boscarelli of New York City, was married yesterday to Peter Michael Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Lee of Portland and Sun River, Ore. The Rev. Thomas F. Scanlon performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: Don't Stop With China Even if it is an election-year stunt, it's good that President Reagan wants to visit China next April, finally to bless an important relationship that President Nixon reopened 12 years ago. But the stunt will be further cheapened if Mr. Reagan keeps begging the Chinese to turn it into an anti-Soviet rally. Dining in Peking while barking at Moscow may seem clever to Washington. But it is the wrong approach to both Communist powers.

title: BALDWIN, TOO, JOINS THE BANKRUPT CLUB
description: Baldwin-United joined Continental Airlines in Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Baldwin, which had teetered on the brink of collapse for months, was forced to file for protection after a dispute among its creditors could not be resolved and a group of three creditors filed a petition seeking to force the company into reorganization. The financial services company responded with its own petition. Baldwin's debt was listed as $1.6 billion. The move was a defeat for corporate rescuer Victor Palmieri, who has been Baldwin's president since May and had vowed to reorganize the company without court supervision. Among the creditors responsible for forcing Baldwin into Chapter 11 was William A. Niskanen Jr., a member of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers. He and two brothers sold a bus company to Baldwin in 1981 and are owed $11 million.

title: Finger Lakes
description: To the Editor: The article by R. V. Denenberg on ''What's Doing in the Finger Lakes'' (Travel, Aug. 14) cap

title: More Australian Joy
description: Time may dim the excitement in Australia over winning the America's Cup, but one young Australian is not likely to need a reminder.

title: 'TALLEY'S FOLLY' IN CHAPPAQUA
description: -holds-barred romantic story,'' as Matt Friedman, the narrator and one of the play's two characters, calls it in his agreeable and outspoken greeting to the audience.

title: Stieb's Profits Grow
description: Dave Stieb of Toronto started well against the Minnesota Twins Friday night, retiring the first 13 batters.

title: FROM ALLY TO ENEMY
description: There ought to be a problem playing against one's former match second - was he not a party to all your opening lore?

title: IMMIGRATION: IS U.S. POLICY ON CUBANS JUST?
description: THE typical political asylum case involves a great writer or scientist, or perhaps a well-known dancer or even a child running from his parents and communism to embrace the freedom offered by our shores.
