title: Miss Szeto Is a Bride
description: Yvonne Yan Szeto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wai Szeto of Hong Kong, New York and Paris, was married yesterday to David Beatty Everson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Everson of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony in the sanctuary of the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: 16 Turkish Politicians Allowed to Go Home
description: Turkey's ruling generals have ordered the release of former Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel and 15 other politicians who were sent into internal exile three months ago.

title: THE NATION
description: Whistle-Blower'sFamiliar Tune

title: CALIFORNIA TIES ARIZONA, 33-33
description: California rallied from a 26-3 deficit with four touchdowns and a field goal today to tie Arizona, 33-33. The 22-yard field goal by Randy Pratt came with 48 seconds remaining in the Pacific 10 Conference game.

title: Circle in Square Plans A Tribute to Saroyan
description: The Circle in the Square Theater will present ''A Tribute to William Saroyan'' Oct. 30 at 7 P.M.

title: RELAYING FOOD GIFTS BY PHONE
description: MARCY HANENBAUM receives telephone calls from Fortune 500 companies, television networks, politicians and celebrities. Her company, Coastal Express Caterers, has not had a slow day since she established it a year and a half ago.

title: HUMAN FOOTPRINTS FROM 4,500 YEARS AGO FOUND
description: Footprints of prehistoric people as well- preserved as the day they were made 4,500 years ago have been found in a cave with the remains of several extinct animals, officials say.

title: Jailhouse Jobs
description: To the Business Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL'S BLOW TO AIRLINE STOCKS
description: WIND shear hit the airline stocks early last week as Continental Air Lines rushed into bankruptcy and Eastern Airlines hinted at a similar move. Suddenly, no one wanted the airlines. And those who held on to their stock needed that essential quality described by author Tom Wolfe as ''The Right Stuff'' to keep from hitting the ejection button.

title: DEBTS OF THE FEW PROMPT GLOBAL FEARS
description: ''Our monetary system is in a rather frightening state,'' H. Johannes Witteveen, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said at the start of last week's annual meetings of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. Most of the world's money men assembled in Washington share his anxiety.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SPARKED by some innovative architectural plans and an infusion of Federal dollars, the old Hudson River town of Hastings may be getting a new look.

title:
ART;
PARRISH INVITATIONAL COVERS A DIVERSITY OF STYLES
description: LAST spring, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton sent out some 3,500 letters soliciting slides from artists with homes and/or studios in Suffolk County. These, the museum's letter said, would provide the raw material from which an invitational exhibition would be selected, and nearly 400 of the region's artists responded, according to the catalogue of the invitational, which is now on view to Oct. 30.

title: Indictment Asserts Bulgarian Paid $300 for Secret Papers
description: A Federal indictment brought Friday in New York said that Penyu B. Kostadinov, a suspected Bulgarian spy, paid an American graduate student $300 for secret United States nuclear documents.

title: SUBTENANCIES
description: I wish to clarify a statement attributed to me in the article ''Talking Subtenancies.'' In that article, it was stated that a prime tenant could sublet his apartment at a 10 percent increase over the legal rent in effect at the time of the subletting.

title: CONSUMER RATES
SAN FRANCISCO PLANS A COHERENT FUTURE
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Turbos Making Their Mark
description: Keke Rosberg, the 1982 world driving champion, stands fifth this year with one event remaining. His competitors say that the 34-year-old Finn is driving better than ever, but Rosberg has won only one race this season and by the end of August was mathematically eliminated from a chance to repeat as the champion.

title: Capital's Mayor Is Penalized
description: A Federal district judge has held Mayor Marion E. Barry of the District of Columbia and other city officials in contempt for violating orders to relieve overcrowding in the capital's jail.

title: Edmund L. Resor Married to Anne-Marie Huber
description: Anne-Marie Huber, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Huber of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edmund Lansdowne Resor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Rogers Resor of New Canaan, Conn. Bishop Taban Paride of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Torit, the Sudan, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Yastrzemski Bids A Fond Farewell
description: Carl Yastrzemski, who inherited the Red Sox left- field job from Ted Williams 23 years ago, said goodbye today in a 58- minute pregame ''Yaz Day'' celebration at Fenway Park.

title: MONDALE TOPS 4 RIVALS, WINS MAINE STRAW POLL
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale won convincingly in a straw poll today at the Maine Democratic state convention after spending heavily and dispatching scores of campaign workers here in an effort to hold his lead in the Democratic Presidential race.

title: STAGE: 'PAY OLD DEBTS,' ELIZABETHAN COMEDY
description: One of Edmund Kean's most popular characterizations was as that grasping extortionist, Sir Giles Overreach in Philip Massinger's Elizabethan comedy ''A New Way to Pay Old Debts.'' Kean's flamboyant performance in the climactic scene provoked his critical admirer, William Hazlitt, to suggest that he should ''contrive not to frighten the ladies into hysterics.''

title: NEBRASKA TOPS SYRACUSE, 63-7
description: The quarterback Turner Gill ran for three touchdowns and the tailback Mike Rozier added two to lead top- ranked Nebraska (5-0) to a 63-7 victory over Syracuse (3-2) today.

title: Polly Vail Is Married to Mark L. Walsh
description: Mary Blair Vail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vail of Bedford, N.Y., and Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Lawson Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Walsh of Baltimore and Dunlewy, Ireland. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: COLLECTOR DEFENDS PALESTINIAN SHOW SHUT BY U.N.
description: A recent exhibition of Palestinian-struggle posters that was dismantled here after one day amid accusations of anti- Israeli bias has been defended by the collector who made them available as an attempt to humanize both Palestinians and Israelis.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. CHIEFS SUPPORT MONDALE FOR '84 NOMINATION
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s general board voted overwhelmingly today to support Walter F. Mondale for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination. The vote gave the former Vice President his second major labor endorsement in two days.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE five East End towns will get their own mental-health facility today with the dedication this afternoon of an 18- bed psychiatric care unit at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport.

title: ATTICA OFFICIALS PLAN TO END LOCKUP OF PROTESTORS
description: The most serious disturbance by inmates at the state prison at Attica since 1976 has simmered for two weeks as the prisoners have taken part in a ''general strike'' to protest conditions at the 54-year-old prison.

title: A BATTLE BUILDS FOR ROBINS ISLAND
description: Since it was deeded by King Charles I to the Earl of Sterling in 1615 not much has changed on Robins Island, except its price. The 440-acre island in the middle of Peconic Bay at the end of Long Island is still mainly a wilderness but it is on the market now for $10.8 million.

title: FOUR SEEK SEATS ON FAMILY COURT
description: FOUR candidates are competing for two positions on the Westchester Family Court bench in the November elections.

title: TAXING PERKS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Mary Beth Connor Weds Christopher Newkumet
description: Mary Elizabeth Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Connor of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher John Newkumet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Blair H. Newkumet of Philadelphia. The Rev. Gerald Kelleher, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., assisted by the Rev. Berthold Forrester and the Rev. Norman Methe.

title: FAMILY COURT: ARBITER IN A SPECTRUM OF SOCIAL PROBLEMS
description: THE visitor quietly waiting to occupy the large leather chair in the judge's chambers has blond braids and would ordinarily be in school. On this warm fall morning in New Rochelle, Judge Barbara Kaiser of Westchester Family Court is about to conduct an in camera interview with the child, whose divorced parents will not speak to each other.

description: Good Times for the Short Story

title: HUMANITIES AIDE UPLIFTS STATE
description: WASHINGTON ''BENJAMIN FRANKLIN,'' says Dr. Richard M. Huber, ''once said that New Jersey is like a beer barrel tapped at both ends, with all the live beer flowing into New York and Philadelphia.''

title: 'EIGHTIES,' A SURREAL REHEARSAL
description: In the first section of Chantal Akerman's ''Golden Eighties,'' a number of actors are seen on videotape, rehearsing lines that are intentionally absurd. The camera studies the auditioners intently as they invest meaningless dialogue with unwarranted passion (''Actually red is not my color, you see,'' one woman declares emotionally in a clothing store). They seem to be speaking about a broken love affair, a tryst that takes place in a shop's dressing room, and the glories of Canada, among other things. The screenplay is by Miss Akerman and Jean Gruault, whose motives here are no less obscure than those of their characters.

title:
ART;
FROM HOBOKEN TO SUMMIT, NOT TO MENTION JERSEY CITY
description: THE state's art geography has slid around a bit this month. A group show from Hoboken is on view at the Summit Art Center, while the Jersey City Museum is showing drawings whose like might be seen across the Hudson on a very good afternoon.

description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPE EXPORTS A BEGUILING ARRAY OF EARLY MUSIC

title: MURPHY PACES ROUT BY BELLEVILLE
description: Mike Murphy, Belleville's powerful senior fullback, ran for 85 yards on 16 carries and scored the first touchdown in a 14-0 shutout of Bloomfield yesterday in Bloomfield.

title: Cynthia Atchison And Evan Jones Exchange Vows
description: Cynthia Lynn Atchison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Atchison of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Evan Jones, son of Curtis Jones of Princeton, N.J., and the late Elizabeth A. Whitehead. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Magistro of the Unitarian Univeralist Society of Stamford, Conn., at the home of the bridegroom's stepfather, Edwin C. Whitehead, in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE RAPTOR TRUST in the Morris County community of Millington, a nonprofit rescue and rehabilitation center for birds, has documented the first endangered species in New Jersey to be caught and maimed in a steel leghold trap.

title: PENTAGON IN YEAR-END RUSH, SPENDS BILLIONS
description: The Defense Department, like all Government agencies, resists having money left over at the end of a fiscal year. When the Pentagon faced the end of the Federal fiscal year 1983 on Friday, it went on a $4.2 billion shopping excursion.

title: No Headline
description: N. Rockland Streak at 21

title: THE WORLD
description: Talking Peace,Thinking WarIn El SalvadorCombatants in El Salvador's civil war find it expedient to keep talking about political solutions even while pressing for a military advantage. Representatives of the Salvadoran Government and leftist insurgents met for the second time last week in Bogota, Colombia, but neither side demonstrated much willingness to compromise. The head of the Government's peace commission said afterward that the talks would not continue unless the rebels reconsidered their refusal to participate in elections.

description: Clare Katherine McKenna, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George G. McKenna, was married yesterday to Robert Joseph Gruendel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hugo J. Gruendel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Stuart, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Sullivan at St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MILLBURN: THE FRENCH CONNECTION
description: MILLBURN EVEN before entering Sara Fiverson Antiques on the main street of this Essex County community, one senses an interior designer's talent.

description: The Male Clubhouse

title: POLITICS IN ULSTER STILL MIX BALLOT AND BOMB
description: Short of the fantasy of a proclamation by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that all British troops were being pulled out of Northern Ireland, the escape last week of 38 Irish nationalists from Maze Prison was the best news Irish republicans could have imagined.

title: OFF THE GRAND CANAL, A SIMPLE VEVETIAN INN
description: ''It's not necessary for you to be saying, 'Grazie, grazie, grazie,' all the time,'' Adriano Carrettin is saying to a pretty young painter from Kansas who is struggling to arrange for a room in Italian. ''You see, it's us men who should be saying 'thank you' to all the women like you for just being beautiful.'' Laughing, Mr. Carrettin reaches across the small marble bar in front of him and clasps the flustered young woman on the shoulder.

title: NEWARK'S FAILING DREAM
description: part one

title: GREECE BEGINS WORK TO SAVE PARTHENON
description: Greece has begun work to save the Parthenon from damage by corrosion, pollution, earthquakes and the hands and feet of visitors.

title: FROM FILM COMEDY TO OFFENBACH
description: Madeline Kahn, the actress and comedienne, will take a few days off from her television show ''Oh Madeline,'' to appear in Offenbach's opera ''La Peri chole'' at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 30. Carnegie Hall's semi-staged version of the opera will replace Offenbach's spoken dialogue with a narration by Miss Kahn in English. She will speak from the side of the stage, tieing the action together and occasionally interacting with the singers themselves.

title: SECRET POLLUTERS: HOMEOWNERS
description: THOUSANDS of Connecticut citizens have suffered the consequences of drinking water contaminated by toxic waste. There is no news in the foregoing statement. After all, it is the highly publicized threat of contamination by industrial waste that keeps citizens steeled against waste disposal facilities in their own communities.

BUSINESS FORUM;
DON'T FAVOR TEEN-AGERS OVER ADULTS
description: EARLIER this year, the Administration proposed legislation that would allow employers, without prior certification by the Secretary of Labor, to hire teen-agers at a wage less than the current Federal minimum.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: SuperpowersTurn to UnquietDiplomacyMuch as President Reagan had used the downing of Flight 007 to launch his harshest condemnation of the Soviet system and leaders, Yuri V. Andropov punched back last week with an unusually sharp denunciation of President Reagan and Washington. This time the subject was missiles and the exchange put a new chill on the already frosty superpower relationship.

title: A SPECTRUM OF BLACK DANCERS
description: Jill Silverman writes frequently on the performing arts.

title: Ann P. Schelpert to Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. John William Schelpert 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Purser Schelpert, to John Apdale Francis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis of Westport, Conn.

title: CONDOMINIUM ABEAM SOUTH ST. SEAPORT
description: It was once the Beekman Downtown Hospital, but the hospital vacated the old seven-story brick structure years ago for more modern quarters. Now the building at 117 Beekman Street has a new life as the Seaport Park Condominiums where 26 apartments are selling for $175,000 to $625,000.

title: ARGENTINA IMPOSES TIGHT FINANCIAL CONTROLS
description: Argentina's military Government has imposed emergency foreign exchange controls and suspended the issue of new import licenses because of the country's foreign-debt crisis.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER

title: CHAMBER BENEFIT TO BE PLAYED IN A SCARSDALE HOME
description: DOES the idea of enjoying fine chamber music in a private home appeal to you? Can you afford to contribute $50 to the Center for Preventive Psychiatry, the nonprofit community agency headquartered in White Plains? If so, you are invited to join the violinist Jacques Margolis, violist Selig Posner and cellist Bernardo Altmann (all members of the New York Philharmonic), plus the host-commentator, June Lebell of radio station WQXR, for a benefit recital and reception at the Scarsdale residence of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schlesinger. The recital, beginning at 3 o'clock this afternoon, features music from Haydn, Handel and Mozart. To check the availibility of tickets, call 723-4984 between 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. today.

title: OILERS LOOK TO OVERTAKE ISLANDERS
description: BREEZING past their opposition throughout the National Hockey League's regular season, the Edmonton Oilers proved themselves worthy of becoming Stanley Cup finalists last season. The Islanders didn't exactly breeze through the regular season - they finished sixth over all and second to the Philadelphia Flyers in the Patrick Division - but when the playoffs arrived, they once again proved themselves not only worthy finalists, but also worthy champions.

title: Nicaragua Will Pursue Rebels in Border Areas
description: The Nicaraguan Army will pursue rebels who attack across Honduran and Costa Rican border areas it considers ''no man's lands,'' Defense Minister Humberto Ortega said today.

title: SOME IN MIDDLE CLASS BEGIN TO FAULT MARCOS
description: Between riots last week, several hundred prominent businessmen gathered in Manila's financial district to scold the Government-restricted press for its reporting since the assassination of opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. All over the capital, business and professional people, the very rich and the merely middle class, were complaining about President Ferdinand E. Marcos's rule. They worry that the political crisis may drive the country's shaky economy into a nose dive, and they hope for changes that would restore their rights and influence and bring long-term stability.

title: THE EDINBURGH, THE FRINGS IS A PHENOMENOM
description: Robert Cushman is theater critic for The Observer.

title: ONE SCALLOP'S NOT THE SAME AS ANOTHER
description: WITH the yearly reopening of the Long Island scallop season (it runs until April), as many as three types of scallops may now be found in fish markets in the New York City area. The Peconic Bay scallops from the waters of Eastern Long Island are considered by many to be the most select among them.

title: INVESTMENT SERVICE CATERS TO WOMEN
description: UNTIL recently, H. Catherine Skinner and Gretchen H. Kingsley considered themselves to be astute in managing their own financial affairs.

title: MENTAL ILLNESS CITED AMONG MANY HOMELESS
description: The vast majority of homeless people studied in two urban areas are mentally ill and many have a history of psychiatric hospitalization, medical researchers have found.

title: THE STRANGLING OF A RESORT
NEW LAWS ON ALCOHOL NOW IN AFFECT
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT intensified its fight against teen-age drinking and intoxicated drivers Saturday as new state laws took effect raising the legal drinking age to 20 from 19 and increasing most of the penalties for drunken driving.

title: NEIGHBORS PROTEST ROUTE 25A PLAN
description: AFEDERAL and state proposal to widen and straighten Route 25A from Little Neck Road in Centerport to Woodbine Avenue in Northport has local residents rallying for what they say is the preservation of their neighborhood. Everyone involved agrees that the one-mile stretch of road is dangerous, but each side has its own, very different solutions.

title: M. E. Klehm Wed To Miss Marcoux
description: Susan Patricia Marcoux, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Marcoux of Randolph, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Early Klehm of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Klehm of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Ambrose J. Keefe, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. James the Greater Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: A STRUGGLE TO SURVIVE IN THE AIR
description: EVEN for the airline industry, where upheaval has

title: Grevey Goes to Bucks

title: WHERE CHINA AND JAPAN MEET
description: OPEN since last June, Sakura is an ambitious restaurant that provides both Japanese and Chinese cuisines unders its narrow roof. This coupling seems to strain the abilities of the kitchen. Japan's cuisine is based on the art of making much of little, it has developed from an imposed orderliness. The country's geographic isolation has limited both variety and quantity. On the other hand, only climate sets limits on the cuisine of China, whose vastness yields a great variety of vegetables, fruit and meat. And, not least, the quest for new dishes or tastes encourages culinary experimentation. The appreciation of innovative chefs has been a tradition as ancient as Chinese culture itself. At Sakura neither cuisine is given its due, Hybrids are always welcome when they work, but this one needs to be rethought, and thus our rating of one dim star.

title: Florida Integration Plan For Colleges Accepted
description: The Federal Government has accepted Florida's latest desegregation plan for public colleges and universities, despite objections from a civil rights group.

title: ADULT EDUCATION MERGES IN YONKERS
description: -education programs of the Yonkers Public Schools will be consolidated this month, when the new Center for Continuing Education opens its doors at the Commerce Community Center. Housed in a building that has served successively as high school, middle school and, in recent years, as a home for a number of community agencies, the center will place Adult Basic Education and employment and training programs in the same location as many of the agencies that refer clients to the programs.

Both, however, are now being presented to the gallery-going public as serious artists, and by a happy accident of scheduling, both are now having retrospective exhibitions at New York University's Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place, through Oct. 15.

title: BIBLE READING
description: Yesterday, Jews began to read the Bible again from the beginning in synagogues. The text, written in Hebrew without punctuation, is recited from a parchment scroll during the service, following a traditional system of chant. This reading of the first five books - from Genesis to Deuteronomy - takes one year and is divided into weekly sections. The first portion told of the creation, the fall, the origins of cities and the decision to blot man from the face of the earth. The second reading will tell of Noah, the flood and the origins of nations and will end with the first mention of the Canaanite who was to become Abraham. The readings will proceed through the five books until they come to completion sometime next September with the death of Moses. Then the cycle of readings will begin again.

description: The C.I.A. is flying supplies to the United States-backed Sandinista forces in Nicaragua from a Salvadoran Air Force base, according to United States officials in Central America. They said that to their knowledge, the flights delivered only medicine, ammunition and communications equipment to the anti-Sandinistas, and that no weapons had been delivered. (Page 1, Column 2.)

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: I cringe each time I read a Vienna article which has the premiere of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' occurring in the Theater an der Wien, the latest being Paul Hofmann's ''What's Doing in Vienna'' (Travel, June 26). Loyal Mozartians the world over will point out that, while the lovely Theater an der Wien, which opened June 13, 1801, is the site of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' premiere, it did not yet exist in 1791 when ''The Magic Flute'' was first performed. That opera was first performed at the now demolished Freihaus-Theater auf der Wieden, a suburban house leased by Mozart's collaborator Emanuel Schikaneder, who also sang the role of Papageno.

title: THAT SATISFIED FEELING
description: I KNOW OF NOTHING THAT gives home cooks a greater feeling of fulfillment than the making and baking of yeast breads and I think I know why. Since biblical times, the leavening of breads has given the baker the sense of creating ''miracles,'' and that seems to be the logical response to that rising of dough before it is placed in the oven. There are other ''miracle- producing'' dishes, of course, notably souffles and cream puffs, both of which go poof as they bake, but somehow it isn't the same.

Rossiter teaches the history of science at Harvard and is the author of ''Women Scientists in America, Struggles and Strategies to 1940.'' and because she has in a sense had two careers, the more recent of which is even more revealing than her first rise from obscurity in the 1930's and 1940's.

title: GREAT ACTING MUST TOUCH THE HEART
description: You may propose Garrick or Macready or Olivier. Someone else may counter with Sir Henry Irving, citing a Macbeth so powerful it was compared to ''a great famished wolf,'' and trying to forget that he was sometimes more like a histrionic Hound of the Baskervilles, baying empty syllables at an uncomprehending gallery. A patriot in this corner wonders why we aren't considering the two American Edwins, Forrest and Booth; and a dusty gentleman beside the bookcase insists that the only serious contender is Richard Burbage, whose performances he has spent a lifetime reconstructing from the hints he's found in Jacobean marginalia. But as long as we are playing this faintly preposterous party-game - which is the greatest- ever of the English-speaking classical actors? - my own preference can't be hidden. It is for the tiny, venomous genius Ben Kingsley is currently playing at the Brooks Atkinson: Edmund Kean.

title: O'NEILL SUMMONS ASSEMBLY FOR BRIDGE FUNDS

title: JAZZ: THE BRAZILIAN SINGER LENY ANDRADE
description: Leny Andrade, who's being heralded as ''Brazil's No. 1 jazz singer'' at the Blue Note, where she is making her American debut through tonight, is a short, plump, round-faced woman who looks somewhat like Mildred Bailey and who does scat singing with an agility that approaches Ella Fitzgerald.

title: QUIET DEMISE FOR STAMFORD STATION
description: THE days of the old Stamford railroad station are ending not with a bang and not with a whimper but with the steady tap, tap of a ''pick and bucket'' operation, as described by the project director, Paul Disario.

description: Question:

title: A 1963 PEACE CORPS GROUP REVELS IN OLD CAMARADERIE
description: The year was 1963. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had a dream, and Bob Dylan said the answer was blowing in the wind. Vietnam was still somebody else's war. Watergate was just an architect's blueprint.

title: COMPUTER SKILLS TIED TO EASING UNEMPLOYMENT
description: State officials seek ways to bring education into the computer age. Page 4.

title: ANTIWAR MARCHES ARE HELD IN SOVIET
description: Muscovites by the tens of thousands converged in well-drilled columns today on six rally sites for what was officially termed an antiwar demonstration.

title: Egypt Seeks to Extend Its State of Emergency
description: The Government of Egypt asked Parliament today to extend special emergency laws for another year, saying that 13 attempts had been made over the past year to overthrow President Hosni Mubarak.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Proliferation of Small Presses

title: THE TROUBLED CAREER OF THOMAS WOLFE
description: ''I FEEL it is wrong to go on writing books and plays about American subjects using ideas and methods that we get abroad,'' Thomas Wolfe announced. As his country's self-appointed bard, he planned to compose a vast saga, using a distinctly American idiom and employing a uniquely American structure, that would capture ''the whole intolerable memory of America, its violence, savagery, immensity, beauty, ugliness, and glory.'' But the three books of fiction Wolfe published during his lifetime fell far short of his ambitious goal, as did the three other volumes issued after his death in 1938. Clearly one of the central problems facing Wolfe scholars is to explain why his reach so far exceeded his grasp.

title: ELIZABETH FRIEDGUT IS BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Hamilton Friedgut , daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Jack Friedgut of New York, was married yesterday to Russell Bertram Selman , son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon D. Selman of Oceanside, L.I. The Rev. Kenneth McLean and Rabbi Jay Hyman performed the ceremony at the Women's National Democratic Club in Washington.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LUCERNE
description: Railroad buffs, aerospace aficionados and parents with mechanically minded offspring in tow are among those for whom a visit to Lucerne makes sense any time of year. The reason: The city's dazzling Transport and Communications Museum, which dramatically traces the development of transportation from the steam locomotive to the space age. It even includes a planetarium. But there's much more to Lucerne: Lying at the geographical heart of Switzerland, the city is one of Europe's most cosmopolitan vacation centers and boasts a wealth of scenic attractions, theaters, museums and festivals.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Another Drop for Rates?

title: STAGE: PARODY OF WATERGATE AT WEST BANK
description: ''A goat, a goat! My kingdom for a scapegoat!'' pleads Richard, the President of the United States, moments before he's undone by Sir Sam, Earl of Richmond and Senator from North Carolina, bearing a shield that reads ''The Bill of Rights.''

title: CONCERT: WOODWIND QUINTET
description: Carnegie Recital Hall houses so much earnest mediocrity in the course of a season that it was a pleasure to enter it Friday evening and listen to the New York Woodwind Quintet. These players are a persuasive advertisement for the virtues of age and experience, and their playing on Friday had a wonderful spirit to it and a sophisticated professionalism.

title: HOW VALID A SYMBOL IS JEJART' 'WEIN' BALLET?
description: The first time I saw Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century was in 1961 in Paris. Rudolf Nureyev was sitting two rows behind with Yuri Soloviev. Then unknown in the United States, the two golden boys of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet were obviously on a night off from their performances in an another theater during the Soviet company's first visit to France.

title: THE ERROR IN WRITING WHAT YOU FEEL
description: THEY were loathsome things, but we were saddled with them anyway. The real cruelty was that they were inflicted on us at precisely the moment we had stopped telling each other what we had done on our summer vacations. The answer was always easier to contemplate than write down. What had I done on my summer vacation in, just to pick a year at random, 1962?

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Blossom Dearie is that anomaly, a nightclub singer who does not like to work at night. Home in bed by nine is her goal.

title: JENNIFER HOLIDAY MAKES THE JUMP FROM BROADWAY TO POP
description: Few pop albums this year have inspired higher expectations - and deeper trepidations - than the solo debut of the ''Dreamgirls'' star Jennifer Holliday. Miss Holliday, whom many regard as the most exciting female gospel singer since Aretha Franklin, has a comparably mammoth voice and strong musical personality. The question facing a producer is how to capture such a singer's essence in a commercial setting without forcing devastating artistic compromises.

title: ADVANTAGES SHIFT SUBTLY IN A DELICATE THREE-HANDED GAME
description: The United States, China and the Soviet Union last week seemed to be playing another round in an international strategy game, with each side trying to avoid being isolated by the others. The stakes were high - if any two joined forces, they might endanger the country left out. Playing the game vigorously in Peking, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met with Chinese leaders and announced that Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang would come to Washington in January and that President Reagan would be going to Peking in April.

title: TO CHASE A SPY
description: Robert Lindsey is the chief of The Times's Los Angeles bureau. This article is adapted from ''The Flight of the Falcon,'' the forthcoming sequel to his initial book about the Soviet spy Christopher Boyce, ''The Falcon and the Snowman.'' By Robert Lindsey ARRY HOMENICK WAS getting tired of pork chops. But the man he was guarding - the former insurance man who had got rich by bribing union bosses with money and clothes and hookers and then, when he was caught, had become one of the Justice Department's best snitches ever against organized crime - always asked for a dinner of pork chops and applesauce to go with his buttermilk. Homenick wondered how the man could eat all that fatty meat when he had an ulcer.

title: Chadian President Meets With African Leaders
description: President Hissen Habre of Chad met here today with the Presidents of Ivory Coast, Zaire, Gabon and Togo in an effort to find a solution to the civil war in Chad, African diplomats said.

title: QUESTIONS ARISE NOT JUST OVER WATT'S WORDS
description: President Reagan has not tapped a vein of luck with his environmental appointees. In March the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne McGill Burford, was forced to leave office amid Congressional investigations of mismanagement and wrongdoing in the agency's hazardous waste program. Now Interior Secretary James G. Watt, a colorful figure from the day he was nominated, is under pressure to resign after praising the diversity of the members of a coal advisory commission by saying: ''I have a black, I have a woman, two Jews and a cripple.''

title: A Pleased Seaver Looks to 1984
description: Tom Seaver pitched yesterday for the 34th and last time in his comeback season with the Mets, said that he had exceeded the expectations of ''the skeptics'' and predicted that he would pitch for perhaps several more years.

title: CONSERVATIVE UNIT GAINS FROM LEGACY
description: The conservationist, philanthropist and inventor John M. Olin gave money liberally to nurture conservative scholars and institutions, saying ''My greatest ambition is to see free enterprise re-established in this country.''

But in the last three weeks, as the heavy bunches of grapes strain the vines, new signs have been appearing on cardboard and scrap lumber, nailed to trees: ''Grape pickers wanted.''

title: COUPLE ARE HONORED FOR CARING FOR 100 BABIES OVER 17 YEARS
description: GLADYS and William Lynn have just celebrated their 100th baby. The Lynns, who live in Yonkers, are foster parents. For 17 years, they have provided temporary homes for infants whose mothers cannot care for them. They take in babies for several days, several months or, once in a great while, several years, and they say goodbye when the children are ready to be placed in permanent homes.

Then there are television cables, steam pipes, telegraph wires and sewers, not to mention lines and pipes long ago abandoned and forgotten. At large intersections, the congestion underground is as bad as it is on the surface.

title: BETHPAGE WINS, 7-0
description: Bethpage, which led Nassau County last week with 41 total points scored, defeated Roosevelt, 7-0, yesterday, a team that also had a strong opening game. Bethpage (2-0) scored the game's only touchdown in the last quarter on a 5-yard run by Mike Mondiello, a halfback. The score was set up after 11 plays moved the Golden Eagles 65 yards. Jim O'Brien kicked the extra point. In the second half, Roosevelt (1-1) was unable to gain a first down.

description: John McEnroe set an American record as he teamed with Peter Fleming for a doubles victory today that gave the United States a 2-1 lead over Ireland in the Davis Cup competition for a spot in next year's championship division.

description: MORRISTOWN LEATHER use is up, wood is advancing, ceramics are steady, stained glass is gaining on blown glass, wearables are down (but still high fashion) and porcelain and copper jewelry are vying with gold.

title: Ballesteros Joins Tour
description: It took a change in the rules to get him, but Seve Ballesteros , the Spanish golfer who has twice won the Masters, has finally decided to join the professional tour in the United States. Ballesteros, a celebrity on the European tour, had balked at joining the PGA Tour because of a rule allowing foreign players to leave the tour for just one tournament outside their home countries for every five P.G.A. events they participate in.

title: EVENTUALLY, 'PICTURES' HIT STRIDE'
description: As Masterpiece Theater opens a new season this evening, on WNET/13 at 9 o'clock, it strikes me that there may be a subtle correlation between Alistair Cooke's appearances and the quality of the episodes he has been introducing for more than a decade. The simpler the setting for Mr. Cooke, it seems, the better the series. He is always found on a set that is keyed to the production itself. He has been seen in everything from Edwardian drawing rooms to rural gardens. As it happens, Mr. Cooke's setting for ''Pictures,'' the new seven-part import from Britain, is rather elaborate, a fact that should immediately leave the viewer wary - justifiably so.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: GROWING UP. By Russell Baker. (NAL/Plume, $5.95.) Russell Baker's best-selling, Pulitzer Prize- winning autobiography is an amalgam of ''sadness and laughter that bears a suspicious resemblance to real life,'' our reviewer, Richard Lingeman, said. Mr. Baker, who has written the Observer column in The New York Times for more than 20 years, creates touching and funny portraits of his redoubtable mother, his spunky sister Doris, various gently eccentric kinfolk and the beautiful girl he married against his mother's wishes as he recalls growing up during the Depression and World War II.

title: ROUGHNECKS CAPTURE SOCCER BOWL

title: No Headline
description: Reverse NepotismThe ghosts of deals past may haunt the future of Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Mr. Presser's uncle, Allen Friedman , was convicted last week of embezzling $165,000 in ''salary'' from a no-show job in his nephew's Local 507 in Cleveland.

title: TYLENOL SLAYINGS REMAIN UNSOLVED
description: A year ago an act as innocuous as brushing one's teeth was transformed into a deadly new form of terror. Between 6 A.M. and 10 P.M. on Sept. 29, 1982, two mothers, two brothers, a recent bride, a schoolgirl and a stewardess in the Chicago area reached into medicine cabinets or purses or across kitchen tables for Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules they had purchased that day. All seven quickly collapsed and died of cyanide poisoning.

title: CHOOSING A COLLEGE: 'WHO WILL I BE'
description: -streaked tresses, my daughter of the tanned face and large blue-green eyes sprawls on the sofa in our living room, amid her scattered possessions (camp trunk, duffel, laundry bag, lacrosse and hockey sticks plus other smaller assorted items), staring off into some unseeable space where parents are obviously not welcome. I dare not ask what's the matter for fear of the usual rebuke - ''Nothing! Nothing's the matter. Why do you always have to ask if something's the matter when nothing's the matter?''

description: Officials of an Iowa and Illinois inmate rehabilitation group say their methods for helping ex-offenders return to a productive life are working far better than other techniques in use.

title: Boxer Still Critical

Perez, who was born in Puerto Rico and now lives in West New York, N.J., was knocked down early in the seventh round but got up and absorbed more punishment before the referee stopped the fight at 1 minute 54 seconds of the round.

title: RECITAL: ELAINE KEILLOR, PIANO

Around the two familiar works in her program - Faure's Theme and Variations and Scriabin's Sonata No. 10 - she lined up Haydn's Capriccio: ''Acht Sauschneider M"ussen Seyn,'' J. G. Eckard's Sonata (Op. 1, No. 2), Michael Colgrass's ''Metamusic: Music About Music,'' Elma Miller's ''Minnemata'' and Patrick Cardy's ''Masks of Astarte.''

Carl Reimers, a Presbyterian minister and chairman of the religion department of the Princeton Day School in Princeton, N.J.

title: KEEPING CURRENT ON THE TAX FRONT
description: The Internal Revenue Service is constantly revising its policy on tax deductions. Often the revisions are forced on it by taxpayers who take the I.R.S. to court. But sometimes the I.R.S. itself makes a change after studying a thorny issue. Some recent changes provide a mixed bag for taxpayers, but should have a widespread impact, since they involve some of the most sought-after tax breaks. Two court decisions concern the home office deduction, and one of them might literally be music to the ears of those who prefer a liberal interpretation in this area. The other will likely strike a discordant note. Another court case may make interest-free loans more attractive. And an internal I.R.S. ruling on individual retirement accounts may help increase I.R.A. returns for millions of Americans. HOME OFFICE DEDUCTION. A Federal appeals court has ruled that a musician employed by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra who maintained home practice studios was entitled to this deduction. But another appeals court rejected a claim by a man who used a room in his house to receive telephone calls connected with his job as a condominium manager. The musician involved was Ernest Drucker, a violinist for the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Drucker set aside one room of his five-room apartment for exclusive use as a practice studio, and furnished it with stereo components, a piano, hundreds of books, records and tapes, musical scores, music stands, a desk and three violins. He used the studio about 30 hours a week and, during opera season, spent about 26 hours a week performing or rehearsing at Lincoln Center, where the Met is located. Mr. Drucker argued that his studio fulfilled an I.R.S. requirement that a home office serve as the principal place of business.

title: CONCERT: HARTMANN'S 'GESANGSSZENE'
description: When the German composer Karl Amadeus Hartmann died in 1963, he left unfinished his massive ''Gesangsszene,'' or ''Song-Scene,'' for baritone and orchestra. Thursday night, the New York Philharmonic, under the direction of Rafael Kubelik, presented the American premiere of Mr. Hartmann's valedictory at Avery Fisher Hall. For this, we can only be grateful, for ''Gesangsszene,'' even in its fragmentary condition, is a worthy capstone to a distinguished career.

description: The following article was written by Susan Chamlin and Sandy Constabile

title: THE BEST OF AMERICANA IN HARTFORD
description: WHEN the British burned the shop of a master clockmaker, Nathaniel Mulliken, in Lexington, Mass., on April 19, 1776, the craftsman was able to save several of his timepieces. They included mantle clocks and the stately case clocks that were almost as much a measure of a man's wealth as the land, cattle and buildings he owned.

title: AGE NO BURDEN TO VOLUNTEERS
description: Hortense Hirsch, who has been an active fund-raiser for well over half a century, says she doesn't work the way she used to, but she does what she can and ''people accept me.''

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
MILAN'S MOODS
description: use this

title: FOOTBALL RETAINING POPULARITY
description: Despite the 1982 football strike and the apparent escalation of drug abuse among National Football League players, football remains more popular than baseball among adult Americans, according to the results of a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: BOSSES AND TAXES
description: To the Business Editor:

title: IT'S APPLE-PICKING TIME
description: EACH fall in Connecticut, hundreds of thousands of bushels of apples are picked by do-it- yourselfers, ranging through orchards with long poles and baskets in search of the perfect McIntosh, Cortland or delicious. Along the way, they also pick up fresh cider and home-baked pies, bread and cookies.

title: DEBATE SHARPENS ON CITY'S USE OF INCENTIVES IN ZONING
description: ''Zoning,'' said Emily Menlo Marks, president of the Parks Council, at a hearing a week ago, ''should not be used as a revenue generator.'' Or, put another way, zoning benefits should not be for sale.

title: Cosmos Get Peterson
description: In the dispersal draft of players from the defunct Seattle Sounders of the North American Soccer League, the Cosmos selected Mark Peterson, a forward who was on loan last year to Team America, for which he had 14 goals and 5 assists.

title: FARMERS TO GET $3 MILLION FROM DEFAULT FUND
description: The State Court of Appeals, reversing a lower-court decision, this week approved the payment of more than $3 million to upstate dairy farmers from a state fund set up to protect them from the default of milk-processing plants.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: 'A Great Story'

title: SUMMER'S DROUGHT DULL LEAFCOLORS
description: THE fall foliage show will go on again this year, but a little earlier than usual and with colors something less than breathtaking.

title: KENTUCKY GOVERNOR PONDERS POLITICAL FUTURE
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. of Kentucky, who recently survived a brush with death and has been shadowed for months by Federal investigations of him and his friends, is blithely and undauntedly considering his options for a political future.

title: FESTIVAL MOVIES OUGHT TO CHALLENGE US
description: Asecond thought: As much as I admire ''The Big Chill,'' Lawrence Kasdan's wise, rueful comedy about some 1960's activists 15 years after all the excitement has died down, I'm not at all sure that it was the best choice to open the current New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. ''The Big Chill'' belongs in this international event, but as the opening attraction it gets things off to a deceptively easy start.

title: LOOK TO INDUSTRY FOR SPECIALIZED TEACHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CLOSING NIGHT OF A HANGOUT IN HOUSTON
description: Eagle Pennell's ''Last Night at the Alamo'' is a small film that raises both the hope and the possibility that Mr. Pennell will make bigger ones. Shot in a primitive style, and using both accents and equipment that sometimes make its sound a little muddy, it's the ribald and faintly mournful chronicle of a seedy Houston hangout that's about to close its doors for the last time, much to the chagrin of the regular clientele.

title: CORN DOLLIES, AN ANCIENT CRAFT
description: Corn dollies are very English, and for that reason they are a bit puzzling to Americans. First, the corn that they are made of is not the Indian maize Americans call corn. Rather, they are fashioned from the dry stalks of what English people call corn, which is any of the cereal grains grown on their island - barley, rye, oats and principally wheat.

title: 'A FUNNY THING... BUT NOT ON STAGE
description: THEATER Three in Port Jefferson has opened its 15th anniversary season with the baudy vaudevillian musical ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' The show, with music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and book by Larry Gelbart and Burt Shevelov, exemplifies the theater's forthcoming season, said artistic director Bradlee E. Bing in his curtain-opening speech. This year's theme is ''Something for Everyone,'' which is taken from a lyric in ''A Comedy Tonight,'' the opening number in ''A Funny Thing.''

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT WAS a little more than a year

title: No Headline
description: Headliners Bad BloodExtremes of filial devotion were the main ingredients in the Salt Lake City murder conviction of Frances Bernice Schreuder last week. Mrs. Schreuder's son, Marc, now serving five years to life for killing his mother's father, Franklin Bradshaw, testifed at his mother's trial that he had done it because she asked him to. The prosecutor contended Mrs. Schreuder wanted her multi-millionaire father dead because there was growing friction between them and she feared he would disinherit her. Mrs. Schreuder, a New York resident who sat on the board of the New York City Ballet, could get the death penalty at her sentencing tomorrow.

title: TODAY'S AVANT-GARDE PUTS ITS ART ON PARADE
description: There is a vital tradition of collaboration in the performing arts, a tradition being upheld by the Next Wave Festival, which begins Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with ''The Photographer/ Far From the Truth,'' a musical theater-piece by Philip Glass and Rob Malasch. For the next nine weeks, the festival will utilize all three of the Academy's performance spaces and offer works by such artists, composers and choreographers as Robert Rauschenberg, Laurie Anderson, Trisha Brown and Lucinda Childs.

title: THE STONY BROOK RIFT: RACISM AND ZIONISM
description: ON Aug. 17, five faculty members at the State University of New York at Stony Brook met to review the evidence against Prof. Ernest Dube.

title: IS PEACE POSSIBLE
description: There can be no real peace in the world unless a new relationship is established between the United States and Soviet Union.

title: Kenneth Telljohann Marries Jean Marie Amabile
description: Jean Marie Amabile, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Raymond Amabile of Elizabeth, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Lane Telljohann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Frederick Telljohann of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Francis J. McGuire performed the Roman Catholic ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Bruce W. Morgan, an American Baptist minister.

title: Idaho Ponders Legal Fate Of Baby Found in Trash
description: A baby born without a complete brain and found in a college waste can by nursing students will remain a welfare case while the state decides her legal fate, officials said Friday.

title: CAN LEBANON'S WARLORDS MAKE PEACE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon THE Phalangist party newspaper, Al- Amal, last week came up with a statistic that said a lot about the prospects for the present cease-fire holding and a real Lebanese national entente being achieved. The paper said Monday's cease-fire was the 179th in Lebanon in the last 10 years. Looking at it another way, the paper added, ''this means that 178 previous cease-fires had collapsed.''

title: FOUNDATION PICKS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: The Edward W. Hazen Foundation, a small Connecticut philanthropy with a national reputation for its innovative work with disadvantaged youths, has chosen a former Ford Foundation official as its fifth president.

title:
WHAT'S HAPPENING IN CANADIAN BUSINESS ;
OIL SANDS WEALTH--A DREAM LIVES ON
description: OTTAWA Canada's oil sands have long been the stuff of extravagant dreams. In the mid-1970's, the futurist Herman Kahn vainly urged Canada to import 50,000 Koreans to build a new oil sands plant every three or four years. Three years ago, the corporate dream-makers were flying high with multibillion-dollar schemes to unlock the sticky black gold from the deep deposits in northern Alberta.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO ATTRACT BIRDS TO YOUR GARDEN
description: MOST gardeners enjoy having birds in their gardens. Birds add color, activity and music to the garden at any time of the year. In addition, birds are beneficial in that many species devour insect pests that would otherwise damage the plants in the garden.

title: Jets' Leahy Takes Little for Granted
description: Pat Leahy's wife, Colleen, calls it her ''cheer-leading, pep-talk speech.'' It is dusted off on special occasions, such as the one today.

title: NO REGRETS FOR MISS AMERICA RUNNER-UP
description: -up to the new Miss America, isn't nursing any wounds over not having taken the top prize in Atlantic City last month.

title: A SWEDISH ORCHESTRA IS MOVING AHEAD
description: S tockholm The Swedish National Orchestra of Gothenburg, one of the oldest orchestras in Scandinavia, will make its American debut at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday under the direction of it principal conductor, Neeme Jarvi. Gothenburg, Sweden's second- largest city, is situated on the west coast of the country and has a population of about half a million. Thanks to the energetic work of Mr. Jarvi, The orchestra - which in Sweden is known as the Gothenberg Symphony Orchestra - has made a remarkable development during the 80's, placing itself on the international musical map,

title: Killer of Woman, 80, Is Given 75 Years After Plea of Guilty
description: Henry Lee Lucas, a former mental patient who has said he killed 150 women in 16 states, has been sentenced to 75 years in prison after changing his plea to guilty in the murder of an elderly woman.

title: 6 Playoff Umpires
description: They may not be household names, but Dave Phillips, Jim Evans, Nick Bremigan, Jim McKean, Durwood Merrill and Mike Reilly will be prominent in the American League championship series between the Orioles and the Chicago White Sox that opens Wednesday in Baltimore. They are the umpires named by the league's president, Lee MacPhail.

title: Cynthia Heneage Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Heneage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Heneage of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Hartman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Hartman of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy performed the ceremony at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport.

title: Kimberly Conroy, Journalist, Wed To Robert Tyrer
description: Kimberley Ann Conroy, a freelance radio and television journalist covering Latin America, was married yesterday to Robert David Tyrer, Latin American correspondent for the British Broadcasting Corporation. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. performed the ceremony at the nondenominational Riverside Church.

title: Frederick Gillmore Jr., Dolores N. Airey Wed
description: Dolores Nancy Airey, daughter of Juliette Airey and Joseph Airey, both of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married yesterday to Frederick Hemsley Gillmore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gillmore of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Canon Gethin Hughes performed the ceremony at the All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore D. Eisler of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lynn Eisler, to Philip L. Vance, son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard F. Vance of Florissant, Mo. The wedding is to be in January.

title: COSTS TO SHELTER HOMELESS IN CITY CLIMBING SHARPLY
description: The ranks of homeless people in New York City are swelling so rapidly that city and state officials estimate they will have to provide temporary homes and food this winter for as many as 18,000 people, about double the number who sought assistance less than two years ago.

title: LEADER OF DRUSE CRITICISES ARAFAT

title: WHY FRESHMAN SHOULD NOT PLAY
description: -being, development and maturation of the young student-athlete would be well served by the elimination of freshmen eligibility for intercollegiate varsity competition in football and basketball in Division I.

title: MUSICAL FESTIVAL OF SEASON OPENERS
description: THE primary advantages in subscribing to a symphony series, instead of buying individual tickets, are that you usually get better seats and pay less per ticket. But a variety of other inducements are also offered, such as admission to receptions, pre-concert lectures, restaurant discounts, newsletters and priority ticket-purchasing rights to special events. In addition, financial support up front helps the orchestra's budget, and your foresight can avoid the frustration of poor seats or sold-out signs.

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times ; BUBBA'S DUD
description: NEARLY 15 years after the fact, Bubba Smith has created fiction. To anyone who will publish or listen to his irresponsible and undocumented theory, Bubba Smith suggests that the New York Jets' 16-7 victory in Super Bowl III was fixed. But he has yet to name anyone involved, except for a vague reference to the late Carroll Rosenbloom, then the Baltimore Colts' owner.

description: Patricia J. Gauvey and John S. Herbert, both lawyers, were married yesterday. The Rev. Peter Dillon performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

Willard Young Howell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Howell, of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: SURVEY OF BUSINESS SEES LAXITY IN 3 R'S
description: WHITE PLAINS ACCORDING to a survey sponsored by the County Chamber of Commerce, a number of Westchester businesses believe that schools need to put more emphasis on the basic skills of reading, writing and arithmetic but are pessimistic about seeing any improvement in the next five years.

title: Wedding at Yale For Miss Zahner
description: Gwendolyn Zahner, daughter of Marjorie Zahner and the late James Burns Zahner of Allestree, England, was married yesterday to Allen Hall Peacock 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Allen Peacock of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Alan Mermann, a Congregational minister who is chaplain of the Yale University Medical School, performed the nondenominational ceremony in the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale.

title: WILL NASA'S PET PROJECT FIZZLE OR FLY?
description: As the National Aeronautics and Space Administration marks its 25th anniversary this weekend, a fierce battle is being waged in Washington over the agency's proposed mandate for the next 25 years - the development of a huge orbiting space station with a full-time crew.

title: HOW CONCERT SERIES SURVIVED
description: MONTCLAIR ADECADE ago, the late Sol Hurok could fill a concert hall on the strength of his reputation as the prime promoter of the most glamorous soloists and groups in the world.

title: STUDY FINDS INCREASE IN WORLD PRESS CONTROLS
description: Government control of the press has increased significantly in most areas of the world in the past year, according to a new study presented to an international conference of representatives of independent news outlets that is taking place here this weekend.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FESTIVAL AT SALISBURY

title: FILM CHRONICLES AGENT ORANGE SUIT
description: WHEN a young Vietnam veteran, Paul Reutershan, died of a mysterious cancer Dec. 14, 1978, a lawyer, Victor J. Yannacone Jr., was approached in Patchogue to participate in a suit charging that Agent Orange, the chemical defoliant widely used in the Vietnam War, had caused Mr. Reutershan's death.

title: FLYING START
description: Next August, on 39 acres of open space in East Windsor not far from Connecticut's Bradley International Airport, construction is to begin on a new office complex. Called the Hartfield Executive Park, it will be built and managed by the Barkan Companies, a Boston developer.

title: ROAMING THE BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY
description: Even then, when the hawks and vultures, the otter and bear, ceded it to man, the southernmost expanse of Appalachia was a special place. Though the heat was beastly in summer and the snow climbed up the tree trunks in winter, the blossoms burst forth like cannon shot in spring and the leaves took on the most brilliant of hues in the fall. And there, across the valley, day after day, season afer season, only a smudge of blue separated the mountains from the horizon.

title: Court Rules That Archivists May Review Some F.B.I. Files
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the Federal Bureau of Investigation may not destroy files of historical value without allowing government archivists to review them.

title: KEEP MONOPOLY POWER AWAY FROM THE LIVING-ROOM TV SET

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A FIRM THAT SPECIALIZES IN INSURING RARE COINS
description: Rare coins have risen in value dramatically in recent years and this has made dealers and collectors more conscious than ever of the need to protect them from loss. It also has led many of them to become acquainted with DeWitt and Jolyon Stern, a father-and-son team of New York insurance executives whose company is among the leaders in providing special coverage for numismatists.

title: MAJESTY'S PRINCE TRIUMPHS
description: Joe Cantey seems to specialize in training big, slow-starting horses who get little respect but win one rich race after another, especially when it rains. That was the case with Temperence Hill, whom Cantey saddled to victories in the Belmont Stakes, Travers and Jockey Club Gold Cup three years ago, and now with Majesty's Prince, who confirmed his fondness for a soft turf course yesterday with a half-length victory in the $292,500 Man o' War Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: Ward Melville Senior Wins 5,000-Meter Run
description: John Hussey, a senior at Ward Melville, won his second race in two weeks today in the St. Anthony's Invitation at Sunken Meadows State Park.

description: Jailbreak LiftsI.R.A.'s Spirits

description: ''COMPARING AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) to the Black Death, as some national magazines are doing, is a highly reckless maneuver that can only feed hysteria and divert us from a serious study of that illness.''

title: Kuwait Seeks to End War
description: Kuwait called on Iran today to respond to mediation efforts to end the three-year- old Iran-Iraq war. Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti Crown Prince and Prime Minister, said Kuwait and other Arab and friendly countries would continue to do ''their utmost'' to end the war.

title: FOR TEANECK, A COMPLEX SOLVES PROBLEMS
description: ROUTE 4 in Bergen County extends for 10 miles, from the George Washington Bridge to Paterson - an almost seamless strip of malls, gas stations, restaurants and commercial glitz. The only part not hemmed in by this kind of suburban sprawl is a one-mile segment in Teaneck.

title: DAY-CARE GROWTH FOUND INSUFFICIENT
description: -SIX years ago, the wives of Paterson silk-mill owners began a settlement house to care for the children of women working in the mills. The day for both sets of women began at 5:30 A.M., when the workers dropped off their youngsters and hurried to the factories.

title: 'ANNIE': STILL FRESH, IN SPITE OF RETREADS
description: MILLBURN TO THIS veteran ''Annie'' watcher, the Paper Mill Playhouse production of the musical hit, which runs through Oct. 23, can be rated somewhere between the true (the original Broadway staging at its freshest) and the tired (most of the ''Annie'' retreads that are crisscrossing the country).

title: Lora Jean Dillard Marries
description: Lora Jean Dillard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Dillard of Los Altos, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. Victor Curtis Baum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton W. Baum of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Howard Berman performed the ceremony in the Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago. The bride's father is a management consultant with the Service Management Corporation in Palo Alto, Calif. The bridegroom's father is a consultant to the tobacco industry, and his mother, Selma Baum, is director of consumer affairs with Gimbels East.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Disaster Village
description: A year ago Livingston, La., became a virtual ghost village overnight. Forty-three cars of an Illinois Central Gulf Railroad train, laden with dangerous chemicals, jumped the tracks on Sept. 28, exploded and began to burn.

title: Harvard Comeback Tops Army By 24-21
description: Mike Dixon returned an interception 75 yards for a touchdown and Jim Villanueva kicked a 26-yard field goal to give Harvard a 24-21 upset victory over Army today.

title: THE NATION
description: Some BudgetProblems AreOnly PostponedThat Senator John C. Stennis has been around no one would disagree. The presumption of the long view only gave more force to his comment on the collected manner with which his colleagues last week dispatched the business necessary to keep the Federal Government operating in the new fiscal year. ''There's something new under the sun after all,'' said the Mississippi Democrat.

title: HAS ANYONE SEEN A GOOD USED CAR?
description: THERE must be thousands of used cars for sale on Long Island at any given time. Why, then, am I having so much trouble finding one?

description: Roann Kim Levinsohn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Perry Levinsohn of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Jay Alan Rubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Rubin of Pembroke Pines, Fla. Rabbi Isaac Swift performed the ceremony at Congregation Ahavath Torah in Englewood, N.J.

description: Marty Horn threw for 282 yards and Richard Benn had 11 receptions and 3 touchdowns today to lead Lehigh to a 24-19 victory over Delaware.

title: PERCY WORRIED ABOUT FATE OF NUCLEAR CURBS
description: A Supreme Court decision earlier this year voiding the legislative veto may have ''profoundly changed the effectiveness of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Act,'' Senator Charles H. Percy says.

title: LOCAL STRUGGLE, LOCAL COMPROMISE
REMEDY FOR A TIN EAR AND OTHER VEXING AILMENTS
description: The mail has piled up again. I can't answer it all, so I'll just take a few from the top. Q. My golden-eared friends hear all kinds of nuances of tonal coloration, both in live music and in sound equipment. I've got tin ears, and those fine distinctions are lost on me. I guess I don't know what I'm missing, but is there a cure for tin ears?

title: WEST VIRGINIA DOWNS PITT, 24-21
description: Jeff Hostetler, who grew up hoping to perform heroics as a Penn State passing quarterback, had his biggest moment of glory as a West Virginia quarterback today by running. He ran 6 yards on a bootleg into the end zone midway through the fourth quarter to culminate a 90-yard drive and give undefeated West Virginia an uphill 24-21 victory over Pittsburgh.

title: Carter and Ford Split On Voter Registration
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said Saturday that the key change needed to raise turnout in American elections is a revamped voter registration system, but he and former President Gerald R. Ford disagreed on how to make such changes.

description: Guerrillas killed at least 46 people, including 39 Philippine soldiers, in an ambush of an army patrol unit northwest of here last week, a high military officer said here today.

title: No Headline

title: Marchers Raise Money For Nuclear Freeze By The Associated Press
description: Hundreds of Americans in 200 cities took part in six-mile walks Saturday and raised hundreds of thousands of dollars to campaign for a nuclear weapons freeze.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a wire- service article in some editions of Sunday's sports section incorrectly identified the manager of the Kansas City Royals. He is Dick Howser.

title: Anne Isherwood Married
description: Anne Marie Isherwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Isherwood of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen B. Burnett, son of Bishop Bill B. Burnett of East London, South Africa. The Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Bronxville.
