description: Bridge:Italy Qualifies for Semifinals In World Team Competition

title: AS TALKS LAG, CHICAGO TEACHERS CALL FOR A STRIKE
description: The Chicago Teachers Union called for a strike today after negotiations failed to produce agreement on salary increases. The action seemed sure to cancel classes Monday for the 420,000 students in the nation's third largest school district.

title: OIL COMPANIES' PROFITS AND ECONOMICS ARGUED
description: In the chilly expanse of the Pacific Ocean off Alaska's southern coast, the offshore oil rig Ocean Odyssey is being towed away this week. The rig has been leased since April by the Atlantic Richfield Company to explore the Gulf of Alaska.

title: KING CRAB FISHING CLOSED IN ALASKA
description: Alaskan king crab, which has become an international delicacy over the last 30 years, will begin to disappear from markets and restaurant menus in the coming months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Taking Leave Of Borough Hall

title: Filly Winner By 20
description: Rose Crescent, a 4-year-old filly with mediocre form on the dirt and little experience on the grass, stepped onto a soft turf course at Belmont Park yesterday and turned into a different sort of animal. The daughter of Nijinsky won the $57,300 Athenia Handicap by 20 lengths, one of the largest margins of victory ever in a stakes race.

title: OUTDOORS: TURKEY HUNTERS NEED SKILL AND PATIENCE
description: THERE was a time when, inspired by an old woodcut of a pilgrim striding triumphantly home from the autumn woods with a Thanksgiving Day turkey over one shoulder and his fowling piece over the other, I longed to do the same.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ''ENNIALS'' This has been a big New York year for ''ennials,'' the centennial anniversaries of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Metropolitan Opera, the bicentennial anniversaries of the American peace treaty with Great Britain, the British evacuation of New York City and the birth of the statesman and author Washington Irving.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: President Reagan meets today with Aristides Pereira, president of the Cape Verde Islands, near Senegal. He also will swear in Katherine Ortega as Treasurer of the United States, attend a ceremony marking the start of Minority Business Week, and attend a Heritage Foundation dinner.

title: LIKE MOTHER, LIKE DAUGHTER
description: The days of serious mother- daughter dresses are long gone. Neither generation looked right in them, anyway. The modern versions seen on city streets these days, while not always identical in style, are nonetheless somehow related in feeling because, of course, the wearers are related and they want the world to know this.

title: VideoUnitsStolen From Art Center
description: Video equipment valued at nearly $20,000 was stolen from the Women's Inter Art Center at 549 West 52d Street early Saturday morning, after thieves broke through two concrete walls.

title: COURT LETS STAND CURB ON S.E.C.
description: In a decision that is expected to impede investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Federal court has refused to review two rulings that impose stringent new procedures for the commission to follow before questioning witnesses.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Oct. 3, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cabby's Atonement

title: SUSPECT IN BANKERS' KILLINGS FOUND DEAD ON TEXAS FARM
description: A man wanted in the slayings of two Minnesota bankers was found shot to death late tonight at a farm in northwestern Texas when his son, also sought in the killings, led police to his body, the authorities said.

title: RECOVERED ALCOHOLICS' CHILDREN
description: EILEEN, who is 16 years old, thought her problems were over when her mother, an alcoholic, stopped drinking. ''But our family was still a mess,'' she related. ''All the resentments, anger and fears continued because the only thing that had changed was that my mother was sober. We three kids needed help in straightening out our lives.''

title: ; PROTECTING INDIVIDUALS FROM COMPUTER INTRUSION
description: To the Editor:

title: A U.S. TURNING POINT?
description: News Analysis

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Cross Bronx Shakes

title: FOR '45 SCIENTISTS, A REVISITING OF SITE OF FIRST ATOMIC BLAST
description: Just before 5:30 A.M. on July 16, 1945, Joe McKibben, a physicist, flipped the last of a series of switches that would detonate the first atomic bomb.

title: COLBERT'S 67 WINS TEXAS OPEN BY 5
description: Jim Colbert compiled a three-under-par 67, set another season scoring record and posted his second victory of the year today, a five-stroke triumph in the Texas Open golf tournament.

title: MRS. GANDHI UNDERTAKES AN ACTIVE ROLE ON THE WORLD STAGE
description: With the possible exception of President Reagan, who spoke here last Monday, the world leader most conspicuous in last week's General Assembly debate was Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ADT has named Anthony J. Grosso vice president of national accounts.

title: Man Held in Capital After Heroin Kills 2
description: The police said a man arrested in connection with a stabbing death today will be questioned about a batch of heroin that left two people dead and caused 18 others to fall ill from overdoses in a one-block area.

title: CONGRESS MOVING ON MAJOR CHANGES IN CRIMINAL LAW
description: After more than a decade of delay in efforts to amend key aspects of Federal criminal law, Congress is working toward passing several measures that could have a major effect on the way defendants are prosecuted and sentenced in the Federal courts.

title: PITCHERS STAND OUT AS BASEBALL ASSEMBLES STATISTICS
description: The 1983 baseball regular season, which ended yesterday, was studded with the sort of statistical achievements and oddities that delight the connoisseurs of the sport and eventually become the answers to trivia questions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1983
description: The Economy Capital outlays for new plants are lagging, while consumer spending has been surging. But many economists believe that the decline in spending by businesses has ended and that substantial growth will begin soon. (Page D1.)

title: KUENN IS DISMISSED FROM BREWER POST
description: Harvey Kuenn, who last year led the Milwaukee Brewers to their only American League pennant, will not return to manage them and General Manager Harry Dalton has reached an agreement with Rene Lachemann to take over the club next season, United Press International reported today.

title: SET ROLE ON KNICKS FOR RAY WILLIAMS
description: Ray Williams recalled a conversation he had last season with Kenny Dennard while they rested on the Kansas City Kings' bench:

title: Debra Zalbe Is Bride Of Jeffrey M. Bochner
description: Debra Ceil Zalbe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Zalbe of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Marshall Bochner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Bochner of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Ben Zion Bokser, assisted by Cantor Erno Grosz, performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Holy Family Stuns St. Anthony's, 7-0
description: Tommy Malone scored on a 15-yard pass from Ed Palermo to help give Holy Family a 7-0 upset victory over St. Anthony's of Smithtown, L.I., yesterday in a Catholic High Schools Football League game at Huntington, L.I. Holy Family (1-1) forced four turnovers by St. Anthony's (1-1).

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: New York Jets vs. Buffalo Bills , at Orchard Park, N.Y. The Jets entered the weekend last in the National Football League in stopping the rush, and the Bills have one of the league's best runners, Joe Cribbs.

title: CITY SPEEDING ITS SUBWAY REPAIRS
description: The New York City Transit Authority - with the help of three French engineers, a handful of retired track supervisors and the guidance of its acting president - has in the last month accelerated its effort to get the city's subways rolling on time.

title: WHEELCHAIR VOUCHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE-BUILT CRECHE IS NO THREAT TO LIBERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Banks Review C.D. Impact The first results of the deregulation of interest rates on bank

title: 2 RESTAURATEURS IN CHELSEA REALIZE A 24-TABLE DREAM
description: Opening night was a blur of handshakes and congratulations. Bunches of flowers arrived at the side door all day long until even the cigarette machine downstairs wore a palm tree and a basket of wildflowers.

title: No Headline
description: CORRECTIONS

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Ginnie Mae Futures To Change
description: NEXT Friday will mark the eighth anniversary of Ginnie Mae futures, a date many hedgers and traders would like to forget. The main reason: this pioneer financial contract encouraged excessive deliveries of the underlying instruments at disadvantageous prices to the buyer.

title: ACTRESS AND EDUCATOR
description: Marguerite Shaw, an actress and former educator, died in the Lawrence Hospital here of a heart ailment Sept. 23. She was 66 years old.

title: CAPITAL SPENDING LAGGING
description: Two weeks ago at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, painted a rosy picture of the nation's economic prospects. With lots of hard work and a bit of luck, he told the annual Business Outlook Conference, there was a good chance for five years of solid expansion in the nation's economy.

title: Co-Tylenol Ruled Out As Cause of Man's Death
description: A coroner's report ruled out a Co-Tylenol cold tablet as the cause of a 34-year-old man's death, and the police rescinded their request today that pharmacies statewide remove the product from their shelves.

title: COLLEGES CUTTING THEIR ENROLLMENT
description: Manhattanville College has decided that smaller is beautiful.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: New Bankruptcy Judge Tackles Baldwin Filing

title: No Headline
description: Nuclear Doldrums at Three Mile Island Four and a half years after the American nuclear industry's worst accident, not much seems to have changed at Three Mile Island. Unit 2, the site of the mishap, has not been cleaned up, and the undamaged Unit 1 is still not back in action. Another thing that hasn't changed is top management. Essentially the same team responsible for the $1- billion accident remains in charge.

title: COWBOYS RALLY AGAIN FOR 37-24 VICTORY
description: Ron Fellows scored on a 58-yard interception return for the go-ahead touchdown, and Tony Dorsett rushed for 141 yards as the unbeaten Dallas Cowboys again rallied from a 24-13 halftime deficit for a 37-24 victory today over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: A VARIED AGENDA FOR JUSTICES
description: During its new term beginning Monday, the Supreme Court will take its closest look in years at antitrust law. The Reagan Administration, in three separate cases, is trying to persuade the Justices to abandon decades-old precedents and adopt new approaches to applying the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: GEMAYAL ASSERTS DRUSE CHIEF SEEKS TO SPLIT LEBANON
description: President Amin Gemayel's Government accused the leader of the Druse today of trying to partition the country by setting up a local administration in Druse- controlled areas and by appealing to soldiers of the Lebanese Army not to carry out orders.

title: L. L. BEAN'S HOMETOWN IS WARY OF MCDONALD'S
description: If Ronald McDonald wore a mackinaw and hip boots, and conducted business in a duck blind instead of under golden arches, he would be at home in this old town of 6,000 people.

title: Jane D. Hartley, Executive, Weds
description: Jane Dorothy Hartley, daughter of Mrs. James E. Hartley and the late Mr. Hartley of Waterbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Ralph Lewis Schlosstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Schlosstein of Philadelphia. The Rev. Joaquin Bazan performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Finding the Holes

title: RIGHTS BODY URGES JAPANESE TO END DEATH PENALTY
description: The retrials of three Japanese prisoners sentenced to death for murder have raised public concern in Japan that innocent people may be executed, according to Amnesty International.

title: 'NEW BABYLON,' SILENT RUSSIAN CLASSIC
description: ONE of the major treats of the current New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center will be the one-time-only screening tonight of that classic of Soviet silent cinema, Grigory Kozintsev and Leonid Trauberg's ''New Babylon'' (1929). The film is as much a celebration of Expressionistic cinema, of which it is a delirious example, as it is of the Paris Commune of 1873, which is its subject.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: A legal pass receiver, while in the air and out of bounds in a National Football League game, bats the ball back into the playing field, where it is caught by a teammate. Is this a completion?

title: 9 AREAS IN STATE GET FEDERAL DEVELOPMENT GRANTS
description: Nine cities and counties in New York State have been awarded a total of more than $12 million in urban development grants by the Federal Government, including $5.5 million for a Buffalo-area food-processing plant that should create 600 jobs in one of the most economically depressed regions of the state.

title: Worker's Compensation Due For Officer Who Killed Boy, 5
description: A former police officer who mistakenly shot and killed a 5-year-old boy has received $35,000 in worker's compensation for psychological damage caused by the shooting, it was reported today.

title: JAZ: ORNETTE COLMAN HOME AGAIN
description: Ornette Coleman made a fascinating homecoming this weekend. Having left the city of his birth in the early 1950's as an unknown, the jazz giant returned to inaugurate a phantasmagorically ambitious avant-garde performing- arts center, Caravan of Dreams, which now sits serenely in the center of what aparently remains one of the most artistically conservative cities in Texas.

title: LUTHER STANDS OUT IN REPLACING FOUTS
description: There was no pleasure all those years in being the second quarterback for the San Diego Chargers behind Dan Fouts, acclaimed by many as pro football's finest passer. ''It's been very, very frustrating,'' Ed Luther said. ''You just take it day by day, year by year.''

title: Submarine Commissioned
description: The nuclear-powered submarine U.S.S. Portsmouth was commissioned Saturday in ceremonies at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard as a small group of demonstrators marched in the rain outside the main gate. The police said the protesters were orderly and no arrests were reported.

title: SCHMIDT CRAVES CALM AS PHILLIES MOVE TO PLAYOFFS
description: THESE are some of the best times of Mike Schmidt's baseball life but also, he says, the most perplexing. Schmidt has made this promise to himself for the National League championship series: ''I'm going to try and keep my brain from thinking. To draw back, and if at all possible I'm going to relax and enjoy myself and leave myself alone.''

title: Lois Agency Creates Knoware Campaign
description: As you might have guessed, George Lois and his Lois Pitts Gershon agency are behind that new company called Knoware Inc., that will soon begin selling instructional disks for personal computers that will eliminate complicated directions.

title: SOVIET DROPS ITS PROTEST ON CHESS
description: The Soviet Chess Federation expressed regret today over its clash last summer with the International Chess Federation and announced it was withdrawing its protest over the sites of the matches. The protest led to a Soviet boycott of the two semifinal matches in the world championships.

title: Debt Issues
description: * First Amarillo Bancorp. announced a public offering of $15 million of 10 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2008, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: FEW BRIGHT SPOTS AMID METS' FUTILITY
description: It was a season that saw the Mets lose two managers, their leading home-run hitter, their No. 1 catcher, their best starting pitcher and their best relief pitcher from 1982.

title: No Headline
description: Education Of 2 Coaches

title: CONVENTION SITE FEARED TO HAVE FURTHER DELAYS
description: The head of the state's Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that lagging production of a key structural element of New York City's Convention Center might raise construction costs above $500 million and delay the center's completion beyond the summer of 1986.

title: DOUBTS IN MOSCOW ON BRITON'S DEATH
description: Shortly before 9 A.M. on June 17, Dennis G. Skinner, a 54-year-old British banker, was found dead after a fall to the sidewalk from his 12th-story apartment on Moscow's Leninsky Prospekt.

title: U.S. Judge Stays Execution
description: A Federal district judge granted a stay of execution Saturday for Wayne Felde less than 60 hours before he was to die in the electric chair at the Angola State Penitentiary. Mr. Felde was convicted in 1980 of murdering a Shreveport police officer, Thomas Glen Tompkins. Judge Tom Stagg said he granted the stay mainly because of the absence of court transcripts on the jury selection process used in the trial. The Louisiana Supreme Court refused Friday to stop the execution, scheduled for Tuesday.

title: All Along First By Neck in France
description: All Along, ridden by Walter Swinburn, won Europe's richest thoroughbred horse race, the $312,000 Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe, today. The French filly burst through the middle at the end of the backstretch and won by a neck.

title: Mt. St. Helens Dome Grows
description: The huge dome of crusty lava in the crater of Mount St. Helens in southwest Washington is inflating at a rapidly increasing rate and new material could be released in 5 to 10 days, the United States Geological Survey and the University of Washington geophysics department said Saturday night.

title: TV: VISITS WITH THE LEGENDS OF NEGERO BASEBALL LEAGUES
description: THE old Negro baseball leagues were born in the early 1920's and died in the late 1940's. They were critical, as opposed to financial, successes, and if they produced nothing else, they produced legends: of men who were mightier than Babe Ruth, faster than Ty Cobb and better at throwing a baseball than Bob Feller. Whether they were really that good is incidental. But it is satisfying to think that once there were giants in the land.

title: 6 Die as Protests Flare In Pakistan Province
description: At least six people were killed in Sind Province today as anti-Government demonstrators protested a second round of local council elections, the police and witnesses said.

title: TV: 'ALICE IN WONDERLAND' AND NEW CBS SERIES
description: WITH considerable inventiveness and more than a little trimming, public television's Great Performances series has transformed a disastrous stage production of ''Alice in Wonderland'' into a production of impressive charm. The clever adaptation, now running only 90 minutes, can be seen on WNET/13 tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Joni Blinderman Weds M. H. Levine
description: Joni Sue Blinderman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Blinderman of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael H. Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Levine of Port Washington, L.I. Rabbi Albert Levine performed the ceremony at the Berlin Chapel at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass.

title: Uganda Is Said to Free Hundreds of Prisoners
description: Hundreds of Ugandan prisoners and detainees have been freed, apparently in a move linked to the country's 21st independence anniversary next Sunday, witnesses said today.

title: MORRISON LAUDS S. CAROLINA ENTHUSIASM
description: Joe Morrison is at it again, rebuilding another football team that has had lean years recently. This time the former Giants' running back is putting life into South Carolina. Last Saturday night, the Gamecocks upset Southern Cal, 38-14.

title: Former Chad Rebel Tells Of Big Libyan Force
description: About 3,000 heavily armed Libyan soldiers are stationed in rebel-held Faya-Largeau, a rebel who deserted to Chadian Government forces has said.

title: BRIEFING
description: Painting the Lily

title: China Said to Execute 5 Tibetans for Crimes
description: Chinese authorities have executed five Tibetans for ''major crimes,'' the Nepalese Consul General said today in Lhasa, capital of the Tibetan autonomous region.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Levine Gets Airline

title: NEW JETS MORE FLAMBOYANT
description: IN only one week, Mark Gastineau managed to create football-wide incidents by dancing

title: The Editorial Notebook; Even Up the Odds at the Court
description: Besides providing the last word on justice, the Supreme Court usually serves up the best show in Washington. Oral argument before the Court may occasionally lapse into farce, but for the most part it's great theater. The stakes are always high and lawyers strive mightily.

title: SAKHAROV'S WIFE SUES A HISTORIAN
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, has filed suit against a Soviet historian who published an account of the Sakharovs' private lives, including assertions that Miss Bonner was the force behind Mr. Sakharov's ''downfall.''

title: Former Y. & R. Brands Reassigned by P. & G.
description: Wasting no time, Procter & Gamble has quickly reassigned the brands with estimated $60 million in total billings that Young & Rubicam's international operation resigned Sept. 22. The winners are all existing Procter agencies with international capability.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 3, Is Shot in Dispute
description: A 3-year-old boy was shot in the groin by a man who fired several shots in a dispute on a Brooklyn street, the police said yesterday.

title: BATTLE INTENSIFYING OVER EXPLICIT SEX ON CABLE TV
description: A nationwide battle is taking shape over sexually explicit programs on cable television.

title: JesseJacksonJoins New Voter Drive
description: A three-day drive by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to register potential black voters in New York City will begin this morning in Brooklyn, a group of black leaders announced yesterday.

title: EARNING GAP IS NARROWING SLIGHTLY FOR WOMEN
description: The difference in earnings for women and men has narrowed slightly, according to new data from the Census Bureau, but women working year-round at full-time jobs still earn only 62 percent of what men make.

title: APPLYING TO MANILA THE LESSON OF TEHERAN
description: As former Ambassador to both the Philippines and Iran, I am struck by the parallels between the American dilemma in Manila today and our problems in Teheran in 1978. We must not miss the opportunity in the Philippines, as we did in Iran, to assist in the emergence of a new, democratic government.

title: No Headline
description: A Iof3onTracks

title: A BANKRUPT SUCCESS
description: The Reagan policy for dealing with the Soviet Union - bristling words and an all- out arms race - is flourishing as never before. The Administration has succeeded in using the Korean airliner incident to intensify anti- Soviet rhetoric and win Congressional approval of an array of new weapons.

title: No Headline
description: Pepperell Net Jumps 49.1% West Point-Pepperell Inc.,

title: NO U.S. BAR SEEN TO LTV STEEL PLAN
description: Economic Analysis

title: A VIEW FROM MANAGUA
description: The recent burst of military activity by the so-called ''contras'' operating out of Honduras against the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua was caused by orders from the Central Intelligence Agency to ''do or die,'' The Washington Post has reported.

title: Shale-Oil Group Abandons Efforts
description: A group of large oil companies has disbanded an organization it created last spring to produce oil from shale, according to the Mobil Corporation, the main sponsor.

title: No Headline
description: SAMUEL L. WELT

title: THE LEBANESE ARMY'S BATTLE: REASON TO BE PROUD
description: News Analysis

title: GETTING THE FACTS STRAIGHT ON THE SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Chocoholics' Paradise

title: ISRAELI PARLIAMENT TO VOTE ON CABINET THIS WEEK
description: Five parties of the coalition Government decided today to present a narrow coalition to Parliament this week for a vote of confidence after failing in talks with the opposition Labor Party to set up a broad government of national unity.

title: DESPITE STRIKE, CONTINENTAL ASSERTS STRENGTH
description: Continental Air Lines canceled 14 flights today, a day after pilots and flight attendants walked off their jobs, but a company official said the carrier was ''stronger than ever.''

title: No Headline
description: Laurie Abrams Marries

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Age Wins Out

title: PLAYWRIGHTS MUST OFTEN DEFER ROYALTIES TO GET PLAYS ON STAGE
description: '' 'Night, Mother'' has won critical acclaim and a Pultizer Prize. It has run on Broadway for six months. Yet in all but five or six weeks, Marsha Norman, who wrote the drama, has received only half her royalties. The money she forgoes is the margin that keeps her play playing.

title: E. Donald Sterner, 89; Held Jersey State Posts
description: E. Donald Sterner, a lumber company president who served as a New Jersey state senator and became the state's first Highway Commissioner, died Friday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune City. He was 89 years old and lived in Avon.

title: EVEN SECOND PLACE ELUDES YANKEES
description: In a season in which they expected to regain the glamour and reap the rewards of a winner, the Yankees sank in a sea of pine tar.

title: Ailing Mormon Leaders Attend Conference
description: The intense faith that brought Mormon pioneers to the Salt Lake Valley is needed today in a world ''where sacred things are mocked,'' a church leader said at the faith's 153d Semiannual General Conference today.

title: No Headline
description: THE first shoe dropped yesterday, as expected. It fell on Frank Howard, a large and decent man, who took the blow and smiled and said: ''It will all work out.''

title: Dianne M. Duthie Marries
description: Dianne Marie Duthie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Hugh Duthie of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony Albert Falzarano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Falzarano of Bloomfield, N.J. The Rev. William Degnan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Newark. The bride is an assistant manager in the marketing department of Citibank in New York. Mr. Falzarano is president of the Cobblestone Real Estate Company in Boston.

title: Chinese Oil Output Up
description: Chinese oil output in the first nine months of 1983 rose 3.3 percent from the 1982 period, to 575 million barrels, according to the New China News Agency.

title: Diane C. Shulklapper Wed To Dr. Richard Rubenstein
description: Diane Carol Shulklapper, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Shulklapper of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Michael Rubenstein, son of Dr. Nathan Rubenstein of Pompton Plains, N.J., and the late Muriel Rubenstein. Rabbi Philip Weinberger performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: RAIN AND FLOODS SWEEPING ARIZONA
description: Flood waters up to eight feet deep surged through hundreds of homes in the southern Arizona desert today, leaving seven people dead and two missing, closing roads and bridges, and forcing thousands of people to evacuate.

title: Devils Are Strong In Young Talent
description: THE Devils are putting so much emphasis on youth that it is enough to make a handful of their players over the age of 25 feel old.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Search for a Coach

title: LONG COAST MURDER TRIAL ENDING
description: It took the defense 12 1/2 days to present its closing arguments in the long trial of Angelo Buono, who is charged in what the police call the hillside stranglings.

title: Kaiser Accepts Frates Bid
description: The board of the Kaiser Steel Corporation has accepted an acquisition proposal by an investor group led by J. A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., subject to a definitive agreement.

title: KN Rejects Mesa's Bid
description: The board of KN Energy Inc., an oil and natural gas producer, has rejected an acquisition proposal by the Mesa Petroleum Company, which would have been carried out by an exchange of shares.

title: TIN CAN BOTTLES CHALLENGERS
description: The venerable tin can, standard for food packaging since the beginning of the century, may be on its way out.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1983 International
description: Lebanon's Druse leader was accused by President Amin Gemayel's Government of trying to partition the country by setting up a local administration in Druse-controlled areas. The Druse chieftain, Walid Jumblat, was also accused of appealing to Lebanese Army soldiers not to carry out orders. In response, Mr. Jumblat said that his decision to set up a local administration was taken to provide basic public services to people living in war-shattered areas under his control and that he would welcome any assistance the central Government could provide. (Page A1, Column 6.) Britain's Labor Party elected Neil Kinnock, a 41-year-old Welshman, who has never held a ministerial office, to succeed Michael Foot as its leader. Mr. Kinnock, the youngest leader in Labor history, won more than two-thirds of the votes by members of Parliament, trade unions and local party organizations. He pledged to ''lift the yoke of Thatcherism.'' Roy Hammersley, somewhat to the right of Mr. Kinnock, finished second, and defeated Michael Meacher, who is on the left, for the job of deputy leader. (A1:4.)

title: No Headline
description: The Final Standings National League YESTERDAY'S GAMES Mets 1, Montreal 0 (1st). Mets 5, Montreal 4 (2d). Atlanta 4, San Diego 3.

title: JORDANIANS MAY REACH OUT TO ARAFAT AGAIN
description: Jordan is prepared to hold new discussions with Yasir Arafat to work out a common approach to efforts toward a Middle East settlement, but only under certain conditions, according to Arab and Western diplomats.

title: Barbara Berg of NBC Weds Louis Goldman
description: Barbara Marcia Berg, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving Berg of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Louis B. Goldman, son of Mrs. Jack S. Goldman of Glencoe, Ill., and the late Mr. Goldman. Rabbi Robert Schreibman performed the ceremony at the Northmoor Country Club in Highland Park, Ill.

title: FRENCH PARLEY ASSAILS ATTACKS ON PRESS FREEDOMS
description: Representatives of independent news outlets from all parts of the world today condemned attacks on press freedom by many third world and Communist governments and by the United Nations Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization.

title: RISES SLOW FOR WORLD STOCKS
description: After six months of rapid advances, the rate of increase in equity prices on major stock exchanges around the world slowed in the third quarter.

title: TAN ZHENLIN IS DEAD IN CHINA, HELD HIGH POSITIONS IN PARTY
description: Tan Zhenlin, a miner's son who rose to high office in China and was among prominent figures purged in the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, died of lung cancer Friday, the official New China News Agency said today. He was 81 years old.

title: BRITISH LABORITES PICK WELSHMAN, AGED 41, AS YOUNGEST LEADER EVER
description: Neil Kinnock, a 41-year-old Welshman who has never held ministerial office, was chosen tonight to lead the Labor Party by the party's annual conference.

title: Bank of Boston Merger
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation has agreed to acquire Colonial Bancorp, a bank holding company based in Connecticut, for $75 million, Bank of Boston said Friday.

title: N.A.S.L. SURVIVAL AT STAKE
description: Survival is the issue that hangs over the North American Soccer League like a heavy cloud despite the success of Soccer Bowl-83 Saturday night, which sold all 60,051 tickets for the Tulsa Roughnecks' 2-0 victory over the Toronto Blizzard.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Most small colleges and a lot of big ones now have a choice.

title: Article 205300 -- No Title
description: In Japanese society, which is strongly influenced by tradition, Seiji Tsutsumi, a businessman and art patron, has made his mark as an untroubled nonconformist: While heading the billion-dollar Seibu business conglomerate, he also pursues a second career as a poet, novelist and a leading promoter of contemporary art.

title: STEPHEN F. LEO
description: Stephen Francis Leo, the first public relations director of the Air Force and a former reporter for the Guy Gannett newspapers in Maine, died of a heart attack Thursday in the Regional Memorial Hospital of Brunswick. He was 74 years old.

title: MCENROE CLINCHES U.S. CUP VICTORY
description: John McEnroe survived a few anxious moments today before defeating Matt Doyle and clinching a United States victory over Ireland in the Davis Cup.

title: ENERGY UPHEAVAL: QUESTIONS ABOUT OPEC, PAST AND FUTURE
description: After a draining 12 days of talks here last March, the members of OPEC agreed to put a ceiling on their oil production and to cut their oil prices for the first time in the group's 23-year history.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Bowmar Debt Paid, Its Chief Moves On

title: Albanian Communist Leader Questions Nonaligned Status
description: Enver Hoxha of Albania, the world's longest- serving Communist Party chief, lashed out at the United States, the Soviet Union and nations espousing nonalignment at a reception to celebrate his 75th birthday, the Albanian press agency said today.

title: REDSKINS TOP RAIDERS WITH 0:33 LEFT
description: It was the kind of football game in which a 99- yard touchdown pass was just another play, and it was finally won by the Washington Redskins, perhaps only because they made one more timely play than the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: MILLIONAIRE STATUS PLAGUES DAWKINS
description: When Darryl Dawkins left high school in 1975, everything added up. On one side of the ledger was Ivy Lane, better known as The Projects, where Dawkins spent his childhood with four siblings and his mother. On the other side were the Philadelphia 76ers, a team that believed the 6-foot-11-inch, 260-pounder was worth a million dollars.

title: RANGER TRADE PRODUCES BENEFITS
description: There was a sharp outcry from Ranger fans when the trade with Detroit was announced last June. Ed Mio, Ron Duguay and Eddie Johnstone were three of the team's most popular players. And sentiment aside, Mio had played a crucial role in keeping the Rangers alive in the playoffs for two successive seasons.

title: GIANTS BEATEN, 41-34, AFTER COMBACK FAILS
description: The San Diego Chargers, who seemed to be frittering away a game they had wrapped up, finally beat the Giants, 41-34, today on Chuck Muncie's 34-yard touchdown run with 4 minutes 32 seconds remaining.

title: MADRID WEEK IN NEW YORK CELEBRATES THE ARTS AND FOOD
description: There will be a touch of Madrid in New York this week when the city becomes host to a series of cultural events to celebrate its shared heritage with Spain.

title: Vietnam Says 97,000 Have Been Resettled
description: The Vietnamese authorities have resettled 97,000 people from the cities and densely populated plains in so-called new economic zones over the past nine months, the state-run Vietnam News Agency said.

title: LoriBeth Rubin Wed To Lewis M. Epstein
description: LoriBeth Rubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Rubin of Paramus, N.J., and Hemlock Farms, Pa., was married yesterday to Lewis M. Epstein, son of Mrs. Esther Epstein of Brooklyn and the late Benjamin Epstein. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: The Final Leaders

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on the vote by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s general board to endorse Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination contained incorrect vote totals in some editions. Unions representing 527,989 members voted not to endorse any candidate, and unions representing 330,701 members abstained from voting.

title: Waltrip Triumphs In Grand National
description: Darrell Waltrip won the 400-lap Nascar Grand National race at North Wilkesboro Speedway today.

title: CITY DRIVE ON ILLICIT TENANTS HAS YET TO BEAR FRUIT
description: Nearly six months after Mayor Koch declared that tenants who did not pay city income taxes would be denied the protection of rent control and rent stabilization, the new policy has yet to produce substantial results, according to landlords, real-estate lawyers and officials of the city government and the courts.

title: CHILDREN AND STRESS: A SEARCH FOR CAUSES
description: A study of the children of Martha's Vineyard is providing new knowledge about the effects of stress on American families and the origins of psychiatric disorders in children.

title: CITY OPERA: 'PECHEURS DE PERLES'
description: THE New York City Opera's Saturday afternoon performance of Bizet's ''Les P^echeurs de Perles'' at the New York State Theater was a mixed bag. To begin with, it's an uneven opera, combining some of Bizet's most inspired music with long passages of treacly notespinning, all set to a silly libretto by Michel Carre and E. Corman.

title: CONGRESS RESTORING ARTS AND HUMANITIES MONEY
description: Congress is expected to finish work this week on a bill to restore Federal money for the arts and humanities to the level that prevailed before the Reagan Administration took office in 1981 and cut it sharply.

title: Advertising; D'Arcy's Electricity Account
description: In shopping malls in 20 markets scattered about the country, selected consumers these days are being asked about the communications quality and convincing nature of four rough commercials that D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, New York, has prepared for the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group of 200 investor- owned electric utilities.

title: PURCHASERS' INDEX SLIPS
description: The economy continued to grow in September, although at a slower rate than in July and August, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report yesterday. Employment and industrial production continued to rise, but the slight decline in inventories indicated that purchasing managers are reluctant to add to stocks.

title: Afghan Radio ReportsDeath of a British Spy
description: Afghanistan said today that a British spy was killed on its territory in a shootout between security forces and a band of smugglers.

title: LIGHT LIST OF BOND ISSUES THIS WEEK
description: The supply of new fixed-rate notes or bonds appears very light in both the Treasury and corporate markets this week, with no auctions planned by the Treasury and only one corporate issue, of $35 million.

title: Ann Holland Married To a Fellow Geologist
description: Ann Elizabeth Holland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Holland of Massapequa, L.I., was married yesterday to Keith Thompson Conrad, son of Mr. and Mrs. Basil W. Conrad of Versailles, N.Y. The Rev. Charles P. Calcagni, minister of the Congregational Church of Manhasset, L.I., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's maternal grandmother, Mrs. Roy C. Olson, at Sands Light, Sands Point, L.I.

title: HOWARD LET GO AS METS' MANAGER
description: After 116 games as ''interim manager,'' Frank Howard was praised yesterday by the Mets but was not rehired.

title: SOME ANALYSTS SEE NEED FOR FED REIN
description: While traders are puzzled about how much the Federal Reserve has adjusted its policy recently, some investors and economists are debating whether a change in Fed policy is appropriate.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Stadium Rises

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PEOPLE MOSTLY: NEW YORK IN PHOTOGRAPHS 1900-1950 By Benjamin Blom. New York: Amaryllis Press. 160 pp. Illustrated. $19.95 until Dec. 31; $25 thereafter.

title: FARMERS IN THE NOOSE
description: Thanks to misguided Reagan Administration policies, the continuing worldwide recession and drought, American agriculture is strangling from a combination of low prices and a meager harvest. It seems as if the Administration's goal is to lower food production by reducing agricultural prices, thereby allowing thousands of farmers to go broke. This is a prescription that offends reason and morality.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.46

title: CUOMO EXPECTED TO PICK M.T.A. CHIEF THIS WEEK
description: Governor Cuomo will announce his choice for chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ''by midweek,'' according to senior officials in his administration.

title: SPEAKES'S CONTROL IN JOB APPEARS TO BE ENHANCED
description: At a recent briefing in his office, Larry Speakes startled reporters by discussing ''on background'' the overnight fighting in Beirut and President Reagan's dealings with Congress over Lebanon.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Turkish Bank Opening First American Branch

title: A Private Prize
description: The America's Cup has arrived at its new home in Perth, but the Australian public may not see much of it.

title: GULF NUCLEAR reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Colt Industries Gets A Chief Executive

title: Envoy Seeks Allied Support For Central America Policies
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America began a European tour today to try to win greater support from America's European allies for United States policy in Central America.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 20
STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW YORK AND UNION REACH PACT ON MEDICAL FACULTY INCOME LIMIT
description: An agreement has been reached to limit the outside income of physicians and dentists on the faculties of medical and dental schools run by New York State, officials said yesterday.

title: ; SUBVERSION OF THE LAW IS LEGAL SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday in uneventful trading.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Dodgers vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Los Angeles. First game of the three-of-five National League championship series, 8:20 P.M. John Denny of the Phillies (19-6) has won more games than any other pitcher in the league and is a top candidate for the Cy Young Award.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Benoit First

title: AMERICA'S COMMUNISTS
description: ''SEEING RED,'' an affectionate documentary by Julia Reichert and James Klein about the history of American Communism, works best on the level of anecdote. The film makers interview a number of longtime radicals who describe why and how they first joined the Communist Party, how they were affected by the 1956 revelations about Stalinism and what their lives and politics have subsequently been like. The material is presented fondly and more or less uncritically, even on several occasions when the interviewees' evident rationalizations would seem to call for closer questioning.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Louis A. Rice, a Former Dean At Fairleigh Dickinson U., 88
description: Louis A. Rice, former dean of the Teaneck, N.J., campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University, died Friday in a convalescent home in Wayne, N.J. He was 88 years old and had lived in Morristown, N.J.

title: Charlotte Curtis A Night at The Buckleys
description: ROSALYN TURECK played the Goldberg Variations at Mr. and Mrs. William F. Buckley Jr.'s house in Connecticut the other night. She came a day early to reacquaint herself with their B"osendorfer piano. The day of the performance, she practiced in the morning, the afternoon and into the evening while the host went sailing and the hostess repotted her begonias. She played so continuously another houseguest took to roaming the property with a Walkman plugged into his ears.

title: Clabir Extends Offer for HMW
description: The Clabir Corporation said it was extending its offer and proration period for 1,050,000 common shares of HMW Industries at $43 a share until tomorrow.

title: ISRAELI SAYS U.N. 'FANS THE FLAMES' OF MIDDLE EAST CONFLICT
description: Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations, Yehuda Z. Blum, charged today that the organization, instead of promoting peace in the Middle East, has become an arena of ''violent rhetoric which has fanned the flames of Arab-Israel conflict.''

title: WORLD BANK TO SURVEY NEEDY
description: The World Bank, the biggest single source of money for debt-plagued countries of the third world, has begun a broad country-by-country analysis of their needs as a guide to increasing the bank's capital.

title: Loose Moose Alarms Maine Capital Police
description: Game wardens and police went on a wild moose chase across the city this morning, tracking down and tranquilizing a 500-pound bull moose that, to all appearances, had come calling on the Governor.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: FESTIVAL When it comes to film making, there are all sorts of leagues, from big-time Hollywood to low-budget independent, by way of films for teaching, for industry and for special purposes. This is the season for the independents, whose movies, starting today, will be unreeled at noon Mondays through Fridays in the auditorium of the Department of Cultural Affairs at 10 Columbus Circle in the white building on the south side of the circle.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR ARMS-BACKBONE OF NATO
description: Are American critics of Western strategy sufficiently sensitive to the real worries of their European allies when it comes to matters nuclear? Until recently, ''nuke-bashing'' was mainly the preserve of peace marchers and bishops. Regrettably, it is now turning into a cottage industry among even well- meaning and well-informed Americans who should know better.

title: STREET FIGHTING BREAKS OUT IN BEIRUT SUBURBS
description: Heavy street fighting erupted today between the Lebanese Army and unidentified gunmen in Beirut's southern suburbs in the worst breach of the tenuous week- old cease-fire.

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Debt Issues
description: * Britoil Inc. announced that it would offer $150 million of commercial paper notes guaranteed by Britoil P.L.C., through Lehman Commercial Paper Inc.

title: SALVADOR TERROR CONDEMNED BY U.S.
description: The State Department today condemned an upsurge of right-wing violence in El Salvador that it said was undermining efforts to promote democracy there.

title: SCOUTING
description: Nastase Umpires

title: FRENCH SAVANT, AGED 78, SUMS UP A SEESAW LIFE
description: At 78 years of age, Raymond Aron, the scholar and political analyst, has made a career out of being flagrantly honest and outrageously intelligent. As much as he is a model of reason, he is also a master of distance, the cold answer, the indulgent question not asked.

title: JUDGE PRESSLER GIVEN LIFE TENURE BY JERSEY SENATE
description: The New Jersey Senate tonight confirmed the reappointment of Judge Sylvia B. Pressler to the Superior Court following a nine- hour hearing on the judge's qualifications by the Senate Judiciary Committee and more than an hour of debate by the 40-member Senate.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Roebling Memorabilia

title: A DUTY OF FREEDOM
description: Freedom of the press, which is essential to the freedom of people to be informed and to influence their fate, is under mounting siege. A study by the International Press Institute showed that government controls and harassment increased substantially in most parts of the world last year.

title: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to July 30
description: b-After an extraordinary item of $3,000,000. c-Net loss

title: NEW PORT CHIEF FACING REVIEW ON BACKGROUND
description: New York City's Department of Investigation has begun a review, described as routine, of the background of the Commissioner of Ports and Terminals, including her role with a family- owned marine company that has a record of disputes with environmental agencies.

title: No Headline
description: British Banks Lower Rates LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)

title: MUSIC: JEAN NEWTON, SOLOIST
description: JEAN NEWTON is a harpsichordist who seems undecided as yet about the kind of career she would like to pursue. That, at least, was the impression she gave in her appearance at Goodman House last Tuesday night.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Crisis in Human Spare Parts
description: Barry Jacobs is a defrocked doctor from Reston, Va., who plans to broker human kidneys. He hopes $10,000 will persuade a donor to part with one. For a markup of $2,000 to $5,000, he would sell the organ to a patient needing a transplant to escape the tyranny of dialysis.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock splits in February of 1982 and 1983.

title: IS STEEL TURNING THE CORNER?
description: With the proposed merger of Republic Steel and the LTV Corporation, heavy layoffs at United States Steel and third-quarter losses predicted for nearly all the major producers, the industry has been even more turbulent than usual in the last few weeks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the first time in the history of the Congress and the executive branch that we have worked out jointly an arms control proposal in which we are truly united.'' - Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois. (A1:3.)

title: Article 208813 -- No Title
description: A gold trading company, whose chairman killed himself the day before he was scheduled to deliver financial records to investigators, filed for bankruptcy yesterday, reporting that between $55 million and $60 million in precious metals was missing from its vaults.

Results for both years include the results of IMM Rayburn Inc. which commenced business Nov. 18, 1981. Results for 1982 are restated to reflect the acquisition of International Moorings & Marine on Aug. 4, 1981, which is accounted for on a pooling-of- interests basis. description: The Center for the Study of Women in Society at the University of Oregon has received a $3.5 million bequest from the husband of the feminist and writer Jane Grant.

title: A $1.1 Million Insider Case
description: A Seattle accountant has been ordered by a Federal Court to give up $1.1 million in profits he realized by trading illegally on inside, or nonpublic, information about the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation's plans to buy the Santa Fe International Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commmission said today.

title: SAFETY RULES FOR 'BIG RIGS' IS THE OVERRIDING ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Meeting Highlights Print Ads
description: Regular adland convention-goers would not be surprised to hear that the 74th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers began today with presentations of case studies of successful advertising campaigns.

title: DELAY IN LAUNCHING OF ANTISATELLITE WEAPON
description: THE maiden flight of a new American missile for knocking out enemy satellites has been delayed and its new schedule is shrouded in secrecy. Military experts say the test flight, originally set for August, has been pushed back to October and perhaps even later.

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $310,587, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and $275,210, or 22 cents a share, for the 6 months.

description: THE ANATOMY OF POWER. By John Kenneth Galbraith. 206 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: TV: MOTHER-AND-DAUGHTER SECRETS
description: THERE is little or no significance at all in tonight's presentation, on CBS at 9, of ''Secrets of a Mother and Daughter'' other than the fact that the plot is so intent on being ''adult'' - at least as far as commercial television is concerned. The networks seem to be saying that if cable can get away with presenting more permissive material we will begin playing the same game, whatever the limitations imposed by the Federal Communications Commission.

AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
200 PROTEST AS ANOTHER FARM IS SOLD
description: Bernard Bates peaceably lost part of his farmland at a public sale here today.

title: TESTING BLOOD PRESSURE CAN RAISE IT
description: VIRTUALLY everyone's blood pressure jumps significantly because they automatically react with alarm as the doctor arrives at the bedside. Moreover, the phenomenon may lead to the misdiagnosis of hypertension and unnecessary treatment of it in many people, an Italian study says.

title: Hopes Dim for Finding Jet's Flight Recorders
description: United States Navy ships pressed their search today for two flight recorders from the South Korean airliner that was shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1, but officials acknowledged that their chances of success were dwindling each day.

title: BRIDGE
description: While Italy took a modest lead against France in one semifinal of the World Team Championship here Monday night, an Aces team including three New York experts built up a substantial lead against their American opponents in the other.

description: A Groundskeeper For All Seasons

title: Nicholas Delagi Dead at 80; Former Criminal Court Judge
description: Nicholas F. Delagi, a retired Criminal Court judge in New York City and a former assistant district attorney in the Bronx, died Friday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx. He was 80 years old and a lifelong resident of the Bronx.

title: ADVERTISING ;  Addendum
description: * McCall's magazine increasing its advertising rates 8 percent with the February issue.

title: BEHIND STRAW POLLS, DEMOCRACTIC PATTERNS CHANGE
description: Amid the current competition over straw polls and endorsements, some striking tactical patterns are emerging in the Democratic Presidential race. While the Mondale-Glenn battle for first place has drawn the most attention, the outcome of that fight may be influenced by the political offensives of Senators Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina and Alan F. Cranston of California.

title: U.S. Steel Talks
description: The United States Steel Corporation and the British Steel Corporation agreed to meet in Pittsburgh in the last week of October and in Pittsburgh or New York next month to discuss a proposed production linkup between the two companies, David Roderick, chairman of U.S. Steel, said.

title: KENNEDY TELLS FALWELL GROUP OF TOLERANCE
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, whose political views sometimes test Moral Majority's belief in forgiveness, came here today to break bread with the Rev. Jerry Falwell and preach a message of religious tolerance. Mr. Kennedy, who was accompanied here by his daughter Kara and his sister Jean Kennedy Smith, received a friendly welcome from the estimated 5,000 students and townspeople who filled the college gymnasium. They laughed heartily at his one-liners and interrupted his remarks 16 times with applause, including his praise of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The college provided tight security for the Senator and carefully screened the questions asked by selected students. Both Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Falwell, who ate at the home of the evangelist before the program, said they had received vicious mail from people opposed to the Kennedy appearance.

title: PARCELLS SAW GIANTS' LETDOWN COMING
description: Coach Bill Parcells said he realized last Wednesday, when the Giants had their first practice of the week, that the players were not concentrating. He said that lack of concentration carried over to the early part of Sunday's game against the San Diego Chargers and contributed to the Giants' 41-34 loss.

title: REAGAN APPROVES NEW ARMS OFFER FOR GENEVA TALKS
description: The Soviet Union published a point- by-point dismissal of the latest U.S. proposals on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe. Page A5.

title: Barnes Closings
description: Barnes Group Inc. said it plans to close two spring plants in Illinois, in Mattoon and Lombard, and a third in Pointe Claire, Quebec, by the end of March 1984.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Boeing Workers Accept Pact
description: Boeing Company machinists overwhelmingly approved a new three-year contract today that grants immediate raises of 3 to 8 percent and provides for improved health insurance and retirement benefits. The Greater Seattle District of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, with 18,000 members, approved the contract by a ratio of better than 3 to 1. A total of 26,085 Boeing workers around the nation were eligible to vote.

title: ATOMS IN SOLIDS SEEN DIRECTLY BY MICROSCOPE FOR FIRST TIME
description: BERKELEY, Calif. THE first microscope able to take directly interpretable pictures of atoms within solids has begun operating here, providing scientists with an extraordinary new window on the internal structure of matter.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,869. c-After loss from discontinued operations of $283,565. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $46,631 for the latest year and $551,165 for the earlier year. The year-ago periods were restated for comparative purposes.

title: C. Itoh & Co. Officials Visit U.S. Operations
description: C. Itoh & Company, a big Japanese trading company, named a new chairman and president this summer and they were in New York yesterday visiting their American interests.

title: 'PASSION,' AN ESSAY ON ART, BY JEAN-LUC GODARD
description: -LUC GODARD'S ''Passion,'' which will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M., is much more light-hearted - breezy even - than I'm afraid almost any description can make it sound. Using a small group of absolutely splendid actors, who follow their leader with extraordinary confidence, Mr. Godard has made a funny, fractured, totally self-absorbed movie, without a real story, about the making of a movie that has no real story.

title: Kingman Due to Go
description: It was no secret that the Mets were unhappy with Dave Kingman this season, and the slugger did not attempt to hide his displeasure with them. Frank Cashen , the general manager, said, ''I don't think so,'' when asked yesterday if Kingman would return.

title: JETS FIND A WAY TO SLOW THE BILLS
description: The Jets had established an alarming trend in their three games previous to tonight's match with the Buffalo Bills. In each game, they allowed an opposing running back to run for more than 100 yards. Curt Warner of Seattle gained 128. Tony Collins of New England gained 212. Eric Dickerson of the Rams gained 192.

title: EAST GERMANY'S MOVES AT BORDER CONFUSE BONN
description: In the last week, Erich Honecker, the East German leader, has demonstrated how simple it is to spread hope, confusion and political bickering in West Germany.

title: COURT LETS STAND GUN BAN IN ILLINOIS
description: The opening of the Supreme Court's new term today also marked the end of the legal road for some 700 appeals that the Justices decided not to hear. The 38-page ''order list'' that the Court issued this morning contained page after unbroken page of cases, most of which accumulated in the Court's three-month summer recess, that the Justices will never look at again.

title: Columbia Names Graduate Dean
description: Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. Gillian Lindt, a professor of religion, would take over as dean of the university's Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

COAST JUDGE ORDERS A TRIAL DELAY OF DELOREAN IN DRUG PLOT CHARGE
description: The start of the trial of John Z. DeLorean on charges of cocaine conspiracy, which was scheduled to begin here in Federal court Tuesday, was delayed today by the trial judge, who must set a new date.

title: R. Henry Norweb, 89; Former U.S. Diplomat
description: R. Henry Norweb, a United States diplomat who served during both world wars and held ambassadorial posts in Latin America, died of cancer Saturday in Cleveland. He was 89 years old.

title: CHAD'S WAR AND POVERTY EXTEND TO E. 43D ST.
description: Chad, struggling at home with a civil war and a drought, is having a hard time keeping its United Nations mission open and its diplomats fed.

title: BUSINESSES IN HARLEM GET ADVICE
description: Observing that members of minority groups were often excluded from social circles that enhanced access to business opportunities, Representative Charles B. Rangel yesterday called on minority businessmen to use special conferences on business development as their ''private country club.''

description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend declared in May 1983.

title: Canada Registers $500 Million Issue
description: Canada yesterday filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $500 million (United States) of bonds. The shelf registration would allow Canada to sell all or part of the $500 million at any time, with maturities to be set at the time of the sale.

title: Koch Appoints Youth Director
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named David R. Jones, his special adviser for race relations, to be executive director of the city's Youth Bureau. He replaces Thomas D. Hemans, who left the bureau last week.

title: Contractor Admits Navy Yard Fraud
description: A man charged with defrauding the nonprofit industrial corporation at the former Brooklyn Navy Yard pleaded guilty yesterday to 11 counts of bribery, forgery and grand larceny, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, said yesterday.

title: FUND-RAISER DISAVOWED
description: To the Editor:

title: DODGERS OUT TO EXTEND THEIR LONG DOMINANCE OVER PHILLIES
description: One of the more one-sided relationships in baseball will be tested again starting tonight, when the playoff for the National League pennant opens in Los Angeles between the Dodgers and their longtime patsies, the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: 'DHRUPAD,' MUSIC OF INDIA
description: MANI KAUL'S delicate ''Dhrupad'' explores an exquisite form of Indian classical music, dating from the 15th century and possessed of a mesmerizing intricacy. The film isn't so much a documentary as it is an exploration.

title: MORE FLIGHTS CANCELED IN STRIKE AT CONTINENTAL
description: Two days after its pilots and flight attendants went on strike to protest salary reductions, layoffs and revised work schedules, Continental Air Lines said that it was forced to cancel between 10 and 20 percent of its flights yesterday because of a lack of staff.

title: SEX IN AMERICA: CONSERVATIVE ATTITUDES PREVAIL
description: AMARKED decrease in casual or promiscuous sex has been occurring in the United States in the last several years, many experts believe.

title: Druse Chief Visits Athens
description: The leader of Lebanon's Druse Moslems, Walid Jumblat, arrived in Athens today on an unexpected visit for talks with the Greek Government. Greek officials said Mr. Jumblat arrived from Damascus and was escorted from the airport by Foreign Ministry officials.

title: MILAN SHOWINGS OPEN WITH A LEAN, SOFT LOOK
description: Erreuno fired the opening salvo Sunday afternoon, Gianfranco Ferre followed with a clean, spare, soft collection this morning and the spring-summer fashion season was off to a smashing start. Later, Krizia provided the obligatory dose of wit and whimsy and Giorgio Armani, the designer of the Erreuno collection, repeated many of his basic shapes in leather for Mario Valentino.

title: COMPANY MEN
description: While the Mets search for a new manager and the Yankees mull Billy Martin's future, there's a lesson to be learned. This baseball season has been a triumph for ''organization'' managers, as opposed to musical-chair managers.

title: A TURNING POINT FOR CARTER
description: The hole was in the right knee of

title: No Headline
description: How Poll Was Conducted

title: Metropolitan Life Buys Seafirst Unit
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said a newly formed subsdiary, the Metlife Capital Corporation, had acquired the Seafirst Leasing Corporation, a Seafirst Corporation unit. The acquisition, which consists primarily of leases and secured loans, totaled about $150 million.

title: TV: 13-PART HISTORY OF VIETNAM WAR ON PBS
description: THE Vietnam War swept over millions of people, altered history, and became the longest and most misunderstood war that Americans ever fought. The contradiction is that even as it was fought, it was studied, analyzed and reported, although when it was over it still seemed draped in ambiguities. ''Vietnam: A Television History'' does not clarify all the ambiguities, and in its way it even deepens them. The documentary series, a landmark in television journalism, tries to tell us what things were, not what we might have liked them to be.

title: GASTINEAU STARS AS JETS TRIUMPH
description: The Jets, as if feeding on controversy and adversity, spoiled the Buffalo Bills' ''upstate showcase'' tonight.

title: Salt River Bonds: Top Yield 9.54%
description: A $100 million bond issue of the Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.54 percent for 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2023 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The financing also included serial bonds with shorter maturities and yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 9.3 percent in 2006.

title: 4,500 JAPANESE REACH SAFETY AS A VOLCANO DEVASTATES ISLE
description: A volcano erupted today on a small Japanese island in the Pacific 100 miles south of here, forcing thousands of people to flee as one village was buried by lava and another destroyed by fire.

title: REAGAN POSTPONES PHILIPPINES VISIT AND 2 OTHER STOPS
description: The White House today announced the indefinite postponement of President Reagan's planned visits next month to the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand, citing the need for Mr. Reagan to be in Washington to deal with Congress on the budget and other issues.

title: STATUS OF ARMS NEGOTIATIONS These are the arms control negotiations that are now under way:
description: Strategic Arms Talks - The United States and the Soviet Union are discussing limitation of long-range nuclear delivery systems. The talks, which are a continuation of negotiations that go back to 1969, resumed in June 1982 and after a recess are to resume Thursday in Geneva.

title: VOGART CRAFTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
ARTIFICIAL GENE CAN BE TURNED ON OR OFF
description: SCIENTISTS have introduced into plant cells artificial genes that are turned on in the presence of light but not in darkness, according to a report yesterday.

title: GOLD ISSUES LEAD DECLINE IN STOCKS
description: Stock prices declined again yesterday with the precious-metal issues big losers as bullion prices plunged on international exchanges.

title: Benign Coach
description: College football coaches like to say something nice about the teams they beat, but it isn't always easy.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Safe Nuclear Reactors

title: RIPKEN AND MURRAY POWER THE ORIOLES
description: Cal Ripken Jr. tried to appear upset. ''I lost, but I'm filing a grievance,'' he complained. ''He didn't play the last few games. It should be pro-rated.'' Then Ripken relented and said: ''It's my own fault. I should've taken off the games where I struck out three times.''

title: WHY DO THE LEAVES TURN?
description: TODAY, as in all past autumns, millions upon millions of leaves are being transformed from green to a multitude of brilliant yellows, scarlets and russets. But a new interest has been awakened in the process; some researchers now see in it possible clues to aging, not only in plants but in animals - including man.

title: COMET MAY BE BRIGHTER THAN EXPERTS PREDICTED
description: TWO researchers have predict that Halley's Comet will be considerably brighter than had been expected when it circles the sun in 1986. Astronomers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., warn, however, that it will still be difficult to see, particularly for those in northern cities.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP IN AUGUST
description: Spending for new construction rose 2.4 percent in August, the fifth consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SCOUTING
description: Timely Victory

title: Hong Kong Bank Stake
description: Sun Hung Kai & Company said that Merrill Lynch & Company and Paribas of Paris had raised their stake in the company to a combined 51 percent, from 40 percent.

title: DEFENDANT GIVES VERSION OF HISPANIC BOY'S DEATH
description: Gerald T. Gerlock Jr. testified in his own defense today that he hit a 7-year-old Hispanic boy with his car accidentally.

title: Required Reading Stay, Oh Jets
description: Colloquy in the House on the possibility that the New York Jets football team might move next year from Shea Stadium in Queens to the Meadowlands in New Jersey, Sept. 30:

title: Shamir Bars Demand By 6 Potential Backers
description: Prime Minister-designate Yitzhak Shamir today rejected a demand by six members of Parliament that he compromise on the issue of West Bank settlements or lose their political support.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: 9 7/8% Maximum Yield For Puerto Rico Bonds

title: BROOKLYN VOTE DRIVE AIDED BY THE REV. JESSE JACKSON
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson swept through sections of Brooklyn yesterday, drawing enthusiastic crowds and chants of ''Run, Jesse, run,'' as he helped collect several hundred voter- registration forms in three and a half hours.

title: GAIL GODWIN TALKS OF HER FICTION AND HER MUSES
description: A hundred people braved a light rain the other evening to hear Gail Godwin read from her new book, ''Mr. Bedford and the Muses,'' at the Endicott Bookstore on the Upper West Side, an independently owned book haven where many authors are glad to show up because they find knowing readers there.

title: No Headline
description: Mating Game Promises, Promises

title: Security Link Is Denied In the Death of Briton
description: The Foreign Office indicated today that the death of a British banker in Moscow last June had no national security implications.

title: GERMAN-AMERICANS MARK MILESTONE
description: On Oct. 6, 1683, 13 families from Krefeld in the Rhineland landed here and were met by a German named Francis Daniel Pastorius, who helped them settle on a tract to which he gave the name Germantown.

title: FACTORY ORDERS RISE 1.1%
description: Orders to factories during August rose 1.1 percent, an improvement after the previous month's decline but the smallest gain since the economic recovery began, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CITY OPERA: THE SECOND YEAR OF LEHAR'S 'MERRY WIDOW'
description: FRANZ LEHAR'S ''Merry Widow'' returned to the New York City Opera on Sunday afternoon. The production is a year old now and remains, visually at least, a handsome one. Acts I and II create a softly colored elegance, and the red interiors of Maxim's restaurant at the end are vivid and striking. These sets - which are by Helen Pond and Herbert Senn - mix well with Suzanne Mess's turn-of-the-century costumes. It was all very nice to look at.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1983
description: International The head of Argentina's central bank was held for questioning about a recent agreement to refinance foreign debts. The action, on the official's return from an I.M.F. meeting, came amid growing nationalist pressure to halt all negotiations aimed at refinancing Argentina's $40 billion in overseas loans. (Page A1.) The World Bank has begun an extensive analysis of aid recipients' needs as a guide to its future capital increases. (D14.)

title: No Headline
description: Whalers Take 3 in Draft The Hartford Whalers were the most active team in yesterday's

title: Strike Starts At Vauxhall
description: Workers at Vauxhall Motors Ltd., the British unit of the General Motors Corporation, went on strike today in a pay dispute involving the company's 14,600 hourly employees.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Oct. 4, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: IN MANILA, OFFICIALS SEE LITTLE IMPACT, BUT OPPOSITION IS DELIGHTED
description: Early reports today that President Reagan had postponed his visit to the Philippines elicited little reaction from Government officials and relief from the opposition.

title: JERSEY'S SENATE VOTES TO REVISE AUTO INSURANCE
description: The New Jersey Senate, in an unusual postmidnight session, gave final legislative passage early today to an automobile insurance reform bill that Governor Kean said should enable motorists to save $150 on their annual insurance premiums.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income which includes a non- operating gain of $205,000 from the sale of the right to purchase office space it had formerly occupied.

title: U.S., CHANGING STAND, RESTRICTS PESTICIDE USE
description: The Reagan Administration resurrected a proposal today that would limit the exposure of workers to the pesticide ethylene dibromide, or EDB.

title: Metromedia Bid
description: Metromedia Inc. said it and the stockholders of American Teleservice Inc. had reached a definitive agreement providing for Metromedia to acquire all of the capital stock of American Teleservice and affiliated companies for $52.5 milllion. American Teleservices, a radio common carrier, provides radio paging and mobile telephone services in the Baltimore and Washington metropolitan areas, Metromedia said.

title: Shultz Plans Visit to Brazil
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will go to Brazil on Oct. 25 to discuss cooperation between the United States and Brazil on economics, space, science and industrial, military and nuclear affairs, a State Department spokesman said today. The spokesman, John Hughes, said he did not know how long Mr. Shultz would stay in Brazil or whether he would stop in other South American countries.

title: No Headline
description: HARRY H. SCHWARTZHarry H. Schwartz, former president of the National Department Stores Corporation, died Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Louisiana Land Co. To Have New Chief
description: Four months after defeating dissident shareholders who sought control of his company, John G. Phillips, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, said yesterday that he would give up the job of chief executive officer on Jan. 1. In his place, the New Orleans-based oil and natural gas company has named E. L. Williamson, currently its president and chief operating officer.

title: Unsuspecting Poisoner of 47 At a Hospital in 1942 Is Dead
description: George A. Nosen, a mental patient who mistakenly brought cockroach poison to cooks rather than powdered milk, causing the deaths of 47 Oregon State Hospital patients in 1942, has died after a scuffle at the institution. He was 68 years old.

title: El Salvador Sued in Death
description: The mother and sister of Michael Kline, 21 years old, who was shot to death in El Salvador a year ago, sued the Government of El Salvador and six United States officials today for $15 million in damages in United States District Court. Renate Kline, the mother, and Julie-Anne Kline, the sister, say soldiers killed Mr. Kline on Oct. 13 after hauling him from a bus. They say the Salvadoran authorities made no reasonable effort to investigate the killing and the State Department failed to insure a proper inquiry.

title: Black & Decker
description: The board chairman of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, Francis P. Lucier, reaffirmed today that he will not seek re-election. The board of directors said no replacement will be named for Mr. Lucier. Instead, the board said, the chairman's duties will be assumed by Laurence J. Farley, president.

title: A.T.& T. BID TO CUT NON-LOCAL RATES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company formally filed a request yesterday for a long-distance rate reduction of 10.5 percent to take effect Jan. 1.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON TRANSIT WAGES AND HOURS
description: The Supreme Court, in its latest effort to map the elusive boundary between Federal and state authority, said today it would rule on whether publicly owned and operated mass transit systems must abide by Federal minimum wage and hour standards.

title: CONTINENTAL'S TOUGH BATTLER
description: At least one top official at the Texas Air Corporation says that its president and chief executive officer, Frank A. Lorenzo, would make a poor poker player since he does not bluff well. ''In most cases he puts his cards on the table,'' the official, who did not want to be identified, said. Then too, he added, ''he also knows when he has a good hand.''

title: INTEGRATED ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Shell Faces Cleanup Bill
description: The Army filed a claim against the Shell Oil Company today, saying the company should share the $1.84 billion cost of cleaning up environmental damage caused by Shell and the Army at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal near Denver. Since 1952, Shell has leased part of the arsenal for a small pesticide-producing operation. The operation closed late last year.

description: President Reagan welcomed Katherine Ortega to her new position as Treasurer of the United States today, opening a week of events related to his role as an all-but-announced candidate for re-election.

title: New Evidence Emerges In von B"ulow Defense
description: Lawyers for Claus von B"ulow said today that they planned to file affidavits in State Supreme Court with new evidence in an attempt to reverse his conviction for twice trying to murder his wife, Martha von B"ulow, by injecting her with overdoses of insulin.

title: SEX IN AMERICA: CONSERVATIVE ATTITUDES PREVAIL
description: THE largest and most comprehensive study of American couples ever undertaken has found them to be far more conventional than expected in their attitudes and behavior toward sex, money and work.

title: ARIZONA ASKS U.S. AID AS HEAVY RAINS FALL AGAIN
description: Heavy rain fell again today in normally arid southeastern Arizona, and forecasters warned of more possible flooding from overflowing rivers that have left 13 people dead or missing and thousands homeless or stranded.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: SIMMS ASKS TO BE TRADED
description: Since training camp, when Scott Brunner was named the Giants' starting quarterback, Phil Simms, who once held that job, has been simmering. Today Simms said publicly for the first time that he wanted to be traded.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Express Co. has elected to its board Anne L. Armstrong, former Ambassador to Britain.

title: STAR'S DUST IS BAFFLING
description: AMASSIVE explosion on a star, detected last year, created a billowing cloud of dust that has astronomers puzzled. Normally, the dust particles are either silicates, carbon or silicon carbide, the products of nuclear processes in stars.
