title: Marc Rich Penalty Is Continued
description: A United States Federal District Court judge yesterday upheld a contempt of court order imposed on Swiss-based Marc Rich & Company A.G. June 29 for not turning over business documents and continued the $50,000-a-day fine. To date, $3.8 million has been paid.

title: Pope Meets Weinberger In a Private Audience
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger had a private audience with Pope John Paul II in the Vatican today.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Regino Cruz, an 18-year-old senior at Seward Park High School, was arrested yesterday and charged with stealing 21 payroll checks from a Board of Education office in a Manhattan work-study program. Mr. Cruz, of 905 East Sixth Street, was able to cash 13 checks, worth $1,300, even though they were all made out to women. . . . Neal Bronson of 189 Pulaski Street, Brooklyn, suspected of robbery and trying to kill a police officer, barricaded himself at 2:30 P.M. in a relative's apartment at 43 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, for more than an hour before surrendering . . . . Robert Bean, 24, of 967 Sheridan Avenue in the Bronx, was shot while in the Fourth Precinct station house in the Bronx after drawing a gun. Mr. Bean, who had been arrested at 1:05 A.M. for setting fire to a car, was shot in the stomach and taken to Lincoln Hospital, where he was listed in guarded condition. . . . Charles O'Brien, 26, of 204 East Fourth Street, was arrested at 2 A.M. and charged with attempted robbery in the stabbing of a cab driver, Lawrence Solomen, 52, of 7606 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, near the Queens entrance of the Queensboro Bridge. Mr. O'Brien was arrested after he was cornered by other cab drivers. Mr. Solomen was listed in serious but stable condition at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst.

title: 3 Latin Nations Agree To Revive Defense Pact
description: The Defense Ministers of Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador, who met here over the weekend along with the chief of the United States Southern Command, have agreed to revive an anti-Communist military pact, the Guatemalan Army said.

title: SUMMATIONS GIVEN IN MASSELLI MURDER TRIAL
description: Both the prosecution and the defense evoked the name of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan yesterday in closing arguments in the Bronx murder trial of Salvatore Odierno.

title: Group in Bahamas Charged In Big Narcotics Conspiracy
description: Federal prosecutors unsealed a 36-count indictment today charging that a northeastern Georgia man led a large smuggling organization that shipped marijuana and cocaine into the United States from a base in the Bahamas.

title: EX-STATE SENATOR OF BROOKLYN
description: Jeremiah B. Bloom, a lawyer and former State Senator from Brooklyn who unsuccessfully challenged Hugh L. Carey for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 1978, died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: POLL INDICATES CONSFUSION ON BREAKUP OF A.T.& T.
description: With three months to go before the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Americans have little understanding of the reorganization and considerable doubt about its benefits, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: FALCON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Garment Blackout: Cost Estimate Cut
description: Some eight weeks afterward, the three-day garment district power blackout appears to have caused far less financial damage than was predicted.

title: Life Sentence in Murder Of Ex-Governor's Wife
description: A man accused of strangling Elizabeth Faubus, the estranged wife of former Arkansas Gov. Orval Faubus, pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of murder today and was sentenced to life in prison, a prosecutor said.

title: No Headline

title: GOLD DROPS $11 TO FALL BELOW $400
description: The price of gold closed below $400 yesterday for the first time in more than a year, touching off widespread selling, much of it forced by margin calls over the weekend.

title: TEACHERS' WALKOUT SHUTS DOWN CHICAGO SCHOOLS
description: Striking teachers, joined by other school employees, shut down the nation's third largest school system today in a dispute over pay. City officials responded by offering supervised games, cut-rate museum admission and radio lectures to keep 420,000 pupils learning and off the streets.

title: MINNESOTA MURDER SUSPECT WAS AN APPARENT SUICIDE
description: The shotgun blast that ended the life of a dispossessed farmer sought for the killings of two bankers in his Minnesota hometown was clearly self-inflicted, the sheriff who viewed the body and inspected the death scene here said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Allegheny International Inc. said its Sunbeam Corp. unit had sold its Aircap Manufacturers and Sunbeam Outdoor subsidiaries to an affiliate of Wesray Corp. for an undislosed price.

title: TO FORCE CHILD SUPPORT
description: The growing number of parents who financially abandon their children is a national disgrace.

title: OIL WILDCATTERS HOPING FOR A GUSHER IN JERSEY
description: As far as anyone can tell, there has never been a barrel of oil or a cubic foot of natural gas drawn from beneath New Jersey's native soil. So when A. Frank Klam and his colleagues from Texas started prowling the hills and hollows here, some of his competitors in Houston had themselves quite a laugh.

title: 450 SWORN IN AS CITIZENS AT A BROOKLYN CEREMONY
description: Mark Man Young Wee traveled from Flushing, Queens, to downtown Brooklyn by car yesterday, but in a sense his journey began seven years ago when he left his native South Korea for a new life in the United States.

title: Loss Is Foreseen At Jersey Concern
description: Electronic Associates Inc. said it expects a loss of about $7 million for the third quarter.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: For reasons known not even to themselves, Italians seem to thrive in times of crisis. After three days of showings of the spring and summer collections in Milan, it is clear that despite the country's recession, foreign buyers are seeing what the Italians call an upswing in their fashion fortunes.

title: Cuomo Proposes Rise In State Textbook Aid
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would ask the State Legislature to approve a $5 increase, to $25 a year, for each pupil in the state's textbook-aid program next year.

title: KING HOLIDAY BILL FACES A FILIBUSTER
description: Senator Jesse Helms started a filibuster today against a bill that would make Martin Luther King's birthday a national holiday. The North Carolina Republican said the slain civil rights leader had followed a philosophy of ''action-oriented Marxism'' that ''is not compatible with the concepts of this country.''

title: African Leaders Seek End to War in Chad
description: President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea began another attempt to negotiate an end to the civil war in Chad today as leaders of 38 African states began a two-day conference here with President Francois Mitterrand.

title: No Headline
description: Durden of U.S. Takes Marathon

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising Column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the chairman of Knoware Inc. He is Archie J. McGill.

title: HIGH COURT TO REVIEW COMMERCIAL PAPER CASE
description: The Supreme Court, entering a high-stakes battle between the securities and banking industries, agreed today to review the Federal Reserve Board's decision to permit banks to underwrite commercial paper on behalf of corporate clients.

title: Link of Death to Tylenol Is Called Overreaction
description: Seven deaths caused by poisoned Tylenol capsules a year ago probably caused the police to overreact and initially link the death of Randall Hummel of East Buffalo Township, Pa., to Co-Tylenol tablets, a state health official said today.

title: TSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Lachemann to Brewers
description: Rene Lachemann, who was dismissed in midseason by the Seattle Mariners, has been named manager of the Milwaukee Brewers. He replaces Harvey Kuenn, who was voted manager of the year in 1982, when the Brewers won the American League title.

title: MOSCOW EXPANDS MISSILE REBUTTAL
description: The Soviet Union today published a point-by-point dismissal of President Reagan's modified proposals on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe and said there was ''absolutely nothing new from the standpoint of constructiveness and real flexibility.''

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1983 International
description: The President's visit to Manila next month has been postponed indefinitely, the White House announced. In addition to canceling his Philippines visit, Mr. Reagan also postponed plans to visit Indonesia and Thailand. Visits to two other countries - Japan and South Korea - will take place about the middle of November. The White House said Mr. Reagan's itinerary was shortened because his presence in Washington was needed in dealing with Congress on the budget and other issues. (Page A1, Column 6.) The U.S. will propose a new concept at the next round of strategic arms negotiations with the Soviet Union, President Reagan told key members of Congress. Under the plan, referred to as a ''build-down,'' for every new warhead deployed, older ones have to be destroyed. (A1:3.)

title: 'SHOULD I BUY A PERSONAL COMPUTERS?'
description: PROBABLY the most common analogy drawn to the impact and spread of personal computers today is with the growth in popularity of the automobile at the turn of the century. While the parallel is less than perfect, it is a way to think about this new technology in our everyday world in a comprehensible fashion.

title: BUT WILL ANYTHING COME OF ALL THOSE REPORTS?
description: CONSERVATIVES say that you cannot solve the schools' problems by throwing money at them. But can you solve them by throwing reports at them? In recent months, the schools have been the targets of a salvo of reports. Recommendations abound.

title: NBC AND HARRY COYLE'S BOOK
description: When the National League championship series between the Dodgers and the Philadelphia Phillies begins in Los Angeles tonight (Channel 4, New York, 8:20 P.M.), Vin Scully and Joe Garagiola will be NBC's most audible spokesmen. But the person who will leave the strongest visual impact for millions of home viewers during this series is Harry Coyle, a self-effacing director, who has literally written the book on the way baseball games should be shown on television.

title: Market PlaceDaniel F. Cuff Semiconductor Outlook Bright

title: Farmers in Ohio and Virginia Offered Federal Loan Relief
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that farmers in 29 counties in Ohio and 20 counties in Virginia would be eligible for Federal emergency disaster loans because of this summer's drought.

title: No Headline
description: The Right Message to Manila President Reagan calls it only a postponement caused by the press of business in Congress, but he has reached the right decision: to cancel next month's visit to Manila. The ugly murder of President Marcos's political foe, Benigno Aquino, is still far from properly explained. Mr. Reagan had no business embracing the embattled dictator or involving himself in any other way in the struggle between his regime and a newly aroused opposition.

title: Contempt Charge Stayed In Hawaii Welfare Case
description: Franklin Y. K. Sunn, Hawaii's welfare director, has won a 30-day reprieve from a judge who had found him in contempt of court.

title: 'RED LOVE,' RADICAL VIEW
description: ROSA VON PRAUNHEIM'S ''Red Love'' takes the form of a tirade about sexuality, revolving around the ideas of Helga Goetze, a West German woman in her late 50's who has a radical viewpoint and more than enough candor. She speaks of the marriage that produced seven children and 30 years of sexual monotony and goes on to explain how she has become radicalized. Her impressions are intercut with a continuing playlet, based on a feminist novel by Lenin's Minister of Culture, Alexandra Kollontai, about a woman who breaks with her early ideals to enter into a more or less conventional bourgeois marriage.

title: KOCH ASKS TO OUST SOME IN SHELTERS
description: The Koch administration has asked the state for permission to evict families from welfare hotels if they decline to move into vacant city-owned apartments.

title: PRESSURE GROWS TO RENOUNCE DEBT
description: The president of Argentina's central bank was held for questioning today on his return from an International Monetary Fund meeting in Washington, as nationalist sentiment mounted to halt talks on repayment of Argentina's huge foreign debt. Repaying the $40 billion is increasingly seen as an affront to Argentine sovereignty. Officials of the Economics Ministry who have been negotiating with creditors to delay repayments have been charged in courts with treason. Argentine lawyers representing American banks have been threatened in anonymous phone calls. And a federal judge in Rio Gallegos has forced the central bank to halt all movement of foreign exchange out of the country, blocking payments for imports. The military Government of President Reynaldo Bignone has scheduled national elections, the first in nearly a decade, for Oct. 30 and every major political party has demanded the suspension of debt negotiations until a civilian government takes over in January. The drama heightened today when Julio Gonzalez del Solar, president of the central bank, was taken into custody. He was ordered held by the judge in Rio Gallegos, who is investigating ''violations of sovereignty'' in a contract that refinanced debts owed by Aerolineas Argentinas, the state airline. Mr. Gonzalez del Solar, who was not charged, holds a position similar to that of Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in the United States. The judge in Rio Gallegos, Federico Pinto Kramer, said a $230 million agreement signed three weeks ago by international banks and the airline violated Argentine sovereignty by giving New York courts some jurisdiction over payment disputes.

title: NEW YORK HEIRESS DUE FOR LIFE TERM
description: Frances Bernice Schreuder, the 45-year-old New Yorker convicted of manipulating her son into killing her wealthy father, will not be sentenced to death, a judge decided today.

title: LABORITE LEADER DEPLORES 'EXCESSIVE' TIES TO U.S.
description: Neil Kinnock, the newly elected leader of the Labor Party, said today that the British ''are not masters of our own foreign policies because of our excessive state of obligation to the American Government.''

title: KIRKLAND RALLIES LABOR FORCES FOR '84 CONTEST
description: Lane Kirkland, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged today that the Reagan Administration was a government of the rich and the privileged. He said the central issue facing the country, now and in the 1984 election, was whether Government should ''be regarded as the natural enemy or used, where appropriate, as an instrument of progress.''

title: Marino Will Start
description: Dan Marino, the former Pitt star who was Miami's top draft choice this year, has been named the starting quarterback for the Dolphins' game against the Buffalo Bills on Sunday. In announcing that Marino would replace the veteran David Woodley , Coach Don Shula said he did not blame Woodley for the club's troubles, but believed that a change was necessary.

title: A Dillon, Read Adviser On Capital Formation
description: Edmund W. Littlefield, a former chairman and chief executive officer of Utah International Inc., the giant mining concern based in San Francisco, has been named a senior adviser at Dillon, Read & Company, the New York-based investment banking house announced.

title: THE CASE AGAINST HEAVY CREAM: A METAPHYSICAL QUIBBLE
description: THE scene is the Great Hall of the International Parliament of Food Authorities. The President, having called the session to order, announces the first item of business - the consideration of a resolution to ban the use of heavy cream. He then recognizes the chairman of the Committee on Endangered Foodstuffs, who rises to address the group:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: BOB MARLEY died in 1981, but a Wailers' reunion is in the works, featuring the other original members of the reggae vocal group - Peter Tosh, Junior Braithwaite and Neville Livingston, better known as Bunny Wailer. ''If Bob was here, it would have happened already,'' Mr. Wailer said by telephone from Jamaica.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid May 31.

title: Oil Buyers Hesitate
description: Weakness in spot prices is causing oil buyers to delay acceptance of fourth- quarter contracts with the British National Oil Corporation, sources said today. Prices proposed include an unchanged $30 a barrel for Brent oil, which is at $29 on the spot market.

title: FINDING PROFIT IN ROADWORK
description: Freddie Brown's contributions to boxing literature must start with his line ''When you're out of town, you're out of town.'' The veteran trainer was referring to hometown decisions, but boxers always have to face the perils of the road. They are itinerant workers,

title: Williams Offer
description: The Williams Companies said about 11.6 million shares, or 62 percent of those outstanding, of the Northwest Energy Company had been accepted for payment by Williams under its offer of $39 a share for any and all Northwest shares. Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., said its offer expires at midnight Friday. Northwest is based in Salt Lake City.

title: HIGHLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
INQUIRY SET ON CHINESE TEXTILES
description: The Commerce Department said today that it is investigating whether Chinese textiles and apparel exported to the United States are being illegally subsidized.

title: O'NEILL SAYS BILL ON ILLEGAL ALIENS IS DEAD FOR 1983
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that the House would take no action this year on a comprehensive bill to revise the nation's immigration laws, but the White House asked him to reconsider his decision.

title: No Headline
description: Calls to the Cathedral Answered by Police

title: Purolator Talks
description: Purolator Inc. said that it had begun preliminary discussions about the possible sale of its armored car unit to a subsidiary of Mayne Nickless Ltd., an Australian company.

title: Kaiser Steel
description: Members of an investment group that has agreed to acquire the Kaiser Steel Corporaton say they are studying plans to revive the company's ailing Fontana steel plant.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Miles Laboratories Names a New Chief

title: Iran Warns the U.S. Not to Interfere in Gulf
description: Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, said today that Iran would not allow any outside power, including the United States, to interfere in the Persian Gulf, even if other nations in the region welcomed the intervention.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Touch of the Fancy From the Plains - Tepees

title: QUALITY OF MERCY, STRAIN'D
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: There Is No Free Drink?

title: No Headline
description: Cry, Indeed, for Argentina Argentina is stumbling toward an election on Oct. 30, to choose a civilian president who is supposed to take office in January. But don't count on its happening. Argentina is so broke, wounded and bewildered that no one can be certain the vote will actually take place, that its outcome will be honored or that the resulting government can exercise real authority. And if Argentina plunges into bankruptcy and chaos, Central America's miseries may seem paltry by comparison.

title: 'NOSTALGHIA,' IN ITALIAN
description: ANDREI TARKOVSKY'S ''Nostalghia'' (Nostaglia), which will be shown at the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M., is the first film to be made outside of Russia by this relentlessly poetic, Soviet director. The setting is Italy, where the hero, Gortchakov (Oleg Yankovsky), has come to research the life of a 17th- century Russian composer who spent a long time in Italy, was terribly homesick, finally went home, became an alcoholic and committed suicide.

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: Bronx Jury Retires
description: The jury in the Bronx murder trial of Salvatore Odierno recessed last night after eight hours of deliberation and without reaching a verdict.

title: No Headline
description: Lucille Armstrong, 69, WidowOf Jazz Trumpeter and Singer

title: Careers; Grocery Managers Wanted
description: WORKING in a supermarket involves rolled-up sleeves and a nose-in-the-vegetable bin approach for prospective managers. That is quite different from the button-down collar and briefcase effect emphasized by a typical trainee at a bank or brokerage firm.

title: TO COMPENSATE AMERICANS FOR LOSSES OVERSEAS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Worm and the Apple Route Problems
description: Bad Signs

title: CONCERT: MARINE BAND
description: THE United States Marine Band, which has been in existence for 195 years, finally played in Carnegie Hall Monday night for the first time.

title: TOWERMARC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $216,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $66,000 for the quarter and $286,000 for the 9 months.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $81,000 for the quarter and $207,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $235,000 for the quarter and $774,000 for the 9 months.

title: Advertising; Campbell Soup Aims At Impact
description: When Herbert M. Baum, vice president-marketing of the Campbell Soup Company, sits down with one of his ad agencies to plan new adverising, he insists on not hearing about reach and frequency, cost per thousand, gross rating points or any other traditional measurements of economic efficiency. The man wants to hear about impact.

title: Repairs Set at Aquarium
description: The two-year-old National Aquarium in Baltimore will close for three weeks in November so workers can correct condensation in the upper areas of the building related to a tropical rain forest exhibit, said William S. Flynn, acting director of the Inner Harbor tourist attraction. He said it was hoped the repairs would be completed by Thanksgiving.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET DISCUSS WHETHER MOSCOW VIOLATED TERMS OF 2 ARMS PACTS
description: United States and Soviet officials in Geneva have started discussing American suggestions that the Soviet Union may have violated the terms of two arms control treaties.

title: HUGE COSTS OF REMOVING ASBESTOS DAUNTS SCHOOLS
description: There is growing alarm among school officials around the country about where they will get the funds to pay to remove potentially dangerous asbestos insulation from local school buildings.

title: Magistrate Backs 'Nail and Mail'
description: A Federal magistrate recommended yesterday that a judge find constitutional the way New York City applies to apartment-house owners its ''nail and mail'' system for citing landlords for sanitation violations.

title: LLOYD'S SETS DISCLOSURE RULES
description: Continuing its effort to shake off the impact of last year's scandals, Lloyd's of London today announced new financial disclosure rules for underwriters working at the insurance exchange. Lloyd's also said that it would acquire Toplis & Harding Inc., a Chicago- based claims adjuster.

title: MUSICIANS PICKET BEJART COMPANY
description: Local 802 of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York has set up what it calls an ''informational'' picket line at City Center to protest the use of taped music by Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century, which is appearing there through Sunday.

title: Insect Fragments Found In School Lunch Beef
description: Fragments of insects have been found in five samples of ground beef processed at a Colorado plant and intended for school lunches, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: INVESTORS ADVANCE OFFER FOR AMSTAR
description: The Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by an investor group for $47 a share, or a total of about $430 million.

title: No Headline
description: Unhappy Families There's no lack of work for President Reagan's new task force on family violence.

title: DRESS BARN reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
2,100 Given Amnesty By Uganda's President
description: President Milton Obote granted full amnesty to 2,100 prisoners today to mark the 21st anniversary of Uganda's independence from Britain, the state-run Uganda radio reported.

title: DEREGULATION CALLED DISASTER FOR AIRLINE INDUSTRY
description: Deregulation is having a devastating effect on the airline industry, Henry Duffy, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, said today. He cited fierce competition that he contended was placing several carriers in terrible financial condition.

title: PASSENGER BACKS DRIVER'S VERSION IN DEATH OF BOY
description: A passenger in a car that killed a Hispanic boy here March 15 testified today that the death was an accident, caused when the boy suddenly started to cross the residential street in front of the car.

title: MUSIC: 'THE NEW BABYLON'
description: THE screening of the 1929 Soviet film ''The New Babylon'' Monday night in Radio City Music Hall was notable not just for film enthusiasts, but for music lovers as well.

title: POLYDEX CHEMICAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Winfield Charity Sues Steinbrenner
description: Dave Winfield's charitable foundation yesterday sued George Steinbrenner for the second time in a year and a half, charging that the Yankee owner had not fulfilled an obligation to make substantial donations.

title: CBS LEADS RATINGS IN NEW SEASON'S FIRST WEEK
description: In the first week of the new television season, the CBS television network dominated the A. C. Nielsen ratings, helped in large part by the strong showings of programs returned from last season. NBC, meanwhile, placed a distant third, with several of its new programs attracting small audiences.

title: ZIP Code Discounts
description: The Postal Service board today approved rate discounts for major business mailers who use the nine-digit ZIP code.

title: RELIGOUS PANEL AND KOCH MEET ON LANDMARKS
description: Mayor Koch and leaders of New York City's major religious groups differed sharply yesterday on the impact of granting landmark status to churches and synagogues. A 45-minute meeting in the Mayor's office ended without a change on either side.

title: Transco Energy
description: The Transco Energy Company said it had asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission for a general rate increase that would raise its revenues by $138 million a year. Although the rate increase would be effective Nov. 1, Transco said it is anticipated that the regulatory agency will suspend the filing for the five-month period permitted under the Natural Gas Policy Act, the Federal law covering such rate increases, making the higher rates effective April 1.

title: New York Magazine Appoints Publisher
description: New York magazine has named Martin Singerman, 56 years old, publisher. Mr. Singerman, president of News Group Magazines, a division of News Group Publications, which is owned by Rupert Murdoch, and also executive vice president of News America, the American parent company of News Group Publications, was named to the additional post of publisher left vacant by the departure of Cathleen Black, who went to USA Today as president.

title: INTEREST RATES SHOW DECLINE
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday in quiet trading.

title: PHILLIES WIN OPENER, 1-0
description: The old men of the Philadelphia Phillies kept on winning tonight when they took the opening game of the National League playoff by edging the Los Angeles Dodgers, 1-0.

title: No Headline
description: 2 Drivers Indicted In Race-Fixing

title: COURT THREAT DELAYS EXPERIMENTS IN GENETICALLY MODIFIED BACTERIA
description: Scientists at the University of California at Berkeley have postponed until next spring planned experiments in which genetically engineered bacteria will be field-tested as a means of reducing frost damage to potato plants.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
MUSIC EDITOR DISMISSED
description: A dispute over a change in editorial policy at High Fidelity magazine has led to the dismissal of James R. Oestreich, the magazine's classical music editor since 1979.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Kean to Authorize Bridge Bonds Vote
description: Governor Kean said today that he would sign legislation authorizing a $135 million bond issue to finance the repair and replacement of New Jersey's most dilapidated bridges.

title: BRIEFS
description: Appalachian Power Co. announced that it had agreed to sell part of its Southern Appalachian Coal Co. unit to Ashland Coal Co., and that it is negotiating to sell the rest; no terms were disclosed.

title: Supervisor Is Held In Gambling Deal
description: A supervisor with the city's retirement system was arrested yesterday on charges of allowing a man addicted to gambling who worked for him to spend workdays at the race track in exchange for a share in his winnings, authorities said.

title: West German Output
description: West Germany's seasonally adjusted industrial production was unchanged in August after a revised 2.8 percent fall in July, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: CARTERS ATTEND GALA PREVIEW OF SOTHEBY AUCTION
description: THERE were klieg lights washing the Sotheby Parke Bernet building last night and a red carpet leading from the curb and all the other accouterments of what is known as an event. But this one had a couple of extra added attractions named Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter, for the event was a benefit preview for the auction to be held Friday to raise funds for the Carter Presidential Library and the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta.

title: ARIZONA FLOODS TAKING TOLL OF BOTH LIVES AND PROPERTY
description: Until 1981, Yoem Pueblo, a Yaqui Indian village of about 85 people here, was without paved streets, electricity, sewers or indoor toilets.

title: No Headline
description: Hearing Set For Gastineau Twelve hours after he had

title: SAUDIS REASSESS THE GAINS BOUGHT WITH OIL
description: A cascade of petrodollars over the last 10 years has dramatically transformed the contours of life in the Persian Gulf.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1983

title: Wang Introduces Office Computer
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. introduced an office computer that can make copies of documents, store them in its memory, and send them to other computers, eliminating another heavy flow of paperwork that still slows office work.

title: HOW NEW INSURANCE LAWS AFFECT JERSEY'S DRIVERS
description: Governor Kean today signed five automobile- insurance bills that he predicted would save the average motorist $150 in annual premiums.

title: No Headline
description: Quiet Trading In Eurobonds LONDON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)

title: American League Playoff; Clubs Seem Evenly Matched
description: In gaining their first championship of any kind since 1959, the Chicago White Sox finished the season with a flourish, winning 57 of their 81 games in the second half of the season and 29 of their last 35 games. Yet, not everyone is convinced that the White Sox are as good as their major-league-leading total of 99 victories would seem to indicate.

title: CARDINAL COOKE 'CLOSE TO DEATH'
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, who is terminally ill with leukemia, underwent a ''radical change'' for the worse yesterday and was thought to be at ''the point of death,'' the Archdiocese of New York reported last night.

title: Market PlaceDaniel F. Cuff Coleco's Adam: Betting Heavy
description: WILL Coleco Industries' new Adam computer be out in time for substantial Christmas sales or won't it? Place your bets, please. The bets are being placed quite heavily on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, where the trading in Coleco options is thriving.

title: Chinese to Distribute A.P.'s News Reports
description: The Associated Press and the New China News Agency agreed today on the first teleprinter distribution of any foreign news agency in China in 34 years.

title: Canadian Tire Stake Purchased
description: One branch of the Billes family has agreed to buy a 30 percent holding in the Canadian Tire Corporation's voting stock outstanding, David G. Billes said in a statement. Mr. Billes said he, his brother Alfred W. Billes and sister Martha Gardiner-Billes, all children of A. J. Billes, one of the co- founders of Canadian Tire, had signed the agreement.

title: DANCE: BALLET HISPANICO OPENS ITS SEASON AT JOYCE
description: BALLET HISPANICO of New York, which opened last night at the Joyce Theater for a week's engagement, celebrates its 13th birthday this year. It is well on its way to completing a $910,000 capital campaign to renovate its headquarters on the Upper West Side, which will house both Ballet Hispanico and its flourishing dance school. And with this season at the Joyce, the company moves into a major dance theater for the first time.

title: Appeals Court Backs Auto Pollution Testing
description: Automobile exhaust pollution tests used in 16 states and contemplated in 12 others were upheld as valid today by the United States Court of Appeals here.

title: Rodale Press Halts Its Spring Magazine
description: Rodale Press, the health-oriented Pennsylvania publishing company, will discontinue Spring, the magazine of High Energy Living, with its November/December issue, Robert J. Teufel, Rodale president, confirmed last Friday.

title: Benjamin Dreyfus, 73; Lawyer for Underdogs
description: Benjamin Dreyfus, a lawyer who made a career of defending the underdog and left-wing causes, died Sunday in Marin General Hospital after being admitted last week with a heart problem. He was 73 years old.

title: SOVIET IN U.N. CALLS FOR AN ARMS FREEZE
description: The Soviet Union called here today for ''a simultaneous, quantitative and qualitative freeze on nuclear weapons'' by all nations with such arms. It said the Soviet Union and the United States should be the first to agree.

title: SCOUTING
description: A First for China

title: THE DODGERS' HAWKEYE
description: LOS ANGELES There were times this summer when Jerry

title: A SAD BONDHOLDER SESSION
description: ''Walk in please. Behave yourself now,'' the uniformed guard said sternly, as he opened the Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden yesterday morning to the first of some 1,200 people who came to hear about the $2.25 billion in Washington Public Power Supply System bonds that may well be worthless.

title: Claude Hamilton Jr., Retired Lawyer, Dies
description: Claude E. Hamilton Jr., retired senior partner of the New York law firm of White & Case and former general counsel of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, died Sunday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 84 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: THE ESSENTIAL KITCHEN: CHOOSING THE BASICS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Pierre Franey and Bryan Miller and was written by Mr. Miller.

title: ROYALE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

DECISION FILE ;  Decision File Medical Emergencies On Airplanes Sometimes regulatory agencies are found by the courts to miss the intent of a law in their quest to enforce its letter. Just recently, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled that if the Federal Aviation Administration could require airlines to carry adhesive bandages on aircraft, then the agency could also require them to carry stethoscopes.
description: The case came up after 56 independent physicians and the Health Research Group, a Ralph Nader organization, petitioned the agency to require airlines to carry emergency medical supplies for use by doctors and nurses who might be passengers.

title: U.S. Warns the Nicaraguans Not to Attack Other Nations
description: The United States warned Nicaragua at a meeting of the Organization of American States today that it would not tolerate armed attacks against other Central American countries.

title: REAGAN AVOWS HIS AMITY FOR MARCOS
description: President Reagan has assured President Ferdinand E. Marcos in a letter that, despite dropping plans to visit the Philippines and two other Southeast Asian nations next month, his friendship for the Philippine leader and his wife was ''as warm and firm as ever.''

title: Economic Scene; Debtors Crowd On the Brink
description: HOW serious is the international debt crisis? The short answer is, ''Very.'' Just how serious was dramatized in Buenos Aires Monday, when the president of Argentina's central bank, Julio Gonzalez del Solar, was held for questioning on his return from the International Monetary Fund annual meeting in Washington. Mr. Gonzalez del Solar has not yet been charged with anything, but he was taken into custody by a judge investigating ''violations of sovereignty'' in connection with a contract to refinance the debts of Aerolineas Argentinas, the state airline.

title: U.S. ACTS TO OVERTURN A WARTIME CONVICTION
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to set aside the conviction of Fred T. Korematsu, who in 1942 was convicted of violating wartime evacuation orders that led to the internment of more than 100,000 Japanese-Americans. His conviction had been upheld by the Supreme Court.

title: PRIVATE AND PUBLIC COLLEGES FEUDING
description: The heads of New York State's major colleges and universities are convening today in two competing meetings hundreds of miles apart to discuss a widening rift between public and private institutions of learning in the state.

title: 5.39 Dow Rise Ends 5 Days of Drops
description: Stock prices, bolstered by some subdued bargain-hunting, reversed five days of declines yesterday in active trading.

title: ROCK: DEVOTO AT IRVING PLAZA
description: IRVING PLAZA returned to a

title: ; NUCLER ARMS CUT ARE NO RISK TO MOSCOWS
description: T o the Editor:

title: COOK FROM MADRID EXPLORES THE VARIED FLAVORS OF SPAIN
description: IN Spain, where cooking schools

title: U.S. Warns Nicaragua On Attacking Others
description: The United States warned Nicaragua today that it would not tolerate armed attacks against other Central American countries, and it threatened to invoke the Rio Treaty for mutual defense.

title: BIG 3'S '83 CAR SALES UP 16.7%
description: The Big Three auto makers ended the 1983 model year with a 16.7 percent increase in sales, the companies reported today. It was the first time since 1978 that the domestic auto makers had been able to report a year-to-year improvement in sales.

title: U.S. ACTS TO OVERTURN WARTIME CONVICTION
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to set aside the conviction of Fred T. Korematsu, who in 1942 was convicted of violating wartime evacuation orders that led to the internment of more than 100,000 Japanese-Americans. His conviction had been upheld by the Supreme Court.

title: Turkey Lists Candidates And Parties It Approves
description: Turkey's military rulers completed their screening today of parties and people allowed to run in next month's elections, publishing the final list of approved parliamentary candidates.

title: GOAT CHESSE: MEETING THE DEMAND
description: When Victor Miller quit his school principalship on Long Island two years ago, he could not tell a goat from a calf. Today he bills himself as the biggest goat milker east of the Mississippi.

title: FOR A WHILE THERE, EUPHORIA IN TEXAS
description: No American city resonates with the ups and downs of world petroleum like Houston, energy capital of the United States.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ALTHOUGH many ways to prevent unwanted pregnancies are widely available, more than half the six million American women and girls who become pregnant each year do not want to have a child either at the time or at all.

title: THEATER: 'RAISIN IN SUN,' ANNIVERSARY IN CHICAGO
description: It was 25 years ago that a 28-year-old black woman from this city changed American theater forever with her first produced play. The woman was Lorraine Hansberry, and the play, of course, was ''A Raisin in the Sun.''

title: MARY CUNNINGHAM IS LEAVING SEAGRAM
description: Saying that her task to devise a strategy for the wine division of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons was complete, Mary E. Cunningham submitted her resignation to the company yesterday.

title: JUSTICES REFUSE DEATH ROW PLEA BEFORE HEARING
description: The Supreme Court's 5-to-4 decision Monday night to deny a stay of execution for a condemned Texas killer signaled a significant departure from the way the Court has handled similar last-minute appeals.

title: No Headline
description: The Cincinnati Reds today hired Vern

title: SCOUTING
description: 2 Kinds of Walls

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Head of Bloomingdale's Recalls France of 1944

title: Need in U.S. For Arab Oil
description: The Reagan Administration formally abandoned today the national goal of energy independence, saying that the United States would rely ''to some extent'' on Arab oil imports for at least the next 20 years.

title: No Headline
description: Suit Is Filed Against Coleco A stockholder of Coleco Industries filed a class action

title: WHAT KIND OF ECONOMY IS BEST FOR WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Transactions

title: SOVIET OIL TOOL CURBS RULED OUT
description: The Reagan Administration, ignoring the recommendation of an interagency advisory group made shortly after the Sept. 1 destruction of a South Korean airliner, has decided against tightening controls over exports of oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.

title: NO FREEZE, PLEASE
description: Following are excerpts from a letter that David H. Burton Jr., an Air Force captain, sent to President Reagan and had distributed in his hometown, Lexington, Mass.

title: SchoolsChancellor To Get a Raise
description: The Board of Education is planning to raise the annual salary of Anthony J. Alvarado, the new Schools Chancellor, from $85,000 to $95,000, officials said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Eyes of Texas Fall on a Redshirt, 13 During the last few weeks, it has become assured that the best-remembered schoolboy football player in Texas this year will be a gangly 13-year-old who plays for the seventh-grade team in tiny Justin, a community most residents of the Dallas-Fort Worth area, 50 miles to the south, cannot locate.

title: U.S. WILL CONTINUE MILITARY ROLE IN HONDURAS, PENTAGON AIDE SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration, buoyed by what it sees as a successful Central American policy, plans to continue an expanded military presence in Honduras, according to a Defense Department official.

title: CHESS DECISION IS REVERSED
description: The World Chess Federation today reversed its decision declaring two Soviet players losers after they had failed to attend semifinals for the world chess crown. The federation said it would reschedule the matches.

title: Fighting Erupts Again In the Beirut Suburbs
description: Fighting broke out in Beirut's southern suburbs tonight, again breaking a fragile cease-fire, the state-run Beirut radio reported.

title: JOHN N. STAUFFER
description: John N. Stauffer, former president of Juniata College in Huntingdon, Pa., died Sept. 28 of Alzheimer's disease at a nursing home in Naples, Fla.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Anderson Rewarded
description: The Detroit Tigers rewarded Manager Sparky Anderson for the club's second-place finish in the American League East, its best in 15 years, by extending his contract for two years.

title: Job Safety Agency Planning Checkups on Asbestos Rules
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has announced that it will conduct 700 inspections in the next year to check on violations of rules on asbestos exposure.

title: Fannie Mae Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association's $1 billion of 11.2 percent debentures due June 10, 1987, were offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers. When the interest rate was announced, the issue yielded about 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than recently issued four-year notes of the United States Treasury.

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SCENE: sidewalk in front of Zabar's.

title: NAVY STILL HOPES TO FIND AIRLINER
description: Seven years ago, 75 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean off the northwest coast of Scotland, an F-14 fighter accidently rolled off the deck of a United States Navy carrier and disappeared in 2,000 feet of water, taking down with it a top-secret missile and some of the most sophisticated electronic gear ever installed in an airplane.

title: Nasdaq Trading Record
description: A record 12 billion shares were traded over-the-counter in the first nine months of 1983, more than double the 5.4 billion shares traded in the same period last year, the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. said yesterday. The association said that trading activity in the July-September quarter was a record 3.9 billion shares, and that on three occasions in the quarter the daily Nasdaq volume exceeded that of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: FOX WILL RE-RELEASE ABANDONED FILM THAT FLOPPED
description: What happens when you give a movie and nobody comes?

title: ARMS TALKS: SHIFT BY U.S.
description: President Reagan's new strategic arms proposal is widely seen here as a significant advance toward compromise with the Soviet Union, an advance that will make arms control policy a more difficult target for domestic critics. In the proposal, which was formally announced today, Mr. Reagan met the main concerns of an influential group of legislators and arms specialists by agreeing to redesign the so-called build-down idea, which provides that the deployment of new warheads must be accompanied by the destruction of older ones.

title: NEW NOTES ISSUE PLANNED BY CITY GETS TOP RATING
description: For the first time since early 1975, notes issued by New York City have received the top investment-grade rating from Moody's Investor Service.

title: AUDIT AFTER GOLD DEALER'S SUICIDE SUGGESTS CUSTOMERS LOST MILLIONS
description: Some $60 million worth of gold, silver and platinum sold to thousands of individuals and then supposedly stored in Rocky Mountain vaults may never have existed, an investigation suggested yesterday.

title: 'MUD SLIDE' BILL ADDING ITS BIT TO TAX LAW MAZE
description: H.R. 2831, one of thousands of bills Congress considers each year, contains little to set it apart from the crowd. Only 37 lines long, it has no known opposition and was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee this afternoon.

title: WEINBERGER FLEXES DIPLOMATIC SKILLS
description: On a journey around the world that ended here late last night, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger mixed military duties with diplomacy, rekindling speculation that he might like to be Secretary of State in a second Reagan Cabinet.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1983 International
description: A national strike in Argentina shut down its businesses, industry and public transportation. The 24-hour stoppage called by two Peronist- dominated labor federations to protest low wages and high inflation has added to political instability only four weeks before national elections are to be held to return the country to civilian rule. (Page A1, Column 6.) The American presence in Honduras will continue after the present military exercises end in March 1984, according to Nestor Sanchez, a Defense Department official. Mr. Sanchez said that the Reagan Administration viewed its Central American policy as successful, and that further military exercises between the American and Honduran forces were being planned. (A1:5.)

title: Electronic Associates Replaces Its President
description: As the company's stock was sliding in response to a pessimistic earnings estimate, Electronic Associates Inc. announced the resignation of Edward A. Petko as president and chief executive officer and the promotion of Robert G. Finney to replace him.

title: REAGAN PROMOTES NEW ARMS OFFICERS
description: President Reagan appeared before television cameras in the White House Rose Garden today to give his new strategic arms proposals to Edward L. Rowny, the chief American negotiator.

title: 4 Rangers Sent to Tulsa Farm
description: The new National Hockey League season begins tonight for the Rangers and the New Jersey Devils, when they play each other at Madison Square Garden. But for four Rangers, it began with an unhappy jolt yesterday.

title: CLARENDON ASSAILS ASSET LIEN OF I.R.S.
description: Clarendon Ltd., a commodities trading firm formerly owned by Marc Rich, the millionaire trader under indictment on charges he evaded $48 million in income taxes, may be forced into bankruptcy if the lien the Internal Revenue Service placed against its assets is upheld, the president of the company said in court documents yesterday.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the years I have heard several explanations for the early French chefs' use of the term Florentine for many dishes in which the characteristic ingredient is spinach. Some say that Florence was at one time considered the spinach capital of Italy, but most of my Italian friends dispute this.

title: Salazar Won't Run
description: Alberto Salazar , who won the last three New York City Marathons, said that a sore hamstring would keep him from running in the race on Oct. 23. He had been considered doubtful since he took a month off from running in August after he finished last in the 10,000 meters at the world track and field championships.

Hospital Corp.
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said it had received a favorable ruling from the United States Tax Court and, as a result, the company is not liable for $17 million in additional taxes that had been requested by the Internal Revenue Service. The concern said the I.R.S. had asserted that a deficiency in the company's 1973 taxable income would have resulted in the additional payment. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: ARCHITECTURE: NEW ATLANTA MUSEUM
description: ATLANTA ALMOST every museum building is the result of a struggle between art and architecture, and it usually ends with one side giving up. Sometimes the architect creates so powerful a presence that the art is overwhelmed, and in other instances the building defers to the art so completely that it has no architectural presence in itself. Rare indeed is the museum that falls into neither extreme - that is a strong and potent work of architecture in itself, yet seems completely to understand and respect the works of art within it.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporaton won a $180.8 million contract from the Navy to procure 73 Phalanx defense weapons, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said the Hayes International Corporation had received a $34.4 million Air Force award for depot maintenance, modification, and data for 128 KC-135 aircraft.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $42,000 for the quarter and $154,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after a tax credit of $68,000. d-Including a tax credit of $136,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Standard Inc. has appointed Raymond R. Paterson to the newly created post of corporate vice president, joint ventures.

title: THE NUCLEAR QUANDARY
description: Sometimes things have to get a little scary around here before anybody pays much attention. This may be happening here now with regard to United States-Soviet relations, though it is not so far in Moscow.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for 6,934,113
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid May 31.

title: Key Items Listed At N.F.L. Meetings
description: Owners and executives from the 28 National Football League teams are scheduled to begin two days of meetings today at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan. Two of the most pressing issues on the agenda are a report on a possible conflict of interest involving Edward DeBartolo Jr., the owner of the San Francisco 49ers, and a discussion about a possible change in the date of the college draft.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income. Share earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in December 1982.

description: To the Editor:

title: TO EASE NIGERIA'S DEBT CRISIS
description: As the United States and the other International Monetary Fund members wrangle over Washington's contribution to the Fund, the organization risks jeopardizing one of its key roles - stabilizing the economies of developing countries beset by global recession. The Fund renounces any political role or political criteria for lending, but its support is sometimes vital for recipient countries trying to consolidate democracy. It must not now abandon this role in Nigeria, where a fledgling democracy is trying to weather severe economic difficulties.

title: ARGENTINE LABOR PARALYZES NATION IN DAYLONG STRIKE
description: A national strike shut down Argentina's businesses, industry and public transportation today.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
LIFE EXPECTANCY IN U.S. REACHES 74.5 YEARS
description: Americans born in 1982 can expect to live longer than those born in any previous year, to an average age of 74.5 years, and infant mortality has dropped to the lowest ever, the Government reported today.

title: ARMS AID TO NICARAGUA STILL RISING, U.S. SAYS
description: In the face of American Navy exercises off the coast of Nicaragua since late July, the flow of military supplies from the Soviet Union, Cuba and Eastern Europe continues to increase, State Department officials said today.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
description: Results are for 13 weeks and 53 weeks for the latest periods and 12 and 52 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: Quakes Shake Japanese Isle After the Volcanic Eruptions
description: Earthquakes rattled the small Pacific island of Miyakejima today as ships and helicopters brought emergency supplies for hundreds of residents whose homes were buried under molten lava by volcanic eruptions Monday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tribute to Kaufman

title: William J. Stoutenburgh Sr.; A Former Investment Broker
description: William J. Stoutenburgh Sr., a retired investment broker who was active in Roman Catholic affairs, died Sunday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Mahwah, N.J.

title: DEVELOPER STRUGGLES FOR TAX AID UNDER NEW LAW
description: In 1978 Lewis Futterman acquired the Vancouver, a vacant single-room- occupancy building on West 94th Street. Under the J-51 program, the city's largest tax-incentive program for developers who rehabilitate rundown housing, he expected to receive tax exemptions for turning the building into luxury cooperatives.

title: RELIGIOUS PARTY BACKS SHAMIR
description: Prime Minister-designate Yitzhak Shamir won the support of the rigorously Orthodox party Agudat Israel today, guaranteeing his new Government a majority in Parliament.

title: NOT-SO-BELOVED INDUCTION CENTER IS GUTTED
description: Unloved but keenly remembered, the old U.S. Army Building in lower Manhattan is a sidewalk demolition spectacle.

title: EXXON'S TAKING OF HUDSON WATER LEADS TO INQUIRY
description: For years, Exxon Corporation oil tankers have loaded their ballast and cargo tanks with millions of gallons of fresh water from a relatively clean stretch of the Hudson River and transported it to the Caribbean for use in a petroleum refinery.

title: Phibro-Salomon Pound Warrants
description: The first issues of currency exchange warrants were sold to investors by Salomon Brothers International, on behalf of Phibro-Salomon Inc., the issuer.

title: Carter on Soviet
description: Former President Jimmy Carter , who directed the boycott of the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow, said it ''would be a serious mistake'' to block the Soviet Union from next year's Games in Los Angeles because of the shooting down of the Korean airliner.

title: PANTRY PRIDE SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for 12 wks to July 30
description: b-After losses of $2,559,000 for the 12 weeks and $2,659,000 for the year from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $589,000 for the 12 weeks and $7,249,000 for the year. c-After losses of $45,000 for the 12 weeks and $4,002,000 for the year from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $270,000 for the 12 weeks and $8,174,000 for the year.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Orioles vs. Chicago White Sox, at Baltimore. Opening game of American League Championship series. The White Sox' right-handed control artist, LaMarr Hoyt, had the most victories in the major leagues this year, at 24-10. He will face the left-hander Scott McGregor (18-7). (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 2:55 P.M.).

title: JETS ARE THRIVING FOR CONSISTENCY
description: There has been much talk about the Jets recently, but as far as the players' performance on the field, not even the team's coaches are sure what to make of it.

description: Metromedia Inc. said it expects earnings from continuing operations in the third quarter to be lower than the 10 cents a share in last year's third quarter.

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: Pact Backed At Vauxhall
description: About 1,000 members of the Transport and General Workers' Union at the Vauxhall Motors Dunstable plant, about half the work force, voted this morning to accept the company's latest pay offer, a Vauxhall spokesman said.

title: New Processor By Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation said it had introduced a multiple parallel processor system that increases the computational power of its Cyber 170 series 800 systems to up to 16 billion calculations a second.

title: MINNESOTA FARMER'S VIOLENCE SHOCKS TEXANS WHO KNEW HIM
description: When James Lee Jenkins showed up here 14 months ago, he seemed just another down-on-his-luck drifter, a dispossessed Minnesota farmer who, like others, was looking for a job doing something, anything, with his hands.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SECOND STRING TO FOOTBALL
description: Many women in the Monday night class describe themselves as ''football widows,'' women who have lost their husbands to televised football. They come to learn about I-formations, nickel defenses and hang time, that this might enable them to communicate once more with loved ones lost.

description: Wasting No Time, Koch Is Raising Funds for '85

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Koch to VisitSanto Domingo By United Press International
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had accepted an invitation from the Mayor of Santo Domingo to visit the Dominican Republic next week.

title: Jury Gets Chicago Lab Case
description: Jury deliberations began today in the trial of three former officials of the Industrial Bio- Test Laboratories Inc., charged with falsifying reports on experiments to determine whether certain drugs contained cancer-causing or toxic effects.

title: Crackdown on Broncos
description: The Denver Broncos have been having their troubles on the field this year, but between games life has been easy for the Broncos, perhaps too easy, according to Coach Dan Reeves . With the club's record at 2-3 after a 31-14 loss Sunday to the Chicago Bears, Reeves has moved to end the relaxed atmosphere that has marked the team's practice sessions. He ordered an end to the free, catered lunches the team had enjoyed, told the players they could no longer take naps between morning and afternoon practices, ordered them to stop ''goofing off'' on the sidelines during practice and appointed coaches to supervise the running of laps to make sure nobody cut corners.

title: SHARP ORATOR FOR LABORITES
description: A few hours before he was elected leader of the Labor Party, Neil Kinnock and his wife, Glenys, were posing for the photographers on the beach at Brighton. Maybe he had in mind the memorable pictures of John F. Kennedy taken on Cape Cod in 1960. But unlike Mr. Kennedy, he tripped and fell into the foaming surf. For many a young politician, it would have been a humiliating moment. But Neil Kinnock has the kind of quicksilver wit that gets him out of jams like that. He picked himself out of the water, shrugged, grinned his wide, freckle-faced Tom Sawyer grin and said, ''Well, at least I didn't try to walk on it.''

title: TV: A YOUTHFUL COMPUTER GENIUS
description: BEING more topical than its producers or the network might appreciate, ''Whiz Kids'' is making its debut as a weekly series on CBS-TV at 8 o'clock tonight. The hero is a young electronics genius who can program his computer to tap into other computer systems, corporate, governmental and private.

title: FILIBUSTER BY HELMS ON DR. KING HOLIDAY IS DROPPED IN SENATE
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, today abruptly dropped his filibuster against establishing a national holiday for the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and agreed to a final vote in two weeks.

title: MEDICAID FRAUD LAID TO DOCTOR
description: A Manhattan neurologist was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing $10,600 from the New York State Medicaid program and New York Hospital.

title: Building Collapse Kills 2
description: Two workers died when a two-story office building under construction collapsed Monday after a gust of wind, Assistant Fire Chief Randy Yost said. Michael Phillips, 44 years old, of Canton was pronounced dead shortly after his arrival at a hospital. Paul Risher, 66, of Massillon died about six hours later.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK CRITICIZES SOVIET
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick told a gathering of conservatives today that an enlightened United States foreign policy was one that recognized the scope of the challenge posed by the Soviet Union as well as Moscow's willingness to use whatever means it could to establish ''a vast empire.''

title: REAGAN HIT ON F.C.C. BRIEFING
description: President Reagan received a private briefing last week from the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission on an issue in which the interests of some of his old Hollywood friends run contrary to the position taken by at least four different agencies of his Administration.

title: Higher Rates Set For Jersey Bell
description: The State Board of Public Utilities approved a $41.5 million rate increase today for the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and a one-time $12 million refund that will lower each November bill by about $4.80.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Now, the Weather - From La Guardia

title: Colgate Assignment Goes to Foote, Cone
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company has assigned $15 million in domestic business, formerly at Ted Bates and Kenyon & Eckhardt, to Foote, Cone & Belding's New York office, FCB/ East.

title: WITH DUE POMP, SAN MARINO ENTHRONES 2 LEFTISTS
description: Two appliance dealers, one a Communist and the other a Socialist, took their places this weekend in a line of succession, unbroken since at least the year 1244, of elected consuls who have governed this last surviving Italian city-state, which also likes to call itself the world's oldest republic.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Morrone , who played four years at the University of Connecticut, has signed a one-year contract with the Cosmos. The 22-year-old midfielder trained on a trial basis with them in August. . . . Al Miller, the Tampa Bay Rowdies' coach, has resigned, citing new ownership as part of the reason. . . . Steve Stipanovich , the 7-foot Missouri center who was the Indiana Pacers' top draft choice last summer, has signed a multiyear contract after missing the first five days of training camp during protracted negotiations. . . . Rod Thorn , the Chicago Bulls' general manager, has sent a message to all National Basketball Association teams asking if they are interested in acquiring Reggie Theus , the Bulls' leading scorer last season. Theus refused to report to camp last week because he was unhappy with his contract. . . . Dan Fouts , the San Diego Chargers' quarterback who suffered a bruised shoulder against the Giants. may not be able to play against Seattle Sunday, the team said.

title: Trial of DeLoreanRescheduled for Nov. 1
description: John Z. DeLorean's trial on charges of cocaine trafficking today was scheduled to begin Nov. 1, but the judge agreed to consider holding a pretrial hearing that could further delay the case.

title: UNCONSCIONABLE EXPLOITATION OF TELETHONS
description: To the Editor:

description: Prime Rate Cut In Australia

title: 75,000 in Stockholm Protest New Tax Bill
description: At least 75,000 bankers, business leaders and white-collar workers marched on Parliament today to protest a bill that would tax company profits more heavily and give the money to trade unions to buy stocks.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHANGING LEAVES: FALLOUT IS GREEN
description: Among people around the country determined to keep a rendezvous with autumn in New England, there is an annual inner anguish: When will the leaves turn color? When will they peak? And when will they fall?

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 2
No Headline
description: The Speaker and the Big Wink Until yesterday, there was something remarkable about the immigration reforms that have developed in the last five years: They have been truly nonpartisan. Putting the United States back in control of the borders is an idea not limited to either the liberal or conservative canon, and a bill to do that has won wide support from both parties. But yesterday, Speaker O'Neill killed both the nonpartisan spirit and the bill, saying ''I don't think there's a constituency out there for it.''

title: CHARLES R. BYRNE
description: Charles R. Byrne, a literary agent and former publisher, died of a stroke yesterday. He was 67 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: CANADIAN TAKEOVER OF HARRIS SEEN
description: The rumored takeover of the Harris Bankcorporation in Chicago by the Bank of Montreal became a virtual certainty today as the two banking companies announced that they will make major news announcements Wednesday morning.

description: Pinstripes, No But Playoff, Yes

German Jobless Rate
description: West German unemployment in September fell to 2.13 million people, or 8.6 percent of the work force, from 2.20 million, or 8.9 percent, in August, the Federal Labor Office said today.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Avnet Inc.'s $100 million issue of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2013 was priced at par, convertible to common stock at $52 a share, through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: Canadians Demote Pilot Who Ran Out of Fuel
description: Air Canada today demoted for six months the pilot of a Boeing 767 that ran out of fuel because of a mix-up over metric measures and made an emergency landing on an abandoned airstrip.

title: SOME ORIENTAL RUG DEALERS MOVING TO MEADOWLANDS
description: For more than half a century, New York's Oriental rug district has been in old buildings and storefronts spread out over a section of midtown Manhattan that runs from 28th to 34th Streets and from Lexington to Fifth Avenue.

title: C.I.A.'S CENSORSHIP BACKED ON APPEAL
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Central Intelligence Agency's censorship of sections of a highly critical article by a former agent about alleged C.I.A. activities in Latin America and Indonesia.

title: SOMETIME KIND OF LOVE
description: Here in New York we suddenly have an outburst of public hard feeling about toilets. At its center are Mayor Koch and a successful oil man, Leon Hess, whose sideline enterprises include owning a sports company trading under the name ''The New York Jets.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DASHIELL HAMMETT. A Life. By Diane Johnson. 320 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $17.95.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT ; HARD ICE CREAM EASY
description: IT could be said that the world is

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -day horticultural extravaganza begins today - in a church. The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine will display more than 500 arrangements of flowers, fruits, plants and vegetables. St. James chapel will sport a floral carpet from the Garden Club of Canada. The candelabra in the cathedral's central crossing will be garlanded.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEATED IS SEASON OPENER
description: The Islanders appear to be right on course to a fifth consecutive Stanley Cup. They stumbled into the 1983-84 season tonight with the same dispirited play that was their regular-season trademark last year.

title: NEW MEDICAL SCANNER GIVES CLOSER LOOK INSIDE THE BODY
description: A powerful magnetic device that can diagnose strokes and other disorders by pinpointing tissues that are dead or dying deep inside the body was unveiled yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Chad's Leader Said to Agree In Principle to Talk to Rebel
description: At a French-African conference that ended today, the President of Chad was reported to have agreed in principle to talk with the leader of the forces battling his Government.

title: CUOMO SIGNS STATUTE ALLOWING BIG TRUCKS TO USE MAIN ROADS
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he had signed legislation that makes the state's laws conform with new Federal statutes allowing heavier trucks and double- trailer trucks on some state roads.

title: GRAPES ARRIVING FOR HOME WINE MAKER
description: LONG before Luciano Deveto left Naples for Brooklyn his grandmother, who made wine for 55 years, warned him never to drink store wine. ''It will make you sick,'' she said. So for the 25th year Mr. Deveto was at Joe Nito's warehouse at 861 Third Avenue in Brooklyn Saturday morning buying his annual supply of wine grapes. ''Alicante to make red wine, Thompson seedless for white,'' Mr. Deveto said. ''Fifty crates - enough to last to next year.''

title: NEW COACH AT YONKERS HIGH
description: A new football coach and a new athletic director have been named at Yonkers High School, where a 17-year-old student died of heart disease during a football game on Sept. 24.

title: WINE TALK
description: -TIMERS around these parts may recall the name Everett Crosby. Mr. Crosby founded High Tor Vineyards in Rockland County back in the 1940's and proved, probably to his own astonishment as well as that of a lot of other people, that decent grapes could be grown and good wine made from them almost within sight of the George Washington Bridge.

title: WIT AND COLOR MAMRK FENDI, MISSONI
description: Fendi and Missoni, two bulwarks of Italian fashion, presented their spring and summer collections back to back this morning, and there were plenty of surprises.

title: GLOBAL COMPUTER NETWORK SPLIT AS SAFEGUARD
description: The Defense Department, in its biggest step to date against illegal penetration of computers, yesterday split a global computer network into separate parts for military and civilian users, thereby limiting access by university- based researchers, trespassers and possibly spies.

title: SAUDIS MAY BUY OIL SALES NETWORK
description: Saudi Arabia is ''seriously studying'' the purchase of a marketing network abroad to sell oil products from its new refineries, the oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said in an interview. The plan was confirmed by the industry minister, Ghazi al-Gosaibi, in a separate interview.

title: Chairman Named At Furman Selz
description: Edmund A. Hajim, a managing director at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, has been named chairman of Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney, an institutional brokerage firm.

title: AIDS RESEARCH FUNDING FOR ALL CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Financial In Credit Accord
description: The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday in Detroit that its financial subsidiary had entered into agreements with 349 financial institutions to renew $4.2 billion of private credit facilities. The term extends through Sept. 15, 1986.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THINGS TO BE DONE THIS MONTH
description: OCTOBER is a busy month for planting since everything must be in the ground before snow comes. Spring Flowering Bulbs

title: Casinos in Accord On Reinvestment
description: A tentative agreement has been reached on the reinvestment of casino revenues into this city, state officials said today.

title: PARTNERS OIL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Partners Oil Co. has been in Chapter 11 proceedings since April.

title: Jet Car Snaps Speed Record
description: Richard Noble of Britain drove Thrust 2, a jet-powered car, to a world land-speed record Tuesday with a time of 633.606 miles per hour.

title: Advertising; Improving Ties With Agencies
description: An ever-popular topic when advertisers gather is ''How to get the best from your advertising agency.''

title: 'Rear Window' Breaks Records at 3 Theaters
description: ''Rear Window,'' an Alfred Hitchcock thriller which began its first commercial theatrical run in 15 years last Sunday, broke one-day box office records at three Manhattan theaters.The film took in $10,595 at the 500-seat Cinema 1 and Cinema 2 Theaters and earned $6,627 at the D.W. Griffith Theater.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First City Federal Savings and Loan Association, Bradenton, Fla., has promoted James J. Heagerty to chairman and chief executive, and James W. Shaw to president and chief operating officer.

title: DODGERS TIE AT 1-1
description: His manager calls him The Incredible Bulk. His 240-plus pounds notwithstanding, LaMarr Hoyt continued his incredible pitching streak today, foiling the Baltimore Orioles on five hits as the Chicago White Sox won the opening game of the American League playoff, 2-1.

title: LANDMARK GROUP PLANS USES FOR BILTMORE FUNDS
description: For all of its 10 years, the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a nonprofit group dedicated to the preservation of noteworthy buildings, has had to ''beg, beg, beg, day after day'' simply to stay in business, according to its chairman, Brendan Gill.

title: Davis to Replace Giulini For Los Angeles's Tour
description: Andrew Davis will replace Carlo Maria Giulini as conductor for the East Coast tour of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in November and December. Mr. Giulini suffered a bronchial illness last spring, and has been dissuaded by his doctors from undertaking the rigors of a tour now, according to Ernest Fleischmann, the orchestra's executive director.

title: STAGE: 'LITTLE MADNESS' IN GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: ''ALITTLE MADNESS'' is a lot of foolishness. The Gerald Zipper play that opened last night at the Provincetown Playhouse is not so much a vanity production as a futility production. It does nothing for the reputations of the actors, director or would- be playwright, not to mention the school psychologists, policemen, waiters and butchers who are the objects of Mr. Zipper's amateurish jeremiad.

title: POP SCULPTURE IN DENVER
description: A New York artist's 3,000 pound pop-art interpretation of a cowboy and Indian shoot- out has been deemed out of step with the memory of the Old West that this new city likes to celebrate.

title: Eruption of Kilauea Volcano
description: The Kilauea volcano shot fiery lava 700 feet into the sky today in the 10th major phase of an eruption that began in January. ''This could be some of the highest fountaining we've seen since January,'' said Robert Decker, the scientist in charge at the United States Geological Survey observatory, which is 12 miles up the slope.

title: LITTLE, BROWN REJECTS NEW NORMAN MIAILER NOVEL
description: ''Tough Guys Don't Dance,'' the novel completed just last Friday by Norman Mailer, was rejected yesterday by Little, Brown & Company, the publisher that Mr. Mailer is leaving in favor of Random House, with which he recently signed a $4 million contract.

title: BULLION RESERVE'S LINKS TO FAILED BANK EXPLORED
description: Officials today refused to disclose the contents of a suicide tape left by Alan David Saxon, the 39-year-old chairman of Bullion Reserve of America who killed himself last week.

title: Army, After Inquiry, Clarifies How a G.I. Died in Honduras
description: A young United States soldier heading back to his base after a night in a Honduran town picked up a ride in a truck that hurtled over an embankment, killing him, the Army said in closing a special investigation into the death.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOMEOWNERS who leave their houses unoccupied for weeks at a time during the cold months and owners of vacation cottages that are being closed for the winter should take a number of important steps to protect against damage from freezing weather and winter storms.

title: Dream Succeeds
description: Ed Bowes, the former runner for Manhattan College who established the Manhattan College interscholastic cross-country meet in 1973, is now pondering whether his dream has become too successful.

title: Elway Is Benched
description: John Elway, the rookie quarterback for the Denver Broncos, lost his starting job yesterday and was replaced by Steve DeBerg, the former starter.

title: VIOLIN RECITAL: MIRIAM FRIED
description: MIRIAM FRIED, who presented a violin recital in Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon, has long had all the necessary credentials for a performing career. A Rumanian-born Israeli citizen, Miss Fried won first prize at the Paganini International Competition in 1968, and later won the Queen Elisabeth Competition in Brussels.

title: SCI-MED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $90,000 for the quarter and $149,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a tax credit of $59,000.

title: AWARD TO WALESA HAILED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan, urging the Polish Government to end the confrontation with its citizens, today hailed the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Lech Walesa as a ''triumph of moral force over brute force.''

title: 3 Aluminum Start-Ups Set
description: Three aluminum companies, citing increased demand, have announced plans to restart potlines.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TOUGH TRANSIT MANAGER
description: When Robert R. Kiley was appointed head of Boston's mass-transit authority in 1975, it was the most profligate government agency in the state. The year before his arrival, it had to apply for eight extra budget appropriations. But during Mr. Kiley's four-year tenure at the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, he ran it at a profit.
