Service improved in minority areas of the city and productivity from the carmen's union increased. Ridership rose in each of the four years.

title: Snow and Wind Atop Everest Delay American Team Again
description: Two days of heavy snow and 50-mile- an-hour winds made an American team postpone starting the final leg of its ascent of Mount Everest, the Ministry of Tourism said today.

title: New Issues Set Record
description: Companies selling stock publicly for the first time set a volume record in the third quarter, raising $3.86 billion, according to New Issues, a newsletter that tracks the new securities market. The previous record of $3.26 billion was set in 1982's second quarter. A total of 277 companies entered the equity markets for the first time in the third quarter, the newsletter said.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bill Seeks Educational TV
description: Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, introduced a bill today that would force all commercial stations to offer at least one hour each weekday of ''programming designed to enhance the education of children.''

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COOKE, 'GRAVELY ILL,' CONTINUES TO RECEIVE BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke is ''gravely ill,'' aides said yesterday, and is continuing to receive heavy doses of medication and blood transfusions at his residence behind St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Suspect in a Slaying For Revenge Is Caught
description: A widower sought by the Florida authorities in the revenge slaying of a neurosurgeon who had operated on the suspect's wife was arrested in Colorado today, the police said.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nippon Plans 2 U.S. Deals
description: Japan's Government-owned telecommunications monopoly, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, said today that it would buy products from two American companies.

title: HOME BEAT
description: JOHN LATHAM, special consultant to the Educational Foundation for the Fashion Industries, thought that they should be seen in New York.

title: Speculators Push Amstar Stock Up
description: Speculators bid up the price of the Amstar Corporation's stock, apparently on the hope that a second bidder would appear to rival the proposed Amstar acquisition by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: 66 Nonprofit Groups Assail Lobbying Curbs
description: Sixty- six organizations ranging from Planned Parenthood to the Girls Clubs of America protested to President Reagan today that a proposal to keep them from spending Federal funds on lobbying went too far.

title: AIDS REASEARCH FUNDING FOR ALL CITIZENS
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Democratic Candidates All on a Single Stage
description: The forums started in Albany with an appearance by Reubin Askew, former Governor of Florida. They end tonight when, for the first time in the campaign, all seven Democratic candidates for President share a stage.

title: CHEVY TURNS TO THE JAPANESE
description: Beset by slumping sales, money-losing small cars and intense competition from Japanese imports, Chevrolet has been the most troubled of General Motors' five automobile divisions.

title: STUART, D A, OIL CO LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: Year-ago net income was restated for an accounting change. All results are in U. S. dollars.

title: Japan Takes Lead in Tools
description: Japan took over world leadership from the United States last year in the $22 billion machine tool industry - a standard for measuring a country's wealth, according to a United States Government report issued today.

title: Dr. Milton Silver Dead at 58; Orthodontist and an Inventor
description: Dr. Milton Silver, chief of orthodontia at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Ex-Journalist Heads The Prize Committee
description: The Norwegian Nobel Committee, which today awarded the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize to Lech Walesa, is composed of two writers, a law professor, a farmer and a movie censor.

title: MUSIC: URUGUAYAN PIANIST
description: HOMERO FRANCESCH, a pianist from Uruguay, returned to the Metropolitan Museum Monday night. He is a very interesting young player - with a fine ear for sound and an ability to express sophisticated musical ideas with directness and simplicity and no trace of artifice or calculation.

title: A Taste of the Deep
description: A fireboat spewed the traditional welcome as the Europa, the new German cruise ship, arrived on her maiden visit to New York yesterday. She leaves this evening for Baltimore and the South.

title: TWinning Football Team Craves Fans
description: There is a hunger within the football community at Nassau Community College. The players are starved for attention.

title: CALEENDAR: FLOWERS, CRAFTS AND ANTIQUES
description: Regionalism in American Landscape Design, Wave Hill, 675 West 252d Street, Riverdale section of the Bronx, 212-549-2055. On Saturday, Oct. 15, from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., Wave Hill will present its third annual conference on American garden history. Dr. Diana Balmori, visiting fellow in history at Yale University, will be among the speakers, and she will discuss ''Region: Tradition and Ideology.''

title: A Panel Backs Increase To I.R.A. Contributions
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, in a surprise move tonight, approved an amendment allowing taxpayers to contribute as much as an additional $1,750 to their individual retirement accounts, or I.R.A.'s.

title: PHILIPPINES DEVALUES CURRENCY 21.4%
description: The Philippine Government devalued its currency by more than 20 percent today in response to financial pressures that have apparently been aggravated by political opposition to President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: FORTUNE SYSTEMS OUSTS HEAD
description: The Fortune Systems Corporation, the increasingly troubled Silicon Valley manufacturer of office computer systems, said yesterday that its board had forced Gary B. Friedman, its founder and chairman, to resign.

title: WASTE SITES FOUND VIOLATING U.S. LAW
description: Fifty- one of 65 licensed hazardous waste dumps that were checked in two states this year were violating the Federal laws under which they received their permits, according to a Government report released today.

title: 2 Men Convicted Of Killing Woman
description: A State Supreme Court jury convicted two men of murder last night in the suffocation slaying of a 91-year- old woman, Dunie Lewis, in her apartment in Rochdale Village, Queens, on Sept. 18 of last year.

title: SCHOOL LUNCH RULE CONTESTED
description: A Federal district judge today took under advisement a request by the school boards of five large cities, including New York, to throw out a Federal rule requiring them to sample the eligibility of children receiving free or reduced- price school lunches.

title: NOBEL COMMITTEE STATEMENT
description: Following is the text, in official translation, of a statement by the Norwegian Nobel Committee today:

title: TV: 'GERMAN-AMERICANS'
description: THERE are supposed to be 50 million Americans, almost a quarter of the population, who are of German descent at least a little, a trifle, or in part. ''The German-Americans: 300 Years in the New Land'' looks at those in whom the German heritage may still be seen. The documentary will be shown on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: Tour by Soviet Appears Revived
description: A hockey series between the American national team and a Soviet squad will apparently take place despite an earlier announcement that it had been canceled, Walter Bush, the chairman of the United States Olympic Hockey Committee, said Tuesday.

title: Shamir Reports Success In Forming a Cabinet
description: Prime Minister- designate Yitzhak Shamir formally notified the Speaker of Parliament today that he had succeeded in forming a new Government.

title: CONCERT: ZINA SCHIFF, VIOLINIST
description: ZINA SCHIFF'S third New York violin recital Tuesday at the Abraham Goodman House was a boldly programmed, expertly played evening of music. The repertory was all American, and although Miss Schiff only rarely ventured into dissonant avant- gardism, her selection still made up a demanding - if rewarding - experience for both her and her attentive audience.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Advance in Prices Expected;  Bellwether Bond at 105 1/2
description: Maybe it was wishful thinking, but a number of bond dealers were predicting yesterday that the credit markets were poised for a further price rise. And some dealers cited bits of hard evidence to back up their point.

title: Tidewater Slump
description: Tidewater Inc., a supplier of marine support services in the offshore oil service industry, said earnings for the fiscal second quarter, which ended Sept. 30, were as much as 80 percent below the 83 cents a share that it earned in the period a year before.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POET AND DREAMER

title: HARD TIMES, FOR ZAIRE'S PRESIDENT, ARE HUMBLING
description: Three weeks ago Zaire devalued its currency overnight by 80 percent. Two days ago armed plainclothesmen attached to the office of President Mobutu Sese Seko swept through this capital city at dawn to search every hotel room for weapons.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Bridge: Italy Defeats France in Rally And Will Face Aces in Final
description: Amid intense excitement, irony and legal confusion, Italy snatched a semifinal victory from France here this afternoon, qualifying to meet the Aces in the final on Thursday.

title: WNBC NEWSCASTER WAS 69
description: John K. M. McCaffery, a radio and television newscaster, master of ceremonies and quiz-show host for nearly three decades, died Monday at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Conn. He was 69 years old and had lived in Litchfield, Conn., since his retirement in 1967.

title: LATE SURGE HELPS DOW RISE 13.51
description: The stock market recorded a strong gain in heavy trading yesterday as investors reacted to an array of positive factors.

title: HEINRICH BOLL TILTS HIS PEN AT WEAPONS
description: Heinrich B"oll, the only German postwar winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, has an engaging way of pulling out a thought or an assertion, with a slow drag on a cigarette, and then appending to it the disarming German phrase ''oder nicht?'' The phrase, literally ''or not?'' is a shorthand way of saying, ''What do you think?'' or even, ''Maybe I'm wrong.''

title: NUCLEAR CARGO SHIPMENT STARTS UPSTATE
description: Amid objections from local officials along the way, a shipment of spent nuclear fuel cells from the West Valley Demonstration Project has begun, according to eyewitnesses.

title: CRUCIAL INTERESTS IN ASIA
description: Among the threats America faces in Asia are pressing challenges in three strategically important countries - Pakistan, South Korea and the Philippines - where internal instabilities create possibilities for damaging political upheavals. American strategic interests often conflict with our human rights concerns, but in these three nations they dovetail, for long-term American security interests would be enhanced by their establishment of more open political systems.

title: LABOR PARLEY ENDORSES MONDALE FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention, with minimal dissent, today endorsed their leaders' decision to back former Vice President Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for 5 percent stock dividend.

title: NETS' RICHARDSON CAN'T BE LOCATED
description: The Nets said today that Michael Ray Richardson had failed to attend practice in training camp and could not be located.

title: Arizona Utility Plans Bond Sale
description: The Arizona Public Service Company said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of $250 million in first mortgage bonds.

title: Court Won't Shift Brink's Trial of 2
description: A New York State appeals court yesterday denied a motion by two defendants to move their trial in the Brink's murder and robbery case out of Orange County.

title: 2,600 SEEK PAY VOTE AT EASTERN
description: A petition signed by nearly half the membership of Eastern Airlines' flight attendants' union was presented directly yesterday to Frank Borman, chairman and chief executive of the ailing carrier. It asks that the members be allowed to vote on a proposal to cut wages by l5 percent to avert a bankruptcy filing by the airline.

title: Trying to Crack Down At 39 Whitehall Street
description: To many, the building at 39 Whitehall Street is a symbol of the Army.

title: A Roosevelt Returns
description: James Roosevelt, 76 years old, returned yesterday to his boyhood home at 47 East 65th Street. ''The neighborhood hasn't changed much,'' he said as he glanced at the top of the five-story building.

title: WEINBERGER HAILS CHINA TIES
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that China and the United States faced a ''common threat'' from the Soviet Union.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
Smaller Waiting Period Set for U.S. Auctions
description: A Treasury official said at a meeting of the Public Securities Association here today that the Government would reduce the number of days between the announcement of new Treasury note and bond issues and the auctions of those issues.

title: Florida Parole Board Votes to Free Canadian
description: Sidney Jaffe, a Canadian businessman who was abducted by United States bounty hunters and convicted in Florida of land sales violations, will be paroled Oct. 11, the State Parole and Probation Commission decided today. However, Mr. Jaffe faces another charge in Florida,

title: Flogging and Torture Reported in Pakistan
description: The leader of a Pakistani right- of-center opposition party accused the authorities today of torturing political prisoners and carrying out flogging sentences on jailed protesters.

title: IMMIGRATION AND POLITICS
description: Supporters of a comprehensive immigration bill have boasted that they were taking a bipartisan or nonpartisan approach. But Tuesday's indefinite postponement of Congressional action on the bill illustrates the perils of underestimating the political importance of a powerful lobby.

title: Addenda
description: * Field & Stream magazine increasing its advertising rates 8.5 percent with the January issue.

title: EAST GERMAN AFFIRMS GUN WORK
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, said today that all the booby-trap guns along the border with West Germany would be removed.

title: Williams Changes
description: The Williams Companies, which has acquired about 71 percent of of the Northwest Energy Company's shares outstanding, announced that five Northwest directors - including the chairman and chief executive officer, John G. McMillian - had resigned and been replaced by Williams nominees. Williams also said that Northwest's president, Thomas W. Dizerega, had resigned, and that Joseph H. Williams, chairman and chief executive officer of Williams, would become chairman of Northwest. Williams, an energy concern based in Tulsa, Okla., is offering $39 a share for Northwest's 29.8 milllion shares.

title: NEW ISSUE 'COMPELLED' A JUSTICE TO BAR EXECUTION, DESPITE POLICY
description: Already strapped down on a wheeled stretcher with intravenous tubes inserted into the veins of his arms, James David Autry came within minutes of meeting his date with the executioner's needle early on this sultry autumn morning in East Texas.

title: LABOR'S BIG RISK IN BACKING MONDALE
description: The leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. have decided to take a historic, high- stakes gamble - their first endorsement ever of a Presidential candidate before the primary elections. They may be making a grave mistake.

title: HERS
description: A FRIENDSHIP QUIZ: If something wonderful happens to you today, which of your friends will you tell? Who do you go to with your personal or romantic problems? Who would you want to visit you in the hospital? Who could you call if you needed someone to talk to at 3 A.M.?

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Salute to Garcia Marquez
description: Back home in Colombia, the affectionate nickname for the Nobel Prize author Gabriel Garcia Marquez is ''Gabo.''

title: G.M. Will Reopen A Plant in Georgia
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it plans to reopen its idled assembly plant in Lakewood, Ga., and transfer full-size car production from Oshawa, Ontario, to Wilmington, Del.

title: POP: NICK SILVER AT THE LONE STAR
description: THOSE who came to see Nick Silver at the Lone Star on Monday might reasonably have expected to hear some psychedelic rock. After all, the band includes former members of Quicksilver Messenger Service, Electric Flag, Spirit and the Jerry Garcia Band.

title: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $573,000 for the quarter and $1,304,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $237,000 for the quarter and $355,000 for the 9 months.

title: STAGE: YIDDISH REVUE, 'LET THERE BE JOY'
description: the last seven at the Norman Thomas Theater, at 33d Street and Park Avenue - Ben Bonus and Mina Bern, his wife, have resumed their laudable task of breathing life into the Yiddish theater. This time it is with a warm, zestful revue called ''Let There Be Joy,'' which opened last weekend and which uses or adapts the music and writings of such giants of the Yiddish theater as Goldfaden, Aleichem, Rumshinsky and Secunda.

title: TASS DISMISSES REAGAN'S 'BUILD DOWN' IDEA
description: In the first Soviet reaction to President Reagan's new strategic arms proposals, Tass, the official press agency, said in a dispatch from Washington today that the suggestions were ''nothing but words.''

title: BEVERLY BOND
description: Beverly Bond, a literary agent and book-marketing specialist, died yesterday in Houston after a short illness.

title: S I HANDLING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Dempsey Uses Head To Stop Double Play
description: In trying to break up a double-play at second base in the sixth inning of the game yesterday, Rick Dempsey of the Orioles did the unconventional: He stuck his head in the way of a thrown baseball. ''I didn't mean to make contact with the ball,'' he said afterward, ''that's for sure. I just didn't slide in time.''

title: Forbes Is Honored
description: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes Inc., has been elected ''1983 Publisher of the Year'' by the executive committee of the Magazine Publishers Association. Mr. Forbes, the recipient of the magazine industry's highest honor, the Henry Johnson Fisher Award, which goes to a magazine leader who has made significant and longstanding contributions to the publishing business, will receive the award at a dinner in January.

title: Chilean Riot Police Disperse First Legal Opposition Rally
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 5 (AP) Riot police used water cannon, tear gas and buckshot tonight to disperse several thousand young people who had gathered for the first legal opposition rally under military rule.

title: Putting Congress on Hold
description: The Federal Communications Commission wants residential telephone users to pay $2 a month and businesses as much as $6 a month for access to long distance. But Congress, fearful of a backlash when the proposed rates start in January, threatens to overrule the decision. That would be an ill-informed mistake.

title: REAGAN RIDICULES DEMOCRATIC RIVALS AS 'OLD MEN OF WASHINGTON'
description: President Reagan mocked the Democratic Presidential aspirants today as ''the old men of Washington,'' contending he offered voters newer ideas than the ''political Rip Van Winkles'' who want his job.

title: MANUAL ON CARE OF COMMUNITY GARDENS
description: Tucked away in the canyons of New York are over 400 community parks and gardens maintained by volunteers. To assist them the Neighborhood Open Space Coalition has published a Park/Garden Maintenance Manual filled with information on pruning trees, planting bulbs - and raising money.

title: UNITY STEPS URGED FOR PROTESTANTS
description: Theologians from major Reformed and Lutheran churches are recommending that their congregations jointly celebrate holy communion, grant full recognition to one another's clergy and plan ''common mission projects'' that could include the formation of Protestant congregations that are both Lutheran and Presbyterian.

title: CBS Publications Names Publisher
description: CBS Publications has named Thomas M. Kenney, 36 years old, vice president and group publisher of the Women's Magazine Group, and publisher of Woman's Day magazine, succeeding Peter G. Diamandis, who was named president of the Consumer Publishing division last week.

title: EVERYONE'S PERFECTLY SURE REAGAN'LL RUN, AND YET...
description: With some alarm, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee cornered Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada the other day to share the latest freshet of Republican gossip coursing through the Capitol.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Agents Uncover Horse-Drug Sales
description: Justice Department investigators have uncovered evidence that a Florida drug supplier sold illegal stimulants to nearly 270 horse trainers and race-track veterinarians in at least 11 states, according to testimony at his Federal trial in Uniondale, L.I.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES $250 BILLION FOR MILITARY
description: With little debate or controversy, the Defense Subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a bill to appropriate almost $250 billion in military spending in the 1984 fiscal year.

title: BECKER MILK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dayton-Hudson
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation plans to spend $2.4 billion between 1983 and 1987 on capital improvements, its vice chairman, Richard Schall, told the news media and bankers. The heaviest spending is expected to occur this year and next and focus on acquiring new sites for expansion of the company's store chains, he said. Mr. Schall said 85 percent of the capital expenditures in 1983 to 1987 will be concentrated on the company's most successful growth areas, the retail chain stores Target and Mervyn's.

title: Out of Boston, Into the Fire
description: Robert Kiley knows mass transit. Five years as chief of Boston's transportation authority is as harsh a test as New Yorkers could ask for in a new Metropolitan Transportation Authority head.

title: Bonn a Stout Ally, Visitor Tells Congress
description: President Karl Carstens of West Germany, saying ''good intentions alone are not enough to preserve peace,'' told a joint session of Congress today that his country would not waiver in its commitment to strengthen the Western alliance.

title: Mistrial Declared for Woman In a Child Pornography Case
description: A mistrial was delared Tuesday in the case of a woman accused of heading one of the nation's biggest child pornography rings after the jury failed to reach a verdict.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 6, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CUBA SAID TO HOLD NICARAGUA TALKS
description: Senior Cuban officials have held a series of meetings with an anti-Sandinista rebel group to exchange views and measure the chances of future negotiations between the rebels and Managua, according to diplomats and leftist sources in Central America.

title: NEW MUSEUM WILL OPEN IN SOHO HOME SATURDAY
description: The New Museum of Contemporary Art, a voice for the most contemporary art since it was founded as the New Museum in 1977, will open to the public in its new SoHo home Saturday.

title: S.E.C. ASKS PARADYNE COURT ACTION M
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked a Federal judge to hold the Paradyne Corporation in contempt of court on the ground that the data-processing equipment company is deliberately thwarting an investigation into charges that it used fraud to obtain a $100 million Government computer contract.

title: PANEL SEEKS SUCCESSOR
description: The American Ballet Theater announced yesterday that Herman Krawitz, its executive director, was ending his ''executive association'' with the company.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 1.

title: BRIEFINGATE, PHASE II
description: Was Brie fingate - the procurement of President Carter's debate briefing papers by the Reagan campaign - merely media ''midsummer madness,'' abetted by sore-losing Carterites and a publicity-hungry Congressman? Or was it the first phase of a yearlong process destined to bedevil and besmirch the Reagan White House?

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HIGH LIFE FADES AT LABOR TALKS
description: Labor leaders have been journeying for years to the east coast of Florida for their conferences and fetes. This began in the time of the old American Federation of Labor, whose leaders enjoyed the sun and salt winds.

title: LYRICAL COLOMBIAN BRINGS THE U.N. TO ITS FEET
description: Standing ovations are unusual in the General Assembly, which in the last 10 days has been addressed by 66 heads of state, foreign ministers and others. Today, the 67th speaker, President Belisario Betancur of Colombia, brought delegates to their feet with a highly personal and philosophical address.

title: New Sabre Goalie Successful in Debut
description: Tom Barrasso, the Buffalo goaltender, made the jump from American high school hockey to the National Hockey League a successful one tonight as the Sabres beat the Hartford Whalers, 5-3, at Memorial Auditorium in the season opener for both teams.

title: Joseph H. Reiner Dead at 71; Crown Publishers Executive
description: Joseph H. Reiner, a book buyer and publisher for more than 50 years, died Sunday in Miami Beach. He was 71 years old.

title: AN EVENING OF BENEFITS FOR ANTIQUES AND CRAFTS
description: DR. ROBERT BISHOP, the director of the Museum of American Folk Art, came back from Europe just in time. Like many other luminaries in the field of folk art and antiques, he didn't want to miss the opening of what has become one of the most popular exhibitions of its kind - the Fall Antiques Show.

title: THE CASE FOR CLINCH RIVER
description: To the Editor:

title: FASHION IN MILAN: VERSACE, BIAGIOTTI, SOPRANI
description: Slithery knee-length tunics slide over narrow pants in the lightest of woolen fabrics at Gianni Versace. Over them go thin loose coats, all in navy, white or a striped combination of the two. They present a distinctive variant on the ubiquitous spring suit. At Laura Biagiotti, mannequins raced down the runway in short knitted cashmere dresses with comfortably deep armholes and ribbed scarfs around the neck. The dresses, scarfs and matching tights are all a bright, cheerful red.

title: MANY POLES REACT HAPPILY TO WALESA'S PRIZE BUT THE GOVERNMENT IS GLUM
description: The announcement that Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity trade union, had been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize was greeted with expressions of happiness and satisfaction by many Poles and with a glum near-silence by the Government.

title: BONNIE BEDELIA AS A RACE-CAR DRIVER
description: JONATHAN KAPLAN'S ''Heart Like a Wheel'' is about a sports figure who struggles to the top of a grueling profession. Since the character is a real woman, racing driver Shirley ''Cha Cha'' Muldowney, and since her triumph seems in some ways a very lonely one, this biographical film is something out of the ordinary. Its story is unusual, but it's told in a style that is immediate and understandable, and that never opts for heroism at the expense of authenticity. The movie doesn't concentrate on glorifying its heroine. It simply tries to make her seem reachable and real, and it succeeds.

title: STATE ACCUSES CAR RENTERS OF BIAS AGAINST YOUTHS
description: Almost all car-rental companies in New York State illegally discriminate against young drivers and drivers without credit cards, according to a state report issued yesterday.

title: First Victory, at 26, Revives a Dream
description: With losses piling up and thoughts of retirement crowding her mind, Kim Shaefer, a 26-year-old tennis professional, sought a few hours of escape in a movie theater last spring. The film was ''Flashdance,'' and one line - ''If you give up your dreams, you die'' - caught her attention.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results reflect restructuring costs.

title: Australian Good Will
description: In a final gesture of good will before leaving Newport, R.I., with the America's Cup, the Australia II syndicate donated more than two tons of food, blankets and linen to a local charitable agency. ''We didn't just want to take from the city of Newport, we wanted to give something in return,'' said Daniel Wilkins, a syndicate spokesman who confirmed the gift to the Dr. Martin Luther King Center of Newport.

title: Top Post at Intelsat Going to an American
description: Richard R. Colino, a 46-year-old telecommunications entrepreneur, will become chief executive officer of Intelsat, the international communications satellite cooperative based in Washington, at the end of the year.

title: PAPP URGES A NATIONAL THEATER ON BROADWAY
description: Joseph Papp is proposing that a national theater be created on Broadway with a combination of private and public financing.

title: Why the Rush to Kill?
description: When the stay order reached the Texas executioners, they had already begun their work by injecting a saline solution to prepare the veins of James Autry for the chemical that would kill him. Had Supreme Court Justice Byron White not intervened, the condemned man would have become the clearest victim yet of the Supreme Court's impatience with death penalty delays. The grisly incident makes clear the need for the high court to contain that impatience.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arrow Electronics Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it had agreed to acquire High Technology Distribution Inc., a distributor of computer products, for stock valued at about $8.5 million.

title: ABC FILM DEPICTING CONSEQUENCES OF NUCLEAR ATTACK STIRRING DEBATE
description: The ABC-TV film ''The Day After,'' which graphically depicts the consequences of massive nuclear attack against the United States, is not scheduled to appear for seven weeks, but already it is generating emotional controversy on both sides of the nuclear-arms issue.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
NEW YORK C.D. RATES RANKED HIGHEST IN U.S.
description: New York financial institutions are paying at least a percentage point more than banks in other parts of the country to attract customers to newly deregulated certificates of deposit, according to a nationwide survey released yesterday.

title: MACY'S FLORIDA STORE IS RESPONSE TO GROWTH
description: With much fanfare, R. H. Macy & Company will open its first Florida store, a three- story white stucco building with a sloping terra-cotta tiled roof, in North Miami's Aventura Mall Thursday.

title: 3 BLACKS WAGE OFTEN BITTER CAMPAIGN TO BE MAYOR OF MEMPHIS
description: Three black candidates will be challenging a white incumbent when voters go to the polls Thursday to elect Memphis's next mayor.

title: LABOR ORGANIZER WITH A TALL DREAM
description: For Lech Walesa, this has been a difficult year.

title: Ticket-Rule Delay Sought
description: The Justice Department, concluding that there is a ''clear need for industry- wide rules'' governing the computerized reservation systems used by travel agents to book airline flights, today asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to extend the deadline for comments on its rulemaking procedure by one month, to Nov. 17.

title: Chemical Workers in Austria Clash With Conservationists
description: Fights broke out between supporters of the international conservation group Greenpeace and workers at an Austrian chemical plant during a protest today against the deadly chemical dioxin, the police said.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SUMMONING. By Robert Towers. 336 pages. Harper and Row. $15.95.

title: Network Is Proposed For Organ Transplants
description: A bill that would outlaw the buying and selling of human organs and establish a nationwide transplant network was introduced in the House today.

title: WITNESS SAYS WILSON PLOTTED DEATHS
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former intelligence agent, was portrayed by the prosecution in his trial yesterday as a convicted arms dealer who had plotted in prison to murder his former wife, two prosecutors and several witnesses.

title: 2 Rail Deaths Tied To Traffic Change
description: Two Amtrak workers killed by a train on a Kearny railroad bridge early Sunday apparently were unaware that their was traffic from both directions on the track where they were struck, an investigator has found.

title: ARGENTINA MOVES TO CLEAR BARRIER TO TALKS ON LOANS
description: A federal appeals court today removed a major obstacle to the resumption of the international negotiations needed to refinance Argentina's huge foreign debt and to keep fresh loans flowing into the country.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $460,000 for the quarter and year reflecting a writeoff of leases. c-Net income.

title: MAN CONVICTED IN SLAYING TIED TO U.S. INQUIRY
description: Salvatore Odierno was convicted last night of first-degree manslaughter for the slaying of a witness in a Federal investigation.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
JURY CONVICTS SLAYER OF 13 IN SEATTLE'S CHINATOWN
description: A 22-year-old immigrant from Hong Kong was found guilty today of murdering 13 people and seriously wounding another person in a robbery at a Chinatown gambling club last Feb. 19.

title: WATER PROBLEM ROILING L.I. DISTRICT'S RESIDENTS
description: Mildred McDonough's electric range was crowded today. The tea kettle was whistling and other water bubbled in three pots. Mrs. McDonough was boiling water for her family to drink.

title: LABORITES VOW TO GIVE UP NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Labor Party strengthened its commitment to nuclear disarmament today, rejecting assertions that its policy contributed heavily to its defeat in the June 9 general election.

title: INDETERMINATE EFFECT OF FIXED PRISON SENTENCING
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LEBANON AGREES TO THIRD-WORLD TRUCE FORCE
description: President Amin Gemayel has agreed to accept observers from countries professing nonalignment to supervise a Lebanese cease-fire, a Foreign Ministry official said today.

title: DCNY CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on June 15.

title: CHAMBER: CAMERATA BERN
description: year-old chamber orchestra from the capital of Switzerland, has recorded several albums of early music for the Archiv label and toured countries in Europe, but until Tuesday night it had not been heard in this country. Because the group was virtually unknown here, it was scarcely surprising that the audience for the American debut in Carnegie Hall was small.

title: Vauxhall Strike Ends
description: Engineers and assembly workers at the Vauxhall Motor Company's plant here voted today to end their strike following a similar vote by workers at plants in Dunstable and Luton. The strike began last Friday. Union leaders here said they still reject the company's 7.75 percent pay offer and the fight for a better wage would continue inside the plant.

title: Executive at Travelers Aids Financial Planners
description: Financial decisions for most people have grown complicated in recent years. The array of products and services available from banks, brokers and insurance companies, among others, has led to confusing choices, and for many families, inflation and bracket creep have made tax planning an important consideration.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net loss.

title: PIE IN THE SKY
description: It is the American dream: The adventurous young capitalist makes a better widget for less and outsells the inefficient old companies. But suppose the old firms - and their unions - have political muscle. They run to Congress and demand instant passage of a bill outlawing competition in the widget business.

title: LAWYERS SUM UP IN AUTO-DEATH TRIAL
description: The lawyer for a youth charged with murdering a Hispanic boy with his car said in his summation today that two weeks of testimony had produced 10 areas of reasonable doubt that the boy had been struck because of ethnic bias. The prosecution said a recantation by its key witness was a lie.

title: LECH WALESA WINS NOBEL PEACE PRIZE FOR UNION EFFORT
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Poland's Solidarity labor union, was awarded the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize today for his struggle for workers' rights.

title: LITTLE, BROWN REJECTS NEW NORMAN MAILER NOVEL
description: ''Tough Guys Don't Dance,'' the novel completed just last Friday by Norman Mailer, was rejected yesterday by Little, Brown & Company, the publisher that Mr. Mailer is leaving in favor of Random House, with which he recently signed a $4 million contract.

title: BRAZIL ASKS TO EXTEND LOANS
description: Representatives of the 66 banks that are coordinating loans to Brazil are to meet in Washington today to discuss terms under which $5.5 billion in Brazilian debts would be refinanced and new loans would be granted for $6.5 billion.

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRA OF SWEDEN
description: IT is easy to forget, during the recess between music seasons,

title: OAKLAND TALKS HALTED
description: Striking Oakland teachers rejected the school board's latest offer tonight and broke off talks in a contract dispute that has prompted thousands of students to stay away from understaffed schools.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Vince Dooley, the Georgia football coach, suspended two players indefinitely for violating training rules. They are Kenny Simms, a starting defensive guard, and Stan Dooley, a reserve defensive end, who is not related to the coach. . . . Dave Stapleton, the first baseman for the Boston Red Sox, underwent minor surgery for removal of a spur on the right hand which plagued him most of the season. . . . Andre Dawson, the center fielder for the Montreal Expos, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee to correct swelling.

title: Berkey Forecast
description: Berkey Photo Inc. said at its annual meeting that it expects to report third-quarter net income of more than $2 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with $791,000, or 16 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Berkey was one of the biggest percentage gainers, rising 75 cents, to $7.125.

title: Axia Holdings
description: Axia Inc. said the financier Victor Posner, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said he plans to increase his holdings in the company to more than 25 percent, from 16.1 percent.

title: French Output Up
description: France's gross domestic product rose five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, revised from a gain of two- tenths of 1 percent, the Government's statistics institute said today. This compared with a decline of two- tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter and a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent a year earlier.

title: Talks on Acid Rain Starting in Quebec
description: Representatives of the eight states bordering the Great Lakes are to begin a two-day meeting Thursday with talks on acid rain.

title: Technology; Touch Screen: Views Mixed
description: WHEN Hewlett-Packard introduced the first personal computer with a touch screen two weeks ago, it was a major vote of approval for a technology that had been around for more than a decade without much success.

title: CHILD ABUSE CARRIED INTO THE STREETS
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKS ON STRATEGIC ARMS RENEWED IN GENEVA
description: President Reagan's new proposals for cutbacks in intercontinental nuclear weapons were presented here today at the opening of a new round of American-Soviet talks.

title: Kohl Is Off on Mideast Tour
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany left today for Jordan on a seven-day tour of the Middle East to assess chances for resuming peace talks there. In addition to Jordan, Mr. Kohl will also visit Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

title: U.S. Move on Ulster Urged
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, joined by four other Senators, urged President Reagan today to appoint a special envoy to see how the United States could assist in resolving the conflict in Northern Ireland. Senator Moynihan said the proposal was similar to one offered recently by Irish- American groups in New York State.

title: New von B"ulow Witness Reports Getting Threats
description: A 24-hour guard will protect a surprise witness who says the comatose heiress Martha von B"ulow was given drugs by her son.

title: RICH SCHOOLS GETTING RICHER AS P.T.A.'S REPLACE LOST AID
description: In New Haven, parent-teacher associations have raised money to hire art and music teachers and librarians.

title: A $544 MILLION BID FOR HARRIS
description: The Bank of Montreal will acquire Chicago's Harris Bankcorp Inc., the 36th-largest bank in the United States, for $544 million (United States), the two organizations announced today.

title: Air Force Indicates a Delay In First Agent Orange Study
description: The Air Force said today it had run into technical problems in analyzing data on the health of about 1,200 men who sprayed the herbicide Agent Orange over Vietnam's jungles. As a result, the service said, it could not disclose the results of the study, expected this month, until next year.

title: CUOMO PETITIONS N.R.C. TO REJECT SHOREHAM PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo has asked the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission to reject an emergency evacuation plan by the Long Island Lighting Company for its Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: ADVERTISING ; Foote, Cone to Acquire North Castle Partners
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications has reached an agreement to acquire North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn.

title: EX-HEAD OF BOSTON TRANSIT AGENCY PICKED BY CUOMO TO LEAD M.T.A.
description: Robert R. Kiley, a former head of the mass-transit system in Boston, has been chosen chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday.

title: A FLOWER DISPLAY BEDECKS ST. JOHN'S
description: AN International Festival of Flowers opened in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday. Everywhere in this vast structure, the largest Gothic cathedral in the world, are vases, urns, pedestals and bowls filled with arrangements of carnations, proteas, gladiolus, chrysanthemums, lilies, statice, roses, daisies and scores of other colorful flowers.

title: 5 CITY DEMOCRATIC LEADERS STEP INTO LIMELIGHT, AND BLUNT TALK FOLLOWS
description: New York City's five Democratic county leaders came from behind the scenes yesterday to give their views on such matters as a third term for Mayor Koch, the party's candidates for President and how judges are selected.

title: EDUCATOR AND FORMER ENVOY
description: Martin F. Herz, director of Georgetown University's Institute for the Study of Diplomacy and former American Ambassador to Bulgaria, died of cancer today at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: Out on the mound, with his beard A Pitcher With 'a Lot of Stomach' and his belly, LaMarr Hoyt resembles a Sunday softball pitcher who belongs in a beer commercial, rather than a Cy Young Award candidate in the American League championship series. But judging by his performance this year, he is the best starting pitcher in baseball. And yesterday, in a 2-1 five-hitter against the Baltimore Orioles, he gave the Chicago White a 1-0 lead in the three-of-five-game fandango that resumes here tonight.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1983
description: International

title: MARKET PLACE
description: LONDON IF the British Government is able to stick to its

title: Olympic Attire
description: When about 700 members of the United States Olympic team march in the opening and closing ceremonies in Los Angeles next year, they will be attired in an Active ensemble designed by Levi Strauss & Company. The uniforms feature red, white and blue zip- front jackets with bold diagonal striping and blue elastic waist sports pants.

title: College Guarantees Jobs for Graduates
description: Graduates of the Brown Mackie College are guaranteed successes. If they do not find a job within 120 days, the school will refund their tuition.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Lech Walesa's activities have been characterized by a determination to solve his country's problems through negotiation and cooperation without resorting to violence.'' - From a citation announcing the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize. (A1:3.)

title: Q & A
description: Q. Some pine flooring boards 8 to 10 inches wide have shrunk, leaving large gaps. Dirt and dust collect in the gaps. Is there any remedy?

title: ON TRAIL OF A LATIN MYSTERY, C.I.A. FOOTPRINTS
description: On Sept. 8, a two-engine Cessna crashed during a bombing raid on Nicaragua's main air base and international airport near Managua, killing the pilot, Agustin M. Roman. Although the identity of the man and his plane were known, almost everything else was a mystery.

title: Tennis Stalemate
description: Four months after a one-year suspension was announced for Guillermo Vilas after he was accused of accepting guarantees to play in a tennis tournament, his case remains unresolved.

title: AIRLINE AND STRIKERS NEGOTIATE
description: Negotiators for Continental Airlines and the pilots' union met today for the first time in the five-day-old strike by pilots and flight attendants.

title: RANGERS OPEN WITH A ROMP
description: The Devils are determined to stick with many young players this season. The Rangers are determined to stick to their style of speed and constant motion.

title: Courthouse Bomb Threat
description: The Cumberland County Courthouse was evacuated today when a man threatened to explode what he said was a bomb strapped to his body, the authorities said. A Fort Bragg ordnance team was called to the scene. Capt. C. B. Morrison of the police said at 1:30 P.M. that the danger was over and that people were being allowed to return to the courthouse. He declined further comment.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split in April 1983.

title: VELASQUEZ RIDES HIS 5,000TH WINNER
description: For one frightening moment in the fourth race at Belmont Park yesterday, it looked as if Jorge Velasquez was going to end up tangled in a hedge instead of being toasted in the winner's circle.

title: HESS SAID TO WEIGH JET MOVE
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that Leon Hess, the principal owner of the Jets, had outlined the problems he has had with the city over a new lease at Shea Stadium, and added that Hess ''may move the team but he hasn't made the final decision yet.''

title: Season Arrives To Hunt Waterfowl
description: Although seacoast gunners associate the sport with bleak winter skies, their inland counterparts are afield before, to borrow a line from Gerard Manley Hopkins, ''worlds of wanwood leafmeal lie'' on the forest floor.

title: JAZZ: BURTON QUARTET
description: THE vibraharpist Gary Burton has changed the fourth instrument of his quartet every few years, from guitar to trumpet to saxophone. A pianist, Makoto Ozone, occupies the hot seat in Mr. Burton's current group, which opened a three-night stint at Seventh Avenue South last Friday.

title: MEETING PONDERS PROFITS IN SPACE
description: When the first Soviet satellite blazed into earth orbit 26 years ago today, many people wondered what practical uses could ever come of going into space.

title: FROM A JETS MUTINEER
description: To the Editor:

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: FALL can be an opportunity to get gardening equipment organized. Various holders will accommodate shovels, rakes, pruners and twine and make finding the right equipment easier.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Gift of Givers

title: New Baltimore Conductor
description: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra today named David Zinman, 47 years old, as conductor beginning with the 1985 season. Mr. Zinman, music director of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra and principal guest conductor of the Baltimore Symphony, will succeed Sergiu Commisiona, who will become Houston Symphony Orchestra music director.

title: HARD LINER ON TRADE MAY QUIT
description: Lawrence J. Brady, an Assistant Secretary of Commerce who is an ardent opponent of trade with the Soviet Union, is expected to resign soon, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: SMALL COLLEGE PUTS THE BITE ON, GENTLY
description: How does one raise money for a small, liberal arts college of little endowment and less profile?

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 10
description: Sales for the latest and year-ago 36 weeks are in thousands. Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective March 31, 1983.

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
POLITICAL ETYMOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: Weaver Prefers The Microphone
description: It appears that Earl Weaver will not be a candidate to fill the Mets' managing vacancy or to take the Yankees' managing job if George Steinbrenner should decide to dismiss Billy Martin. Weaver's job with the American Broadcasting Companies apparently comes first on his list.

title: Fight Is Knocked Out
description: A Copenhagen fight promoter, accusing a New York matchmaker of misrepresenting the age and fight record of a Boston heavyweight, has sent the fighter home and canceled his scheduled bout against the 25- year-old Swedish fighter Anders Elkund. In sending Al Brooks back to Boston just 24 hours before tonight's scheduled fight, the promoter, Mogens Palle, said he had been told by Don Majeski that Brooks was 29 years old and had won of 8 of 13 professional bouts, including 2 this year. When Brooks arrived in Copenhagen, however, he told a Palle representative that he was 39, had made his professional debut in 1966 and had not fought since September 1982. . . . Hector (Macho) Camacho , the World Boxing Council's superfeatherweight champion, will stage his first title defense against Rafael Solis Nov. 18 at a site to be determined, according to the promoter Don King, who also announced that Greg Page, the top ranked heavyweight contender would face Rick (King Kong) Kellar in Miami Oct. 15.

title: PIANO RECITAL: PETER KATIN
description: PETER KATIN'S beautiful Chopin recital in the Abraham Goodman House Monday night was immensely satisfying. Mr. Katin does not mine the romantic furies from this music the way some legendary pianists of the past have done. Instead, he opted for clean, continent performances of refreshing lucidity.

title: THEATER: 70'S DREAM REVISITED
description: THE BEATLES give M. Z. Ribalow's ''Marmalade Skies'' its title and an overlay of nostalgia. This is still another play about the quick collapse of youthful dreams, an elegy for the 1970's almost before they have turned the corner into the 1980's. In a field creatively tilled by such playwrights as Michael Weller, as well as the current movie, ''The Big Chill,'' ''Marmalade Skies,'' at the Actor's Outlet Theater Center, is a case of dramatic dej a vu.

title: BRITISH VIEW OF THE CITY BALLET COSTUMES
description: THE New York City Ballet's summer visit to London must certainly be accounted a critical and popular success. Yet, whereas almost everybody liked the company's dancing, absolutely nobody liked its costumes.

title: STATUS OF THE WEST BANK UNDER CUSTOMARY INTERNATIONAL LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 SURVIVE 300-FOOT PLUNGE
description: Four teen-agers in a pickup truck survived when the vehicle plunged down a nearly vertical 300-foot cliff to a beach, the police said today.

title: I.R.S. Wins Ruling in Rich Case
description: A United States District Court judge yesterday upheld the $90.4 million Internal Revenue Service jeopardy assessment against a trading company that was formerly the United States operation of Marc Rich, the commodities trader charged with evading a record $48 million in income taxes.

title: A SALVADORAN REBEL LEADER SAYS U.S. DOES NOT WANT PEACE
description: A leader of the Salvadoran insurgents says that the United States is not sincere in its efforts to negotiate peace in El Salvador and is instead trying to regionalize the conflict throughout Central America.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1983
description: nternational

title: LSI LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Including tax credits of $745,000 for the quarter and $1,914,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: ROCK: ROMAN HOLIDAY PLAYS
description: DURING the high tide of punk rock, raw emotion and combative rhythms replaced technical competence as dominant musical values. In the last two years, however, the pendulum has swung sharply back toward tradition.

title: Trainers Accused
description: According affidavits submitted by Border Patrol agents to Federal court, ''hundreds of illegal aliens'' had been seized at a southern California training center for thoroughbred race horses in ''numerous'' previous raids. A sweep Sept. 12 netted 184 more, according to the United States Attorney's office in San Diego, which has filed criminal complaints accusing six trainers and two stable foreman of harboring illegal aliens. The defendants include Wayne Lukas, who trained the 1980 Preakness winner Codex, and Darrell Vienna, a prominent Los Angeles trainer.

title: CONCERT: ROGER-SALANDER, CLARINETIST
description: THE clarinettist Roger Salander is a thoughtful and accomplished musician, and his Saturday evening concert in Carnegie Recital Hall was a model of its kind. There were no elaborate pretensions; this was just an intimate evening of musicmaking.

title: DESIGNS FOR TODAY'S KITCHEN: A PLACE TO WORK AND LIVE
description: IN a kitchen scene in the movie ''Annie Hall,'' a squeamish Woody Allen and Diane Keaton confront, drop and then chase a live lobster they are about to cook. The kitchen itself is forgettable - a bland room in a Long Island beach house - but the episode advances the movie and the romance because of this small event in an apparently inconsequential place.

title: Jesse Jackson Ends Registration Drive
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that a three-day voter registration drive he led had helped enroll 3,000 new voters.

title: U.S. Will Instruct Used-Car Buyers
description: A nationwide campaign by the Federal Trade Commission to educate buyers in the purchase of used cars was announced yesterday at the World Trade Center by the commission's chairman, James C. Miller 3d.

title: Auto-Death Jury Starts Deliberating
description: A jury of five women and seven men began deliberations today in the case of a motorist, Gerald T. Gerlock Jr., who is charged with using his car to murder a 7-year-old boy, George DeCasanova, last March 15 after making ethnic slurs.

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO APPROVE MOVE FOR RE-ELECTION
description: President Reagan has given ''acquiescence and acceptance'' to forming a re-election committee, a senior White House official said today. The President's approval was his biggest step toward a formal re-election announcement.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,686,000 for the quarter and $1,935,000 for the 9 months.

title: Louis Vaczek Is Dead at 69; Novelist and Science Editor
description: Louis Vaczek, a novelist and editor, died of leukemia in New York on Sept. 30. He was 69 years old.

title: BLACK'S MAYORAL BID BRINGS CHANGE TO BOSTON
description: ''Hey, Mel!'' the voice cried. Bald, bearded, more than 200 pounds, more than six feet tall, Melvin H. King looked up from the corner of Kneeland and South Streets downtown.

title: MATT DILLON IN COPPOLA'S 'RUMBLE FISH'
description: THE stunning black-and-white cinematography in Francis Coppola's ''Rumble Fish'' functions rather like a cold compress, subduing a film that is otherwise all feverish extremes. Mr. Coppola made ''Rumble Fish'' just after ''The Outsiders,'' and apparently in the same breath.

title: UNICAN SECURITY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to June 30
Richardson Still Missing
description: More than 48 hours after anyone with the Nets had seen or spoken to Michael Ray Richardson, the players and staff expressed growing concern for his safety and condition today at the club's training camp. ''I'm very concerned,'' said Darryl Dawkins.

title: PRO-ISRAELI CHIEF KILLED IN LEBANON
description: A car bomb killed a pro-Israeli Moslem militia commander in southern Lebanon today. The Palestine Liberation Organization said the slaying had been carried out to eliminate traitors to the Arab cause.

title: AUTHOR WHOSE WORKS DEFY NORMAL LABELING
description: An Appraisal

title: BRITON WINS THE NOBEL LITERATURE PRIZE
description: The Swedish Academy today awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature to the British novelist William Golding, author of ''Lord of the Flies,'' whose books plumb the nature of evil in man. But a senior member of the jury, in a rare public dissent, challenged the decision.

title: A 7-Year-Old's Priorities
description: When Robert J. McGuire set out from home yesterday to announce his resignation as Police Commissioner, he asked if his 7-year-old son, Brendan, would like to come along.

title: ROSENBERG CASE: ERNST DID NOT ACT FOR A.C.L.U.
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rare Sound on the IRT
description: The midday service on the Lexington Avenue is sluggish. The young people congregating on the uptown platform at 77th Street and Lexington Avenue are noisy.

title: FINDING OUT ABOUT ANTIQUES
description: Americana collectors who frequent antiques fairs and gallery shows discover early on that knowing quality counts in making any purchases. To compare American Indian art, American antiques and American folk art available in the marketplace with the finest works extant is often - but not always - possible in New York's museums.

title: PUBLISHING: RISING IMPORTANCE OF BOOK PUBLICITY
description: THE first time Dan Green flew to Chicago to meet a California author whom he had booked on a television talk show, ''the writer and I were so dumb,'' he recalled recently, ''we both forgot to change our watches and we didn't meet one another.'' Later he managed to book Jessica Mitford on a show in Cleveland to promote ''The American Way of Death,'' but it turned out to be a children's show - ''complete with 25 mothers and children dressed in identical leotards.''

title: VOLUNTEERS GLEAN FARMERS' FIELDS TO ASSIST FOOD PROGRAMS
description: A Colorado law giving farmers a break on state taxes and the efforts of volunteer gleaners have combined to give charity groups tons of produce that would otherwise have been plowed under or discarded.

title: Postal Productivity Rises
description: Postal Service productivity increased 45 percent in the last 12 years, with the average number of letters and parcels handled annually by each employee rising to 170,365 from 117,000, Congress was told Wednesday. Postal Service officials also said the taxpayer share of mailing costs dropped to less than 4 percent in fiscal year 1983 from 24 percent in 1970. That subsidy holds down rates for nonprofit groups.

title: WELCH AND HUDSON: TWO FAST STARTERS
description: Bob Welch considered the question: How are you different, in pitching and personality, from your rookie season of 1978?

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by United Press International in Sports Pages yesterday about the sale of illegal drugs to horse trainers and veterinarians misidentified Joseph Faraldo and gave an incorrect name for the judge in the case. Mr. Faraldo is president of the New York Standardbred Owners Association and has no connection with the defendant in a trial at Uniondale, L.I., where Judge Jacob Mishler is presiding.

title: Casey Awarded C.I.A. Medal
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, was awarded the Central Intelligence Agency's highest intelligence medal today ''for outstanding leadership.'' In a surprise ceremony at the agency's headquarters in Langley, Va., Mr. Casey was awarded the Distinguished Intelligence Medal for restoring the credibility of the C.I.A.

title: 25 YEARS IN POP MUSIC
description: WHEN Gladys Knight and the Pips take the stage at the Westbury Music Fair tonight, the venerable pop-soul quartet will have logged more than 25 years as a professional ensemble. This makes them one of the longest-lasting family groups in all of pop music.

title: Author Whose Works Defy Normal Labeling
description: An Appraisal

title: DISCOVER THE CULTURE THAT STIRS LATIN HEARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Jim Frey, who managed the Kansas City

title: CHINA FIGHTS A BOOMING MARKET IN BOGUS BICYCLES
description: Psst, comrade, wanna buy a counterfeit bicycle for the same price as the genuine model?

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRIBUTES TO CARDINAL
description: With expressions of love, respect and admiration, Pope John Paul II and religious and secular leaders around the nation paid tribute yesterday to the late Terence Cardinal Cooke. Excerpts from some of their statements follow: Pope John Paul II

title: SEAN CONNERY IS SEASONED JAMES BOND
description: ONE of the key questions of the current film season can now be answered: This is the better Bond, and by a wide margin. It's not a matter of casting - though Sean Connery makes a welcome return in ''Never Say Never Again,'' Roger Moore has certainly done nicely with the role - but rather one of creaks. Last summer's ''Octopussy'' reworked the same old Bond formula in all its anachronistic glory, with 007 winking his way through the usual intrigue, a figure of devilish charm and inexhaustible vigor. In ''Never Say Never Again,'' however, the material has been successfully updated. Here, time has caught up with Bond - and he's very much the better for wear.

title: Star Time for Guerrero
description: When Pedro Guerrero inherited Ron Cey's position at third base this season, he also inherited the crowd of journalists who used to flock to Steve Garvey in the Los Angeles Dodger clubhouse. In that process, he lost some of the fat pitches that used to come sailing into his strike zone.

title: PHILIP GLASS'S 'PHOTOGRAPHER'
description: -heralded Next Wave Festival formally opened last night with a new version of a mixed-media piece called ''The Photographer: Far from the Truth.'' This 80-minute play-concert- dance amalgam, which will run at the Academy through next weekend, is a complex, fascinating, striking collaboration. And even if it finally falls short of complete success, its earnest intentions and sometimes dazzling realization make it worth both seeing and admiring.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC DEBUT OF SWEDISH BARITONE
description: THE New York Philharmonic went into the fourth week of its season last night with another surrogate on the podium in place of Zubin Mehta, who apparently has better things to do elsewhere than to act as master of ceremonies at Avery Fisher Hall. This time it was Larry Newland, the orchestra's assistant conductor, who deputized for the music director in a program that introduced the Swedish baritone Hakan Hagegard to the Philharmonic audience.

title: REAGAN WIDENS ARIZONA AID
description: Two more counties were declared Federal disaster areas today after a series of floods in which at least 15 people died or were reported missing.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income after a gain from the exchange of securities of $3,785,000, or 75 cents a share.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jon English , the Tulane quarterback who was declared ineligible by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for not sitting out a year after transferring from Iowa State, will be able to play against Memphis State on Saturday, because a state appeals court yesterday decided not to rule on his eligibility before the weekend. . . . Robert Atwell , executive vice president of the American Council on Education, said that the council would press ahead with its proposal that a board of 36 to 44 college presidents be given total power over collegiate athletics. He made the comment after addressing the Collegiate Commissioners Association. . . . Steve Renko , the Kansas City Royals right-hander who had a 6-11 record and a 4.30 earned-run average over 121 innings this year, has been placed on waivers to give him an unconditional release.

title: DANCE GROUP'S FATE IN CITY'S HANDS
description: For years Louise Roberts, director of the Clark Center for the Performing Arts, has been dreaming of a permanent home for the small dance company. Finally last year in an unusual arrangement, the city agreed to provide funds to renovate a building on West 42d Street's Theater Row as a home for the 24-year-old dance group.

title: ART: NEW MUSEUM
description: ONE of the great moments in the history of European railroads was the completion in 188O of the tunnel beneath the St. Gotthard Pass. Those who had tunneled from the north might not have met up in the middle with those who had tunneled from the south. But they did, just as planned, and you could almost have heard the cheering way up above on the mountain.

title: American Financial To Buy a Circle K Unit
description: In a transaction that brings two prominent executives closer together, the Circle K Corporation said yesterday that it would purchase a chain of 960 Sun Belt convenience stores called Utotem from the American Financial Corporation in a $225 million transaction.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of American Heritage Industries, acquired in February.

title: Market Place; Analysts Back K Mart Moves
description: A HUGE company that concedes it made some merchandising mistakes in the past, the K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest non-food retailer after Sears, Roebuck, is banking on the belief that even in discount stores shoppers want better quality. It is embracing - management says it started - the current hot trend of upscale discounting.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest quarter and year reflect a charge of $4.2 million for the projected cost of the realignment and closing of a plant in St. Paul.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Nouveau cafeteria, American-style.

title: THEATER TICKET AVAILABILITY
description: Following is the ticket availability, at press time, for Broadway shows on Friday, Saturday and Sunday: A Chorus Line : Friday evening, mezzanine only; Saturday matinee, all sections available; Saturday evening, sold out. Amadeus : All sections for all performances.

title: STAGE:'MEDICINE SHOW'
description: THROUGH the late 18th and early 19th centuries, pitchmen traveled the country promoting variety and musical acts along with patent medicines, but by World War II the medicine show had become a fading provincial pastime. The American Place Theater opens its 20th season with ''The Vi- Ton-Ka Medicine Show,'' an attempt at reviving and re-creating this authentic slice of Americana. Though the intentions are apparently sincere as well as historical, the show is a marginal entertainment.

title: DISCOVER THE CULTURE THAT STIRS LATIN HEARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PEACE MEANS POLITICS
description: The Nobel Peace Prize committee has truly served its founder's intentions this year with the award to Lech Walesa.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,388,000 for the quarter and year from land sales and a provision of $250,000 for the quarter for losses in connection with the company's Hawaii investment. c-After a provision of $1 million for losses in connection with the company's Hawaii investment.

title: 3 IN BRINK'S CASE GIVEN LONG TERMS
description: Three radicals convicted of murder in the $1.6 million Brink's armored car robbery were each sentenced today to three consecutive terms of 25 years to life in prison.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1983
description: International

title: Quotations of the Day
description: Leon Hess, owner of the Jets, in announcing that the Jets would move to New Jersey and that Mayor Koch has forced the issue of the move.

title: ART: GERMAN PAINTERS FROM POSTWAR PERIOD
description: WITH somewhat less hoopla than the Italian branch of the family, German neo-Expressionist artists have had a fair amount of exposure on the New York scene, mostly in individual shows at commercial galleries. Baselitz, Penck, Kiefer - these names are now beginning to roll off the tongue as smoothly as those of our local stars, and we are getting used to their mythicizing imagery that - though more figurative than abstract - relates to attitudes and emotions rather than visual facts.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, has named Gary E. Cortopassi vice president and assistant treasurer.

title: Big Mama Thornton
description: The blues singer Big Mama Thornton will perform tonight at Folk City, 130 West Third Street (254-8449). Shows begin at 9 P.M. and midnight. Tickets are $8.

title: Advertising; Publisher's Next Goal: Art World
description: HAVING completed his Army service in the cushy position of company clerk of a military police unit, Wick Allison, who had a bachelor's degree from the University of Texas, enrolled in the M.B.A. program at Southern Methodist. What he really wanted was not the degree, but, having decided to start a city magazine for Dallas, to get faculty specialists to act as nonpaid consultants on the writing of his business plan.

title: Indian Dancers at Y
description: The Thunderbird American Indian Dancers will present a Columbus Day concert at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue at 53d Street, at 7:30 P.M. Monday.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 20
description: b-Including tax credits of $317,000 for the latest first quarter and $857,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: ISLANDERS WIN ON BOSSY GOALS
description: Mike Bossy grew up not far from downtown Montreal, in the suburb of Laval, some 20 miles north of the Forum. The Canadiens, once the proudest of all National Hockey League franchises, had been in the midst of building their record of five straight Stanley Cup championships when Bossy was born on Jan. 22, 1957.

title: TUGGED INTO SUNSET
description: To the Editor:

title: MCGUIRE LEAVING POLICE POST DEC. 31
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, who said several weeks that he was planning to step down, announced yesterday that he would resign Dec. 31.

title: Spain's Parliament Votes To Ease Abortion Law
description: The Socialist majority in Parliament voted today to legalize abortion in certain cases. It would be the first such legalization in nearly a half century.

title: Interest Rates Down Again
description: Interest rates continued to fall yesterday, but the decreases were small compared with the larger declines earlier this week. Trading volume was described as light to moderate.

title: Glenn Close to do Tom Stoppard play with Jermy Irons
description: ONE night three years ago, the director George Roy Hill went to see the musical ''Barnum'' on Broadway and was captivated by his first glimpse of the beautiful, serenely composed Glenn Close as Mrs. Barnum. Mr. Hill soon signed Miss Close to play Garp's mother, Jenny Fields, in ''The World According to Garp,'' and a film career was in bloom. Miss Close, who has a leading role in the new film ''The Big Chill,'' is returning to Broadway this season, and this time she is hoping the theater will once again open new doors - especially ones leading to something spicier than mother roles.

title: Noles Drops Appeal
description: Dickie Noles, the Chicago Cubs pitcher, has dropped an appeal of his conviction for hitting a policeman and will return to jail in Cincinnati today to finish a 16-day sentence. Noles, 26, had pleaded no contest to a charge that he hit Kim Cohen on April 19 as the officer tried to break up a fight involving a friend of Noles outside a downtown bar. Noles had served one day of the sentence before he was released on a $1,000 appeal bond.

title: LOTUS PUBLIC OFFERING GETS WARM WELCOME
description: The Lotus Development Corporation's initial public offering received a warm welcome yesterday.

title: BONN LEADER CELEBRATES WITH PHILADELPHIA
description: Karl Carstens, the President of West Germany, said today that German immigrants 300 years ago founded Philadelphia to be the ''City of Brotherly Love'' William Penn said it was.

title: Continental Plans Profit Sharing
description: Continental Air Lines said it would offer a profit-sharing plan to distribute to employees from 15 to 25 percent of the company's profits.

title: OLIVETTI IS SAID TO OFFER 20% STAKE TO A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which is beginning to enter overseas markets, is being asked to purchase a 20 percent stake in Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the big Italian office- equipment maker, European executives familiar with the negotiations said today.

title: MOVIE CAMERAS BRIGHTEN UP A MIDWEST TOWN
description: First the corn crop dried up, and then, toward the end of Illinois's brutal summer, red mites ruined the soybeans. Pontiac, surrounded by dry cornfields, has had its share of gloom, but fall is bringing a respite.

title:
SCOUTING;
Base Path Basics
description: One reason that the Chicago White Sox are in the American League playoffs may be that the team received some expert advice on base running in the last year.

title: TRADE DATA SOUGHT ON BULLION DEALER
description: New York State officials said yesterday that they were investigating whether a West Coast gold dealer who committed suicide a week ago might have suffered multimillion-dollar losses in the gold and silver market.

title: OIL - X IN A STRATEGIC EQUATION
description: News Analysis

title: New Chief Named By Household Unit
description: Bernard F. Brennan, Montgomery Ward's executive vice president, retail, resigned yesterday to become president and chief executive officer of the Household Merchandising Corporation, a subsidiary of Household International.

title: TEACHER, NOT POLICEMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: 'LaBrava'
description: JOE LABRAVA knows his way around, especially South Miami Beach and environs. He notices things. He's tough and smart, though by no means ruthless, which is something that gets him in trouble now and then in Elmore Leonard's latest novel (his 17th book, no less), ''LaBrava.'' Joe is a former Internal Revenue Service officer, Collection Division, and a former Secret Service agent who once did duty guarding Bess Truman at home in Independence, Mo. ''Not even counting protective-detail in Mrs. Truman's living room,'' LaBrava reflects, ''a life that sounded exciting was 80 percent boring.''

title: New Honda Plant
description: Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. said it plans to build a $30 million motorcycle engine factory in Ohio. Output will begin in early 1985 and will create 150 jobs, with workers on a single shift producing 60,000 engines a year, according to a Honda spokesman, Bonnie Manning. She said a site had not been selected.

title: TWO RUSSIAN PROGRAMS
description: THE Kitchen's programs of ''Constructivist Music and Performance'' this weekend and next, devoted to vanguard Russian composition, theater and dance of the early 1920's, hardly stand alone.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 7, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Michigan Acts to Stop Presidential Primary
description: A bill that would cancel Michigan's 1984 Presidential primary was approved today by the State Legislature.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
PERON, DEAD, SEEKS OFFICE
description: Juan Domingo Peron has been dead since July 1974. According to most responsible observers, he will be elected president of Argentina on Oct. 30, when the nation votes for a civilian government after more than seven years of military dictatorship.

title: Antiques on the Hudson
description: Not many passengers use the Passenger Ship Terminal at 50th Street and the Hudson River. Often there's not a single ship docked there because when the six-berth facility opened in 1974, passenger business was declining.

title: Tax Bill Meets Delay
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today turned down a plea from large tax-exempt foundations that they be permanently exempted from a requirement to sell some of their assets. The requirement is included in the Tax Reform Act of 1969.

title: CONGRESS PUSHES FOR TRIAL IN SALVADOR KILLINGS
description: Committees in both houses of Congress, frustrated over the issue of human rights in El Salvador, are moving to make some future United States aid to El Salvador conditional on a trial of the Salvadoran national guardsmen implicated in the killings of four United States Roman Catholic churchwomen.

title: MEMPHIS MAYOR RE-ELECTED BY WIDE MARGIN
description: Mayor Dick Hackett won re-election today with a clear majority of the vote, avoiding a runoff.

title: 'ROMANTIC COMEDY,' WITH DUDLEY MOORE
description: TAKING a good idea and several very good actors, Arthur Hiller, the director, and Bernard Slade, who adapted his Broadway play for the screen, have made a movie of remarkably little wit, humor, charm or interest. It's called ''Romantic Comedy,'' which is an expression of its aspirations, and it opens today at the Baronet and other theaters.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Left in the Dark
description: Why was there no New York Ranger hockey game on cable TV in northern Manhattan Wednesday night?

title: NO-FAULT MALPRACTICE INSURANCE FAULTED
description: To the Editor:

title: Laurels and Leaves; Evergreen
description: ''We've got a lot of pleasures of a kind here,'' said the stage manager in Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' about life in Grover's Corners, N.H., in 1901.
