''We like the sun coming up over the mountain in the morning, and we all notice a good deal about the birds. . . . And we watch the change of the seasons; yes, everybody knows about them.''

title: Student Is Killed In Brooklyn Brawl
description: One high school student was killed yesterday and one was injured when six students on their way home from Brooklyn Technical High School became involved in a fight with ten other youths, the police said.

title: ACTIVE IN EDUCATIONAL AFFAIRS
description: Frank Karelsen, a lawyer active in educational and community affairs in New York, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.

title: BRAZIL IS TO GET TWO NEW LOANS FOR $12 BILLION
description: Sixty major banks agreed today to Brazil's request for $12 billion in new loans.

title: A Measure of Security
description: Heads of state and government have been in for the United Nations session and been given heavy security by the Secret Service.

title: Dunlop S.A. Bankruptcy
description: Dunlop S.A., a unit of Dunlop Tire and Rubber of Britain, said today that it had filed for bankruptcy because of heavy losses. The company said the French Government would try to find a buyer for Dunlop S.A. The company's losses in 1982 widened to $25.2 million.

title: Laurels and Leaves; Poland's Honor
description: True peace depends on the willingness of governments to respond to the humanity of their citizens and, even when provoked, to do everything possible to avoid bloodshed.

title: DINER'S CHOICE
description: PASTA with sweet red pepper sauce, pasta with salmon, pasta with sage sauce, pasta with vodka sauce - and this is just the beginning. Good old grainy meatballs are becoming as scarce as $400-a-month, two-bedroom apartments on the East Side. Pasta is unquestionably ''in'' this fall, and imaginative Italian restaurants are in a creative frenzy. Some are inventing exotic dishes, with varying success, and others are reinterpreting old classics.

title: HESS ASSAILS KOCH IN ANNOUNCING JETS ARE MOVING
description: Leon Hess, the principal owner of the Jets, accused Mayor Koch yesterday of ''forcing the issue'' of the team's move to New Jersey, saying that the Mayor had announced it before Hess even made the decision.

title: SBD ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHARMACONTROL CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-No year-ago results were reported because this year was the company's first as a public concern.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ONLY in New York would one week's parties include a vernissage of animal paintings attended by royalty, a gathering of horticulturists to look at re-creations of medieval gardens, a 40th anniversary party for an elevator operator in a fashionable apartment building, a black-tie fund-raiser for musicians and a surprise birthday party for a grown woman that featured clowns and balloon sculptures.

title: Vintage Thought
description: She will turn 40 next month, but Billie Jean King , the six-time Wimbledon and four-time United States champion, isn't thinking about retirement. After defeating 15-year-old Carling Bassett in an exhibition in Toronto Wednesday night, Mrs. King, who has reached the quarterfinals of every tournament she has entered this year, explained why. ''With age,'' she said, ''you appreciate things more.''

title: A HOST OF PROBLEMS AWAIT KILEY AT THE M.T.A.
description: Picketing by angry workers, economic crises, citizen revolts, fires and floods. They may seem like scenes from a nation in turmoil, but they are pages from the lives of the officials who run transit systems in New York.

title: NATIONAL MEDPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-There were no comparison figures available because the company went public in November 1982.

title: ACORN COMPUTER MAKES U.S. DEBUT
description: Acorn Computers Ltd., which dominates the educational computer market in Britain, introduced its BBC microcomputer in the United States yesterday and said it had already received $21 million in orders from American schools.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1983
description: International

title: Publication for Doctors Is Available to Public
description: As if being a paid magazine for physicians is not strange enough, here is a magazine, owned by a pharmaceutical company, that is going to offer subsciptions to the public, too.

title: Teddy Bear Time
description: Know a good-looking teddy bear? Bloomingdale's will conduct its first annual teddy bear contest tomorrow at 4 P.M., with competition in such categories as smallest, largest, best dressed, most loved, best preserved. Peggy and Alan Bialosky, authors of ''The Teddy Bear Catalogue,'' will judge the contest and offer tips on repairing worn bears, appraising antique bears and general bear care. Contest winners will receive bears as prizes.

title: More Insect Fragments Found in Ground Beef
description: One of 22 new meat samples from shipments headed for the school lunch program was found to contain tiny pieces of insects, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: T R V MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a special gain of $428,609. The company did not disclose revenue figures and the year-earlier results were restated.

title: NIGER REPORTS ITS FORCES FOILED A COUP BY A 'FEW AMBITIOUS PEOPLE
description: Forces loyal to President Seyni Kountche of Niger foiled an attempted coup in the West African nation Wednesday night, it was announced today.

title: Regan Criticizes Waste at Prison
description: Controls are weak at the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora over the amount of food inmates eat, the charging of gasoline on state credit cards and even how much it costs to clean the superintendent's house, a new report contended today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: HOPE FADES FAST FOR NEW CYPUS TALKS
description: Hopes for a quick renewal of direct negotiations on the question of reuniting Cyprus were dashed today when the President of the island nation, Spyros Kyprianou, left New York without responding to a new initiative by the leader of the Turkish Cypriots.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Friday on energy conservation misstated the capital investments of Time Energy Systems Inc. It has $10 million invested in 550 facilities.

title: KENYA ELECTION SHIFTS POWER AWAY FROM THE LARGEST TRIBE
description: Last month's parliamentary elections here confirmed a shift in power away the country's largest tribe.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid June 10.

title: 2D MISTRIAL IN MURDER OF OFFICER
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Queens declared a mistrial yesterday in the second trial of two former Black Panthers accused of killing a police officer when he and his partner stopped their van on a Queens street in April 1981.

title: The Television War (R)
description: How does the first television war stand up as a rerun? Public television's ''Vietnam'' assumes that Americans still care enough to tune in for 13 prime-time hours, the first two this week. It's a worthy risk.

title: 7 Are Arrested In Cross Burning
description: Seven people have been arrested in connection with one of four recent cross burnings in central New Jersey, but no connection was found to the other incidents, officials said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A. H. Belo Corp. said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell two television stations - KFDM in Beaumont-Port Arthur, Tex., and WTVC in Chattanooga, Tenn. - to Freedom Newspapers for $49 million.

title: SENATE RESOLUTION ON WATT AWAITED
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that their priority in the controversy over Interior Secretary James G. Watt was to avoid bipartisan approval of a Senate resolution condemning him.

title: WALESA PROMISES CHANGE IN TACTICS
description: Lech Walesa said today that he would launch what he said would be ''more effective'' tactics to restore the outlawed Solidarity labor union on Dec. 16.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TCommonwealth Oil Bankruptcy Study
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said the sale of its refining assets in Puerto Rico may be delayed and, as a result, it is considering bankruptcy proceedings. The company said it had been forced to postpone the completion of the sale because certain conditions of an agreement between the buyer and Puerto Rican authorities have not been met. Commonwealth Oil previously had planned to complete the sale to a subsidiary of Apex Oil of St. Louis by next Wednesday.

title: Studio Fire Laid to Arson
description: A $3 million Paramount Studio fire that destroyed a number of historic street sets, including the one used in both ''Godfather'' movies, was caused by arson, Fire Chief Gerald Johnson said today. The Aug. 25 fire started behind a tattoo shop facade on a collection of intertwining roadways known as New York street.

title: COLUMBIA PICTURES CHIEF REPORTEDLY RESIGNING
description: Frank Price, one of the most respected and powerful figures in the movie industry in recent years, will be stepping down as chairman of Columbia Pictures in the aftermath of a power struggle, according to sources within the industry.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Results for the latest 9 months reflect an adjustment of first quarter 1983 results to correct overstatement of sales by $801,000 and net income by $439,000, or 5 cents a share, resulting from a billing error. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 3.

title: ARMANI: MANNISH GLAMOUR
description: The week belonged to Giorgio Armani. He followed successful presentations of spring and summer fashions for Erreuno and Mario Valentino with the showing of his major collection under his own name last night and it was triumphal. It expressed clearly and forcefully a concept that will undoubtedly affect the course of fashion throughout the world in the next six months. The idea is not new: simply stated, it is men's clothes for women.

title: KIRKLAND OPPOSES TEAMSTERS MERGER
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, moved today to block a merger of the International Typographical Union with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: A Jacobs Move On Kaiser Steel
description: An investor group led by Irwin L. Jacobs disclosed that it had increased its stake in the Kaiser Steel Corporation to 24 percent of the common shares outstanding, from 16 percent.

title: A REBUILDING SUCCESS IN LOWER BRONX
description: At West 179th Street and Sedgwick Avenue in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx stands the shell of a substantial six-story apartment building, the only residential structure at the intersection. Weeds choke the entrance and sprout to first-floor window level. On the upper floors, empty windows gape.

title: DEBERG AND MARINO GET STARTING ROLES
description: The first and last of the six quarterbacks taken on the opening round of the college draft were given new responsibilities this week. John Elway of the Denver Broncos was told by Coach Dan Reeves that he would not start this weekend; Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins was told by Coach Don Shula that he would.

title: Slayer of 13 at Seattle Club Receives Sentence of Death
description: Kwan Mai Mak, a 22-year-old immigrant from Hong Kong, was sentenced to death today for the murders of 13 people at a gambling club in Chinatown last Feb. 19.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
HITACHI LTD. AND I.B.M. SETTLE CASE
description: A Federal judge announced today that a settlement had been reached between Hitachi Ltd. of Japan and the International Business Machines Corporation over the return of trade secrets stolen from I.B.M.

title: TERENCE CARDINAL COOKE: A CALM VOICE IN AN AGE OF UPHEAVAL
description: Cardinal Terence Cooke rose to a great height in the Roman Catholic Church without losing the simplicity and soul of a village priest.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February and a 2-for-1 stock split in August.

title: BOODICKER STRIKES OUT 14 AS ORIOLES TIE SERIES, 1-1
description: Mike Boddicker, who at this time of year is usually drying corn at a grain elevator in the tiny town of Norway, Iowa, shut out the Chicago White Sox tonight and pitched Baltimore into a 1-1 tie in the American League pennant playoff.

title: Devils Complete Deal for Mulvey
description: The Devils officially acquired Grant Mulvey from the Pittsburgh Penguins today and are expected to use him in their home opener here Friday night against the Rangers.

title: Rights Panel Scoffs At the Aquino Inquiry
description: A delegation of lawyers just back from the Philippines said today that the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was guilty of continuing human rights violations and that the commission investigating the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was not credible.

title: Volcano in Hawaii Erupts
description: Kilauea spewed lava hundreds of feet into the air this morning from its east rift zone, feeding two lava flows that coursed through a remote area of Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, scientists said. Neither flow posed any immediate threat to developed property, said Bob Decker, a spokesman for the United States Geological Survey.

title: Longer Final
description: The two women who reach the final of the Virginia Slims championships to be played at Madison Square Garden from Feb. 28 to March 4 will have to put in more time and effort than usual.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The latest 9 months and quarter include income from proceeds of life insurance policies of $154,000 and an after-tax expense of $94,000 for survivors benefits provided under the terms of an employment agreement with a deceased officer of the company. The 1982 amounts reflect extraordinary tax loss arising from carryback of operating loss of $469,000 in the 9 months period.

title: 4,000 Pakistanis Hold March To Protest Rule by Military
description: About 4,000 people marched through the Punjab capital of Lahore today to protest Pakistan's military rule in a demonstration called by lawyers from around the country.

title: Experience Helps
description: Pete Liske, a quarterback who played professionally from 1964 until 1975 with the Jets, the Calgary Stampeders, the Denver Broncos, the Philadelphia Eagles and the British Columbia Lions, is nearing the middle of his first season as a back judge for the National Football League.

title: SITES WHERE THE UNUSUAL IN MUSIC IS THE USUAL
description: MOST taxi drivers can probably find Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, the Rainbow Room or even the Village Vanguard. Schedules for them, and other established venues, are regularly advertised and listed in newspapers. Every weekend in New York, however, music can also be found at out-of-the-way storefronts, lofts and other ''alternative spaces'' - places with names like Inroads or Plugg or the Experimental Intermedia Foundation. The production tends to be homier and sometimes off-the-cuff - and is reflected in low admission prices - but the music can be as striking as what's regularly heard on concert stages.

title: No Headline
description: The police shot and killed a suspected black nationalist guerrilla who fired at them from a train today and tried to hurl a grenade, according to a report by the Government-administered South African Broadcasting Corporation. Two civilians were wounded. The shooting took place midway between Johannesburg and Cape Town.

title: Photo Show of Cranes
description: The Asia Society is presenting a free exhibition of photographs of the Japanese crane.

title: Two on Giants Called Doubtful
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants has listed Pete Shaw, a backup safety, and Joe McLaughlin, a linebacker, as doubtful for the game against the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday.

title: S.E.C. QUESTIONS DEFENSE DEPUTY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Paul N. Thayer, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, passed along inside information to others in 1982, when Mr. Thayer was chairman of the LTV Corporation and a director of several other public companies, according to Administration officials.

title: Economic Scene; Getting Banks To Help Banks
description: THE release from jail of the president of Argentina's central bank, Julio Gonzalez del Solar, by a federal judge has opened the way for negotiations to resume on how Argentina may refinance its huge foreign debts. But the crisis is far from over, either in Argentina or Brazil or Chile or the Philippines or throughout the world's debt-ridden financial system.

title: Mrs. Reagan Due In
description: President Reagan's wife, Nancy, is scheduled to travel to New York Tuesday to open a public service advertising campaign against drug abuse. Sheila Tate, Mrs. Reagan's press secretary, said today that the First Lady would visit Needham, Harper & Steers, the advertising agency that created the radio, television and print campaign sponsored by the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

title: TALE OF TWO TREATIES
description: When W. Averell Harriman arrived in Moscow in the summer of 1963, a reporter asked how long it would take the American envoy and his team to negotiate a ban on nuclear tests in the atmosphere.

title: F.B.I. AND LOS ANGELES POLICE FUED OVER OLYMPIC SECURITY
description: The Federal authorities and the Los Angeles Police Department are feuding over security arrangements for the Olympic Games next summer.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Guarding the OSHA Chickens
description: Another fox sent to guard the chicken coop: that was the fear when President Reagan chose a construction executive, whose company had been repeatedly cited for safety violations, to head the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. In his 30-month tenure, Thorne Auchter has justified that fear, and now some Congressmen are asking hard questions about delay and dilution of vital safety standards. It's none too soon.

title: For Stewart, Hitchcock lives still. $
description: T ''IT just was a wonderful experience working with him,'' said James Stewart, ''and as I say, I consider him real close to genius.''

title: PRIVATE AUDITORS AUDIT COMPTROLLER AND FIND FAULT
description: The State Comptroller's office, which is often critical of the way other state agencies tend to their paper work, was tweaked today by a private auditing firm for some of the same shortcomings.

title: U.S. EXPERTS SAY SOVIET DIDN'T SEE JET WAS CILILIAN
description: Five weeks after a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean airliner, United States intelligence experts say they have reviewed all available evidence and found no indication that Soviet air defense personnel knew before the attack that the target was a commercial plane.

title: CRIME COMMISSION BOGS DOWN IN POWER STRUGGLE
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime, formed in July with great ceremony and given a mandate to examine organized crime in the country, has become embroiled in disputes with the Justice Department about its leadership and independence.

title: ST. PATRICK'S TO OFFER RITES
description: The following services have been scheduled at St. Patrick's Cathedral for Cardinal Cooke:

title: Clarion Concerts Plans Zelenka Mass Dec. 14
description: This season's performances by the Clarion Concerts Orchestra, which plays authentic Baroque instruments, will include what is believed to be the first performance in modern times of a Christmas mass by Jan Dismas Zelenka, an 18th-century Bohemian composer, according to a spokesman for the orchestra.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MORRISTOWN CRAFTS

title: CHINA MAKES ISSUE OF SOVIET MISSILES
description: China and the Soviet Union opened new talks today aimed at normalizing their relations amid indications that the Chinese will press the Russians to reduce the number of Soviet nuclear missiles deployed along China's northern frontier.

title: THE COURT VS. RIGHTS
description: There is a little noticed yet real power struggle being waged by the United States Supreme Court against state courts. The battlefield is familiar - civil liberties. But the struggle is unprecedented. For the first time, state judgments are being reversed because, in the Justices' view, too much constitutional protection is being given to claims of individual rights.

title: THE NEW NEW MUSEUM
description: 26 times over - of New York's American Folk Art Week, a celebration that extends from the Hudson River in midtown to the Upper East Side. The bounty of mostly American antiques on view in two antiques shows and five museum and gallery exhibitions includes Navajo blankets, Pennsylvania quilts, folk carvings, painted furniture, carousel horses, weather vanes, toys and botanical prints and porcelains. The keystone of the celebration is the Fall Antiques Show at the Passenger Pier Terminal, Hudson River at 48th Street, a bazaar in which ''Uncle Sam: An American Folk Hero'' is the theme exhibition sponsored by the Museum of American Folk Art. On view are 26 examples of the patriotic symbol, from images on tobacco tins to seven-foot-tall wood carvings set against a color-splashed red-white-and-blue display, and the most graphic of all designs - an outsized American Flag.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split effective June 24.

title: Bridge: Acesand Italy Are Engaged In a Close Fight for the Title
description: The final of the World Team Championship began here today and proved to be a seesaw battle between the Aces and Italy.

title: ART:20 YEARS OF DAVID SMITH PAINTING
description: ALTHOUGH it is widely known that David Smith began his career as a painter and worked in this medium all his life, his paintings remain something of a gray area. Part of the reason is that they are not easy to place. The paintings do not need to be seen in terms of Smith's sculpture, but if his sculpture did not exist, they would only be of marginal interest. They are better than the paintings one normally identifies with an artist who is first of all a sculptor, but they are nowhere near as considered and resolved as the paintings of Giacometti, to cite the other major 20th-century sculptor who left behind a body of painting.

title: Moderate Quake in Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake shook the Anchorage, Alaska, area early today but caused no reported damage, the United States Geological Survey said. The earthquake registered 4.6 on the Richter scale and was centered about 90 miles northwest of Anchorage. The tremor was reported felt in the Anchorage area.

title: ARMS ISSUE IS IN THE FORE AS 7 DEMOCRATIC HOPEFULS APPEAR AT FORUM HERE
description: Nuclear arms was the dominant issue as seven candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination answered questions from a panel and from one another on the stage of Town Hall last night before an audience of 1,500 politicians and reporters.

title: HOUSE VOTES WATER PROJECTS BILL AS OBJECTIONS ARE OINKED
description: With one opponent oinking, grunting and sporting a novelty pig snout, the House today approved a $119 million spending bill for water development projects, rejecting arguments that the measure was Congressional pork barrel spending at its worst.

title: Suspect in Trooper's Death Is Captured in Oklahoma Pit
description: An unemployed gun collector accused of killing a highway patrolman eluded 200 officers for more than a day before he was captured today in a gravel pit, officials said.

title: LIVING IN THE MYSTIQUE OF CULT STATUS
description: Three years ago, just prior to winning the Booker McConnell Prize, Britain's most prestigious prize for fiction, William Golding showed an interviewer a shelf in his study lined with books containing critical essays on his writing.

title: BATES MOTEL MAY BE RETIRED
description: When Bates Motel was at his best this year, his stretch run was powerful enough to mow down any horse in the country. So when he failed to pass Slew o' Gold in the Woodward Stakes and hung badly when third to Highland Blade and Slew o' Gold in the Marlboro Cup, something had to be wrong with him. It turns out that there was, and his career on the track is probably over.

title: INDICTMENT IS SEEN OVER 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Justice Department officials said today that indictments against the operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant should be announced in the next few weeks.

title: BISHOP JOSEPH O'KEEFE IS NAMED INTERIM HEAD OF ARCHDIOCESE
description: Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe, vicar general of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was selected yesterday to be administrator of the archdiocese until a successor to the late Terence Cardinal Cooke is installed.

title: Geneva Arms Session Lasts 2 Hours 50 Minutes
description: The United States and Soviet delegations to the negotiations on the reduction of strategic nuclear arms held a two-hour-and-50- minute meeting today, the first formal session of their new round of talks.

title: DIOGENES'S JUDGEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Books: Replacing God
description: THE POLITICS AT GOD'S FUNERAL. By Michael Harrington. 308 Pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95.

title: ISRAELI INVASION OF LEBANON WAS NO TAKEOVER
description: To the Editor:

title: Americus Shareowner Trust
description: The Americus Shareowner Service Corporation announced that it had registered with the S.E.C. for a proposed public offering of 45 million units of a new trust that will hold shares of the American Telephone and Telegrap Company. Americus said that the trust would offer to exchange its units for common shares of A.T.&T. on a one-unit-for-one-share basis, plus a sales charge.

title: 280 Lake Pleasure Boats Burn in Alabama
description: About 280 expensive pleasure boats went up in flames today as a fire that billowed smoke across Lake Martin destroyed the Kowaliga marina and boat warehouse. No injuries were reported.

title: A.T.& T. Acts On Access Fee
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company began a large-scale lobbying campaign urging Congress to let the Federal Communications Commission go ahead with its plan to impose a new telephone ''access fee'' on individual consumers and businesses.

title: More Suits Filed Against Coleco
description: Two more lawsuits have been filed in Federal District Court against Coleco Industries charging that investors were not adequately told about problems with the company's new Adam home computer. The lawsuits, the second and third filed this week against the West Hartford-based company, seek class-action status for people who bought Coleco stock from late May to late September.

title: CONFIDENT MONDALE ACCEPTS LABOR'S ENDORSEMENT
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale today used his speech accepting the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement of him as an opportunity to try to wrap a cloak of inevitablity around his candidacy.

title: B. I. INC.  reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Briton Wins the Nobel Literature Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 6

title: EXCERPTS FROM TESTAMENT
description: Following are excerpts from the last will and testament of Terence Cardinal Cooke, as read yesterday by Bishop Joseph T. O'Keefe, administrator of the Archdiocese of New York:

title: DR. GEORGE GENG
description: Dr. George Geng, an educator and Christian philosopher who founded the Association of the World University in hopes of bringing about world peace, died at his home here on Monday after suffering a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: U.S. PROPOSES RULES TO AVERT DEATHS IN JETLINER CABIN FIRES
description: The Federal Government, in a move prompted by the death of 23 people aboard an Air Canada jetliner, today proposed rules designed to prevent casualties from cabin fires.

title: CZECH PAPER SAYS POPE MEDDLES
description: An official Czechoslovak newspaper accused Pope John Paul II today of meddling in politics and using religion as a tool for subverting the Communist Governments of the Soviet bloc.

title: INDIAN GOVERNMENT TAKES OVER A STATE SWEPT BY RELIGIOUS STRIFE
description: The central Government dismissed the Punjab state government Thursday night and took direct control of the state in an attempt to halt more than a year of religious and political violence.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A judge set bond at $250,000 today for Steven Todd Jenkins, the 18-year-old man charged with killing two officers of the bank that foreclosed on his father's farm.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Share earnings have been restated for a stock dividend declared Sept. 12.

title: No Headline
description: Silas Tries Life After Basketball

title: For Children; Music, Plays, Shows
description: SALSA MUSIC PROGRAM, presented by Johnny Colon's 12-piece orchestra from the East Harlem Music School, Sunday, 2 P.M., the Belvedere Castle in Central Park, 79th Street, south of the Great Lawn. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy and the Vanneck-Bailey Foundation. Free. Bring a blanket or cushion for seating. Call: 772-0210.

title: FESTIVAL FOCUSES ON GLENN GOULD
description: IN 1964, after a meteoric concert career, Glenn Gould shocked the

title: SYRIA IS REPORTED AWAITING MISSILE
description: The Soviet Union has begun making preparations to deploy a mobile missile in Syria that could reach targets in Lebanon, Israel and the American Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean, an official traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz said last night.

title: GURU'S CITY FOUND UNCONSTITUTIONAL
description: The incorporation of Rajneeshpuram, a city founded by an Indian guru's followers, violated state and Federal constitutional guarantees of separation of church and state, the Oregon Attorney General ruled today.

title: 'SEPTEMBER GUN,' A COMEDY DRAMA
description: TOMORROW at 9 P.M. on Channel 2, CBS is presenting what it calls a ''light comedy western drama'' bearing the title ''September Gun.'' The gun is Ben Sunday, a gunfighter of some note in the late 1800's. The September refers to the fact that he's getting old. Making all of this worthwhile is the fact than Ben is played by Robert Preston, the fine actor who made his movie debut 45 years ago and went on to leave his distinctive mark on such disparate projects as the musical ''The Music Man'' and the whacky farce ''Victor, Victoria.''

title: New School Jazz Series
description: The pianist Hilton Ruiz, with Major Holley on bass and the jazz singer Daniella, will open the New School's Jazz at 6 series tonight at the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. Tickets are $6. Information: 741-5667.

title: CONGRESS SENDS JOBLESS BILL TO PRESIDENT
description: Congress, breathing new life into the Federal benefits program for the long- term unemployed, agreed today to extend it through Oct. 18. It sent the measure to President Reagan for his signature.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Tax U.S. Jewish Funds, Arab Lawsuit Argues
description: The Mayors of four West Bank towns and others asked a Federal court here today to revoke the tax exemptions of the United Jewish Appeal and five other Jewish organizations on the ground they were channeling contributions to Israeli organizations to confiscate land from Palestinians.

title: Too Many Tickets
description: His parents were inside Baltimore's Memorial Stadium as the guests of the Orioles' owner, Edward Bennett Williams, and Robert Sargent Shriver 3d , the 29-year-old son of the former Vice Presidential candidate and a nephew of the late President Kennedy, found himself with some extra tickets to the American League playoff game Wednesday night between the Orioles and the Chicago White Sox. So Mr. Shriver did the natural thing.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Antiquary Sale Is Set

title: SWITCHCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue for the latest year includes sales of $2,554,000 by Time & Space Processing Inc., an acquired subsidiary, as well as interest on investments.

title: EMERGENCY RULES ISSUED BY STATE FOR HOUSING OF WELFARE FAMILIES
description: The State Commissioner of Social Services yesterday issued emergency regulations that prohibit New York City and other localities from putting displaced families in hotels and motels that do not meet certain living standards. The state will refuse to reimburse costs to communities that fail to follow the rules.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: The Youngest Cardinal
description: When Archbishop Terence Cooke became Cardinal Cooke in 1969 he was only 48 years old, the youngest cardinal in the world. That seemed to augur long service, but his death at 62 concludes the shortest term of any cardinal ever to head the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Worker Is Killed By Gas in Jersey
description: A Union Carbide Corporation employee died late Tuesday night or early Wednesday morning after being asphyxiated while checking pipes carrying gases manufactured at the facility, a company official said today.

title: Bank Inquiry
description: First National Bank of Midland has disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Comptroller of the Currency are investigating the bank to determine whether it adequately disclosed its deteriorating financial condition. First National has also told its stockholders that unless it can sell from $40 million to $60 million in new stock to replace dwindling equity, the $1.5 billion institution will have to be sold.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LABRAVA. By Elmore Leonard. 283 pages. Arbor House. $14.95.

title: A President Is Chosen For Honeywell Venture
description: Honeywell Inc. has formed a trading company with plans to sell its services to smaller technology companies hoping to export their products. Biorn Biornstad, vice president for marketing of Honeywell Europe, has been moved to Minneapolis as president and general manager of the new venture.

title: CARDINAL COOKE DIES AT 62 AFTER FIGHT WITH LEUKEMIA
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, the spiritual head of the Archdiocese of New York and the Military Vicar of the United States, died at 4:45 A.M. yesterday at his residence behind St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: JO FISHER FREEMAN
description: Jo Fisher Freeman, an international finance expert, died Tuesday of Alzheimer's disease.

title: 2 Subway Fires Delay Thousands
description: Two fires in subway tunnels yesterday injured 31 people, including 12 firemen, and knocked out service for thousands of riders in Manhattan and Brooklyn, the Transit Authority and the Fire Department said.

title: Deadline Holds
description: The two-day meetings of National Football League executives ended here yesterday with a decision not to extend the trading deadline by two weeks. The deadline is next Tuesday. The matter will be taken up again at the spring meetings next March.

title: DOW SOARS 18.60 TO A RECORD
description: Stock prices soared yesterday in heavy trading as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 18.60 points, to a record 1,268.80.

title: ARGENTINES CROWD THE BANKS TO WITHDRAW DOLLARS
description: Argentines, shaken by the country's foreign debt crisis, crowded banks today to withdraw dollars and empty their safe- deposit boxes.

title: ROENICKE IS ORIOLES' RIGHT-HAND MAN
description: After what Gary Roenicke called ''the biggest game I've ever had,'' the Orioles' left fielder tonight had no complaints that John Lowenstein would be playing there Friday night in Chicago in the third game of the American League championship series.

title: WORKERS AND ASBESTOS: PITTING A RISK AGAINST HOLDING A JOB
description: An employee at the Johns-Manville plant here leaned against a fence and talked about his job and how he felt about working so long with asbestos, which can cause cancer and other illnesses.

title: AFTER THREE YEARS, KINDRED ENEMIES
description: Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was castigating President Reagan in a speech late last month when he was interrupted by a telephone call from Mr. Reagan. The Speaker wanted to continue his denunciation of the President's ''Beverly Hills friends,'' and ''rich man's recovery,'' but the President was reported to be insistent.

title: Hoboken House Tour
description: A tour of Hoboken's historic homes, including Victorian brownstones, Trinity Church and the landmark Elks Lodge, will be conducted Sunday from noon to 6 P.M. Tickets for the tour, to be held rain or shine, are $5, and can be bought Sunday at Trinity Church, Washington and Seventh Streets. Hoboken can be reached by PATH train and by bus from the Port Authority terminal or by car via the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: Wilson Foods Posts a Loss
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation, which is reorganizing under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said today that it lost $17 million in the final quarter of its fiscal year ended July 30, compared with a $2.3 million profit a year earlier. The loss came on sales of $436.5 million, down from $596.4 million a year earlier.

title: ACQUISITION STRAINS AT ESMARK
description: Well before Esmark swallowed Norton Simon last month, the heterogeneous holding company, whose assets range from bacon and girdles to phosphate mines and cosmetics, had been writing its own corporate strategy textbook.

title: Money Market Mutual Funds Up $39 Million
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose only $39 million, to $164.48 billion, in the week ended yesterday, the Investment Company Institute reported.

title: BOXER INJURED IN BOUT DIES
description: Isidro (Gino) Perez, a lightweight boxer, died yesterday morning having been comatose ever since he was knocked out in a bout at the Felt Forum last Friday.

title: EARL TUPPER, THE FATHER OF TUPPERWARE, DIES
description: Earl S. Tupper, who created the line of plastic food and drink containers known as Tupperware, died of a heart attack Monday in Costa Rica. He was 76 years old.

title: The Price of Honesty
description: All that Florida State's injured star tailback, Greg Allen, had to do last Saturday to hold his position as the nation's collegiate rushing leader was to stay on the bench. Allen, who is nursing an injured knee, had led the week before with a three-game average of 156.7 yards, and by missing Saturday's game against Auburn, his average would have remained the same.

title: BRIEFING
description: Black Caucus Warning

title: Bruins 9, Nordiques 3
description: Ray Bourque and Craig MacTavish scored two goals each as Boston opened its season in a game marked by four seperate fights and 68 minutes in penalties in the third period. The Bruins threw up a tight defense early in the game, refusing to allow a shot on goal while two men short for 65 seconds.

title: Changing Times
description: Enrique Tierno Galvan, the Mayor of Madrid, is in town for Madrid Week in New York. Yesterday, in a lecture in Spanish at the Spanish Institute,he said the early Spanish explorers of America experienced some culture shock.

title: PARLEY DISCUSSES PLANS FOR ROBOTS TO REPLACE FARM LABORERS
description: In an age when standing still means falling behind, scientists are straining to develop sturdy, cost-saving robots to replace humans as agricultural laborers.

title: Canada Offers to Take Central American Role
description: Canada is ready to send observers to Central America to monitor any peace agreement that the so-called Contadora group might arrange, Deputy Foreign Minister Jean-Luc Pepin said.

title: On Broadway, a Show Called '1984'
description: The 1984 Presidential campaign, it might be said, opened on Broadway Thursday night - and whatever happens for the rest of its run, for New York Democrats it was a hit.

title:
PATENTS;
New Alarm Clock Emits Nice Odors
description: An inspector for the New York City transit system and a Brooklyn surgeon have invented an alarm clock that wakes sleepers by emitting pleasant odors.

title: PROGESS AT EASTERN
description: Eastern Airlines yesterday reported a loss of $34.4 million for the third quarter, somewhat larger than the loss of $32.8 million in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: SOVIET IS SAID TO SHAKE UP FAR EAST AIR COMMAND
description: The Soviet Union has begun to shake up its Far Eastern air defense command, which was responsible for shooting down a South Korean passenger plane with the loss of 269 lives on Sept. 1, according to Administration officials.

title: Paris-Madrid Military Pact
description: France and Spain signed a military pact today providing for close cooperation between their armed forces. The agreement, under discussion since April, was signed by the French Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, and the Spanish Defense Minister, Narcis Serra.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET HASN'T RULED OUT REAGAN PROPOSALS AT ARMS TALKS
description: A senior State Department official said today that Soviet negotiators in Geneva ''have not formally rejected'' President Reagan's recent proposals to reduce medium- range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLAN ON TRANSIT DISCOUNTS IS BACKED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee has backed the concept of giving tax breaks to employers for selling discount monthly subway and bus tickets to their employees.

title: Suharto Voices Hope Reagan Will Reschedule Jakarta Visit
description: President Suharto has said he understands why President Reagan has postponed his visit to Indonesia and hopes a new date can be set for it.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-After a special charge of $1,325,000 for the quarter and 6 months related to closure of a manufacturing facility. c-Net income.

title: TELETEK INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss including income of $44,600 from discontinued operations.

title: Miss Whitelock And Executive Exchange Vows
description: Veronica Penelope Whitlock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmet Whitlock of Syosset, L.I., was married to Alexander Mellon Laughlin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Laughlin of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas F. Murphy at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., with the assistance of the Rev. John Rick, an Episcopal priest.

title: THE GHOSTS OF RECIPES PAST
description: Untried recipes, many yellow with age, fill shoeboxes, folders and kitchen drawers in homes from coast to coast. Few of us ever weed them out, and as the years pass it seems that we are less and less likely to try them.

title: Hospital Patient Killed by Gunman
description: A gunman slipped into a Bronx hospital at 3 A.M. yesterday and shot to death Jose Enrique, 44 years old, of 2267 Ellis Avenue, the Bronx, the police said.

title: News Analysis
description: Concern is growing at the highest levels of the Reagan Administration that developments in Syria and Israel are producing trends that could set back any chances for a peaceful settlement in Lebanon and even touch off another conflict in the Middle East.

title: AMID GRINDING SHORTAGES, A PARTY IN MOZAMBIQUE
description: President Samora M. Machel was unhappy, it is said, with the large painting depicting his ''liberation'' of this capital from Portuguese colonial rule that North Korean artists contributed to the Museum of the Revolution, where it now hangs at the head of the first flight of stairs.

title: Columbia Wins
description: Columbia's soccer team, ranked fifth nationally, raised its record to 7-0 tonight by beating Princeton, 3-1, on goals by Steve Pratten, Mark Prochilo and Steve Sirtis. The Tiger goal came from John Lamping.

title: 'ENTRE NOUS,' THE FRIENDSHIP OF TWO WOMEN
description: Neither of Diane Kurys's two previous films, ''Peppermint Soda'' (1977) and ''Cocktail Molotov'' (1980), gives any hint of the wonderfully sustained artistry that she demonstrates in ''Entre Nous,'' her very personal, moving new film that, all of a sudden, places her among those in the forefront of the commercial French cinema.

title: Peters Given Probation
description: Tony Peters, the Washington Redskins' all-pro safety who pleaded guilty to drug trafficking, was fined $10,000 today, placed on four years' probation and ordered to perform 500 hours of community work.

title: Reward Is Increased For Stolen Stallion
description: The insurers of the stolen race horse Shergar believe he is still alive, and his owners have increased the reward to $150,000 in an effort to find him.

title: SENATE PASSES BILL TO REDUCE SURPLUS IN DAIRY PRODUCTION
description: The Senate approved legislation today to pay farmers to scale down milk production. The measure, aimed at cutting overproduction by dairies that cost taxpayers $2.7 billion this past fiscal year, passed on a voice vote.

title: Bill Auction Delayed
description: Because of the Columbus Day holiday Monday, the Treasury Department will delay its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills until Tuesday.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Kaypro Price Cut
description: The Kaypro Corporation, a Solana Beach, Calif., computer manufacturer, announced that it had reduced the price of its Kaypro 4 personal portable computer by $200, to $1,795. Kaypro said the price reduction, which does not affect the Kaypro 10 model, is a result of supplier cost reductions in both disk drives and video display screens, coupled with increasing volume orders. The Kaypro 4, which uses double-density disks, features 392K of formatted storage per disk for a total of 784K for the unit's two disk drives.

title: CONCERT: EUGEN JOCHUM AND THE BAMBERG
description: The first of two concerts by Eugen Jochum and the Bamberg Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Thursday - the second will be an all-Beethoven program this coming Thursday - turned out to be a distinguished occasion. The evening was devoted entirely to Bruckner's Symphony No. 8 in C minor, in the Nowak edition.

title: COMP-U-CARD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Fan Arrested
description: A 25- year-old man was held today in connection with the beer-throwing incident involving Ron Kittle. The police said they arrested Robert Malzone of Bowie, Md., after Kittle had pointed him out.

title: New York Waste Gets Ohio Road Clearance
description: A judge has delayed for at least a month a ruling on whether to block nuclear waste shipments from New York through Ohio, although the shipments have already begun.

title: PRICE IS REPLACED AS CHIEF OF COLUMBIA PICTURES
description: The resignation of Frank Price as chairman of Columbia Pictures became official today. Mr. Price, who has been one of the movie industry's most respected, powerful and well-paid executives in recent years, resigned after a yearlong power struggle with Francis T. Vincent Jr., chairman of Columbia Pictures Industries, which is now a subsidiary of Coca-Cola.

title: Scatter-Site Mania
description: To the Editor:

title: Wickes Agrees To Sell Subsidiary
description: Wickes Companies said it had agreed to sell its Wickes Machine Tool Group to a group headed by the division's key managers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MEDICAL STUDENTS CHEATED ON EXAM
description: Cheating was widespread among foreign medical school graduates who took a test in July to qualify for American internships and residencies, and 10,000 of them will have to take it again, an official said

title:
PATENTS;
Reflecting Collar
description: Reflecting Collar

title: 2 U.S. Pilots Reported In Sicilian Air Incident
description: The pilots of two United States Air Force fighter- bombers almost hit an Italian airliner last month because they disobeyed ground control instructions, an Italian Air Force officer said today.

title: PAUL CADWELL
description: Paul Cadwell, a lawyer, businessman, farmer and lifelong banjo devotee who in his 80's became a familiar figure at folk-music festivals and concerts, died of a stroke Tuesday at Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was was 94 years old and lived in Jackson Heights.

title: DRUSE AND CHRISTIAN FORCES EXCHANGE 44 PRISONERS
description: Lebanese Christian and Druse militias exchanged 44 civilian prisoners today, most of them old men and women captured in the three weeks of fighting that ended with a cease-fire 11 days ago.

title: ECHLIN INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Quotations of the Day
description: ''It felt like my bed was plugged in and was going to take off.''

title: No-Fault Reform, at Last, in Trenton
description: Compared with reforms in other states, the no- fault auto insurance bill signed by New Jersey's Governor Kean is modest. After such a protracted struggle, however, even modest improvements are worth applauding.

title: BRAZIL DEBT PACT HAILED, BUT EASING IS URGED
description: Political leaders today hailed an agreement between the Government and foreign banks to ease repayment terms on the country's $90 billion foreign debt, but some said it did not go far enough.

title: L.I. Lawyer Slain
description: A 49-year-old Sea Cliff lawyer was found stabbed and bludgeoned to death behind an electronics concern here today, the police said.

title: CHIEF OF BATTLE AGAINST DRUG CRIME
description: Just after the Senate, by a voice vote, confirmed Francis M. Mullen Jr. as the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration today, the telephones started ringing in the modern, 12-story office building that is the agency's headquarters.

title:
PATENTS;
Chemical Substitute
description: A safe substitute for the toxic compound DMF, a chemical ingredient found in electrolytic capacitors, was patented this week for the North American Philips Corporation. Roland F. Dapo, a senior development engineer for Mepco/Electra Inc., a subsidiary in Columbia, S.C., obtained patent 4,408,258 for the substitute, an electrolyte containing ethylene glycol, which is much less toxic than DMF. Capacitors are a fundamental component of most electronics devices.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: APPRAISING WHO DID MOST FOR BASEBALL
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS TO RETAIN CITY IDENTITY
description: ''The name of the team is still, and will be, the New York Jets.''

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $30,000 for the latest first quarter and $9,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: REPORTS ON PICKENS SPUR GULF STOCK
description: Nearly two million shares of the Gulf Oil Corporation stock changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as reports circulated that T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company of Texas, had been buying stock in the nation's sixth-largest oil company.

title: CARL SCHURZ'S LEGACY
description: In an age when ethnic politics has become so controversial, it is well to remember that appeals from political leaders to immigrant interests are nothing new. In this tricentennial of German settlement in America, Carl Schurz, one of the greatest German- Americans, deserves to be recalled as a model for ethnic politicians.

title: WALESA'S NOBEL: TARDY BUT STILL USEFUL
description: Last year, Lech Walesa sheltered great hopes for the Nobel Peace Prize. He felt he deserved it more than any other candidate, and he was fully aware of its potential impact on the Polish situation. This year, he no longer expected it.

title: BRIEFING
description: Far East Itinerary

title: Kellogg Honored
description: Thirty years ago when Junius Kellogg was graduated from Manhattan College, his name was already well known. Two years earlier, he had reported a bribe offer of $1,000 to him to ''fix'' a basketball game against DePaul.

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including income of $900,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $300,000 from discontinued operations. Previously reported results have been restated to reflect the classification of the poultry product segment as a discontinued business.

title: 'REDISCOVER ASYLUM' FOR HOMELESS MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Collateralized Mortgages
description: A NEW type of mortgage-related security has created a stir among many investors - individuals as well as institutions - because it combines features of both the corporate and the mortgage markets. As a result, the investors receive not only the high yields and relative safety of pass-through mortgage securities but also the ownership convenience derived from the corporate bond structure.

title: Yonkers to Get $1.4 Million Grant
description: The state's fourth largest city has been formally notified that an expected $1.4 million Federal job training grant was no longer in jeopardy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day Thursday listing banks' interest rates for certificates of deposit incorrectly listed the Bowery Savings Bank's rate. It is 11 percent on six-month certificates.

title: Letter: On School Prayer ; Court Confusion Over Church and State
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon Bank Failure
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today announced that the liabilities of a defunct bank in Redmond, Ore., had been assumed by the United States National Bank of Oregon in Portland. The Deschutes Bank was closed today by Oregon's Superintendent of Banks, John B. Olin. who said that ''during the past three years the banks losses have been heavy and earnings have been nonexistent.'' The bank had 2,800 accounts.

title: U.S. ASKED TO BAN SOVIET ITEMS MADE BY FORCED LABOR
description: The Commissioner of Customs has recommended that three dozen products made in the Soviet Union be barred from the United States because he has reason to believe they were made with the help of forced labor.

title: A PRISON DOESN'T OFFER JOBS FOR THE FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. REBELS SAY THEY'RE WINNING
description: In the last two weeks the Syrian-backed rebels seeking to overthrow Yasir Arafat as the Palestinian guerrilla leader feel they have gained the upper hand.

title:
Patents;
Decoding Scrambled TV Signal
description: THE unauthorized reception of television programs from cable and pay television stations has led to much coding and decoding of TV signals. The Zenith Radio Corporation of Glenview, Ill., received patent 4,408,225 this week on a subscription television unscrambler invented by two employees, James W. Ensinger and Melvin C. Hendrickson.

title: NUCLEAR WASTES THROUGH CITIES
description: Highly radioactive nuclear-waste shipments are again moving through or near America's cities. Ironically, emerging technologies allowing on- site storage will make most shipments unnecessary until final disposal facilities are ready in 10 to 15 years. Moving the waste to a temporary dump today multiplies the number of trips, raising the specter of a tragic accident in a major city. Congress must take action to restrict these unneeded shipments, and investigate the real risks involved in transporting such hazardous materials.

title: RULES ON TV NETWORKS' SYNDICATION OF SHOWS
description: For more than a year, the three commercial television networks and Hollywood program producers have been battling over an issue that both sides contend is central to the future of television programming: whether to permit the networks to profit from and control the sale or syndication of prime-time series to individual stations after the shows have appeared on the networks. Last year, these syndication sales brought Hollywood program producers $800 million.

title: PSYCH SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a reduction in a tax credit of $13,108. c-Net income including a tax credit of $3,504.

title: TREMORS FROM ADIRONDACK QUAKE SHAKE NORTHEAST U.S. AND CANADA
description: An earthquake struck deep in the Adirondack Mountains in northern New York yesterday morning, setting off tremors felt throughout the northeastern United States and the Canadian provinces of Quebec and Ontario.

title: PAUL STEINDLER, RESTAURATEUR AND CHEF IN NEW YORK, DIES
description: Paul Steindler, a chef and the proprietor of several restaurants in New York City, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: Americans Lose In Suntory Golf
description: For the first time in the tournament's 20-year history, no American has reached the semifinals of the $225,000 Suntory World Match Play Golf Championship. Calvin Peete, Bill Rogers and Hale Irwin were beaten in the quarterfinals at Wentworth today.

title: Arthur Foerster, 84 Worked On Designing the Hindenburg
description: Arthur F. Foerster, an engineer who was a member of the German team that designed the Hindenburg zeppelin, died Sept. 28 in a hospital in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 84 years old and had lived in Lakewood, N.J., for the last 11 years.

title: Roommate Held in Death Of Colorado U. Student
description: Thayne Smika, a prime suspect all along, was arrested Thursday on charges of killing his roommate.

title: BRAZIL PACT OUTLINED TO BANKS
description: A delegation of Brazilian officials and international bankers set out yesterday on a round-the-world trip to sell a tentative $11.8 billion credit agreement to the 800 commercial banks that have lent money to Brazil. The agreement postpones for five years payment of debt principal owed in 1984 by Brazil.

title: Argentina Detains Falkland Commander
description: The former Argentine governor of the Falkland Islands was ordered detained for 60 days today for publishing a book about the war last year with Britain over the islands, relatives said. They said Gen. Mario Benjamin Menendez was taken to Magdalena, 60 miles south of here, to serve the sentence.

title: PUNJAB POLICE ARE GIVEN BROAD POWERS
description: The police and paramilitary forces, under orders to shoot lawbreakers on sight and empowered to raid the sanctuaries of suspected Sikh terrorists at will, patrolled parts of Punjab today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 34.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Piece of the Past In Search of a Future

title: THE SECRET COURTING OF ROBERT KILEY
description: Everybody in Boston seemed to have good things to say about Robert R. Kiley, a leading candidate to be the new chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, but they did not have time to tell Governor Cuomo's counselor. It was Yaz Day at Fenway Park, and some things come first.

title: Bulls Sign Green
description: Sidney Green, the Brooklyn-born all-American from the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, signed a multiyear contract with the Chicago Bulls that is expected to bring him $1.2 million over the life of the contract. Green, a 6-foot-9-inch forward who had starred for Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn and who averaged 22.1 points a game in his last college season, had been the fifth player selected in the 1983 N.B.A. draft and was the Bulls first pick.

title: HMW Merger Bid
description: -a-share tender offer from the Clabir Corporation and a $44-a-share merger offer organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, announced that after reviewing the two offers, the board of directors had decided to go after the K.K.R. merger as quickly as possible. The board has set Nov. 21, 1983, as the meeting date for consideration of the K.K.R. merger proposal, and Oct. 24 as the record date for shareholders entitled to vote at that meeting. Under the amended tender that the HMW board urged shareholders to reject, Clabir was offering $43 a share for 1,075,000, or approximately 67 percent, of HMW's outstanding shares.

title: Article 217787 -- No Title
description: A jury in Spokane County Superior Court has awarded $3.5 million to a woman and her teen-age son for brain damage that he suffered in a midget- league hockey game three years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Thursday about Cuban discussions with anti-Sandinista groups misidentified the person who helped the anti-Sandinista leader Eden Pastora Gomez to leave Cuba in 1982. The person was Dumas Torrijos, a son of the late Panamanian leader Omar Torrijos Herrera.

title: G.E. Aircraft Deal
description: The General Electric Aircraft Engine Business Group in Lynn, Mass., announced that it had received a $738 million multiyear contract for helicopter engines, the largest military engine contract in the history of the Lynn aircraft engine business. The contract calls for G.E. to supply engines to power four types of military helicopters for Navy and Air Force programs for the Government's next three fiscal years. Normally, such contracts are awarded on an annual basis.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 10 Down, 299,990 to Go

title: The Balance of Robert McGuire
description: For Robert McGuire, becoming New York City's Police Commissioner in 1978 was something like walking into a meat grinder. The department was reeling from heavy layoffs; the streets seemed overrun with criminals. And Mr. McGuire was 41, too young, some thought, to lead the nation's largest police force.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: JOBLESSNESS FALLS TO 18-MONTH LOW AS RECOVERY GAINS
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell by three- tenths of a percentage point to 9.1 percent in September, the lowest level in 18 months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock dividend effected Aug. 22.

title: PRESIDENT DENIES BLAME FOR DEFICIT
description: President Reagan disowned responsibility for record Federal deficits today and told voters they would be ''taxed into the poorhouse'' if Democrats regained control of the White House.

title: Nicaraguan Guerrillas Report Laying Mines at a Key Port
description: Anti-Sandinista rebels said here today that their forces had planted mines in the waters around the port where Nicaragua receives its oil.

title: Defense Wants to Close Case In Death of Officer in Queens
description: Defense lawyers said yesterday that murder charges against two former Black Panthers should be dropped, after a second jury was unable to decide if the two had killed a Queens police officer.

title: Niekro and Braves Part
description: After a 25-year affiliation with the Braves organization that produced 268 major league victories, three 20- game seasons and two divisional championships, Phil Niekro announced his exit from Atlanta yesterday and promptly began looking for another home. Standing in front of his locker with his release papers in his hands, Niekro, a 44-year-old knuckleball specialist who is the oldest player in the major leagues, said he had sought the release because the club's coaches thought he should retire, and he didn't want to accept an offer from the Braves' owner, Ted Turner , to remain on the roster as a relief pitcher next year.

title: DON'T REACH MY WAY
description: Not long ago I was hugged by Dr. Leo Buscaglia, who agrees with the telephone company and certain church people that everybody ought to reach out and touch somebody. Though I was meeting Dr. Buscaglia for the first time and don't usually take to hugging even from old friends, it was a pleasant experience.

title: REAGAN REPLACING LEGAL AID BOARD
description: President Reagan today announced plans to nominate new members for all 11 positions on board of directors of the troubled Legal Services Corporation.

title: ENVOY OF VATICAN TO LEAD FUNERAL
description: Pope John Paul II's personal representative in the United States will preside Monday at the funeral of Terence Cardinal Cooke at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: 2 Expelled at Pace
description: Two members of the Pace football team have been expelled from school and six others have walked off the team in protest, the school's athletic director, Peter Finnerty, said yesterday. He identified the expelled players as a team co-captain, Mike Robustelli, son of the former Giant star and general manager, Andy Robustelli, and Bob Monti.

title: SOVIET FILM MAKES KANSAS CITY REGRET HOSPITALITY
description: A year ago some Kansas City residents volunteered to help a Soviet television crew to film a documentary about American life. But when they saw the product three weeks ago, they were sorry.

title: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY FIGHTS A COURT BATTLE ON ITS HONOR SYSTEM
description: Princeton University's honor code, a prescription for academic honesty conceived in part at the urging of Woodrow Wilson, is being examined in a court of law for the first time since its inception 90 years ago. The case, which is in its final stages, is expected to conclude next week.

title: NUCLEAR DILEMMA FOR OHIO UTILITY
description: A decision by the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company to cancel the nearly completed nuclear power plant in Zimmer, Ohio would have ''grave'' consequences not only for the utility but also for the already struggling nuclear power industry, analysts said yesterday.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LARGE LOSS AT BALDWIN
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, which filed for protection last week under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, yesterday announced a loss of $44.4 million for the second quarter. A year earlier, the financial services company earned $28.5 million, or $1.27 a share.

title: Bush Speaks To Jersey G.O.P.
description: Vice President Bush told 400 Republicans at a $500-a-plate luncheon today that the New Jersey legislative elections this fall would be viewed across the country as a referendum on the Reagan Administration's policies.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results include proceeds from safe harbor leasing transactions of $32.9 million and $66.5 million for the latest quarter and 9 months respectively and $300,000 and $1.2 million for the year-ago quarter and 9 months respectively.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: DOWNTOWN CHURCH SALUTES A LEADER AND A CENTENNIAL
description: Those who made their way to the Colonial-style church at the tip of Manhattan yesterday sang joyful praises to the church's century of service, a saint's devotion and a religious man's virtues.

title: Smoke Fills Jet Cockpit, But Plane Lands Safely
description: An electrical fire filled the cockpit of a Western Airlines jet with smoke today, but it made a safe landing at Anchorage International Airport, officials said.

title: MOFFAT COMMUNICATIONS LTD reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
BOOMING AUSTIN FEARS IT WILL LOSE ITS CHARMS
description: This appealing college town set in the lovely Texas hill country is rapidly becoming a major city with a high-technology economy, and many an Austinite is wondering if that will spoil a good thing.

title: CORBY DISTILLERIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Jury Finds Man Guilty Of Killing by C.B. Radio
description: A jury convicted a citizens' band radio operator of involuntary manslaughter today for setting up a fatal shootout between the police and a 70-year-old man who was nearly blind.

title: MARCOS FREEZES PRICES AND PAY RATE
description: The Government announced today that it would delay an increase in the minimum wage and would freeze the prices of key commodities to cushion the shock of this week's currency devaluation.

title: DEALER GOT GOLD SENT RECENTLY
description: Alan David Saxon, the gold dealer whose suicide last week touched off a search for $60 million in precious metals presumed missing, did actually take regular delivery of gold and other investment bars, and was doing so as late as Sept. 26, according to an international bullion wholesaler.

title: ACES MOVE AHEAD OF ITALIANS IN THE BERMUDA BOWL FINALS
description: Shortly after the midpoint of the World Championship finals here this afternoon, the Aces pulled ahead of their Italian opponents after the two teams had been neck and neck for a day and a half.

title: BIFLYX CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $249,000 on the sale of assets.

title: THE PROFIT MOTIVE AS PRAGMATIC CENSOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Nine Mile Pt.Plant Faulted by N.R.C.
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday cited the operator of the Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear power plant in Oswego, N.Y., for running the reactor with safety equipment out of order and using procedures that could allow radiation to escape during an accident.

title: Poland Grain Import Plans
description: Poland plans to import 3.5 million metric tons of grain from the West next year at a cost of more than $600 million, the official P.A.P. press agency said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Familiar Faces

title: A WRENCHING WEEK AT AIRLINE
description: Eastern Airlines reported a wider loss but also some headway with three of its unions. Page 38.

title: DOW RISES BY 3.35, TO ANOTHER RECORD
description: The stock market ended one of its more successful weeks yesterday with a moderate advance in continued heavy trading.

title: Another Role For a Runner
description: Last December, Christine Curtin became an established figure in long- distance running when she won the Kinney National High School Cross- Country championships in Orlando, Fla.

title: 3 ELECTED TO BALLET BOARD
description: The American Ballet Theater yesterday announced the election of three new board members: Philip L. Thomas, vice president of Esmark; Leslie H. Wexner, chairman and president of Limited Inc., and Audre Mendel of Miami Beach. Announced also was the resignation from the board of Dr. Irwin M. Stelzer.

title: WHERE'S THE MARKET FOR FILAMENT CLOTHES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Institute Says Turkey Is Harassing a Writer
description: The International Press Institute accused Turkey's military Government today of harassing a prominent columnist who is on trial for criticizing the military.

title: INTERFIRST BANK POSTS HUGE LOSS
description: The Interfirst Corporation of Dallas, the nation's 14th-largest bank holding company, reported late yesterday that it had lost $194 million in the third quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: BUSINESS COMPUTING INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Court Backs Reduction In Burnett Libel Award
description: The California Supreme Court let stand Thursday an appeals court ruling that trimmed from $750,000 to $150,000 the punitive damages that The National Enquirer had been ordered to pay Carol Burnett.

title: MATTHEWS AT BEST AGAINST DODGERS
description: Whenever Gary Matthews found himself on the bench this year, left out of a lineup shuffle that sometimes baffled him, he looked to Pete Rose as a model.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Wednesday about auto sales incorrectly reported the number of companies involved in the 16.7 percent sales increase for the 1983 model year. The sales of all the American auto manufacturers yielded this percentage increase from the 1982 model year.

title: CARDINAL COOKE REMEMBERED FOR KINDNESS IN LIFE AND COURAGE UNTIL DEATH
description: News Analysis

title: RANGERS DOWN DEVILS AGAIN
description: The Rangers outmuscled and outskated the Devils for the second time in three nights, spoiling New Jersey's home opener tonight with a 3-1 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: 2D SUSPECT SEIZED IN SLAYING OF LAWYER VISITING 'VILLAGE'
description: A Brooklyn handyman was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a lawyer from Philadelphia on a busy street in Greenwich Village during the Labor Day weekend.

title: Bates Motel Retired to Stud
description: Bates Motel, who won four major handicap races this year before finishing second in the Woodward Stakes and third in the Marlboro Cup, was retired from racing yesterday, as had been expected. He will stand at stud at Gainesway Farm in Lexington, Ky.

title: Bangladesh Plans Elections
description: The military Government announced today that several local elections would be held between December and March. Opposition leaders have been demanding parliamentary elections to restore democracy, and they immediately opposed the local- election schedule, saying the parliamentary elections should come first.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES SAY WATT'S DEPARTURE IS LIKELY
description: White House aides predicted today that Interior Secretary James G. Watt could not survive a Senate resolution urging his resignation and said they viewed his departure as likely.

title: Appointment at Whitney
description: Lisa Phillips has been named head of branch museums and associate curator of the Whitney Museum. Miss Phillips, a graduate of Middlebury College, studied at the Institute for European Studies in Vienna and in the doctoral program in art history at the graduate center of the City University of New York. She has been with the museum since 1975.

title: Sampson's Debut
description: It was billed as a superstar's first professional appearance, and if it didn't turn out to be a superstar performance, nobody was complaining after Ralph Sampson played his first game with the Houston Rockets in an exhibition Thursday night. ''Ralph played a sporadic game, but I'm not disappointed,'' said the Rockets' coach, Bill Fitch , after Sampson, the former Virginia star, scored 24 points, the game high, as the Rockets lost to the Dallas Mavericks, 122-111.

title:
PATENTS;
Optical Switching
description: For the hair-thin optical fibers that carry communications on lightwaves, an accurate switching system has been invented that keeps the loss of light signal extremely low. Patent 4,407,562 was awarded this week to William C. Young of the Bell Laboratory technical staff. The switch, which can be used in undersea or underground operations, moves a glass fiber less than a tenth of a millimeter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Rikers Cup

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $600 MILLION
description: The nation's basic measure of the money supply rose by a relatively small $600 million for the week ended Sept. 28, the Federal Reserve System reported late yesterday.

title: In a New Dugout
description: Jim Frey says he is ''ready to roll the dice again, give it my best shot.'' The 51-year-old batting coach of the Mets agreed on Thursday to become the manager of the Chicago Cubs, a team that finished in fifth place in the National League Eastern Division this season.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. IS SAID TO REJECT JUDGE'S CHOICE FOR CRIME JOB
description: The Justice Department decided today not to accept Judge Irving R. Kaufman's choice for executive director of the anticrime commission the judge heads. But it did not name anyone else as director of the commission, which has not held a meeting since it was named in July.

title: NEW YORK JOBLESS DECLINE
description: The unemployment rate for New York City dropped to 10.1 percent in September, compared with 10.6 percent in both July and August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: 11 Bombings in Corsica
description: Eleven bombs exploded between 3 and 3:20 A.M. today, damaging several banks but causing no injuries. The police said they believed Corsican nationalists were responsible. Ten of the bombs were in this northern port city and one was in the interior town of Corte.

title: GEN. MARTIN M. OSTROW
description: Brig. Gen. Martin M. Ostrow, U.S.A.F., retired, who founded a scholarship program to aid the children of United States servicemen killed or missing in Southeast Asia, has died of a heart attack.

title: AGENT TESTIFIES ON 'HIT MAN' ROLE IN WILSON CASE
description: An undercover agent testified yesterday that he had posed as a ''hit man'' willing to carry out killings for Edwin P. Wilson, who was accused of plotting several murders while in prison for shipping arms to Libya.

title: RICHARDSON ADMITS RELAPSE
description: Three days after his sudden disappearance from the Nets' training camp on the Princeton campus, Michael Ray Richardson informed the National Basketball Players Association today that he had suffered a relapse of cocaine abuse.

title: TRIBUTE TO BELOVED COACH
description: Fifty years after the fact, Chester Elson can conjure up the sensations of sleeping in the field house at DePauw University in Greencastle, Ind., earning a dollar a day as night watchman and some spare change mowing his football coach's lawn and baby-sitting for his coach's children.

title: OFFICIALS SAY BORDER AID FUNDS ARE USED TO UNDERWRITE OIL RIGS
description: Nearly $100 million described by the Reagan Administration as aid to areas hurt by devaluation of the Mexican peso went to underwrite offshore oil rigs built in Mississippi and for development of rental property near Palm Springs, Calif., Federal officials said today.

title: VOLCKER STRESSES NEED TO REIN IN PAY AND PRICES
description: The head of the nation's central bank expressed concern today that American businessmen and workers would ask for excessive wage and price increases because they did not realize how far inflation had fallen.

title: CARTER AUCTION BRINGS $320,000 FOR NEW CENTER
description: With the sale of 300 donated items ranging from four hickory chairs handcrafted by former President Jimmy Carter to Willie Nelson's used running shoes, $320,000 was raised at an auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet to benefit the Carter Presidential Library and the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta.

title: CHICAGO, CHICAGO!
description: Chicago is a place where one Valentine's Day visitors arrived not with flowers but with machine guns and left their hosts strewn on the floor, red as roses.

title: CONCERT: BACH FESTIVAL OPENS
description: The challenge that Bach's B Minor Mass poses to its interpreters may be seen in one of its smallest details. At the center of the work - which was performed by Richard Westenburg, leading the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra, Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall at the opening of the Basically Bach Festival - is the chorus ''Et incarnatus est.'' The descending, imitative choral lines are accompanied by repeated descending sighs and breaths in the violins, like the pulses of the Holy Spirit of the Mass's text. Then, after the words ''and was made man,'' those patterns descend from their positions on the staff and become incarnate in the music's foundation, its continuo line.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1983
description: International

title: Rightist Death Squad Kills 4 in El Salvador
description: Three men and a woman, including a top leftist, were found strangled near a market in San Salvador today.

title: TELLING A WINE BY ITS LABEL
description: SOME wine lovers believe that wine labels do not contain enough information.
