Others think they say too much, particularly California back labels - the label on the back of the bottle that offers a history of the winery and a chemical analysis of the product. For consumers, knowing how to read a California label can make buying wine easier and drinking it more enjoyable.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 21
Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issue

title: MANSLAUGHTER VERDICT IN JERSEY AUTO DEATH
description: A motorist who was charged with running over a 7-year-old Hispanic boy because of racial bias was found not guilty of murder today but guilty of aggravated manslaughter.

title: Canada, Textron In Helicopter Pact
description: Under an agreement by the Canadian Government, the Quebec government and Bell Helicopter, a unit of Textron Inc., a total of $514.1 million will be invested to build a new model light twin-engine helicopter line at an assembly facility in Mirabel, Quebec.

title: REGRETTABLE LEGACY OF PUBLIC HOUSING BATTLES
description: To the Editor:

title: New Chock Full Proxy Fight Seen
description: Dissident stockholders attempting to gain control of Chock Full o'Nuts, the New York fast-food chain, plan to start a new proxy fight at the next annual meeting, it was disclosed by sources close to Jerry Finkelstein, the New York investor heading the group.

title: Power Seat Wins Trot in Kentucky
description: Power Seat surged to the lead at the half-mile pole of the Red Mile today, then held off TV Yankee and Tarport Lizzy in the homestretch to win the Kentucky Futurity, the final race of the triple crown series for 3-year-old trotters.

title: ORIOLES DEFEAT WHITE SOX
description: The Philadelphia Phillies moved within one victory of the National League pennant today when they defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-2, on the four- hit pitching of the rookie Charles Hudson.

title: BENCH THE BOSSES
description: Stanley Friedman, who revels in his role as the hard-nosed Bronx Democratic boss, may just have performed - unwittingly - a major public service.

title: News Analysis
description: In politics, as in sports and gambling, it is sometimes as important to be lucky as to be good. And Senator John Glenn's remarkable run of political luck continued Thursday night when the seven Democratic Presidential candidates made their first joint appearance.

title: A DOCUMENTARY ON WILLIAM BURROUGHS
description: Rarely is a documentary as well attuned to its subject as Howard Brookner's ''Burroughs,'' which captures as much about the life, work and sensibility of its subject as its 86 minute format allows. Part of the film's comprehensiveness is attributable to William S. Burroughs' cooperation, since the author was willing to visit old haunts, read from his works and even playfully act out a passage from ''Naked Lunch'' for the benefit of the camera. But the quality of discovery about ''Burroughs'' is very much the director's doing, and Mr. Brookner demonstrates an unusual degree of liveliness and curiousity in exploring his subject.

title: SHOPPING MILAN: CHOICE GOODS
description: The central shopping area of Milan could probably fit into the bedding department of Macy's. But within that concentrated area there are more designer boutiques, trendy emporiums and traditional stores for furnishings than one might expect in such a physically unprepossessing location.

title: FOR 2-1 EDGE
description: Eddie Murray, whose explosiveness had been defused in postseason games, ended his futility tonight. The Chicago White Sox, though, again failed to find the power they desperately need to put them back in contention for the American League pennant.

title: TORRANCE LEADS SOUTHERN OPEN
description: Sam Torrance of Scotland shot a 67 today to take the second-round lead in the $250,000 Southern Open with a seven-under-par 133 total.

title: Mariners Drop O'Brien
description: Dan O'Brien was dismissed as president and general manager of the Seattle Mariners yesterday and his protege, Hal Keller, the director of player development, was promoted to general manager.

title: GRAIN SALE TO CHINA FALTERING
description: China, the largest foreign market for American wheat, seems unlikely to meet its obligation to buy a minimum of 6 million tons of grain from the United States this year.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dr. George O. Abell, 57, Dies; Observer of Galaxy Clusters
description: Dr. George O. Abell, an astronomer and cosmologist, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 57 years old.

title: Tosco Puzzled Over Stock
description: The Tosco Corporation said it knew of no reason for the high volume of trading in its common stock yesterday, or for the 27 percent drop in its market price.

title: SPAT OVER NOBEL PRIZE EMBARASSES ACADEMY
description: It has been some time since the venerable Swedish Academy, founded in 1786 by King Gustav III, has been quite so embarrassed.

title: Toni Morrison Is '93 Winner of Nobel Prize in Literature
description: Toni Morrison, the author of "Song of Solomon" "Beloved," "Jazz" and other lyrically narrated novels of black American life, has won the 1993 Nobel Prize in Literature. The announcement was made yesterday in Stockholm by the Nobel Committee of the Swedish Academy, which stated that Ms. Morrison "gives life to an essential aspect of American reality" in novels "characterized by visionary force and poetic import."

title: Light Tax in Breakup Expected by A.T.T.
description: The distribution of shares of the regional Bell holding companies to be formed on Jan. 1 will be almost completely tax-free for its shareholders, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday.

title: British Pensions Get Rampac Stake
description: Two pension plans of the National Coal Board of Britain have purchased a 10.4 percent interest in Rampac, a California real estate investment trust, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Books of The Times; The Life of a Legend
description: LOUIS ARMSTRONG: AN AMERICAN The Life of a Legend GENIUS. By James Lincoln Collier. Illustrated. 383 pages. Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: SINGULAR DRIVING FORCE IN HISTORY
description: ''When you start from nowhere, it is all uphill,'' says Joan Challinor, the woman who single-handedly put together the international observation that marks the Bicentennial of the Treaty of Paris, a celebration that began Sept. 3 and is to go on to March 1984.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $109,000 for the quarter and $471,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $3,740,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FRANK G. MORRISON
description: Frank G. Morrison, a civic leader wo was the retired president and business manager of The Pittsburgh Press, died Wednesday in St. Clair Memorial Hospital in suburban Mount Lebanon.

title: ADI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A BOXER'S DEATH EVOKES LAMENT
description: The word came Thursday morning, and for Amparo Perez, the hours of waiting and the nights of restless sleep in the hallway of St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan were finally over. Her son Gino, a 24-year- old lightweight boxer, died Thursday morning, after being comatose since he was knocked out in a fight at the Felt Forum a week ago Friday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CONTROVERSIAL DIRECTOR

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: A BOOKSELLER'S TALE AND HOW IT GREW
description: AT a time when paeans to the powers of the computer seem to issue endlessly, Hayward Cirker (the ''C'' is sibilant) of Hewlett stands fast in defense of the book.

title: WARMTH IN CHILLY LONDON
description: London in the 1950's. Winter. Men and women in the grave ''utility clothing'' left over from the war. Home fires foul with a compressed coal dust called ''nutty slack.'' Bus conductors walking ahead of their vehicles like elephant handlers, in what was to be one of the last of the great fogs. My first season ever outside my own country, on a scholarship won me by stories I would have been compelled to tell anyway. Though I have come by boat, it half seems as if I am really there by magic carpet.

title: Glen Kohl to Be Wed To Julie Abrahamson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Abrahamson of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Abrahamson, to Glen Arlen Kohl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Kohl of Fair Lawn, N.J., and Aspen, Colo.

title: SYRIAN LEADER'S PLANS THREATEN ARABS TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.P. Position Is That of Union
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MISS CRITTENBERGER TO WED GEORGE GAY
description: Maj. Gen. Willis Dale Crittenberger Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Crittenberger of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Dale Crittenberger, to George Edward Harper Gay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Newton Gay Jr. of Baltimore. A Jan. 7 wedding is planned.

title: ELDERLY FLORIDA COUPLE FINDS WAY 'TO LEAVE THIS WORLD TOGETHER'
description: Julia Saunders, 81 years old, had her hair done. Her husband, Cecil, 85, collected the mail one final time and paused to chat with a neighbor. Inside their mobile home, they carefully laid out a navy blazer and a powder-blue dress.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: DATA USED by the state's Department of Environmental Protection to justify its recent warning against eating some pesticide-contaminated bluefish were known to scientists at least nine months before an announcement was made.

title: KENT STOPS AVON OLD FARMS
description: Kent, which usually relies on its passing game to put points on the board, scored three touchdowns on the ground yesterday for a 24-8 victory over previously undefeated Avon Old Farms. It was the visitors' third straight triumph; Avon is 2-1.

title: DOWN TO THE WIRE IN STOCKHOLM
description: One of the most exciting moments in the history of the world team championship occurred in Stockholm a week ago. U.S.A. II had already clinched one semi- final place; and with one match remaining New Zealand was the front- runner for the vital second spot. They were closely pursued by Italy, Pakistan and Sweden in that order.

title: THE REGION
description: Senate ShowsJurist Prudence

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: 'Skimming' to a Happy Ending

title: BELLPORT EXTENDS STREAK TO 17
description: Greg Cooke scored three times to help Bellport trounce Amityville yesterday, 41-0, in League V play. Bellport (3-0) now holds Suffolk County's longest winning streak at 17 games.

title: Data Bank; October 9, 1983

ANTIQUES;
SPECIAL SPOON SHOWN IN HARTFORD
description: ONE of only two pieces known to exist today, made at the turn of the 18th century by a Connecticut silversmith, has been found by I. E. Liverant of Colchester. It is a silver spoon made by Rene Grignon of Norwich, a Huguenot who had emigrated from France and who settled first near Deerfield, Mass.

title: TOUR FOR THE AVANT-GARDE
description: The New York State Council on the Arts is the largest, most innovative State arts council in the country. But now it is embarking on something entirely new - a project the council itself has produced, as opposed merely to funding. This is the New York State New Music Network, which will enable eight avant-garde musical performers and groups of varying kinds to tour six New York cities over the first three weekends in November.

title: PARENTS AND TEACHERS VOICE FRUSTRATION OVER PAUCITY OF PROGRAMS FOR THE GIFTED
description: FRUSTRATION over what is perceived as a lack of support from, and ''foot dragging'' by, both the state and Federal Governments on programs for New Jersey's most talented students appeared to be evident at a recent conference here.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: STATE IS BILLING COMPANIES ON ANTIPOLLUTION COSTS
description: The State Environmental Conservation Department has mailed bills totaling $12 million to 13,000 industrial companies and 1,000 Federal, state and local agencies to collect funds to help pay the costs of regulating air and water quality and hazardous wastes in the state.

title: AN ITALIAN PRODUCER PRESERVES THE GLORIES OF THE LATEST JAZZ
description: One of the most important figures in current jazz is a genial, silver-haired, 53- year-old Italian businessman based in Milan. He is Giovanni Bonandrini, the president of Black Saint Records, which is virtually the only label now recording a full spectrum of up-to-the-minute jazz.

title: No Met Manager Yet
description: Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, said yesterday that he had not yet decided on a new manager for the team. And he denied reports that he had asked the California Angels for permission to talk to their manager, John McNamara.

title: For Hummingbirds, A Fatal Electric Lure
description: Hummingbirds left without a food supply by a summer drought are being killed because they mistake red wire insulators on electrified fences for fall flowers, according to conservation officials.

title: ANDROPOV'S ECONOMIC DILEMMA
description: Leonard Silk is the economics columnist of The New York Times. HE WHOLE HECTIC SCENE, WITH ITS LONG queues, surly saleswomen and shoddy goods, was as familiar as a recurrent dream. But it's one thing to read about the jumble of the Soviet economy; it's another to see it for yourself. Here I was, in a general store in a small town in northeastern Siberia, and what I saw struck me as the heart of the mystery that had brought me to the Soviet Union for the first time in my life. Brassieres next to children's toys, fabrics next to souvenirs, fountain pens next to shirts and pants, pots and pans next to shoes and socks. Sofas and chairs that belonged in a thrift shop. Small refrigerators that could have come out of a 1924 Sears catalogue. And everybody - men and women jamming the place after their normal working day - buying like crazy, as though the ruble were about to collapse.

title: NETS PUZZLED BY RICHARDSON
description: When Eddie Phillips awakened on Wednesday morning, he thought nothing was amiss. His roommate's belongings were in order - shoes lined up neatly by the wall, clothes in the closet. In the bathroom, a toothbrush was in its proper place on the sink.

title: ...AND JAMES STEWART RECALLS 'HITCH'
description: L.B. Jeffries, the inquiring photographer whose broken leg prevents him from doing anything more strenuous than gazing out his window, is back. And he's in very good company, or soon will be. He will be joined by John ''Scottie'' Ferguson, who loves one woman because she reminds him of another and who is paralyzed by his fear of heights; Dr. Ben McKenna, whose child is kidnapped as part of an international assassination plot; and Rupert Cadell, a professor who attends a party and solves a murder mystery in the same apartment, and on the very same evening.

title: A FEAST FOR THE DO-IT-YOURSELFER
description: The Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue will be turned into a do- it-yourselfer's paradise Friday when the second annual Big Apple Fix-Up opens for a three-day run. More than 150 exhibitors will display and demonstrate products for renovating, remodeling and repairing houses and apartments.

title: REMOVING OLD PAINT IS THE KEY TO A BRIGHT NEW PAINT JOB
description: THE most important part of any paint job is making certain that the surfaces to be painted are first properly prepared. On most exterior paint jobs, this means removing lots of old paint that is peeling, flaking, blistering or cracking. Applying new paint over old paint that is no longer firm and solid is a sure invitation to premature failure of the new coat - regardless of the quality of the paint you use, and regardless of how carefully it is applied.

title: FEDERAL RESEARCHERS CONDUCT STUDY OF PINE BARRENS CULTURE
description: The residents of New Jersey's Pine Barrens are under study by Federal researchers who want to learn more about the region.

title: Radio Warnings on Used Cars
description: The Federal Trade Commission has begun a radio advertising campaign to warn consumers about their rights and salesmen's tactics when they enter a used car lot.

title: Headliners Brush with Notoriety
description: Georgia O'Keeffe, the artist, apparently would rather be remembered for what she did than for where she did it.

title: Air Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Future Events; All for Good Causes
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: PAPERBACK: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: 1790. By Rhys Isaac. (University of North Carolina Press, $9.95.) Winner of the 1983 Pulitzer Prize in history, ''The Transformation of Virginia'' utilizes the techniques of anthropology and treats drawings, maps, architectural plans and other visual materials as one means of access to what Rhys Isaac calls ''the alien mentalities of a past people.'' He begins his innovative study by characterizing ways of life in Virginia around 1740, goes on to examine historical episodes that reveal forces of stress and change, and ends by discussing how Virginians lived and thought toward the end of the 18th century.

title: STUDY FINDS A THIRD OF DRUG INGREDIENTS EFFECTIVE
description: An 11-year study of 700 key ingredients in over-the-counter drugs found only one- third had been proven safe and effective, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Andrew Arno Is Married To Janis E. Koopersmith
description: Janis Ellen Koopersmith, daughter of Kenneth Koopersmith of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Marcia Koopersmith, was married yesterday to Andrew Arno, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Arno of New York. Rabbi Maurice Weisenberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWSHospital Shopping
description: 'Shop around,'' Florida's Insurance Commissioner, Bill Gunter, advised people who contemplated gallbladder surgery.

title: 'REAR WINDOW' - STILL A JOY
description: After having had two retrospective showings at the 21st New York Film Festival, which closes tonight, Alfred Hitchcock's 1954

title: Humane Comedy
description: SCENES FROM PROVINCIAL LIFE was published in England in 1950, and Scenes From Metropolitan Life appeared 32 years later in the interim, the third portion of the trilogy - Scenes From Married Life - was published. This flouting of chronologhy is not the result of some eccentric whim of the author. Because of the threat of a libel suit, William Cooper ( whose real name is H. S. Hoff) had to wait until the death of the would-be pliantiff before Metropolitan Life ' could appear. its publication last year thus condluded one of the longest periods of to be continued since Arthur Conan Doyle was obliged to rescue Sherlock Holmes from the reichenbach falls.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''IWAS a contemporary of one of the greatest scare periods in history,'' said Lyle Stuart, president of the publishing house that bears his name, in recalling its origins.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Football

title: ASSEMBLY MEETS TUESDAY, ON BRIDGE BONDS
description: THE General Assembly will convene in a special session starting Tuesday to take the first step toward repairing Connecticut's bridges and highways following the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge in Greenwich last June 28.

title: John B. Kathner Weds Miss Cushing in Jersey
description: Candace Whitney Cushing, daughter of Mrs. Robert Lee Cushing of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Cushing, was married yesterday to John Bart Kathner, son of Mrs. John Robert Kathner of San Francisco and the late Mr. Kathner. The Rev. David B. Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: TREASURES FLOW IN PUSHCART PRESS
description: THEIR names are Salmagundi, Ploughshares, Kayak, the Agni Review, Ironwood, Antaeus, the Georgia Review and Snail's Pace, among others. And in their pages can be found what many people consider is some of the most challenging, heartfelt and invigorating writing being produced today - writing that rarely appears in the increasingly constrained world of today's commercial publishing.

title: Topics; Truth in Packaging
description: The Sponsors' Message

title: ISLANDERS WIN IN OVERTIME BY 8-7
description: The Islanders tonight became the first team in more than 40 years to win a National Hockey League regular-season game in overtime since 1942, pinning an 8-7 loss on the Washington Capitals with Bob Bourne's goal at 2 minutes 1 second of sudden death.

title: SQUASH STAR READIES AUSTRALIA CHALLENGE
description: WHEN Mariann Greenberg, a ranked tennis pro from Mamaroneck, turned 30 years old, she found it harder to shrug off a loss to a 14-year-old prodigy or a woman she should have beaten handily. ''I still felt very competitive,'' she recalled, ''and if I wasn't going to the top, at least I wanted a good shot at it.''

title: 7 Nursing Home Employees Enter Pleas on Heat Deaths
description: Seven employees of the Center for Human Development nursing home here have pleaded not guilty to charges of involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of four patients who died in a heat wave last summer.

title:
CAMERA;
CLOSEUP PHOTOGRAPHY WITH ELECTRONIC FLASH
description: One problem often encountered when shooting closeups is insufficient light to provide the necessary depth of field when shooting at the shutter speed required to stop motion. In many cases you may have to choose between one or the other - either you will have to close the lens down to a small aperture to give you the front-to-back sharpness you need, or you can choose to shoot at a fast shutter speed to prevent the picture from blurring (because of camera shake or the subject's movement). Bear in mind that if you choose the first option - closing the lens down - then more of your subject will be in sharp focus.

title: TRANSFORMATION OF MADISON: AD ALLEY TO BANK ST.
description: MADISON AVENUE, which once was to advertising what Broadway is to show business and Central Park West to psychoanalysis, is no longer the same. The ad men are going and the bankers are coming.

title: ATHLETES' ADVERTISING IMAGES: BULLIES TO 'BEEFCAKE'
description: HE is a big man with a full beard who might look intimidating if it weren't for the smile on his face and his gentle nature. He once played for the Los Angeles Rams and was part of a defensive line that was called the Fearsome Foursome. But now, Merlin Olsen can be seen on television extolling the virtue of flowers.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THREESCORE and six years ago, when the world was young and so was I, I was getting $75 a month from the Government to help me get through Adelphi College. But even in the late 1940's, $75 didn't really stretch over a month, unless, as I sometimes did, I lived on five cans of beans a week and as many eggs, and talked the landlady of the little room I lived in over a laundry in Garden City into letting me hold off on my $8 a week payment until the next G.I. Bill check came in.

title: THE AFRIKANERS ARE TORN OVER NEW CONSTITUTION
description: The most conspicuous and, for the moment, most emotional political conflict being waged in South Africa is not the fundamental, gradually sharpening struggle between white nationalists and black nationalists. It is white versus white. More specifically, it is Afrikaner versus Afrikaner.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: While on a recent trip to England, a Massachusetts traveler was impressed with how thorough the security check was at Heathrow Airport outside London as she prepared to board her flight home. She had been prepared for the metal detectors through which passengers pass and the X-ray machines that scrutinize hand luggage. What surprised her was that when she handed over a plastic bag holding rolls of film, an inspector opened every container of exposed film and looked inside the container - though without unrolling the film itself - and when he came to boxes of unexposed film he examined the ends of the boxes to make sure they had not been tampered with. ''It made me feel quite secure to think that there was little likelihood that anyone would be able to board our flight with a weapon that could be used to hijack the plane,'' she said later.

title: FROM MILAN: LOW HEELS AND HIP WRAPS
description: The best accessories shown here with the spring and summer collections are either serviceable or amusing, like the best clothes. The keynote is the low-heel sandal or oxford, which gives the clothes a comfortable foundation. Next comes the belt, which holds the basically loose clothes close to the body at one point, notably the hipline.

title: FREE AND CLEAR
description: WATCH TIME FLY By Laura Furman. 184 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: NUCLEAR RAZING OF SAN FRANCISCO DESCRIBED IN BOOKLET BY THE CITY
description: A city-sponsored booklet that describes in vivid detail how San Francisco would be destroyed if a one-megaton bomb fell on City Hall has been sent to every household here.

title: A DECK THAT DEALS TWIN TAPES
description: Faced with the difficult task of ruling the United States without a Xerox machine, President Thomas Jefferson - an inveterate gadgeteer - invented his own copying device. He built a contraption in which two pens were linked by metal rods. When he wrote with one pen, the other automatically followed the motions of his hand and scribbled an instant duplicate.

title: Coast Town Weighs Its Own Nuclear Ban
description: An ordinance introduced here outlaws ''research, production, design, testing, transportation, deployment, disposal or use of nuclear weapons within the city limits.''

title: DEMOCRATS, TOO, FACE A GENDER GAP
description: For nearly two years, the fact that women like Ronald Reagan less than men do has frustrated Republicans and cheered Democrats. And when Democratic women began last weekend to press seriously their claim for a Vice Presidential nomination, the occasion got far less attention than more conventional political events, such as straw polls and labor endorsements. But it may have signaled something of greater long-term significance to the Democratic Party: that the ''gender gap'' is not solely a Republican concern.

title: Harrumph!
description: In Britain, where sex is still scandalous, Margaret Thatcher's Trade Secretary, Cecil Parkinson, found himself in the thick of it last week. Mr. Parkinson publicly acknowledged he had had a lengthy affair with his secretary and that the British population would thereby be increased by one sometime in January.

title: A MODEST PROPOSAL FOR THE SERIES
description: THERE is an old saying in baseball, which has more old sayings

title: MUSIC: GYPSY INSPIRATIONS AND EXPLORATIONS
description: When Lydia Skidan sang four authentic Russian gypsy folk songs as part of the Concerts Plus program at Merkin Hall on Thursday night, sweet melody, sudden changes of tempo, invocations of natural life, vocal acrobatics and authentic feeling were woven together with immediacy and pleasure.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I told the lady I work for, 'I have to go and see the cardinal.' I feel he's a good man, that's all.'' - Mary Adipietro, of the Bronx, at St. Patrick's Cathedral. (40:1.)

title: BUSY SIGNALS FOR PHONE COMPANY
description: TO alleviate the delays customers of the Southern New England Telephone Company have been experiencing in trying to call its business offices, company officials last week extended call-in hours from 8:30 A.M. to 7 P.M. on weekdays and from 8:30 A.M. to noon on Saturdays. Usually, the telephone lines are open until 5 P.M. and closed on Saturday.

title: SCHOOL CRITICIZED FOR FACILITIES
description: LEDYARD HIGH SCHOOL, highly regarded for its students' academic achievements, has been placed on probation by a New England accreditation group, principally because the school's physical facilities need upgrading.

title: CONCERT: FLUTE SOUNDS
description: Robert Dick takes nothing about the flute for granted - not its range, its tone, or the assumption that it plays only one note at a time. His solo concert Thursday at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation was, in part, a demonstration of the unconventional sounds that Mr. Dick has codified in his book ''The Other Flute.''

title: MICHIGAN LEGISLATURE VOTES TO DROP PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY ELECTIONS
description: Michigan has become the largest state in the nation to do away with Presidential primary elections. The decision will leave delegate-selection procedures for the 1984 national conventions entirely in the hands of caucuses or conventions run by the state's political parties.

title: ART
description: The poet Charles Baudelaire once wrote of ''that charmer, Evening, the criminals' friend.'' But in art, at any rate, evening has a better name.

title: New Rochelle Tops Yonkers
description: A sophomore who carried the ball only three times before yesterday's game gained 110 yards and led New Rochelle to a 35-6 victory over Yonkers.

title:
STAMPS;
VINTAGE VEHICLE ON TRANSPORTATION ISSUE
description: The latest addition to the ongoing Transportation Series - a 5-cent coil stamp being issued tomorrow at San Francisco - features a motorcycle from the early years of this century, when these two-wheeled vehicle were just beginning to get popular.

title: Miss Atchley Has Nuptials
description: Marion Woodward Atchley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Winslow Atchley Jr. of Lincoln and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Rollie Birdsall Merrick 3d, son of Mrs. Richard B. Horn of Chicago and Mr. Merrick of Phoenix, Ariz. The Rev. John D. Schule Jr. performed the Protestant ceremony at the Federated Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: 'EAGLE'S WING' WITH SAM WATERSTON
description: The grandly actorish manner of Anthony Harvey's ''Lion in Winter'' is less at home in the American West than it was in the court of medieval England, on the evidence of ''Eagle's Wing,'' a 1979 film by Mr. Harvey, previously unreleased in America, that opens today at the Thalia.

title: Alien Crackdown in Hawaii
description: A crackdown on the estimated 30,000 to 40,000 illegal aliens in Hawaii has been announced by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. Harold Ezell, the agency's Commissioner for the Western Region, said Tuesday that the new enforcement effort would focus on capturing illegal aliens engaged in criminal activities or occupying jobs that could be done by American citizens and legal permanent residents.

title: VICTORY WITH NO SHOTS FIRED
description: THE Supreme Court gave gun control advocates a victory last week by deciding not to hear a case. It let stand an appeals court ruling that a ban on private possession of handguns in Morton Grove, Ill., is constitutional.

title: PROFESSOR AT N.Y.U. IN THE 1940'S
description: Dr. Henry P. Jordan, a former German diplomat and professor of government at New York University, died Thursday in Freiburg, West Germany. He was 86 years old.

title: CHAS CONERLY FIRST AT BELMONT
description: Allen Jerkens figured there was so much early speed in the Fall Highweight Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park that stretch-runners like Chas Conerly and Singh Tu would benefit. The trainer was right on both counts as the stablemates he saddled ran one-two. The victory made Chas Conerly a strong contender for an Eclipse Award as the champion sprinter in the country.

title: New Artificial Heart Tested in Calf in Utah
description: A longer, thinner version of the artificial heart implanted in Dr. Barney B. Clark is being tested on a bull calf at the University of Utah Medical Center.

title: MATCHING A MUSEUM
description: Columbus House, a slim 18- story condominium apartment building nearing completion on the west side of Columbus Avenue between 78th and 79th Streets, looms over its low-rise neighbors, but it makes a design gesture to the American Musuem of Natural History, the massive landmark complex sitting just across the avenue.

title: THE RIO BEAT
description: Warren Hoge is chief of the New York Times bureau in Rio de Janeiro. By WARREN HOGE

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Reports of bogus insurance claims are legion. But Robert P. Yarrington was accused last year in California of refining such plotting to an extreme.

title: No Headline
description: Irvington Player Hurt

title: MICHIGAN WINNER BY 42-0
description: Steve Smith completed 11 of 16 passes for 149 yards and a touchdown and broke the school record for completions as Michigan routed Michigan State, 42-0, in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: SELLING A JEWEL FROM THE CORPORATE CROWN
description: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES has always been, and will probably always be, a railroad company. But in this era when stock market investors want more high-tech razzmatazz, Kansas City does not want to be known only as a company whose basic technology predates the widespread use of electricity in the American home.

title: QUEBEC CITY'S PRIME TIME
description: In a Canada justifiably better known for its spaces rather than its places, we have for the most part built nondescript utilitarian cities (say Edmonton or Calgary), anchored against the wind rather than rooted in history, with little to delight the eye. There are two shining exceptions to this rule. Montreal, or what remains of it now that the developers have had their way, and Quebec City, still happily intact.

title: IN FARM CRISIS, THE LAND ITSELF BECOMES A LIABILITY
description: The courtyard of the Graham County courthouse was surrounded by more than two dozen state troopers and helmeted sheriff's deputies summoned from other counties one morning last week. On the roof, more than a dozen other officers, some wearing flak jackets and manning videotaping equipment, monitored the scene below. When more than 200 chanting protesters entered the courtyard, a fire truck pumper quietly moved in behind, its high-powered hoses unfurled and ready.

title: Mozambican Sees Ties With U.S. Improving
description: President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique, who is here on a European tour, said in an interview today that Mozambique's relationship with the United States was improving.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Better Late

title: Sibson Stops Collins In Second for First Loss
description: Tony Sibson of England stopped John Collins early in the second round today, handing the Chicago middleweight his first loss in 30 fights.

title: YEAR-END SPENDING BY MILITARY QUESTIONED
description: Sixteen senators say they cannot believe the Pentagon can wisely spend $4.2 billion in one day, and they want an investigation into the Defense Department's buying spree on the last day of the 1983 fiscal year.

title: WASHINGTON FORMULATES A COMPUTER AGENDA
description: When is a supercomputer not a supercomputer? When it is the goal of the Defense Department's new Supercomputer Project, which is devoted to another type of advanced computing technology, artificial intelligence. The project is one of a panoply of American responses to the Japanese computer challenge. The name is unfortunate, for it confuses two technologies whose proponents face stiff competition from Japan and who are vying with each other for national priority.

title: COMPUTER VS. CARD CATALOGUE AT N.Y.U.
description: At one time, Lisa Howe hated working with computers. She took a computer class, became annoyed and typed into the machine, ''Why are you doing this to me?'' The computer responded only with question marks.

title: WHO'S PLAYING THE BOARD GAME?
description: ''MR. WALL STREET'' himself, the legendary Sidney J. Weinberg, made his reputation by being one of the canniest wizards of finance and also by sitting on no fewer than 35 boards of directors. In his 60-year career, he watched over the management of the bluest of the blue chips, a list that included such giants as General Electric, Ford and B. F. Goodrich.

title: Julie Gill Is a Bride
description: Julie Gill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Gill of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Kast, son of Paul E. Kast and Dr. Lisl Ivanyi Kast of Massapequa, L.I. The ceremony, at the home of the bride's parents, was performed by Justice of the Peace Clifford Frost of Greenwich. Mrs. Kast, who graduated magna cum laude from Wesleyan University, is a research editor for the investment banking concern of Goldman, Sachs & Company. Her father is vice president of Julius Levenson Inc., representatives in New York for toy manufacturers. Mr. Kast, a graduate of Wesleyan and the New York University School of Law, is a lawyer with Texaco in White Plains. His father is a lawyer in Massapequa. His mother is a dentist in Seaford, L.I.

title: Hilary S. Frank Marries Executive in Mamaroneck
description: Hilary S. Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Frank of New York, was married yesterday to Lonny F. Unger, son of Raquel Unger of Armonk, N.Y., and the late Nathan H. Unger. Rabbi Morris Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VINTAGE CARS TOUR

title: Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Mnemonic Memories

title: MONMOUTH BUILDING BOOM RAISES CONCERN
description: EVEN on raw, stormy mornings, the towers of the World Trade Center and parts of Brooklyn are visible from the high-rise buildings along the Monmouth County shore.

title: KILEY MOVES FROM BACK BAY TO FRONT BURNER AT THE M.T.A.
description: Page Protect Region's 'Vital Heart'

title: CONCERT: MUSICA ANTIQUA
description: Musica Antiqua K"oln, one of Europe's well-regarded early music groups, put in an appearance at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night. It is a small ensemble - with two violinists, Reinhard Goebel and Hajo B"ass; two continuo players, Andreas Staier, harpsichord, and Phoebe Carrai, cello and gamba, and finally, Wilbert Hazelzet, a bright, secure virtuoso of the transverse flute.

title: RICCARDO MUTI MAKES MUSIC HIS WAY
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: OF FATHERS AND MOTHERS ON THE IRISH STAGE
description: Imagine the English-language drama without Farquhar, Sheridan, Wilde, Synge, O'Casey and Samuel Beckett, and you'll speedily see how tremendous Ireland's contribution has been and is. Indeed, it wouldn't the least surprise me to learn that Shakespeare's oeuvre was really written by Seamus O'Draimatoigh, an obscure penpusher in Francis Bacon's secretariat. It would be foolish to generalize very far about so diverse a collection of playsmiths, but one quality they would seem to share, along with humor and verbal brio, is a highly skeptical turn of mind. Nowhere is this more marked than among those who, instead of assimilating into cultures overseas, continued to write about their own fellow- countrymen. ''We are bound to notice, as a continuing and determining factor,'' declares the critic Raymond Williams - Synge and O'Casey especially in his thoughts - ''how little respect, except in the grand gestures, the Irish drama had for the Irish people.''

title: For Democrats, Issues' Means Personalities
description: For months now, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and other runners- up in the early rounds of the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination have been saying the campaign stage that began last week would produce a ''competition of ideas'' that would be damaging to the front-runners, former Vice President Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio. That was not quite the effect of the first of a series of public forums at which the seven declared candidates will appear jointly.

title: ILLINOIS TOWN SUFFERS A FATE OF AGING: ABSENTEE OWNERS
description: Two fixtures of life in this farming community, the bank and the daily newspaper, have passed to absentee owners after being held for generations by local families. As in other small towns, the owners became too old to manage them and no family member stepped in to take over.

title: METHOD USED IN CONDUCTING SURVEY
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 24 through Sept. 28 with 1,587 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Lucy Heath Wed to Dr. R. K. McLellan
description: Lucy Westgate Heath, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Fenno F. Heath Jr. of New Haven, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Keene McLellan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur S. McLellan of New Vernon, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Chorba at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon.

title: FROM MONTGOMERY TO HARLEM
description: A MEASURE OF TIME by Rosa Guy. 365 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95

title: Bridge in Louisiana Replaces A Ferry Route Where 78 Died
description: The Luling-Destrehan bridge, built to replace the Mississippi River ferry route on which 78 people drowned after a collision of a ferry and a freighter seven years ago, has opened.

title: SERVED FOUR TERMS IN KANSAS
description: Former Gov. Robert Docking of Kansas died early today in his sleep at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: GRIMM 'FAIRY' TALES AS THE LORE OF LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: AID TO JORDAN FROM ARAB NATIONS SAID TO FALL
description: Aid to Jordan from oil-producing Arab countries is expected to total $750 million this year, reportedly the lowest figure since the program was begun in 1978.

title: BALLET AND MODERN IDIOMS BLEND IN BAT-DOR
description: The Bat-Dor Dance Company of Israel has recently concluded its second visit to New York. It was the company's first appearance in Manhattan, at the Joyce theater, and on the whole, it was successful. The level of dancing was much higher than on a previous visit in 1979, especially among the men who who project strongly within a company style that accents correct body placement and line. The repertory, however, was uneven. As a modern-dance troupe that works in a fusion of both ballet and modern, and as an eclectic company, Bat-Dor faces the kind of problems other troupes will as more and more so-called eclectic dance companies keep on increasing.

title: 277 Alligators Slain This Year In Experimental Florida Hunt
description: An experimental alligator hunt has ended with the killing of 277 alligators, a steep decline from last year's total.

title: EX-NOW FIGURE FACES LOUISIANA MURDER TRIAL
description: Eighteen years ago Moises Chayo, an Argentine businessman here to visit his son, who was ill, disappeared from the French Quarter and was discovered dead in a drainage ditch in Metairie, his head battered. On Tuesday Ginny Foat, the former president of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women, will stand trial on a charge of murdering him.

title: SUBSTITUTING SOCIALISM FOR GOD
description: THE POLITICS AT GOD'S FUNERAL

title: Cloistered Life Clarification
description: In the article, ''The Cloistered Life'' (July 10), Julia Lieblich quoted the Prioress of the Carmelite Monastery in Haifa, Israel, comparing our ultraconservatism with their more balanced equilibrium after Vatican II. We wrote to the Prioress, in Haifa, asking if she had expressed herself to Miss Lieblich in those terms.

title: PARKING LOT YIELDS SOME OLD ARTIFACTS
description: MEMBERS of the Wethersfield Historical Society recently found in a church parking lot pieces of pottery, bottles, clay pipes and other artifacts that may be 300 years old.

title: FROM BROADWAY TO SUBURBS
description: ONE OF Harold Prince's first Broadway hits as a co-producer was ''West Side Story,'' which had a book by Arthur Laurents.

title: Politics Puts Congress on Hold
description: ''Do you think the President is political enough to veto a bill to gain votes for his party?'' asked the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. ''The answer,'' the Massachusetts Democrat continued, ''is yes. He's the most political man I've ever seen over there.'' The White House was replying in kind last week - and so were some members of his own party, particularly those who have been working for years on the comprehensive immigration law revision that Mr. O'Neill, using the Speaker's prerogative to set the House's schedule, effectively tabled, probably until after November 1984.

title: Leslie Kahler Is Married
description: Leslie Mary Kahler, daughter of Arthur E. Kahler of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Lois Ann Kahler, was married yesterday to W. Ryder Kern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius G. Kern of Locust Valley, L.I. and Beaufort, S.C. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FINGERPRINTING schoolchildren is widespread in the state, perhaps no more so than in Bergen County. Before schools recessed last June, nearly 62,000 children in 60 of the county's 72 communities had been fingerprinted under a program organized by the County Sheriff's office. When school resumed last month, three more towns - River Vale, Cresskill and Wood-Ridge - enlisted in the program.

title: SAUL ORKIN, COLLEGE PRESIDENT
description: Dr. Saul Orkin, president of Union County College in Cranford, N.J., died, apparently of a heart attack, Friday evening at his home in Hillsborough, N.J. He was 60 years old.

title: Cup Retrieval Planning Starts
description: With the America's Cup now ensconced in the Royal Perth Yacht Club in Western Australia, the New York Yacht Club and the United States Yacht Racing Union already are making plans to retrieve it.

title: PRINCETON TOPS COLUMBIA
description: Columbia beat Princeton ''attitudewise and moralewise'' today, according to the Columbia coach, but these are not categories in Ivy League statistics. Princeton beat Columbia by 35-26 on the football field, where it counted, but the victory was not that easy.

title: IN HARTFORD, COMMONPLACE OBJECTS OF ITALIAN LIFE
description: MUSEUM shows are more likely to come with books than catalogues nowadays, and these, though tied to their respective events, are meant to outlive them. But the organizers of the Italian design show current at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford have gone one better: They have produced a book that all but renders the exhibition superfluous.

title: U.S. TO RESTORE PARK
description: PLEASURE BEACH PARK, once a dazzling amusement center in Bridgeport's East End, is getting $1.3 million in Federal funds for its restoration.

title: NEEDED: ATLANTIC CITY RAIL SERVICE
description: DEAR GOVERNOR KEAN:

title: WE DON'T KNOW HOW TO CARE FOR OUR YOUNG
description: IN PHILADELPHIA, homicide is

title: A PRINCESS AND THE RACCOONS
description: actually a few weeks ago - a Long Island princess awoke from her beauty sleep to an unfamiliar whining sound echoing through the house. She tiptoed downstairs to her electic living room and followed the cries, which became increasingly louder as she approached the fireplace.

title: POPULATION NEARS ITS PEAK
description: THE signs of population shrinkage are subtle here but present, and according to the Federal Bureau of the Census, they foretell what will happen to the whole state. This town has ceased to grow, just as growth in Connecticut as a whole appears to be approaching a limit.

title: UNION COUNTY COLLEGE MARKS ITS GOLDEN ANNIVERSARY
description: WHEN Richard P. Muscatello attended Union Junior College in 1938, the school, with its 500 night students, bore little resemblance to the institution now known as Union County College.

title: Sobriety Checkpoints Urged
description: The chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, James E. Burnett Jr., has called for the nationwide adoption of checkpoints to catch drivers who are drunk. Officers at sobriety checkpoints would either stop all traffic or use an unbiased formula for deciding which automobiles to stop, thereby increasing what Mr. Burnett told a police chiefs' convention this week were 1,000-to-1 odds against being apprehended for driving drunk.

title: Back on the Playing Field
description: In its first game since a teammate died of heart failure on the field two weeks ago, the Yonkers junior varsity football team lost to New Rochelle today, 8-0. ''Considering we haven't been able to practice with all these problems, we did real well,'' said 16-year- old Preston Roberts, a team co-captain.

title: Are Private Utilities More Efficient?
description: Wayne Prospect sounds like a politician in search of votes (''Shoreham: A Way Out?'' Opinion Page, Sept. 11).

title: Jets Have Big Edge In Returning Kicks
description: When this season of inconsistency started for the Jets, they did not have one primary kick-returner who had ever performed that specialized job in a regular-season game.

title: LAWMAKERS DECRY DRUG-PROJECT CUTS
description: FEDERAL budget cuts under the Reagan Administration have stunted New Jersey's war on drugs, and unless funds are restored to earlier levels, state officials say, the battle will be lost.

title: BRIDGEMARKET WORK ABOUT TO START
description: WHEN Harley Baldwin first walked through the soaring, arched space beneath the Manhattan end of the Queensborough Bridge, he reached an immediate decision.

title: YES, WE CAN DO SOMETHING TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE
description: LIVING and working so close to New York City has its disadvantages. Everything is measured in bigness.

title: NEW COURT OPENS FOR BUSINESS
description: THE newest branch of Connecticut's judiciary - the Appellate Court - opened for business last Tuesday.

title: Mark Herman Marries Bonita Maris Bennett
description: Bonita Maris Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay I. Bennett of New York, was married yesterday to Mark Herman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Herman of Belmont, Mass., and Marco Island, Fla. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: C. D. Adams Wed To Elizabeth Gill
description: Elizabeth Stephenson Gill, daughter of Mrs. Robert A. Falise of Bedford, N.Y., and William McIntyre Gill of Roanoke, Va., was married yesterday to Christopher David Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Patton Adams of Pleasantville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford.

title: Q/A
description: Question: My fiance and I are planning to take our honeymoon in Nepal. Could you tell us where to find out when and how to travel there, and what we might do and see. - C.H., Boulder, Colo.

title: High-Tech Law
description: To the Business Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ONE hundred years ago, the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery was opened for the purpose of stocking local waters with a variety of fish.

title: FILIPINO MOSLEM REVOLT SEEMS TO EBB
description: Moslem separatist guerrillas still lurk in the wilderness outside cities like Zamboanga, occasionally kidnapping travelers for ransom and committing other acts of terrorism. But their war for independence on Mindanao and other southern Philippine islands with large Islamic populations, once a major security threat, seems to have declined drastically in intensity.

title: A FAMILY TRADITION: GRAPES AND WINE
description: JOSEPH VISCONTI watches as a loaded pickup truck spills a trail of red and white wine grapes along Housatonic Avenue in Bridgeport. Mr. Visconti, who has sold grapes there for 14 seasons, then turns to answer a familiar question in Italian.

title: DEALMAKER: John J. Schmidt
description: THE din of activity at Santa Fe's 80-year-old white terra cotta headquarters building announces loudly that change is under way. Marble walls and stairways are being spruced up. A central air conditioner is replacing the dozens of window units that once hung over Michigan Avenue. An old air shaft is being converted to a 16-story atrium.

title: A PRIZE AND A BOOST FOR LECH WALSEA
description: LECH WALESA, who has had a frustrating year, savored sweet triumph last week. The Nobel Peace Prize - and $190,000 - was his in recognition of his attempts to promote a free trade union under a regime that permitted it for a time but finally could not abide such heresy.

title: Parakeet Killer Sentenced
description: A 26- year-old man has been sentenced to one year's court supervision and was fined $90 for killing his girlfriend's pet bird in what a prosecutor called a case of ''brutal parakeetcide.'' Janice Huffines and John McDannell were arguing about her refusal to go out with him, Miss Huffines testified, when Mr. McDannell took the parakeet out of its cage, cupped its body in one hand and ''tore off its head'' with the other. The defendant said he accidentally killed the bird when it pecked his hand.

title: SHORTENED 'CAMELOT' LONG ON QUALITY
description: ''CAMELOT'' does not need a multi-million dollar mounting. In 1960, the musical was produced for $700,000 - at the time, a record- breaking cost. By highlighting the human elements of a real legend for our times, the production now at the Darien Dinner Theater was put together for less than $50,000, and comes up a winner.

title:
THE WORLD;
If Only Salvador Would Behave
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to defend El Salvador against a Marxist takeover assume that the embattled Central American nation wants democracy instead. Rightist terrorism aimed at democrats has persisted, however, and last week it provoked an embarrassed outburst of official condemnation.

title: Film Festival
description: ''Streamers,'' Robert Altman's screen adaptation of David Rabe's tough, bloody, sorrowful stage play, is a maddening movie. It goes partway toward realizing the full effect of a stage play as a film, then botches the job by the overabundant use of film techniques, which dismember what should be an ensemble performance.

title: Recovery Tales
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 2 Charged With Fraud Of $500 Million in Sales
description: Federal prosecutors say two international businessmen have been charged with defrauding up to 4,000 investors of as much as $500 million in land sale deals.

title: MALL BOWS, GRANTS BID TO GROUP TO PETITION
description: THE Passaic County Nuclear Freeze Committee won ''a battle and a half'' last week, its secretary, Lawrence Rubin, said, when administrators of the Willowbrook Mall here agreed to let committee members gather petition signatures.

title: VIGILS HELD FOR AIDS VICTIMS
description: The plight of the victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome and the call for increased research into AIDS were addressed by vigils and marches in cities across the country yesterday.

title: TRUTH IN PACKAGING Change of Address
description: Change of Address

title: MNEMONIC MEMORIES
'HELLS ANGELS,' A DOCUMENTARY VERSION
description: As documentaries go, ''Hells Angels Forever'' is not the sort to be remembered for the dispassion and depth of its inquiry.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS; Seed Longevity
description: ''Lotus seeds that lay dormant in an Asian lake bed for 400 years or more have been found alive and capable of growing into new plants,'' the news account said in October 1982. It was based on a report in a scientific journal by Dr. David A. Priestly, a biochemist at the Boyce Thompson Institute at Cornell University, and Dr. Maarten A. Posthumus, a researcher in the Netherlands.

title: GROMYKO WAS KEPT FROM LANDING FOR PUBLIC SAFETY REASONS
description: To the Editor:

title: AN EPICURE IN KYOTO
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is Food Editor of The New York Times. BY CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: The Man Who Would Run the Transit System
description: Robert R. Kiley was an assistant to the director of the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1960's and took responsibility for public safety during Boston's school desegregation crisis in 1974. Emboldened by his success, Mr. Kiley agreed last week to take on a real challenge: making New York's subways, buses and commuter railroads run on time.

title: Lebanon Army Fights Shiites In Sections of South Beirut
description: Lebanese Army troops and Shiite Moslem militiamen battled in Beirut's southern neighborhoods today.

title: NASSAU DEMOCRAST EYE COUNTY ISSUES
description: TAKING a new political tack, Nassau Democrats are running town candidates under a countywide umbrella this year in an effort to break the Republican grip on town offices in Hempstead, North Hempstead and Oyster Bay.

title: DIPLOMATS AT U.N. DEPLORE ITS INEFFECTIVENESS
description: Many diplomats who rose to speak at the General Assembly this week had harsh words for the United Nations.

title: MAYORAL CONTEST HITS BOSTON WHERE IT LIVES
description: This is two cities. One is the business district - modern and expansive, rejuvenated by infusions of Federal aid and private investment. Its symbol is the Faneuil Hall Marketplace, an 18th-century meat market turned into glossy bars and boutiques that draw more visitors annually than the total population of New England. The other is ethnically divided neighborhoods, with decaying schools, potholed streets and arguably the oldest and poorest housing in the country.

title: Torrance Leads by 3 Strokes
description: Sam Torrance of Scotland shot a 66 today and took a three-stroke lead after three rounds of the Southern Open.

title: A New Start for Labor Party
description: After suffering its worst electoral defeat in more than 60 years in June, Britain's Labor Party tried a fresh face last week. At the annual convention in Brighton, Neil Kinnock, a Welsh leftist with charm and a talent for oratory but no experience in government, was elected leader by a big majority to replace the hapless Michael Foot.

title: FOUR PRIZE WINNERS GETTING UNDER WAY
description: THE proliferation of major international competitions has gone hand in hand with the emergence of an extraordinary new generation of performers: young artists of amazing technical accomplishment and deep musical sensitivity. If one is willing to ''take a chance'' on players whose names may be unfamiliar today, one may well meet some of the superstars of tomorrow. At least four prize-winning young pianists will be appearing locally over the next fortnight.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Attica, Kan., with 740 residents and mainly unpaved streets, was running on a yearly budget of $250,000 when the tiny city struck it rich a year ago.

title: LEONARDO A LA STEADMAN
description: OPENER: Ralph Steadman may well be the most savage political cartoonist of the late 20th century. His posters, spattered with ink blobs like thrown mud, recall the nightmare etchings of Goya. His scratchy pen-and-ink drawings, as in his illustrations for Hunter Thompson's ''Fear and Loathing'' books, are as cruel as those of George Grosz. Yet he is a gentle man. ''I'm not the kind that would go out in the street and commit violence, so I do it in drawings,'' he explains. Now he has found ''a way to shut myself off from the hellish political world'' - the creation, in words and pictures, of a supposedly long-lost autobiography of Leonardo da Vinci, titled ''I, Leonardo,'' to be published this month by Summit Books. It is a homage to a frustrated genius. Steadman calls it ''a quasi-historical mishmash . . . tongue-in-cheek.'' It is also a tour de force.

title: Michael Gleason Weds Miss Lione, A Senator's Aide
description: Ann Kendall Lione, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick M. Lione Jr. of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Palmer Gleason, son of Ethel E. Ware of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Robert W. Gleason. The Rev. Donald W. Emig of the United Methodist Church of Rowayton performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: China Says Many Defy Its Birth Control Policy
description: China's family planning chief says many Chinese families are still having more than one child despite a Government policy discouraging this.

title: A TRANSLATOR'S LEGACY
description: WRITERS IN RUSSIA: 1917-1978 By Max Hayward. Edited and introduced by Patricia Blake. 340 pp. San Diego: A Helen & Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: THE PLAYER NAMED LATER
description: THE security guards led him through narrow corridors jammed with sullen fans. Winter was coming on fast in their faces, and Tito Landrum had just ruined their autumn.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: A Time for Hobgoblins and Haunted Houses
description: Murder to Go Is on the Menu For Halloween

title: Sarah R. Whitley and Stephen Ferguson Marry
description: Sarah Reeves Whitley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Whitley of Cohasset, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Ferguson of Rossmoor, N.J. The Rev. Jonathan D. Parsons of Newton, Mass., performed the ceremony in the chapel at Princeton University, where the bridegroom is curator of rare books.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: 'Right Words'Save a ConvictAt 11th HourWhen the Supreme Court last week refused to block the execution of a convicted Texas murderer, it sent an unwelcome message not only to James D. Autry, whose execution was scheduled for Wednesday, but to other condemned prisoners who have exhausted lower court appeals.

title: Melissa Mueller AndJamesAllen Wed at Harvard
description: Melissa Chloris Mueller, daughter of Joan Mueller of Miami Shores, Fla., and the late Frederick W. Mueller, was married yesterday to James Philip Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Allen Jr. of Burlington, N.C.

title: TWO SCHOOLS OF THOUGHT DIVIDE TWO SCHOOLS OF LAW
description: Margaret O'Malley and Jeffrey Keitelman wanted to be lawyers. Both had impressive undergraduate records and high admissions test scores. Both think they enrolled in the best law school in New York City and one of the best in the country. Miss O'Malley opted for New York University. Mr. Keitelman chose Columbia.

title: DANCE: JOAN FINKELSTEIN AND TROUPE
description: Things got off to a bad start in a concert by Joan Finkelstein and Dancers on Wednesday at Theater of the Riverside Church and they never quite picked up. The program was new, and recent dances by Miss Finkelstein, a former member of the Don Redlich Dance Company, opened with a walking and jiving solo called ''Tania,'' a silly and shallow depiction of a rich kid turned guerrilla warrior.

title: N. Rockland Makes It 22
description: North Rockland, ranked ninth in the state, rolled to its 22d consecutive victory over host Clarkstown North yesterday, 28-0. The senior running back Derek Beamon led the Red Raiders, rushing for 150 yards on 21 carries and two touchdowns.

title: Myung-Hi Kim Bride Of Dr. Hiram Cody 3d
description: Myung-Hi Kim, a violinist with the New York Philharmonic, was married yesterday to Dr. Hiram S. Cody 3d, a surgeon at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. The Rev. Ernest Heeren performed the ceremony at the Orange (Conn.)

title: HOSPITALS CONSIDER SPIN-OFF VENTURES
description: CONNECTICUT'S 36 private, nonprofit hospitals are increasingly looking to corporate restructuring as a way to battle financial problems caused by declining Federal support, lagging donations from philanthropies, and the cost of new equipment and salaries for their employees.

title: NOTED CHEFS DEMONSTRATING 'HOW TO'
description: IN today's food-conscious world, well-known chefs and renowned cookbook authors have begun to attract an increasing number of followers. Book signings, television appearances and cooking demonstrations continue to proliferate since Julia Child first pioneered this phenomenon.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the activities of the John M. Olin Foundation designated it incorrectly in some references. The John M. Olin Foundation has no connection with the Olin Foundation, a separate charitable organization with different grant programs.

title: Immigration Reform, O'Neill Style
description: A champion for fairness: That's the role House Speaker O'Neill has played when confronted with severe Reagan Administration cuts in spending to help the poor. Last week, by killing the immigration reform bill, Mr. O'Neill created a much less heroic image: of someone who, for coarse political gain, traffics in consummate unfairness.

title: PLAN FOR OCEAN LAB SITE STIRS DEBATE
description: THE New York Ocean Science Laboratory at Montauk is considered by some to be an eyesore, a crumbling World War II torpedo plant that Perry Duryea, the former State Assembly Speaker, would like to replace with 200 apartments, a sports complex and a marine science education center.

title: VOLUNTEERS WORK 4,000 HOURS TO BUILD ORGAN FOR A CHURCH
description: Michael Conlon was installing air- conditioning at Rockefeller Center when Dannell Maguire, a vice president at Banque Indosuez, approached him and asked about obtaining the air ducts Mr. Conlon was replacing.

title: INFRARED EYE CATALOGUING UNSEEN MATTER IN SPACE
description: Twice a day the coldest man-made object ever to fly in space passes over Chilton, England, and delivers to astronomers their first look at some of the hottest but heretofore best-hidden matter in the universe.

title: UNFILED DOCUMENTS CAUSE STIR IN WESTCHESTER
description: The discovery of hundreds of unfiled and unprocessed documents in the office of the Westchester County Clerk has created extra work for the department and worried the county's lawyers and financial companies.

title: LOVE IT AND LEAVE IT
description: As a rule, winter vacations demand a choice between sun and snow. But the obstinate imagination may yet linger on the possibility of having it both ways. Even the most enthusiastic skier may yet find himself chilled and bored with the whiteness of northern latitudes, beset by visions of basking by a tropical pool. And all but the most insatiable of seekers after a tan, lying browned and anesthetized by sun and tepid water, may suffer occasional yearnings for crisp alpine vistas.

title:
ART;
BEYOND THEORY AT THE CASTLE GALLERY
description: SCHOLARS are forever trying to identify the common factors that make American art distinctively American. Their task would be compounded, but made more zestful, if they attempted to discern the peculiar Italian qualities linking Italian-American artists.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film listing today in The Guide (section 2A) and a picture caption on page 21 of the Arts ans Leisure section incorrectly name the theater where the film ''Streamers'' will play. It opens Friday at the Sutton.

title: CABLE TV IRKS EAST END
description: THE battle between East End residents and Long Island Cablevision appears to be intensifying.

title: THE BARD IN JIVE AT CROSSROADS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK IN ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' Shakespeare's comedy ''The Taming

title: No Headline
description: Conditioning Athletes' Minds

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 DEMOCRATS VISIT A DINNER IN IOWA
description: Converging here today in the wake of the A.F.L.- C.I.O.'s endorsement of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, several candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination pressed their criticisms of the influence of special interest groups in the political process.

title: Quake in Salt Lake City
description: An earthquake rattled windows and awakened people in the Salt Lake City area this morning.

title: CEILING AT MUSEUM IN NORWALK GETS A TOUCH UP
description: FOR almost six months, seven hours a day, two women lay on their backs, 14 feet off the floor atop a maze of scaffolding, meticulously repainting the decorative motifs on the ceiling of the dining room in the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk. The work was completed last month.

title: AMERICA'S MIDEAST POLICY IS IN SHAMBLES
description: Five years after Camp David and one year after the Reagan Plan - both high-water marks of constructive United States engagement on behalf of peace in the Middle East - our Middle Eastern policy is in shambles.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Parker has rejected the Pittsburgh Pirates' one-year contract offer and has indicated he will place his name in next month's re-entry draft. Parker batted .279 with 12 home runs and 69 runs batted in last season, the final year of the outfielder's five-year contract. . . . Carlos Alberto has accepted an invitation to play for the Cosmos in Giorgio Chinaglia's final game next Sunday in Rome.

title: DR. T. F. WALKOWICZ
description: Dr. Thaddeus F. Walkowicz, a general partner in Advanced Technology Ventures, died Thursday at New York Hospital.

title: Patrick Deignan Dead; Former District Leader
description: Patrick C. Deignan, a former Democratic district leader from Jackson Heights, Queens, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief gastrointestinal illness.

title: HELLO, COLUMBUS
description: EDITH EVANS ASBURY, now retired, was a reporter for The Times for 29 years.

title: Of Mothers And Daughters
description: Linda Howard's recent article, ''Mistakes of Our Mothers'' (Opinion Page), reads as an earnest attempt to answer an essay assignment in 300 words or less. Her message of anticipated doom was one weary, whopping whine.

title: Xavier Is Trounced By Poly Prep, 34-8
description: In what exuberant team members called ''the battle of Bay Ridge,'' Poly Prep trounced Xavier yesterday, 34-8.

title: NEW MEDICINE CALLED KEY AID IN KIDNEY TRANSPLANT SURVIVAL
description: A major study has confirmed that a newly approve drug, cyclosporine, significantly improves the survival rate of kidney transplant patients.

title: JAZZ
description: During the past 20 years Buddy De Franco, the preeminent clarinetist of the be-bop era and, aside from Tony Scott, virtually the only clarinetist who played bop in the late 40's and 50's, has rarely been heard in New York. This was partly due to the fact that from 1966 to 1974 he was on an endless tour of one-nighters as leader of the Glenn Miller Orchestra, which subordinated his be-bop instincts, and partly because he has since been traveling by himself more often outside the United States than in it.

title: BALANCHINE ON TV: A TRIBUTE
description: In the process of working on the tribute, Mr. Martins found himself challenged by television in much the same way as his distinguished predecessor. ''Ballet on television is always a compromise between that medium and the dance,'' Mr. Martin said recently, sitting in his office backstage at the New York State Theater.

title: MEXICO SAID TO HAVE DETAINED 4 CUBAN DIPLOMATS
description: Two Cuban diplomats were arrested last month by the Mexican authorities and held incommunicado for a week after they were apparently lured to a secret meeting with two Cuban exiles here, according to Mexican and diplomatic sources.

title: ALL-DAY KINDERGARTENS GAINING ACCEPTANCE IN COUNTY
description: THERE is a story Clayton Akin likes to tell about two kindergarten students playing outside during recess. Seeing a 747 jet airliner flying overhead, they get into a discussion about its technical capabilities. In the middle of their conversation, the school bell rings, and one of them remarks to the other, ''Well, I guess it's time to go back in and string those darn beads again!''

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: APPROXIMATELY 1,200 unemployed residents of the Middletown area last week became the first in the state to receive benefit checks through a new Central Office Payment System being introduced by the Connecticut Department of Labor.

title: Guatemala Opposes O.A.S. Seat for Belize
description: A Foreign Ministry official said Friday that a territorial dispute between Guatemala and Belize must be settled before Guatemala can approve the membership of Belize in the Organization of American States.

title: THE WORLD
description: Manila isNot Even a NicePlace to VisitAuthoritarian governments that are also close allies can pose touchy problems for the United States as their public support begins to dwindle. One example was the Carter Administration's attitude toward the Shah of Iran, which helped make him a lonely and vulnerable figure as the revolution picked up steam. And - although the outcome is far from clear - the case of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines may be another. Last week, as opposition to Mr. Marcos continued to build, he appeared more isolated than ever as President Reagan called off a visit to Manila that was to be part of a November tour of five Asian countries.

title: AL ELLIS: HAVE DRONE, WILL TRAVEL
description: On the boat where he lives, not many miles from the orphanage where he grew up, Al Ellis smiles now when he recalls the jokes some of his friends used to make about his preoccupation with toy airplanes. In Salt Lake City this summer, Mr. Ellis was honored by the Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems, a technical society, for having been the ''driving force'' behind the development of ''the first Mini-RPV to be successfully deployed operationally anywhere in the world.''

title:
LEISURE;
GROUNDCOVERS PROVIDE AN ALTERNATIVE TO THE POWER MOWER
description: Hope Raymond is a freelance writer .

title: 16 in Yonkers Charged With Drunken Driving
description: The Westchester County police set up a checkpoint on the Bronx River Parkway this morning and charged 16 motorists with driving while intoxicated, authorities said.

title: HOSPITAL PRESSURED TO AID ANOTHER IN HARLEM
description: New York State health officials have told Mount Sinai Medical Center that they will not consider approving the hospital's rebuilding plan unless it agrees to help rescue North General Hospital, a small, private institution struggling to survive in Harlem.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TOKYO
description: A few residents left Tokyo last month, fearing the worst was about to happen. They had taken seriously a meteorologist's prediction that Mount Fuji would erupt and that the city would be hit by an earthquake at about the same time. The people who left have returned, perhaps a little embarrassed. Tokyo is still very much with us this fall, and a good thing, because few times of the year are better for a visit. The heat that wilts collars by 9 A.M. has been gone for several weeks. Autumn tends to be clear and crisp, with good views of not-too-distant Mount Fuji. It is also a good time to take advantage of the relatively strong dollar, which has slipped lately but still commands more than 230 yen, a rate about 10 percent higher than earlier this year. Getting There

title: SOME STEWS THAT DON'T REQUIRE BEING HOME ALL DAY
description: THE sort of stew that simmers gently all day on the back of the stove is an appealing notion, but not very practical for those who can't stay at home to watch over it. But this does not mean that stews are out for the working cook. Certainly beef, lamb and pork need long, slow cooking, but fish, veal and chicken do not. A stew made with the latter ingredients can be ready for dinner the same evening.

title: HALL OF FAME PREVIEW
description: ORDINARILY, the image of the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown is that of bronze plaques and out-of-style uniforms, of sepia photos and dusty bats, of yellowed clippings and scuffed gloves. But on the Phillies now, it's as if the Hall of Fame has come to life, as if that little red brick shrine in upstate New York is appearing in a Philadelphia preview. Five potential Hall of Famers are wearing the Phillies' red pin-striped double- knits: Pete Rose, Steve Carlton, Joe Morgan, Mike Schmidt and Tony Perez.

title: BEACH RESIDENTS PONDER FIRE SAFETY
description: A FIRE that cost three people their lives and destroyed four homes in the Fire Island community of Point O'Woods has prompted new discussions on fire safety in the resort communities that run the length of the island.

title: SNAPSHOTS
description: Since returning from England, we have seen no one. Nobody has dropped by, nobody has phoned. Friends and relatives, invited to come by and socialize, say they will be too busy until after Christmas.

title: IT'S PURE FICTION, SAYS RABBI'S WIFE
description: FOR 32 years, Marilyn Greenberg has been the wife of a rabbi. It is a life she knows well. And because a cardinal rule for beginning writers is write about what you know, when Mrs. Greenberg decided to try her hand at fiction, she wrote about a rabbi, his wife, their children - and his congregation.

title: PENN STATE UPSETS ALABAMA BY 34-28
description: There's life in the old champ, after all. Penn State, 1982 national collegiate football champions but loser of its first three games this season and an 8-point underdog before a record crowd of 85,614 in its own stadium, rose up today and knocked third- ranked Alabama from the unbeaten ranks with a 34-28 victory. The old champ had to survive a final-round knockdown.

title: STUYVESANT POLYCLINIC, AT 100, ATILL TENDS TO LOWER EAST SIDERS
description: In the 100 years since the Stuyvesant Polyclinic was founded in lower Manhattan by a group of doctors with decidedly German names, it has changed both its address and its name three times.

title: PASSAIC'S HEYWARD IN CONTROL OF WHAT NEXT YEAR BRINGS
description: It was in the spring of 1980 that Ray McCrann first saw Craig Heyward perform.

title: Echoes on Economy
description: And as it has for weeks, politics dominated budget deliberations. Arguing that squabbling with the White House over appropriations won't gain anyone anything any more, the Republican majority, liberal party members included, expeditiously disposed of a Democratic attempt to beef up, by $559 million, the education portion of a $91 billion domestic spending bill.

title: POLL CITES QUALITIES OF IDEAL PRESIDENT
description: Americans cite personal qualities more often than political ones to describe their notion of an ideal President, according to the New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: THE HARD CODE OF THE SUPERCHIEFS
description: THE POLICE FOUNDATION BALL, HELD every January at headquarters in lower Manhattan, is an incongruous social event eagerly attended by the Brass, by local politicians and by private citizens who actively support their police. It is the one time when cops pretend not to be aliens and the rest of the partygoers pretend they are perfectly at ease among the gun- bearing men they acknowledge as guardians of their society.

title: Q AND A
description: Hot-Air Encroachment Question: How close to my window can a neighbor install an air-conditioner? The windows concerned are in the building's air shaft and his air-conditioner is about two feet from my window frame, which means I am the recipient of a blast of hot air. . . . B.F.P., Manhattan Answer: Frank A. Dell'Aira, assistant commissioner for code enforcement in the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said he knew of no city law concerning your problem. He suggests that you consult the tenant, who may not be aware he is creating a problem, and notify the landlord. If the landlord does not help, consult a lawyer about the possibility that your neighbor is creating a ''nuisance'' and interfering with your quiet enjoyment of the premises, which is guaranteed by the landlord in most leases.

title: White House Voices Concern Over 4 Killings in El Salvador
