description: The White House said today it was disturbed by reports from El Salvador of the ''death squad'' murders of four people, including one said to be a union leader.

title: 4 Food Outlets Listed by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited four food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: SCIENTISTS WORK TO IMPROVE THE CROPS
description: CHATSWORTH IN THE early years of this century, Elizabeth White took the

title: A GRATEFUL HIKER'S SALUTE TO FRANCE
description: ADAM NICOLSON is the author, with Charlie Waite, of ''The National Trust Book of Long Walks in England, Scotland and Wales'' and ''Long Walks in France'' (Harmony). Walking abroad, Hazlitt wrote, ''like a dream or another state of existence, does not piece into our daily modes of life. It is an animated but momentary hallucination.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE FALLACY OF A MODERN-DAY R.F.C.
description: WHEN the A.F.L.-C.I.O. proposed the creation of a national development bank last week, it joined several distinguished financiers, corporate executives, politicians and professors in urging Washington to bankroll the reindustrialization of our economy.

title: WHY HIGH INTEREST RATES ARE HERE TO STAY
description: FOR many Wall Street forecasters, the big question these days is whether interest rates will tumble a point by Thanksgiving, or two by Christmas. Such predictions may be critical to the bond market and may fascinate forecasters, but they hide a deeper truth that in recent months has come to dominate the thinking of an increasing number of economists here and abroad. For the United States economy - the linchpin of the industrial world - has entered a new era this year: one of high interest rates.

title: ALPINE TREK FOR THE TIMID
description: Straight ahead yawned a crevasse big enough to swallow a horse. ''You go first,'' suggested my companion. ''No, no,'' I insisted, ''after you.'' Shaking with fright, we threw our backpacks across the chasm; then we leapt over the narrow end, trying to ignore the eery moans and sighs of the shifting ice echoing from the 100-foot depths. Above, a massive snow cliff rumbled, avalanche-style.

title: NOUVELLE VAIL
description: Peter Benchley's most recent novel is ''The Girl of the Sea of Cortez.'' By PETER BENCHLEY

title: LIFE AND DEATH IN MEDICINE AND LAW
description: As one who has followed the Claire Conroy case with much interest, and who attended the oral arguments before the Appellate Division, I am outraged by Mary K. Brennan's vitriolic attack on the court-appointed guardian, John J. Delaney Jr., and the state's Public Advocate (Aug. 28).

title: NOTRE DAME ROUTS SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Steve Beuerlein passed 26 and 53 yards for touchdowns, and Mike Johnston kicked three field goals as Notre Dame scored the first five times it had the ball en route to a 30-6 victory over South Carolina tonight.

title: THE FIRST CASE OF MARATHON FEVER
description: MOST of the multitude that will watch or run in the New York City Marathon can date its popularity to the late 1970's. But few realize that for a brief period 75 years ago the marathon may have been the most popular spectator sport in America.

title: CLOSE RACE IS PREDICTED IN 11TH DISTRICT
description: IN the race for county legislator from the new 11th District, in southern Westchester, three candidates are waging what observers describe as a tight race - all battling hard and none considered a sure winner.

title: ARGENTINE JUDGES ALLOW DEBT TALKS
description: A federal appeals court overruled a judge in Patagonia today and said that the Government was free to resume talks with foreign bankers on refinancing Argentina's $40 billion debt.

title: YOUTHS 'AGING OUT' OF FOSTER CARE POSING A CHALLENGE
description: FRANK DE BENEDETTO lived with the same foster family in Baldwin for most of his 20 years - since he was 17 months old. ''The social worker always pushed adoption,'' he said, ''but I always felt like I was born to this family. I wouldn't feel any different if I was adopted.''

title: EDISON DOWNS COLONIA BY 30-0 FOR 3D SHUTOUT
description: The Edison defense, which has shut out all three opponents this season, showed its muscle again yesterday in a 30-0 victory over Colonia in Colonia.

title: MONTCLAIR SCORES EARLY TO BEAT BELLEVILLE
description: Brandy Wells went 2 yards for a touchdown and Dennis O'Hare returned an interception 34 yards for another score to lift Montclair (3-0) over Belleville, 14-6, yesterday in Montclair.

title: AMERICAN MAYHEM, SOVIET INTRIGUE
description: MANEUVERS by Fredric Neuman 376pp New York: The Dial Press $15.95MAY DAY IN MAGADAN by Anthony Olcott 317pp New York: Bantam Books $13.95

title: AS FLOODS EBB, BITTERNESS RESURGES IN STRIKE TOWN
description: A prayer tacked on the door of the steelworkers' union hall here begins, ''We ask you, heavenly Father, to be with us in these difficult days.''

title: Letters; Dream Apartment
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDER SAFAD'S MYSTIC SPELL
description: LINDA GREENHOUSE covers the Supreme Court for The New York Times.

title: NEW EFFORTS ARE UNDER WAY TO SAVE THE GREAT SWAMP
description: ''AN URBAN wilderness'' is what people have called the Great Swamp, with its bone-bare trees, its meadows and its wildflowers, since efforts to save it began in 1959.

title: More Bungling Than Barbarity?
description: American intelligence data disclosed last week took some of the edge off the almost universal condemnation of the Soviet Union for shooting down a Korean Air Lines passenger plane with 269 people.

title: SIKH LEADER VOWS FURTHER STRUGGLE
description: The leader of a Sikh civil disobedience movement here in Punjab said today that the agitation would continue despite the assertion of central Government authority in the state two days ago.

title: DOSE ISRAELIS, BEIRUT NOW SEEMS ONLY A SIDESHOW
description: Israeli policy in Lebanon today appears to be torn between two contradictory impulses. On the one hand, Israeli officials still seem to have a lingering hope that they can salvage some kind of normalized relations with the Beirut Government as a prize of the 1982 invasion. On the other hand, they increasingly recognize that the most they may ever gain from their invasion of Lebanon is 25 miles of relative peace and quiet.

title: Aide Says U.S. Seeks Philippine Democracy
description: Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam said today that it was obvious that the Philippine Government would change ''at some point'' and that the United States hoped for moves toward democracy.

title: TWO DATES TO REMEMBER
description: The United States and West Germany are getting into a tight corner these days, with two important dates ahead.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS STIFFEN DIPLOMA REQUIREMENTS
description: The academic requirements for a high school diploma in the United States are becoming stiffer.

title: Recent Sales
description: Chester $225,000 *2*Old Gladstone Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*100-year-old carriage house; 5 acres, cedar shakes, *2*storage barn; taxes $3,500. Cranford $138,000 *2*3 Victoria Court, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*25-year-old split-level; in-ground sprinkler, *2*wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,569. Flanders $94,000 *2*29 West Grover Street, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*25-year-old split-level; 1 acre, fireplace *2*in living room, large trees; taxes $1,730. Keyport $85,000 *2*28 St. George Place, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old colonial; screened porch, attached *2*one-car garage; taxes $1,655. Maplewood $81,500 *2*27 Warren Road, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old colonial; new kitchen, large yard; *2*taxes $2,966. Ridgewood $190,000 *2*204 Hempstead Road, 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*85-year-old ranch; enclosed porch, fireplace; *2*taxes $6,189. OTHER AREAS Purchase, N.Y. $375,000 *2*34 Century Ridge Drive, 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*26-year-old, contemporary; playroom, terraces *2*on two floors heated pool, 1 acre; *2*taxes $4,580. Milford, Conn. $237,500 *2*114 Trumbull Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*new town-house condominium on waterfront; *2*monthly common charges $151; taxes $3,484. Commack, L.I. $87,000 *2*47 Larry Drive, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*24-year-old colonial; full basement, formal dining *2*room, den, garage; taxes $2,900.

title: Carol A. Mattson and Lieutenant Wed
description: Carol Anne Mattson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Mattson of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Second Lieut. Bruce Edward Heylmun, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Heylmun of Pottstown, Pa.

title: O'ROURKE AND REID BEGIN FINAL ROUND
description: WHEN former Representative Ogden R. Reid began his quest for the County Executive job earlier this year, he seemed to have a number of advantages over the Republican incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, a county legislator who had been appointed to the $81,000 post in January.

title: Jocelyn Samuels a Bride
description: Jocelyn Frances Samuels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Samuels of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Parker Olson, son of Mrs. William Mosteller of Falls Church, Va., and Richard Olson of Fairfax, Va. The ceremony was performed by Justice Martin B. Stecher of State Supreme Court at the Novo Arts gallery in New York. The bride, who is keeping her name, graduated magna cum laude from Middlebury College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and the Columbia University School of Law. Mr. Olson graduated from the University of Michigan, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and the Harvard Law School.

title: COMING OF AGE IN KENYA
description: Twilight had enveloped our tent encampment by a stream on the great Serengeti Plain just outside the protected park of the Masai Mara game reserve in southwest Kenya. We - my son, John-Michael, and I - were sitting in front of the campfire while dinner was being prepared. Behind us a huge, blood-red equatorial sun was touching down on a cloudless horizon. To our left, some 30 miles away, a giant storm moved slowly west. It looked like one of those A-bomb test blasts, only infinitely magnified.

title:
GARDENING;
WATERING LESSONS LEARNED IN THE WEST
description: ONE has only to see the deserts of the Southwest to gain insight into the importance of water to the survival of plants. Only where irrigation water is abundant are crops grown and landscapes verdant.

title: NEBRASKA DEFEATS OKLA. STATE, 14-10
description: Nebraska, the nation's No. 1-ranked team, had to overcome a halftime deficit for the first time this year as it rallied for a 14-10 triumph over previously undefeated Oklahoma State.

title: A 6-Touchdown Day
description: Maurice Owens, the Foss tailback, handled the ball only 12 times Friday night and didn't play most of the second half. But he turned the opportunity into the most prolific performance in Tacoma high school football history as he returned the first Stadium punt of the game 62 yards for a touchdown and then rushed for five others as the Falcons won, 49-6. The 5-foot-6-inch Owens rushed for 171 yards in 11 carries from scrimmage.

title: LITERARY WORKS TAKE A TURN FOR THE DRAMATIC
description: Most recordings of novels - sometimes complete, more often in selected passages or condensations - consist of straight readings by the actual author, or quasi-performances, frequently by some celebrated member of the acting profession who indulges in a certain amount of vocal characterization as he or she goes along. In a few cases, several stars have joined forces, dividing up passages from a classic work of fiction to compelling effect.

title: The Big Woods
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Dublin
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SEEKING RULES TO ALLOW STATES TO CUT MEDICAID
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking changes in the Medicaid program that would give states new power to restrict eligibility and to reduce benefits for thousands of children and elderly people with high medical expenses.

title: BIRMINGHAM PICKS A MAYOR TUESDAY
description: Four years ago, in a victory that underscored the new era of biracial politics in the South, Richard Arrington Jr. was the first black elected as Mayor of Birmingham.

title: Miss Brown Wed To M. F. Brewer
description: Janet Huidekoper Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Travis Taylor Brown of Washington, was married yesterday to Michael Fabian Brewer, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Fabian Brewer of Chicago. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, assisted by Bishop Robert W. Estill of the Diocese of North Carolina.

title: I LOVE NEW YORK AND L.A., TOO
JANETTE SMITH SETS MEET MARK
description: For Janette Smith, who raced yesterday at the Manhattan College Inter-scholastic Cross-Country Meet, it was the highlight of her career. It wasn't so much that she won the girls' Eastern States championship in 14 minutes 13.1 seconds, a women's record for the Van Cortlandt Park 2.5- mile course, though. What really thrilled the 17-year-old senior at J. P. Stevens High School in Edison, N.J., was beating Christine Curtin, the defending national cross-country champion from Mepham in Bellmore, L.I.

title: 'WE'LL SEND YOU AND ESTIMATE...'
description: SIXTEEN years ago two men spent an entire evening at our house surveying it for the installation of central air conditioning. They prowled through the attic, poked into closets, took sun and shade readings with impressive instruments and spent an hour sketching an air conditioning scheme; a wondrous maze of ducts, vents and pipes making their way through the walls and ceilings of our inefficiently designed Tudor. When we asked what the cost would be, they replied, ''We'll send you an estimate,'' and disappeared, never to be heard from again.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The 'Endless Summer'

title: JETS HAVE A POINT IN MOVING TO STATE
description: WHETHER it's Wesley Walker slashing through the defense like a green dart or Mark Gastineau doing the Studio Stomp on a quarterback's face mask . . .

title: REVOLUTION IN NICARAGUA
CORRECTION
description: An article on page 16 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the dancer Bertram Ross gives the dates incorrectly for his engagement at the Theater of the Riverside Church. He will perform Thursday, Saturday and next Sunday.

title: BUILDING DOWN THE MISSILE RACE
description: A MID the anti-Soviet rhetoric, the Reagan Administration continued last week to make conciliatory gestures apparently designed to draw Moscow into serious arms negotiating and, in the process, appease American and foreign opponents of the Administration's military programs.

title: 'HOMETOWN' SOCIETIES IN NEW YORK AID NEEDY
description: A native of Czestochowa, Poland, who now lives in Israel needed financial help. A group of people living in the New York metropolitan area who had all emigrated from the same Polish city met the other day and voted to send the woman $100.

title: WINTER: LOVE IT OR LEAVE IT
description: WINTER BENEDICTION

title: ATHENS AREA TRYING ANEW ON LAND USE
description: ''Now I can sleep easily at night because my home is legalized,'' said Constantine Carlosze ropoulos, the owner of a three-room wooden house in suburban Loutsa, 15 miles to the north.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.
description: 1 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $3.95.) A fictional saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization.

title: AN EXECUTIVE'S IRANIAN ADVENTURE
description: On Wings of Eagles by Ken Follett. William Morrow & Co., N.Y. 444 pages, $16.95.

title: Pennsylvania Highway Reopened After Crash
description: Firefighters extinguished a persistent blaze under Pennsylvania's busiest highway today, more than 24 hours after a gasoline tanker truck crashed and exploded, killing two people, severely injuring another person and paralyzing traffic.

title: FORESTATION BRINGS THE WILDS TO LIFE
description: JULES BOURGLAY, the famous itinerant Leatherman who in silence walked the county's roads and slept in its caves in the 1870's and 1880's would scarcely find a familiar sight here a century later, and not just because of changes caused by the larger population. The biggest change in Westchester is the woods. One hundred years ago 80 percent of the county was cleared of trees. Today the numbers are reversed: The forest covers 80 percent of the land.

title: NEW DELAYS SEEN FOR POWER PLANT
description: The cost of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant, already 1,000 percent over its budget, will increase beyond $4.2 billion, and the upstate plant will be completed later than predicted, the Public Service Commission has been told.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
AH, SWEET MYSTERIES OF SINGING
description: What's an ''A-flat tenor''? It's a male creature with an upper voice constricted in range and quality, just as you might guess even without looking up the term in Cornelius L. Reid's ''A Dictionary of Vocal Terminology.'' But is an ''A-flat tenor'' different from a ''necktie tenor,'' and if so, how? What does it mean to say that a singer is ''chewing bread'' or ''drinking in the tone''? What is the difference between a tone with ''ping'' and one with ''ring''?

title: SHOREHAM: UNRESOLVED ISSUES
description: LAST month, a Federal panel cleared most of the obstacles to the loading of nuclear fuel at the Shoreham nuclear power plant. But significant problems remain to be solved - principally with the emergency diesel generators and with the lack of an emergency plan. Both must be in place before the plant can be licensed for commercial operation.

title: JET'S NEW ORLEANS TAKEOFF FOUND CLOSE TO DISASTER
description: The cockpit crew of an Eastern Airlines jetliner that came ''very close to tragedy'' did not realize they had made a dangerously low takeoff until an air traffic controller told them, a Federal official said Friday.

title: FEW CHARGES SEEN AS KENTUCKY INQUIRY NARROWS
description: An investigation of gambling and trafficking in cocaine and guns among leading figures in the Blue Grass region has narrowed, Federal law-enforcement sources say. No more than three or four indictments, if any, can be expected, and they may not come soon, the sources say.

title: FAR-FLUNG FESTIVITIES
description: In the Holy Land, where it all began, Christmas is a somewhat austere holiday. It comes in the season of winter rains and raw winds. Its celebrations are muted, transitory and isolated from the larger society, which is overwhelmingly Moslem and Jewish.

title: AGING: TIMELES ESTATE, NOT TERMINAL ILLNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOK, MA-NO HANDS, AND STILL ALIVE
description: I TRIED to be a good mother. I fed him chicken soup, introduced him to nice girls, even got him a good summer job on Wall Street. But he decided to ride a bicycle across the country - alone.

title: Kenneth M. Wineland Weds Barbara Browne
description: Barbara Beazell Browne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Browne of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Michael Wineland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollis Ferdinand Wineland of Blackwood, N.J. The Rev. James B. Reynolds of St. Henry's Roman Catholic Church in Pompano Beach, Fla., performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J.

title: ADDING A DASH TO MEAT AND POTATOES
description: WE WERE AMUSED recently to think of the connotation of the phrase ''meat and potatoes.'' It is, in its figurative sense, a demeaning term, a ''meat and potatoes'' individual being a person of little or no taste, an indiscriminate eater with a hearty appetite.

title: TEXAS DEFEATS SOONERS
description: The Texas Longhorns scored three touchdowns within a 7-minute-7-second span of the third quarter today and defeated Oklahoma, 28-16, in the Cotton Bowl.

title: COACHED BACKFIELD FOR GIANTS' OFFENSE
description: Bob Ledbetter, the offensive backfield coach of the Giants, died Friday night at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. He had been hospitalized since Sept. 24, his 49th birthday, after he suffered a stroke at his home in Northport, L.I.

title: SEVEN CANDIDATES VIE FOR BENCH IN 9TH
description: FOR the first time in nearly 75 years, the county's Republican Party has endorsed a Democratic candidate for judicial office. The candidate, Judge Lawrence N. Martin Jr., is one of seven people seeking four seats on the State Supreme Court from the Ninth Judicial District.

title: ITALIANS FALTER IN BRIDGE PLAY AND ACES WIN
description: The final deals of the World Championship bridge tournament here this afternoon gave the United States a victory over Italy when all seemed lost.

title: Film Festival
description: The clash of cultures revealed in Mira Nair's ''So Far From India,'' which was shown at the New York Film Festival together with ''Dhrupad,'' creates some fascinating contradictions, which Miss Nair has ably explored.

title: 'RE-REGULATIN' WOULD AID COMPETITION
description: A panel headed by Vice President Bush is looking into a pro- posal to consolidate most of the Government's regulation of com- mercial banks in a new, single Federal banking commission. Under the draft plan, the new agency would supplant the Comp- troller of the Currency, abolish the Federal Reserve Board's juris- diction over most banks and holding companies and assume many of the noninsurance functions of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The plan also would expand the powers of the Fed- eral Home Loan Bank Board to include regulation of smaller com- mercial banks in addition to savings and loan associations.

title: JERSEYANS TO GET U.S. ENERGY FUNDS
description: Ninety- three school districts and hospitals in New Jersey will share $4.1 million in Federal grants for energy-conservation work, the State Energy Commissioner has announced.

title: Unburden the Arms Build-Down
description: The Reagan Administration has finally negotiated a strategic arms deal - but only with key members of Congress, not the Russians. Its flexible- sounding proposal for a ''build-down'' - trading safer new warheads for unsafe older ones - is a nod to some legislators to win their support for missile budgets. But it's been grafted to a familiar demand that Moscow restructure its missile forces much more than Washington.

title: DANCE: LOCALMOTION OFFERS 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: Three choreographers demonstrated that less is more at Thursday night's program by Localmotion at the Kazuko Hirabayashi Studio.

title: AS OFF BROADWAY THRIVES, ITS PROBLEMS MOUNT
description: ''One of the things I regret,'' the playwright said, ''is the passing of the experimental group theater.'' The speaker was Eugene O'Neill and the time was 1931. His obituary for innovation may have proven premature, but his concern persists, not least among those who attempt to bring new vision to the theater.

title: REVITALIZATION SET FOR ST. JAMES AREA
description: THE Smithtown Town Board has approved a one-year program to improve the business district in St. James, using $270,000 in Federal money from the Community Development Block Grant Program.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 116 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form.225 CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. 3316 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 4510

title:
NUMISMATICS;
LOTS OF ACTION PROMISED IN UPCOMING AUCTIONS
description: There have been an unusual number of high-powered coin auction sales in recent months, and the schedule is equally crowded in the weeks and months ahead. Reaffirming New York City's acknowledged status as the coin world's auction capital, a number of these upcoming sales will take place in and near this city.

title: Air Force Meets Its Full Goal On Officer Recruiting in 1983
description: The United States Air Force met 100 percent of its officer recruiting goal this year for the first time since the all- volunteer force began in 1973, officials said Tuesday.

title: Rayne Allyn Draffin and Jeffrey Mayer Are Wed
description: Rayne Allyn Draffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Frederick Draffin of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Jeffrey Robert Mayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mayer of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Carl Gillmeister, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: B.Y.U. WINS, 41-10
description: Steve Young led Brigham Young (4-1, 2-0) to scores on five of its first seven possessions for a 41-10 victory over Wyoming today in a Western Athletic Conference game. Young passed for 356 yards and 2 touchdowns. Washington 34 Oregon State 7

title: ON HOLIDAY, THE GAME IS AFOOT
description: Taking to the road means planning ahead. Weather is everything to the walker. Although the temperate climate of Western Europe makes it possible to walk anywhere at almost any time of year, spring and autumn may be best for the walks described below, especially in some areas of France, where the summer is hot and dry. Spring arrives later in the northern climes and is delayed by altitude. The suggested itineraries cover histsoric and scenic regions of Britain, France, Germany and Switzerland. The degree of skill and amount of time involved vary from a day or two to a week. Some of the walks are gentle rambles, others are demanding treks over sometimes tricky terrain. Suggestions for guidebooks and accommodations follow each walk. BRITAIN

title: Whose Deficit?
description: To the Business Editor:

title: KNICK ROOKIE BATTLING ODDS
description: There is a player like Mark Jones in every National Basketball Association training camp. They are the ones trying to beat the odds that are reflected in these statistics: Of the 244 players selected in the 1982 college draft, only 49 made N.B.A. rosters, and only 4 of them were selected later than the third round.

title: TWO THEATERS LOOK TO THE FUTURE
description: MINDFUL that many people in Fairfield County find an evening in Manhattan very expensive, inconvenient and for some, a bit scary, two performing arts theaters here, the Palace and the Center for the Arts, are attempting to bring culture a bit closer to home.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: AT 6, HE STARTED A VIOLIN CAREER
description: TO say that Darel Stark is single-minded about the violin would be an understatement. For 11 years now, ever since he was introduced to the instrument in kindergarten, the 16-year-old Port Jefferson Station musician has devoted his life to the violin - first ''dreaming about playing it'' and then studying it, practicing it at least six hours a day and performing whenever the opportunity arises.

title: JOURNAL
description: ''I'VE never cooked wearing an Adolpho before,'' Roberta Peters exclaimed, glancing down at her beaded top and pleated silk pants as she put the finishing touches on mushrooms stuffed with blue cheese and pecans. ''Someone just came over to me and said, 'I'd rather hear you sing than see you cook.' ''

title: IMMIGRANT BILL: A BLOW
description: Last Tuesday, after the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill, pronounced immigration reform dead for 1983, Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx said, ''This was a major victory for the Hispanic Caucus.'' Perhaps it was. But it was a triumph only in the tactical sense, as an exhibition of muscle. If fact, since it may well kill the bill, it was no victory for most Hispanic Americans, nor for the Democratic Party, nor for the United States.

title: REAGAN RATING REMAINS SAME
description: The percentage of of Americans of voting age who view President Reagan favorably is about the same as it was three months ago, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Neither Borrower Or Lender Be?
description: Robert L. Ernst's recent piece on delinquent borrowers of books (''Throwing the Book at Bad Borrowers,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 4) reminds me of the message Sir Walter Scott placed in books he loaned out to his friends: ''And please return it. You may think this a strange request, but I find that although many of my friends are poor arithmeticians, they are nearly all good bookkeepers.''

title: CLINTON BLANKS KENNEDY
description: Coach Joe Prezioso kept his Clinton players low all week so that they'd be eager to fly when they played Kennedy. His strategy worked, as Clinton soared to a 16-0 victory yesterday.

title: HOW TO PICK A LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE
3 PIANISTS, A FLUTIST AND A BARITONE PERFORM IN RECITALS
description: If the walls at Carnegie Recital Hall could talk, they might have told you about three pianists, a flutist and a baritone - all of whom made New York debuts in the newly refurbished chamber auditorium within the last seven days.

title: REAGAN QUESTIONS BUILDUP IN SYRIA
description: President Reagan said today that a ''massive'' influx of new Soviet military equipment into Syria had caused the United States ''to wonder aloud'' about the Syrians' interest in peace in the region.

title: Others Perished In the Holocaust, Too
description: David L. Blumenfeld, executive director of the New York City Holocaust Memorial Commission, presented a distorted picture of the Nazi Holocaust with his assertion that it was an exclusively Jewish phenomenon (Long Islanders, Sept. 4). Although Jews were the first to be killed, they were not the only victims.

title: THE MAKING OF A WRITER: LISTENING IN THE DARK
description: SINCE being read to and after, when I began reading to myself, there has never been a line read that I didn't hear. As my eyes followed the sentence, a voice was saying it silently to me. It isn't my mother's voice, or the voice of any person I can identify, certainly not my own. It is human, but inward, and it is inwardly that I listen to it. It is to me the voice of the story or the poem itself. The cadence, whatever it is that asks you to believe, the feeling that resides in the printed word, reaches me through the reader- voice.

title: Riding Team Named
description: Leslie Burr of Westport, Conn., currently the leader for Grand Prix Association rider-of-the-year honors, was named to the team that will represent the United States at the Washington International Horse Show Oct. 23-30 at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., and the National Horse Show, Nov. 1-6 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Nov. 26 Wedding For Miss Sullivan
description: Mr and Mrs. Dwight Sullivan of Coconut Grove, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Gibson Sullivan, to Andrew MacDonald Lindseth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon A. Lindseth of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Susan A. Droney Plans June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Droney of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann Droney, to William VanArsdale Shannon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shannon, also of Darien. A June wedding is planned.

title: Weighing Business Spending on Initiatives
description: To the Editor:

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Books Are Part Of the Story
description: The Remarkable Book Shop interior in Westport, Conn., is as warmly remarkable as its hot strawberry exterior paint - busy with a red dot sale at 40 percent off in the gift shop early last month and a window promotion heralding ''My Son the Author'' about a local writer, Mark Kramer, and his book, ''Invasive Procedures,'' following the autograph party. The weekly special of a current hardcover best-seller is always 25 percent off.

title: NEW LOOK AT A POLICY CAN PAY OFF
description: ONCE families buy a house and insure both the structure and the contents, they rarely re-examine their coverage. Yet changing circumstances can radically alter a family's insurance needs. Inflation or a major improvement may leave some homeowers underprotected, while others may find themselves paying high premiums for more insurance than they need.

title:
IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES;
PHOTOGRAPHY
description: ''The Way We Live Now: Beyond Social Documentary'' at P.S. 1, curated by the critic Abigail Solomon-Godeau, is a group show in which 10 photographers use words and pictures to deal with issues, from nuclear power to abortion, from the point of view of the radical left. The most effective presentation is Lisa Lewenz's 1884 calendar entitled ''A View From Three Mile Island,'' which is illustrated with photographs of tacky but lovable American bedrooms, living rooms and kitchens.

title: NEW ART ANIMATES THE TATE
description: It's an All over the Western world, a phantom has walked free since the end of World War II. As phantoms go, it is benign, and when it turned up in London, just the other day, no one was scared.

title: Alice Clare Goldsmith Weds
description: Alice Clare Goldsmith, daughter of C. Gerald Goldsmith of Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla., and Barbara Goldsmith Perry of Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to David Elgart, son of Dorothy Elgart of Deerfield Beach, Fla., and the late Jacob Elgart. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the St. Regis Hotel.

title: SUFFOLK ROAD-WIDENING PLAN FOUGHT
description: COMMACK ROAD and Suffolk Avenue traverse an area of Suffolk County that many visitors to the Island rarely get to, but if a project that has been dormant for two decades gets off the ground, it could be an area that will have many more visitors.

title: JACKSON TOLD HE MUST START BID SOON
description: On Thursday, before white students at the University of New Hampshire, and again Friday, before a mostly black group of students at Harris-Stowe Teachers College in St. Louis, the Rev. Jesse Jackson began devoting more of his voter registration exhortations to criticism of the Reagan Administration's foreign policy and disarmament positions.

title: TIPS FOR BETTER PICTURES
description: Taking pictures is a lot like participating in a particular sport - the better you get at it, the more you enjoy doing it. Unfortunately, sometimes disaster strikes and the result is disappointment - usually due to such things as bad composition, poor exposure, or blurry images.

title: SELLING THE ROPE
description: In the midst of a rousing, hawkish speech to a dinner of conservatives assembled by the Heritage Foundation, President Reagan claimed as one of his central achievements: ''We have significantly slowed the transfer of valuable free world technology to the Soviet Union.''

title: TWO ISRAELI NOVELISTS
description: Writers need not travel too far to find their themes in Israel. They can dip into the well of their own experiences or simply step outside their front doors. I spent some time there recently with two novelists who come from different backgrounds: one grew up in Israel, the other survived the European Holocaust. Both reflect the country's modern and traditional literary interests.

title:
ART;
UNEXPECTED MESSAGES IN GEOMETTIC FORM
description: IT is rare to find geometric abstraction evoking specific associations with worldly experience, but this is exactly the intention in many of Marianne Vecsey's tightly structured gridlike paintings now on view in the East Hills Gallery.

title: LISA JO NUSS IS AFFIANCED TO DAVID BEATTY WALLOVER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Nuss of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Jo Nuss, to David Beatty Wallover, son of Mr. and Mrs. James I. Wallover of Beaver, Pa.

title: Miss Critten Berger to Wed George Gay
description: Maj. Gen. Willis Dale Crittenberger Jr. U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Crittenberger of McLean, Va. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Dale Crittenberger, to George Edward Harper Gay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Newton Gay Jr. of Baltimore. A Jan. 7 wedding is planned.

title: A 2D GREENHOUSE ON THE 6TH FLOOR
description: Thirty stories above Third Avenue, on a north- facing setback near the top of an office tower under construction between 54th and 55th Streets, sits a four- story-high, glassed-in greenhouse that gives the building an unusual profile when viewed from the east or west.

title: INFECTION FATAL TO 4 AT CANCER INSTITUTE IN BUFFALO
description: Four cancer patients at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo, all under 30 years of age, died of a fungal infection that is believed to have been transmitted through the air-conditioning system, officials of the institute said yesterday.

title: RENTS BEDEVIL ARTS GROUPS
description: WHEN the Dance Theater Workshop moved into the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater eight years ago, its members hoped they had found a permanent home. The low rent - $14,000 a year - would enable them to concentrate on the experimental dance they loved.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
THE ONION BRAIDER
description: HE LIKES BRAIDING ONIONS. HE LIKES BRAIDING tight, adding in an onion every second or third plait, putting as many of the flat yellowish-brown bulbs on each string as he can. Dumping the onions into a mesh sack and hanging the sack by its drawstring would keep them just as well, but onions deserve to be done up fancy. They are his onions, and, as he touches them, he remembers the times he brought them water, carefully unrolling the hose so as not to drag it over the neighboring lettuce. June and July were dry, so dry the lilacs wilted, and water was as scarce as it was needed. ,up a low dike of soil along the downhill side of the nion row so that the narrow stream of water flowing from the hose end stayed close ot the bases of the young plants and soaked in.

title: A RETREAT FOR MOVIE FANS
description: THE lights dim, the eyes widen and ears perk as the film begins its march through the projector and this season of Judith Crist Film Weekends gets under way at the Tarrytown House Executive Conference Center.

title: MAKING OTHER PEOPLE BEHAVE
description: THE ANATOMY OF POWER By John Kenneth Galbraith. 206 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95.

title: CHICAGO SETS UP HOMEWORK CENTERS IN STRIKE
description: As talks in the school employees' strike halted Friday, school children around the city were turning to homework centers run by parents, city volunteers and even striking teachers.

title:
ART;
DEBUT OF A MUSEUM SERIES
description: THE inauguration of an annual juried exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead is good news for the region's artists and also for museumgoers who may be looking for something out of the ordinary.

title: Sarah Fay Weds W. S. Cottingham
description: Sarah Symington Fay, daughter of Paul Burgess Fay Jr. and Anita Marcus Fay, both of San Francisco, was married yesterday to William Stuart Cottingham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Sherwin Cottingham of Montreal. The Rev. George L. Thomas performed the ceremony in Our Lady of the Wayside Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, Calif., assisted by the Rev. Jack Shriver, a Presbyterian minister.

title: ARMY SETS BACK RUTGERS, 20-12, ON PASS
description: Army, its quarterback situation scrambled by injury, nonetheless used a surprise 78-yard touchdown pass to defeat Rutgers, 20-12, at Michie Stadium this afternoon. The pass was thrown by the team's star halfback, Elton Akins, who also gained 128 yards in his more familiar role as a runner.

title: ARGENTINE INTRIGUE SURROUNDS A BANKER
description: Argentina teetered on the brink of default for several days, with its central bank president in jail, all repayments halted on its $40 billion of debt and a much needed injection of $500 million in new funds shut off. Julio Gonzalez del Solar, the Paul Volcker of Argentina, was arrested upon his return from the recent I.M.F. meeting in Washington by a federal judge in the Patagonia region. Judge Federico Pinto Kramer charged that the banker had compromised Argentina's sovereignty in a $200 million refinancing agreement signed with New York banks that gave them some jurisdication over payment disputes. Two days later, after a nationwide work stoppage and pressure for repudiation of all debt payments, a higher court stripped Judge Pinto Kramer of jurisdiction in the case and set Mr. Gonzalez del Solar free.

title: SPAIN'S ABORTION LAW FACES COURT CHALLENGE
description: Parliament's vote this week to liberalize an antiabortion law has been greeted, as expected, with opposition by the Roman Catholic Church. The left has criticized the law for not going far enough.

title: SENATORIAL COURTESY: WHAT ARE ITS LIMITS?
description: TRENTON ''SENATORIAL COURTESY'' is one of those phrases whose words belie its real intent. It describes an unwritten rule of the State Senate that allows a home-county Senator to block gubernatorial appointments indefinitely without having to give a reason. If the Senator does not ''sign off'' on someone the Governor has nominated to a state post, the potential appointee is blackballed and may never know why.

title: Giants to See 7-Back Defense
description: When the Giants play the Philadelphia Eagles at 4 P.M. Sunday at Giants Stadium, the Eagles may sometimes line up in a defense used by no other team in the National Football League.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: NORTHERN (''BALTIMORE'') ORIOLE Icterus galbula

title: Barbara Grossman Wed To Andrew M. Clearfield
description: Barbara Ruth Grossman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Grossman of New York, was married yesterday to Andrew Mark Clearfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon E. Clearfield of Greensburg, Pa. Rabbi David Posner of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: MICHAEL CAINE: OUTTAKES
description: Michael Caine spent his time in Tarrytown in much the same manner as other guests except, perhaps, that he ate somewhat less than most as he continued to watch his weight. He has lost 30 pounds - in six weeks - since filming the current film ''Educating Rita,'' in which he portrays a paunchy professor who likes his Scotch whisky. In an interview in the basement barrooms of the 19th- century Biddle House, Mr. Caine spoke of England and Westchester, of investments and weight, of cooking and career. Following are excerpts:

title: CALIFORNIA'S TRUE WILD SIDE
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL is a novelist who lives in Honolulu. His latest book, ''Poker Game,'' has just been published by Doubleday.

title: I LOVE NEW YORK AND L.A. TOO
Miss Cunningham Wed To a Graduate Student
description: Katharine Hobart Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis de Lancey Cunningham Jr. of New York, and Daniel Robert Darst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Steinberg of Wilton, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Kenneth A. Gorsuch of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church and Rabbi Bernard Schachtel, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: SUBDUED DODGERS LAUD THE PHILLIES' GRIT
description: The Dodger clubhouse was a subdued but not a morose place tonight as the team that had never before lost a National League championship series digested its defeat at the hands of the charging Phillies.

title: HEYWARD BROTHERS LEAD PASSAIC ROMP
description: The Heyward brothers, Craig and Nate, made Passaic's 27-0 shutout of Bloomfield a family affair yesterday in Passaic.

title: Ferraro Looks Ahead
description: The baseball record book will show that before Mike Ferraro's short term as manager of the Cleveland Indians ended with his dismissal on July 31, his team had a 40-60 record in the American League Eastern Division. But losing has not dampened Ferraro's enthusiasm for the game.

title: Judge vs. Justice
description: If it were as organized as the people it's supposed to study, the Presidential Commission on Organized Crime, appointed in July, might be investigating gangsters by now.

title: 2 FIGURES IN DRUG RING CASE ARRANGE TO ENTER GUILTY PLEAS
description: Last December, a British lawyer whose clients had included rock singers was arrested at Kennedy International Airport with what Federal agents said was several hundred thousand dollars worth of cocaine that he was smuggling into the United States from Brazil. Two weeks later, a woman was arrested at the airport with heroin from India that reportedly had a retail value of $4 million.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Welcome To Splitsville

title: Give-and-take Car Insurance
description: New Jersey's motorists will finally be able to save some money on their ''no fault'' auto insurance premiums, provided they are willing to shoulder some new responsibilities. After months of wrangling over details, the State Senate last week agreed on a package of bills reforming the state's 10-year-old auto insurance system.

title: Passes for '84 World's Fair
description: Season passes to the 1984 World's Fair go on sale Nov. 1 at $90 each.

title: OPERA TO PRESENT 'SOUTH PACIFIC'
description: GEORGE D. OSBORNE will take a new tack when the Connecticut Opera opens its 1983-84 season Thursday at Hartford's Bushnell Memorial Hall.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, Jay Coleman, president of Rockbill Inc., a company that specializes in putting corporate sponsors together with rock groups, was misquoted in ''Rock Puts on a Three-Piece Suit'' Oct. 2. He said, ''1979 was the first year that record sales did not increase.''

title: THE CHINESE NOSTALGIA FOR A 'PEOPLE'S WAR' IS FADING
description: For years, Chinese defense strategy revolved around the late Chairman Mao's dictum of a victorious ''people's war.'' By such logic, even well-armed aggressors were no match for a guerrilla fighter whose heart was ideologically pure. The notion had some basis in the long civil war that swept the Communists to power in 1949, but it has since been overtaken by modern realities like the deployment of Soviet nuclear missiles along China's northern border.

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1983
description: International

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: It may be mere coincidence that makes 1983-4 a Britten opera season in New York, but chance has a way of attesting to genuine trends. This season alone we shall hear both ''Peter Grimes'' and ''Billy Budd'' at the Metropolitan Opera, and then in June London's English National Opera, playing at the Met, will bring us ''Gloriana.''

title: WINTER IN ITS PLACE
description: Peter Viertel's most recent novel is ''American Skin,'' forthcoming from Houghton Mifflin. By PETER VIERTEL

title: DOWN HOME IN ACADIA
description: Roy Reed, a former Times correspondent, is a writer who lives in Arkansas.

title: French Hold Armenians In Orly Airport Bombing
description: The French police have arrested six Armenians here and a seventh in Marseilles on suspicion that they were involved in the July bombing that killed eight people at Orly Airport, police sources said today.

title: LABOR GIVES MONDALE ALL THAT IT'S GOT
description: Delegates of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. climaxed their bi-annual convention in Florida last week on a rousing note, making their first preprimary Presidential endorsement. But they remained troubled by declining membership, high unemployment and the annoying difficulties of organizing workers in new white-collar service industries, which continue to grow while the blue- collar workforce in smokestack industries shrinks.

title: COLLEGE IN KANSAS IS GUARANTEEING JOB OFFERS
description: When Dee Ann Smith finishes her secretarial studies at Brown Mackie College in Salina, Kan., in May and tests the job market, college administrators will have money riding on her success.

title: MYSTERY AT AN INTERSECTION
description: SINCE moving to Connecticut six years ago, I have been troubled by a traffic regulator that seems to me to do more harm than good.

title: Diane M. McCabe Is Married in Rye
description: Diane M. McCabe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. J. McCabe of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Brandon Reid, son of Mrs. Bruce B. Grynbaum of New York and Whitelaw Reid of Purchase, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald W. Poole at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: The Shea Problem
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Spain Reinforces the Guard At Its Embassy in Costa Rica
description: Spanish antiterrorist policemen have been flown to Costa Rica to reinforce the guard at Spain's Embassy in San Jose, the capital, official sources said today.

title: ARMS AND THE MAN
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's policy toward the Soviet Union is becoming highly pragmatic, seriously confused or heavily political, depending on who is doing the explaining.

title: No Headline
description: I Love New York And L.A., Too

title: CONDO PROJECT AT A STANDSTILL
description: THE future of Harbour Landing, New Haven's first seaside luxury condominium, hangs in limbo as city officials debate whether a tax abatement should be granted there.

title: ADVICE FOR HOMEOWNERS ON 'SAFE' TREES
description: AT 5 A.M. in the Sunday quiet of Aug. 7, a 90-foot oak tree on Brite Avenue in Scarsdale fell without warning. Standing about 20 feet inside the property line of one homeowner, the tree came tumbling down on the garage roof of the neighbor next door, causing more than $2,000 in damage and scaring nearby residents, some of whom said they had rushed outside to see if a plane had crashed.

title: Miss Lawrence, Architect, Weds
description: Roberta Dianne Lawrence, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Lawrence of New Haven, was married yesterday to Brian Donald Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Moore of Houston. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Lee M. Langstaff To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Kennedy Langstaff of Stamford and Mystic, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lee Meredith Langstaff, to Peter Stephen Bowe, son of Millia M. Bowe of Stratford, Conn., and the late Francis P. Bowe.

title: YELLOWSTONE: FIRE AND ICE
description: The first hard snow usually comes to Yellowstone in October, and by Thanksgiving most of the mountain passes and the roads into the interior have been surrendered to winter. As the snow deepens in the high country, the park's thick herds of bison and elk begin to cluster in the lower valleys that are their winter range. The animals stand out sharply against the white landscape, their shaggy flanks flecked with snow, as they push through belly-deep drifts in search of forage.

title: TRUE OR FALSE? THIS IS PARTY REFORM
description: SOME myths live on. Ask yourself: Which political party stands for legislative reform in Connecticut? Or election reform? This answer might surprise you.

title: Revolution in Nicarague
description: Stephen Kinzer does well in highlighting the excesses of the Sandinista directorate, although by no means does it rank with the worst of Central America's regimes (''Nicaragua: The Beleaguered Revolution,'' Aug. 28). Indisputably, Managua has sharply curtailed press freedom, and its hedging on a fixed election date gives credence to the domestic opposition's fears that the Sandinistas will not permit a democratic political opening.

title: College Integration Plans Approved for 3 States
description: The Department of Education has approved amended college desegregation plans submitted by Arkansas, Oklahoma and Georgia.

title: WORKING IN A RELIGIOUS SETTING
description: ALTHOUGH the corporate art collector has largely assumed the patronage role once held by religious institutions, commissions are occasionally granted that call attention to the church and synagogue as potential clients for artists.

title: Soviet, Silent on Prize, Again Assails Walesa
description: The Soviet newspaper Izvestia described Lech Walesa today as a money-grubbing, foul-mouthed demagogue, without mentioning his Nobel Peace Prize.

title: THE CORPORATE ASSAULT ON WAGES
description: TROUBLED American corporations, beset by deregulation and imports, are stepping up their campaign for labor concessions and their efforts are paying off.

title: SCHOOLS TIGHTENING SPORTS REGULATIONS
description: PROMPTED by the death of a Yonkers, N.Y., High School student in a football game on Sept. 24, officials of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association are planning to reinforce the rules for those taking part in competitive high school sports.

title: Averill Babson, Writer, Is Bride
description: Averill Babson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Babson of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Gregory E. Sohns, son of Dr. Ernest R. Sohns of McLean, Va. Justice of the Peace Frederick Goodridge performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: FUCHSBERG FAULTS SCHOOL FINANCING
description: Jacob Fuchsberg, a former member of the State Court of Appeals, told Assembly leaders this week that New York State's system of financing public education must be overhauled if education is to be a weapon against social ills.

title: PITT STUNS FLORIDA STATE, 17-16
description: John Congemi lofted a 20-yard scoring pass to the freshman Chuck Scales on the first play of the fourth quarter as Pitt, rallying from a 13-point deficit, edged Florida State, 17-16, today.

title: ONE WAY TO MAKE HOUSING AFFORDABLE
description: MOBILE HOMES are making their appearance in the far suburban reaches of Manalapan, in Monmouth County, N.J. But they are not in a mobile- home ''park,'' they are not easily mobile and there is a question whether they should be called mobile homes.

title: LEADERS OF FARM PROTEST TRY TO HEAD OFF VIOLENCE
description: About 60 angry farmers, who had tried to protest a farm foreclosure by occupying a bank, stood around in the sun on the main street of Stockton, Kan., the other morning. The farmers, from several surrounding counties and states, broke up into several discussions on where their region's protest movement should direct its attentions now.

title:
GARDENING;
WATERING LESSONS LEARNED IN THE WEST
description: ONE has only to see the deserts of the Southwest to gain insight into the importance of water to the survival of plants. Only where irrigation water is abundant are crops grown and landscapes verdant.

title: TOP MOSLEMS ISSUE A WARNING TO MARCOS
description: A group of prominent Filipino Moslems warned President Ferdinand E. Marcos today to heed calls for national reconciliation or risk a revival of Moslem separatism in the Philippines.

title: DAILY NEWS SHOWS SIGNS OF A RETURN TO PROSPERITY
description: The Daily News says it has begun to recover from the problems that brought it to the verge of collapse a year ago.

title: RAY EBERLE SINGS FOR HIS DAUGHTER
description: HAMILTON SQUARE AVISIT to the home of Dennis and Jan Eberle Gordon here is a trip down memory lane. Photographs of Ray Eberle, Mrs. Gordon's father and lead vocalist with the Glenn Miller Orchestra from 1938 to 1942, line the basement walls and, through the loudspeakers, Mr. Eberle still croons:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SADDLE RIVER
description: RESIDENTS of Saddle River, N.J., don't mind saying that theirs is a dull little town. They note that there are no movie theaters or places to buy a beer or anything of that sort. Mayor Duncan Cameron says, only partly in jest, that the greatest excitement in town may be filling bird feeders.

title: TEvery Little Bit Helps
description: Call it the case of the missed conversion. August Martin and Bayside matched each other on offense and defense. Each team monopolized the quarter when it scored a touchdown, and passed about as often as it rushed. But Bayside converted all its extra points and pulled off a 16-14 victory, as August Martin missed a key 2-point conversion in the second quarter.

title: EXECUTIVE CAMPAIGN HEATS UP IN SUFFOLK
description: IN the race for Suffolk County Executive, if you want a man who is opposed to the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, who has distanced himself from the Island's business establishment and gained the support of the area's strongest unions, you will have to vote Republican.

title: DEER HERDS IN STATE INCREASE RAPIDLLY
description: WHEN the first colonists arrived in Connecticut, the white-tailed deer was abundant in the hardwood forests that made up most of the land here. But by the 1700's, because of commercial hunting, a sighting of one of the graceful creatures was uncommon.

title: PERVASIVE POLLUTANT IS TESTED
description: TRENTON THE state's Department of Environmental Protection is expected to recommend soon regulations covering a seldom-heard-of but potent carcinogen.

title: VIVE LA BAGUETTE: AS FRENCH AS PARIS
description: Does it still exist, the great, slender French baguette, with its crackling crisp, golden exterior, its elastic and creamy interior, its flavor of fresh-milled wheat, the bread that's carried naked through the narrow streets of France from daylight until dusk?

title: Disney's World
description: To the Business Editor:

title: THOUSAND BID GOODBYE TO CARDINAL
description: Yesterday, for the second time in her life, Mary Adipietro, a dressmaker, made a pilgrimage from her home in the Bronx to St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: THE JEWS OF FRANCE
description: Day was fading in the Bois de Boulogne, but the lights that shine out at this hour from the windows of the Pavillon Dauphine were obscured by heavy velvet curtains. The curtains were drawn, explained a policeman in the driveway, to protect the diners from flying glass. The guests, as they arrived, were observed closely from two police cars. Once inside, they were met not by the ma^itre d'h^otel but by burly youths wearing yarmulkes and carrying black rubber truncheons. The leaders of the Jewish community of Paris were holding their Passover seder. The precautions against attack were, by now, routine.

title: REAGAN SEEMS READY TO RUN IN A POSTURE OF DETACHMENT
description: RONALD REAGAN is approaching his presumed campaign for a second term with the same detachment and coyness that has characterized so much of his Presidency. His aides proceed on the assumption that he will run. He remains in the background, a professed noncandidate. Last week, Mr. Reagan's political advisers disclosed that he had quietly given ''acquiescence and acceptance'' to the formation of a re-election committee later this month. But there were many other signs that a ''re-election mode,'' as one official put it, had descended on the White House.

title:
DINING OUT;
BROAD-RANGING 'AMERICANA'
description: FLIMSY though it may be, there is a bit of history attached to the site of Fife and Drum Restaurant. The spot, the menu cover informs us, once held a church that during the Revolutionary War served as a hospital at various times for British Redcoats and Continental soldiers. The small adjoining cemetery dates to the early 18th century.

title: Fouts's Wrist Broken
description: The wrist that Dan Fouts, the San Diego Charger quarterback, was supposed to have sprained two weeks ago, is actually broken, but it probably won't keep the right-handed quarterback out of today's game against the Seattle Seahawks.

title: ; THE LOYALTY QUESTION
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OWNERSHIP SHIFT SOUGHT BY BANKS
description: Savings banks across New York State are asking their customers and employees to vote for an amendment to the State Constitution that would allow the banks to convert to stock ownership.

title: SEASON OPENER
description: Andre Watts, the pianist, will open the Unity Concerts 1983-84 season next Sunday afternoon with a recital at Montclair High School.

title: TWO PORTRAITS WHO ARE UNITED IN THEIR PESSIMISM
description: Annie Leibovitz's celebrity portraits are not the kind of images one expects to find at a blue- chip art gallery like Sidney Janis, but surprise is one of their virtues. They are photographs that achieve their power over us not so much by what they are, as objects to be looked at on their own merits, but by what (and whom) they show us - Mick Jagger of the band The Rolling Stones, Sylvester Stallone of the movie ''Rocky,'' Dan Ackroyd and John Belushi of the TV show ''Saturday Night Live.'' Miss Leibovitz's preoccupation is with popular culture, not fine art; what her photographs are about has to do with life in the fast lane, not in the garret.

title: Elaine P. Claar, Financial Aide, Wed in Virginia
description: Elaine Pritchard Claar, daughter of Catherine Houseal Sisson of Charlottesville, Va., and the late E. Alan Claar Jr. of Chicago, was married yesterday to Ray Worthy Campbell, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Malcolm Campbell of Johnson City, Tenn. The Rev. Ramsey Richardson performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville.

title: TWO REALISTS FROM CHICAGO
description: THE DEVIL'S STOCKING by Nelson Algren 308 pp. New York: The Arbor House Library of Contemporary Americana Cloth, $16.95. Paper $9.95 SAM HOLMAN by James T. Farrell. 276 pp. Buffalo: Prometheus Books $15.95

title: Affront to Dignity
description: For Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, living in exile in Gorky is tough enough without having her ''honor and dignity'' affronted.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE ENDURING APPEAL OF SAMPLERS
description: SAMPLERS have an enduring appeal. As with other types of miniaturizations, design elements in a sampler are essays on refinement in a confined space.

title: ; CONDITIONING ATHLETES' MINDS --
description: Emily Greenspan quotes Dr. Bruce Ogilvie as getting ''out of the use of hypnosis 20 years ago, because several athletes kept coming back to me for another fix.'' While I respect Dr. Ogilvie for not wanting athletes to create a dependency on him, hypnosis can be extremely useful.

title: ROMAN COINAGE
description: OXFORD LATIN DICTIONARY

title: Wenda L. Harris Becomes a Bride
description: Wenda Leigh Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Harris of Lynnfield, Mass., was married yesterday to William John Millard 3d, son of Mrs. Emmalie Wright Millard of Austin, Tex., and Dr. Millard Jr., of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. Stanley Dransfield performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York City.

title: Explaining Why Couples Part
description: Two of every three couples who marry this year will split up, demographers say. And yet Dr. Pepper Schwartz, a sociologist at the University of Washington in Seattle, says, ''It is the fondest wish of most people, heterosexuals and homosexuals, to be a couple.''

title: MENTAL CARE POLICY WORRIES EDUCATORS
description: A NEW state policy requiring public schools for pay for some students' psychiatric care is causing concern and confusion among local school officials and state officials because no one seems to know how much money it will entail, according to Deputy Education Commissioner Lorraine M. Aronson.

title: BRADLEY INTRODUCES BILL TO RAISE FEDERAL FUNDS
description: Advocates of programs for gifted and talented children have received welcome help from Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of Denville, who has introduced a bill to increase Federal financing for exceptional students.

title: For Investors, Precious Little
description: More than 30,000 people who thought they had bought gold, silver and platinum from Bullion Reserve of North America may have to prospect for it in court. Officials of the company, whose chairman committed suicide 11 days ago, filed a bankruptcy petition last week, saying nearly all of $60 million in bullion supposedly stored in an underground depository in Utah was missing.

title: Congress' Perks
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Holy Cross Stays Unbeaten
description: A reserve quarterback, Tom Heffernan, threw a 20-yard touchdown pass to Bill Cowley with less than 5 minutes remaining today as undefeated Holy Cross rallied for a 21-18 victory over previously unbeaten Colgate.

title: JAZZ ARTISTS RECALL THEIR SUMMER OF EUROPEAN FESTIVALS
description: An army of jazz musicians, perhaps as many as 400, has begun trickling back home to the U.S.A. after a summer of ''jamming'' the concert stages of jazz festivals throughout Europe, from Pori to Pisa. For three top-ranked stars, Wynton Marsalis, the young trumpeter, the bassist Jaco Pastorius and the guitarist James ''Blood'' Ulmer - each of whom toured separately - managing itineraries was a test of endurance. In Mr. Ulmer's words: ''It was a race from plane to plane with stops in between just long enough to wolf down a meal, say hello to a friend and snatch a few winks before hitting the road.''

title: Danise Amoruso Wed To Mark Joseph Riley
description: Danise Anne Amoruso, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick F. Amoruso of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Joseph Riley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Riley of Binghamton, N.Y. Msgr. John J. Wiest performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: MAMET TURNS TO THE WORLD OF SALESMEN
description: Michael Billington writes frequently about theater in Britain. LONDON

title: SAN QUENTIN CALLED ON EDGE WITH THE ILLS OF OVERCROWDING
description: Behind the walls of San Quentin Prison, barbells lie rusting in the exercise yard and weeds sprout near a ball field.

title: Hofstra Beats Wagner, 19-0
description: Rich Codella, a sophomore quarterback, threw two touchdown passes of 4 yards each in the first half to lead undefeated Hofstra to its fifth victory, 19-0, over Wagner yesterday at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, L.I.

title: LACK OF RAIN HURTS FALL FOLIAGE SHOW
description: THE fall foliage show will go on again this year, but a little earlier than usual and with colors something less than breathtaking.

title: FAIRWAY HOMES
description: Behind a masonry gateway in Florham Park, a few miles east of Morristown, clusters of town houses hug the rolling countryside of New Jersey's Morris County, overlooking the Braidburn Country Club and a 12-acre lake.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: CREW RECRUITS ALL FRESHMEN TO LEARN HOW TO PULL FOR YALE
description: Incoming Yale freshmen received recruiting letters from a variety of campus organizations last summer - clubs, student publications, religious groups - and one sports team: the crew.

title: THE INNS OF WINTER
description: I generally come to Ludlow, a small market town in the English county of Shropshire, after a long hard drive over the moorlands from my home in Wales. It seems to me then the perfect haven, so snug upon its hill, architecturally so elegant, with a church and a castle to look after it and a sweet river winding below: and in no time I am esconced beside the fire in the bar of the Feathers Hotel, which is all Ludlow distilled into one warm, grand and ancient hostelry.

title: COSTS FORCE OMAHA PAPER INTO CLOSING
description: The Omaha Sun, a weekly newspaper that at its peak reached about 50,000 homes in the city, has printed its final issue.

title: REMEMBERED GESTURES
description: David Bromwich teaches English at Princeton University. His book, ''Hazlitt: The Mind of a Critic,'' will be published in January. SUMMER CELESTIAL

title: D. P. Rosendale, Ellin Dixon Wed
description: Edith Eleanor Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Eugene Dixon Jr. of Philadelphia and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Donald P. Rosendale, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Rosendale of Cradock, Va. The Rev. James Trimble, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, assisted by the Rev. Richard La Hart, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FILMMAKERS ON FILMMAKING

title: Lucinda Herrick, J. A. G. Strothe Exchange Vows
description: Lucinda Jackson Herrick, daughter of Daniel Herrick of New York and Edith B. Herrick of Princeton, N.J., and Browington, Vt., was married yesterday to J. A. Gunther Strothe, son of Franz Strothe of Erkelenz- Holzweiler, West Germany, and the late Mrs. Strothe. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: FRANCE REPORTED TO SEND FIGHTERS TO IRAQ AIR FORCE
description: France was reported today to have started delivery to Iraq of jet fighters that the United States and other Western countries believe may increase the dangers of the Iran-Iraq war.

title: VILLAGE AND STORE JOIN IN JOB PROJECT
description: A TINY North Fork village and a 55-year-old family-operated department store have qualified for the first Federal loan granted in Suffolk County to create jobs in an economically depressed area.

title: WHAT IS NEEDED TO ATTAIN HARMONY OVER NOISE AT THE AIRPORT
description: THE 22-month-old mandatory curfew at the County Airport is dead. On Aug. 24 the Federal District Court found that the Federal Aviation Administration has ultimate control of navigable airspace and aircraft noise. And the county government had the first indication that it had lost local control of its airport.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant; Anglers Split on Bass Issue
description: AS concern over dwindling stocks of East Coast striped bass intensifies, so does the tension between recreational and commercial fishermen.

title: 'GIVE ME ONE MORE RIDE'
description: THERE was a time, in the not too distant past, that the black dress hanging in my closet, worn in concert with the delicate strand of pearls, was a symbol of smart sophistication. Unfortunately, I have now reached the age when it ceases to represent gaiety and has become, instead, a symbol of my own mortality.

title: NATURALIST LOOKS AHEAD AT 80
description: JUST about everyone can point to an accomplishment or two in life, and John K. Terres is no exception. Not only is he the author of the million-word Audubon Society Encyclopedia of North American Birds, a book that took 21 years to write, but he also has two other books in the works.

title: REVUE ON COWARD IN 5 ACTS
description: SAY for Marc Alexander, who ''devised and directed'' ''A Talent to Amuse,'' which is billed as ''an evening of N"oel Coward exclusively,'' that he has opted for accessibility at the expense of distinctiveness and, it turns out, distinction. In this songfest, the master of urbanity comes off as a composer for the masses.

title: CHRISTINE A. ALEXANDER ENGAGED TO A PHYSICIAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Alexander of North Bellmore, L.I., and St. Croix, V.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Ann Alexander, to Dr. Norman A. Ernst Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst of Garden City, L.I., and New York.

title: ESSEX SUPERMARKET HAS NEW ATTRACTION FOR SHOPPERS: COOKING SCHOOL
description: SHORT HILLS SHOPPERS who look up from the shelves at a supermarket here can see their neighbors hard at work kneading dough, concocting sauces and putting the finishes touches on gourmet meals.

title: CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL, 2-DOOR AUTOS LISTED AS WORST IN STUDY OF SAFETY
description: Small, two-door automobiles, many of them Japanese imports, have the worst accident records while station wagons, even compact models, have performed most safely, according to a study by the insurance industry.

title: LET THE MARKET CALL THE SHOTS
description: The New York banking community recognizes that some revamping of the Federal Government's regulatory structure is in order. A major question, however, is at what point in our evolution from a closely regulated industry to a relatively deregulated industry should changes be made.

title: ANTINUCLEAR MEASURE IS AIMED AT MISSILE DESIGNER
description: Voters here will decide next month whether conducting nuclear weapons research in the city limits is a crime. Unlike similar measures adopted by other towns and cities around the country, this one has a specific target, a designer of missile guidance systems for the Pentagon.

title: Lucinda Anthony Marries
description: Lucinda Haines Anthony, daughter of Mrs. Frank Benton Anthony of Xenia, Ohio, and the late Mr. Anthony, was married yesterday to Philip Baldwin Kimball, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kimball of Walpole, N.H. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York. The bride is director of communications for Thorne E.M.I. Video there. Mr. Kimball is vice president of C. R. Cushing & Company, naval architects and marine transportation consultants.

title: Sushi
description: To the Editor:

title: AGING: TIMELESS ESTATE, NOT TERINAL ILLNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: MONTAUK LIGHT DIMMING?
description: ON a crystal-clear day, from the top of the Montauk Light, one can see past Block Island, R.I., to Martha's Vineyard, Mass., in the most dramatic view on Long Island. The 1797 lighthouse, which George Washington predicted would stand for 200 years, has nearly done so, but it is threatened by two time-tested factors - erosion and automation, both of which are contributing to the disappearance of these historic maritime towers.

title: NAVAJO WEAVINGS ARE CHOICE COLLECTORS ITEMS
description: They dazzle the eye, delight most who see them and command top prices in galleries and at auctions of American Indian art. These are what are called ''eye-dazzlers,'' the visually arresting blankets and rugs woven by Navajo women between 1870 and 1920 that are regarded as the precursors of the Op Art paintings of the 1960's. Explosive in their colors and dynamic in their designs, these weavings date to the period when aniline dyes transformed blankets into color-pulsing designs devised by the most skilled of the Navajo artisans.

title: CONSUMER RATES
LUDLOWE DEFEATS NEIGHBOR WARDE
description: In Fairfield, many players for Ludlowe and Andrew Warde are friends - the schools are just three miles apart. But yesterday the Flying Tigers and the Crimson Eagles met to play football and it was a game of rivals.

title: A PASSION FOR ART AND MOTHER
description: MARBOT

title: Ann Durie Leidner Is Wed To William U. Westerfield
description: Ann Durie Leidner, daughter of Mrs. Leonard Thomas Titus of Freehold, N.J., and the late Albert Eugene Durie of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to William Underwood Westerfield, son of the late Millicent Underwood and William Westerfield, both of Patchogue, L.I. Municipal Court Judge Lawrence A. Carton 3d of Middletown, N.J., performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Rumson, N.J.

title: KISSINGER'S PANEL TO LEAVE ON TRIP
description: The members of President Reagan's commission on Central America are scheduled to fly to Panama on Sunday to start a six-day, six-nation mission that will include talks with Government leaders but not rebels in El Salvador and Nicaragua.

title: FLORIDIANA . . .
description: Artists and writers have their own Floridas. Alison Lurie chooses Key West, at once an old-fashioned small town and a setting for lively street theater. For Roger Tory Peterson, Florida means Sanibel Island, where bald eagles soar overhead. James Rosenquist's Florida is a remote bay on the Gulf Coast where the intensity of the sunlight has caught his painter's eye. The Sophisticated Traveler asked a dozen part-time Floridians to write about the areas they know best; their insights illumine special worlds that may elude the casual visitor. BY ALISON LURIE

title: Federal Patrons of the Arts
description: The Reagan Administration cut Federal money for the arts and humanities sharply after taking office in 1981. Last week, Congress took action to put some of it back again.

title: Life and Death In Medicine and Law
description: Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City, has called to our attention a Department of Health and Human Services regulation requiring federally financed health-care facilities to post, at the nurses' station of each maternity, pediatric and intensive-care ward, a notice that failure to provide food and care to handicapped infants is prohibited by law and will include a ''hot line'' number for reporting violations.

title: CO-OP CONVERSIONS CREATE NEW SPECIALTY AMONG LAWYERS
description: BECAUSE of the boom in the conversion of rental apartments to cooperatives, a new legal specialty has developed in which certain lawyers now concentrate on negotiating reserve funds, wraparound mortgages and financing terms for landlords and tenant groups.

title:
ART;
HOBOKEN GALLERIES WALK A THIN LINE
description: LOOKING back over a decade of change, a commercial art gallery was bound to open on Washington Street, the main business district in this city that many have billed as a burgeoning artists' enclave.

title: A DANCER ADDS WORDS TO THE SOLO TRADITIONN
description: The solo dance recital is one of the riskiest forms of entertainment for the performer. To succeed, it requires a stage presence strong enough to captivate - or at least interest - an audience throughout an entire evening. Despite the hazards, evenings of solo dance have been surprisingly popular with modern dancers from Isadora Duncan, Ruth St. Denis and Martha Graham on. Following in that tradition, on Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week, will be Bertram Ross, for nearly 20 years a principal dancer with the Martha Graham Dance Company. Mr. Ross, who left Miss Graham in 1973, will present a program of five solo dance ''portraits'' at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Mr. Ross's portraits are idiosyncratic hybrids of speech and dance, a form he feels he invented himself. He recites a text while performing dances of his own invention. Sometimes there is music, sometimes not.

title: M.T.A. EXPECTS TO RAISE FARES BY END OF YEAR
description: Fares on New York City's subways and buses and on commuter rail lines run by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will have to be raised by the end of the year, according to Richard Ravitch, the M.T.A. chairman.

title: Djuna Barnes
description: To the Editor:

title: Joint Film Series Begins on Oct. 18
description: Your article about noncommercial film series (''Noncommercial Film Series Roll Again,'' Sept. 18) did not include the Joint Film Series. This is the 14th year for this series, which is sponsored jointly by the Friends of the Larchmont and Mamaroneck Libraries.

title: TELEPHONE DEVICE TRACKS TRUANTS
description: IF Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer

title: A PLACE WITH TWO PERSONALITIES
description: LA GALLERIA in Westbury is a restaurant with a split personality. Its mood swing makes it more appealing on weekdays. On weekend evenings, not only the service but also the food and the very atmosphere suffer from the crush of a capacity crowd.

title: DEVILS TRIUMPH OVER DETROIT, 6-3
description: The Devils spoiled the debut in this city of Eddie Mio, Ron Duguay and Eddie Johnstone, three popular members of the Rangers last season, with a 6-3 victory over the Red Wings tonight.

title: MITTERRAND'S GLOBAL ROLE TROUBLES HIS SUPPORTERS
description: The Frenchman who voted Socialist in May 1981 thinking that with Francois Mitterrand he was striking a blow against interventionism, neo-colonialism, and militarism got this: French troops in Chad and Lebanon, the first Atlantic alliance meeting in Paris in 17 years, a French signature on the bottom of President Reagan's Williamsburg declaration on global security, and full Socialist embrace of NATO's projected missile deployment.
