The list skips over arms deals, support for African autocrats, business with South Africa and yesterday's report that France had sent to Iraq five Super-Etendard fighters able to fire Exocet missiles.

title: J. M. Read Wed To Molly Sexton
description: Molly Sexton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Sexton of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to J. Miles Read, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Read of Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. James Hinchey performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral Basilica of St. James in Brooklyn.

title: A SOVIET GENERAL IS SAID TO DEFECT IN TURKEY
description: A Soviet general has crossed into Turkey and defected to the West, it was reported here today. The report could not be confirmed.

title: MUSIC: CONSTRUCTIVISM AT THE KITCHEN
description: The latest installment in the rash of early modernist performance reconstructions seen recently in New York arrived at the Kitchen on Thursday, with the first of two programs devoted to ''Constructivist Music and Performance.'' This first program, of music by Nikolai Roslavetz and performance works by Nikolai Foregger, will receive its final showing tonight at 8:30; the second program, with music by Alexander Mossolov and theater by Vsevolod Meyerhold, runs from Thursday through next Sunday nights.

title: AGING: TIMELESS ESTATE, NOT TERMINAL ILLNESS
description: While correctly observing the fate of today's elderly, Jack Levin and Arnold Arluke failed to include what may well be the most important reason for the conditions they deplore: the virtual non-existence today of the extended family.

title: Infrastructure Help Is Needed Now
description: The article ''Data on Every Town Sought by Governor's Panel'' (Sept. 25) overlooks a major point concerning Connecticut's crumbling infrastructure - that municipal roads, bridges, dams, sewers, etc. require immediate attention, and that needed help from the state government may not be provided in time to avert further disasters.

title: Funeral Held for Officer Slain on Traffic Stop
description: Law officers from at least six states were among 1,200 mourners today at the funeral of Leon Bench, an Oklahoma trooper who was slain while making a traffic stop.

title: COMBINATION MAGIC
description: ''It's all done with mirrors.''

title: FAILING MATH AND LIFE
description: FLIGHTS

title: Policeman Turned Producer
description: Starting out as a rookie in New York City's 25th precinct, Sonny Grosso eventually worked his way into the Narcotics Bureau. There, with Eddie Egan, he broke the ''French Connection'' case, resulting in one of the largest heroin seizures in history. Since retiring from the force in 1976, Mr. Grosso has written two books, acted as technical advisor to Francis Ford Coppola on ''The Godfather'' and, most recently, set up his own company, Grosso- Jacobson Productions, which produces movies, series and mini-series for network and cable television.

title: ENDING WAR BEFORE IT STARTS
description: NUCLEAR WAR, NUCLEAR PEACE By Loen Wieseltier. 109 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Holt, Rinehart & Winston. Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $2.95.THE COMMAND AND CONTROL OF NUCLEAR FORCES By Paul Bracken. 252 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: An L.I. Man Is Seized In Killing of a Lawyer
description: An unemployed Sea Cliff man has been arrested and charged with second-degree murder and first-degree robbery in the beating and stabbing death of a Long Island lawyer.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: QUARTET'S MILESTONE

title: King Crab Gets a Breather
description: The Alaskan king crab may be going the way of the passenger pigeon. After discovering a disastrous decline in the species, which is found only along the Aleutian coastline, the Alaska Department of Fish and Game last month ordered a total shutdown of king crab fisheries.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GOING, GOING . . .

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A DAY IN THE COUNTRY
description: ''EXCUSE me, where's Route 124?'' the driver of one car asked a passenger in another as both vehicles inched up to a stop sign not far from Route 684.

title: AFLOAT, BUT NOT AT SEA
description: JOHN D. MacDONALD is the author of the Travis McGee novels, of which the most recent is ''Cinnamon Skin'' (Harper); he has also published, with Capt. John Kilpack, a book about a long cruise, ''Nothing Can Go Wrong'' (Harper). By JOHN D. MacDONALD

title: MUSIC ABOUNDS AT THE MET MUSEUM
description: Apparently discontent with being merely the largest repository of priceless paintings, drawings and sculptures in New York, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has made a concerted effort to delight the ear as well as the eye. And, since 1968, the responsibility for programming and producing the museum's series of concerts and lectures has rested in the hands of a vivacious, dark-haired woman named Hilde Limondjian.

title: CLASSIC TYROL
description: James Salter's novels include ''A Sport and a Pastime'' (Penguin) and ''Light Years'' (Northpoint Press). By James Salter

title: Marxist Dialectic?
description: To the Editor:

title: SCALLOPERS FIND SLIM PICKINGS
description: THE Peconic Bay scallop is back in season on the Island, but, since the state waters opened last month, scallopers towing their steel-tooth dredges through the quiet coves and shallow bays from Flanders to Shelter Island have been hauling up more bay grass and old shells than mature scallops.

title: Inquiry for Texas Prisons
description: The Texas Department of Corrections board ordered a full investigation today into reports of brutality by guards in the prison system and promised more control over operations. The statement was a response to charges in a Federal report that accused state guards of abusing prisoners,

title: NEW PRESSURE FOR POLITICAL RETREAT BY THE MILITARY
description: At a red light, a taxi driver pulled up next to an army colonel who had just cut him off in the heavy downtown traffic. ''Hey, precious,'' the taxi driver called from his window, ''I wouldn't employ you for the little bit that you're worth.''

title: Miss Pollard Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Pollard of Devon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Joan Pollard, to Kurt Parant Metzger, son of Jeanne Metzger of Rumson, N.J., and the late Samuel Metzger 3d. The wedding is to be Feb. 28.

title: A NEW MOVIE BOASTS UNLIKELY STARS - WOLVES
description: Shooting a movie about wolves in the Arctic was asking for a pack of headaches. Weather was often the least of the worries. There were 10 wolves to be trained, including one that had to learn to lift its hind leg on cue as if urinating to mark off its territory. That took two weeks and 57 takes. There was the herd of 500 wild caribou that had to be rounded up on the tundra and then released, along with the wolves, at the right time and in the right direction for the big chase scene. That took a month to bring about.

title: SENATOR WEICKER'S PROPOSAL IS NOT AS GOOD AS IT MAY LOOK
description: IN August, United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced his plan to revamp the Republican Party by abolishing the state convention in favor of a direct primary, and allowing unaffiliated voters to participate in that primary. With one stroke, the Senator created a whirlwind of publicity and gained the support of much of the media.

title: LIVER TRANSPLANTS LIKELY TO INCREASE
description: NEW HAVEN AFTER performing the first liver transplant in the state last week, doctors at Yale- New Haven Hospital say the anticipate an increased demand for the operation from those people who need it and who live in Connecticut and its neighboring states.

title:
GARDENING;
WATERING LESSONS LEARNED IN THE WEST
description: ONE has only to see the deserts of the Southwest to gain insight into the importance of water to the survival of plants. Only where irrigation water is abundant are crops grown and landscapes verdant.

title: EAGLES TROUNCE YALE, 42-7
description: Doug Flutie, the Boston College quarterback, passed for 4 touchdowns and 325 yards today as the Eagles routed Yale, 42-7.

title: Gallup Poll Finds McGovern Third Most Popular in Race
description: Former Senator George McGovern's entry into the contest for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination has attracted enough supporters to make him the third most popular candidate, behind former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Rodgers Picks Chicago
description: Bill Rodgers, who has won the Boston and New York City Marathons, has decided to pass up the New York event on Oct. 23 in favor of running in the America's Marathon/Chicago the week before, according to the director of the Chicago event, Bob Bright. . . . Tony Sandoval, the 1980 United States Olympic Trials marathon winner and the ninth-fastest American marathon runner in history, has entered the New York City Marathon.

title: Lucie L. Kinsolving Is Bride
description: Lucie Lee Kinsolving, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Lee Kinsolving of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Richard Lippincott McElhiney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. McElhiney of Washington. The Rev. Dorsey McConnell performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: CRANBERRY GROWERS MAKING BEST OF FICKLE SEASON
description: ALL YEAR long, the talk in Hog Wallow, Speedwell and other parts of southern New Jersey's cranberry-growing country has been about the weather. First, it was about the extraordinarily wet spring - a dozen rainy weekends in a row that flooded the bogs and promised a bountiful growing season that might even surpass last year's record 295,000-barrel harvest.

title: Jean Tuttle, Teacher, Wed to R. M. Coon Jr.
description: Jean H. Tuttle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin C. Hall of Irving, N.Y., and Mount Dora, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert M. Coon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Coon of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Bronxville.

title: GUERRILLA FIRES IN NICARAGUA PUT THE HEAT ON COSTA RICA
description: THE only thing that ever happens in Costa Rica, it is often said, is Nicaragua. This quiet Central American democracy again feels itself being sucked into the violent struggle for power beyond its northern border.

title: Miss O'Daniel Weds G. D. Morgan 3d
description: Cathleen Ruth O'Daniel and George Dwight Morgan 3d, both vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, were married yesterday by the Rev. William J. Murphy Jr. at the Camp Hill (Pa.) Presbyterian Church

title: Brink's Convicts Get the Maximum
description: Prosecutor Kenneth Gribetz asked that the three radicals convicted of killing two police officers and a Brink's guard in a 1981 armed robbery be ''removed from the streets of society for the balance of their natural lives.'' The Rockland County District Attorney appeared to have gotten what he wanted last week, when all three were sentenced to a minimum of 75 years in prison.

title: THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ANDRE MEYER
description: Financier: The Biography of Andre Meyer, by Cary Reich. William Morrow & Company, N.Y. 396 pages, $15.95.

title: WINTER: LOVE IT OR LEAVE IT
description: ISLAND SUN

title: SKILLFULLY MANGAING A HARD TRANSITION
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, the Archbishop of New York who died of leukemia Thursday, was one of a handful of leading prelates caught in a vast sea change within the Roman Catholic Church. He was among those who were trained for service in a church that in many respects no longer existed when they rose to the hierarchy. To the end of his life, Cardinal Cooke seemed to belong to both the new order and the old.

title: WILL PLAY IN WORLD SERIES
description: The Baltimore Orioles, who for more than 20 years have had one of the most productive minor league systems in baseball, won their sixth American League pennant today with a 3-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox that was sparked by a player they acquired from another team's farm system less than six weeks ago.

title: Alzheimer's Disease Month
description: President Reagan has set aside the month of November as National Alzheimer's Disease month to recognize progress against the disease and the toll it takes on its elderly victims and their families. In a proclamation Monday, the President said Alzheimer's was ''a devastating disease that affects the cells of the brain, and is now recognized as a major form of old age 'senility.' ''

title: ADVICE TO HIGH-TECH MILLIONAIRES
description: Viewers of 1950's television may remember a series called ''The Millionaire.'' In each episode, a never-seen tycoon experiments with human nature by having his assistant, Michael Anthony, hand over a check for $1 million to some unsuspecting individual.

title: CHEATING INVALIDATES MEDICAL EXAM RESULTS
description: Cheating was widespread among foreign medical school graduates who took a test in July to qualify for internships and residencies in the United States, and 10,000 of them will have to take it again, an official says.

title: U.S. Historic District Dedicated at Beale Street
description: Warm fall sunshine, 4,000 celebrants and millions of dollars in public and private funds revived Beale Street today, bringing music back to the ''birthplace of the blues.''

title: BRAZIL FEARFUL OF EXPLOSION OF DISCONTENT
description: Last week, in the midst of a debate over austerity measures that the International Monetary Fund has asked Brazil to adopt, Representative Mario Juruna leaped to his feet in frustration.

title: Port Washington Wins, 27-0
description: Port Washington, in defeating Glen Cove, 27-0, narrowed Glen Cove's advantage in the oldest rivalry in Nassau County. Glen Cove now leads 31- 26-4 in a series that began in 1917 and only recently was revived.

When, for the first time, our son would not be with us for Christmas we lost interest in spending it at home, and ever since then have gone to the Caribbean, though not to stay on islands. Our attachment to the Caribbean is to a way of visiting it; and for us this means by cruising sailboat.

title: CHICAGO'S POLITICAL DISPUTES REMAIN IN COURT
description: As the impasse in the city government here wears on, the factions of the City Council have once again turned to the courts to settle their differences.

title: CUTS FAIL TO FAZE CAMDEN GROUP
description: MEMBERS of the Concerned Citizens of North Camden sat around a table in the group's busy row-house office at 543 State Street here - in the heart of one of the most- depressed neighborhoods in New Jersey's most-depressed city - and talked about the future.

title: Discounting Wars
description: To the Business Editor:

title: RANGERS DEFEAT PENGUINS FOR 3D STRAIGHT
description: Mark Osborne and Jan Erixson scored third- period goals just over a minute apart as the Rangers won their third straight game of the National Hockey League season, beating the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-1, tonight.

title: THE NETWORKS FLIRT WITH SEXUAL EXPLICITNESS
description: Coping with a gradual but fairly steady erosion in their audience numbers, the three commercial networks are clearly nervous these days, alternating between old patterns and increasingly bold forays into formerly forbidden territory of sexual explicitness. They are being noticeably conservative in the area of weekly series, most of which appear to be clones from past successes - more action-adventures featuring offbeat partners, male, female or any combination thereof, or simply outright imitations along the lines of ''Webster,'' plucked from the entrails of ''Diff'rent Strokes,'' and ''We've Got It Made,'' doing an obvious turn on ''Three's Company.'' But then there are the made-for-TV movies, and these are the vehicles through which the networks are increasingly competing with the greater, and occasionally notorious, permissiveness allowed cable television, not to mention video cassettes and disks.

title: TRAIN RIDERS PLEAD AGAINST FARE RISE
description: METRO-NORTH commuters from New Haven and Danbury, complaining about the condition of the passenger rail cars and restrooms, about delays and the loss of lights and air-conditioning, implored state transportation officials last week to improve train service before putting a proposed fare increase into effect.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: JEROME HINES, the basso whose career has set longevity records at the Metropolitan Opera Company, is not noted for his cooking - nor should he be, he says. But when speaking of his wife's culinary abilities, Mr. Hines waxes lyric.

title: Nuclear Plant's Alarm Set Off by Earthquake
description: Friday's earthquake in the Adirondack Mountains triggered a seismic alarm at a nuclear plant on the shores of Lake Ontario, 95 miles away, resulting in a low-level alert, but an adjacent nuclear plant continued operation, unaware of the quake because its alarm was broken.

title: Ohio Concern Pleads Guilty To Overbilling the Air Force
description: The Davey Compressor Company of Cincinnati has pleaded guilty to 25 felony counts of overbilling the Air Force $1,704,429 for spare parts and will pay a total of $3 million in criminal fines and civil damages, the Justice Department has announced.

title: CHANGE, YES-BUT NOT NOW
description: The question of consolidation of bank regulatory agencies is not new, but the Congress should not be asked to resolve this issue under current circumstances with the entire financial system in flux.

title: A Letter Rebutted
description: To the Editor:

title: If It's Friday, It's Managua
description: The Kissinger Commission's numbing itinerary to Central America - six countries in six days - leaves little time for digesting information, let alone food. Nonetheless, it's a useful trip. The whirling voyage of its 12 commissioners contrasts tellingly with the passivity of American diplomacy, which drifts with the same lack of choice and purpose that caused Mr. Reagan to summon the aid of Henry Kissinger in July.

title: GAINS FOR SOUTH KOREAN AUTOS
description: There are any number of economic success stories in South Korea, but the automobile industry is not one of them. At least, not yet.

title: COLLEGIANS' BID TO VOTE BALKED IN WESTCHESTER
description: A registration drive to allow college students to vote at their campus in Purchase instead of in their hometowns has been blocked by a Westchester County elections commissioner.

title: WON 1982 OSCAR NOMINATION
description: Joan Hackett, a respected actress who won critical acclaim throughout her career, died of cancer in Encino Hospital in California on Saturday night. She was 49 years old.

title: Jordan, Case and AC&R Are Given Added Work
description: Two agencies - AC& R Advertising and Jordan, Case & McGrath - were rewarded by clients last week with additional assignments.

title: No Headline
description: DURING the first half, Phil Simms had been standing impatiently on the sideline, his flaxen hair fluttering in the breeze, his hands flipping a football. But in the third quarter, after Scott Brunner had thrown an interception, the chant of the Giant loyalists had erupted: ''We want Simms, we want Simms.'' Moments later they had him. Behind the Giants' bench, Phil Simms had put on his blue helmet and he was warming up. The next time the Giant offensive unit went on the field, Phil Simms trotted with them.

title: Designer at Tiffany Moving to Bergdorf
description: Angela Cummings, one of Tiffany & Company's leading jewelry designers, says she is planning to leave in January and to sell her high-priced designs exclusively through Bergdorf Goodman.

title: ART: AL HIRSCHFELD SHOW
description: The idea that every great university should have its theater collection took a long time to win acceptance. But when it bit, it bit deep. All over the Western world, scholars are poring over prompt books, collating programs, recording oral history and looking for picture material. The university theater collection is here to stay.

title: Regina Still Restrained On Consumer Reports
description: Federal Judge Henry F. Walker of the Southern District of New York on Friday continued the temporary restraining order that prevents the Regina Company of Rahway, N.J., from mentioning Consumer Reports evaluations in TV commercials.

title: COLLEGE ACCESS FOR BLACKS DEBATED AT OBERLIN
description: R. SHIPP

title: SHOOTING BY NEW ORLEANS POLICE SETS OF PROTESTS
description: The shooting by a white police officer of a black policewoman's teen-age son Aug. 31 is evoking protests reminiscent of those following four shootings of blacks by white officers in November 1980.

title: MUSIC: BRITISH FOLK DUO
description: EWAN MacCOLL and Peggy Seeger, the British folk duo who appeared at Town Hall on Friday with their sons Neill and Calum, treat folk music not simply as a valuable collection of antiques but as a spiritual legacy in which everything, ancient and modern, is assumed to be alive and pertinent. Seventeeth-century Scottish ballads sit comfortably alongside contemporary antinuclear songs.

title: Bishop of Des Moines Kidnapped and Released
description: Roman Catholic Bishop Maurice Dingman was kidnapped by two men outside a convenience store and forced to drive around for eight hours before being released early today.

title: Ruling Costs Giants a Score
description: For a while, Frank Marion thought he had a touchdown for the Giants today in their 17-13 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Milwaukee Crime Figure Guilty in Gambling Case
description: Frank P. Balistrieri, described by prosecutors as the city's organized crime boss, was convicted today of five gambling and tax charges but acquitted of five other counts stemming from a sports betting ring.

title: Risque Ad In New Yorker
description: The Paco Rabanne men's cologne advertising campaign has been around since 1980, with all of its playful sexual innuendo, and except for its winning a few advertising awards for Ogilvy & Mather, it has caused little comment.

title: MUSIC: CONFERENCE ON COMPUTER USE
description: The computer can be used to store information, teach children, even help plan a trip to the moon. It can also be an effective tool in the creation of contemporary music, as the 1983 International Computer Music Conference, which took place here this weekend, made clear. The four-day event, ending Monday, brought over 500 people to the Eastman School of Music's Kilbourn Hall.

title: 2 TROUBLED YEARS ON SUBWAYS SEEN BY M.T.A. NOMINEE
description: New York's subway riders can expect two to three years of ''frustration'' as major work on rebuilding the system gets under way, Robert R. Kiley, the chairman-designate of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said today.

title: RESTRAINT, NOT RACE, IS KEY POLICE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Textron Venture With Canadians
description: Textron Inc. has agreed with the Canadian Government and Quebec on a $766 million (Canadian) project to build Canada's first helicopter manufacturing plant.

title: Oakland Teachers Endorse a New Contract
description: Oakland teachers voted heavily tonight in favor of a contract settlement that would give them a 14 percent salary increase over two years and would allow schools to reopen Monday for 49,000 students idled by a four-day strike.

title: BRIEFING
description: Dear Sir: Shut Up

title: CABARET: SPOOF OF 50'S CLUBS
description: THE best thing about ''Nite Club Confidential,'' a musical that cheerfully spoofs the pseudo-sophisticated ambience of the 1950's saloon world, is its deadpan musical humor. Dennis Deal, the director who co-wrote seven of the show's 24 songs, has an acute ear for the sillier pretensions of 50's nightclub music.

title: JET WATCHERS' SPIRITS SOAR AT KENNEDY
description: Swissair Flight 100 from Zurich was a quarter-mile from Kennedy International Airport. As it neared, Myron Shulman lifted his camera and began snapping pictures.

title: ISRAEL MAY AID SHARES OF BANKS
description: Israeli authorities closed the stock exchange today to confer with banking officials in Jerusalem on whether the Government should intervene to help the country's banks from heavy losses after a run on their shares.

title: Police in Jersey Investigate Fatal Shooting by a Trooper
description: The state police are investigating what appears to be the accidental shooting death of a 25-year-old computer repairman by an off-duty trooper who was his cousin, a state police spokesman said.

title: ALL ABOARD FOR RAILROAD SERIES
description: NOW we get to find out whether those Amtrak commercials are telling the truth. All those gleaming red white and blue projectiles spurting along the BosWash Corridor, smiling hosts and hostesses, flowers in glass vases, lots of leg room.

title: BALLET: THE CINCINNATI/NEW ORLEANS CITY TROUPE
description: WHEN the Cincinnati Ballet came to Brooklyn College in 1980, it made a decidedly favorable impression. It did so again on Saturday night when it returned to the college's Whitman Hall. However, it is no longer simply the Cincinnati Ballet.

title: SALVADOR UNIONS ARE UNDER SEIGE
description: United States labor advisers working here have charged that right-wing Salvadoran groups have embarked on a concerted effort in the last few weeks to intimidate and cut the power of Salvadoran unions through murders and threats.

title: ROCK: MARSHALL CRENSHAW
description: TODAY'S pop music culture is so steeped in the self-consciousness of its own history that it is difficult for a young rock musician to find an approach that is simple and fresh and not overweighted with irony. But Marshall Crenshaw, the Detroit-born singer and songwriter whose early work evoked repeated comparisons to Buddy Holly, continues to refine a style that is allusive in form yet decidedly contemporary in spirit.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: ARDEN TRIO
description: CHARLES WUORINEN'S Trio (1983), given its premiere in an Arden Trio concert at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night, represents a continuation of the composer's effort to relax his compositional style and make it more accessible to the listener.

title: PHILS TURNED AGE TO THEIR BENEFIT
description: From the start of the season, this Phillies team of codgers and future Hall of Famers was dubbed ''The Wheeze Kids,'' and when the time came to celebrate their defeat of the Dodgers in the National League championship series, the joke was turned on its head.

title: LEADER ON WEST'S WATER PROJECTS
description: Former Representative Wayne N. Aspinall, whose work helped bring water to a thirsty and growing West in his 24 years in Congress, died today of cancer at his home. He was 87 years old.

title: TV: 'ADAM,' MOVIE ON MISSING BOY
description: TWO years ago, on July 27, Reve Walsh went to a department store in Hollywood, Fla., with her 6-year-old son. Warning young Adam not to wander, she left him in the toy department as she went to inquire about buying a lamp in another area, some 150 feet away. She returned in less than eight minutes and found the boy gone. He had been kidnapped in front of a good many customers and employees of the store.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PETIT JUGGLING

title: THE FED IN ATLANTA LOOKS FOR A LEADER
description: WANTED: President for large financial institution in Southeast. Must have exceptional economic skills and be a strong administrator. Will have opportunity to be regional spokesman and influence national economic policy. Incumbent's 1982 salary: $106,000.

title: BOMB KILLS 19, INCLUDING 6 KEY KOREANS
description: At least 19 people, including two leading advisers to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea and four of his Cabinet ministers, were killed Sunday when a bomb exploded as they prepared for a wreath-laying ceremony in Rangoon, Burma. Forty-seven people were wounded, many seriously.

title: JETS FOR IRAQ: FRANCE PLAYS DOWN EFFECT
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson declined to confirm today that France had delivered advanced jetfighters to Iraq, but spoke as though the planes' arrival in Iraq was a foregone conclusion.

title: CHANGE IS MANDATED ON JUDICIAL SELECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Agencies Approve Trust for C.I.A. Chief
description: William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, has announced that he has obtained the approval of two Government agencies of his plan to set up a blind trust for his investments.

title: Bridge: Sure' Bermuda Bowl Victory Slipped From Italians' Grasp
description: The weirdest conclusion to a World Team Championship occurred here Saturday evening, leaving six happy Americans and six grieving Italians.

title: 2 GREAT RACE HORSES WILL COVER SOME OLD GROUND
description: THE grooms at Woodstock Farm in Chesapeake City, Md., didn't know what to expect when they threw a saddle on Kelso last week. The 26-year-old had not been ridden by anyone, even for a pleasure jog, for almost 15 years.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: BRANDEIS INSTALLS ITS 5TH PRESIDENT
description: Evelyn E. Handler was inaugurated today as the fifth president of Brandeis University.

title: Schoolboy Injured In Football Game
description: A 17-year-old New Jersey high school football player who was injured Saturday remains in critical condition at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield with a fracture of the second cervical vertebra, which has left him paralyzed from the neck down.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: HOLY CROSS FINDS AIR ATTACK
description: The undefeated Holy Cross football team would make a good entry in the St. Patrick's Day Parade. Its passing attack, which led to a 21-18 victory Saturday over Colgate, has been given the nickname Aer Lingus, the Irish airline.

title: PENNSYLVANIA EX-TEACHER FACES MURDER TRIAL
description: A former teacher in a suburban high school near Philadelphia will go on trial here Tuesday on charges that he murdered a fellow teacher and her two children for her $1 million estate.

title: BIG EFFECTS OF SMALL CHANGES
description: SOMEWHERE, sometime when

title: Old Horses Get an Assist
description: Monique Koehler was startled when she read a magazine article three years ago about a English trainer who was trying to found retirement homes for retired race horses. Miss Koehler, an amatuer rider and a racing fan who works in Manhattan, had never stopped to consider what happened to horses past their prime.

title: Ann Batchelder Is Married
description: Ann Carol Batchelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Batchelder Jr. of Peoria, Ill., and Mountain Lake, Lake Wales, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Henri L. G. Kieffer 2d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Spangler Kieffer of Derby, N.Y. The Rev. James G. Birney performed the Episcopalian ceremony at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The bride is an account executive with Benton & Bowles Inc., the advertising agency in New York. Her father, chairman of the Batchelder Company, a Peoria advertising agency, was formerly president of the New York Subway Advertising Company. Dr. Kieffer is a resident in radiology at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York.

title: BANKERS TO CONFER ON BRAZIL
description: The president of Brazil's central bank is to meet here Tuesday with scores of American bankers in an effort to convince them to participate in a restructuring of Brazil's foreign debt.

title: BRUISED DR. PEPPER SHOPS FOR A BUYER
description: Next year, in the tagline of its new $33 million advertising campaign, the Dr Pepper Company will urge consumers to ''hold out for the out of the ordinary - hold out for Dr Pepper.''

title: Spacelab Plans Proceed Despite Booster Problem
description: Kennedy Space Center crews went ahead today with plans for a simulated launching of the European Spacelab, even though the mission could be delayed from Oct. 28 until next year because of worries about the safety of booster rockets.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1983
description: The Economy

title: ARAFAT MOVES TO PLAY HIS JORDAN CARD
description: News Analysis

title: FOR PRETORIA, LAWS ARE BASIC TO KEEPING BACKS IN CHECK
description: The crime with which the white prosecutor charged Loti Sikhakhana as he stood tautly in the dock before the white magistrate would have been no crime at all if he had been any other color than black: that he ''did wrongfully and illegally enter the prescribed area of Durban.''

title: Job Seeker and Friend
description: The Jacob K. Javits Building at 26 Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan is a large center for government workers who handle everything from crime to air pollution.

title: RAMS EDGE 49ERS
description: The rookie Eric Dickerson, held to 34 yards rushing in the first half, broke loose for 108 in the second, as the Los Angeles Rams (4-2) edged the San Francisco 49ers, 10-7, today. Ivory Sully of the Rams blocked a field-goal attempt by Ray Wersching on the last play of the game.

title: Rabbi Finds Inspiration As He Runs
description: People all over town, many of them drawn with exhaustion, are running longer and longer every day preparing for the New York City Marathon Oct. 23. One of them is Rabbi Marc Angel, 38 years old, who said he felt ''a little self-conscious at first in shorts.''

title: HARLEM CHURCH HAILS COOKE AS ONE OF ITS OWN
description: As the bells of the St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church pealed, the sound reverberating off the tenements of central Harlem and carrying for blocks in the crisp air, the sanctuary filled to overflowing on a special Sunday.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Friday about foreign and military aid incorrectly reported an action by the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Government Operations. It increased military aid to Egypt to $1.315 billion.

title: Alternative Programming: Or, Politics vs. Sports
description: The only continuing, detailed, year-round look that New York City gets at what goes on in the state capital, the ''Inside Albany'' television program, is being moved from prime time by Channel 13.

title: Jorge Javier Sanchez, Ellen Pouschine Wed
description: Ellen Catherine Pouschine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Pouschine Jr. of Sea Cliff, L.I., was married yesterday to Jorge Javier Sanchez, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorge Sanchez of Baton Rouge, La. The Rev. Daniel Hubiak, chancellor of the Orthodox Church in America, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Kazan in Sea Cliff.

title: Frances Cohen, Dr. Alan I. Green Wed
description: Frances Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Cohen of New York and Wainscott, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Alan Ivan Green, son of Irene Wouk Green and the late Dr. H. Howard Green of South Norwalk, Conn. Rabbi Marc Angel performed the ceremony at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Cowboys Win in Overtime
description: The Dallas Cowboys remained the only undefeated team in the National Football League today, but it took some doing.

title:
Market Place;
Stock Rally: Not Just I.B.M.
description: THE ascent to a new high of the bluest of the blue-chip stocks - the International Business Machines Corporation - was perhaps the most conspicuous single development in the stock market last week. Ending at a record 132 1/4, up 1/8 on Friday, I.B.M. led what began as an institutional glamour stock rally but soon was joined by individual secondary issues.

title: 2d Autopsy on Black Farmer
description: The second autopsy on a black farmer who died after being arrested by four white policemen showed that he died of ''coronary insufficiency,'' the same conclusion drawn by state pathologists, officials said Saturday.

title: NOW Leader Says Her Group Will Endorse Democrat in '84
description: The head of the National Organization for Women said today that her group would endorse a Democratic candidate for President, although she added that she thought the candidates were more interested in women's votes than women's issues.

title: Imagination and Kites Take Flight in the Park
description: Harold Hirsch, an architect, was flying a kite yesterday the size of his thumbnail. ''You'd think I'd have one as big as a house,'' he said at the New York City Kite Jamboree, ''but it gets too crowded with the big ones.''

title: PHONE RATES ARE IN MIDST OF UPHEAVAL
description: The plan by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to charge 75 cents for long-distance calls for directory information is the latest example of an idea that could radically change how telephone users pay for services.

title: Trojan Pride
description: The opening and closing ceremonies and the key track and field events will be held in their home football stadium, the swimming and diving competitions will be held in their pool and most of the athletes will be living in their dorms.

title: EXECUTIVES BACK TAX INCREASES
description: Although they insist on spending reductions, some of the nation's leading business executives are saying that substantial tax increases are inevitable and even a good idea if they reduce the Federal Government's budget deficits.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, the Market Indicators in Business Day Saturday reversed the Market Diary figures for the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.

title: OWNERS' FIGHT AGAINST CRIME CONSIDERED BUSINESS AS USUAL
description: The morning had gone by with customers coming in and going out, asking for shampoo, shaving cream or a certain brand of lipstick. Some of the regulars had been in, and Silvia Gonzalez, behind the cash register as usual, had asked about mothers and fathers and how the children were doing.

title: CONDITION GOOD
description: Mayor Koch collapsed while eating dinner yesterday evening at a restaurant on the Upper East side and was taken to Gracie Mansion, where he was treated by his personal physician, a spokesman for the police said.

title: DENVER CHARITY BALL PULLS OUT ALL THE STOPS
description: Right this moment, it is no picnic being Barbara Davis. For, according to Mrs. Davis, the day after her annual Carousel Ball for the Children's Diabetes Foundation, she starts thinking about the next one. How she will ever out- spectacular Saturday night's event at Currigan Hall is hard to imagine.

title: BEDFORD, IND., FINDS A PYRAMID IS NOT EASY
description: No one ever said it was easy to build a pyramid.

title: 2 Officials Under Carter Join Satellite-TV Unit
description: Two names from the Carter Administration are in the lineup of officers of a new company in the business of beaming television from satellites to rooftop receivers.

title: Black First In Playoff
description: Ronnie Black came from three strokes off the pace to catch Sam Torrance of Scotland, then dropped a 6-foot birdie putt on the fourth playoff hole to win the $250,000 Southern Open golf tournament today.

title: Actors Fund Operating A Blood Drive Today
description: The Actors Fund will hold a blood drive today from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. in Shubert Alley.

title: COUNTERFEITING OF GOODS RISES
description: Earlier this year, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation obtained from the Philippines what appeared to be one of its circuit breakers, a widely used device that automatically cuts off electric power in case of overloading to prevent fire and shocks.

title: U.S. ROLE IN THE U.N. IS DEBATED
description: Two Congressional hearings that were intended to examine whether the United Nations should stay in New York evolved instead into a forum on continued American involvement in the world organization.

title: Missing Student's Body Is Found Hear Colgate
description: The body of an epileptic freshman at Colgate University who had been missing since last Monday was found this morning in a wooded area near the university, according to a spokesman.

title: A DISPUTED IDEA
description: The idea of ''human rights'' seems simple enough. In fact, it means different things - not all of them obvious - to different people. That was seldom better demonstrated than at the Frank P. Graham Conference on Human Rights, meeting last week at the University of North Carolina.

title: Bike Racer Injured By Angry Jogger
description: Jonathan (Jock) Boyer, a former national champion and the only American to compete in the Tour de France, suffered a broken collarbone yesterday when he was pushed from his bike by a jogger near the finish of a 50-mile race in Central Park.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A pitcher, with two out in the ninth inning, is working on a no- hitter. The batter drives a ball into short right field for an apparent hit. The pitcher, upset, tackles the batter as he runs toward first. The right fielder throws the ball to the first baseman, but the batter is awarded the base. Is it still a no-hit game?

title: WHATEVER IS, IS RIGHT
description: The power of television to make us think about the world has never been displayed as impressively as in the current PBS series ''Vietnam: A Television History.'' It is journalism without certainties, without stridency. Its detached professionalism, approaching art, leaves us to the draw the conclusions.

title: Air Rights for Genetic Creations
description: Genetic engineers working to improve crop plants now want to start releasing some of their creations from the laboratory into the field. The National Institutes of Health, the Federal agency that oversees gene-splicing research, approved the first such releases. But it was promptly sued by critics who consider the action premature and hazardous.

title: SALARY CAP A PROBLEM FOR NETS
description: The opening scene took place seven months ago in Byrne Meadowlands Arena when, sitting on the sidelines as his team struggled for a victory, the Nets' president, Joe Taub, was dreaming. ''If we're going to make that step toward becoming a championship caliber team,'' he said, ''we'll need someone to handle the big guards like Andrew Toney, and George Gervin and Magic Johnson. I think that's our next step.''

title: MOVIES FOR '84 WILL TRY TO COPY SUCCESSES OF '83
description: Nothing succeeds in Hollywood like what has succeeded before.

title: EGYPT'S PERCEPTION OF ITS SELF-INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SURGERY FOLLOWS PACT ON CUSTODY
description: A 16- year-old boy who suffers from Down's syndrome returned to his home here this week after a potentially life-saving heart operation. The surgery followed a six-year legal battle with national implications for the rights of children and the handicapped.

title: Miss Prager and Eric Imm Are Married in Tarrytown
description: Robin Ann Prager, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Prager of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Eric Imm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Imm of Cleveland.

title: STRAW POLLS: FORUMS FOR CANDIDATES OR VOTE-BUYING EVENTS?
description: Knowing laughter rippled through the audience at the Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinner here Saturday night when Senator Ernest F. Hollings brought up the subject of tickets to the event.

title: FOR HOMOSEXUALS' PARENTS, SRENGTH IN COMMUNITY
description: Amy Ashworth, a housewife from Bronxville, N.Y., was talking about the day her son Tucker first told her he was homosexual. ''For the first 24 hours, I felt awful,'' she said. ''I kept thinking, 'What did I do wrong?' The next day I called him and said, 'Tucker, I love you, but I need help.' ''

title: BURMA, UNDER GENERAL'S RULE, KEEPS TO ITSELF
description: The bomb that killed at least 16 South Koreans and three Burmese today exploded in a closed and tightly ruled country that has only recently tried to strengthen its ties with such Western- leaning nations as South Korea.

title: Barber Scores No. 400
description: Bill Barber became the 19th player in National Hockey League history to reach the 400-goal plateau, scoring two goals tonight to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 7-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Loopholes Big Enough for Bombs
description: Is President Reagan serious about wanting to control The Bomb? He says he is. Just last week, before the United Nations, he said: ''We must insure that world security is not undermined by the further spread of nuclear weapons. Nuclear nonproliferation must not be the forgotten element of the world's arms control agenda.''

title: O'NEILL MEDAL FOR ROBARDS
description: The annual Eugene O'Neill Birthday Medal was awarded last night to Jason Robards ''for enriching the universal understanding'' of the United States' only Nobel Prize playwright.

title: AMID CHANGE, GLITTER REMAINS
description: ''WHEN I was a boy growing up in Zeeland, Michigan,'' said Jim Kaat, who will be 45 next month, ''the World Series was always exciting. It was that time of year. The Fall Classic. You got out of school early, and listened to the games on the radio. Time sort of stood still for baseball.

title: Power Bond Role Troubles Dealers
description: The default by the Washington Public Power Supply System - the biggest in the history of the municipal bond market - has left securities dealers in an awkward position: they are being blamed for their role in selling the bonds, but they are unable to do anything to restore the financial health of the system.

title: TEXT OF RESIGNATION BY WATT AND ITS ACCEPTANCE BY REAGAN
description: Following are the texts of James G. Watt's letter of resignation, read to reporters in Santa Ynez, Calif., and President Reagan's reply, issued from Camp David, Md., and read by telephone to reporters in Washington.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is my view that my usefulness to you in this Administration has come to an end.

title: JETS FALL, 10-7; Jaworski Leads Eagles
description: Almost everything went wrong for the Giants today in a 17-13 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Draft Problems
description: As dismal as the fortunes of the Houston Oilers may appear to be, with no victories after six games, Coach Ed Biles may not necessarily fear for his job. At least not right now.

title: HISPANIC CAUCUS IS FLEXING ITS MUSCLE
description: For years, the small band of Hispanic members of Congress were outsiders on Capitol Hill, bit players in the national political drama who were expected to deliver votes, not lines. Few colleagues knew much about them.

title: LOWER FARES, MORE CABS WILL HURT NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: AMERICA FESTIVAL
description: The composer Pauline Oliveros stood barefoot at the center of Western Plaza, chanting and holding a conch shell. Around her, two dozen musicians walked in an ever-widening circle, tootling and clanging on such assorted instruments as sopranino saxophone, toy concertina, Indian bells and a hunk of scrap metal. ''Do you know what this is supposed to be?'' one spectator asked another. ''Music,'' was the reply.

title: THE HUDSON AS A LURE FOR FISH
description: THE day was gray and for much of it, a cold rain slashed across the Hudson River, but I am sure that Tom Lake, our angling guide, would have been equally ebullient in a blizzard.

title: Kissinger Panel Arrives In Panama for Talks
description: A United States commission headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here late tonight to begin a weeklong, six-nation tour of Central America.

title: Dr. David Stuchiner Weds Miss Fanning, Health Aide
description: Kathleen Ellen Fanning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Fanning of Marlborough, Mass., and Dr. David J. Stuchiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Martin Stuchiner of New York, were married yesterday at the Stuchiner home on the shore of Raquette Lake, in Long Lake, N.Y., by Town Justice A. Gregory Timm.

title: Chance to Be Seen
description: It may not be on the calendar of major sporting events, but for a group of high school basketball players in New York City, the finale of the Blue Chip Classic at Brandeis High School in Manhattan this afternoon could be the most important basketball they ever play.

title: ELECTRONIC MAIL CONTROVERSY
description: The United States Postal Service is thinking of expanding its faltering electronic mail system, which the Justice Department, the Federal Trade Commission, the House Government Operations Committee and private industry have all criticized as uneconomical and possibly illegal.

title: INTERFIRST REASSURES BANKERS
description: The big third-quarter loss reported late Friday by the Interfirst Corporation of Dallas surprised many of the 11,000 bankers here for the annual convention of the American Bankers Association.

title: U.S. to Send Observers For Birmingham Voting
description: The Justice Department will send 72 Federal observers to monitor municipal elections Tuesday in Birmingham, Ala., the department said today.

title: Petty Fined $35,000 For Rule Violations
description: Nascar officials fined Richard Petty $35,000 for two rules violations after he finished first ahead of Darrell Waltrip in the Miller High Life 500 Grand National race today at Charlotte Motor Speedway.

title: Gusty Lange Is Wed To Stephen Ettlinger
description: Jean Claire Lange, daughter of Jean D. Lange of Riverside, Conn., and Col. H. W. W. Lange, U.S.A., retired, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Stephen R. Ettlinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ettlinger of Glencoe, Ill. The Rev. Stephen Marsh, a Lutheran pastor, performed the ceremony at the Daycroft School Chapel in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Susan A. Robbins Becomes a Bride
description: Susan A. Robbins, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Irving R. Robbins of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Jordan E. Yarett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome W. Yarett of Lake Success, L.I. Rabbi Marvin Tokayer, assisted by Cantor Eleazer Schulman, performed the ceremony at the Great Neck Synagogue on Long Island.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing yesterday of Columbus Day schedules incorrectly described today's N.J. Transit operations. The agency is on a regular weekday schedule.

title: BOTH TEAMS ARE DEEP IN BALANCE AND EXPERIENCE
description: BEFORE the fourth and final game of the American League pennant playoff Saturday, one of the many major league scouts attending the series remarked that he didn't really know anything about Tito Landrum, the reserve outfielder who spent only the final month of the season with Baltimore.

title: Zia Said to Plan Talks With Pakistani Party
description: President Mohammad Zia ul- Haq is to meet with leaders of a religious party on Monday, opening long- awaited talks with civilian politicians, the party's leader said today.

title: Soviet Scientist Flies to U.S. After His Defection in Japan
description: A 52- year-old Soviet scientist, Yevgeny Novikov, left Japan today for the United States, where he has been granted asylum, the police said.

title: Punjab Reported Quiet On 3d Day of Delhi Rule
description: The troubled northwestern Indian state of Punjab was reported quiet again today, its third day of central Government rule, as the neighboring state of Haryana and the Union Territory of Delhi prepared for strikes called by opposition groups to protest the killings of Hindus by Sikh terrorists.

title: Washington Watch; Toyota-G.M. Doubts Grow
description: THE Federal Trade Commission is rapidly losing patience with the Toyota Motor Corporation for failing to supply additional information about the Toyota-General Motors plan for joint production of a subcompact car in California.

title: LOWER FARES, MORE CABS WILL HURT NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH PROVINCES TURN NOSES UP AT LEFT'S CULTURE
description: When the Socialists and the Communists came to power in this city, one of the things they promised was to open a window to let in the fresh breeze of culture. When they were voted out last spring, the opened window was probably a major factor in their defeat.

title: SEVERAL BIG ISSUES DUE THIS WEEK
description: Several large tax-exempt and taxable issues will dominate market activity this week. With no Government security trading today in observance of the Columbus Day holiday, the weekly auction of Treasury bills will be held tomorrow.

title: Watt Stays on Horse For Quick Getaway
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt rode into a cow pasture to announce his resignation to reporters today, and then mounted his horse again, joking that he wanted to ride off quickly if questions got too tough.

title: Margaret Engel Wed To Bruce T. Adams
description: Margaret Engel, daughter of Eleanor Engel of Nevada, Iowa, and the late Jack Engel, was married yesterday to Bruce T. Adams, son of Mrs. John Webster of Potomac, Md., and the late Tinsley Adams. The Rev. Dr. T. Guthrie Speers performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Strathmore Hall, an art center in Bethesda, Md.

title: COLUMBUS CAN MEAN A STILL NEWER WORLD
description: How do we in the United States celebrate Columbus Day?

title: WATT BATTLED A RISING TIDE
description: News Analysis

title: ROBERT E. ANDERSON JR.
description: Robert E. Anderson Jr., a former general partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment banking and brokerage concern, died Wednesday at Monadnock Hospital in Peterborough, N.H. He was 81 years old and lived in Peterborough.

title: Zimbabwe Threatens To Seize Whites' Land
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe has threatened to confiscate white-owned land for the resettlement of peasants if Britain refuses to give promised compensation.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 10, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Hawaii Volcano Falls Quiet
description: The Kilauea volcano was quiet today, four days after the latest in a series of eruptions spewed lava 900 feet into the air, geologists said.

title: Deborah Cooper Is Wed in Boston
description: Deborah Sue Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen R. Cooper of Washington, formerly of New York, was married yesterday to Henry Paris Burstyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Burstyn of Lake Hiawatha, N.J. Dr. Roland B. Gittelsohn, rabbi emeritus of Temple Israel in Boston, performed the ceremony at the University Club there.

title: Elaine F. Weiss and Dr. Julian H. Krolik Are Wed
description: Elaine Francine Weiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Weiss of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Julian Henry Krolik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Krolik of West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi Alvin Harris, a cousin of the bride, assisted by Rabbi Norbert Baumann, performed the ceremony at the Conservative Synagogue of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: STUDENTS LEARN TO PUT DRAMA INTO VIDEO ADS
description: It was only one line, but Nadine Vazquez gave it all she had.

title: Miss Texon Wed To T. S. Rogers
description: Sylvia Texon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Meyer Texon of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas S. Rogers, son of Sydney Michael Rogers Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., and Mrs. Roger W. Steinhardt of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Haskel Lookstein at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: COMMENTS ARE MIXED ON WATT'S RESIGNATION
description: Reaction to Interior Secretary James G. Watt's decision to resign was mixed yesterday. Republican leaders expressed regret but said Mr. Watt's decision was a political necessity, while environmental groups said they were pleased.

title: Kennedy Center Award For Music Won by Lee
description: Thomas Lee of Somerville, Mass., is the winner of the $5,000 Friedheim Award of the Kennedy Center for the best new work of chamber music by an American composer. Mr. Lee, a professor at the New England Conservatory of Music, won for his Third String Quartet, which was performed by the American String Quartet.

title: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS WITH 'RELUCTANCE'
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, declaring that ''a different type of leadership'' would best serve President Reagan, resigned tonight in the face of growing support for a resolution in the Senate calling for his ouster.

title: Beth Rosenberg a Bride
description: Beth Diane Rosenberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Rosenberg of Massapequa Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Phillip Alpert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Alpert of Brooklyn. Rabbi Robert Applestone performed the ceremony at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. The bride is a speech pathologist in the San Diego school system. Mr. Alpert is a partner in the San Diego law firm of Cline & Alpert.

title: Federated Stores
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. of Cincinnati said it had agreed to sell four shopping center properties to affiliates of the JMB Realty Corporation for $128.3 million. Federated said one property is the Riverside Square in Hackensack, N.J., and the rest are in Texas. Federated, making the announcement Friday, said that it would receive $112.2 million before taxes, commissions and other costs, and that JMB would assume a $16.1 million mortgage.

title: Audrey Schneider and James Simon Are Married
description: Audrey Schneider, daughter of Dr. Judith Schneider of New York and Bert Schneider of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to James Simon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Simon of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: A New Magazine For Hospital Patients
description: Sandra M. Sullivan, an entrepreneur out of the health-care field, has raised $1.2 million in venture capital and started a magazine called TLC, The Magazine for Recuperation and Relaxation, for distribution free to hospital patients.

title: Harry Nkumbula Dies; Led African Congress
description: Harry Mwanga Nkumbula, a veteran politician from Zambia and a former president of the African National Congress, died Saturday at Lusaka University Hospital in Lusaka, Zambia. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. SELLING 'PYRAMID' AND LOTS ELSE BESIDES
description: The Government brochure was provocative: ''Pharaoh Wanted. Pyramid for Sale.''

title: Danelo's Kick Beats Dolphins
description: Joe Danelo kicked a 36-yard field goal with 62 seconds left in overtime today to give the Buffalo Bills a 38-35 victory over the Miami Dolphins. The Bills' Joe Ferguson completed 38 of 54 passes for 419 yards and a career-high 5 touchdowns.

title: DENYING MOSCOW HIGH-TECH
description: Heightened tensions between the superpowers triggered by the downing of the South Korean airliner threaten to fog some issues before Congress, including a law governing high-technology trade with our allies that is up for renewal.

title: COMPUTER MARKET STRONG IN BRITAIN
description: Thanks to Clive and the Beeb, they packed them in at the Barbican Exhibition Hall here.

title: JOB PLAN PASSED TO TRIM WELFARE
description: In an attempt to trim welfare costs, Los Angeles County is requiring 14,000 general relief recipients to participate in job- training programs or lose their benefits.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY TO WIN
description: The turnaround began long before the mayhem. The Islanders, mired by indifference and penalties for much of the game Saturday night, cut a four-goal Washington lead to 5-2 with 2 minutes 11 seconds to play in the second period.

title: Free Trade Zone Asked
description: The Ford Motor Company said it is seeking a free trade subzone for its Lorain, Ohio, car plant. Ford said that such a status would permit the plant to import, duty-free, transmissions from France and turbocharged engines from Brazil for assembly in cars. Ford said Friday the components would be subject to duties when the cars leave the plants for local markets, but added that such duties would not apply if the autos were exported.

title: Beirut Radio Reports Truce Observer Plans
description: Some 600 Italian and Greek observers will soon travel to Lebanon to supervise the country's 15-day-old cease-fire, official Beirut Radio said tonight.

title: WORDS CITED BY WATT CRITICS
description: Here are examples of remarks and actions by Interior Secretary James G. Watt that drew political criticism:

title: Obote Urges Ex-Leaders To Return to Uganda
description: President Milton Obote of Uganda today marked the 21st anniversary of the country's independence from Britain by calling on his immediate predecessors, former Presidents Yusufu K. Lule and Godfrey L. Binaisa, to return from exile.

title: JETS FALL, 10-7; Browns Win On Bahr Kick
description: The Jets played like a .500 team today and thus, after six games in what they thought would be their brightest season since the Super Bowl year, they remained a .500 team.

title: KEY VICTIMS OF BOMB BLAST IN RANGOON
description: Suh Suk Joon

title: ON HOUSING THE HOMELESS, THE CITY IF FIGHTING AN UPHILL BATTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Russian Roulette' Is Cited In Highway Crash Death of 6
description: A pickup truck playing ''a game of Russian roulette'' crossed a two-lane highway Saturday and smashed ''headlight to headlight'' into an oncoming car, killing six people and seriously injuring four others, the state police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ACT OF DARKNESS. By Francis King. 332 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $14.95.

title: Four Texans Found Slain in Ranch Hangar
description: Four men, including a deputy sheriff and former police officer, were found shot to death in a hangar at a north Texas ranch, where they had met to discuss selling an ultralight aircraft to a fifth person, a sheriff said.

title: BOUNDING BASQUE WINS AT BELMONT
description: The major sprints of the Belmont Park fall meeting turned out to be a throwback to last spring at Aqueduct. On Saturday, Chas Conerly beat the best older sprinters in the country to win the Fall Highweight Handicap, and yesterday Bounding Basque wore down A Phenomenon to upset the $85,800 Jamaica Handicap for 3-year- olds.

title: TV: CITY BALLET TRIBUTE TO BALANCHINE
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE left us more than his ballets; he left a whole esthetic, a way of looking not just at dance but also at all of art. It had to do with rigid discipline, although within the discipline was room for many separate beauties. Some of them will be seen tonight in ''A Lincoln Center Special: A New York City Ballet Tribute to George Balanchine.''

title: DEFICITS HURT LAW AGENCY ON EAST SIDE
description: Earlier this year, M.F.Y. Legal Services Inc., whose headquarters on Avenue A on the Lower East Side was among the nation's first storefront law offices, began a campaign to close a budget deficit left by a $400,000 cut in Federal funds for its legal services.

title: A NEIGHBOR IS ARRESTED
description: The body of an 11-year-old boy who was apparently strangled was found yesterday behind a new housing development in College Point, Queens, and the police said they had arrested a neighbor and charged him with the crime.

title: Dr. Jeri E. Riggs Weds Peter Gottlieb
description: Dr. Jeri Ellen Riggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Nevin Riggs of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Adam Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Gottlieb of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Judge Adrienne H. Scancarelli of Westchester County Family Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Advertising; A Network Of Sunday Magazines
description: TODAY the National Sunday Magazine Network really begins to spend its record-breaking ad budget for the coming year.

title: KNICKS IMPRESS HAWK COACH
description: The scene Saturday night at the Mississippi Coast Coliseum in Biloxi was a strange one. Instead of sitting on the Knick bench discussing strategy and keeping the statistics as an assistant to Coach Hubie Brown, Mike Fratello, the new Atlanta Hawks' coach, was on the opponents' bench trying to beat the Knicks. He succeeded.

title: YVES MONTAND AND THE LEFT AT ODDS
description: On stage, Yves Montand offers audiences the extraordinary gift of a man at ease with himself. The voice is passion restrained, as relaxed as a walk in the sun.

title: Commodities; Use of Dow In Contract Stirs Fight
description: FEW legal wrangles have so preoccupied the futures industry as that involving the Chicago Board of Trade and the Dow Jones Company. At issue is whether Dow Jones can prevent the exchange from using its popular industrial stock average as the basis for a futures contract, although the Chicago Board proposes to trade it under another name.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1983
description: International

title: A BRILLIANT LONER IN LOVE WITH GENETICS
description: When Barbara McClintock learned she had won the Nobel Prize in Medicine, she was heard to exclaim, ''Oh, dear,'' and then she walked out into the brisk morning air to pick walnuts. She is like that. She is known for baking with black walnuts. She is also known as a very private person, a loner in the laboratory and in life. The 81-year-old Dr. McClintock, dressed in dungarees and carrying tongs for grappling the walnuts, left her apartment on the grounds of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and strolled alone along a wooded path down by an inlet of the Long Island Sound. She once confessed that she finds ''applause is crushing.'' It was quiet out there in the woods.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $467,770,000 for the quarter and $472,373,000 for the year. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $40,902,000 for the quarter and a gain from discontinued operations of $3,624,000 for the year.

title: CUTBACKS WEAKEN RIGHTS POLICIES, U.S. PANEL SAYS
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights says in a new report that two years of fiscal austerity and staff reductions have seriously eroded the enforcement of civil rights by the Federal Government.

title: MULTITUDE OF JOBS ESTABLISH BEE AS THE MASTER OF COMPLEXITY
description: THE worker struggles valiantly to haul the corpse of another bee out of the hive. She pauses at the entrance platform before flying away with the lifeless body in her grasp. Far from her abode, she drops the carcass in a field, then flies back home and searches for more bodies.

title: Biles Quits Oilers
description: Two football coaches in Houston decided yesterday that they had had enough. First, Ed Biles of the Oilers, whose 13-game regular-season losing streak dates to September 1982, announced his resignation, saying: ''I've been a punching bag.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Lure of the Water

title: Market Place; Strong Revival For Car Parts
description: WHEN the nation's Big Three automobile makers report their third-quarter earnings later this month, Wall Street expects comparisons with last year's period to be quite spectacular. Meanwhile, profits are climbing for those companies that supply automotive replacement parts, as well as original equipment.

title: Jobs in Steel Off in E.E.C.
description: Employment in the European Economic Community's steel industry declined by 20,000 jobs in the first half of 1983, continuing a decade-long slide, the organization said today.

title: Tesoro Petroleum
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it is terminating its previously announced agreement to buy an additional 1.29 million shares of the Enstar Corporation from Roy M. Huffington Inc. Tesoro continues to hold 172,600 shares, or 1.1 percent, of Enstar common and 17,260 shares of Enstar convertible preferred series A. It said it would continue evaluating its interest in Enstar, an energy concern, but has no current plans to purchase more shares.

title: Advertising; Olympics Insurance Campaign
description: HOW far will the gang at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners go for a client?

title: Europe Seeking Technology
description: Western European governments, troubled by the losing battle Europe's computer companies are waging against United States and Japanese competitors, are enacting measures aimed at lessening Europe's dependence on high- technology imports.

title: Chief Operating Officer For Applied Magnetics
description: The Applied Magnetics Corporation yesterday promoted William R. Anderson, the head of its main division, to the additional post of chief operating officer.

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CITY OPERA: MISS KELM IN A DEBUT
description: OF principal interest in Sunday afternoon's ''Turandot'' at the New York City Opera was the debut of Linda Kelm in the title role. Miss Kelm, an American in her mid-30's from Salt Lake City, sang Puccini's music with an arresting and powerful soprano.

title: Members of Cabinet Under Shamir Listed
description: Following is a list of Israeli Cabinet members with their party affiliations. They were approved today by Parliament:

title: CORRECTION
description: An Al Hirschfeld drawing yesterday, accompanying a review of the artist's show at Harvard University, lacked a credit line. It was from the Margo Feiden Galleries in New York.

title: Laurin Returning
description: Lucien Laurin, who trained Secretariat, the 1973 Triple Crown winner, will return to training in New York for the first time in five years when he takes over the 20-horse Leone J. Peters Stable today. Laurin, who has been training in the South and the Middle West recently, also trained Riva Ridge, winner of the 1972 Kentucky Derby.

title: CORRECTION
description: A United Nations dispatch Friday on the reunification of Cyprus incorrectly described the position of President Spyros Kyprianou on a request for a meeting with Turkish Cypriot leaders.

title: COMPANIES LEAVE CITY AND FIND NEW TROUBLES
description: A week and a half after the American Can Company announced that it would leave its Greenwich, Conn., headquarters, executives of another corporation, Mutual of New York, announced that they were moving major divisions from Manhattan to Westchester County.

title: GENSCHER TO MEET GROMYKO IN VIENNA OVER THE WEEKEND
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher will meet with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union this weekend in Vienna, West German officials said today.

title: AIDES HOPE TO FILL WATT'S POST SOON
description: White House officials said today that the formal process of selecting a successor for Interior Secretary James G. Watt, who resigned Sunday, would begin Tuesday and that an effort would be made to have a new secretary on the job before Congress takes its Thanksgiving recess.

title: STAGE: 'THE JEWISH GYPSY'
description: or are curious about - the hearty and melodic musicals that once made Second Avenue the Jewish Broadway, ''The Jewish Gypsy'' is the show and Town Hall is the place.

title: CABARET: FRED SILVER
description: THE pull of autosuggestion might lead one to expect something dazzling from a mini-revue titled ''Silver on Silver'' at a new restaurant and cabaret called Silver Lining, 349 West 46th Street. The revue is made up of songs by Fred Silver, a songwriter and pianist who is celebrating his silver anniversary in show business.

title: DANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.7 million from an exchange of stock for debt in July. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Oct. 10.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comdisco Stock Plunges
description: Comdisco Inc., which buys, sells and leases computer equipment, lost more than one-third of its market value yesterday, with its stock plunging $14.25, to $24 a share. With 1,525,000 shares trading hands, it was the most actively traded stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cook Rift Worsens
description: The impasse between the Nets and the free-agent guard Darwin Cook widened today - so much so that Cook's attorney, Fred Slaughter, advised him to leave the team's hotel headquarters near their Princeton University training camp. ''If I'm forced to, I'll go back to the West Coast,'' said Cook, who flew in from his home in Los Angeles on Wednesday when it seemed as if he and the Nets had reached an agreement on a four-year, $1.5 million contract.

title: American Hospital
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said it would invest more than $600 million in research and product development from 1984 through 1988, up from $250 million over the last five years. The company said half of the funds would be used for high-technology research in cardiovascular surgery, critical care medicine and ophthalmology; one- third would be used for patient care and general surgery products, and the rest would be spent on instrument systems and new diagnostic tests for clinical laboratories.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including income of $736,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $2,080,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $250,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $694,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year.

title: Amtrak Series
description: Recognizing that Phillie and Oriole fans may well want to take advantage of the nearness of the opposing team's stadium, Amtrak has put on a ''World Series Special'' train between the cities.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly described the new position of Paul E. Huber at United Telecommunications Inc. He will be president and chief executive officer of the Megatek Corporation, a subsidiary.

title: WIDE-RANGING STRATEGY TO SAVE THEATERS
description: To the Editor:

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results reflect a 3-for-1 stock split effective Oct. 5. Results for the latest periods include operations of Texas Gas Resources Corp. since Aug. 6, 1983, the date of acquisition.

title: Head of Princeton Testifies on Suit
description: Princeton University's president testified today that he had no right to second- guess students who rule on cheating cases brought against their peers under the school's 90-year-old honor system.

title: TUCSON ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After discontinued operations of $323,000, or 1 cent a share. c-After discontinued operations of $27,741,000, or $1.22 a share, for the latest year and $21,351,000 or 96 cents a share, for the earlier period. The latest year earnings include extraordinary gain of $111,658,000, or $4.92 a share.

title: PHILIPPINE PANEL ON ASSASSINATION DISSOLVES ITSELF
description: The commission that President Ferdinand E. Marcos appointed to investigate the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. resigned today.

title: FERRET'S COMEBACK FROM 'EXTINCTION' CONTINUES
description: -footed ferret, thought to be extinct until a single live animal was discovered in 1981, is now reported to be having a population boom.

title: TV: 'NOVA' BEGINS ITS 11TH SEASON
description: ''NOVA,'' which now calls itself, with justification, ''America's premiere science series,'' begins its 11th season on public television tonight with ''Signs of the Apes, Songs of the Whales,'' an exploration of how well animals use language. It will be seen on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8 P.M.

title: FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DONALDSON LUFKIN & JENETTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPLITTING THE APPLE, FOUR WAYS
description: ON the whole, I find myself burrowing within the innards of the Apple IIe more than I do inside other personal computers. In part, these forages occur because more Apple-compatible gadgetry and software are on the market than any other varieties. But they are also a result, in large measure, of the way in which the trackball and other game-port-connected accessories are attached. For want of a simple plug on the computer's case, one must pop open the top of the Apple and insert a card or a plug on the main computer board itself to connect an accessory or add to the computer's capabilities.

title: CURRENCY AND STOCK SALES HALTED
description: Banks in Israel halted sales of foreign currency Monday and the stock exchange was shut for the second day as Government and banking officials tried to stem heavy sales of shekels.

title: Joblessness in Ireland
description: Unemployment in the Republic of Ireland in September rose by 2,500 people from August's level, to a seasonally adjusted 197,600, the Central Statistics Office said today. The Government does not issue an unemployment rate, but analysts said the unadjusted total is about 15 percent of the labor force.

title: Phils Aided Depth In Bullpen
description: Earl Weaver bounced into the Philadelphia Phillies' locker room and went straight to Paul Owens, the general manager who appointed himself manager on July 18 and then won the National League pennant.

title: A LISTING OF NATIONAL MERIT SEMIFINALISTS IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: The semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's annual competition represent one-half of 1 percent of all high school seniors in the country.

title: Freedom to Borrow, Sensibly
description: New York State's Constitution places strict limits on local debt, but sometimes there's a good reason for modifying the strictness. Two proposals on November's ballot would allow local governments to exceed debt limits prudently. Proposal 8 will help localities stimulate the development of underutilized land. Proposal 2 will extend for 10 years local government's freedom to borrow for sewage projects. Both seem reasonable.

title: WASHINGTON VOTERS CHOOSE NOMINEES FOR SENATE TODAY
description: Washington's voters will select two of 33 candidates Tuesday as major party nominees to fill the seat vacated by the death of Senator Henry M. Jackson.

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1983
description: Markets

title: A CHRONOLOGY OF WATT'S ADMINISTRATION
description: Following is a chronology of the major actions and initiatives of James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior: 1981

title: JOHN MACRAE JR., A BOOK PUBLISHER
description: John Macrae Jr. of Naples, Fla., former chairman of the board of E. P. Dutton, the publishing company that under his leadership published the ''Winnie the Pooh'' series, died of heart failure Friday at his summer home in Nantucket, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * California Federal Savings and Loan Association has named James B. Jacobson executive vice president in charge of non-real estate subsidiaries, and Charles W. Woodford chairman and chief executive officer of its Trust Services of America Inc. subsidiary.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Everything here is br-r-rilliant, a word filled with a trill of r's and used by the English to describe everything from a pair of Katharine Hamnett trousers to Bombay Brasserie, the Indian restaurant that they call ''fab'' when they tire of the word brilliant.

title: DR. WILLARD UPHAUS, LEADER OF PACIFIST CAUSES IN THE 50'S
description: Dr. Willard Uphaus, a pacifist preacher who was jailed for a year for refusing to disclose names in an investigation of Communists, died on Saturday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 92 years old.

title: 40 Ships Trapped in Arctic
description: The newspaper Izvestia said today that a cold snap earlier this month had trapped 40 ships, including icebreakers, in thick ice in the Chukchi Sea off northeast Siberia. Ice conditions were unusually hard all summer, Izvestia said.

title: Jogger No Culprit
description: The incident on Sunday between a jogger and Jonathan Boyer, a top bike racer who suffered a broken collarbone, was an accident, the police said yesterday.
