Some eyewitness in Central Park had said that the jogger intentionally struck Boyer because he was annoyed by the cyclists' competing in a 50-mile race there. But Sgt. Patrick Murphy said that the jogger had stayed at the scene and expressed concern for Boyer, and that no charges had been filed.

title: Southland Life
description: The Southland Financial Corporation said it had received ''indications of interest'' in the offered sale of its Southland Life Insurance Company subsidiary.

title: MRS. REAGAN TAKES HER ANTI-DRUG CAMPAIGN TO TELEVISION
description: In the next month, Nancy Reagan will take her favorite cause, the prevention of drug and alcohol abuse by teen-agers, to the airwaves four times. The White House characterizes these unusual television appearances as a major effort to demonstrate the First Lady's concerns about the subject.

title: TO GIVE THE VOTERS MORE REASON TO VOTE
description: To the Editor:

title: ANCIENT AND MODERN BLENDED IN RITE FOR CARDINAL
description: The bishops, priests and laity who filled St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for the funeral of Terence Cardinal Cooke took part in a rite that drew together the ancient tradition of Christian worship and the radical change made in the Catholic mass in the past two decades.

title: ONTARIO QUAKE FELT UPSTATE
description: An earthquake centered 10 miles south of Ottawa shook parts of eastern Ontario and Quebec early this morning, waking people and knocking pictures off walls, the National Earthquake Information Service said. Its tremors were heard as far as 90 miles south in upstate New York.

title: FROM A CROWD OF THOUSANDS, PRAISE COMES FOR THE ARCHBISHOP
description: They were young, they were old. Some had traveled distances. Many had been out on the street since early morning.

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Net income.

title: 2 Reputed Crime Figures Sentenced in Casino Plot
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced two reputed organized crime figures to long prison terms and ordered them to pay restitution to a Las Vegas, Nev., casino for the skimming of gambling profits.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 1.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Natural Resources Co. announced that its Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line Co. unit had filed a request with Federal regulators to reduce its wholesale natural gas prices by $50 million.

title: DETROIT'S NONSILVER LINING
description: All the superficial signs - sales, profits and employment figures - point to a recovery in the automobile industry. But the sad fact is that the much-celebrated recovery is long on pomp and short on circumstance: There are dark rain clouds gathering up ahead.

title: MERCHANTS TAXING THEMSELVES TO OFFER MORE SERVICES IN SPECIAL DISTRICTS
description: The Young World clothing store that Stanley I. Chera's family owns on Fulton Street in Brooklyn was billed $140,311 in property taxes last year, but Mr. Chera says he willingly paid $10,900 more.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Article 224246 -- No Title
description: Gulf and Western Industries, citing a one-time charge against earnings stemming from its major divestiture program, announced that it had a loss of $401.6 million in its fourth fiscal quarter of 1983 contrasted with $1.2 million in net income in the same period last year.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRESENTING MR. T AND TIPPY
description: When the World Series opens tonight, the most important players won't be in the lineups. Instead, they will be sitting in the bullpens beyond the green outfield fences at Memorial Stadium in Baltimore, their left arms bundled in jackets, as each waits for a phone call from the dugout in the late innings: the Phillies' Alfred Willis Holland, alias Mr. T, and the Orioles' Felix Anthony Martinez, alias Tippy.

title: PRETORIA'S WHITES PREPARINGFOR DECADES OF CONFLICT WITH BLACK INSURGENTS
description: When whites who are near the levers of power in this country are asked whether they see any end to the underlying racial conflict, their usual reply is to say it is possible only to ''manage the conflict,'' not resolve it.

title: WILDFLOWER ART GRACES COAST ROAD
description: Colorful wildflowers arranged by Evelyn Cunha grace an 8-by-22-foot wall along Fresno's year-old Freeway 41, a crosstown highway, in one of California's few highway mural projects.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LOOK OUTSIDE

title: LORIMAR reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'Megatrends' Author's Rise
description: He is high-tech. He is global. He is an entrepreneur. He is John Naisbitt and, if he is exemplary of just about every megatrend defined in the best seller, it is no accident; he wrote the book.

title: German Layoffs Set
description: Maschinenfabrik Augsburg N"uremberg A.G. said today that it planned to cut its work force by up to 2,350.

title: SIMMS FRUSTRATED BY THUMB INJURY
description: Twice this morning and twice this afternoon, Phil Simms climbed out of his fourth-floor bed in the Pascack Valley Hospital, sat in a wheelchair and took an elevator to the first floor for X-rays. In between were tests, ''every kind you could think of,'' he said.

title: SEOUL CONDEMNS BOMBING AS PLOT BY NORTH KOREA
description: The Government stepped up its war of words against North Korea today, blaming it for the ''barbarous'' bombing in Burma Sunday that killed 19 people, including some of South Korea's highest-ranking officials.

title: HELPED DEVELOP MODERN ROCKETRY
description: Dr. Kurt H. Debus, a pioneer of modern rocketry who played a pivotal role in projects ranging from the creation of Germany's V-2 rocket in World War II to the arrival of Americans on the moon, died of a heart attack yesterday in Cocoa, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: The U.N. Today;  Oct. 1Oct. 11, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EMIL MAZEY, LEADER OF AUTO WORKERS, IS DEAD OF CANCER
description: Emil Mazey, who was secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers for 33 years, has died of cancer, the union said today. He was 70 years old.

title: DISABLED FISH IN POLLUTED WATERS
description: Fish taken from polluted parts of the Hudson River cannot swim as well as fish taken from cleaner areas, biologists report.

title: A SPUNKY BOUTIQUE CHAIN
description: At one time, business was so slow that the owners of Charivari, the high-fashion Manhattan boutique chain, chopped the bottoms off a line of $45 jeans in the hope they would sell better as shorts.

title: Dow Jones Net Up 31.5%
description: Dow Jones & Company announced yesterday that its net income in the third quarter rose 31.5 percent, to $28.4 million, or 44 cents a share, from $21.6 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier. The company, which publishes The Wall Street Journal, Barron's and a chain of regional papers, said revenues climbed 21.3 percent, to $216.9 million, from $178.8 million.

title: P.L.O. UNITS CLASH IN DAMASCUS
description: Gun battles, apparently between rival Palestinian factions, broke out in two areas of Damascus today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TITAN OF SENATE STILL GIVES COUNCEL
description: He laughs and calls himself ''an old fogey.'' At his cluttered desk, he squints at a sheet of paper and starts to read and mumbles: ''I don't have my best glasses for reading. Getting old and blind, lucky to be here.''

title: ANOTHER LAST CHANCE
description: A bright young Lebanese came home last year full of hope that at last, with the Palestinians out of the way, his country could manage its own fate.

title: LONG ISLAND BIOLOGISTS WINS NOBEL IN MEDICINE
description: Dr. Barbara McClintock, an 81-year- old scientist from Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., won the 1983 Nobel Prize for medicine yesterday for her discovery that genes can move from one spot to another on the chromosomes of a plant and change the future generations of plants it produces.

title: Change in the Cityscape
description: Two familiar Manhattan landmarks disappeared in recent days - the guard booth outside the Dakota apartment building at 72d Street and Central Park West, and the Castro Convertible furniture showroom at Broadway and 47th Street, across from the TKTS booth.

title: Hunter Students Set Own High Standards
description: At the first meeting this fall of the international-relations course she teaches to juniors and seniors at Hunter College High School, Anna Morello overheard a conversation as the students were filing into the room.

title: BUILD-DOWN (-DOOM?)
description: Observers on both the right and the left have nodded approvingly toward President Reagan's ''build-down'' proposal for simultaneously reducing and modernizing our strategic forces. This is not surprising: Liberals and conservatives alike are drawn to the idea because it would allow the procurement of new weapons while reducing the total numbers in the stockpile. People on both sides see it as a laudable compromise and do not notice that it totally fails to address the key goal of arms control - to reduce the risk of the outbreak of a nuclear war. Nor, apparently, do they understand that it is President Reagan's latest attempt to subvert the arms control move

title: AMERICA'S EMPTY CUP
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLAND RESIDENTS FIGHT TO KEEP U.S. DOCTOR
description: A federally paid doctor has been ordered to return to Washington to take a desk job, but residents of this island town of 1,200 people started a letter- writing campaign to keep him.

title: Firebomb Hits Grocer's Home After Fights With Street Gang
description: A grocer's house was hit by a firebomb in the latest in a series of attacks that started when a street gang member was wounded by the grocer's father.

title: Happy Times For Danelo Again
description: Only a month ago, Joe Danelo was a place-kicker without a job. In training camp he had lost the assignment he held for seven years with the Giants to Ali Haji-Sheikh, a rookie.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH FOR FOURTH IN ROW
description: The Rangers, with last night's 2-1 victory over Los Angeles, have won their first four games, their best start since 1938-39. They have allowed a mere total of five goals and have killed 28 consecutive power plays. In short, they have played their way to the top of the National Hockey League - with 76 games to play.

title: Required Reading War on Drug Abuse
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, in remarks to the Senate, Sept. 22, 1983:

title: SALE OF LIFEMARK UNDER DISCUSSION
description: The Lifemark Corporation, the country's fifth-largest hospital chain, said yesterday that it had entered into preliminary discussions with several other companies concerning the sale of Lifemark.

title: Citizen Group Assails Schools' Block Grants
description: A citizens' group said today that the Reagan Administration's block grants for education had shifted funds from states with large numbers of poor, nonwhite children to more sparsely settled states with fewer members of minority groups.

title: TCSX Net Off 17.5% in Period
description: The CSX Corporation, hurt by lower coal shipments as a result of a soft export market, reported yesterday that net income in the fiscal third quarter fell 17.5 percent, to $34.9 million, or 28 cents a share, from $42.3 million, or 34 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: TORIES TO CONVENE UNDER A SHADOW
description: Only four months after its victory in the June 9 general election, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party holds its annual conference this week in an atmosphere of controversy and confusion.

title: Argentine Air Force Officers Among Dead in Plane Crash
description: Twelve members of the Argentine Air Force, including the commander of air operations during last year's Falkland Islands war, were killed today when a twin-engine plane crashed in north-central Argentina, the air force reported.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL HEADED BY SHAMIR IS VOTED IN, 60-53
description: Yitzhak Shamir became Prime Minister of Israel Monday on a 60-to-53 vote in Parliament.

title: World Series Schedule
description: Tonight - at Baltimore, Denny (19-6) vs. McGregor (18-7), 8:30 P.M.

title: Lebanon Aid Falls Short
description: Less than half of the $10 million requested by the United Nations to help 100,000 to 150,000 Lebanese refugees has been donated, a United Nations official, Iqbal Akhund, said here today.

title: 9 FIREFIGHTERS ACCUSED OF ARSON, REPORTEDLY AN INITIATION TO FORCE
description: Nine volunteer firefighters have been arrested on charges of setting a series of fires between 1978 and 1980 in West Elizabeth Borough, in what the authorities say was part of an initiation rite.

title: Bridge: Four With New York Roots Joinorld
description: The dramatic events in Stockholm on Saturday added four names to the long list of experts with New York roots who own, or have owned, world championship titles. They are Mike Becker, Ron Rubin, Alan Sontag and Peter Weichsel.

title: 10-YEAR-OLD BOTTLE LAW: VERMONTERS BUY IT
description: Vermont's bottle law, which is 10 years old this fall, has created hundreds of jobs and drastically reduced litter, and the extra few cents at the store does not seem to have affected statewide beverage sales.

title: Head of Atari Unit Is Hired by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. yesterday appointed John Cavalier vice president and general manager of its Personal Computer Systems division. Mr. Cavalier, 44 years old, comes to Apple from Atari Inc., where he was president of the Atari Products Company, which markets a home computer as well. He resigned the Atari post on Friday.

title: MANILA IN NEED OF LONG-TERM LOANS
description: Last week's devaluation of the Philippine peso could be followed by further weakening because the political crisis is prompting extensive purchases of foreign currencies, business executives say.

title: Perkins Praised
description: Joe Paterno, who refused to compete with Ray Perkins for the Giant coaching job four years ago, finally met him on opposing sidelines last Saturday with Paterno's Penn State team holding on to upset Perkins's Alabama squad, 34-28. The game, and especially Alabama's comeback from a 34-7 fourth-quarter deficit, left Paterno very impressed with Perkins.

title: MATCHUPS OF THE WORLD SERIES TEAMS Orioles
description: Pitchers (Age, Throws, Won-Lost, ERA) Scott McGregor (28, LH, 18-7, 3.18)

title: Chemical Burns At Plant on S.I.
description: An undetermined amount of sodium nitrite caught fire yesterday in a vacant gypsum factory on Staten Island, but the blaze was quickly extinguished, officials said.

title: DOW UP BY 12.50, TO 1,284.65
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday in quiet holiday trading with all three major market indicators ending at record highs.

title: Polish Activist Gets 4-Year Sentence
description: A leader of the banned Solidarity union's underground faction was sentenced to four years in prison by a military court in the western city of Poznan today, official informants said.

title: HMW INDUSTRIES ACCEPTS CLABIR'S $63 MILLION BID
description: The Clabir Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., vigorously pursuing longstanding plans to expand its defense business, succeeded yesterday in persuading HMW Industries of Stamford, Conn., to accept a takeover bid after it raised the price to $63 million.

title: UNUSUAL INCENTIVES IN FLORIDA SCHOOLS HAILED
description: At an academic pep rally where eighth graders chant ''beat the test,'' a principal declares he will come to school painted blue if test scores are high.

title: COMPUTER TRANSCEIVER SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BRIEFING
description: Politics and Grizzlies

title: THE MILAN MESSAGE: LESS IS MORE
description: With his impeccable presentation of men's fashions for women, Giorgio Armani clearly established himself as the dominant force in Italian fashion.

title: MEDICAL STUDENTS CONCERNED WITH HUMANISM
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. GANDHI IS REPORTED WEIGHING EARLY ELECTION
description: A conviction is growing among politicians here that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will call national elections next February or March, nearly a year before she is required to do so.

title: Donaldson Net Climbs by 31%
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter rose 31 percent, to $5.5 million, or 37 cents a share, from $4.2 million, or 33 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: CHALLENGES FOR SHAMIR
description: Israel's new coalition Government under Yitzhak Shamir faces two issues that may well help determine whether Israel can continue functioning as a democratic political community and to what extent Israel will be a Jewish state.

title: PITNEY QUITS WORD PROCESSING
description: Pitney Bowes Inc., the postage meter company, announced plans yesterday to withdraw from the manufacture and marketing of word processors.

title: Holiday-Affected Tables
description: Because of the Columbus Day holiday yesterday, these tables do not appear: Foreign Exchange; Treasury Bonds and Notes; Government Agency Bonds and Money Rates. The Treasury Department delayed its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills until today. The Toronto and Montreal exchanges were closed in observance of Canada's Thanksgiving.

title: Rangoon Mausoleum Recalls 1947 Killings
description: On July 19, 1947, in the transition period between internal autonomy and full independence from Britain, Burma's Executive Council was in session in Rangoon.

title: IN PURSUIT OF THE CAUSE OF AIDS
description: WHAT if the cause of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) were discovered tomorrow and a reliable diagnostic test developed?

title: Paris Warned On Steel Woes
description: Steel industry executives have told the Government that France's two steel groups, Usinor and Sacilor, must drop 10,000 to 12,000 jobs in addition to the 12,000 already planned if the groups are to return to profitability, industry sources said today.

title: 6.2% GAIN FOR CITY RETAILERS
description: Retail sales in New York City registered a strong improvement in September over a depressed performance a year ago, according to a monthly spot-check of seven major retailers.

title: OCCIDENTAL REACHES ACCORD WITH 1,300 AT LOVE CANAL
description: A tentative settlement on billions of dollars in lawsuits has been reached by Occidental Petroleum and former residents of the chemically contaminated Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, both sides said today.

title: BURMA POLICE SEARCH RANGOON FOR THE KILLERS
description: Security agents checked hotel rooms, stopped cars and searched for weapons today in what the Burmese Government called an intensive hunt for assassins who bombed a memorial site Sunday, killing 16 South Korean visitors.

title: Sony Disk Player
description: The Sony Corporation introduced a compact audiodisk player priced below its existing products in an attempt to capture a broader market, company officials said at a news conference.

title: PANAMANIAN URGES REAGAN PANEL TO SEEK NEGOTIATIONS FOR REAGAN
description: President Ricardo de la Espriella of Panama told members of President Reagan's commission on Central America today that the solution to the region's political, economic and social problems must come through negotiations.

title: Reader's Digest Picks New Publisher
description: George V. Grune is switching back to Reader's Digest as publisher on Jan. 1 after a tour as vice president and director of condensed books, general books and recorded music for the company. He will be replacing Richard F. McLoughlin, in the job since March 1980.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $787,000. c-Including a special gain of $15.2 million.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Argentine Designs On Gibraltar Reported
description: The Spanish Foreign Minister today confirmed a British newspaper report that a group of Argentines had been caught in Spain while apparently planning an attack on the British colony of Gibraltar during the 1982 war between Britain and Argentina in the Falkland Islands.

title: SCHOOLS FACE RISKS IN RUSHING TO BUY COMPUTERS
description: COMPUTERS will neither solve the schools' problems nor greatly improve the students' job prospects. Schools that rush into buying computers, without first evolving a computer policy, may find themselves educationally as well as fiscally bankrupt.

title: Iraq, With French Jets, Vows to Crush Iran
description: Iraq's President threatened today to mount a new offensive against Iran and inflict ''a decisive defeat,'' a day after five advanced jet fighters from France were reported to have been delivered to Baghdad.

title: BOSTON MAYORAL PRIMARY TO MARK START OF A NEW POLITICAL ERA
description: Before the start of the Bonne Bell 10-kilometer race for women in Boston today, Cathy Hoffman dragged her young daughter over to meet Melvin H. King. He is tied in public opinion polls with two other leading candidates, Raymond L. Flynn and David I. Finnegan, going into the city's mayoral primary Tuesday.

title: CHILDREN WHO KILL: PERSONALITY PATTERNS ARE IDENTIFIED
description: WITH stunning frequency, new stories appear about one of the most perplexing of all crimes - homicide committed by children. Just a few examples from the New York region this year:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The prize is such an extraordinary honor. It might seem unfair, however, to reward a person for having so much pleasure over the years, asking the maize plant to solve specific problems and then watching its responses.''

title: ESQUIRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $268,000 for the quarter and a gain of $389,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $2,950,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid Oct. 31.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net income after a loss of $16,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $328,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $117,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ACADEMIC FREEDOM TENET IS TESTED
description: ACADEMIC freedom is a tenet that everyone supports - up to a point. But it is often not a simple matter to decide when a professor has crossed the line between responsibility and irresponsibility in the classroom.

title: 'SHADOW SHOGUN' OF JAPAN: THE FINALE OF A SCANDAL
description: In a country that usually does not like its leaders larger than life, former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka is a puzzlement. According to the rule book, there is no percentage here in being a blunt, self-made man, with a sharp tongue.

title: ALABAMA SENATOR DENTON USES ETHNIC LABELS WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) - Senator Jeremiah Denton, Republican of Alabama, addressed a speech in Westchester County to his ''fellow Republicans and Democrats, Americans all, guineas, micks and polacks,'' and he said today his audience ''thought it was great.''
description: Senator Denton said he made the remark Friday night at a dinner and dance held by the county's Conservative Party in New Rochelle, partly in response to the controversy surrounding Interior Secretary James G. Watt, who had been the party's first choice as a speaker.

title: Rights Monitors Accuse Chad of Atrocities
description: Government troops in Chad have killed more than 160 civilians in the last 15 months, many of them in areas untouched by the country's civil war, the human rights group Amnesty International said today.

title: MUSIC: 'ELEMENTAL VOLTAGE' IN BROOKLYN
description: ''ELEMENTAL VOLTAGE,'' presented at the Brooklyn Army Terminal last Saturday afternoon, was one of those exercises in sound in which the space becomes the musical instrument and the performers within it a power source.

title: JETS' CONFIDENCE IS DECLINING
description: The confidence among the Jets that this could be a big year seemed diluted today.

title: Lakers Sign Jabbar; Nixon Sent To Clippers
description: The Los Angeles Lakers signed their star center, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, to a multiyear contract today, only hours after trading the guard Norm Nixon to the San Diego Clippers in a four-player deal.

title: UNITED STATES HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIGERS ARE SOLD
description: Thomas S. Monaghan, who once dreamed of playing shortstop for the Detroit Tigers, bought the team today from John E. Fetzer. The price was not disclosed, but the value of the team, viewed as one of the better properties in baseball, is estimated to be from $25 million to $35 million.

title: COOKE ENTOMBED IN ST. PATRICK RITES
description: The life of Terence Cardinal Cooke was celebrated yesterday in prayer, music and sacrament by bishops, priests and laity in his funeral mass and burial at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: J.J. SCHWARTZWALD, EX-JUDGE
description: Jacob J. Schwartzwald, who served almost 50 years in the State Legislature and the courts, died Saturday at Interfaith Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 83 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Service Merchandise
description: The Service Merchandise Company said today that it had named James E. Poole president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Raymond Zimmerman, who remains the company's chairman. Mr. Poole had been president of the Natural Resources group of Gulf and Western Industries. Service Merchandise is a catalogue showroom merchandiser.

title: Volcker Urges Aid For Latins
description: The nation's banks must support the refinancing of Latin America's foreign debt if economic recovery is to succeed in the underdeveloped world, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today.

title: 'GETAWAY SPECIALS' SEEN AS LESS THAN A GREAT SUCCESS
description: WASHINGTON

title: Honeywell System
description: Honeywell Inc. said it had introduced a system at the Instrument Society of America show that integrates process control data and plant management information.

title: HYPNOSIS PLANNED IN HANGAR DEATHS INQUIRY
description: A sheriff said today that he would hypnotize a widow to see if she could remember the name of a man who may have killed her husband and three other people.

title: MAJOR ENCYCLOPEDIA ON JAPAN WRITTEN IN ENGLISH
description: A nine-volume Japanese encyclopedia about Japan written in English, a project that required more than 12 years and involved 1,300 scholars from 27 countries, will be published in the United States on Oct. 20. American scholars say it is remarkably candid as well as the most comprehensive reference work about one nation ever published in the language of another.

title: Baldwin-United Sells Unit
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Baldwin Life Insurance Company, which operates in New York State, to the Transamerica Insurance Corporation of California, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation, for about $5.4 million in cash.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE STORIES OF BERNARD MALAMUD. 349 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: 'WELFARE FAMILIES': THE LATEST EPITHET
description: To the Editor:

title: Contempt Citation Canceled
description: Circuit Judge Billy Joe Sheffield has decided to withdraw a contempt of court citation and $100 fine he imposed on Connie Cox for indirectly criticizing him in a letter to the local weekly newspaper, her lawyer said today. According to the lawyer, Denny Holloway, the judge changed his mind after studying defense arguments.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: L.I. Expressway To Get New Signs
description: An electronic road sign on the Long Island Expressway will go into operation Wednesday, the first of 74 planned for the expressway and for the Northern State Parkway.

title: Norwegian Prices Rise
description: The Norwegian consumer price index rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, after falling by two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the National Bureau of Statistics said today.

title: U.S. AIDE BLAMES CHINA FOR DELAYING ARMS DEALS
description: A senior State Department official said today that there had been no sales of American military equipment so far to China because the Chinese had been seeking special treatment before they would agree to buy any arms.

title: What James Watt Said - and Did
description: With the departure of James Watt, the Department of Interior loses its most active secretary probably since Harold Ickes. Mr. Watt has been a mover and shaker. He has also been a loudmouth with a taste for controversy. That appetite brought him down, but not until he had radically revised the way Federal lands and minerals are managed.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 17
A Day for Martin Luther King
description: Now that Jesse Helms has relented, the Senate will have to decide whether it wants a holiday commemorating Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Two Lex Acquisitions
description: Lex Service P.L.C. said today that it had bought Sasco G.m.b.H. and Panel G.m.b.H., two private West German distributors of electronic components. The purchase price was about $5.3 million, Lex said.

title: TO GIVE THE VOTERS MORE REASON TO VOTE
description: To the Editor: The price tag on the 24-hour voting proposal is outrageous. Rather than forge ahead into an unchartered area, we should consider a tried and true method that has been in use in several European countries: holding elec

title: A FORCE IN THEATER 63 YEARS
description: Sir Ralph Richardson, who was ranked with England's actor-knights, Sir Laurence Olivier, Sir John Gielgud and Sir Alec Guinness in a career that spanned more than 60 years, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: 'Clean Bill of Health' For Koch After Tests
description: Mayor Koch spent an hour at a hospital for tests yesterday following a fainting spell on Sunday night. His doctor gave him ''a clean bill of health,'' the Mayor's office said.

title: Key Rates
description: N.A. Not available because markets closed for Columbus Day holiday.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 2 WHO FOUGHT FOR LEPROSY CENTER TO BE TRIED
description: Bernard Punikaia, 53 years old, and Clarence Naia, 55, are leprosy patients who fought for five years to stay at the antiquated treatment facility known as Hale Mohalu, about 10 miles from downtown Honolulu.

title: Continental Group
description: The Continental Group said it had completed its sale of its containerboard, kraft paper and certain other units to the Stone Container Corporation for about $510 milllion.

title: COMMODITIES Iranian Threat Lifts Oil; Grain and Soybeans Off
description: Fears that renewed tension between Iran and Iraq could interrupt the supply of a significant portion of the world's petroleum prompted a rally in the prices of oil futures yesterday.

title: AMONG LOBBYISTS, KIP, SON OF TIP, HAS AND EDGE
description: The way some see it, with the last name of O'Neill, being Kip, son of Tip, is like having a master key to doors on Capitol Hill. That is one advantage that the Washington lawyer and lobbyist Christopher (Kip) O'Neill, son of the House Speaker, Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., would appear to have over competitors.

title: A Town's Symbol To Be Torn Down
description: The century-old steeple atop the Dutch Reformed Church of Fairfield, the township's official emblem, will be torn down this week because dry rot has made it structurally unsafe, the church pastor said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Minority's Loss Was the Sergeant's Gain

title: Charlotte Curtis An Award for a Rothschild; Cocktails, dinner, introductions, violins, speeches and human rights.
description: THE Appeal of Conscience Foundation is an interfaith group concerned with religious freedom, and it gave its annual award to Baron Guy de Rothschild the other night at the Pierre Hotel. The black-tie dinner for 500 began with cocktails, a receiving line and the dazzling arrival of the Honorable Joanne Herring, the Houston heiress.

title: E.E.C.-China Talks
description: The European Economic Community and China failed in informal talks last week to agree on future export levels for Chinese textiles and garments to the Common Market, a spokesman for the community said today. Formal negotiations to renew a five-year accord are expected to begin next month.

title: TERA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Chess: West German Is the Leader In Kavkasian Tournament
description: Eric Lobron, a 23-year-old West German grandmaster, is virtually assured of first place in the Kavkasian International Tournament in New York. He has finished the event, held at the Kavkasian Restaurant, with a 9 1/2-4 1/2 score that no one else is expected to equal.

title: DANCE: KIBBUTZ TROUPE FROM ISRAEL
description: THIS might well be called Israeli dance year in New York. Seven troupes from Israel will have visited this city by the end of the season. And one of the best is likely to have been the Kibbutz Dance Company, which made an all- too-brief stop on Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, in the final performance of the company's first American tour.

title: CONTINENTAL INTERVIEWS PILOTS
description: Bargaining between Eastern Airlines and its flight attendants' union resumed today after a seven-hour break, and negotiators said they were hopeful they could beat a Thursday strike deadline.

title: Olympic Unit Plans Drug Tests
description: The United States Olympic Committee announced today details of a new testing program designed to eradicate the use of illegal or internationally banned drugs by American amateur athletes ''once and for all.''

title: THE DELICATE ART OF PLAY-BY-PLAY
description: Pairing successful sports announcing teams involves more than routinely designating a colorful play-by-play commentator with a thoughtful analyst. Like good doubles teams in tennis or skating, announcers must complement each other and bring out the best in each other at the expense of individual egos.

title: DANCE: WYNN IN DEBUT
description: THE Kevin Wynn Collection, a new dance group, came to the Merce Cunningham Studio Sunday night, and the energy of Mr. Wynn's dancers could have raised the roof.

title: NATIONAL BANCORP OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures reflect last Friday's 4-for-3 stock split.

title: SYRIA BACKS SITE OF LEBANON UNITY TALKS
description: -Efforts to organize a national reconciliation conference made progress today as Syria agreed to hold the meeting at the Lebanese presidential palace and the warring factions approved the use of Greek and Italian troops to monitor the two-week-old cease-fire.

title: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL PLANS TO VISIT NICARAGUA
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that a senior State Deparment official would go to Nicaragua this week to probe the intentions behind recent Nicaraguan diplomatic moves and to caution Managua not to send its troops into Honduras or Costa Rica.

title: An Output Dip in Garments
description: Production in the nation's women's and children's garment industry in the first seven months of 1983 dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent below the level in the comparable 1982 period, according to a report issued yesterday by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. But the decline actually represented an improvement compared with last year, when output fell 7 percent from the 1981 period's level, the union said.

title: BOXER AIMING HIGH AFTER A BIG UPSET
description: Instead of a health spa's getting a new customer, amateur boxing got a new star when a former high school football player, who had let himself get out of shape, went into the ring to lose weight.

title: A THEATRICAL REPUTATION OF LANDMARK STATUS
description: An Appreciation

title: JOHN GLENN ANSWERS MONDALE'S CRITICISM OF VOTE ON ECONOMY
description: Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, today responded to Walter F. Mondale's accusation that he had rallied behind ''Reaganomics.'' Mr. Glenn said the former Vice President shared the blame for ''failed and disastrous'' economic policies of former President Jimmy Carter.

title: 3 SLAIN IN RESTAURANT IN MOUNT KISCO
description: A father and his two sons were found shot to death today in a Chinese restaurant in this northern Westchester village, the police said.

title: Southern Medical
description: Beverly Enterprises said it had agreed in principle to acquire Southern Medical Services Inc. of Birmingham, Ala. Southern Medical operates 43 facilities with 4,916 beds in five states. Beverly, based in Pasadena, Calif., operates 735 facilities with 83,058 beds in 41 states and Washington, D.C. Terms were not disclosed.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HOMILY AT MASS FOR CARDINAL
description: Following are excerpts from a homily by William Cardinal Baum, former Archbishop of Washington, D.C., and personal representative of Pope John Paul II at the Mass of Christian Burial for Terence Cardinal Cooke yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral:

title: CARRIAN'S VAST NETWORK UNRAVELS IN HONG KONG
description: The vast, high-flying Carrian real estate empire is crumbling as spectacularly as it began three years ago.

title: NEW IMAGE FOR HELENE CURTIS
description: Things have been relatively quiet for Helene Curtis Industries since 1964, when it created considerable stir with its Magic Secret, a wrinkle preparation made from cow's blood. A drop or two of Magic Secret could mask crow's feet for up to eight hours, the company said, unless the wearer got caught in the rain.

title: GROUP BEHIND BOMBING IN RANGOON IS MYSTERY
description: The bomb that killed 19 people and wounded 48 in Rangoon on Sunday could have been planted either by Burmese dissidents or by North Korean terrorists, diplomatic sources in the Burmese capital said tonight.

title: Woman Jumps to Flee Fire
description: A fire injured at least two people today and destroyed eight downtown buildings, officials said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Mixing Bowls: More Than Art
description: Kay Leiland Strong, Vassar '33 and a member of Mary McCarthy's ''The Group,'' had ''a Russel Wright cocktail shaker in the shape of a skyscraper.'' She also had Russel Wright cups, blond Swedish chairs, steel standing lamps, a couch covered in mattress ticking and a folding table ''made of birch with natural finish.'' She loved them because they were new. Fifty years later, those who love them do so because they're old.

title: GENETIC PROCESS DUPLICATED IN LAB FOR FIRST TIME
description: AFTER years of experimentation in the laboratory, research scientists have duplicated one of the most important but mysterious of life processes. They have succeeded in ''splicing'' ribonucleic acid (RNA) - a crucial step in the production of protein in all human and animal cells.

title: Setback for Mays
description: Financial problems brought on by admittedly overambitious goals and inexperience have forced the closing of the California branch of the Willie Mays Say Hey Foundation, established to help underprivileged children. The year-old branch of the organization, whose New York office is still operational, was aimed at helping disadvantaged children in Palo Alto, Redwood City, San Mateo and Menlo Park through job counseling and scholarships.

title: Darien to Allow New Apartments
description: For the first time since the 1950's, this wealthy town has opened its doors to apartment builders in hopes of meeting the needs of an aging population.

title: Wreaths for Columbus And for the Cardinal
description: Twin wreaths were placed below the Christopher Columbus statue at Columbus Circle yesterday, in a somber, restrained ceremony on a bright, bracing day.

title: Oriolis' Singleton Out of Lineup
description: When the Philadelphia Phillies and the Baltimore Orioles play the first game of the World Series Tuesday night, the Orioles will have to open without a player who hit 18 home runs and drove in 85 runs this season.

title: China's Output Rises by 10.1%
description: China's industrial output climbed 10.1 percent in the first nine months of 1983, and the Government expects another good harvest this year, economic officials said today.

title: For Scarsdale H.S., Tradition of Success
description: ''There is a saying among Scarsdale residents that education is the village's major industry,'' said Liz Jaffe, president of the Parents Teachers Association at Scarsdale High School.

title: RATE WOES IN FARM BELT
description: Times are tough in the farm belt, especially for small farmers and their bankers. On top of the problem of getting repaid, many small banks are having to adjust to deregulation, which has driven up the cost of their funds. John A. O'Leary Jr. is close to many of these problems. Not only is he president and chief executive officer of the Peoples State Bank of Luray, Kan., which has $20 million in assets, but he also recently completed a one-year stint as the state's banking commissioner. Mr. O'Leary was interviewed at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which is being held in Honolulu.

title: Bear Creek Sale
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries said its R. J. Reynolds Development Corporation had agreed to acquire the Bear Creek Corporation for $39 a share, in a transaction valued at $74.1 million for the 1.9 million Bear Creek shares outstanding.

title: CONCERT: BEETHOVEN 9TH
description: LAST night's concert by the Boston Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall gave us, first of all, a progress report on a young ensemble hovering between its beginnings four years ago as a maverick community orchestra and its still-unrealized ambitions.

title: FOUNDING FATHERS' RELIGIOUS BELIEFS
description: To the Editor:

title: 13 Firefighters Injured in Jersey
description: A fire fueled by exploding chemical drums leveled a trucking company warehouse here today, injuring at least 13 firefighters and forcing 20 families within a five-block area to leave their homes.

title: 3 Group Vice Presidents Get Colgate Promotions
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it had promoted three executives to executive vice president in a move it said was designed to broaden management.

title: Vasco Jardim, Owned Portuguese Newspaper
description: Vasco S. Jardim, owner and publisher for 40 years of a weekly Portuguese-language newspaper, Luso- Americano, died of a heart attack last Wednesday at his home in Stirling, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE TOYOTA-G.M. VENTURE
description: Last February the Toyota Motor Corporation and the General Motors Corporation, the largest automobile producers in Japan and the United States, announced an agreement under which the two companies would jointly produce a new front-wheel- drive subcompact car at a now-closed G.M. plant in Fremont, Calif., near San Francisco.

title: Fire in a Substation Darkens Central Area of Los Angeles
description: A fire in a utility substation tonight knocked out power to more than a square mile of downtown, including a city hospital, officials said.

title: Transsexual's Marriage Challenged in Texas
description: A marriage license issued to a woman and a transsexual is being challenged by prosecutors who say it is not clear when a sex change operation legally takes effect.

title: CHAMBER: FOR LOVE OF MUSIC
description: IT was easy enough to accept the

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1983
description: International

title: 600-Year-Old Ming Bills Fetch $1,000 at Auction
description: The three oldest known banknotes in the world, all from the Chinese Ming dynasty of the late 14th century, were auctioned for a total of $1,000 today.

title: Q & A
description: Q. A picture in The Times (Aug. 30) of a lightning strike near the space shuttle launching pad was taken by a sound-operated camera. How could this be, since thunder follows lightning by about five seconds per mile?

title: TV: VICTIMS OF CRIMES
description: ''NIGHT PARTNERS,'' tonight's made-for-television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock, is set in Bakersfield, Calif., and is a fictionalized treatment of something that actually happened in Tucson, Ariz. The ways of television can be wondrously bizarre.

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
STEELERS RALLY TO TOP BENGALS
description: Ron Johnson and Harvey Clayton returned interceptions for fourth-quarter touchdowns tonight to help the Pittsburgh Steelers score a 24-14 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: ONLY 7 WOMEN HAVE WON NOBELS IN SCIENCE
description: UNTIL Barbara McClintock received the Nobel Prize in chemistry yesterday, only six women had become Nobel laureates in science among more than 350 winners since the prizes were inaugurated in 1901.

title: MUSINGS ON CANCER CURE
description: The doctor who discovered that at least two genetic changes were needed to turn normal cells into cancerous ones says the average life span would not increase appreciably even if a cure for cancer were found.

title: CENTRALIA'S BIG DAY: JAMES BRADY IS BACK
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, celebrated a joyous homecoming here today, giving his signature ''thumbs up'' sign to applauding townspeople who lined downtown Elm Street.

title: GOVERNORS REJECT ACID RAIN TAX BUT SEEK ACCELERATED U.S. EFFORT
description: Middle Western governors today rejected a tough statement calling for a national tax on emissions that cause acid rain, deciding instead on a milder request for an accelerated Federal program to reduce those emissions.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Paul Holmgren, the aggressive and talented wing of the Philadelphia Flyers, is expected to miss at least a month because of sprained ligaments in his left knee. . . . Elaine Zayak of Paramus, N.J., the former world figure-skating champion, withdrew from the Skate America competition in Rochester because of an ankle injury. . . . Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears has benched Jim McMahon and named Vince Evans to start at quarterback in next Sunday's game at Detroit. . . . World B. Free has signed a three-year contract with the Cleveland Cavaliers. The contract is reportedly worth as much as $1.7 million.

title: Census Bureau Finds Women Marry Later
description: Women are now marrying almost two years later than they did three decades ago, a Census Bureau report says, and are more likely to work and less likely to have children.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Koppitz, Writer And Consulting Psychologist
description: Dr. Elizabeth Munsterberg Koppitz, an author, lecturer and former consulting psychologist for the Northern Westchester and Putnam County Board of Cooperative Educational Services, died last Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: COUNTRYMEN OF BONES. By Robert Olen Butler. 217 pages. Horizon Press. $13.95.

title: PANEL URGES RISE IN TEACHERS WAGES
description: Immediate steps must be taken to raise the salaries of all teachers rather than concentrate only on rewarding some with merit pay, a Congressional study group said today.

title: Unions Challenge Continental Filing
description: The Airline Pilots Association, along with the two other unions on strike against Continental Air Lines, filed court papers seeking to dismiss the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition, a pilots' union official said.

title: Topics; Apologies and Alarms; Baby Non-Boom
description: Those children born in the post- World War II baby boom are now between the ages of, roughly, 17 and 37. That means they're all old enough to have babies of their own.

title: MANY ARE DIVIDED ON WATT'S LEGACY
description: In the 134- year history of the Department of the Interior, perhaps no Secretary of the Interior made so dramatic an impression in so short a time as did James G. Watt, his friends and foes agree.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTH KOREA BOMBING PLOT QUESTIONED
description: Some Asian and European diplomats here expressed doubt today that North Korea was responsible for the bomb explosion in Burma over the weekend that killed 20 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers.

title: TV: A GLIMPSE OF RICHARDSON IN BRITISH THRILLER
description: AS chance would have it, ''Charlie Muffin,'' a 1979 British spy thriller being shown on Channel 13 tonight at 8 o'clock, includes a brief, cameo appearance, tossed off with characteristic brilliance, by Sir Ralph Richardson, who died Monday in England at the age of 80. Sir Ralph's connections with television were many and varied, not to mention splendid. But more about that later.

title: CONCERT: SELMA EPSTEIN PLAYS THE PIANO
description: SELMA EPSTEIN, a pianist, devoted much of her recital in Alice Tully Hall Sunday night to compositions by relatively minor composers of her acquaintance.

title: JUDGES OVERTURN SERVICES METHODS IN CAPITAL CASES
description: The nation's highest military court today struck down the procedures used for sentencing members of the armed forces to death but said the President could remedy the constitutional defect without new legislation.

title: 5 Are Killed and 5 Kidnapped In Texas; Suspect Arrested
description: Five people, including a state trooper, were shot and killed and a sixth critically wounded today by a man who later kidnapped a family and stole a car before being captured near Houston, the authorities said.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $2,556,000 from the sale of the company's Popular Bank of Florida stock.

title: GAULT'S SPEED REVIVES BEARS
description: Ten days before his Chicago Bears were to open their National Football League season against the Atlanta Falcons, the head coach, Mike Ditka, sat in his office and talked about Willie Gault.

title: Ann C. Murphy Is Married To Elliott Vose, Executive
description: Ann Coswell Murphy and Elliott Evans Vose were married yesterday in New York. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. George S. Johnston, by Judge Richard M. Palmer of the Family Court.

title: Phillies 2 Orioles 1
description: Just as President Reagan was leaving Memorial Stadium tonight, Garry Maddox, the Phillies' Secretary of Defense, turned offensive and hit an eighth-inning home run that catapulted Philadelphia to a 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in the first game of the World Series.

title: FEMINIST'S MURDER TRIAL IS POSTPONED
description: A state district judge today postponed the murder trial of Ginny Foat, former president of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women, because of a front-page newspaper article that appeared Monday.

title: Jets And Giants Pay Ledbetter Tribute; 500 Attend Services
description: Players from the Giants and Jets attended the funeral service here today for Robert Lee (Bob) Ledbetter, who was the offensive backfield coach for both teams within the last year.

title: KEY TRONIC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-After a loss of $338,000 from discontinued operations.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (COLO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Negotiations Break Off In Chicago School Strike
description: Striking teachers and the Chicago Board of Education broke off contract talks today and the union vowed not to return to the bargaining table until teachers were offered more than a 0.5 percent salary increase.

title: Economic Scene; Jawboning And Volcker
description: IN the realm of economic policy, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has been called the second most powerful man in the country. Is this an understatement?

title: Agency Must Rethink Rules on Smokestacks
description: A Federal appeals court, in a ruling that could reduce acid rain pollution, today ordered the Reagan Administration to rewrite and toughen a complex set of regulations on industrial smokestacks.

title: OUR SCHOOLS' QUALITY IS AN INSIDE AFFAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GIVING HOLLYWOOD PARTY IS A SERIOUS BUSINESS
description: LOS ANGELESThe cold shrimp devoured at Hollywood parties since the middle of September might, if laid tail to tail, extend across the Santa Monica Mountains from 20th Century-Fox to Warner Bros.

title: WHAT VICE PRESIDENT?
description: The main talk here these days is about the potential Presidential candidates of 1984, but very little is being said about the potential Vice Presidential candidates. It's a topic worth considering.

title: Koch Changes His Diet
description: Since being felled briefly by what he described as a ''monster meal'' of spaghetti, veal parmigiana and wine on Sunday night, Mayor Koch has been eating carefully.

title: ROSEMARY B. BLACKMON
description: Rosemary Barnsdall Blackmon, managing editor of Vogue Magazine from 1962 to 1973, died in her sleep Sunday at her home in Provence, France.

title: Uganda, at U.N., Calls South Africa 'Volcano'
description: The Foreign Minister of Uganda said in a speech to the General Assembly today that the South African Government was ''sitting on an active volcano'' that ''is now showing signs everywhere of erupting.''

title: ROBERT M. LOVE, 74, FOUNDER OF ALLEGHENY AIRLINES CORP.
description: Robert MacClure Love, founder and former president of Allegheny Airlines Inc., died Sunday at his home in Pomfret, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: CCB FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: METS SAY JOHNSON IS NO. 1 CHOICE
description: Dave Johnson, who led the Tidewater farm club to the championship of the Class AAA minor leagues this season, is ''the prime candidate'' for manager of the Mets, Frank Cashen confirmed today.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT doesn't make elbows and insults in the subway any more pleasant, nor surly taxi drivers nor indifferent sales clerks; still it's nice to know that New York's reputation as a rude and uncaring city is apparently vastly exaggerated. It may even make some New Yorkers, who take a sort of perverse pride in living through it all, rather unhappy to hear that they are not unique. In short, as far as courtesy is concerned, life everywhere isn't what it once was and the Big Apple is pretty rosy.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
A Frustrated Page Settles for Tuneup
description: Greg Page, feeling as though all roads in the heavyweight division bypass him, is getting ready for his fight Saturday night against King Kong Kellar of Council Bluffs, Iowa, who recently lost to Gordon Racette. It's not much of a challenge for a man who, according to the easily stretched rules, should be fighting Larry Holmes next.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Adventist Health Unit Offers Revenue Bonds

title: CONCERT: MUTI CONDUCTS CARNEGIE HALL 'MACBETH'
description: SOME orchestras save their blockbusters for the climax of the season. Not the Philadelphia Orchestra, which opened its Carnegie Hall series last night with a concert performance of Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' the first opera the orchestra has essayed in nearly 50 years. It was enough to attract the expected full house, even if true-blue Philadelphians might have been expected to stay at home in front of their television sets for the first game of the World Series. As it happened, the Phillies won last night and so, by and large, did Riccardo Muti and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: AIRBUS GETS A320 ORDER FROM A BRITISH CARRIER
description: The often-delayed plans to begin production of a 150-passenger version of the European Airbus jetliner received a boost yesterday when British Caledonian Airways announced it would buy seven of the planes for $225 million.

title: Bengal Coach Upset
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers raved about their defense, which scored three touchdowns in a 24-14 victory over Cincinnati Monday night.

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After loss of $157,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ...AND RECRUIT FOR THE GOVERNMENT
description: President Reagan's most enduring impact here may not be his budget cuts or his vigilance against the Russians. His greatest legacy may be Steve Britt, Lennie L. Pickard, Robert W. Whitaker and Charles Kupperman.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $960,000 from a terminated pension plan.

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 14
FOOD NOTES
description: Pastry Shop

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: PEOPLES JEWELERS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a $1 million gain on sale of property and a $8,714,000 loss on sale of U.S. division.

title: Boy Is Charged With Murder Of Mother of Three in Texas
description: A 14- year-old boy who played hooky from school to drink beer with his friends has been charged with murdering a mother of three children, the authorities reported.

title: CANADIAN, KIDNAPPED TO STAND TRIAL IN FLORIDA, IS FREE ON BOND
description: Sidney Jaffe, a Canadian businessman seized by bounty hunters to stand trial in Florida, regained his freedom today when he was released on $150,000 bond.

title: BOOK PUBLISHERS AT FAIR ARE WARY
description: The cloudburst that soaked this city around noon Monday not only sent pedestrians scurrying for shelter but also dampened the spirits of people safely out of the rain.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $14,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock distribution in March.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the year-ago quarter and 9 months include a net charge of $6,231,000.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRENTWOOD TAKES 43 NASSAU INMATES
description: Governor Cuomo agreed today to accept the transfer of 43 county inmates to the state's prison at Brentwood, the former Pilgrim Psychiatric Center. Mr. Cuomo was faced with a Federal court order to help reduce overcrowding at the Nassau County jail.

title: GREAT AMER BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: RICHARDSON WAIVED BY NETS
description: Michael Ray Richardson was waived by the Nets yesterday after the National Basketball Association had informed them that he had refused to enter a rehabilitation center for treatment of cocaine abuse.

title: THE ONLY SOLUTION TO THE CAMBODIAN TRAGEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BETWEEN SUFFOLK EXECUTIVE CANDIDATES
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Peter F. Cohalan, a Republican who is seeking election to a second term as Suffolk County Executive, and his opponent, Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat:

title: PRICES INCREASED
description: The new Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir moved swiftly on the economic front today, devaluing the Israeli shekel by a total of 23 percent from its value Friday, raising prices of subsidized foods and offering a plan to protect investors in commercial bank stocks.

title: EX-ACADEMIC AND UNESCO OFFICER
description: Walter H. C. Laves, a political scientist who served as an official of Unesco, held several positions in the Federal Government and was a university lecturer and administrator, died Thursday in Bloomington, Ind. He was 81 years old.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $361,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Aide to Aquino Panel Identifies 2 in Dispute
description: Two soldiers who were guarding Benigno S. Aquino Jr. when he was assassinated and who had fired weapons about the time of the assassination were identified today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Either we will pay now or we will pay more later.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DELAY SET BY TEXAS INSTRUMENTS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that contrary to expectations it will not introduce a new home computer this year.

title: EXPORT ACT EXPIRATION DRAWS OLMER WARNING
description: An Administration official said today that the Government will continue to enforce controls on the export of American goods and technology after the law authorizing them expires at midnight Friday. With Congress in recess this week, there is no prospect that the Export Administration Act will be extended by Friday.

title: Lewis Will Replace Domingo in 'Troyens'
description: The tenor William Lewis will substitute for Placido Domingo in tonight's Metropolitan Opera performance of ''Les Troyens.'' Mr. Lewis, who is the cover for the role of Aeneas, will also sing the role on Oct. 17.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DETROIT MUSEUM AUDIT DISCOVERS 'DEFICIENCIES'
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit said today that a special city audit of the Detroit Institute of Arts had disclosed that there were ''administrative deficiencies which need to be dealt with and corrected.''

title: FRENCH-LIBYAN RELATIONS WORSEN
description: Relations between France and Libya have worsened, with Libya keeping 37 French citizens from leaving the country and France telling the Libyan envoy here that the action was ''unacceptable.''

title: NEW TRIAL ALLOWED IN PHONE SUIT
description: The Supreme Court today let stand an appeals court's order for a new trial to set damages in the MCI Communications Corporation's nine-year-old antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: DOW DOWN 19.51 AFTER RATES RISE
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday in moderate trading, depressed mainly by a surge in interest rates in the credit markets.

title: BROTHER OF A RAPIST ENDS SUIT BY PAYING $475,000 TO VICTIM
description: A rape victim from Manhattan settled a suit yesterday against the rapist's twin brother for $475,000.

title: DR. SIDNEY A. FOX
description: Dr. Sidney A. Fox, a retired ophthalmologist and a benefactor of the Brown University Medical School, died Saturday of a heart ailment at his home in Manhattan.

title: WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $326,000 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $35,000.

title: ARISTOTLE'S VIEW OF THE PROPER ROLE OF ANGER
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: O'Neill-Smith Feud

title: CONCERT: MEHTA CONDUCTS
description: WITH the New York Philharmonic's season a month old, Zubin Mehta rejoined the orchestra last night and conducted it in a muscular, frequently gripping performance of Mahler's massive Symphony No. 5. The Philharmonic's music director had delayed his return to lead a tour of the Israel Philharmonic, of which he is music director for life, and to preside over the opening concerts of that orchestra's new season. It seems that there simply are not enough music directors to go around nowadays. Even if you are the New York Philharmonic, time-sharing is called for.

title: Topics Apologies and Alarms
description: The FWOTSC

title: Carly Simon Is Planning Feature - Length Videodisk
description: ESTABLISHED pop stars who have watched how MTV has helped spur the careers of dozens of new rock acts are beginning to take the marriage of video and rock very seriously. Just how seriously is suggested by Carly Simon's decision to film a feature-length video music project for RCA Videodiscs. It will be the company's first full-length video program starring a major pop performer.

title: TRANSWORLD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WINE TALK
description: THE great California wine glut is disappearing. Even experienced grape growers and wine makers are astonished at the speed with which a huge surplus has turned into a shortage. ''I've been in this business a long time,'' said Rodney Strong of Sonoma Vineyards in Windsor, ''and I've never seen anything like this. I figured it would take three years for the market to balance out, and it's happening virtually overnight.''

title: DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $172,000 for the quarter and $304,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $114,000 for the quarter and $17,000 for the 6 months.

title: New Breed Of Military Reformer...
description: An Under Secretary of Defense calls them ''the new breed of military reformers'' and says that resisting them poses a problems similar to ''being against motherhood.''

title: Abortion Foe Sentenced For Florida Clinic Fires
description: An opponent of abortion who abducted an Illinois doctor and his wife has been sentenced to 30 years in prison for setting fire to two abortion clinics here.

title: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1983
description: International

title: UNION NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BANCAL TRI-STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,928,000.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Rates Jump; Fed's Stand Cited;  3-Month Bill Up to 8.83%
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday because of widespread disapointment that the Federal Reserve has not acted more vigorously to encourage declines in short-term interest rates.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net income after a loss of $16,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including a gain of $328,000 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $117,000 from discontinued operations.

title: JAZZ-FUNK: CRUSADERS
description: -funk group, has changed drummers after more than two decades, leaving just two charter members, Joe Sample on keyboards and Wilton Felder on saxophones. The new lineup, with Leon Chancler (Ndugu) on drums, has considerable potential, but the group had not jelled for its show last Saturday in the Beacon Theater.

title: Dutch Jobless a Record
description: Dutch unemployment, seasonally adjusted, rose to a postwar record of 825,200 in September from 821,800 in August, provisional social affairs ministry figures showed today.

title: GOODBYE, CENTRAL: CRANK PHONE DIES
description: BRYANT POND,

title: AFTER YEARS OF DECLINE, SWEATSHOPS ARE BACK
description: In the area of Roosevelt Avenue and 108th Street in Corona, Queens, and in other immigrant neighborhoods around New York, a new industry has emerged in recent years. It is the sweatshop.

title: Charges Against Boggs
description: Tommy Boggs, the former Atlanta Braves pitcher released earlier this month because of a sore arm, has been charged with placing bets with bookmakers in Decatur, Ga.

title: Late and Lame on Legal Services
description: For the first time since his inaugural vows to execute the laws faithfully, President Reagan has complied with the Legal Services Corporation Act of 1974. It requires him to nominate 11 directors of the federally funded poverty law program. Mr. Reagan wants the program abolished, but Congress won't oblige, so he tried to starve it with budget cuts, inexperienced administrators and the recess appointment of directors who would never survive a Senate confirmation hearing.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Sales are from continuing operations.

title: PENTAGON CITES SHIFT IN FRAUD INVESTIGATIONS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today cited a military contractor's plea of guilty to 25 counts of fraud as a milestone in the Pentagon's campaign against such fraud.

title: Conatitutional Views
description: Abortion should not have been made a constitutional question, Federal Judge Whitman Knapp said yesterday. It should have been legislated state by state, he said, but the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion had created ''polarization'' that was ''unhealthy for our country.''

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Advertising; Drug Drive Outlined to First Lady
description: NANCY REAGAN visited Needham, Harper & Steers yesterday to preview its two-pronged advertising attack on drug abuse, her favorite cause.

title: GULF OIL IN MOVE TO THWART 'WOLF'
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it would reorganize as a Delaware holding company. A Gulf spokesman, Keith A. Anderson, said the reorganization was designed to prevent a ''Wall Street wolf'' from ''shooting his way onto the board.''

title: CORN DOG A STANDBY AT TEXAS STATE FAIR
description: DALLAS LIKE the Earl of Sandwich or a blind Benedictine monk named Dom Perignon, who is credited with creating the first true Champagne, Neil Fletcher was a man with an idea. Unlike the others, he is still around to talk about it.

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SMITH, A O, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The share earnings reflect 50 percent stock dividend on Sept. 30, 1983.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Grand Union Co., Elmwood Park, N.J., has named Anthony P. Misasi vice president in charge of produce merchandising and operations.

title: BACHE AIDE IS ARRESTED IN $5 MILLION THEFT CASE
description: A manager in the stock dividend department of Prudential-Bache Securities was arrested yesterday and charged in connection with the theft of more than $5 million from the investment firm, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Almaden Ex-Manager Heads Geyser Winery
description: John P. McClelland, who resigned last week as president and general manager of Almaden Vineyards Inc., has been named chairman and chief executive of Geyser Peak Winery, a smaller privately held northern California company.

title: THE DEATH PENALTY'S IRON LAW
description: Events have conspired to give the death penalty a bad name.

title: Islanders 5 Kings 2
description: The Islanders unveiled their 1983-84 team to the home fans tonight with shining lights and trophies, a new Stanley Cup banner for the Nassau Coliseum rafters and a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Wells, Rich Wins MGM/UA Account
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has won the MGM/UA Entertainment Company account for marketing, planning and media placement and is starting a new entertainment division around it.

title: SRI LANKA INVESTIGATING BURMA BOMBING LINK
description: Sri Lanka authorities have begun an investigation into whether a North Korean ship ordered out of Sri Lanka last week was linked with the bombing in Burma on Sunday that killed 19 people, including several South Korean officials.

title: Introductions Surge
description: The first nine months of 1982 marked the first such period when new product introductions broke the 1,000 barrier, with a total of 1,074. This year introductions surged ahead of that mark with 1,341, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. And in September, as in each month this year, totals were ahead of the comparable month last year, 136 to 120.

title: Argentina's Inflation Skyrockets to 924%
description: Argentine consumer price inflation last month soared to an annual rate of 924 percent, according to the Government, the highest since just after the military took power in a coup more than seven years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about changes in the Roman Catholic mass misstated the church's position on permitting non- Catholics to receive communion. Although there are times when they are permitted to do so at a mass, widespread approval has not been given.

title: WHEN BONDS DEFAULT
description: To the Editor:

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHINA CLOSING IN ON MAOIST REMMNANTS
description: China's Communist Party is about to mount an extensive drive to examine the loyalty of its 40 million members and discipline or expel those who oppose the policies of Deng Xiaoping.

title: Pretoria Charter Opposed
description: Harry Oppenheimer, the industrialist and former chairman of the Anglo American Corporation, said today that the proposed constitution was a step backward because it continued to exclude the black majority.

title: SUN BANKS N A reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPUTED ORGANIZED CRIME HEADS NAMED IN CASINO SKIMMING CASE
description: A Federal indictment made public yesterday accuses purported Mafia leaders in three Middle Western cities of using their influence to get teamsters' union pension fund loans that enabled them to become secret owners of Las Vegas casinos.

title: ALABAMA PASS CALL REVIEWED
description: Jack O'Rourke, an assistant superintendent of a small-town Ohio school system, may be remembered as fondly in Alabama as the boll weevil.

title: WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Osborne Contract
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, which has been holding takeover talks with several companies since it filed for reorganization under bankruptcy laws, announced a service contract with the Xerox Corporation that includes the sale of $1 million in spare parts. Osborne's president, Robert Jaunich, said the agreement would ''help stabilize and restore customer confidence'' in Osborne.

title: Koch Appoints Adviser
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that he had appointed Oliver J. Gray as a special adviser on race relations, immigration and public education. Mr. Gray, 42 years old, has been an assistant vice president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, specializing in community and patient relations, since 1978.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bridge: Italian Team Reveals Signs Of Slippage Over the Years
description: In bygone years, when Italy dominated the world bridge scene, the Italian players often seemed to find the right moment to play three no-trump when an eight-card fit in a major suit was available.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Too Many Debts, Too Many Crises
description: How many more crises can the world's financial system survive? Political stability everywhere depends on its surviving every challenge, but the odds on its doing so decline with every new shock.

title: CRITICS AND CURVES DON'T STOP MORGAN
description: The symbol of everything that was wrong with the Philadelphia Phillies this season, and all that was right with them tonight, was Joe Morgan: 5 feet 7 inches tall and 40 years old.

title: MUSIC: 17TH-CENTURY ENGLISH SONGS
description: THE resurgent interest in early music has led to a proliferation of worthy performing groups throughout the city. On Sunday afternooon at St. Michael's Church, one of the most promising of these, an ensemble called Musick's Monument, offered several selections from the English composer John Dowland's 1612 collection of songs entitled ''A Pilgrimes Solace.''

title: Chairman Resigns At Baldwin-United
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, which is seeking to reorganize under the bankruptcy laws, said yesterday that Max H. Karl had resigned as chairman.

title: Brazil Asks Rise in Loans
description: The Brazilian Government today asked about 120 American bankers attending the annual convention of the American Bankers Association here to increase their loans to Brazil by 11 percent of levels at the end of 1982.

title: Gaulke to Gannett
description: Gaulke to Gannett

title: MORRIS HALPERN
description: Morris Halpern, a Manhattan restaurateur for three decades, died Sept. 29 at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., after a brief illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif., in the house he bought from President Reagan in 1981 after moving from Great Neck, L.I.

title: Kirkland Is Criticized On Warning to Printers
description: The president of the International Typographical Union has criticized as ''unfortunate and premature'' a warning by Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., that the printers' union could be ousted from the labor federation if it merged with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: NEW YORK VOTERS HAVE TWO DAYS TO REGISTER
description: Polling places in New York City and the neighboring suburbs will be open tomorrow and Saturday for registration to vote in the Nov. 8 election.

title: The Indirect Approach
description: ''When you're a white-collar worker, you can't shut down an assembly line,'' Bernice Krawczyk said yesterday as she stood with a line of chanting pickets in front of the Lincoln Savings Bank at 20 West 48th Street. ''So you have to find another way to pressure a company.''

title: Achieving Goal Of a Lifetime
description: Win or lose the World Series, the ''baseball brat'' who runs the Philadelphia Phillies has the prize of a lifetime back home on his mantelpiece in in Villanova, Pa.

title: Dierdorf's Last Season
description: The spirit was willing, and so was most of the flesh.

title: HYTEK MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIDE OF CHANGE LAPS AT THE THAMES'S SOUTH BANK
description: ''The English suffer from a particularly disabling disease,'' Cedric Price said the other day, letting his architect's mind frame each word into a construction that he admired as it took shape. ''Once something has lost its purpose we immediately romanticize it. That's the trouble with the Thames.''

title: Father Gets 50 Years For Daughter's Slaying
description: A blind man, who acted the part of a grieving father and was showered with gifts after his 11-year-old daughter was slain, has confessed the murder and was sentenced Monday to 50 years in prison.

title: Key Rates
Greeks Protest Over NATO Games
description: The Greek Government said today that a protest had been sent to the United States Government over what it termed a series of violations in recent days and in some cases ''blatant infringements'' of Greek airspace by American jetfighters during NATO maneuvers in the eastern Mediterranean.

title: KILLINGS DOMINATE TALK ON SOUTH PHILIPPINE ISLAND
description: In this centuries-old seaport on the southern island of Mindanao, a large ''crime chart'' with red lettering is mounted over the entrance to the gray stone city hall.

title: TWO ENTER RUNOFF FOR BOSTON MAYOR
description: Melvin H. King, a black former State Representative, and Raymond L. Flynn, a member of the City Council, won the mayoral primary today, marking a historic shift in Boston politics. They will meet in the November general election.

title: Mixed Feelings
description: ''You don't take a great deal of pleasure in a victory like that,'' said Jeff Scalf, the coach of Batesville after a 115-0 triumph over North Decatur in a football game last week between southeastern Indiana high schools.

title: XICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRUSE SHUNS SITE FOR MEETING
