description: Efforts to bring about negotiations among Lebanon's warring factions suffered a setback today when a key figure said he would not attend any meeting at the presidential palace outside Beirut.

title: U.S. SAYS MOSCOW THREATENS TO QUIT TALKS OF MISSILES
description: Administration officials said today that they were preparing for the possibility that the Soviet Union might soon suspend negotiations with the United States on limiting missiles in Europe.

title: LUXURY STRATEGY AT MERCEDES
description: Mercedes- Benz will introduce its new, downsized ''baby Benz'' model 190 on Oct. 19. It is 2 feet shorter and 1,000 pounds lighter than the company's full-size 380SE model, and gasoline-powered versions of it will get 26 miles a gallon in city driving, compared with 18 for the larger car.

title: American Express
description: The American Express Credit Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for the sale of up to $600 million of debt securities. Underwriters were not named. A spokesman for the company said proceeds would be used to reduce short-term debt, and said the financing was not related to the American Express Company's recent agreement to acquire Investors Diversified Services.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HARRY GOLDEN'S cry, ''Only in New York,'' is echoed with such regularly in the strange, sad, funny, ironic, silly, improbable and touching letters dropped in our box that we tend to tune it out. Surely, we think, there are other large cities and even small towns where life occasionally takes the same curious turns and where people shake their heads and remark, say, ''Only in Ashtabula.''

title: TRUST COMPANY OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to include operations of a bank acquired during 1983 on a pooling-of- interests basis.

title: SOYUZ ACCIDENT QUIETLY CONCEDED
description: Soviet officials have now privately admitted that a Soviet rocket exploded on its launching pad two weeks ago and that three astronauts were jettisoned to safety by emergency escape rockets.

title: Deal Squelched
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates were looking for some help in their drive for the championship of the National League's Eastern Division, and the San Francisco Giants were willing to provide it, for a price. But when the two clubs agreed on a deal that would have brought the outfielder Jack Clark and the pitcher Gary Lavelle to the Pirates in late August, Chub Feeney, the president of the National League, said no.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Dr. Harry Grundfest; Professor of Neurology
description: Dr. Harry Grundfest, professor emeritus of neurology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and who researched the nervous system, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan and Woods Hole, Mass.

title: Careers; A Need for Strategic Planners
description: CHIEF executive officers, perhaps because of the recession, perhaps also because of competition from the Japanese, have changed their attitude toward strategic planning: They want more control over it.

title: COURT EXTENDS REPORTERS' PROTECTION AGAINST LIBEL
description: A Federal appeals court decided yesterday that journalists were protected from libel for accurately reporting newsworthy accusations, even if the accusations involved secret grand-jury proceedings.

title: N.Y.U.'S FUND DRIVE DRAWS $70 MILLION
description: New York University, a little more than halfway through a two-year, $100 million fund-raising campaign, announced yesterday that it had received $70 million in donations since Sept. 1, 1982.

title: Dunes Hotel Deal
description: Clifford and Stuart Perlman propose to assume a 46 percent controlling interest of the Dunes Hotel and Country Club in exchange for a $34 million debt owed them by the resort. The sales agreement requires that the transaction close by Dec. 31, and that employees take 20 percent of their salary in stock for about two years.

title: TOP SUFFOLK CANDIDATES SQUARE OFF IN A DEBATE
description: The two major candidates for Suffolk County Executive debated the issues of the campaign for the first time yesterday, with each taking stands more commonly associated with the other's political party.

title: Blood Donations
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Q&A
description: Q. Once in a while a recipe calls for whole, unpeeled garlic cloves. Why would this be preferable to chopped or minced garlic?

title: MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The lower per share earnings in the latest quarter reflects a $1.7 million preferred dividend requirement that did not exist in the year-earlier period. It also reflects a greater number of common shares outstanding as a result of the acquisition of Girard Co. and Mortgage & Trust Inc.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 'CONTINUED ASSAULT' ON FURTWANGLER'S MEMORY
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. NET UP 10.6% IN 3D QUARTER
description: The General Electric Company, citing a gain in operating margins, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter of 1983 rose 10.6 percent, while sales edged up 2.5 percent.

title: Bass, Niarchos Named To the Board of Modern
description: The Museum of Modern Art has named Sid Richardson Bass and Stavros Spyros Niarchos as trustees of the museum.

title: NEWHOUSE'S PRIVATE EMPIRE
description: A $900 million Federal tax case against the estate of Samuel I. Newhouse has opened a small window into the affairs of the very private company that he had built into one of the nation's largest newspaper, magazine and broadcast empires.

title: Tribune Offering
description: The Tribune Company is making an initial public offering of seven million shares at $26.75 each, through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The Tribune Company, based in Chicago, owns The Daily News in New York City, The Chicago Tribune and other newspapers and broadcast units.

title: Vote for New York's Transport Bond
description: No one who has sweated in a sealed commuter rail car with broken air-conditioning, or worried that bridge girders are flawed, or stumbled over potholes doubts the necessity of refurbishing New York State's transportation system. Is the $1.25 billion bond issue on November's ballot the way to do it? Some say no, but until they offer a better way, the bonds deserve firm support.

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: Saga's fiscal 1983 financial statements have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Grandy's which has been accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: COLUMBIA ENTERS NEW ERA WITH COMPUTER CENTER
description: Far away and long ago, before silicon chips, Robert Spinrad sat in the basement of an engineering building at Columbia University and built a primitive computer. The 21-year-old student was proud of his clunky black box, which could add and subtract, but his classmates were unimpressed.

title: ALASKA MUTUAL BANK (ANCHORAGE, ALASKA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable per share figure was not available since the company converted from a mutual bank in the first quarter of 1982.

title: Crownless Chapeaus, Initialed Patholder
description: 1. Crowned with Glory

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday with an article about James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, misidentified two people riding with him. His daughter, Melissa, was at the right; Heather Reichenbacher, a family friend, was at the left.

title: 3 ON KISSINGER PANEL MEET ANTI-SANDINISTA CHIEF
description: Members of President Reagan's commission on Central America, apparently in a change of plans, met today with a leading member of a rebel group fighting to overthrow Nicaragua's Sandinista Government.

title: WEINBERGER IS REPORTED TO REBUKE TOP AIDE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger called in the Secretary of the Navy today to rebuke him for making public his differences with the Deputy Secretary of Defense over the Navy's proposed 1985 budget, according to Pentagon officials.

title: Market Place; Behind the Rise In A. H. Robins
description: LAST week, 243 issues posted new highs for the last 52 weeks or longer on the New York Stock Exchange. Electric utilities were well represented, thanks to renewed buying of moderate- growth, interest-sensitive shares. International Business Machines, the pacesetter of the bull market, rose to record levels.

title: ALVARADO SAYS SCHOOLS NEED $1 BILLION MORE
description: The sudden and intense focus on American education will mean little unless government provides money to pay for the improvements so many experts say are a necessity, a group of leading New York City educators, politicians and union leaders said yesterday.

title: EIGHT CHILDREN'S TV SHOWS ASSAILED
description: A television consumer group today charged that the nation's television stations were broadcasting children's programs that were ''program-length advertisements.'' The group contended that the practice violated both Federal law and the regulations and policies of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Bobby Baker, Johnson Aide, Can Present New Evidence
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ordered a district judge today to reopen the 17-year-old fraud and tax evasion case against Bobby Baker and consider new evidence.

title: Oilers Name Studley
description: Chuck Studley, defensive coordinator of the Houston Oilers, was named interim successor to Coach Ed Biles, who announced his resignation Monday after 13 straight regular-season losses. Studley, 54, spent six seasons as coach at the University of Cincinnati before joining the Bengals as an aide in 1968. He was named Oilers' defensive coordinator in January after holding a similar post four years with San Francisco.

title: Poland's Rulers Call Prize an Embarrassment
description: Poland's Government spokesman said today that most Poles were embarrassed by the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity union.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 12, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. CONCERNED BY DELIVERY OF FRENCH WARPLANES TO IRAQ
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were increasingly concerned that shipments of oil from the Persian Gulf might be disrupted by Iran now that five French Super Etendard jet fighters have been delivered to Iraq.

title: L.I. DIVERS FIND SHIP SAID TO BE VANDERBILT'S
description: A marine research team said yesterday that it had discovered the wreck of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt's elegant, silver-laden passenger and cargo ship, the Lexington, which burned and sank in Long Island Sound more than 140 years ago.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNDERAPPRECIATED: THE HUMBLE PRUNE
description: IT'S impossible to say ''stewed prunes'' with a smile on your face. There you have the problem. Prunes, lacking the cachet of the kiwi or the glow of the peach, suffer from a poor public image in this country, dating at least from the 1940's when the cartoon detective Dick Tracy faced a mean and severely wrinkled adversary named Pruneface.

title: CHECKPOINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: REMOVE THE BASES FROM THE PHLIPPINES
description: In a climate of explosive Philippine nationalism and gathering anti-Americanism, President Ferdinand E. Marcos is counting on what he sees as his trump card: an implicit threat to cut off United States access to military bases at Clark Field and Subic Bay and the communications center at San Miguel. Mr. Marcos hopes to use this leverage to guarantee American support for his increasingly embattled regime. In fact, it is a trump card without value. These bases are not essential and we would be better served to move our facilities to safer, stabler ground elsewhere in the region.

title: HEAVY-DUTY BAKEWARE
description: AS Bryan Miller and I emphasized in an article last week on seeking the most for your money when buying kitchen utensils, it is essential to consider quality over quantity. This applies not only to major items but also to accessories. I have always had a high regard for the commercial baking equipment made by Chicago Metallic in Lake Zurich, Ill., whose products have never chipped, peeled, rusted or deteriorated. Under the name Bakalon the company has offered quality bakeware for home use.

title: PROFESSOR MAKES PLEA BARGAIN
description: Paul Arthur Crafton, who sprang into national headlines when he was charged with simultaneously maintaining identities as professors at two Pennsylvania state colleges 75 miles apart, has arranged a plea bargain, his lawyer said today.

title: Some Things Never Change
description: When everyone was much younger, the Pennsylvania Hotel's telephone number was PEnnsylvania 6-5000 and Glenn Miller's band made a hit song with that title. The Pennsylvania, at Seventh Avenue and 32d Street, became the New York Statler and now, under ownership of a group headed by the builder Abe Hirschfeld, it is the New York Penta. And the telephone number - you could try it - is 736-5000.

title: China Joins Agency That Inspects Reactors
description: China today became the 112th member of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which operates safeguards and inspections on civil nuclear reactors.

title: THEATER: LEN JENKIN DIRECTS 'MY UNCLE SAM'
description: THOUGH there may be theatergoers who will love Len Jenkin's ''My Uncle Sam,'' I suspect that its biggest fan will always be Mr. Jenkin himself. This theater piece is the creation of a writer who so adores his own voice that he insists on sharing his every thought with the audience - even when his unedited reveries trail off into inanity and irrelevance. And by serving as his own director, Mr. Jenkin raises self-indulgence to an exponential power. Not only will he write a pointless joke about, say, a ship called the S. S. Guernsey, he'll also instruct the sound man to punch up the gag with a chorus of moos.

title: JUSTICES TO CONSIDER ACCESS TO PESTICIDE DATA
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a recent Federal law that gives the public access to health and safety data about new pesticides that have been submitted for Federal approval.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF THE FLORIDA KEYS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,652,000 for the quarter and $3,906,000 for the 9 months.

title: Coleco's Adam
description: A Boston-area retailer, Herb Kline, the president of Markline Inc., said that Coleco Industries had told him it would begin shipping the long-delayed Adam computer on Monday. A spokesman for Coleco would neither confirm nor deny the report, but said the company stood by its plans to begin shipments in mid-October.

title: WASHINGTON STATE HOLDS PRIMARIES
description: Early returns tonight in Washington's special senatorial primary appeared to give Senator Daniel J. Evans the Republican nomination, while Representative Mike Lowry was leading for the Democratic nomination.

title: President Sent a Letter I P o C
description: President Reagan's representative to the funeral of Terence Cardinal Cooke carried a letter of mourning that praised the Cardinal for his staunch stance against abortion, authorities said yesterday.

title: NEW RESEARCH ON THE VEGETARIAN DIET
description: HE central question about vegetarian diets used to be whether it was healthy to eliminate meat and other animal foods, which are rich sources of essential nutrients, especially complete protein, iron and vitamin B-12. Now, however, the main question has become whether it is healthier to be a vegetarian than to be a meat eater. With more than 10 million Americans (most of them young) saying they are vegetarians and millions of others limiting their consumption of meat and poultry, those are important health questions for the people involved and the society at large.

title: THOUSANDS TAKE TO STREET IN CHILE IN NEW ANTI-GOVERNMENT PROTEST
description: Thousands of Chileans gathered near the center of Santiago this evening in what was described as one of the largest and most militant anti-Government protests in 10 years of military rule.

title: WOMAN AND CHAIR
description: Pressed by Democratic women to say whether they would accept a female Vice Presidential candidate on their tickets, the touring Presidential hopefuls, all men, take the easy way out by saying sure they would. Why shouldn't they? In politics as in baseball, when somebody feeds you a big, fat, soft pitch right down Broadway you knock it out of the park.

title: Suspect Is Still at Large In Mt. Kisco Shootings
description: The police in this northern Westchester village were still looking today for a man they suspected of having shot and killed three men in a restaurant Monday.

title: Power Blackout Strikes Downtown Los Angeles
description: A power station explosion Monday blacked out a two-square-mile section of the downtown business area for up to 17 hours, idling thousands of workers today and costing companies millions of dollars in lost production.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK (SEATTLE, WASH) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Paine Webber Inc. To Offer Bonds
description: Paine Webber Inc. filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $500 million of bonds collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association pass-through securities. The bonds would be issued by Programmed Amortization Term Securities Inc. and would be underwritten by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. as sole underwriter.

title: Nets' Cook Signs Pact
description: Darwin Cook, the Nets' free-agent guard, signed a new four-year contract for about $1.5 million yesterday, just 24 hours after threatening to leave training camp because of a discrepancy between a draft and an oral agreement that he had made with the team last week.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $80,000 for the quarter and $330,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary gains of $60,000 for the quarter and $400,000 for the year.

title: THE DEMPSEY DIAZ AFFAIR
description: Ten years ago, during winter ball in Maracaibo, Venezuela, Rick Dempsey saved the life of Bo Diaz. Last night they were the starting catchers on opposing teams in the World Series, Dempsey for the Orioles, Diaz for the Phillies. But back then, Dempsey was the first-string catcher for Caracas, and Diaz was his backup catcher.

title: UTILITIES ARE ALLOWED, NOT GUARNANTEED, A PROFIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Santa Fe Delay On Conrail Bid
description: Santa Fe Industries is still considering a bid for Conrail, Santa Fe's chairman and chief executive, John J. Schmidt, said, but the bid will be delayed because of Santa Fe's plan to merge with the Southern Pacific Company.

title: New Safety Rules At Building Sites
description: The city's Buildings Department will have the power to stop work at construction sites when protective sidewalk sheds are taken down before all exterior hoisting and lowering is completed, under a law signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JUST PIANO AND BASS

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Argentine Debt Meeting Held
description: Members of Argentina's 11- bank advisory group met yesterday at the law offices of Shearman & Sterling in New York to consider how to proceed in rescheduling some $7 billion worth of principal payments due this year and next from about about 30 Argentine state-owned agencies.

title: Furry Offerings at the Bank
description: There was a little extra diversion yesterday for the people in the line that inched up to the tellers at the Chemical Bank branch at Madison Avenue and 52d Street - cages of dogs and cats.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Berry, English Updates
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn refused yesterday to dismiss a suit filed against the National Collegiate Athletic Association by St. John's and Walter Berry, a former high school star who sought to play basketball at the university but was ruled academically ineligible. The N.C.A.A. requested the dismissal because Berry is now attending another school, San Jacinto Junior College in Pasadena, Tex.

title: BLACK CHALLENGE TO PRETORIA: REBELLION,STILL PUNY, IS SHOWING MORE MUSCLE
description: The South African authorities seem constantly torn between an urge to magnify the threat posed to the white Government by the underground African National Congress and a desire to belittle it.

title: DISHES OF WHICH MEMORY IS MADE
description: THERE are certain dishes that captivate the appetite so powerfully they give pleasure even in reminiscence. In 1961, I made a trip to France, and for the first time I had enough money to enjoy some of the two- and three-star restaurants of that country. We traveled through Burgundy and down to Marseilles, stopping as the Guide Michelin dictated our journey, and wound up for lunch one sun-drenched day at the Baumani ere restaurant in Les Baux-de-Provence, where we dined from the kitchen of Raymond Thuilier.

title: TANAKA IS GUILTY IN BRIBERY TRIAL
description: Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka was found guilty today of having accepted $2.1 million in bribes to arrange the purchase of Lockheed aircraft by Japan's largest domestic airline.

title: UNION DISTRIBUTES FIRST FUNDS FOR RELIEF OF JOBLESS MINERS
description: The United Mine Workers of America has distributed about $70,000 as the first payments from a fund set up for unemployed miners, the union has announced.

title: Hamburger Quest
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Wigmores Bid
description: Wigmores Ltd.'s takeover offer for the Broken Hill Proprietary Company has expired with less than 1 percent of Broken Hill shares being tendered. Wigmores, a small western Australian tractor marketing company owned by Robert Holmes A'Court, had offered $3.8 billion in United States funds for Broken Hill's 340 million shares outstanding. But analysts, noting that Broken Hill has a market value 10 times that of its suitor, have questioned all along whether the bid was a serious one.

title: THE FAMILY
description: AS families go, the Bayers are among the blessed. That's how they think of it. Shirley Bayer and her husband of 11 years, Jack, enlarged upon this theme on a golden September afternoon, as they sat in the backyard of their trim white house with its startling view of the Pompton River and the wooded hills to the west. ''Jack and I have shared so much,'' she said. ''We have two beautiful, healthy boys. We're really very lucky. A lot of women don't have all the things I have.''

title: APPETITES WHETTED AT ORCHARD
description: Two hundred Manhattan nursery-school children were unleashed on the 350 unsuspecting apple trees of Duryea's Farm here today in an unequal contest that has become something of a fall ritual for a number of New York City schools and institutions.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net for the year-earlier periods include a gain of $2.4 million, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of certain mortgage loan servicing during the first quarter of 1982. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: VINEGAR is not often thought of as a principal ingredient in cooking. Most people probably view it as something to put in a salad. Yet there are many dishes in which vinegar - red, white or flavored - plays an important role: the sweet-and-sour dishes of the world, from Germany to China; steamed mussels, sautees of chicken.

title: QUOTATION BUREAU IS LEAVING WALL ST. FOR JERSEY CITY
description: When the National Quotation Bureau went into business in 1913, it used runners to go from one brokerage house to another to collect the stock quotes it printed on the daily ''pink sheets'' sold to stock dealers.

title: HIGH COURT'S '9 MEN' WERE A SURPRISE TO ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW MEANS TO MOBILIZE LABOR TRIED
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is moving to harness the power of television, computers and other advanced technology in an ambitious effort to improve its ability to mobilize organized labor.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $57.9 million for the quarter and $131.7 million for the 9 months. c-Net income after tax credits of $9.7 million for the quarter and $16.6 million for the 9 months. The year-earlier revenue figures include a nonrecurring gain of $180.6 million from the sale of natural gas rights.

title: Fairbanks Waits
description: Chuck Fairbanks, the president and coach of the New Jersey Generals during their first season in the United States Football League, is in a state of limbo. The franchise, including Fairbanks's minority ownership, which has been estimated at around 10 percent, was sold last month to Donald J. Trump, a real estate executive.

title: Du Pont Assets
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has been approached about the sale of Conoco Inc.'s chemical assets, which it bought in 1981, but has made no decision on whether to sell them, a company spokesman said.

title: JAPAN'S DRUG INDUSTRY SCANDAL SOLE REVIVAL
description: Senior executives pursuing their corporate dreams woith bribes; Government watchdogs with sticky fingers, and the apparent burning of documents minutes before the police arrive.

title: Pacific Telephone
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Pacific Telephone subsidiary said it plans to build a fiber optic communications system south of San Francisco to carry cable television programming and two-way information services. Under the plan, Pacific would construct up to a 422- mile network, called a wideband transmission system. The network could carry cable television programs to more than 50,000 homes.

title: WEARABLE FASHIONS, NOT FANTASY, FROM LONDON
description: This city is beginning to swing

title: BILES TOPS FOLLOWING A TOUGH ACT
description: On Tuesday, the day after he had resigned as coach of the Houston Oilers, Ed Biles played golf with the quarterback Gifford Nielsen, Nielsen's father and Alan Ashby, the catcher for the Houston Astros. Later, Biles drove to the Oilers' training complex and cleaned out his office so that Chuck Studley, the defensive coordinator, who was named to succeed him, could move in.

title: NICARAGUA EVACUATES PORT RAIDED BY REBELS
description: The 25,000 residents of Nicaragua's main oil port were evacuated from the city today after anti-Government rebels attacked fuel storage tanks, setting off major fires, officials here said.

title: AMERICA'S SELFISH MOTIVES IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: To the Editor:

title: Government Securities Steady; Rally Erases Early Losses
description: The market in fixed-income securities stabilized yesterday after being battered earlier in the week. After a weak opening on carry-over selling from Tuesday, prices of Government securities rallied modestly, erasing the earlier losses and went on to close largely unchanged on the day, dealers said. But rates on Treasury bills declined.

title: Lanes Reopened On Riverside Dr.
description: The two center lanes of Riverside Drive between 125th and 135th Streets, where traffic had been restricted since last Friday because of construction, reopened last night.

title: Soviet Archers Cancel U.S. Visit
description: The Soviet Union notified the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee by cable Tuesday that it would not send a team to the world archery championships here next week.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Manila Is Not Managua
description: As the Marcos regime in the Philippines shows signs of unraveling, the Reagan Administration faces a familiar dilemma. Anything it does, or doesn't do, will be taken by the embattled dictator and his impassioned opposition as a signal. So some strategists, recalling the chaotic collapse of dictators in Nicaragua and Iran, urge the United States to rally to the side of an anti-Communist ally who has kept the Philippines safe for American bases.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of American Heritage Industries which was acquired this year.

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DATATRAK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BURST AGRITECH reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $243.9 million from discontinued operations.

title: REAGAN SIGNS BILL ALLOWING MARINES TO STAY IN BEIRUT
description: Text of Reagan statement, page A7.

title: Ameritech Sets 2 Ventures
description: Ameritech, the Middle Western regional holding company that will be created by the breakup of the Bell System, today will announce an agreement with Aetna Telecommunications Laboratories to develop an optical fiber local communications network. The company will also announce the start of business of the nation's first cellular mobile telephone service, which will serve the Chicago area.

title: Italian Prices Up
description: Italian wholesale prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in August after increasing seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, the National Statistics Institute said today. Prices were up 8.7 percent from August 1982.

title: COSTA RICA TELLS ANTI-SANDINISTAS BORDER ATTACKS WILL BRING OUSTER
description: Members of a key rebel group fighting the Nicaraguan Government ''are very close to being expelled'' from Costa Rica because of their military activities in the country, according to an official close to Costa Rica's Security Council.

title: Stocks Retreat; Dow Off 5.49
description: Stock prices fell yesterday in moderate trading after having dropped sharply on Tuesday.

title: CERTAIN-TEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Giants May Shift Defense Against Chiefs; Parcells Experiments
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants experimented today with some defensive changes that the team may use Sunday against the Chiefs at Kansas City.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS COME OF AGE
description: The environmental lobby, variously known by friends and foes as the ''greenies,'' ''bird watchers'' or ''tree huggers,'' is being taken very seriously these days as a political force to be reckoned with in the nation's capital.

title: Kenyan Takes Oath Again
description: Daniel arap Moi was formally installed in office today for a second five- year term as President of Kenya. Mr. Moi, who ran unopposed in the Aug. 29 election, read the presidential oath of allegiance before several thousand people in Nairobi's Uhuru Park.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $5.3 million, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of property.

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1983
description: Companies

title: CHILDREN IN SOVIET EXPRESS WAR FEAR
description: Three American psychiatrists who taped interviews with children in Soviet youth camps say the children echo the fears of nuclear war expressed by their American counterparts in a similar study.

title: German Price Rise
description: West German wholesale prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in September after increasing eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Federal Statistics Office said today. September wholesale prices were nine-tenths of 1 percent higher than in September 1982.

title: GIVING CHINTZ WIDE DESIGN DIVERSITY
description: ONE of the themes of the recently opened eighth-floor model rooms at Lord & Taylor, according to Ken Schliemann, the store's director of visual merchandising, is chintz used as a fabric appropriate to a diverse range of interior designs. Its presence is striking in a reception hall, left, in which a banquette is covered in a vegetable-patterned chintz.

title: Elizabeth S. Hughes, 61, Dies; Wife of Ex-Governor in Jersey
description: Elizabeth Sullivan Hughes, the wife of Richard J. Hughes, the former Governor and State Supreme Court Chief Justice, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday night in Boca Raton, Fla. She was 61 years old.

title: A PROFILE OF STERLING HAYDEN
description: DOCUMENTARY film making is at its most laissez faire in ''Pharos of Chaos,'' a profile of the actor Sterling Hayden by the West German film makers Wolf-Eckart Buhler and Manfred Blank. Mr. Hayden - disdainful of his acting career, ashamed of having named names before the House Un-American Activities Committee in the 1950's and tremendously proud of his accomplishments as a seafarer - is undoubtedly a very interesting man.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
PROJECT ON COAST UPHELD BY COURT
description: A Federal appellate court has upheld the construction of a huge hydroelectric project on the north fork of the Stanislaus River in California that has been opposed by state officials and environmentalists.

title: Initial Tribune Issue Raised
description: Demand for the first public offering of the Tribune Company was so strong yesterday that the company decided to sell more shares than it originally planned. The company, which publishes The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News, in New York, offered 7.7 million shares of common stock, up from the 7 million that it said yesterday it would offer, at $26.75 each.

title: Damson Oil Bid
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said it had turned down an unsolicited acquisition proposal from a corporation it did not identify. Damson said no further talks were planned with the suitor. On the American Stock Exchange yesterday, Damson declined 75 cents, to $11.625.

title: PLAZA PLAN GALVANUZES NEW CANAAN
description: For more than three hours, the battle of the office complex raged at the Saxe Middle School auditorium. The dueling weapons were estimates of traffic jams and peak rush hours. The battle cries were individual property rights versus the future of New Canaan's small-town character.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Spinoff Serves Smaller Clients
description: At Laurence, Charles & Free, Brett Shevack, 33-year-old executive vice president, is being given a company of his own and the title president to go with it. LCF&S is the name, and it will be a subsidiary of L.C.&F., which itself is one of the agencies in the Mickelberry Company.

title: Investors Offering
description: Investors G.N.M.A. Mortgage-Backed Securities Trust Inc. filed for an offering of $1 billion of G.N.M.A.-backed sequential pay bonds, the Securities and Exchange Commission said. The offering is being underwritten by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The company said the proceeds of the offering would be used to purchase Government National Mortgage Association pass-through certificates.

title: WOMETCO CABLE TV INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Sept 10
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Friday about the Esmark Corporation misidentified a label under which its cosmetics are sold. The label is Jhirmack.

title: 3 GROUPS HELP RESULTS
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income more than doubled from the same period last year, to $33.4 million, or $1.12 a share, largely on the strength of improved performances in the broadcasting, records and publishing divisions.

title: Warning On Deficits
description: Economists told the closing session of the American Bankers Association annual meeting here today that the prospect of $200 billion Federal budget deficits poses the danger that interest rates will not come down far enough to sustain strong economic growth and will eventually abort the recovery.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for 1983
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: BILINGUAL EDUCATION TAKES MANY FORMS
description: To the Editor:

title: BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct. 3, 1983.

title: MERCK'S BIG VENTURE IN JAPAN
description: Perhaps the most striking sign of the changes that are reshaping the Japanese pharmaceutical industry came in August when Merck & Company bought a controlling interest in the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company, a major drug maker in Tokyo.

title: CALENDAR: TOURS AND DESIGN WORKSHOPS
description: Annual House Tour, Trinity Lutheran Church, Fourth Avenue and 46th Street, Brooklyn, 212-853-0684 or 212-435-4371.

title: MY WAY
description: Nothing is more maddening to some public figures than a muckraker on their trail. Business and political associates, old enemies and embarrassing former friends all call to say how nasty the questions were and how loyal they were in answering them. A haunted, hunted look comes across the face of the proud and powerful; it seems that there is nothing that money and influence, or lawyers and press agents, can do to shoo the intruder away.

title: DON'T REGULATE AIRLINES AGAIN
description: With Braniff Airways bankrupt, Continental Air Lines in reorganization and Eastern Airlines, among other carriers, considered near the brink, airline employees' unions are urging repeal of the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978. Their concerns deserve serious attention, but re-regulation is not the answer.

title: A Move to Retailing From Minerals
description: When James E. Poole resigned recently as president of Gulf and Western Industries' natural resources group in Nashville, he left a career in the cement industry for a new one in retailing.

title: M.I.S.L. Chief Quits
description: Earl Foreman, the commissioner of the Major Indoor Soccer League since its inception five years ago, announced that he would step down at the end of the 1983-1984 season, perhaps to take over an M.I.S.L. team of his own.

title: Xerox Introduces Portable Computer
description: The Xerox Corporation stepped into the volatile portable computer market today with a unit that weighs five pounds and slides into a briefcase.

title: FOREIGN 'PIRACY' OF TV SIGNALS STIRS CONCERN
description: In the last two years, United States satellite signals carrying entertainment and news programs intended for cable television viewers in this country have been intercepted by a growing number of television stations throughout the Caribbean and Central America and broadcast without authorization.

title: ARGENTINA LOAN DELAY IS REPORTED
description: Argentina's 11-bank advisory group has advised that nation's other bank lenders that a $500 million disbursement from a $1.5 billion medium- term commercial bank loan to the country will be further delayed, banking officials said yesterday.

title: Hollings Remark Stirs Anger and an Apology
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina has apologized for using the term ''wetbacks'' to describe another Presidential candidate's supporters in a Democratic straw poll last weekend.

title: THEATER: HUGHES POEMS
description: THE story of Langston Hughes's discovery as a poet has become legendary. While working as a busboy in a hotel in Washington in the 1920's, he left several of his poems at the table of Vachel Lindsay. A celebrated poet and reader of his own work, Lindsay was so impressed by the young man's poems that he read them to an audience in the same hotel - and Hughes's career soared.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include warranty-related charges of $1,300,000 and $1,800,000, respectively.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN GA.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WASHINGTON STATE PICKS SENATE FOES
description: Daniel J. Evans, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, and Mike Lowry, his Democratic rival, came out fighting today, trading charges at the start of their four-week campaign.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Stan Williams, the onetime Yankee pitcher who spent three years as a Yankee coach and this season as a scout, has been named pitching coach of the Cincinnati Reds. . . . A $6,000 diamond ring marking Hank Aaron's record-breaking 715th home run in 1974 has been returned to him two years after it was stolen from his home in Atlanta. An Indianapolis businessman said he had bought the ring from a street peddler. . . . A day after an appeals court ruled that he was ineligible to continue as the Tulane quarterback, Jon English appealed the ruling to the Louisiana Supreme Court.

title: FOLK-POP: HOLLY NEAR, RONNIE GILBERT
description: HOLLY NEAR and Ronnie Gilbert, two warm and magnetic personalities whose folk-pop music is inseparable from their politics, concluded their tour together at Avery Fisher Hall in an atmosphere that was as much like a revival meeting as a pop concert.

title: CARNEGIE HALL AIDS ARTISTS
description: Carnegie Hall, as part of an effort to expand its community programs, yesterday announced a plan to work with Affiliate Artists in presenting musicians, actors and dancers in concerts throughout the city. Each of the artists will then be presented in a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Police Confer on Drifter Who Claims 150 Killings
description: Police investigators from 19 states met here today to compare notes on a 47-year-old drifter who says he has killed more than 150 women since he was 13.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DIAMOND-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Peter Roger's Wish Granted With Vodka
description: ''Finally the big break came,'' said Peter Rogers, president and creative director of Peter Rogers Associates, upon winning the Wodka Wyborowa brand from the Sazerac Company, a New Orleans distilled spirits concern.

title: 10 KILLED AS ILLINOIS COMMUTER PLANE CRASHES IN THUNDERSTORM
description: A commuter airplane flying through a thunderstorm crashed near here Tuesday night, killing all 10 people on board. The pilot had radioed about an electrical problem on takeoff but continued the flight, officials of Air Illinois said today.

title: GREAT HOME HAS A HISTORY TO BE SHARED
description: It was, for six decades, a very private house, situated at the end of a long driveway and surrounded by 100 acres of land. No one in the family ever counted the number of rooms but, in addition to a generously proportioned drawing room, dining room, loggia and library, there was ample space for master bedrooms, accommodation for three children, guest quarters, a schoolroom, night and day nurseries, a tutor's room, walls of closets and servants' quarters.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share results for both the latest quarter and 9 months reflect dividend requirements on adjustable- rate preferred stock issued in the 1983 first quarter.

title: ANRET PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $586,160 for the latest year and $710,700 for the previous year. The company is listed on the Philadelphis Stock Exchange.

title: PACWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3 Kaiser Plants Put Up for Sale
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it was looking for buyers of refractories plants in Plymouth Meeting, Pa.; Gary, Ind., and Frostburg, Md.

title: MARINE BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1983
description: International

title: CONCERT: STEEL ORCHESTRA AT TULLY HALL
description: HERMAN JOHNSTON may be the Antonio Stradivari of Trinidad, where his well- tuned steel drums have won contests since the 1960's. He moved to New York two years ago and organized the Johnston Fantastic Symphonic Steel Orchestra, whose 12 members include his wife, sons, brother and nephews.

title: Yankees Block Zimmer Move
description: The Chicago Cubs are interested in hiring Don Zimmer as a coach, but the Yankees, at least temporarily, have blocked the effort and in doing so have created something of a mystery.

title: Marc Rich Stirs Swiss Town
description: Along the lake are the inns of the old town, refuges of yesterday where guests eat pike and drink dark beer and listen to yodeling and accordions that are busy with ''Roll Out the Barrel.''

title: CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net losses of $4.3 million for the quarter and $14.2 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations and a net loss of $6.5 million for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Koch Gets His Licks In
description: Mayor Koch and Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink, who pride themselves on being among the more outspoken people in the political trade, matched oratory the other day.

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 35-to-1 stock split paid in September.

title: Required Reading; Walesa's Nobel
description: Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts, on Lech Walesa's Nobel Peace Prize, Congressional Record, Oct. 6, 1983:

title: O.E.C.D. Price Rise Is 0.4%
description: Consumer prices in the non-Communist industrialized nations rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, matching the July increase, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: One Million at Funeral For 17 South Koreans
description: More than a million mourners, summoned by the wail of sirens, bowed their heads in prayer today in a funeral for 17 South Koreans killed in the weekend bombing in Burma.

title: Fatal Car Accident Is Under Inquiry
description: The Passaic County Prosecutor's office today was investiagting an auto accident in which an off-duty Haledon police officer is accused of striking and killing a crossing guard and injuring four schoolchildren.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: No Headline
description: A quarter of a century ago, the controlled psychic made its appearance and had a brief vogue, mainly with New York experts. The idea was to open certain very weak hands, with 3-6 points, sometimes pinpointing a lead. Any response would be passed unless the responder indicated overwhelming strength.

title: Soviet Jewish Activist Is Put on Trial
description: A Jewish activist, Iosif Begun, went on trial today, charged with producing and distributing anti-Soviet propaganda, the official press agency Tass said.

title: People
description: * George G. Guimaraes has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh.

title: Combating Garment Sweatshops Is An Almost Futile Task; The New Sweatshop
description: On April 24, 1981, Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan led a raid on a garment factory at 125 Canal Street in Chinatown.

title: 4 HOSPITALS CRITICIZED BY STATE IN DRIVE ON DOCTORS' ABUSES
description: Three hospitals in New York State have been cited as ''deficient'' for failing to report doctors charged with incompetence or drug impairment, the State Department of Health said yesterday.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Of Politics and Pairings
description: Politicians often use courts to try to get opponents off the ballot. But some Liberal Party politicians want the courts to keep two judicial candidates on.

title: WAPLES FINDING WEALTH AT HOME
description: ''There are only two ways to get out of Canada,'' Buddy Gilmour said jokingly. ''You've got to be either a hockey player or a harness-racing driver.''

title: Coastal Recovery
description: The Coastal Corporation expects a ''significant'' increase in 1983 earnings and is comfortable with analysts' estimates of $3.75 to $4 a share, compared with last year's $2.65, said James R. Paul, senior vice president- finance. He said the company, which is primarily engaged in petroleum refining and marketing, is ''in the early stages of a strong profit recovery'' that is expected to continue in 1984.

title: Bank Rate Differential
description: While New York banks continued to compete heavily over newly deregulated certificates of deposit, there were few signs of a growing rate war in other areas of the country, The Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dime Savings Bank of New York has appointed Arthur J. Bassin executive vice president and chief banking officer.

title: MANVILLE READY TO FILE ITS REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: The Manville Corporation, the big forest-products company that sought protection from its creditors 14 months ago, said yesterday that it would file its reorganization plan on Monday.

title: PHILLIES AWED BY ROOKIE
description: ''If I were a pitcher,'' Mike Schmidt said, giving the view from the batter's box, ''I'd like to be exactly like him.''

title: OWNER OF TRAVEL AGENCY IS SLAIN
description: The owner of a travel agency on upper Broadway was shot to death yesterday in his store when he apparently resisted two men who were trying to rob him, the police said.

title: Brady Seen Quitting Today
description: Lawrence J. Brady, who tried unsuccessfully last month to have the Administration adopt new restrictions on trade with the Soviet Union, is expected to announce Thursday that he is resigning as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for 1983
Circle K Stake
description: The American Financial Corporation said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it owns 1,876,004 shares, or 16.5 percent, of the common stock of the Circle K Corporation. Circle K, based in Phoenix, owns a chain of convenience stores primarily in the West and Southwest. On the American Stock Exchange today, Circle K's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $23.875.

title: SUMMIT HEALTH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
BANK OF NEW YORK, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1983 results give effect to dividend requirements on adjustable rate cumulative preferred stock issued in February 1983. Figures reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 7.

title: A CELEBRATION OF DESIGN SINCE 1945
description: HERE are few among us who have not been fascinated when looking at museum cases of pre-dynastic Egyptian household objects. ''Design Since 1945,'' a brilliant show that will open to the public at the Philadelphia Museum of Art on Sunday, is an almost archeological examination of the artifacts that have surrounded our own everyday lives for the last four decades. In part because of the quality of their presentation, these mundane objects are almost as intriguing as those of ancient Egypt.

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Includes income of $223,425 from discontinued operations.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Eurobonds Off Slightly LONDON, Oct. 12 (Reuters)

title: Happy Clipper
description: ''I was initially very disappointed, very disturbed,'' said Norm Nixon, the guard who was traded on Monday from the Los Angeles Lakers to the San Diego Clippers. The 6-foot-2-inch guard and Eddie Jordan, a reserve guard, were sent to San Diego for Swen Nater, a 6-11 center, and Byron Scott, a highly regarded rookie guard from Arizona State.

title: Lotteries for Oil Leases Suspended
description: The Interior Department today suspended its lotteries of oil and gas drilling leases, which drew 2.5 million applications last year, to give officials time to correct abuses.

title: Tamco Purchase
description: Tamco Enterprises Inc. said a subsidiary had acquired the 3,541,100 shares of the Imperial Corporation of America owned by a Reliance Group unit for $15 a share.

title: TOURISM CONFERENCE IN INDIA CONDEMNS AIRLINER DOWNING
description: An international tourism conference condemned Moscow today for its destruction of a South Korean civilian airliner last month. The delegates adopted a resolution of censure that was presented by the United States and its supporters.

title: Orioles Even Series At 1- on 3-Hitter By Boddicker
description: Following their pennant-playoff pattern, the Baltimore Orioles sent out Mike Boddicker, their outstanding rookie pitcher, to even the World Series tonight. He did, pitching a three-hitter and gaining a 4-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Aide for Glenn

title: NORTHERN TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BIG APPLE FIX-UP TO OPEN TOMORROW
description: -Up will open tomorrow at the Seventh Regiment Armory and will continue on Saturday and Sunday.

title: CONCERT: MUTI CONDUCTS CARNEGIE HALL 'MACBETH'
description: SOME orchestras save their blockbusters for the climax of the season. Not the Philadelphia Orchestra, which opened its Carnegie Hall series Tuesday night with a concert performance of Verdi's ''Macbeth,'' the first opera the orchestra has essayed in nearly 50 years. It was enough to attract the expected full house, even if true-blue Philadelphians might have been expected to stay at home in front of their television sets for the first game of the World Series. As it happened, the Phillies won Tuesday and so, by and large, did Riccardo Muti and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: WESPERCORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Dolphins Are Still Struggling
description: The 38 points scored by the Buffalo Bills last Sunday were the most given up by the Miami Dolphins in a regular-season game in six years.

title: New Schlichter Charge
description: The National Football League is investigating a charge that Art Schlichter, the suspended Baltimore Colt quarterback, has run up an additional $20,000 in gambling debts while under treatment for compulsive gambling following his suspension, according to the police in Columbus, Ohio. The former Ohio State star, who lives outside Columbus, was suspended last April after he sought police protection from Baltimore bookmakers.

title: THINK WAR, MAKE WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
UST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The earnings for the year-earlier quarter included a net gain of $460,000, or 17 cents a share, from the sale of real estate.

title: A Resignation at Kasler, And Return of Founder
description: Warren W. Gaylord has resigned as president, chief executive and a director of the Kasler Corporation, a San Bernardino, Calif., builder of freeways and other heavy construction projects in the West. Mr. Gaylord, who is 49, said he resigned after 25 years with Kasler for personal reasons and would be available as a consultant to the company.

title: Boggs Inquiry Planned
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, said his office would look into the gambling charge that has been lodged against Tommy Boggs, the former Atlanta Braves pitcher, in Decatur, Ga. Jim Hartley, a DeKalb County police sergeant, said Boggs placed bets on football games before his release from the Braves last week, but that there was no evidence that he had wagered on baseball games. He was charged Monday after a series of raids on bookmaking operations in the Decatur area.

title: Schoolgirls to Remain In Philadelphia Central
description: The Philadelphia School Board decided Tuesday not to appeal a Common Pleas Court ruling that allowed girls to enroll at the previously all-male Central High School.

title: HERS
description: THE LITTLE RED HEN is the unrecognized tragic heroine of the feminist movement. It may not have been Anon's literary intention to fashion an allegorical feminist figure out of an egg-laying bird, but her creative unconscious must have known what it was doing.

title: DEMOCRATS OPEN AD BATTLE IN NOMINATION DRIVE
description: In New Hampshire towns such as Keene, Laconia and Lebanon, radio listeners are being invited by Senator Gary Hart of Colorado to join his ''campaign for a new America.''

title: COLUMBINE EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VIRGINIA NATIONAL BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SECRETARY GENERAL'S WIFE HAS DUAL ROLE
description: Marcela Temple's father told each of his seven children, ''Just because you are born here doesn't mean you have to wind up here.'' And each one took him at his word. They left their home in northern Peru and were educated in England. The exception was Marcela, who, by her own admission, was somewhat lazy. The apple of her grandmother's eye, Marcela remained at home.

title: LIST FOR WATT JOB DESCRIBED AS LONG
description: The White House said today that a long list of candidates was still under consideration to succeed James G. Watt as Interior Secretary but that Clifford P. Hansen, a former Senator from Wyoming, had taken himself out of the running.

title: Negotiators at Impasse In Chicago School Strike
description: The Chicago Board of Education and the striking Chicago Teachers Union refused today to move on the question of salary increases for the city's 22,797 public schoolteachers, and no further bargaining sessions have been scheduled.

title: First Pennsylvania Files Preferred Offering
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 6 million shares of convertible depositary preferred stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Europartners Securities Selects a New President
description: The Europartners Securities Corporation, an investment banking firm that is owned by five leading European financial institutions, has named Pierre Misrahi as president and chief executive.

title: Big Plans for Giants
description: Warning that the San Francisco Giants might decamp if they do not get a new stadium when their lease on the remote, windswept Candlestick Park expires in 1994, Mayor Dianne Feinstein announced plans for a new multisport stadium, perhaps with a retractable dome, which would make it the largest such sports facility in the country. Mrs. Feinstein, who said that the ultimate price would depend on whether the stadium was built with public or private funds, said it could cost as much as $227.5 million. It would be built on 15 acres of city-owned land in the China Basin area and would serve as the home of the Giants and the football 49ers and could also be used for basketball games and other events, she said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a decisive, historic moment. All the Middle East is remaking itself.

title: New Products Help To Ease The Chores
description: SEVERAL new products make tasks easier for the gardener, both indoors and out. One of them, the innovative Bag-a-Bug Insecticide stick from West Germany, eliminates the need for using aerial sprays and cotton swabs against indoor pests. These one-and-a-half-inch sticks, made of biodegradable cardboard, contain 50 milligrams of the systemic insecticide butoxicarboxim.

title: Getting a Shine Is Getting Ever Harder
description: Neat black letters on the brown marble of Grand Central Terminal still direct people to the ''bootblack,'' but one is hard pressed now to find a place to get a shoeshine in the station.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issuses

title: GEMAYEL TERMS FACTIONAL TALKS 'A CAMOUFLAGE'
description: President Amin Gemayel said today that Lebanon's main problem was to get foreign troops out of the country. He said the reconciliation conference between Lebanese factions, which he has called at American urging, was ''a camouflage, a distraction.''

title: Injured in Game, Player, 15, Dies
description: A 15-year-old high school football player died today after having received head injuries when tackled in a game last weekend.

title: HAYES-DANA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
China Helps a U.S. Company
description: The Santec Corporation, a small manufacturer of computer printers, recently received the first of two capital infusions from the Chinese Government. It is an unprecedented investment that may prove financially risky, though educational, at least for the Chinese.

title: Teledyne Net Drops 13.8%
description: Teledyne Inc. reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings dropped 13.8 percent, to $70.5 million, or $3.46 a share, from $81.8 million, or $3.96 a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: MANITOWOC CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Musto Is Allowed To Remain on Bail
description: A Federal judge ruled today that William V. Musto, former Union City Mayor and former State Senator, and four of his co-defendants could remain free on bail while appealing their racketeering convictions to the United States Supreme Court.

title: INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-3 stock split effected Aug. 12.

title: SOUTHTRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mets to Name Johnson
description: Dave Johnson, a successful manager in the minor leagues the last two years, will be named manager of the Mets at a news conference Thursday. He will succeed Frank Howard, who served as interim manager this season after George Bamberger retired on June 3.

title: 'A Lot of Pizza'
description: Tom Monaghan, the new owner of the Detroit Tigers, has been a fan of the club since he was 7 years old and pulling for the Tigers as they defeated the Chicago Cubs in the 1945 World Series.

title: IDEAS FOR MORE POLICE HEARD BY PANEL
description: A panel of law- enforcement experts, educators and politicans today suggested to the State Legislature strategies for getting more police officers onto the streets.

title: Polish Jokes in Time Capsule Lead to Its Quick Unearthing
description: Workers using a backhoe dug up the town green today after irate Polish-Americans demanded that a book of Polish jokes be removed from a bicentennial time capsule.

title: DEADLINE STRESSED FOR RENT APPEALS
description: The New York State Attorney General warned yesterday that because of a recent change in state law, tenants in rent-stabilized apartments have only until next March 31 to file complaints about rent overcharges that occurred before April 1, 1980.

title: Fire Hits Luxury Ship on Nile; PStS
description: A fire swept through a luxury liner on the upper Nile River near Luxor, Egypt, forcing passengers to jump from the decks of the flaming ship into the river, a spokesman for the State Department said yesterday.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brokerages Strong in Half
description: Brokerage firms had a strong six months in 1983, the Securities Industry Association said yesterday. The after-tax return on equity for the 397 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange was nearly 31 percent on an annual basis, compared with 21 percent for all of 1982, the industry group said.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MOSCOW SPOKESMAN WARNS OF A WALKOUT FROM 2 ARMS TALKS
description: Leonid M. Zamyatin, a Soviet spokesman, said today that Moscow would pull out of the Geneva arms talks if NATO deploys Pershing 2 missiles in Western Europe starting in December as planned.

title: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credits of $77,000 for the quarter and $197,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a tax credit of $109,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $194,000. Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: ISRAELIS FRET IN SHEKELS AND DO BUSINESS IN DOLLARS
description: If you can say the English word ''over'' with a heavy Hebrew accent, you're on your way to gaining fluency in the Israeli lexicon of economic survival.

description: b-After a loss of $8,820,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,858,000.

title: EASTERN AND 3 UNIONS AVOID A STRIKE
description: Eastern Airlines and its flight attendants' union reached an agreement on a new contract yesterday, averting a strike and paving the way for negotiations with all three of the unions at the airline on steps to avoid bankruptcy.

title: MORGAN (J.P.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTINENTAL HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $175,000 for the quarter and $190,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss. d-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $70,000.

description: b-Includes a gain of $87,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter from the sale of certain common stock investments, and a gain of $1,750,000, or 17 cents a share, for the 9 months from the sale of a radio station and certain common stock investments.

title: SCHOOL TIES IGNORED IN PICKING OFFICIALS
description: Ray Perkins, the Alabama football coach and athletic director, wanted Don Guman replaced as the head linesman for the Alabama-Penn State game last Saturday because Guman is the father of a former Penn State running back, Mike Guman.

title: KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STUDY SAYS U.S. CURBS ON SOVIET TRADE DON'T WORK
description: American advocates of doing business with the Soviet Union have charged in a new book that Government restrictions have damaged the reputation of the United States as a reliable trading partner and have been self-destructive.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Youth Who Watched Doctor Slain in Florida Is Sentenced
description: A youth who ''got sick to his stomach'' and fled as his friends murdered a professor pleaded guilty today to lesser charges in the case and was sentenced to four years in prison.

title: ADVERTISING ; Compton Resigns Its Campari Account
description: Compton Advertising, which has been trying to sell Campari, the strange-tasting Italian aperitif, with a celebrity ad campaign, has now resigned the business ''due to fundamental differences concerning advertising approach.''

title: BOSTON TRANSIT SYSTEM SEEMS TO SATISFY RIDERS
description: It is smaller, but cleaner. It carries far fewer people, but it gets them where they are going more punctually. And it is cheaper.

title: KREISLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $12,294 from the retirement of debt.

title: Court-Ordered Ballot Results In White Homecoming Queen
description: A high school football team chose a white homecoming queen for the second time today in a vote that was ordered by a Federal district judge after a black candidate challenged an earlier election.

title: AMERITRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DR. ROYAL S. DAVIS
description: Dr. Royal Stanton Davis, who practiced medicine for 45 years in New Rochelle, N.Y., and was a past president of the New York State chapter of the American Academy of Family Physicians, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: 2 COMPUTER COMPANIES SETTLE SUITS
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation and Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that they had settled their 18-month battle involving charges of patent infringement, unfair competition and raiding of employees.

title: AFTER THE ARMS TALKS
description: NewsAnalysis

title: RICHARDSON SEEKS GRIEVANCE
description: Michael Ray Richardson's lawyer said yesterday that he had asked the players' union to file grievances against the Nets and the National Basketball Association to gain Richardson's reinstatement from waivers.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KISSINGER, IN SALVADOR, URGES BROADER RIGHTS
description: Henry A. Kissinger said today that it was ''absolutely imperative'' that the principles of democracy and human rights be ''preserved and extended'' in El Salvador.

title: Ethyl Shutdown
description: The Ethyl Corporation said it was shutting down most of the chlorinated hydrocarbon operations at its Baton Rouge, La., plant because the need for its products had diminished.

title: FEDERAL STRATEGY IS DEBATED AT DRUG TRAFFICKING HEARING
description: The flow of illegal drugs into the United States has not been significantly reduced, despite increased drug confiscations in south Florida and drug-related prosecutions, a Congressional committee and a panel of the top Federal law-enforcement officials in south Florida agreed today.

title: Nurse's Trial Delayed In Texas Infant's Death
description: A judge agreed Tuesday to grant a delay of two and a half months in the trial of Genene Jones, a practical nurse accused of murdering an infant girl and seriously injuring six other children with injections of a paralyzing drug.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $2.2 million on the sale of the company's factoring division and a $5.9 million charge for an addition to reserves for the liquidation of discontinued operations.

title: ADOLPH STERN
description: Adolph Stern, a retired lawyer and former State Assemblyman and New York City magistrate, died yesterday at Brooklyn Hospital.

title: . . . AND PREFABRICATED HOMES: AN IDEA THAT DIDN'T TAKE
description: MARCO ZANUSO, the Italian designer of the sheet metal Lambda Chair, borrowed from automobile technology to design his elegantly contoured chair of 1962. At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the mid-1950's, the American architects Marvin Goody and Richard Hamilton, studying the application of plastics in housing, used hull technology from the boat industry to design prefabricated houses, an example of which became Monsanto's House of the Future at Disneyland.

title: Military Mission To the Rose Bowl
description: Transporting both the corps of cadets and brigade of midshipmen to Pasadena, Calif., for the Army-Navy game in the Rose Bowl on Nov. 25 will entail an airlift of huge proportions. Between 30 and 35 chartered commercial airline planes will fly the young servicemen from their academies on the East Coast across the country.

title: COOPER TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A & M FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
Poland Protests To Norway Over Prize
description: The Polish Government has filed a formal diplomatic protest to Norway over the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize to Lech Walesa.

title: WOODWORKING TOOL IS A COLLECTOR'S ITEM
description: The collection and display of old woodworking planes have become more and more popular, with many antiques shows and flea markets now offering these wooden tools. Historical societies also collect them by the hundreds, often without duplication.

title: Letter: On Navy Research Hudson Remains Independent
description: To the Editor:

title: SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
TURNER BUYS SOLE RIVAL IN CABLE NEWS MARKET
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based cable entrepreneur, announced yesterday that he had bought out his only challenger in the cable news business, The Satellite News Channels. The 24-hour headline service will shut down on Oct. 27 after little more than a year in operation and an estimated loss of more than $40 million.

title: SPENCER HARRISON DEAD AT 66
description: Spencer Harrison, a lawyer and executive at Warner Communications Inc., died at his home today after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: U.S. LEGAL SERVICES MEETING IS BARRED
description: A Federal district judge today barred the directors of the Legal Services Corporation from meeting in Salt Lake City on Thursday.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $933,000 from discontinued operations. The year-ago revenue figure excludes discontinued operations.

description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

description: b-Net income

description: To the Editor:
