description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much Time
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, has vetoed a proposed trade that would have sent the New England Patriots' unsigned all-pro cornerback, Mike Haynes, to the Los Angeles Raiders for a first- and third-round draft choice next year. The problem, Rozelle said, was that Al Davis, the Raiders' owner, didn't agree to the Patriots' terms and didn't notify the league office of the trade until more than half an hour after Tuesday's 4 P.M. trading deadline. As a result, Haynes said he would seek a berth in the United States Football League.

title: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures are fully diluted.

title: VERBATIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Joe Morgan Stretches Out His Career
description: ''Make way, please,'' the usher said as he walked ahead of Joe Morgan in a corridor under the stands at Memorial Stadium. Morgan had just played in his first World Series game since 1976, and his home run had helped the Philadelphia Phillies beat Baltimore in Game 1 on Tuesday, and now, with ushers to escort him, he was walking past the quiet Orioles fans.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: CHINA OUTLINES A PLAN TO PURIFY PARTY
description: The Chinese Communist Party's Central Committee has endorsed plans for a major campaign to rid the party of members considered to be corrupt, indolent or too radical.

title: A RECOVERY WITHOUT COPPER
description: It is used for electrical wiring in everything from automobiles to amplifiers; so copper prices usually increase as the nation's economy gathers steam. But despite the recovery now going on, a worldwide copper glut is keeping prices unusually low. Spot copper prices have plummeted from their February 1979 high of $1.25 a pound to below 66 cents yesterday.

title: Sooners Suspend Dupree
description: Marcus Dupree, the outstanding Oklahoma tailback, was suspended for at least one game yesterday after having failed to report for practice for two days. He has not returned to the campus after a weekend visit to his home in Philadelphia, Miss.

title: 6 Are Indicted In Race-Fixing
description: Robert (Cowboy Bob) Ellis, a former professional wrestler, was among six people indicted by a Federal grand jury in Rochester yesterday on five counts of criminal conspiracy involving race-fixing.

title: A TEXAS BANK GETS $100 MILLION LOAN FROM GOVERNMENT
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday lent $100 million to the First National Bank of Midland, Tex., as an emergency measure to keep the bank afloat while the Government agency seeks a buyer.

title: CONCERT: LAUSANNE ORCHESTRA
description: THE parade of visiting orchestras in and out of New York each season is a lively and enlightening phenomenon, keeping us alert to the best that the world has to offer and providing us with a yardstick against which to measure our resident ensembles. Too often, however, the programs that touring groups bring turn out to be so hackneyed and unimaginative that it is hard to know what they hope to prove by playing through them. In this day, we have a right to expect orchestral precision of almost any group that offers itself for international inspection. We also have a right to expect - and too seldom get - programs that go beyond the standard repertory.

title: STAGE: IBSEN'S 'MASTER BUILDER' OPENS
description: FROM a distance, at least, ''The Master Builder'' looks as solid and simple in structure as the towering churches designed by its protagonist. With the inexorable rush of classic tragedy, Ibsen's drama climbs steadily upward - until finally it sends the master builder, Solness, tumbling to his death from a great height. But the closer one gets to this play, the autobiographical masterwork of its author's final phase, the more it confounds: every dramatic step up is also a step down, into the snake pit of the 64-year-old Ibsen's consciousness. ''The Master Builder'' looks like a logical well made drama only until we realize that its foundations are built on characters who are mostly mad.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Explosives Found On Jersey Shore
description: At least 50 sausage-shaped explosives of a type used in underwater demolition washed up along a 40-mile stretch of the Jersey Shore Monday and yesterday, and police officers were out in the rain last night combing the beaches for more.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes equity in net earnings of Mexican operations of $479,000 for the quarter and $3,113,000 for the year. c-Includes equity in net earnings of Mexican operations of $132,000 for the quarter and $7,571,000 for the year. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend distributed to shareholders on Feb. 11, 1983.

title: A Week Has 7 Days, But Sometimes Less
description: Governor Cuomo has proclaimed October as Empire State Candy Month. Candy helps build strong bodies, the State Association of Tobacco and Candy Distributors said in a statement hailing this, ''and contrary to public opinion is not a junk food.''

title: MORGAN OFF 4.7% IN QUARTER
description: J.P. Morgan & Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company and parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, reported yesterday that third-quarter net income fell 4.7 percent, to $101.1 million, or $2.30 a share, from $106.1 million, or $2.57 a share, in the 1982 period.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Niagara, which had offered flights between Newark and Niagara Falls, said it had been sold to John Burns of the Worldwide Burns Security Agency in New York for an undisclosed price.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about boxing incorrectly described an out-of-court settlement involving Greg Page and the promoters Don King and Butch Lewis. It gave the fighter's services to Mr. King, and gave Mr. Lewis $200,000 and a third of Mr. King's gross earnings from the first three title fights.

title: Technology; Home Barriers Against Theft
description: SALES of burglar alarms for the home are growing rapidly. A 1980 report by Frost & Sullivan, a market research firm, estimated that in 1978 only 1.9 percent of the approximately 75 million private homes in the United States had antitheft protection. This year, a survey by National Family Opinion and the trade magazine SDM (for security distributing and marketing) found that the share had grown to 8.6 percent.

title: TOLEDO TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S Says Soviet Ship Menaced Search Boat
description: A Soviet intelligence ship menaced a Japanese ship participating in the search for the remains of a downed South Korean airliner, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Youth Is Convicted on Coast For Murder of Police Officer
description: A teen-ager was convicted today of first-degree murder for shooting to death a policeman while masquerading as a deputy sheriff in his stepfather's patrol car.

title: Guatemalans Publish A Guerrilla Statement
description: The newspapers defied a Government ban today and published a guerrilla statement to save the life of a kidnapped editor.

title: Gannett Net Rises 7.5%
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that net income rose 7.5 percent, to $46.1 million, or 87 cents a share, in the third quarter, from $42.9 million, or 81 cents a share, in the period a year erlier, despite ''continued substantial'' start-up costs for its year-old USA Today newspaper. Third-quarter revenues rose 12.1 percent, to $412.6 million, from $368.1 million in the 1982 third quarter. Gannett, based in Rochester, owns a chain of newspapers, six television stations and 13 radio stations.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carrian-Williams
description: Arthur Williams, a partner in a New Zealand joint venture with the debt-ridden Hong Kong Carrian Group, said he is buying out the Carrian interest. Mr. Williams, chairman of Carrian-Williams Holdings Ltd., a New Zealand-based property and investment company, said members of his family are buying back the 7 million shares acquired by Carrian Investments Ltd. in a share swap valued at about $14 million two years ago when Carrian shares were near their peak value.

title: E.E.C. Faces Lack of Cash
description: To help avoid running out of money this year, the European Economic Community today announced a 10-day freeze on some agriculture subsidies.

title: ROBESON INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: Results for the latest periods include tax credits of $214,900 for the quarter and 281,900 for the 6 months. Results for the year-ago periods include a tax credit of $60,000 for the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 1.

title: NOTABLE CHILDREN'S LETTERS AT MORGAN LIBRARY
description: ''Letters from Notable Children,'' the current show at the Pierpont Morgan Library, offers a chance to see the developing minds of 50 youngsters whose names have come down in political, literary and artistic history. In later life, the letter-writers became famous figures - for good or ill.

title: PIANO MUSIC: ALDO MANCINELLI
description: THE pianist Aldo Mancinelli plays with command and an earnest sobriety; his recital Monday night in the Abraham Goodman House was most effective in music calling for these attributes.

title: NASA SAYS FLAW COULD DELAY SHUTTLE FLIGHT SEVERAL MONTHS
description: A delay of one to four months for the next space shuttle mission was being weighed yesterday by space agency officials, who said they were increasingly concerned about the reliability of nozzles in the shuttle's booster rockets.

title: Addendum
description: * McCrudden & Sullivan, a new marketing and public relations company, at 360 East 65th Street.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
'Peanut' May Be Near
description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce soon two models of its new home computer, the PC Junior, according to a computer industry newsletter.

title: 'KILL HIM, KILL HIM, KILL HIM'
description: The case against capital punishment rests, in the end, on the belief that the process of carrying out the death penalty degrades the society and distorts the law. Anyone who doubts the strength of that case should think about three scenes enacted in this country late on the night of Oct. 4.

title: TV: 'INSIDE STORY,' A HOUSE DIVIDED BY NICARAGUA
description: ''INSIDE STORY,'' the public television series that examines the press, looks tonight at a Nicaraguan publishing family, and, by extension, at a revolutionary society as well. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review Sept. 28 of Andrzej Wajda's film ''Danton'' incorrectly described its distribution. The movie, a French-Polish co-production, was released in Poland in January.

title: FIRST FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHAMBER: MUSICIANS OF SPAIN
description: TIMED to coincide with Columbus Day, the Classic Chamber Orchestra presented a concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday that brought to these shores a selection of Spanish orchestral music. The Spanish orchestra is conducted by Max Bragado- Darman, Madrid-born and trained at Oberlin and the University of Michigan, and one of its goals is to take music from the new world back to the old.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES POLICE CHIEFS' GROUP OVER GRANT
description: A Federal grand jury in Baltimore is investigating whether the International Association of Chiefs of Police misused a $500,000 Justice Department grant, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the year-ago 9 months included proceeds from the sale of tax benefits totalling $38,400,000.

title: SEVER ISRAEL'S TWIN
description: Israel's immediate headaches are economic, but in the long run the gravest problem that the new Government of Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir has inherited from its predecessor is the galloping annexation of the West Bank and Gaza.

title: RACIAL 'BREAKTHROUGH' HAILED
description: Richard Arrington, the first black to serve as Mayor here, said today that his re-election reflected a coming ''breakthrough'' in race relations because of the support he got from whites.

title: HERBERT H. SEGERMAN
description: Herbert H. Segerman, a leading importer of knitwear who was instrumental in opening postwar trade with Japan, died yesterday at his home in Hewlett Bay Park, L.I. He was 63 years old and also had a home on Longboat Key at Sarasota, Fla.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $95,000 from discontinued operations.

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $5,300,000 from an exchange of securities.

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $575,000, or 11 cents a share, from a contract settlement with Ford Motor Co., a gain of $400,000, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of Chrysler Corp. securities, and a charge for cost to bring waste handling systems in line with EPA standards of $1,600,000.

title: STUDIO GLASS: A GALLERY'S SHOW OF PATE-DE-VERRE
description: Given that all p^ate-de-verre glass is rare, the Heller Gallery is staging an exhibition of some of the rarest and the newest. A wealth of loaned examples by turn-of-the-century French artists serves as a historical reference for technically excellent, often whimsical work produced by the contemporary studio glass artist Doug Anderson.

title: CHICAGO HAS BLOSSOMED INTO A THEATER CENTER
description: WHEN New Yorkers talk about the arts in Chicago, they tend to rhapsodize about the Art Institute, the symphony and the staggering architectural treasures. But if there's one area of artistic accomplishment in which Chicago has often been rated as a second city - or even a fourth or fifth - it's the theater. Though there has long been homegrown theater in Chicago, we often think of the city as another stop on the road. The Loop is the place where last season's Broadway hits go to die.

title: GLENN URGES HOLDING UP MISSILE DEPLOYMENT
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio urged President Reagan today to call a halt to the planned deployment of cruise missiles in Europe to show a sign of ''good faith'' toward the Soviet Union.

title: Marcos Puts Off All Official Engagements
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos postponed all official engagements today ''to confer with his immediate staff and legal advisers,'' according to a statement from Malacanang Palace.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $3,978,000 for the quarter and $17.5 million for the 9 months from discontinued operations. c-After losses of $3,421,000 for the quarter and $13,134,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split last February.

title: Car Buyers Taken for a Ride
description: It's still possible to buy a Japanese automobile if it's loaded with expensive dealer-installed options, reports a Toyota salesman. But ''if you want to pick the color, I give you less than a 50-50 chance of ever getting the car you want.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THOUGH due diligence may have been applied to insulating the ceilings and walls of a house, the basement and foundation may have been neglected.

title: Advertising; Dentistry Franchise Is Planned
description: SMILES is the name of a new franchising company based in Waltham, Mass., and it hopes to do for dentists what Century 21 did for the real estate business.

title: Peugeot Labor Accord
description: Labor Minister Jack Ralite approved early retirement for 4,635 workers at Automobiles Peugeot and its Talbot subsidiary, but he rejected a company request for 2,905 layoffs at Talbot's Poissy plant, a ministry statement said today.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes equity in net income of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $17,900,000 for the quarter and $75,100,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes equity in net income of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $33,400,000 for the quarter and $90,200,000 for the 9 months. The use of equity accounting for certain investments of unconsolidated subsidiaries increased net income by $10,900,000 for the latest quarter and $26,900,000 for the latest 9 months, and $12,900,000 for the year- ago quarter and $43,400,000 for the year-ago 9 months.

title: MCI UP 37% INTEL NET SOARS
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone service, reported yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter of 1983 climbed 37 percent, while revenues jumped 51.4 percent.

title: ADOPTION CENTER AIDS WILD HORSES
description: Frank and Doris Goodlander, operating the first Federal adoption center for wild horses and burros in the Northeast, have helped find homes for 500 animals in their first year.

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOCAL CONTROL UNDERCUTS SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE NAME, TWO ORIOLES
description: The name across the back of their Oriole uniforms reads ''Ripken'' as if there were only one. But no identification beyond their last name is necessary for Cal and Cal Jr., professor and pupil, third-base coach and shortstop. Together, they represent the essence of the Baltimore Orioles in this World Series, if not the essence of baseball itself - the onetime minor-league catcher with the gray crew cut who has been with the Oriole organization throughout his 27-year career, the rangy son with the ice-blue Paul Newman eyes who grew up absorbing the Oriole way to play baseball in the minor-league towns where his father managed.

title: OGDEN REID IS RUNNING ONCE AGAIN
description: It was 7 A.M. and Ogden R. Reid, who served for six terms as a United States Representative from Westchester County, was greeting commuters, as he does almost every day now. On this morning, they were converging from Yonkers and Mount Vernon at the top of a stairway leading to the Fleetwood Station of the Metro-North railroad.

title: Bossy and Morrow Out
description: After Mike Bossy was indefinitely sidelined with a pulled muscle in his right hip Tuesday night in the 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings, the Islanders also lost the services of the defenseman Ken Morrow.

title: U.S. IS PREPARING BASES FOR THE NATO MISSILES
description: As the time for NATO deployment of new medium-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe nears, electronic systems and testing equipment are being delivered and control shelters are being built.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SIGNS OF CHANGE APPEARING IN BOSTON'S ELECTORATE
description: The virtual tie in the mayoral primary Tuesday between Melvin H. King, a black neighborhood organizer, and Raymond L. Flynn, a self-styled populist, reflects the emergence of a more liberal electorate in Boston after a century of domination by conservative and Irish politicians.

title: U.S. URGES SEOUL TO EXERCISE RESTRAINT ON KILLINGS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had urged President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to show restraint and not retaliate with force if it turned out that North Korea was responsible for the assassination of 16 South Koreans, including four Cabinet ministers, in Burma last weekend.

title: TANAKA VOWS TO KEEP PARLIAMENT SEAT
description: Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, convicted Tuesday of accepting bribes from the Lockheed Corporation, said today that he had no intention of relinquishing his seat in Parliament.

title: Respiratory Ills Linked to Landfills
description: A health survey has found a greater incidence of reported respiratory illnesses and other ailments among longer-term residents of a Brooklyn housing project near two large city landfills, a research group said yesterday.

title: Toys 'R' Us
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said it expects net income in the third quarter to exceed the $4.7 million, or 8 cents a share, earned in 1982's third period. Charles Lazarus, chairman of the company, said that while sales of video games and home computers continue strong this year, they represented 13 percent of total volume for the first 10 weeks of the third quarter, ending Oct. 31, compared with 19 percent of the volume a year before.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Knicks Win Game With Rugged Bulls
description: The coaching credos of the Knicks and the Chicago Bulls are much the same. Hubie Brown of the Knicks and Kevin Loughery of the Bulls both believe in pressure defenses and traps.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1983.

title: Fight to Ban Tour Buses In Beverly Hills Gains
description: The fight to ban tour buses from the residential streets of Beverly Hills gained some official backing today when a Superior Court judge ruled the police could resume enforcing an ordinance barring overweight buses from designated city streets.

title: LINEAR INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OHIO GOVERNOR BATTLES TAX REPEAL DRIVE
description: Earlier this year the newly elected Governor of Ohio, Richard F. Celeste, gave the state a dose of what he termed ''reality therapy.'' At his behest the Legislature balanced the state budget by making permanent a temporary 50 percent income tax surcharge and by approving an additional increase of 40 percent.

title: LONG TENURE FOR MCGUIRE
description: News Analysis

title: Breaking 'Illogical Barriers'
description: Barbara McClintock's discovery that genes ''jump'' won her the Nobel Prize in Medicine this week, but when she first reported it 32 years ago, she was met with silence. Her views were unorthodox and, a colleague says, ''It didn't help that she was a woman.''

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
For Taking Charge Of A Messy Desk
description: ANYONE going through the fall rite of getting a desk and work area organized will find many new helpers around town.

title: The U.N. Today; Oct. 13, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE KINGDOM BY THE SEA. A Journey Around Great Britain. By Paul Theroux. 353 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

title: REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $83,581 on the early extinguishment of debentures.

title: 2 PROMOTERS HELD IN A LAND SCHEME
description: Federal officials moved today to return Rienk Kamer, one of two international businessmen charged with conspiracy and fraud in a huge land scheme involving foreign investors, to the United States to stand trial in Los Angeles County.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results include the operations of WUI Inc. since July 1, 1982. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 100 percent dividend paid in August.

title: REGGAE: ITALS AT BOTTOM LINE
description: AN eerie calm - the steadfastness of true believers - filled the songs of the Itals when they performed Monday at the Bottom Line. The reggae trio's lyrics are about surviving hunger, captivity and a brutal daily life; in verses that often echo biblical phrases, the Itals counsel determination and faith.

title: '25 Brooklyn Team And Coach Celebrate Past
description: Boys High School in Brooklyn had a championship football team in 1907, George Horowitz remembers. ''The guys from that team would come around and give us pep talks when we were in school.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Every time it rains a basement wall gets wet. The water seeps through a lot of tiny holes, the wall is constantly damp and mildewed and it sheds a white powder. We have built up the soil on the outside so water doesn't puddle there and have checked the downspouts and gutters, but the problem persists. Contractors who specialize in wet basements offer various solutions. One says dig trenches around the floor and connect these to a sump pump. The second says paint the interior with waterproof paint. The third says replace the outside storm drains with PVC piping. The fourth says dig up around the outside and repoint the foundation. What do you think?

title: Popularity Breeding Problems In New All-Day Kindergartens
description: As the Board of Education's new all-day kindergartens begin their second month, the widely hailed program is nonetheless troubled by overcrowding and equipment shortages in some areas of New York City, officials in those areas say.

title: RECORD DOWNPOUR DELAYS THOUSANDS
description: Record rains whipped by strong winds struck the New York metropolitan area yesterday, flooding highways, knocking out subway lines and causing severe delays for commuters during the evening rush hours.

title: Nets Routed by 30
description: Mike Wilson scored 16 points tonight to pace the Washington Bullets to a 130-100 victory over the New Jersey Nets in a preseason game.

title: Market Place; Weak Dollar May Aid Drugs
description: FOR several years now, the strength of the United States dollar has adversely affected the earnings of companies with extensive business operations abroad. But in recent weeks, the dollar has weakened against several currencies, notably the yen. And there exists some sentiment - but no guarantee - that the dollar will continue to weaken somewhat and, in the process, help those corporations doing business abroad and those competing with foreign-made goods.

title: ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $394,000 from discontinued operations.

title: OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'FILLE DU REGIMENT'
description: REGINA RESNIK and Spiro Malas, who were not in the season's first Metropolitan Opera performance of Donizetti's ''La Fille du Regiment,'' have now joined the cast.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HINDSIGHT. By Peter Dickinson. 192 pages. Pantheon. $12.95. KEYSTONE. By Peter Lovesey. 256 pages. Pantheon. $12.95.

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

CREDIT RATES;
Interest Rates Rise Again
description: Prices of Government securities slid and interest rates rose slightly for the second day this week in quiet credit market trading yesterday. Analysts said fears that the renewed strength of the economy might spark a less accommodative Federal Reserve policy had caused investors to retreat from the market.

title: Bowie to Lead Trio
description: Lester Bowie, the trumpeter for the Art Ensemble of Chicago, will lead his Triple Crown Trio Sunday at the Manhattan Healing Arts Center, 386 Broadway below Canal Street (431-3009). The group includes the drummer Phillip Wilson and a bassist. Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $7.

title: ISRAELI RESIGNS AS DOLLAR PLAN SETS OFF FUROR
description: Israel's Finance Minister resigned today after the Cabinet rejected a plan he proposed to replace the shekel with the United States dollar as the nation's legal tender.

title: SASHA DALTON RELIVES DINAH
description: ''GOD, me and my mama are the only three people who know how many times I've been married,'' Dinah Washington used to quip in her nightclub act, which interspersed salty, freewheeling humor with the powerful pop-jazz singing that earned her the sobriquet ''Queen of the Blues.''

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Sunday misidentified a general partner in Advanced Technology Ventures. He was Dr. Tadeusz Walkowicz.

title: THEATER: 'THE PHILANTHROPIST,' IN AN IVORY TOWER
description: PHILIP, the title character of Christopher Hampton's ''Philanthropist,'' teaches philology at an English university. As befits his calling, he loves to create anagrams: let someone give him the words ''Shakespeare'' and ''Hamlet,'' and he'll instantly deliver the phrase ''make the real shapes.'' But Mr. Hampton, who wrote this farce in 1970 at the age of 24, is far cleverer still: ''The Philanthropist'' is a theatrical double-crostic.

title: COURT BACKS BAN ON LEGAL SERVICES MEETING
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a lower court ban on a meeting of the board of directors of the Legal Services Corporation today in Salt Lake City.

title: E.P.A. Approves Grants for Jersey
description: The Environmental Protection Administration has approved $158 million for 17 grants to be used mainly for the construction of waste-water treatment plants in New Jersey, Senators Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey said today.

title: Moscow Says It Plans To Counter Any U.S. Missiles In West Europe
description: Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, commander in chief of Warsaw Pact forces, today offered the most explicit warning yet that the Soviet Union would deploy additional nuclear weapons in Europe if the United States proceeded with plans to deploy medium-range missiles.

title: Market Place; Utilities With Nuclear Woes
description: UNDER ordinary circumstances, a common stock yielding 14.5 percent, selling at less than six times earnings and priced at a 25 percent discount to last year's stated book value might be considered an appealing investment. The Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company fits this description, but it is hardly operating these days under ordinary circumstances.

title: L & N HOUSING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Court Clears 2 Doctors Who Let a Patient Die
description: The California Court of Appeal has overruled murder charges against two doctors indicted for withdrawing all life-support systems from a patient.

title: Migrating Falcons Are Tested For Pesticides From Canada
description: Scientists from the United States and Canada took blood samples today from migrating Arctic falcons, an endangered species that makes brief, semiannual stops on the Texas Gulf Coast.

title: U.S. Dropping Effort To Ban Uses Of Lindane, A Pestocode
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today abandoned efforts to outlaw most uses of lindane, a cancer-causing chemical that is one of the most popular pesticides.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago resuls have been restated for the acquisition of Simmonds Precision Products Inc., accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: THE PRICE OF RHETORIC
description: It's now clear that there was an amazing misunderstanding between Lebanon's President Amin Gemayel and top American officials last spring. It may have cost the lives of over 1,000 Lebanese as well as the U.S. marines who died in Beirut.; Tom Wicker is on temporary leave.

title: BANKERS TRUST OF S C reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. and Japan Widen Search Area For Plane
description: United States and Japanese ships have expanded the area of the Sea of Japan where they have been hunting for wreckage of the downed Korean Air Lines 747, officials said today.

title: Polish Police Break Up A Pro-Solidarity Crowd
description: Policemen using concussion grenades broke up a crowd today of 1,000 Solidarity supporters who hurled stones and garbage on a statue of Lenin.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Olympics Promotion By United Airlines
description: United Airlines, which is the official carrier of the 1984 summer Olympics and of the United States Olympic team, will announce its ''Five Million Mile Challenge'' tonight during the World Series telecast on the ABC-TV network.

title: METS PUSH A GOOD BUTTON
description: At first he was going to be a doctor, so he enrolled at Texas A&M and took courses toward a pre- med major. Later he realized he was going to be a baseball player, so he gave up the thought of medicine and majored in architecture at Trinity University, instead.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a foreign currency exchange loss of $260,000.

title: FIRST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings have been adjusted for 1982 to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend declared in November 1982.

title: 'DOSTOYEVSKY'
description: THE 1981 Russian film ''26 Days in the Life of Dostoyevsky'' that begins a two-day run at the Thalia today is about several distraught weeks in the life of Fyodor Dostoyevsky in 1866. Pursued by creditors, mourning the deaths of his wife and his brother and working under the threat of bondage to his publisher, Dostoyevsky eventually triumphed over his writer's block and gloomy nature to finish ''The Gambler.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Derrick Hatchett, the cornerback who, the Baltimore Colts said, left the team after losing his starting job to a rookie, Kendall Williams, and then told Coach Frank Kush, ''that he might well do it again,'' has been suspended by the club for four weeks. . . . Emile Zatopek, the Czechoslovak distance runner who won four gold medals at the 1948 and 1952 Olympics, has been asked to carry the Olympic torch at the opening of next year's Summer Games. . . . Normand Leveille , the Boston Bruin who suffered a paralyzing cerebral hemorrhage last year, underwent surgery in Montreal to replace a skull fragment. . . . The Islanders called up Darcy Regier from Indianapolis of the Central Hockey League to help fill the shortage created by injuries to the defensemen Tomas Jonsson and Ken Morrow.

title: Honoring Cooke
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke was to have received the first annual award of the Partnership for the Homeless, the interfaith group that has set up emergency shelters for the homeless.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avco Corp. said it had agreed to sell substantially all of the remaining real estate of its Avco Community Development Inc. unit to MCO Holdings Inc. for an undisclosed amount.

title: RANGERS WIN FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: The Rangers are off to the best start in the team's 58-year history, thanks to a victory last night that set the Madison Square Garden crowd to roaring as if it were playoff time.

title: Carrie Smith to Sing
description: The blues and gospel singer Carrie Smith will open the Heavenly Jazz concert series Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. Tickets are $7 ($5 for students and the elderly). The number for more information is 369-8040.

title: Mesa Retracts Offer for KN
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had decided to withdraw its offer to acquire all of KN Energy Inc.'s shares outstanding.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $52,700,000 associated with the planned closing of several uneconomic production facilities. c-Net loss. d-Net income which includes an extraordinary gain of $4,600,000. Year-ago revenue figures have been restated.

title: ART: AMERICAN IMAGERY BY JJAMES ROSENQUIST
description: ONE of the most succinct descriptions of James Rosenquist was recently supplied by another artist, who called him ''the most American painter we have.''

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Russians Will Visit
description: Peter Ueberroth, the president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, said that he had been notified that a delegation of Soviet Olympic officials would be coming to southern California soon ''to make all the final arrangements'' for the team's participation in next summer's Games. Ueberroth, who said the delegation would be mainly ''technical people,'' said no date had been set for the visit, which is expected within a few weeks. . . . A request for a pre-Olympic hockey game Dec. 14 between teams from the United States and Soviet Union in Madison, Wis, has been checked by the Dane County Board.

title: Moscow Dissident Gets 1-Year Term on Slander
description: Oleg Radzinsky, a member of a small unsanctioned group founded last year to promote understanding between the Soviet Union and the United States, was sentenced to a year in prison and five years in internal exile today on charges of slandering the Soviet state, his friends said.

title: A TEXAS BANK'S TIES TO OIL
description: The search for a buyer of the Midland bank is narrowing. Page D4.

title: ROBERT B. PICKETT
description: Robert B. Pickett, a former vice president of Gulf and Western Industries, died of cancer Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OPERA: NEW NADIR IN 'LES PECHEURS'
description: IT was Jon Garrison's first performance as Nadir in Bizet's

title: STATE DEPT. AIDE VISITS NICARAGUAN FOR TALKS
description: Langhorne A. Motley, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, arrived here today for two days of talks that he said were aimed at gauging the willingness of Nicaraguan leaders to bring a negotiated peace to the area. His visit will also include talks with leaders of business, the Roman Catholic Church and the press.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $900,000 for the quarter and $5,400,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $22,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: South Indian Flutist
description: The South Indian flutist N. Ramani will perform tonight at 8 at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street, three blocks south of Canal Street. He will be accompanied by his son, R. Thyagarajan, on flute and the mrdangam drummer R. Ramesh. Admission is $8.

title: IF JESSE JACKSON RUNS
description: Jesse Jackson's interest in the Democratic Presidential candidacy reflects the growing maturity of Afro-American politics. Although it is unlikely that a Jackson bid can either gain or significantly influence the party's nomination, a candidacy could generate political spinoffs that would have a momentous impact on electoral politics in the future.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The earnings per share in 1983 reflected the issuance of additional preferred and common stock.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Sales include leased departments.

title: Liquidation Urged
description: The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation said its chairman, C. Douglas Dillon, who together with his family controls about a third of the company's stock, had recommended to the board that the corporation be liquidated and dissolved. The company, a diversified closed-end investment fund, said the recommendation was made in view of increasing operating costs and ''the discount that the market generally places on the shares of closed-end investment companies.'' On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the company's stock rose 87.5 cents, to $26.75.

title: Search Narrowing For Midland Buyer
description: The efforts of Federal bank regulators to rescue the First National Bank of Midland, Tex., are focusing on a handful of big Texas banks, industry executives said yesterday.

title: Japanese Morality, and Ours
description: Mindless moralism: that's the charge some American companies still make about Congressional action forbidding bribery of foreign officials to secure business. Americans may be pious about business methods at home, the argument goes, but they have to understand that ''grease'' is essential to doing business in foreign lands with foreign moral standards.

title: Cruz's Bunt Confuses The Phillies
description: When Todd Cruz stepped to the plate in the fifth inning of the second game of the World Series Wednesday night in Baltimore, Rich Dauer was at first base with his first hit in 19 times at bat in postseason games and the Baltimore Orioles had a 1-1 tie with the Philadelphia Phillies, the result of a leadoff home run that John Lowenstein hit just before Dauer batted.

title: CULLEN/FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aquanautics Corp., San Francisco, has named Claude L. Ganz chairman, president and chief executive officer.

title: AMBER RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOREA'S EDGY DMZ EXTENDS TO AMERICA
description: The ugly events involving South Korea - the downing of its airliner; the Rangoon bombing, which killed 20 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers - fit a pattern we have almost come to accept as par for the course for the divided peninsula.

title: Welfare Employee Accused of Adding Relatives to Rolls
description: A Bronx woman who worked for New York City as a welfare eligibility specialist has been arrested and charged with illegally placing four relatives and a friend on the welfare rolls.

title: G.M. Model Delay
description: The General Motors Corporation said a shortage of parts from suppliers would delay the start-up of production and sales of 1984 model A-body cars for one to three months. The company's new front-wheel-drive station wagon model was due to go on sale Sept. 22, but the shortage will cause a delay until the first week of November. Low dealer inventories are expected until late January.

title: Official at ABC Sports Is Joining TV Producer
description: John Martin, vice president of ABC Sports, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Ohlmeyer Communications Corporation, which provides entertainment, sports and general programming. Ohlmeyer was founded in May of last year by Donald W. Ohlmeyer, 38, who previously headed sports programming at NBC.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Knicks Defeated
description: Randy Breuer, the Bucks' rookie center, scored 12 of his 22 points in the last 3 minutes 55 seconds of the third quarter to help Milwaukee to a 105-92 exhibition victory over the Knicks tonight.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $38,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $300,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $90,000 for the quarter and $1,242,000 for the 9 months.

title: A STUBBORN PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: 633,000 Unemployed Receive Extended Aid
description: Nearly 633,000 unemployed workers receive benefits from the Federal supplemental compensation program, now set to expire on Oct. 18, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Pepsico Declines 13%; Mead and Boise Surge
description: Pepsico Inc., blaming poor results in its foreign markets, said yesterday that its third-quarter net income declined 13 percent, to $95.2 million, or $1 a share, from $109.4 million, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCERT: MUSIC FROM TURKEY
description: WITHIN the last few years, the Alternative Museum, in downtown Manhattan, has presented a host of intriguing concerts devoted to world music - an alternative for the ear as well as the eye. On Sunday night, a delegation of performers based in Istanbul offered an evening of music of the Turkish court and Sufi traditions.

title: WHITE HOUSE TO REVIEW REGAN, FELDSTEIN TEXTS
description: President Reagan's two top economic advisers, Martin S. Feldstein and Donald T. Regan, who have clashed publicly over the dangers posed by budget deficits, have been ordered to have their speeches reviewed by the White House from now on, ''to insure conformity,'' Mr. Reagan's chief spokesman said today.

title: 1.6% RETAIL SALES GAIN RECORDED
description: Retail sales increased 1.6 percent in September after declining by the same amount in August, with every category except building materials showing an increase, the Commerce Department said today.

title: STAGE: 'ROCKET TO MOON' IS REVIVIED
description: Clifford Odets labeled ''Rocket to the Moon'' a romance, but, seeing the play in Edwin Sherin's carefully modulated revival at the Hartman Theater, one would more properly classify it as an antiromance. The author allows his characters no options. They are either too old, too inexperienced or too weak, and in the play's hot summer weather, they stultify on the vine.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
BANK SOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a dividend paid June 1983.

title: Boxing Issue Revived
description: Last July, the House of Representatives rejected by 254-167 legislation that would have created a study commission to make safety recommendations on professional boxing to Congress. Yesterday in Washington, citing the death last week of Gino Perez in New York from a bout the previous week, Rep. James J. Florio , D-N.J., said that the House should reconsider his proposal because ''the health and safety problems in professional boxing are so severe and so dangerous that action must be taken now.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Virginia Housing Bonds Will Yield 5.5% to 10%

title: KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Bridge: L.I. Double Knockout Won By Successful Tucker Team
description: Indications are that the most successful team in the New York area in 1983 will be one consisting of Judy Tucker, Jim Becker, Ethan Stein, Joel Friedberg and Howard Chandross.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1983
description: International

title: MOHAWK RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 3 EXTRA-FINE JEWELS

title: NAVY'S BLUE ANGELS BUZZ SAN FRANCISCO
description: The Blue Angels, the Navy's aerobatic flying team, buzzed the city for 30 minutes today, rattling windows and residents with sonic booms.

title: MUSIC: SERIES BY WEBSTER
description: BEVERIDGE WEBSTER, one of the grand older men in the fraternity of American pianists, has committed himself to play another series of recitals here - perhaps to show how lively one can be at the keyboard at 75 years of age.

title: Suspect Charged As Fake Doctor
description: A Long Island man who assisted in 70 operations at a Fort Dix Army hospital and reportedly anesthetized a patient who was left severely brain damaged was indicted today on charges he falsely said he was a licensed doctor.

title: CARLSBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Carvin Leads Quartet
description: The drummer Michael Carvin will lead a quartet Sunday at the WBAI Free Music Store. The live concert will take place at 8 P.M. at P.S. 41, 116 West 11th Street, and will be broadcast on WBAI, 99.5 FM. A contribution is requested at the concert; the number for more information is 279- 0707.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The third quarter and 9 months' figures include the earnings of newly acquired banks since the date of their respective acquisitions and although the mergers contributed significantly to the increased net income, they did have a modest dilutive effect on Norstar's earnings per share. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Hard Times At Alfred E. Smith's Church
description: Alfred E. Smith served as an altar boy there, notes a plaque on the shabby front of St. James Church on the lower East Side.

title: IN LONDON, STREET STYLES AND TAFFETA CLOTHES
description: King's Road is still crowded on Saturdays with English youths who shape their hair into enormous spikes, each spike a different shade of Italian sherbet, to paraphrase a line from Clive James's novel ''Brilliant Creatures.'' And the World's End shop of Vivienne Westwood, the spiritual mother of punk fashion, is still at one end of the road, the hands of its clock spinning backward at a madcap rate.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was to have been a celebration of the second annual Candace Awards (pronounced can-DAY-say), given by the National Coalition of 100 Black Women to 12 women and one man this year. The awards, named for a queen of ancient Ethiopia and financed by Baileys Original Irish Cream Liqueur, were indeed presented. But the party, which flowed around the Temple of Dendur, became nothing less than a birthday party for Rosina Tucker.

title: Job for Official Who Left Atari
description: Jeffrey A. Heimbuck, one of three executives who recently left Atari Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., has been named chief executive of the Koala Technologies Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Jazz Clarinet Recital
description: The clarinetist John Carter will perform new jazz compositions tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street. Tickets are $8.50, and the number for more information is 247-7459.

title: Greening of Peking: Chinese Grow Grass
description: The grass is beginning to grow in Peking, city authorities said today.

title: HARP CONCERT: NEW YORK QUARTET
description: THE New York Harp Ensemble, which appeared at Goodman House on Wednesday night, is a quartet of women under the musical direction of Aristid von W"urtzler. Since little, if any, music of consequence has been composed for harp quartet, the ensemble is pretty much restricted to playing transcriptions and minor works composed for it.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Overtime Games Setting a Record Pace
description: In 1974 the National Football League changed its rules so that if a game were tied after four quarters, the teams would play an overtime period, not to exceed 15 minutes, to determine a winner. The game would end when one team scored, but if neither team scored in the additional period, the game would stand as a tie.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the year-ago quarter include a cumulative adjustment of $4,619,000, or 30 cents a share, due to using the actual effective tax rate for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1982, which currently reflects the best estimate of the annual effective tax rate. Results for the latest quarter include a gain of $4,075,000, or 27 cents a share, net of tax effect, from the sale of a folding carton plant.

title: CARDINAL COOKE REMEMBERED IN A MEMORIAL BY CITY COUNCIL By United Press International
description: The New York City Council held a brief memorial service yesterday in tribute to Terence Cardinal Cooke, who died last week.

title: CLARK APPOINTMENT CATCHES STATE DEPARTMENT UNAWARES
description: President Reagan's decision to name William P. Clark Secretary of Interior came as a shock to the Administration's foreign policy and military experts, who said they had no inkling that the national security adviser would be replaced.

title: Books: Grant and Cagney
description: CARY GRANT. A Celebration. By Richard Schickel. 192 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tax Votes Get Key Democratic Aid
description: House Democratic leaders have agreed to allow a series of floor votes this fall on proposals to raise $73 billion in new taxes over the next three years, mostly from the business community, Congressional aides said today.

title: Permanent Lodging for the Homeless
description: Two years ago New York City officials promised in court to give shelter to every homeless person who requested it. Since then the homeless population has doubled. This winter officials expect up to 18,000 people a night. The costs could reach $135 million, up from $18 million in 1978.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
OPERATING SHOREHAM POWER PLANT WILL NOT LOWER RATES, STUDY SAYS
description: A draft report for Governor Cuomo's special panel on the Shoreham, L.I., nuclear power plant has concluded that electric rates on Long Island will double in five years whether or not the plant ever operates.

title: REAGAN, AGREEING TO '84 RACE, WILL FILE MONDAY, LAXALT SAYS
description: President Reagan, taking his closest advisers by surprise, today chose William P. Clark, his national security adviser and longtime associate, to serve as Secretary of the Interior.

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
The Crucial 50
description: Saul Bellow, Gore Vidal, John Updike, Marilyn French, Kurt Vonnegut, Tom Wolfe, William Styron, Truman Capote, Frances FitzGerald, Norman Mailer, Ken Kesey, Alistair Cooke, Arthur Miller and a bunch of other writers have been invited to breakfast Nov. 7 at Gracie Mansion.

title: UNLISTED BEST SELLER
description: To the Editor:

title: 'NEVER CRY WOLF,' ARCTIC TALE
description: CARROLL BALLARD'S ''Never Cry Wolf,'' which opens today at the Gemini 2 Theater, is a perfectly decent if unexceptional screen adaptation of Farley Mowat's best-selling book about the author's life among Arctic wolves. Being virtually a one-character film, and largely a straightforward record of that character's daily observations of the ways of the wolf, the film is considerably different from the melodramatic romance of Mr. Ballard's ''Black Stallion.''

title: INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Health Study Section Added to Carter Center
description: Former President Jimmy Carter outlined plans today for a project at his Emory University policy center aimed at improving health care through a broad study.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
RESEARCHERS SUGGEST IMPROVED SCREENING FOR HEART ILLNESSES
description: Heart disease could be controlled better if younger people were screened more strictly for potential problems and more attention was paid to family patterns of risk, researchers say.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He is a God-fearing Westerner, fourth-generation rancher and a person I trust.

title: Richardson Is Unclaimed
description: Michael Ray Richardson, dropped Tuesday by the Nets because of what they contended was his refusal to undergo drug rehabilitation, cleared waivers yesterday. That meant he was unwanted by any of the 22 other teams in the National Basketball Association.

title: Wobblies, Yippies and Youth
description: Watching the Democratic candidates at the recent New York Presidential forum, I found myself thinking, ''John Glenn really does look like Eisenhower.'' At that moment, my daughter, almost 16, asked, ''Is John Glenn the one who looks like Johnny Carson?''

title: ART: AT MET, SCULPTURES BY ERASTUS DOW PALMER
description: IF you hear a persistent hum in

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED STATES HOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,026,000.

title: A Truly Thoroughbred Day for Belmont
description: The acts are all set for the three-ring spectacular at Belmont Park tomorrow, where more great horses will be in any one place for an afternoon except for the stallion barns at a few blue-chip breeding nurseries in Kentucky. Twelve 2-year-olds are entered in the Champagne Stakes, 11 older horses will run in the Jockey Club Gold Cup, and the latter group will be led to the post by Kelso and Forego.

title: WARNER CUTS CORPORATE STAFF BY 250
description: Warner Communications, the troubled entertainment concern that has been trying to stem huge losses at its Atari Inc. unit, said yesterday that it was laying off one-third of its New York headquarters staff.

title: James A. Burke, 73, Is Dead; Served in Congress 20 Years
description: James A. Burke, who represented Massachusetts' 11th Congressional District in Washington for 20 years, died today at New England Deaconess Hospital, Representative Brian J. Donnelly, Democrat of Massachusetts, announced. Mr. Burke was 73 years old.

title: 'FAME' NOW ON WNEW
description: ONE of the more interesting wrinkles of the current season can be found in the return of ''Fame'' for a third year. The series had been canceled by NBC because of disappointing ratings. That normally spells death on the television circuit. But ''Fame'' was then picked up by a consortium headed by M-G-M Television, to be distributed in syndication to individual stations, some of which, ironically, may be affiliates of NBC. In the New York area, the weekly show can be seen on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, beginning Sunday at 5 P.M.

title: Vermont Town's Voters Back Gun-Owner Law
description: A local ordinance encouraging residents to own guns was upheld by voters today, ending a three-month controversy that had divided this rural Vermont community.

title: TV FILM HELPS REUNITE FAMILIES
description: A 3-year-old boy has been reunited with his mother after an 11- month separation, bringing to at least two the number of missing children returning home because of a television movie about child abduction this week.

title: 'EVIL SCHEMES' SCORNED AT SOUTH KOREAN'S BURIAL
description: The South Koreans killed in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma, were buried today after an outdoor funeral service that turned into a huge rally denouncing North Korea for what one speaker called its ''evil schemes.''

title: Environmental Groups Angered By Reagan Choice For Interior Job
description: Some environmental groups reacted angrily today to President Reagan's announcement that he would name William P. Clark, his national security adviser, as Secretary of the Interior.

title: FRANKLIN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $800,000 from the sale of programmed power division.

title: INJURIES SLOW JETS AT FULLBACK
description: The Jets, burdened with injury since the season began, suffered another setback today when Dwayne Crutchfield and Mike Augustyniak, the top two fullbacks, were designated as questionable performers for the game at Shea Stadium Sunday against the Miami Dolphins.

title: CELLULAR MOBILE PHONE DEBUTE
description: The call to New York was placed from a moving automobile, but there was no wait for a dial tone, and none of the static interference that usually comes with such mobile phone calls. The dialed number appeared as a digital readout on the phone console before the call was connected. And the voices came through crisp and clear.

title: About Real Estate; Manufactured Housing Moves Into City
description: Manufactured housing is making its appearance in a widening spectrum of new single-family buildings across the city. At the same time, talks aimed at establishing facilities to do the construction within city limits are intensifying.

title: Argentina Loan Release
description: Argentina's 11-bank advisory group met late into the night yesterday discussing when it might release a $500 million disbursement from a $1.5 billion bank loan.

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Clarendon Assets Ruling
description: A Federal judge yesterday issued two orders to keep Clarendon Ltd. operational. The company, which trades metals and other basic goods, is the New York affiliate of the trading network of Marc Rich, who fled the country after the Government charged that he and an associate had evaded at least $48 million in taxes.

title: JUDGE WITHDRAWS FROM SUITS OVER AGENT ORANGE
description: The judge who since 1979 has been presiding over the multibillion-dollar lawsuit by Vietnam veterans against manufacturers of the defoliant Agent Orange unexpectedly withdrew from the case yesterday, citing the ''increasing pressure'' of other court duties.

title: GIANTS OBTAIN DEFENSIVE END
description: The Giants' defense, which has become a thing of shreds and patches, received another patch today with the signing of Casey Merrill, a free-agent defensive lineman.

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $39 million from an accounting change.

title: SEARLE, G D, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter and $2,200,000 for the 9 months, and gains on the disposition of discontinued operations of $24,600,000 for the quarter and $27,400,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,800,000 for the quarter and $8,500,000 for the 9 months.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
WABC-TV Retains An Interim Agency
description: Because of the difficulty of finding an agency to replace Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, its agency for 11 years, WABC-TV, Channel 7, has retained an interim agency to serve it for the remainder of the year while it completes its search for a permanent agency.

title: Australian Jobless Rate
description: Australia's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 10.4 percent in September from 10.2 percent in August and 7.5 percent a year earlier, the Statistics Bureau reported today. Its preliminary figures showed that the number of unemployed rose to 730,400 in September from 713,100 in August and 514,800 in September 1982.

title: BOB MARLEY IN 'HARTLAND'
description: ''HEARTLAND REGGAE'' hinges on a handshake - a meeting, during the violent election year of 1978, between Prime Minister Michael Manley of Jamaica and his opponent and successor, Edward Seaga. It's a film and not a snapshot because it took place onstage at a concert by Bob Marley and the Wailers, adding a bit of gravity to what is basically a reggae concert movie.

title: CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
43 Are Treated In Brooklyn Fires
description: Forty-three firefighters and members of a civilian fire patrol were treated for exposure to potentially hazardous fumes in two unrelated Brooklyn blazes, but tests found the fumes were not toxic, authorities said yesterday.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'GREGORIO CORTEZ'
description: ''THE BALLAD OF GREGORIO CORTEZ,'' which opens today at Cinema I, tells of heroism, bigotry and a legendary miscarriage of justice. The sincerity of Robert M. Young's film is readily apparent, yet in its soft-spoken and serious way, ''The Ballad of Gregorio Cortez'' presents a no less exaggerated portrait of the old West than the wildest and woolliest cowboy sagas. If frontier characters didn't truly rope and ride and yell ''Yahoo!'' without interruption, neither can they have been as solemn, quiet and reflective as the figures in this deliberately muted drama.

title: FINGERMATRIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-There were no revenues reported for the year-ago first quarter since the company is in the developmental stage.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Wilson and Aikens Plead
description: Willie Wilson and Willie Aikens of the Kansas City Royals were accused by the United States Attorney's office today of attempted cocaine possession, a misdemeanor, and both immediately pleaded guilty.

title: Driver Loses Appeal
description: A New Jersey appeals court has upheld a suspension of the harness driver Ronald Turcotte in a case that began in 1981 when he was accused of driving in an inconsistent manner at Freehold Raceway. Turcotte, whose lawyer noted that the charge carried an implication that the owner-driver-trainer had deliberately lost a race, said that his horse had simply ''pooped out.''

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: QUESTIONS ARE RAISED ABOUT NEW EVIDENCE IN VON BULOW CASE
description: On the evening of Aug. 16, policemen patrolling just north of Boston came upon a scene that continues to puzzle them, one that is now raising questions about some of the new evidence offered in the case of Claus von B"ulow, who was convicted last year of trying to murder his wealthy wife.

title: Shaklee Fills No. 2 Post After a Yearlong Hunt
description: The Shaklee Corporation, a maker of household and personal-care products based in San Francisco, has named David M. Chamberlain, a Nabisco executive in Canada, president and chief operating officer.

title: Two Oklahoma Men Sentenced in Vote Fraud
description: A Federal district judge today gave the former Oklahoma House Speaker, Dan Draper, and the former majority leader, Joe Fitzgibbon, three-year prison terms in a conspiraacy to rig votes.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'DOMINOES' MAY FALL IF THEY ARE PUSHED
description: Before making the domino theory the underlying motif of his Central American policy, President Reagan should have taken a closer look at the history of our involvement in Southeast Asia. In fact, despite dire threats about exported revolution, the only ''dominoes'' that fell in Southeast Asia were the ones dragged into the war by United States intervention - Cambodia and Laos. Today, the Administration's policies risk bringing the same sad fate on our ''friends,'' Honduras and Costa Rica.

title: Republic Airlines
description: The financially pressed Republic Airlines said it welcomed a proposal by leaders of its six unions to create a new employee stock-ownership plan that could buy up to 25 percent of the company's shares. The union leaders endorsed such a proposal at a meeting on Wednesday and intend to submit a plan to the master executive councils of the unions on Nov. 3. A. L. Maxson, senior vice president-finance, said that of the company's 13,300 employees, about 8,300 are already shareholders and own about 15 percent of the carrier's shares outstanding.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Megabus' Arrives In Westchester
description: With an escort of buses from the 1940's, a new form of mass transit called the Megabus made its debut in Westchester County today.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Broadening Corruption Case Against Official
description: The Federal authorities broadened their corruption charges against New York City's director of lease negotiations yesterday, saying he had extorted or tried to extort more than $1.5 million from owners of buildings in which the city leased space.

title: Carlton Bolsters Phils' Hopes in Series
description: With visions of Mike Boddicker's curveballs and change-ups still dancing and darting before their eyes, the Philadelphia Phillies were looking to Steve Carlton, their silent but steady veteran, to pitch them back into a one-game advantage over Baltimore in the World Series, which resumes here Friday night.

title: WEST GERMANS START MISSILE PROTESTS
description: Several thousand demonstrators tried to blockade a United States Army barracks in Bremerhaven today. It was the first major action of a planned 10 days of protests against the deployment of American medium-range nuclear weapons in West Germany.

title: MONDALE-GLENN DUEL: IMAGE IS PRIZE
description: NewsAnalysis

title: Parish Reaches Terms
description: The Boston Celtics said yesterday that they had come to terms on a one-year contract extension for their holdout center, Robert Parish, and that Parish would be in uniform for the exhibition home opener Sunday against the Philadelphia 76ers. No terms were disclosed, but the Celtics said the agreement did not change Parish's basic contract, which has three years to run and is reported to bring him about $650,000 a year. Parish, who had refused to go on an exhibition trip with the Celtics last week, said that as the starting center he should make more than Kevin McHale, the backup forward, who recently signed for more than $1 million a year.

title: GLENN MISSILE PROPOSAL MAY SPUR BONN CONFLICT
description: Senator John Glenn's suggestion Wednesday that the United States delay the deployment of cruise missiles in Europe grew out of an opinion that both the United States and the Soviet Union should try to avoid introducing wholly new types of weapons. However, it seemed probable the proposal could cause diplomatic difficulties with the West German Government.

title: Foliage Bus Tour
description: There will be a foliage bus tour to Kent, Conn., tomorrow, starting at 9 A.M. from the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, and ending there at 7 P.M. The tour will stop in Macedonia State Park for a picnic (bring your own), and will visit a glass blower and a potter en route. Reservations: Batia Plotch at (212) 427-6000, extension 179. The cost is $36; major credit cards accepted.

description: MR. SPEAKES: Before we have our regular daily briefing today, keeping with our policy of keeping you briefed by experts on events as they happen, we've got a special briefer today.

title: DORSEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $16.5 million from discontinued operations.

description: The year-earlier share data was restated to reflect the effect of the 5 percent stock dividend declared in February 1983.

description: b-Reflects the estalishment of a reserve of $28,000,000, after taxes, to provide for the completion of the company's program to close some manufacturing plants. c-Net income which includes a credit of $51,000,000 for the 9 months from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Back on the Farm
description: For a man who had just been released from a major league ball club at age 43, Woodie Fryman sounded remarkably cheerful yesterday from his home in Ewing, Ky.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose by $399 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: NESTLE PUTS CURBS ON MARKETING
description: Nestle S.A. of Switzerland, the world's principal seller of infant formula, said today that it had made several changes in its marketing practices to make them conform to an international marketing code.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO EQUIP JORDAN'S SOLDIERS AS A STRIKE FORCE
description: The Reagan Administration has proposed a secret $225 million plan to enable two Jordanian Army brigades to serve as a special strike force for use in emergencies in Jordan and the Persian Gulf, according to Congressional, Administration and diplomatic sources.

description: BASEBALL

title: NEW BOSS FOR CONVENTION CENTER
description: When Thomas F. Galvin moved from New York City to Dallas two years ago, he left behind a career that mixed success with the sort of frustration that frequently breaks local political careers. In the 1960's and early 1970's, he built a successful architectural practice and won praise as the chairman of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals.

title: LAKE ONTARIO CEMENT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LUNS TO RETIRE AS CHIEF OF NATO
description: Joseph M. A. H. Luns will announce in December that he is retiring as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a spokesman said today.

title: Campus Violence Erupts As Chilean Protests End
description: The police fired tear gas grenades at groups of stone-throwing students on three university campuses in Santiago today at the end of a third day of protests against President Augusto Pinochet, witnesses said.

title: Advertising; Word Play To Sell a Brokerage
description: AFTER being around for 103 years, the Moore & Schley brokerage has decided to mount its first advertising campaign. The initial goal will be to get the firm's name better known.

title: BRUNO'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Hutton to Open Bank
description: The E. F. Hutton Group Inc. said it had received final approval from Delaware authorities to start a state bank in Wilmington. The bank, due to open in November, will have only one office but serve clients nationwide, the company said.

description: Neighborhood cafe for stylish food.

SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,091,000 from the exchange of common stock for debentures and a charge of $5,230,000 for plant closings.

title: Seagate Agrees To Acquire Atasi
description: Seagate Technology said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Atasi Corporation for 7.2 million common shares.

title: W.R. GRACE FALLS 36.7%
description: The Allied Corporation, buoyed by strong gains in the defense, housing, auto and electronics markets, said yesterday that earnings rose 17.6 percent in the third quarter. W. R. Grace & Company, hurt by weakness in its natural resources business, said its earnings fell 36.7 percent in the third quarter.

title: NEW YORK THROUGH ARTISTS' EYES
description: THERE are no statistics to tell us whether New York is as ''painted'' a metropolis as Paris, but if it's not, it's only because our city is slightly younger. Artists are attracted here because - quite simply - New York is where it's at. And while they come to live and work out their own invented imagery, such is the visual power of the city that it often becomes a subject for them, too.

title: VLI to Sell Stock At $13 a Share
description: The VLI Corporation, an Irvine, Calif., manufacturer of female contraceptive sponges, announced that its initial public offering of two million shares of common stock had been priced at $13 a share, through an underwriting syndicate managed by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin and Seidler Amdec Securities.

Rate Increase Is Predicted
description: Solomon Brothers chief economist, Henry Kaufman, said today that interest rates would move up slightly in this quarter, probably in December.

description: Officials of the National Air and Space Museum have announced that they will seek Congressional approval for a new facility at Dulles International Airport to display such large craft as the space shuttle, a Boeing 747 jetliner and the Enola Gay, the name its crew gave the B-29 that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima.

title: High School Fair
description: The second annual Citywide High School Fair will be held tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., at Martin Luther King Junior High School, 122 Amsterdam Avenue, between 65th and 66th Streets. The fair will help students entering high school and their parents in deciding on programs, career training and extracurricular activities available in the city's 110 public high schools. The fair is presented by the Board of Education's High School Division and the United Parents Association.

title: COLUMBIA TO GET CENTER ON FREE PRESS
description: The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism yesterday announced that it had received a $3 million gift, the largest in its history, to establish a center to study First Amendment issues.

U.S. Threatens to Quit World Nuclear Agency
description: American officials said today that the United States would withdraw from the International Atomic Energy Agency if Arab countries succeeded in getting Israel suspended from the United Nations-affiliated organization.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Honda's Founder, At 77, Quits Board
description: Soichiro Honda, the 77-year-old founder of the giant motorcycle and auto company that bears his name, has resigned from the company's board of directors. Mr. Honda, who began the company in 1948, will remain as supreme adviser, a lifetime position, the auto maker said.

description: THE filing by Continental Air Lines for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy law and the threat by Eastern Airlines to do the same have prompted some union leaders to press Congress to reconsider the deregulation of the airline industry.

description: When the Senate Foreign Relations Committee held hearings in 1981 to confirm William P. Clark in the second ranking post at the State Department, his ignorance startled even supporters of the new Reagan Administration.

description: An upswing late in the session yesterday enabled the stock market to reduce some of its earlier losses and close with minor price changes in slower trading.
