title: Nascar Stiffens Rules
description: Nascar drivers and owners whose cars exceed official specifications will be automatically suspended for 12 weeks and at least three races under new enforcement procedures that have been imposed in the wake of last Sunday's violations by Richard Petty. According to Chip Williams, a Nascar spokesman, the automatic ban is designed to eliminate some of the discretion that had been allowed officials in enforcing rules limiting engine displacement to 358 cubic inches.

title: Kaiser Cement Loss in Quarter
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation reported yesterday that it lost $340,000 in the third quarter of 1983, compared with a net income of $2.5 million, or 31 cents a share, in the same period of 1982. The company said that, despite increases in its domestic cement production and shipments, ''our 1983 results will reflect the extremely low level of cement prices in the United States and abroad.''

title: PAN AM, AMERICAN WEIGH PLANE SWAP
description: Pan American World Airways and American Airlines said yesterday that they were negotiating a possibly large swap of jumbo jets aimed at providing each carrier with a fleet more suitable to its routes and less expensive to operate.

title: MITTERRAND PRESSES NATO TO BE FIRM
description: President Francois Mitterrand is calling on the countries of Western Europe to reject what he calls pacifist notions and remain firm in their decision to deploy new nuclear missiles if negotiations in Geneva fail.

title:
PATENTS ;
Three New Solar Cells Win Separate Patents
description: A high-intensity solar cell - described by its inventor as capable of operating at an intensity of between 500 and 1,000 suns - was patented this week by Bernard L. Sater of Olmsted Falls, Ohio. Mr. Sater, who obtained patent 4,409,422, serves on the staff of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Lewis Research Center in Cleveland.

title: DEAL WITH CITY'S SPORTS TEAMS AS BUSINESSES
description: To the Editor:

title: PHONE-MATE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Weekender Guide in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for a performance of ''One Touch of Venus.'' It is tomorrow at 4 P.M. in Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: 12 Writers Arrested in Oslo
description: Twelve writers were arrested Thursday night after the police raided the homes of the editorial staff of Ikkevold, a leftist magazine accused of publishing military secrets that included the location of a United States submarine listening post in Norway, the authorities said today. The police said they confiscated printed material relevant to the case.

title: Kaiser Price Rise
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that it will raise prices for its rod, bar, and wire products from 3 percent to 6 percent, effective with orders placed after Oct. 21 and with shipments after Nov. 1. The company said that the increases were made to offset rising raw material costs.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOR LEBANON AND U.S. PROBLEM OF CONFIDENCE
description: A problem of confidence is developing between Lebanon and the United States over Syria.

title: DR. HASKELL A. REICH
description: Dr. Haskell A. Reich, manager of the design automation systems group at the Thomas J. Watson Research Center of the International Business Machines Corporation, in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., died of leukemia Tuesday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 57 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Time Out For a Harbor Cruise
description: Like a harbor ferry, the huge QE2 circled - albeit cautiously - around the Statue of Liberty Thursday night, interrupting her turnaround between ocean cruises to play host to the Time magazine staff.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August. Year-ago revenues have been adjusted for the consolidation of the company's wholly owned subsidiaries.

title: HOAN PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: Producer Prices Up by a Modest 0.2%
description: Food prices surged in September, but lower costs for new cars and gasoline helped hold inflation at the producer level to a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.

title: BELO, A H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for 31,447,000
DEJESUS OFFERS NO EXCUSE
description: Paul Owens, the Phillies' manager, said the runner might have screened Ivan DeJesus from the ball. Al Holland, the pitcher, said the ball might have hit a wet spot. Mike Schmidt, the third baseman, said the ball was hit very hard and anyway, the Phillie hitters aren't hitting and ''you can't put yourself in the position where you have to make the play every darn time.''

title: U.S. Trade With Reds
description: The United States's historic trade surplus with Communist countries has virtually disappeared, according to a new report from the United States International Trade Commission.

title: MONCHIK-WEBER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
A Private Stand
description: A proposition on the election day ballot in San Francisco calls for the immediate withdrawal of all United States military aid and personnel from El Salvador. Proposition N has received endorsement from David Meggyesy, the former St. Louis Cardinal linebacker who is now the Western regional director of the National Football League Players Association.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $1,150,000 for the 9 months.

title: RICHARDSON BEGINS TREATMENT
description: Michael Ray Richardson yesterday entered a drug treatment center for the third time in the last four months, in an attempt to ''get my own life clear'' and alleviate personal problems that, he said, caused him to disappear from the Nets' training camp at Princeton University 11 days ago.

title: COMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Family Asks Koch To Oust Coroner
description: The family of a Brooklyn man who died while in the custody of transit police officers called on Mayor Koch yesterday to discharge the city's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: TAX COLLECTIONS IN CITY EXCEED THE PROJECTIONS
description: Tax collections in New York City are running ahead of projections and, if the pace continues for the whole fiscal year, the city will collect at least $50 million more than it had expected, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BIG CITY GAME
description: As the World Series settled into Philadelphia for the weekend to help determine the championship of the Continental Congress, it became more and more clear that this is to be a World Series for the role players.

title: NICARAGUA REPORTS AN ATTACK BY INSURGENTS ON MAJOR PORT
description: Nicaragua announced today that a major port had been attacked by rebels and said it was making a formal request to foreign governments for the ''military means to defend our coasts and our airspace.''

title: MIDLAND BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Continental Air Ruling On Secrecy Overturned
description: A Federal District Judge in Houston yesterday overturned a broad secrecy order issued Wednesday night prohibiting the disclosure of Continental Air Lines' cash position, cash projections and profit-and-loss projections.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $464,000. Qtr to Aug 31 1983 1982 Revenue 2,187,000 1,495,200 Net inc 433,900 b530,000 Share earns .05 .06 Shares outst 8,532,500 8,519,500 b-Including an extraordinary nonrecurring gain of $167,400 from the sale of stock.

title: Helping the Dwelling
description: From all five boroughs, people poured into the cavernous Seventh Regiment Armory - homeowners and apartment renters, looking for ways to improve their dwellings.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: TWO-YEAR BATTLE WON AT DIOXIN SITE
description: For two years, Mary Lou Sharon and her neighbors passed out pamphlets and petitioned officials, complaining that waste dumped in the landfill up the road from them was contaminating their water and their land.

title: KAISER CEMENT & GYPSUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FEDERATED GUARANTY LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEVILS ARE BEATEN ON A LATE MISTAKE
description: The Devils have seven rookies and are willing to tolerate their mistakes, but tonight it was one of their veterans who committed an error that proved costly.

title: 2 Life Terms Given In Fire Fatal to 14
description: A man with a long criminal history was sentenced to two consecutive life terms today for setting a tenement fire that killed 14 people last year.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results reflect Connecticut National Bank merger and acquisition of Nattatuck Bank & Trust Co.

title: A DECADE LATER, IT IS STILL VENICE VS. THE ADRIATIC
description: Venice is no longer sinking, said Deputy Mayor Paolo Cacciari, but it is still subject to the capricious buffeting by nature that has left it ''exposed to catastrophe.''

title: ADIRONDACK LANDMARK LODGES, FOR HISTORY AND REGIONAL ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: Committee Favors Yonkers Project
description: Plans to build a $100 million office park at the site of a former Yonkers city dump have been approved by a committee of the Westchester County Board of Legislators, a spokesman said today.

title: Energy Corp.
description: The Energy Management Corporation of Denver announced that it had missed an interest payment of $562,500 that was due on Sept. 30 to holders of its 15 percent participating investment certificates. The company added that it would also not be able to meet the semiannual interest payment of $900,000 due to holders of its 12 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: PRIAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $560,000 for the latest first quarter and $43,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: GOALIE, 18, ANSWERS CRITICS
description: The mail started arriving quickly.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago results reflect the acquisition of Talsol Corp. in June 1983.

title: Europeans Leading In Ryder Cup Golf
description: A team of professional golfers from Europe emerged with a surprising lead today in the first round of the Ryder Cup Matches. The Europeans won four matches to the Americans' three, and the eighth match of the day ended in a tie. Since a tie gives each side a half-point, the score was 4 1/2 for Europe to 3 1/2 for the United States.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Inventories Rose 1.2% In August
description: Inventories held by American businesses rose 1.2 percent in August, the largest month-to-month increase since April 1980, as the economic recovery prompted retailers to restock to keep up with sales, the Government reported today,

title: DEAL WITH CITY'S SPORTS TEAMS AS BUSINESSES
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers in Chicago Resume Contract Talks
description: Striking Chicago teachers resumed talks with the school board today as the walkout in the nation's third-largest school district ended a second week with 436,000 students out of classes.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JAPAN GOES OWN WAY IN PARIS
description: Drums rolled and 16 models took giant steps down the runway of one of the four tents set up in the courtyard of the Louvre. The French ready-to-wear shows for spring and summer had begun. On Thursday, the first significant day of more than a week of showings, the dominant accent was Japanese.

title: CARRUTHERSES IN PAIRS
description: Peter and Caitlin Carruthers, who have won three United States titles, captured the gold medal tonight in the pairs competition in Skate America '83.

title: ROCKET INQUIRY DELAYS SHUTTLE
description: Unable to resolve a potential problem with a rocket nozzle, the space agency tonight postponed the planned Oct. 28 launching of the space shuttle Columbia with a $1 billion European Spacelab. The flight was tentatively rescheduled for Nov. 28.

title: Volvo Bus Pact
description: The Volvo of America Corporation was awarded a $10 million contract to supply 50 buses to the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority of Philadelphia, the auto maker said. It is Volvo's first contract for transit buses in the United States, the Rockleigh, N.J., concern said.

title: WITNESS CHARGED AS PERJURER
description: An important prosecution witness who told conflicting stories in the trial of Gerald T. Gerlock Jr., convicted of fatally running down a 7-year-old Hispanic boy with his car, was indicted today on perjury charges.

title: Regan Belittles the Idea Of U.S. Industrial Policy
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, taking the offensive in the intensifying political debate over Government policies to aid particular industries, said today that none of the proposals being considered by Democratic Presidential candidates ''can stand the test of reality.'

title: MUSE AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $3,957,000 from the sale of tax credits. c-Net income including a nonrecurring gain of $3,592,000 from the sale of tax credits.

title: UNGERMANN-BASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $312,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $48,000 for the quarter and $114,000 for the 9 months.

title: Quarterback Loses Plea
description: Jon English has lost his latest court effort to continue as Tulane's quarterback. In a 5-2 ruling, the Louisiana Supreme Court refused to impose a new stay of a ruling by the National Collegiate Athletic Association declaring him ineligible.

title: SuperSonics Sold
description: Sam Schulman, long at odds with the National Basketball Association's hierarchy and other N.B.A. owners, announced today that he had sold the SuperSonics to Barry Ackerley, a 49- year-old Seattle billboard entrepreneur, for $21 million.

title: CONTROVERSY OVER JANE FONDA COSTS NASA OFFICIAL HIS POST
description: The space agency's director of public affairs is leaving his post amid controversy over the attention given to Jane Fonda, the actress and political activist, who was an invited guest at a space shuttle launching last June. Both White House and space officials confirmed yesterday that they had been upset by the controversy and by remarks made by the director that were considered favorable to Miss Fonda.

title: IN EAST HAMPTON, LAND NEEDS PROTECTION
description: What should be a great local resource is turning into a local disaster at the hands of the Reagan Administration.

title: Swedish Prices Up 0.7%
description: Sweden's consumer prices increased seven-tenths of 1 percent in September from August, rising to a level 9.5 percent higher than in September 1982, Statistics Sweden said today. The month-to-month increase resulted primarily from higher prices for clothing, footwear and home heating oil, the Government agency said.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1983
description: National

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
STANDARD SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including equity in earnings of Pittway Corp. of $2,635,000 for the quarter and $5,570,000 for the 6 months. c-Including equity in earnings of Pittway Corp. of $2,705,000 for the quarter and $6,960,000 for the 6 months.

title: REAGAN AND AIDES SAID TO DISPUTE CLARK'S SUCCESSOR
description: President Reagan was said today to have encountered disagreement among his senior foreign policy advisers over who should succeed William P. Clark as the White House national security adviser.

title: Staff Disciplined In Football Death
description: The Superintendent of Schools here announced today that as a result of her investigation into the death of a 17-year-old junior varsity football player she had transferred several teachers to other schools and barred them from ever taking part again in the district's sports program.

title: PALSEY ORGANIZATION OF NEW YORK STATE FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The United Cerebral Palsy Associations of New York, the private, nonprofit organization that assumed care of hundreds of severely handicapped and retarded patients released from the state's Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island, filed for bankruptcy yesterday.

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The decrease in the quarter resulted primarily from a nonrecurring $3.8 million after-tax gain recorded in the third quarter of 1982 following the sale of an equity interest.

title: OPERA: 'MICE AND MEN'
description: The New York City Opera has never been afraid to put its money on modern American works. Its continuing effort in that regard is not to be undervalued, no matter what the record of success or failure. Thursday night the company gave another fairly recent opera an opportunity to shine by introducing New York to Carlisle Floyd's 13-year-old verismo drama, ''Of Mice and Men.''

title: BLISS, A T, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SNIPER IN LEBANON KILLS U.S. MARINE
description: One United States marine was killed and another wounded today when Marine positions at Beirut International Airport came under sniper fire from neighboring Shiite Moslem quarters, a Marine spokesman said.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Dr. Henry A. Barton yesterday misstated the date of a memorial service. It will be held Oct. 24 at 10:30 A.M. in the Princeton University chapel.

title: I.B.M. NET UP 24.8% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, showing its muscle in virtually every segment of the computer industry, reported yesterday that net income climbed 24.8 percent in the third quarter, to $1.3 billion, from the comparable period last year.

title: AIDS Doctor Gets Stay of Eviction
description: A doctor who treated patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome was granted a temporary injunction yesterday barring tenants of a Greenwich Village cooperative building from evicting him.

title: Rollins Suspension Cut
description: Commissioner Larry O'Brien has reduced the suspension of Wayne (Tree) Rollins , the Atlanta Hawk center, which is scheduled to begin at the start of the regular season, from five games to two games following an appeals hearing held earlier this week, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday. Rollins was fined $5,000 and suspended by the league after an incident that took place during a playoff game between Atlanta and Boston April 24, when he elbowed Danny Ainge of the Celtics and bit one of Ainge's fingers.

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The shares outstanding and per share figures were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 3, 1983.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a tax credit of $100,000.

title: '84 CONVERTIBLES: SHAKEOUT SEEN
description: The convertible, symbol of youth, freedom and romance, has come cruising back since it was abandoned by the domestic auto industry in the 1970's.

title: RAI RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Trooper Guilty Of Stealing Tires
description: A suspended New Jersey state police sergeant today pleaded guilty to stealing more than $500 worth of tires from the state.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell by $1.1 billion in the week ended Oct. 5. Analysts hailed the sharp drop as the strongest evidence in weeks that the money supply was under control.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: An Attempted Coup Is Reported in Grenada
description: An attempted coup against the Cuban-backed Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop in Grenada was reported yesterday, but there were conflicting accounts about the outcome.

title: A FRESHMAN STABILIZES NOTRE DAME
description: Coach Gerry Faust of Notre Dame found his new quarterback, Steve Beuerlein, in a high school game scheduled by Coach Gerry Faust of Moeller High in Cincinnati. This could turn out to be a turning point in recent Notre Dame football history.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOSPITAL CORP OF AMER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for a 4-for-3 stock split in January 1983.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
TO GET MULTINATIONALS FROM BEHIND FOREIGN SKIRTS
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.I.C. Sues Chase on Penn Square
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation charged the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday with using ''economic coercion'' to force executives of the insolvent Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma to pay Chase more than $19 million that ''rightfully belongs'' to the Government agency to pay off creditors.

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $10,148,000 for the quarter and 9 months from closedown costs.

title: JAPAN'S NEW MUSEUM OPENS ON MODERN NOTE
description: It is hard to say which is rarer in Japan - Art Deco buildings or Modern paintings. But for the next three months, art enthusiasts here have an unusual opportunity to view prime examples of both.

title: Reid Weighs Return
description: When he left the Houston Rockets last year to pursue a Pentacostal ministry, Robert Reid said his departure would be permanent.

title: Great Picture
description: Nostalgic fans of thoroughbred racing will receive a treat today when Kelso and Forego, two of the champion horses of all time, parade through the stretch before the eighth race at Belmont Park, leading the entries in the Jockey Club Gold Cup onto the track. Among the challengers in the $570,000 race will be the 8-year-old gelding, John Henry, who won the race in 1981.

title: REPUBLICBANK OF DALLAS GETS MIDLAND
description: The First National Bank of Midland, Tex., beleaguered by nonperforming energy loans, was declared insolvent last night by the Comptroller of the Currency, and regulators immediately arranged for its purchase by the Republicbank Corporation of Dallas.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A STOIC FOREIGN WORK FORCE FILLS SAUDI JOBS
description: Jenna, a cousin of a foreign worker in Saudi Arabia, says she does not know how old she is, or exactly how long ago she came to this country from Pakistan. She does know that she has borne nine children, all of whom died. This year - ''Thanks be to God,'' she said - she had a son, whom she proudly displayed.

title: A 3d Royal Pleads Guilty
description: Jerry Martin today became the third Kansas City Royal in the last two days to plead guilty to a Federal charge of attempted cocaine possession, a misdemeanor. Like Willie Wilson and Willie Aikens, Martin, a 34-year-old outfielder, was released on a $5,000 personal recognizance bond and will be sentenced Nov. 17.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
Reagan Selects Emery For St. Lawrence Post
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate the former minority leader of the New York State Assembly, James L. Emery, a Republican of Geneseo, to be the administrator of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.

title: Rooseveltor Jump in Rents
description: More than 1,700 tenants in all three rental buildings on Roosevelt Island have received notices from the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal that their rents may rise 50 percent or more beginning Jan. 1.

title: INQUIRY FINDS ABUSE OF INMATES IN A YOUTH HOUSE
description: The Hudson County Prosecutor charged today that inmates at the Hudson County Youth House had been physically and sexually abused.

title: A.M.C. Rehirings
description: The American Motors Corporation said that, starting next week, it will have no workers on indefinite layoff for the first time since 1979. The No. 4 United States auto maker, which had 2,700 workers on indefinite layoff on Jan. 1, will have called back all its idled workers at plants in Kenosha, Wis., and Toledo, Ohio, by next week, the company said. A.M.C. will be the first domestic auto maker to empty its layoff lists.

title: TELEPHONE SUPPORT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: HONDURANS SEEK MORE U.S. AID
description: Officials here have told President Reagan's commission on Central America that Honduras will need $500 million a year in American economic aid over the next 12 years, a fivefold increase, a Government spokesman said today. In addition, military officials are expected to ask for an increase in military aid to $400 million over the next three years, a tenfold rise.

title: PENTAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Consumer Debt Rose In August
description: Consumers took on $3.39 billion more in installment debt in August than they paid off, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Singapore Official Dies
description: Finance Minister Hon Sui Sen, a 13-year veteran of Parliament, died of a heart attack today, the Government announced. He was 67 years old. Mr. Hon played a major role in the development of Singapore's economy and in strengthening the island-state as a leading financial center in Southeast Asia. A graduate of Raffles College in Singapore, Mr. Hon joined the British Straits Settlements Civil Service in 1939 and later held a variety of posts.

title: CBS IS ORDERED TO GIVE WESTMORELAND ITS NOTES
description: A Federal District Judge yesterday ordered CBS News to supply Gen. William C. Westmoreland with the notes used to prepare an investigation of how it put together a documentary that accused the general of conspiring to falsify figures on enemy troop strength.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Oct 2
Governor Cancels Plan For 2-Day Quebec Trip
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he had called off an official visit to Quebec that had been scheduled for next week.

title: GULF STOCK TRADING IS FANNING RUMORS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation stock was the most active yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 3 million shares changing hands. The stock closed at 47, up 1 from the day before.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $73,000 for the quarter and $376,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dr. Hymie Nossel Dies at 53; Columbia Medical Professor
description: Dr. Hymie L. Nossel, professor of medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and an authority on blood coagulation, died of a heart attack last Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1983
description: The Economy

title: EMPTY SILENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CLARK PRAISED AND ASSAILED ON ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES
description: Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, today defended the qualifications of William P. Clark to be Secretary of the Interior, saying Mr. Clark had ''a lifetime history of interest in environmental issues.''

title: Toyota, Nissan
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company built more motor vehicles in September than they had a year earlier, according to reports released separately.

title: DOW HALTS FIGHT TO SELL HERBICIDE
description: The Dow Chemical Company announced today that it was abandoning its efforts to have a herbicide that contains dioxin certified as safe for use as an agricultural chemical. The chemical, 2,4,5-trichlorophenoxyacetic acid, was a component of Agent Orange, a defoliant used in Vietnam.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: The father of a 19-year-old man who spent $6,000 in savings on lottery tickets, then attempted suicide when he did not win the $2.5 million jackpot, says he blames the state for offering the lure of such large winnings.

title: Confession Frees Man Serving Life for Murder
description: A man who spent nearly four years in prison for a murder another man has confessed was released today from the Missouri State Penitentiary.

title: SUBWAY QUEENS OF OLD TO GATHER FOR REUNION
description: Once there was a young woman - Ruth Ericsson was her name - who worked at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel filing the nails and pushing back the cuticles of people she imagined were on their way to glamorous nightclubs, expensive restaurants and elegant society affairs.

title: BRIEFING
description: Bid to Cool Feud

title: STAGE: 'WAY OF HOW,' GEORGE COATES COLLAGE
description: George Coates's performance piece ''The Way of How'' is a visual and aural essay in the orchestration of human behavior. It has no story or even serial movement as it shifts artistic gears from photographic projections to surrealistic choreography to opera arias and vaudeville pranks. The eclectic 80-minute collage is unified by Paul Dresher's mesmerizing score. ''The Way of How'' follows ''The Photographer'' as the second event in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival.

title: New Zealander to Visit U.S.
description: President Reagan will meet Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon of New Zealand in Washington early next year, the White House announced today. The two will confer on Feb. 24.

title: National Gallery to Buy Pollock and Segal Art
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington voted yesterday to buy major works by Jackson Pollock and George Segal.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-earlier per share figures were adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock split May 31, 1983.

title: BERKLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
BRIEFS
description: * Amstar Corp. said that several lawsuits, purporting to be class actions, had been filed against the corporation, its directors and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. in the Chancery Court in Delaware. The suits charge that the previously announced agreement in principle for the acquisition of Amstar by a group of investors led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. violated Delaware law.

title: Letter: On Energy Store Oil Where It's Used To the Editor:
description: The recent spate of editorials urging that the U.S. get on with the purchase of oil for the nation's strategic petroleum reserve (S.P.R.) reveal another very important advantage that could stem from accelerated oil purchases for the reserve.

title: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEST CHEMICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Including tax credits of $36,000 for the quarter and $92,000 for the 9 months and a loss from discontinued operations of $90,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a charge of $70,000. d-Including a tax credit of $242,000 and a gain of $133,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Father Who Took Girl Gets Temporary Right
description: A California court today granted a part-time landscaper temporary custody of the daughter he fled with three years ago after losing a custody case in New York.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: DOUBLE BLESSING FOR AN INTERNATIONAL CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOLARS FIND BAD IMAGE STILL PLAGUES U.S. ITALIANS
description: Much on the minds of the scholars at a two-day conference this week on the Italian experience in the United States was how to lay to rest negative images plaguing Italian-Americans for generations.

title: Strawberry Bids Goodbye to Tutor
description: When Jim Frey was named manager of the Chicago Cubs last week, one of the first phone calls he received came from Darryl Strawberry. It was a conversation of decidedly mixed moods, a parting between professor and pupil.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Frazier-Holmes In Atlantic City
description: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, said yesterday that his son's title fight with Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, would take place at Atlantic City. Marvis Frazier, 23 years old, who is unbeaten in 10 pro fights, is scheduled to face Holmes in a 12-round bout on Nov. 25.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tactics Important in Gold Cup
description: Six months ago, John Henry was on the verge of being retired, Slew o' Gold and Play Fellow had not won a stakes race, and Highland Blade had not won a race on the dirt for more than two years. Today, they are the favorites for the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park and if one of them wins, he will be the top candidate for the horse-of-the-year title.

title: BLACKS EXPRESS REGRET AT MCGUIRE'S QUITTING
description: Several black activists who had called for the Congressional hearings into allegations of brutality toward minority groups by New York City police officers expressed regret yesterday over the resignation of Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire.

title: Argentina Debt Plan
description: Argentina's 11-bank advisory group yesterday recommended that the nation's 300 commercial bank creditors agree to the disbursal of $500 million from a $1.5 billion loan on Oct. 28.

title: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $31,000. c-Net loss after charges of approximately $165,000 on start-up costs for new contracts. Share earnings figures are fully diluted.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $31,000 for the quarter and $24.6 million for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,991,000 for the quarter and $5.2 million for the year.

title: Pavelich Rouses the Rangers
description: Herb Brooks is not one to single out players for individual praise after games. Almost to excess, the Ranger coach stresses the team concept.

title: CONSCIENTIOUS STUDENTS CAN LEARN LANGUAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LADD FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
VICTOR M'QUISTION
description: Victor McQuistion, president of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation in the late 1940's, died Thursday at the Humana Hospital Cypress in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THOMAS BENJAMIN GAY
description: Thomas Benjamin Gay, who served as chairman of the House of Delegates of the American Bar Association from 1939 to 1941 and was a member of the Richmond law firm of Hunton & Williams for 75 years, died of pneumonia Thursday at Henrico Doctor's Hospital in Richmond.

title: CARNEGIE HALL ANNOUNCES MANAGEMENT CHANGES
description: Edward Michaelsen, the managing director of Carnegie Hall, has resigned, effective Nov. 15, and the management of Carnegie Hall will be restructured to replace him with two managing directors, James D. Wolfensohn, the Carnegie chairman, said yesterday.

title: LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $1.2 million, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $2.7 million, or 24 cents a share, for the 9 months from the liquidation of LIFO inventories. c-Including gains of $2.5 million, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and $3.5 million, or 31 cents a share, for the 9 months from the liquidation of LIFO inventories and a gain of $1.5 million, or 13 cents a share, on the sale of properties. Certain year-ago results have been restated.

title: ACKLANDS LTD. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a gain of $1,391,000 on the sale of subsidiaries.

title: UNION BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Turkish Company Gets Ford Link
description: The Ford Motor Company announced that it would buy 30 percent of the Turkish auto maker Otomobil Sanayii Anomin Sirketi, over the next three years to expand Ford's presence in the region.

title: Bridge: The Fine Points of Making A Lead Can Be Important
description: Teachers and textbooks do not always make clear the delicate distinction between leading against no- trump and against a suit.

title: FERN LOWRY
description: Fern Lowry, a former professor at the Columbia University School of Social Work, died of a stroke on Oct. 3 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. She was 87 years old and resided in Stamford.

title: Associate of Trump Is Generals' Chairman
description: Jay Seltzer, a 53-year-old retired real-estate lawyer, will run the day- to-day business operations of the New Jersey Generals as their chairman, sources familiar with the team said yesterday. The formal announcement is expected next week in Houston at the meetings of United States Football League executives.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Overlap Possible
description: If today's World Series game is a slow one, or if it goes into extra innings, college football fans are likely to miss some of the early play between Nebraska and Missouri at Columbia, Mo.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Computer Snag Halts Trading
description: Futures trading at the New York Commodity Exchange Center was interrupted yesterday afternoon - and halted for some commodities - because of a computer failure, the exchange announced. Officials said the problem occurred at about 2:30 P.M., just before the final bell in silver and gold trading, and that those contracts were settled.

title: EAST SAYS MISSILE TALKS MUST CONTINUE
description: Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact said today that it was essential for negotiations on medium-range missiles to continue past the end of the year, but they made their call contingent on a change in American plans to start deploying new missiles in December.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reduction of $2,200,000 from the discontinuance of the electronic ballast operation and income of $450,000, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of certain properties. Sales for the latest year have been adjusted downward to reflect the discontinued electronics.

title: GIBRALTAR SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: JAPANESE ASTRONOMERS MAKE FIRST IMAGE OF DUST RINGS AROUND SUN
description: Japanese astronomers have taken a picture of twin rings of dust around the Sun. While the existence of the rings had been hypothesized as early as 1927 and evidence of them was recorded in 1966, American astronomers yesterday hailed the Japanese achievement as one of special importance, since the rings have never before been seen in their entirety.

title: FLORIDA COAST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $1.4 million from an equity-for-debt exchange.

title: CINCINNATI BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Polish Communist Party Starts a Delayed Parley
description: The leaders of Poland's Communist Party began a long-postponed meeting to chart their ideological future today amid signs of division, but with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's position apparently secure.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CYPRESS SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRITISH CABINET MEMBER RESIGNS IN SCANDAL OVER HIS EX-SECRETARY
description: Cecil Parkinson, who managed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's re-election campaign last summer, resigned in a scandal today from his senior post in her Government.

title: King Drops Jersey Bid
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, has abandoned his two-year quest for a New Jersey gaming license that would allow him to stage fights at Atlantic City casinos. State law requires those with ''continuing'' financial dealings with the casinos to obtain such a license from the Casino Control Commission, and King applied for his in 1981.

title: INTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 16
description: b-After a loss of $293,000 for the quarter and 6 months from securities transactions. c-Net income including tax credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $25,000 for the 6 months.

title: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,051,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,238,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: EXXON IS FAULTED ON USE OF HUDSON
description: The Exxon Corporation, which has been dumping polluted sea water into the Hudson River and taking fresh water from the river to a refinery in Aruba, was accused yesterday of not getting two permits necessary for the operation.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT GREW LAST MONTH BY A STRONG 1.5%
description: The nation's industrial production surged 1.5 percent last month, strong evidence that economic expansion has remained vigorous despite high interest rates.

title: BRING BACK THE RIGOR COLLEGES PRACTICED
description: The welcome concern about thinking and writing and rigor in education, much of it by college teachers and administrators, has failed almost totally to focus on college education itself.

title: LA POINTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CLARK'S CHANGE OF JOBS
description: News Analysis

title: UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: The listing of lottery numbers yesterday misstated the daily New York State winner. It was 597.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-The company said that share earnings were not relevant for any period prior to the second quarter of 1982 because Savings Bank of Puget Sound had no shares outstanding prior to its initial public offering.

title: Socal Profits Forecast
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said yesterday that it expects third-quarter earnings to approximate those of the 1982 period.

title: Independence Day
description: Shopping bags proclaiming ''White Cane Safety Day'' and containing information about blindness will be distributed today near Bloomingdale's and Macy's in Manhattan and at the Queens Center in Queens. The white cane, says David Stayer, president of the state Federation of the Blind, signals to the sighted ''the independence that blind people have achieved.''

title: MACROSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results were reclassified.

title: 6 Students Seized In Racial Fights
description: Fights between black and white students in and around Beach Channel High School in Rockaway Park, Queens, resulted in minor injuries and the arrest of six students this week, school and Police Department officials said yesterday.

title:
Patents;
Urine Thermometor
description: Dr. Joel R. L. Ahrenkranz, an endocrinologist on the faculty of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, has invented a body thermometer that registers temperature from urine. Patent 4,408,905, issued to Dr. Ahrenkranz this week, explains that urine is collected in a chamber containing liquid crystal measuring units; registered temperature is then displayed on an outside monitor. Prototypes have been in clinical use and the instrument will be manufactured for marketing next spring.

title:
Patents;
Alkaloid Compound
description: A new compound called xeronine, described as an alkaloid useful in medical, food and industrial fields, was patented this week for the Research Corporation of the University of Hawaii in Honolulu.

title: Dupree Visits Coach at Southern Miss
description: Marcus Dupree talked to the University of Southern Mississippi football coach today about transferring from Oklahoma next season.

title: HEARING DELAYED ON DR. KING DATA
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, today lost a bid for an early court hearing on his request to unseal transcripts the Federal Bureau of Investigation made of overheard conversations involving the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Informer Says Wilson Wanted Wife Killed
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, was described in trial testimony yesterday as a man who hired professional killers to murder his former wife.

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: The New Ditka
description: He has screamed at officials, scolded his players in public and broken his hand punching a steel filing cabinet, but now, with his club's record at 2-4, Mike Ditka, the hot-tempered coach of the Chicago Bears, has adopted a new coaching formula - cool detatchment. ''I got my priorities out of whack for the last couple of weeks, and it hurt me as an individual,'' said Ditka, who expressed hope that his relaxed new stance will take some of the pressure off his players.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

Patents;
Decorative Laminate
description: Ty solA New York consultant has conceived a decorative laminate for home, business or even military use.

title: The Virtues and Vices of Bees
description: ''How doth the little busy bee / Improve each shining hour.'' So exclaimed Isaac Watts, the 18th- century hymn writer, in holding up the industrious insect as a model to idle children. And those who grind morals from the social mores of bees will find new grist in the latest tidbit of apian lifestyle. Bees, it seems, have discovered the advantages that accrue from extreme specialization of labor.

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $46.9 million for the quarter and $113.3 million for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: Railroad Double Crossing
description: Here is a television commercial trying to sell household computers between innings at the baseball tube:

title: FILLING PHYLLO (STRUDEL) WITH SURPRISE STUFFINGS
description: The freewheeling spirit that has characterized American cooking in the past few years has reached into Middle Europe and the Middle East for one of its newer inspirations. The translucent sheets of pastry known as phyllo in Greece, yufka in Turkey and strudel in Central Europe are being used to wrap things that had never seen the inside of the dough until Americans began experimenting with them.

title: NO SIGN OF MAJOR POLICY CHANGES
description: President Chun Doo Hwan, moving swiftly to demonstrate the continuity of his Government, reorganized the top levels of his Cabinet tonight to replace officials who died in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 9.

title: MARCOS BEGINS A NEW INQUIRY ON FOE'S DEATH
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that a new commission would investigate the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: BONDS WHOSE TIME HAS GONE
description: Closing a tax loophole is often like pulling a sugar cube out of a horse's mouth. You don't want to be bitten, yet there is no way to convince the horse that the sugar is bad for him. That's the lesson being learned by the Administration and Representative J. J. Pickle, Democrat of Texas, as they try to curb the use and abuse of industrial development bonds.

title: NEW BIBLE TEXT MAKES GOD MALE AND FEMALE
description: A new translation of Bible readings designed to eliminate references to God as solely male was released yesterday by the National Council of Churches.

title: A Harmonious West Side Takes a Look at Itself
description: ''When I began to succeed as a writer,'' said Isaac Bashevis Singer, ''people told me writers can afford to move to the East Side.'' But he decided to stay and go ''up, up, up with the West Side.''

title: DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION IMPRESARIO
description: ''If you could plan the perfect convention, it's right here in what we call our bible,'' Rosalind W. Wyman announced as she flipped the pages of a fat ledger with tabs that read ''platform committee,'' ''page coordinator,'' ''rules,'' ''arrangements committee.'' She paused and added cheerfully, ''But you know how disorganized Democrats are - we are already off schedule.''

title: To Interior, a One-Way Secretary
description: President Reagan's nomination of William Clark to succeed Interior Secretary James Watt compliments a friend. It will soon be apparent whether the choice also insults friends of the environment. For all those who hope for a reasonable balance between development and preservation, the initial signs are discouraging.

title: EXPANDED RECYCLING IS FAVORED IN A STUDY TO HELP SLASH COSTS
description: Costs of some basic materials could rise in industrial countries unless greater efforts are made to recycle used materials, according to a study released here today by the Worldwatch Institute, a research center.

title: COMPUTER SEVICE FOCUS OF INQUIRY
description: Federal investigators who seized computer equipment from youths around the country last week say their inquiry is focusing on computer enthusiasts' unauthorized use of an electronic message service that has 130 companies as clients.

title: RACING FANS CHEER KELSO AND FOREGO
description: If it seemed more like 1963 or 1973 than 1983 at Belmont Park yesterday, there were plenty of reasons: a crowd of more than 30,000 for a race other than the Belmont Stakes, the voice of Fred (Cappie) Capossela over the public-address system, and a couple of horses on the track named Kelso and Forego.

title: INTERNSHIPS: TESTING THE WATERS
description: AFTER 20 years as a wife and mother, frequent fund-raiser and community volunteer, Claudia Michalson wanted a full-time job. She knew, however, that without contacts or concrete work experience, her job search would be difficult.

title: MARCOS TRIES ANOTHER TACK
description: Despite President Ferdinand Marcos's most vigorous efforts to dispel it, the ghost of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. continues to haunt the Philippines. Last week, the high-level commission the President had appointed to investigate the murder of Mr. Aquino, the opposition leader, abruptly quit, in response to widespread doubts about its impartiality.

title: GETTING AHEAD: M.B.A. VS. LAW DEGREE
description: THE increasingly complex and competitive nature of the business world long ago reduced the bachelor's degree to an educational steppingstone on the path to the executive suite. In the past, the final, surest step to the corner-office door was the law degree. By World War II, according to figures compiled by the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company, three-quarters of all executive officers of leading corporations held law degrees. But today the road that a promising young trainee should take, by most accounts, is the one that leads to a master of business administration degree.

title: CLARK'S MOVE TO NTERIOR MAKES EXTERNAL WAVES
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN'S abrupt decision to nominate William P. Clark, the national security adviser, to be Secretary of the Interior had immediate implications for foreign and domestic policy, campaign politics and the Reagan Presidency. It also offered a window on the relationship of two close friends and on a paradox of the President's style. Reliant as he is on his aides for guidance, Mr. Reagan's independence of mind can still startle.

title: Tiffany Chin Takes Singles Skating Final
description: Americans competing in the Skate America tournament made a clean sweep today in the finals of the Ladies' Singles competition, with Tiffany Chin of Toluca Lake, Calif., taking the gold medal.

title: CITY IS SHORTED IN SOME DEVELOPMENT DEALS
description: In the midst of a fierce battle two years ago over demolition of the Biltmore Hotel, a nonprofit preservation group signed an agreement that it thought would preserve the elegant charm of the hotel's famous Palm Court. The developers who were replacing the hotel at 43d Street and Madison Avenue with an office tower promised to re-create the Palm Court and other hotel features in the lobby of their new building. In return, the New York Landmarks Conservancy agreed to testify against designation of the hotel as a city landmark, something that would have made demolition difficult.

title: FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION
description: 140,12THE SEARCH FOR NEW FASHION TALENTS IS AN ONgoing one, no matter how successful and expansive are the horizons of ''name'' designers. Both stores and customers are always on the lookout to make that big discovery. Among the current finds are Stephen Sprouse, Frans Haers and Andre Walker, each of whom has a definite view of what fashion should be. Sprouse, a 30-year-old who opened his own business nine months ago, cuts understandable shapes and aims for what he calls comfortable and functional clothes - functional in that his buttons are for buttoning, his pockets are for hands, not just for decoration. But what makes his clothes distinct are his explosive, fluorescent colors and his graffiti-type prints. They are of high quality, made with expensive materials, which, of course, makes for high prices. One of his wool coats goes for $1,720, a cashmere dress for $560.

title: REPLACING OF WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE IS STUDIED
description: State engineers now engaged in extensive repairs of the deteriorating Williamsburg Bridge have begun studying the feasibility of replacing the 80-year-old East River bridge if restoration proves too costly, the state's top regional transportation official said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Dual Job-Holding By Officials Decried Dual job-holding is a way of life in New Jersey. There are mayors who are freeholders, councilmen who are county job-holders and state legislators who have municipal or county jobs, or both.

title: TEXAS DOWNS ARKANSAS, 31-3
description: Rob Moerschell completed three long passes, two for touchdowns, as Texas routed Arkansas, 31-3, today in a Southwest Conference game.

title: No Headline
description: Correction

title: NEW BREED OF WORKERS: COMPUTER WATCHDOGS
description: -PROCESSING manager for a major corporation suddenly notices unusual levels of activity on his company's computer. He investigates, and discovers that the system has been tampered with over telephone lines. Corporate panic follows as company officials try to determine what was disclosed, what was damaged and how vulnerable their computer is to further invasions.

title: WEDEL WEEKS IN ZERMATT
description: BANNON McHENRY is a writer who lives in New York. Although in late fall the sound of sleigh bells on the horse- drawn taxis greets the arriving train, the sleds are not yet attached for the snow hasn't quite reached the village. But snow covers the mountains and glaciers above, as it does even in summer, and it is time for early skiing. Beginning in mid-November, under brilliant autumn skies, the ski teachers of Zermatt hold four one- week Wedel (pronounced vadle, rhyming with ladle) Ski Courses and their preseason prices offer one of the best bargains around.

title: THE LAST HARVEST
description: FROST is in the air. Tomorrow my garden will be blackened waste. I put my hands in my jacket pocket and discover a packet of seeds from spring, butternut squash. I harvested the last of that crop, a baby butternut squash found among the leaves of a sprawling plant.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHEN it comes to concert tours, Beverly Somach of Franklin Lakes is an old hand. The only thing she usually worries about is whether the two violins she carries on flights (one is a spare) will not be lost or damaged.

title: SOME IN ALABAMA CITY LIKE IT DRY, OTHERS WET
description: Over the last two decades, George Royer has repeatedly tried to convince his fellow citizens here that there is profit and even virtue in legalizing the sale of alcoholic beverages.

title: I.M.F.'s Perils
description: To the Business Editor:

title: MYSTERIES OF A HARDCASE
description: DASHIELL HAMMETT

title: A $200 BILLION FAMILY FEUD
description: Robert Ortner's analysis of the week's economic indicators was shared by most specialists. ''The economy is still humming along,'' the Commerce Department's chief analyst said.

title: ON THE L.I.R.R., WOULDN'T IN BE NICE
description: YEARS ago, when I was a boy growing up in Brooklyn, I would go to the movies on Saturday afternoons. The movies always displayed in those Depression days of the 30's exotic cities and exotic actors: Shanghai, the Casbah, Charles Boyer, Ronald Colman, etc. I was like any other kid at the time, except I never quite lost the impression of those golden messages of the Orient Express.

title: No Headline
description: Cello Prize Awarded To California Student

title: THIS IS THE BALLGAME
description: ''This is the ballgame,'' opined one of the President's closest longtime advisers. To him, the choice of the national security adviser to replace William Clark would determine both the image and the reality of Reagan foreign policy.

title: SHOREHAM ISSUE SPLITS PARTY RANKS IN SUFFOLK
description: WITH Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin, the Democratic candidate for Suffolk County Executive, and Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk Democratic County chairman, going one way on Shoreham and 18 Democratic candidates for the County Legislature going another way, the party is split on the issue dominating the Suffolk election campaign.

title:
SPORTS;
OVER THE HILL GANG IS ANYTHING BUT
description: ALTHOUGH the calendar clearly indicated that it was September, the weather on that warm autumn evening in Miller Place was more indicative of July. The flow of play from the ankles on up suggested ice hockey; yet the playing surface was not frozen. The ultimate paradox was a team known as the Over the Hill Gang, with its trim, wiry athletes, playing more like a well-oiled machine than its name implies.

title: ART ; RIVIERE AND JAPONISME AT THE RUTGERS MUSEUM
Lindsay Harper To Wed in Fall
description: Anne Lindsay Harper, an artist, and Emile Francis duPont, executive producer at Jaguar Productions, a television commercial production company in New York, plan to be married Nov. 26.

title: SPECIAL COVERAGE FOR CO-OPS
description: -cut insurance needs of rental tenants, who should cover their furnishings and personal belongings, or the owners of a house, who should cover the structure as well as its contents, the coverage requirements of a condominium or cooperative owner are complex.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A TEST FOR MATURITY AND MANHOOD
description: IN a day when two-, three- and four-car families are not unusual, it is hard to realize how

title: GRASSROOTS ARE BECOMING A TRICKY POLITICAL THICKET
description: Every four years, as part of the Presidential campaign ritual, political candidates and reporters begin scouring grassroots America, that land of part myth and part reality, part clover and part briarpatch, for those issues that boil up from the people.

title: 10,000 Demonstrate Against Nuclear Arms
description: About 10,000 people held a peaceful demonstration against the arms race today at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant but failed in their effort to form a human ring around the facility some 15 miles north of here.

title: A BLOW FOR INHUMANITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Congdon Wed To Margaret Herrity
description: Margaret A. Herrity, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Herrity of Grand Rapids, Mich., was married there yesterday to Michael Congdon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Congdon of Brooklyn Heights. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William O'Brien at St. Michael's Episcopal Church.

title: No Headline
description: Woodbridge Stops Edison Mike Doering caught a pass for a touchdown and ran for another to

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS THE cowboys are riding their quarter horses, the man with the lariat is showing his skill, a singer is telling tales of the streets of Laredo. At the same time, people are lining up for Nathan's Famous hot dogs and potato knishes, and chatting about the latest building to ''go condo'' in their neighborhood.

title: CABARET: WOMEN VS. WOMEN
description: The High Heeled Women, the musical comedy quartet that performs Thursday nights at Upstairs at Greene Street, has fashioned a revue that moves at high velocity and delivers an abundance of sharp witticisms.

title: Marian T. Campi and Jerome A. Henderson Marry
description: Marian Teresa Campi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor John Campi of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jerome Anthony Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Henderson of Rumson and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. William J. Kokoszka, assisted by the Rev. Michael Vona, performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: COMPUTER INDUSTRY: MORE JOBS DESPITE LAYOFFS
description: WHEN the Osborne Computer Corporation, in Hayward, Calif., laid off David Berg along with more than 300 other people as it filed for bankruptcy last month, he didn't spend much time unemployed. One week later, Mr. Berg, a software engineer, had accepted a job for higher pay at a new company in nearby San Jose that designs computer systems for hotels.

title: ; MARTIN LUTHER'S RELEVANCE TODAY --
description: Jaroslav Pelikan dealt admirably with Martin Luther's complexities. It is surprising, however, that he failed to mention Luther's miysogyny, which like his anti-Semitism was not extraordinary during the period in which he lived, but which was an equally important element in his character and his theology.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DRAMATIC SERIES

title:
CRAFTS ;
THE 'CRAFTSMAN IDEAL' AT NABISCO
description: EAST HANOVER FURNITURE designed to express an early 20th-century philosophy of ''plain living and high thinking'' is on view at the Nabisco Gallery here.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: It appeared that Senator William Proxmire, who has built a career on fighting wasteful Government spending, had won a public victory but suffered a private defeat in November 1982.

title: WHEN A DEBT PAYS A DEBT
description: The finances of many debtor countries are so weak that only new loans will repay old ones; it is called restructuring. Last week, Brazil, the biggest of the third world debtors, was out trying to persuade about 800 banks to go along with a plan to extend $6.5 billion in new funds so it won't have to default on some of the $90 billion it owes.

title: SLUGGING IT OUT ON THE SOFTWARE FRONT
description: When 32-year-old Mitchell L. Kapor took his fledgling computer software company, the Lotus Development Corporation, public less than two weeks ago, he made a fortune - roughly $70 million in fact. That this former radio disc jockey and teacher of transcendental meditation turned to computer programming only a few years ago simply adds to the feat. It is the stuff of which legends are made, especially in the personal computer software business.

title: Jill Meredith Winer Wed To Howard Benjamin Fife
description: Jill Meredith Winer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Winer of Morristown, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Howard Benjamin Fife, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Fife of Manhattan and Nantucket.

title: HOLDING THE BRASS RING
description: Opening variations are on a perpetual merry-go- round. At any given moment some are up and some are down, and nobody knows where any of them will be in six months - or even six weeks.

title: ACCEPTING A HEROIC CHALLENGE
description: THE AENEID

title: Karen Weiss Wed To R.M. Corbetta
description: The marriage of Karen Ann Weiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Leonard Weiss, to Richard Matthew Corbetta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Corbetta, took place yesterday. Both families are of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Francis O'Malley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: THE SUBJECT IS KURT WEILL
description: After leaving Germany in 1933, and then France in 1935 to come to the United States, Kurt Weill wanted nothing more than to become an American composer and write for the American theater. His musical style never really left behind the Berlin of the 1920's, but American scholarship is now assuring at least his posthumous musical citizenship. From Nov. 2 to Nov. 5, an International Conference on Kurt Weill will be presented in New Haven by the Yale Music Library and the Kurt Weill Foundation for Music. The same week will also see the opening of the Foundation's Weill/Lenya Research Center here in New York, at 142 West End Avenue.

title: MUSICAL--HISTORICAL SLEUTH TRACKS THE 'GHOSTS OF GERSHWINS'

title: WOMAN AND 3 BOYS ARE KILLED BY SMOKE IN CONNECICUT FIRE
description: A woman, her two sons and a visiting child were killed when smoke from a fire swept through a house in Meriden, Conn., local fire officials said yesterday.

title: STAN GETZ TO OPEN CONCERTS
description: AJAZZ concert featuring Stan Getz kicks off the 1983-1984 concert series sponsored by General Foods and the State University of New York Oct. 29 at 8 P.M.

title: ARE THESE THE ALL-TIME GREAT VOICES?
description: On Saturday - 100 years to the day it opened its doors in 1883 - the Metropolitan Opera will celebrate by running an all-day marathon. Promised are some 70 singers who will flock on and off the stage at the matinee and evening events.

title: HEADLINERS

title: BEST SELLERS FICTION 117

The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. 3317 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) title: SOLVING THE MYSTERIES OF BAKING BREAD
description: THE inspiration to light the oven comes as soon as the weather begins to cool. Not just any old baking will do. Rich whole-grain breads, their satiny doughs set to rise after a vigorous kneading, are what we have in mind.

title: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS OFFER PROFITABLE WORK
description: ANGELA M. ANGEROSA moved from her home in upstate New York to Washington, in 1979, armed with what she called a ''generic'' college degree but not knowing quite what she wanted to do with her life. One of her first stops was at an employment agency, and, she said, ''they really opened my eyes to the opportunities in associations.'' The agency led her to a staff position with a small trade association, and thus she became one of more than a million people working for the more than 40,000 nonprofit national and local trade associations and professional societies in the United States.

title: MOVEMENT CAN REACH BEYOND DANCE
description: The Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has gotten off to a lively start with ''The Photographer/Far From the Truth,'' an almost unclassifiable musical theater-piece conceived by Philip Glass and Rob Malasch.

title: Exxon Stops Supplying Nicaraguans With Oil
description: The Exxon Corporation will no longer transport oil to Nicaragua because of the increased sabotage of Nicaraguan ports, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: AFTER 'DALLAS,' THE FANTASIES ON PRIME-TIME KEEP MULTIPLYING
description: In Spain several months ago, I was invited to participate in a radio show and, with the aid of an interpreter, discuss American television. The first

title: DESPITE INTEGRATION ACCORD, PROBLEMS REMAIN N HILLSIDE
description: HILLSIDE ON MOST school days in the last eight years, Kimberly Dolan, now 12 years old, walked five blocks to Hurden-Looker Elementary School, just beyond her neighborhood of two-story Colonial houses near the center of this Union County community.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WHEN Randy Truss decided to ride a bicycle from the White House to a spot near his home in Yonkers, his family and friends were concerned: Mr. Truss has epilepsy and the trip, gruelling for any bike rider, sounded impractical and risky. The 19- year-old Lincoln High School graduate persisted, however, and he recently arrived at Getty Square, huffing and puffing a bit but otherwise apparently fine after pedaling 316 miles in two-and-a-half days.

title: Dashiell Hammett
description: If you were to go merely by the quantity (rather than the quality) of his imitators, you could argue that Dashiell Hammett was a more important writer than James Joyce. There were one or two writers of at least parboiled crime fiction before Hammett, but Hammett gave his imitators more than an attitude. He gave them a cast of characters, a resilient plot, a setting, a repertory of images, a style, a keyhole view of society, an ethos and, above all, a hero. Sam Spade is an old American type brought up to date, Hawkeye become private eye with fedora and street smarts instead of leatherstockings and wood lore, his turf the last frontier of San Francisco. The invention of a new popular genre is to the lesser world of literature what the invention of a new form of government is to the larger world of institutions - and just as rare. There are good reasons, then, for reading or writing a biography of Hammett, and Diane Johnson's cool, steady-eyed and engrossing ''Dashiell Hammett'' is the third in as many years.

title: SACHEM STAYS UNDEFEATED
description: Although Sachem lost its starting quarterback in the first quarter, the Flaming Arrows maintained their undefeated record (3-0) by beating Northport yesterday, 31-7. Fred Crasa, the team's short-yardage specialist, scored two touchdowns, both on running plays of 1 yard, and rushed for a total of 75 yards. Charlie Dixson, who suffered a bruise of the lower left back muscle after being hit by a helmet and face guard, was replaced by Mike Johnson halfway into the first quarter. Johnson completed 10 passes of 13 for 101 yards.

title: OPERA: JON VICKERS IN 'PETER GRIMES'
description: It is difficult to separate Benjamin Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' from the look and the sound of Jon Vickers in the title role. The Canadian tenor returned in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Britten's opera Thursday night, and if reports currently circulating are true, Mr. Vickers, 57 years old this month, will retire ''Peter Grimes'' from his repertory after scheduled performances in Los Angeles next year.

GARDENING;

title: POWERFUL PRISON DRAMA
description: THE Studio Theater in Lindenhurst has opened its 1983-84 season with Marsha Norman's powerful drama, ''Getting Out.'' This play, a precursor to Miss Norman's Pulitzer Prize-winning '' 'Night, Mother,'' deals with the first difficult 24 hours of freedom for an ex-convict, Arlene. It takes place simultaneously in her bleak Louisville apartment and in the Alabama prison from which she came.

Consider having a drink in the cocktail lounge beyond the central entrance. Deep chairs and tinkling piano create a serene ambience despite the airplane-hangar proportions of this area.

title: UNIQUACK ON THE ELECTION
description: Once every four years before the Presidential primary elections, we turn in this corner to our old computer buddy Uniquack for help. It was invented here in the popular days of the lie detector in the belief that what we really needed was a truth detector. We had a little private discussion:

title: Shanghai Sports Club Stops Over in Taiwan
description: A Shanghai soccer team returning from Europe made an unusual stopover here on Thursday after its airliner was diverted because of a typhoon, airline sources said today.

title: GOVERNOR WAS THE WINNER IN SESSION ON BRIDGE REPAIRS
description: HARTFORD LAST week's special session of the General Assembly was billed as an emergency meeting to authorize $42 million in bridge and highway repairs following the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge in Greenwich last June 28.

title: No Headline
description: In his Music View column Sept. 11 (''Will the Philharmonic Live Up to Its Advertising?'), Donal Henahan criticized the ''self-defeating attitudes'' of the New York Philharmonic and the policies of its music director, Zubin Mehta. Mr. Henahan also recalled that ''15 years ago, (Mr. Mehta) made some candid observations in print about the Philharmonic's reputation and quality'' and that, ''called before the musicians' union for his indiscretion, (Mr. Mehta) chose to duck, saying he was misquoted.'' In the following letter, Albert K. Webster, executive vice president and managing director of the Philharmonic, replies. To the Editor:

He was right. The Knights, who had lost nine starters to graduation, were defeated in two of their first three games.

title: 2 Terrorists Slain in Turkey
description: Security forces shot and killed two terrorists and captured two others in an operation to wipe out an outlawed leftist gang in the Black Sea coastal town of Fatsa, the martial law command said today.

title: NEW POLITICS IN BOSTON
description: No matter who is elected mayor of Boston in November, the two candidates who ran each other to a dead heat in the nonpartisan primary last week will each have illustrated a point - the same one. Increasingly, in races in which community interests are the issue, a new politics of combination matters more than old racial divisions.

The ceremony was performed at St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Cornwall Bridge, Conn., by the Rev. James B. Reynolds, an uncle of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien, headmaster of the Fairfield College Preparatory School.

The Environmental Protection Agency, commending Dow for its ''corporate statesmanship,'' took the occasion to announce that it would soon ban the sale of 2,4,5-T by other manufacturers.

You hooked them up just the way it said in the instructions. Then, at last, you flipped the switch, waiting for your new sound system to burst into song.

Before shifting his friend William Clark from national security adviser to Secretary of the Interior, the President surely considered what he would lose as well as gain. Appropriately, he seems to have concluded that Mr. Clark's performance in foreign affairs was dispensable.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER

The family-run business was established 65 years ago and last year began selling directly to the public from a one-room factory outlet. Two days each week the trimming and braid for family clothing, hats, belts, shoes, lamps, pillows, bedspreads and curtains in 50 colors and seemingly endless combinations is available at half the usual retail price or less, beginning at 3 cents a yard for odds and ends.

And treasures they are, for these paintings are masterpieces, offering as much artistic boldness and visual excitement as Raphael's idealized depictions in the papal apartments or even Michelangelo's mighty frescoes in the Sistine Chapel.

One of that episode's heroes was Felix Rohatyn, a Lazard partner highly regarded in the financial community but unknown to the general public. Mr. Rohatyn's prestidigitation as head of the Municipal Assistance Corporation propelled him to national prominence and showered more incidental publicity on the firm than it desired.

title: Lita Kean Marries in Jersey

Haack 3d, son of Mr. Haack Jr. of New Orleans and Mrs. Harry R. Neilson Jr. of Malvern, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me. The Rev. David P. Hegg performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: MONET, SUMMER, 1900
description: SIX decades ago, it seemed to many observers that the era of realism was finished. Virgina Woolf boldly denounced the old-fashioned materialist novel by arguing that in the experience of ordinary consciousness, there can be no plot, no comedy, no tragedy, no love interest or catastrophe in the accepted style. Her pronouncement of 1919 has long since become famous as a manifesto of sorts in defense of a new and revolutionary art: ''Life is a luminous halo, a semi-transparent envelope surrounding us from the beginning of consciousness to the end. Is it not the task of the novelist to convey this varying, this unknown and uncircumscribed spirit, whatever aberration or complexity it may display, with as little of the alien and external as possible?''

description: Room 522: Male, 65 . . . quadruple coronary-bypass surgery . . . very anxious about going home . . . needs to be prepared emotionally . . . wife and daughter still seem confused about his care, although nurses have talked to them many times. Recommendations: Refer for follow-up medical care and restorative cardiac nursing . . . put all instructions for family in writing.
