title: OUTDOORSHowell Raines; Fishing Off a Raft In a Cool Potomac
description: WASHINGTON WHEN we lived in the Deep South, my sons and I never had a chance to fish in waters cool and fast enough to support smallmouth bass. Since we moved to Washington, these handsome, willing fish have become a favorite quarry. For the capital of our nation, as it happens, is surrounded by network of fine smallmouth rivers that, considering their nearness to a metropolitan area of 3 million people, receive remarkably little fishing pressure.

title: A VICTORIAN CLUSTER
description: It's been a fixture in a graceful section of Greenwich, Conn., for 115 years, but the stately Victorian house at East Putnam Avenue and Old Church Road is undergoing a transformation. By next February it will have been completely refurbished and turned into the centerpiece of a seven-unit condominium development, Old Church Green.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BERGEN PUTS ITS FOLK ART ON VIEW
description: RIVER EDGE THE popularity of American folk art today is reflected by the many shows, museum exhibits and scholarly lectures analyzing the works of such self- taught craftsmen.

title: REPAIRING WATT'S DAMAGE
description: It is hard to guess what led President Reagan to choose his national security adviser, William P. Clark, to replace James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior. Still, now that the choice is made, Mr. Clark - and the environmental community - must begin to think how to repair the damage done by Mr. Watt during his three-year tenure.

title:
ART;
TAKING A NEW LOOK AT THE PICTORIALISTS
description: PHOTOGRAPHY'S acceptability as an art form, as a medium with as much expressive potential as painting, was not easily won, and it is still challenged from time to time by those who consider a photograph a product of technology, not art. But from the time of the earliest successful experiments in the 1830's, many proponents of photography have called attention to its esthetic qualities and have sought to exploit them.

title: China Denies 6 Executed Were Tibetan Dissidents
description: China's official press agency denied today that six people who were executed last month were Tibetan dissidents.

title: ON THE L.I.R.R., WOULDN'T IT BE NICE IF...
description: IT seems to me that morale

title: PAT O'BRIEN, MOVIES' ALL-AMERICAN, IS DEAD
description: Pat O'Brien, the actor who played policemen, priests and the Notre Dame coach Knute Rockne opposite Ronald Reagan's portrayal of a dying football player, ''the Gipper,'' died of a heart attack today. He was 83 years old.

title: RISING MIDEAST DANGERS
description: The Soviet Union has stationed 7,000 troops and advisers with Syrian forces - some within 50 miles of our Marines - to operate and guard highly sophisticated Soviet planes and missiles. If the fragile cease-fire collapses, as seems likely, in another round of American bombing and shelling of Syrian-supported Druse forces, Soviet personnel might be killed, producing a major American-Soviet confrontation.

title: THAT CERTAIN SMILE
description: It's been a month since I read the great news. ''Smile,'' it said. ''Smiling is healthy. Smiling is good for you.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALANDMARK that was literally a symbol of the Essex County community of Fairfield became a victim of old age and new economics last week.

title: RESTORING THE BEAUTY OF OLD IRONWORK
description: -TIERED, cast-iron fountain, a century old and partly dismantled, occupies a parking place outside Edmund Wittkamp's Danbury workshop. Inside, on a table, are a pair of old wrought-iron lamps that came from a Westport home and a fierce- looking cast-iron gargoyle from a historic building in Indianapolis.

title: POTATO FARMERS SEE GLOOMY TIMES
description: EVEN though the wholesale price for potatoes this season is more than double last year's price, many Long Island farmers say the hard times are not over.

title: CLIFFHANGER VIEW IS PUT UP FOR SALE
description: The view is, to put it mildly, breathtaking from the house atop the Palisades just south of the Tappan Zee Bridge at Grand View-on-Hudson, N. Y. And that's been the problem for Bill Higgins, the Hillsdale, N. J., real-estate broker who has been trying to sell it at an asking price of $525,000.

title: PRIVATE LIBRARY A VESTIGE OF THE PAST
description: ON commercial Chapel Street in New Haven, nestled between a submarine shop and a store that advertises ''clothes for guys and chicks'' is a 157- year-old private lending library, complete with first editions, antique furniture and globe lamps with pull cords.

title: VINTAGE SINATRA IN AN EXPENSIVE PACKAGE
description: Mobile Fidelity Sound Lab, the Southern California concern that last year favored us with a 14-disk, $325 boxed collection of the complete Beatles British albums, all of them half-speed-mastered and pressed in Japan on special vinyl, is at it again. This year, also on its Original Master Recording label, it has just released a 16-disk, $350 set called ''Sinatra.''

title: Laura Buck and Samuel Marshall Wed
description: Laura Knapp Buck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Clifton Buck of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday to Samuel Rhoads Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marsall of Devon, Pa. The Rev. Stephen Price performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: EXETER WINS, 27-12, IN FAST-START GAME
description: ''I've never seen anything like that before in all my years of coaching,'' said Ed Frey after an unusual occurrence in the Exeter-Mount Hermon game yesterday, which was won by Exeter, 27-12.

title: KING OF THE STREETS
description: Philippe Petit, son of a French Air Force colonel, caught New York's fancy nine years ago when he walked on a wire between the World Trade Center's twin towers. Last year, he carried a symbolic silver trowel from the 16th story of a building across Amsterdam Avenue to the chronically unfinished tower of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Shakeup on Royals
description: Coming in second may not be the worst thing in the world, but finishing second in the American League East, 20 games behind the Chicago White Sox, gave Dick Howser the notion that his Kansas City Royals could stand some changes. Now, in a shakeup of his coaching staff, Howser has signed Mike Ferraro, the former Cleveland Indians' manager who had served under Howser on the 1980 Yankees, as the Royals' third-base coach, and promoted Gary Blaylock, a Royals scout and pitching instructor since 1969, to the post of pitching coach.

title: CATHOLIC AND DARIEN TRIUMPH
description: Joe Anzalone, the coach of Stamford Catholic, thinks his team has improved a lot this year. The Crusaders beat Waterford, 34-6, yesterday to raise their record to 4-0.

title: 'THE RIGHT STUFF': FROM SPACE TO THE SCREEN
description: There were heroes in those days, some 25 years ago, when Americans still seemed to feel sure enough of themselves to believe in heroes. Like the dragon-slayers of myth, a few men went forth to meet the demons in the sky and do battle in behalf of all lesser mortals. They were acclaimed heroes because they seemed to embody the qualities most esteemed by Americans, rare qualities that were thought to define the best in the national character.

title: DEBATE RAGES ON LAND PALN IN EAST END
description: THOMAS LESTER, a bay fisherman who lives in East Hampton, is not surprised that his fight to save a way of life has snarled multimillion-dollar developments and become the most volatile issue in a town used to land battles.

title: WESTLAKE TOPPLED BY 26-8
description: Greg Rogers, who leads the county in scoring, rushing and yards per carry, led undefeated Byram Hills past visiting Westlake, 26-8, yesterday to break Westlake's 14-game winning streak.

title: SPORTS FANTASIES --
description: As a psychologist and a tennis player

title: Escaped Inmate Surrenders
description: One of two prisoners with histories of violent crimes who escaped last Thursday from the Queensboro State Correctional Facility in Long Island City, Queens, surrendered to the police last night. The man, Richard Taglianetti, 23 years old, of Brooklyn, who is also known as Richard Tagley, surrendered at the Imperial Motel in Monticello, N.Y., at 6:30 P.M. and was taken to the 112th Precinct stationhouse in Queens, according to Sgt. Edwin LeSchack, a police spokesman. He was charged with first-degree escape and held pending an arraignment today. Mr. Taglianetti said he did not know the whereabouts of the other escaped prisoner, John Frank Maier, 24, of Yonkers, Sergeant LeSchack said.

title:
CRAFTS;
CLAY IS KING IN SCARSDALE SHOW
description: FOR its 10th anniversary show, the Craftsmen's Gallery in Scarsdale has chosen clay as the medium to highlight. ''We believe that clay is one of the most exciting areas today,'' said Sybil Robins, the gallery director.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
PORTUGAL'S PASSION FOR COD
description: For more than four centuries, the Portuguese have been eating bacalhau - pungent, dried, salted cod. From the time of the great explorations, Portuguese fishermen have suffered hazard and hardship in the coldest and cruelest seas for what has become their national passion. And nothing in the passing of time - not refrigeration, not expanding supermarkets, not even a huge bounty of fresh fish from the Atlantic ocean, which borders the entire west and south of Portugal - has persuaded them that there is any tastier food.

title: No Headline
description: Community Group And the Music Hall A recent article on the latest attempt to restore and revive the old Clinton Music Hall neglected to mention the important earlier work of a group of inspired residents. I refer to the Clinton Music Hall Preservation Society, formed in 1978 and incorporated early in 1979.

title: CONGRESS UNLIKELY TO LIVE UP TO ITS OWN BUDGET
description: Economic and budgetary issues will dominate the Congressional agenda when the lawmakers return Monday from the Columbus Day recess and head into the home stretch of this year's legislative session.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: MIDWEST GOVERNORS FAE ATTACKS ON TAXES
description: Less than a year after being swept into office as Governor of Ohio with 62 percent of the vote, Richard F. Celeste is running scared. Speaking last week to a group of high school athletic directors, he invoked his grandmother, quality education and one of the state's ranking deities, former Ohio State University football coach Woody Hayes, to enlist their support.

title: PUTTING YOUR JOB INTERVIEW INTO REHEARSAL
description: NO ACTOR would be so foolish as to walk onto a stage in front of a first-night audience without weeks of rehearsal. Yet every day thousands of job seekers at all stages of their careers walk into interviews without even a minimum of preparation. Hours of effort and expense invested in an effective resume that successfully obtained the interview are thrown away through lack of preparation.

title: P
description: A contempt of court finding against former State Senator Vander L. Beatty, Democrat of Brooklyn, was rendered uncertain last week because of a lapse by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: TURMOIL CAPSIZES ISRAEL'S ECONOMY
description: No sooner had Israel's new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, been sworn into office than the nation's worst economic crisis in years hit like a storm. Widespread fear that the Government would institute a 50 percent devaluation of the Israeli shekel had created panic buying of dollars and dumping of the usually stable bank stocks on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. The Government reacted swiftly. It shut down the exchange, halted all foreign currency trading and a day later devalued the shekel by 23 percent. It also cut subsidies on basic foodstuffs in half and promised to support the value of the bank shares. Such austerity measures were cheered by some and scorned by others. Israelis flooded stores, buying up goods before the devaluation took effect, and many called for the resignation of Finance Minister Yoram Aridor, whose economic policies have been under attack for months. Late in the week, Mr. Aridor did indeed resign after the Shamir Cabinet rejected his plan to replace the shekel with the dollar as the currency for salaries, budgets and prices.

title: DEEP RIVER HAILS ITS MAJOR-LEAGUE HERO
description: NOT many ballplayers from Connecticut make it to the major leagues, and until Brian Dayett was called up by the New York Yankees in early September, none from Deep River had ever played at the big league level.

title: DOG'S LIFE/WOMAN'S PLACE
description: The Imperial Pet

title: MICHAEL CAINE AT 50 TESTING THE LIMITS OF THE ACTOR'S ART
description: Michael Caine, looking for a light for his morning cigar, examined its dead ash through the tinted lenses in his horn- rimmed glasses. ''I'm a bit shattered,'' he said, put down the cigar, seized on a glass of juice and downed it. He had been out the night before with John Mackenzie and Bob Hoskins, the director and co-star of ''Beyond the Limit,'' one of Michael Caine's two new pictures. ''I don't do that much anymore,'' he said. ''I'm a married man. New York's a better town if you're single. The first time I came to New York I didn't sleep at all for five days. I just lay in bed for a couple of hours once in a while with my eyes open.'' He laughed, and lighted the cigar at last, rolling it in his big white hands. ''Excited,'' he said.

title: Extra Police Assigned To Jets' Game at Shea
description: Extra policemen have been assigned to Shea Stadium for today's Jets-Dolphins game in case of adverse fan reaction to the Jets' expected move to New Jersey.

description: MOROCCO

description: Cold ComfortFor Lilco Users

title: EGGPLANT: IT'S GOOD ANY WHICH WAY
description: VER THE years it has been our conceit to categorize foods. The richest doubtlessly would be foie gras; the most pedestrian would be cabbage; the vilest, a Malaysian fruit called durian (Waverley Root in his last book on food noted that ''the only way to protect yourself from a durian eater is to eat durian yourself''); the most coveted, caviar.

title: Jean Muchmore, B. W. McCleary Exchange Vows
description: Jean Luce Muchmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry George Muchmore of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Benjamin Ward McCleary, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. McCleary of Asheville, N.C., and Little Compton, R.I. The ceremony was performed by Dr. George E. Chorba at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon.

title: UNBEATEN HOFSTRA CAPTURES ITS SIXTH
description: Hofstra rolled to its sixth straight victory today, defeating the Merchant Marine Academy by 10-6.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY C.I.A. HELPED NICARAGUAN REBELS PLAN ATTACKS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency recommended and helped plan recent rebel attacks against an oil storage depot and other industrial targets in Nicaragua, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: YALE PROJECT ENDS AFTER 59 YEARS
description: APROJECT that began in 1924 with the casual purchase of six letters ended recently as Yale University celebrated publishing the letters of Horace Walpole - all 48 volumes worth.

title: Piquet Wins Driving Crown
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, in a Brabham-BMW, intentionally abandoned the lead in the South African Grand Prix today and coasted to a third-place finish that assured him the 1983 world driving championship.

title: AQUINO'S FINAL JOURNEY
description: Ken Kashiwahara is an ABC News correspondent based in San Francisco. By Ken Kashiwahara AIPEI ON THE MORNING OF Aug. 21 was hot and humid, so warm that Ninoy was not wearing his bulletproof vest underneath his cream-colored safari suit with a patch bearing his initials, ''BSA'' - for Benigno S. Aquino. It was the same suit he had worn when he left Manila three years ago. We left the Grand Hotel for the airport at 9:30 A.M., resembling the archetypal tourists loaded down with cameras, shoulder bags, hand luggage and other traveling paraphernalia. Traffic to the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, where we were taking the 11 o'clock China Airlines flight to Manila, was unexpectedly smooth and we arrived at 10:10 A.M., which was far too early for Ninoy to enter the terminal. Since he wanted to proceed to the boarding gate at the last minute to reduce the chances of being detected, he had his car circle the airport. Earlier in the morning, a friend had taken our tickets and passports to check us in ahead of time; Ninoy was prepared to have military officials meet him at the airport and escort him to prison, and he had asked that his baggage claim stubs be stapled to my ticket.

title: RUSSIANS STRUGGLE TO FREE SHIP STUCK IN ICE
description: More than two dozen Soviet ships have been trapped in Arctic ice by a combination of northerly winds and subfreezing temperatures that mariners say have no precedent at this time of year.

title: THE TRUTH ABOUT ISRAEL'S SHEKEL
description: The main fact about Israel's sudden sense of economic crisis is that the crisis isn't sudden at all. It's been building for years. Israel is in the same fix as dozens of other countries whose plight has created a global debt crisis. It, too, suffers from roaring inflation, economic mismanagement and an inability to make ends meet. But Israel's trouble has deeper roots: a chronically precarious existence requiring huge military budgets.

title: COMING ATTRACTIONS
description: URNITURE, LIKE FASHION, IS SUBJECT TO the vicissitudes of taste and season. One autumn, a manufacturer's showrooms are a sea of curvaceous upholstery covered in a rainbow of pastel prints; a mere six months later, the same manufacturer's space is hospital white with nothing but cube-shaped sofas, chairs and coffee tables.

title: RUMORS SWRILING AROUND LASORDA
description: There's no place like the World Series for rumors running rampant. One that has spread like a fire in a dry forest this week involves Tommy Lasorda and the Yankees. Lasorda, the rumor goes, would leave the Los Angeles Dodgers, where he has managed for seven seasons, and replace Billy Martin as the Yankee manager.

description: CONVERSATIONS WITH THE ENEMY

title: BACK TO INDUSTRIAL BASICS
description: IN the current debate about the best ways for the United States to regain its economic momentum, no one disputes the importance of vigorous corporations. The highest bankruptcy rate since the Depression, the lowest corporate profits in 30 years, the largest trade deficit ever in manufactured goods - these chilling statistics have raised large questions about corporate nurture and renewal. Do the rigors of global competition, the breakdown of free trade and other circumstances beyond American control require a national industrial policy to spur this country's corporations? If not, how can American companies match foreign excellence in old-line and high-tech industries?

title: Republic Steel's Loss Cut to $35.3 Million
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, which last month announced a merger agreement with the LTV Corporation, yesterday reported a third-quarter net loss of $35.3 million, in part because of a one-time tax credit. The company had sales of $677.6 million in the quarter.

title: A JOURNEY INTO MUSICAL ISOLATION
description: GLENN GOULD

title: HAS THE AUDIENCE GOT TV BLUES?
description: Right now we are going through a state of mind, heart and soul that has no official designation but that I always think of as the Pre-Season Blues. These normally begin in mid-September, but this year, like the plays, they are late.

title: THE WORLD ; FOOD EMERGENCY SWEEPS AFRICA
description: All across Africa, drought is causing potentially calamitous food shortages. Experts said four million tons of emergency grain were needed to avert mass starvation in 18 parched African countries with 120 million people.

title: Natalia Huryn Marries James B. Hicks
description: Natalia A. Huryn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ihor M. Huryn of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to James B. Hicks, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hicks of Van Nuys, Calif. The ceremony was performed at the Ukrainian Greek Orthodox Holy Ascension Church in Clifton, N.J., by the Very Rev. Artemy Selepyna, assisted by the Very Rev. Wolodymyr Bazylesky and the Rev. Myron Pacholok.

title: GRENADA CURTAILS COMMUNICATIONS TO THE OUTSIDE
description: The mystery of who is running the Marxist-oriented Government of the Caribbean island of Grenada 150 miles west of here remained unsolved today as lines of communication with the outside world were severed one by one.

title: NAVY TOPS PRINCETON BY 37-29
description: Napoleon McCallum did all his work in the first half today, tying a national collegiate record of 32 carries in a half, and scoring Navy's first three touchdowns en route to a 37-29 triumph over Princeton.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW

Not Alexander Markov's debut. The 20-year-old Russian emigre violinist, who has already won several competitions, appeared last Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, no less, which was well-filled with many Russian-speaking listeners.

title: UNDER A MAGNIFYING GLASS
description: PHILADELPHIA WHEN the fifth game of the World Series begins today, Veterans Stadium will continue to appear to Mike Schmidt as if it suddenly has been domed with a huge magnifying glass. While the Baltimore Orioles have jumped to a 3-1 lead, the Phillies' third baseman has produced only 1 broken-bat single in 16 times at bat - the same slugger who was voted the most valuable player in the 1980 World Series, the same slugger who hit 40 homers this season, the same slugger who batted .466 with a homer that won the 1-0 opener against the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League championship series.

description: The English summer - Wimbledon, Glyndebourne and all that - has its champions. But they have to fib a lot; they have to leave out all those days when the courts are covered with tarpaulins, not players, and when the entr'acte picnickers eat with one hand and hold umbrellas with the other.

title: KEEPING ALIVE THE INTIMATE ART OF SONG

title: NEW HYDE PARK TOPS BETHPAGE, GOING 4-0

Cappellino, a senior, ran 9 yards to score, capping a 10- play, 65-yard drive. Cappellino, a linebacker on defense, also had 10 tackles.

description: It's beginning to look as if we may see a rerun of the economic-disaster movie called ''The 1970's.'' If we're lucky, it will be in slow motion; if not, hold on to your seats.

description: The marriage of Margaret Kimberly Heyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris A. Richard Garcia, performed the ceremony at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Frederick Paulson of Summit and Halsey Island, N.J. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Stemen Nix Jr., also of Summit.

title: WHY A LAG IN MALE-ORIENTED BIRTH CONTROL?
description: Though science's understanding of male reproductive physiology has leapfrogged in the last decade, the research has not yet produced effective, easy-to-use contraceptives for men. Only one method, the century-old condom, is both as effective and safe as some of the contraceptives available to women.

title: CUTS SHAPE THE BUDGET AS A POLICY TOOL
description: With much fanfare, the President submits his budget to Congress every January. Congress then scrutinizes the details, challenging the Administration to explain why it selected certain options and rejected others. Often the legislators' priorities differ markedly from the President's; that will be amply demonstrated this week as they return from Columbus Day recess and again take up spending bills for fiscal year 1984.

title: WEST GERMAN AIDE AND GROMYKO TALK IN VIENNA ON ARMS
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany and his Soviet counterpart, Andrei A. Gromyko, met today for seven hours but failed to narrow the differences separating Moscow and Washington at the Geneva arms limitation talks, West German officials said.

title: DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS FOR TWO YOUNG QUARTERBACKS
description: DENVER DURING the week before the Denver Broncos' final exhibition game, Coach Dan Reeves named John Elway to be his starting quarterback for the regular season. Elway, the rookie from Stanford who was the first player selected in the college draft, had won the job from Steve DeBerg, a seven-year veteran, and on the day the competition ended, Reeves said: ''This is the toughest decision I've had to make since I've been a head coach.''

title: Bias Against Homosexuals By Georgetown U. Is Upheld
description: Georgetown University's religious beliefs exempt it from local laws prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals, a judge of the District of Columbia Superior Court has ruled.

title: BELLEVILLE OVERWHELMS TEANECK BY 33-0
description: Mike Murphy, a senior fullback, ran for three touchdowns yesterday to lead Belleville (3-1) to a 33-0 shutout of Teaneck in Belleville.

title: FOR THIS PIANIST, BACH IS THE GREATEST ROMANTIC OF ALL
description: When the Franz Liszt Chamber Orchestra of Budapest visited Carnegie Hall in May 1978, it brought along, as its soloist in Bach and Mozart concertos, a young Hungarian pianist named Andras Schiff. At 24, Mr. Schiff was not entirely unknown in pianist-watching circles: He had placed respectably at the 1974 Tchaikovsky and the 1975 Leeds competitions; he had made several recordings for the state-owned Hungaroton labels; and although he was still living in Budapest and was managed by the official Hungarian concert agency, he was touring freely in Europe.

title: THE PLAYERS' WAR ON DRUGS
description: THE National Basketball Players Association, together with the league, announced a new program late last month dealing with the illegal use of drugs in the N.B.A. As of this date, the public reaction has been overwhelmingly positive, for which we are grateful.

title: EDUCATORS WEIGH ISSUE OF MERIT PAY

title: ANCIENT PERU ETCHED IN CLAY
description: Ancient Peruvian pottery - robust in form, boldly incised with fanged felines, falcons, monkeys and demons, and painted in black pigment or earth tones - has always been admired and collected. Some of the reasons why, and the problems these antiquities pose, can be seen in two shows: one, at the Metropolitan Museum, focuses on esthetics; the other, at the National Geographic Society in Washington, deals with illicit international traffic in such art works.

title: NEXT AT CINEMA CLUB, A FRENCH THRILLER
description: HAVING started the season with an intellectual, historical spectacle about the French Revolution, the Westchester Cinema Club is turning to a ripping, contemporary cops and robbers action thriller. The club's fourth subscription series, which began with the American premiere showing of the Polish-French co-production ''Danton'' on Sept. 25, continues with ''La Balance,'' also an American first, at 10:30 A.M. today.

title: THE GOOSE WITH A Z-SHAPED NECK
description: MIGRATION time is always a busy time of year for us. Every spring and fall, during our 20 years on Northport Bay, hundreds if not thousands of waterfowl have recognized our big white house on the beach as a familiar landmark from the air. Whether they needed rest, food, a protective cove during a storm or help in time of illness or injury, they always seemed to know where to come.

title: 'TALKING' WITH PICTURES
description: On the theory that one picture is worth 10,000 words - especially to the traveler who has no foreign language facility - small picture books have been making their way to the market.

title: UNION DOWNS PLAINFIELD TO REMAIN UNDEFEATED
description: Union remained undefeated after four games when it scored a 13-6 victory over formidable Plainfield yesterday in Union.

title: ; MARTIN LUTHER'S RELEVANCE TODAY
ENVIRONMENT GROUPS MARK A WATERSHED WITH WATT
description: The resignation of Interior Secretary James G. Watt last weekend was seen by many critics of the Administration's environmental policies as an opportunity to reopen a dialogue. But the harshness of the comments that greeted the selection of William P. Clark as his successor would would seem to rule out any declaration of peace, at least for the time being.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: GEORGE MILLS. By Stanley Elkin. (Dutton/Obelisk, $8.95.) Stanley Elkin's National Book Critics Circle Award winner careens through 1,000 years of family history, from the first George Mills, who roamed Europe during the crusades, to the last of the line, a married man in his 50's who lives in St. Louis. He works for a company that dispossesses ghetto blacks, and - in two widely separated sections of the novel that constitute its ''emotional and imaginative center'' - cares for a dying woman. Our reviewer, Leslie Epstein, called this work by a talented writer ''a whirling mass of horror and humor.'' Dutton is also releasing an $8.95 Obelisk edition of Mr. Elkin's funny, frightening 1971 novel, THE DICK GIBSON SHOW.

title: THEATER: PIXILATED CHARACTERS
description: There are three men in the house in John von Hartz's new comedy, ''A Man in the House,'' and the fun is trying to guess which of these misfits can cope with the super-achiever woman in their lives.

title: CHANGES UNSETTLE PLUM ISLAND LAB
description: ASWEEPING reorganization is taking place at the United States Agriculture Department's Animal Disease Laboratory at Plum Island as it begins a new fiscal year this month.

title: CHUN REBUILDS IS SHATTERED GOVERNMENT
description: A Confucian concept holds that some rulers are ill-starred, and that whether or not their misfortune is their fault is not particularly relevant. Such leaders are regarded as having lost their ''mandate'' from heaven and perhaps having become too great a burden for their subjects.

title: Nancy Shenker, Banker, Marries
description: Nancy A. Shenker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis Shenker of Tucson, Ariz., was married at the Hotel Pierre in Manhattan yesterday to Kenneth Philip George, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman George of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Justice Israel Rubin of the State Supreme Court, who is Administrative Judge of the New York City Civil Court.

title: RESTORING HOPE TO A FAMILY
description: NEWARK FRANCISCO PALMIERI believed that he would never return home again as he was being carried down the three flights of stairs from his apartment to an ambulance one night last April.

title: 42 Killed in Indian Floods
description: Torrential rains that flooded 871 villages have killed at least 42 people in Uttar Pradesh, India's largest state, the United News of India reported today. Most of the victims were crushed when their houses collapsed in the storms on Friday, the news agency said. More than a thousand people have died in widespread flooding in India since the annual monsoon began in July.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
ABOUT THAT COTTAGE YOU RENTED US...
description: YOU'LL find the keys to your A-frame enclosed, George, and let me tell you right now: It was all that you said it was - and more.

title: No Headline
description: Claudia J. Myers Is Bride

title: STUDENT DESIGNS COMPUTER PROTECTION
description: IN the world of computers no one

title: THERE ARE STILL PLENTY OF BUGS IN SILICON VALLEY SECURITY
description: It is a case laden with the elements of espionage fiction: stolen documents, secret agents, clandestine meetings in Vienna and Geneva, a safehouse in Warsaw, a spy called ''The Minister,'' a mysterious American businessman code-named ''The Big Man.''

title: Margaret Herz Weds Lawyer in Brookville
description: Margaret Ann Herz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Herz of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to William Floyd-Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd-Jones of East Norwich, L.I. The Rev. Arthur Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I., assisted by the Rev. John X. Jobson, an Episcopal priest.

title: AN ECONOMIC INDICATOR IS SLIPPING
description: WILLIE BROWN slipped into a chair near the door and neatly unfolded a white paper napkin on his lap. With meticulous care, he took a baloney sandwich out of a plastic bag and sipped iced tea from a Styrofoam cup.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're not handling 50 percent or even 25 percent of the problem, but we're making a significant impact.'' - The Rev. Robert Polk, at a conference on New York City's homeless. (38:2.)

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY ; A NEW CARIBBEAN HOTEL AND A MADRID PACKAGE
description: That Other Long Island Opens a Resort

title: No Headline
description: Constance Cope Turner, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Turner of Walpole, N.H., was married yesterday to Walter H. Haydock 3d, son of Alicia Roux of New York and the late Mr. Haydock. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Holland Applauds Oriole Relievers: They Do the Job'
description: Based on the off-field performance that complemented his on-field effort, Al Holland was the early favorite to become the dominant personality of the World Series. The Philadelphia relief pitcher saved the first-game victory, and followed that performance with an engaging and colorful commentary.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Richie Hebner, the Pittsburgh Pirate utility man, has rejected a contract offer and said he planned to join his teammates, Dave Parker and Kent Tekulve, in becoming a free agent. . . . Mike Murphy, a former Ranger who spent nearly 10 years with the Los Angeles Kings, has retired as a player and taken a front-office job with the Kings.

title: RUSSIAN CLARIFIES ACCIDENT OF SOYUZ
description: The Soviet spacecraft involved in an explosion on a launching pad late last month carried two astronauts, not three as previously believed, and the men are recuperating at a medical complex near the launching site, a Soviet official said today.

title: JUDGE TO RULE ON AN L.I. MAN ACCUSED IN SLAUGHTER OF JEWS
description: A Federal judge must now decide whether to strip a retired Brentwood construction worker of his American citizenship after the man testified that he had been aware of the murder of hundreds of Latvian Jews but, contrary to Government charges, had not taken part in the slaughter.

title: No Headline
description: Course Record By Douglas MANLIUS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -

title: Anthony Quitting Tour
description: He has been named the Professional Bowling Association's bowler of the year for three years in a row, and that to Earl Anthony is enough. Anthony, a member of the P.B.A. Hall of Fame who began his career in 1970, announced his retirement from the professional tour and said he would limit his bowling activities to two bowling alleys in San Francisco's East Bay area.

title:
DINING OUT;
STYLISH DINING OUT IN WEST ORANGE
description: BELMONDO, a stylish West Orange restaurant, opened six months ago on the site of the former Rock Spring Inn. The owners, Gene and Joanne Angelo, extensively refurbished the old building, and the result is a spacious dining room and ''eat-in'' bar.

title: CLOSE CALL ON SHUTTLE ROCKET DELAYS LAUNCH
description: Close Call onShuttle RocketDelays LaunchThe thrill over a near-perfect space shuttle mission last month gave way last week to the chilling realization that the mission had come very near to disaster. The protective lining of one of Challenger's two booster rocket nozzles burned almost completely through during the two-minute firing that helped propel the spacecraft into orbit.

title: HIS CHOREOGRAPHY STIRS ARGUMENT
description: ''You get it? I love it. They hate it. You got it? I get it. I love it. You hate it? We get it. They hate it . . . '' ''It'' is ''Square Deal,'' the Joffrey Ballet's newest acquisition and a ballet in which the dancers not only move, but speak in a litany of comments on what they're doing.

title: SPORTS FANTASIES
description: Sports Fantasies

title: ; Shapelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Beer-Ad Ban Urged
description: The way one California Congressman sees it, beer and televised sports shouldn't mix. In a letter to the heads of seven major breweries, Representative Don Edwards urged the executives to stop advertising beer on sports programs because of the impact of the ''seductive'' commercials on impressionable teen-agers.

title: POLISH WRITER FINDS REFUGE
description: WHAT the Polish people still need most in the struggle against their Government is moral support from the West, according to Jacek Kalabinski, a former union leader in Poland.

title: GERMAN DEMONSTRATORS BLOCKADE U.S. BASES
description: Thousands of demonstrators blockaded United States military bases today on the third day of a planned week of actions protesting the scheduled stationing of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: TANAKA LOSES BRIBERY CASE BUT KEEPS FIGHTING
description: TOKYO

title: AIR-SAFETY PANEL TO CONVENE TUESDAY
description: An international commission begins talks in Montreal this week to test the Soviet Union's willingness to join in new measures that could prevent a repetition of a tragedy such as the shooting down of a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1.

title: MONETARY FUND CHIEF IF FIRM ABOUT DEMANDS ON DEBTORS
description: Despite demonstrations against the International Monetary Fund in Argentina, Brazil, the Philippines and other debtor countries, Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the fund, is standing firm on how to resolve the international debt crisis.

title: CLASSES TAILORED TO BUSINESS PREPARE THE JOBLESS FOR JOBS
description: For Patsy Cruz, an alert 23-year-old from East Harlem who had not had a steady job in four years, September came up roses.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
MUYBRIDGE'S ACHIEVEMENT IN YOSEMITE
description: Prominently displayed in an exhibition of photographs at the Daniel Wolf Gallery is a drawing by Degas of a jockey on a horse. This drawing was made by Degas after a photograph by Eadweard Muybridge, whose stop-motion photographs of human and animal figures in motion created a sensation in artistic circles when they were published in the 1880's, and are still one of the outstanding achievements of 19th-century photography.

title: AN APARTMENT MARKET WITH ULTRA-HIGH RENTS
description: ASMALL but growing apartment

title: DREAMING OF SAVANNAH
description: Foreign place names are the Sirens of geography. They pull the armchair traveler to his feet. For me it is a matter of syllables that run like a tune and end in a consonant. Samarkand has luxury and a peremptory drum roll in it because of the final ''d.'' I am repelled by the insipid ''ville,'' even in France. Names that end in a plain ''a'' tell me nothing, though I was allured by ''iana'' when I was a dreamy boy, for it stirred the nostalgia for the faraway and limitless and the Utopian American dream: Huck Finn's longing to ''light out into the territory!'' For the British islander there is no territory to ''light out into,'' except the sea.

title: Tillie Page Laird Weds Hunter Donaldson Brown
description: Tillie Page Laird, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Eli Mygatt 3d of Wilmington, Del., and Washington Depot, Conn., and Joseph Packard Laird, also of Wilmington, was married in Wilmington yesterday to Hunter Donaldson Brown, son of Mrs. John Kaestner of Mequon, Wis., and Dr. Murray Hunter Brown of Santa Monica, Calif. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred.

title: MONEY IS NOT THE LEAST OF ISRAELI WOES
description: Why anyone would have wanted to become Prime Minister of Israel last week is hard to imagine. The army was still mired in Lebanon, the Syrians were getting new Soviet missiles, the politicians were at each other's throats to the point where one resigned from the new Cabinet and, worst of all, the public was fleeing in near panic from the enfeebled Israeli currency, the shekel.

title: N. Rockland Makes It 23
description: North Rockland extended its unbeaten streak to 23 games, defeating visiting R. C. Ketchum yesterday by 28-0.

title: PINKETT SCORES 3 AS IRISH ROMP
description: There were 75,131 fans at Giants Stadium today, attracted more by tradition than by competition, as Notre Dame routed an Army team no longer in its league, 42-0.

title:
GARDENING;
CHRYSANTHEMUMS: AUTUMN'S LANDMARKS
description: CHRYSANTHEMUMS have become so completely associated with autumn that the two are practically synonymous in the minds of gardeners. Their great diversity of color and flower form, added to their timeliness of bloom, have made them the most widely planted of all fall flowers.

title: Sarah D. Heacock and Anthony Menchaca Marry
description: Sarah Deane Heacock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest E. Heacock of Omaha and Crystal Lake, Mich., and Anthony Louis Menchaca, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Menchaca of Huntington, L.I., were married yesterday at Central Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Charles Henderson performed the ceremony.

title: REVUE: JULIE KURNITZ, SONGS
description: Julie Kurnitz, a singer with a comedy style that is a mix of the libidinous archness of Beatrice Lillie, the long, loose angularity of Charlotte Greenwood and the facial agility of Carol Burnett, has been around, on and off Broadway and in cabarets for a number of years. But she has rarely had the opportunity for the kind of triumph she enjoys in ''I've Still Got This Song'' which is playing at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, Thursdays through Saturdays at 11 P.M. and Sundays at 8:30.

title: PRESIDENT TO MEET SECURITY ADVISERS ON MIDEAST PLANS
description: President Reagan has scheduled a meeting of the National Security Council on Tuesday to decide on new American actions in the Middle East, Administration official said today.

title: OVERFISHING THE LOBSTER
description: looking day out on Long Island Sound, a speeding lobsterboat headed directly for my anchored runabout. When the boat came near, its engines quieted, its bow lowered into the water and three men in black fishermen's aprons stood staring at me and a few of my wooden lobster pots. One of the men grabbed onto the gunwhale of my boat with both arms, as a choppy sea banged us into each other. All three men were silent. Their boat smelled of fish. I spoke to them in a friendly but nervous way, as one would to a silent guard dog.

title: PROTESTS TURN LEFT N CHILE;SEVEN KILLED
description: After taking something of a back seat to centrist groups, Chile's Communist and Socialist Parties showed their strength last week in the continuing attempt to end Gen. Augusto Pinochet's 10-year regime. Some 40,000 people turned out for a leftist- led demonstration, one of the largest in Santiago since the Pinochet forces overthrew and killed the Marxist President Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973.

title: SLEW O' GOLD WINS THE GOLD CUP BY 3
description: On an afternoon rich with new and old heroes, Slew o' Gold won the Jockey Club Gold Cup and Devil's Bag won the Champagne Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park. Their victories made it certain that Slew o' Gold will be the champion 3-year-old, Devil's Bag the champion 2-year-old, and that one or the other will be the horse of the year.

title: F.D.A. IS REBUFFED ON DRUG EXECUTION
description: A three- judge panel of the Federal appeals court here has ordered the Food and Drug Administration to examine evidence that the drugs used for executions by lethal injection, far from causing an easy and painless death, actually ''pose a substantial threat of torturous pain.''

title: A NEW BREED OF DIPLOMAT
description: The article ''A New Breed of Diplomat'' (by B. Drummond Ayres Jr., Sept. 11) may very well explain why our Foreign Service is so often incompetent. Let me explain.

title: HEALTH CARE PROFITS PAID BY U.S. ARE QUESTIONED
description: Federal investigators have concluded that the Department of Health and Human Services is illegally paying profits to home health-care agencies and other Medicare providers.

title: MRS. GANDHI SAYS TERRORISM WILL END
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, facing new political violence in northwestern India, said today that terrorism ''is not going to succeed'' as a political weapon in the country.

title: LEHMAN TAKES 4TH STRAIGHT
description: It was business as usual yesterday for Lehman. The business was football and the usual was a victory. The Lions beat Kennedy, 7-0, raising their record to 4-0 and securing the lead in the Bronx-Manhattan division of the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: DEFENSE SPENDING: ITS EFFECT ON JOBS
description: TAXPAYERS from New York City and its upstate and New Jersey suburbs were expected to contribute about $11.8 billion to the Pentagon in the fiscal year ended last month, $3 billion of which will return to the area through defense expenditures. That $8.8 billion gap between military tax dollars paid and benefit to the local economy from defense spending was the largest for any area in the country, according to Employment Research Associates, a nonprofit economic-consulting firm based in Lansing, Mich.

title: JERSEYAN IN LINE FOR HIGH E.P.A. JOB
description: AFORMER director and developer of the Environmental and Community- Health Program of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has been proposed as the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's assistant administrator in charge of research and development.

title: OUT OF HISTORY'S MISTS COMES ARTHUR DOVE
description: DURING the reign of Abstract Expressionism, one of the mode's major influences, Kandinsky, got most of the credit for inventing abstraction, around 1910. Since then, less-biased readings of history have shown that the rejection of external reality, already presaged in Cubism and other movements, was the accomplishment of not one, but several painters working in the years immediately preceding World War I.

title: THE REGION
description: Hospitals FaultedOn Fired Doctors

title: MARCOS URGED TO EAST POLITICAL STAND
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has been urged privately in recent days by members of his Cabinet, his political party and his circle of personal advisers to make major political concessions to his opponents, according to Filipino officials and leading businessmen.

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1983;  International
description: New U.S. actions in the Middle East will be discussed at a meeting President Reagan has scheduled of the National Security Council, Administration officials said. They said the actions include steps to break the impasse on a troop withdrawal from Lebanon, to engage Israel in a closer strategic relationship, to enhance American ties with pro-Western Arab states, and to offset a perceived growth in Syrian and Soviet strength in the region. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: GREENWICH REASSESSING ITS FORM OF GOVERNMENT
description: GREENWICH ABOUT seven times a year in Greenwich, the 232 members of the Representative Town Meeting gather to discuss town topics such as traffic, finances or land use. The representatives, elected by the town's voters, stand up and talk about pressing issues, question town officials about policy, or pass resolutions urging action on a particular subject.

title: SANDSTONE HOUSES OF OLD GO ON VIEW
description: NEW CITY, N.Y.

title: PICKERS PURSUE THE PERFECT PUMPKIN
description: blue sky in a pumpkin patch not far from the center of this small rural town, dozens of Connecticut children came in search of a fantasy last Saturday. The 250- acre C. F. Woodford tobacco and vegetable farm, nestled at the base of Talcott Mountain, was offering local families the chance to pick their own pumpkins.

title: REAGAN'S CRUCIAL YEAR
description: Hedrick Smith is The New York Times's chief Washington Correspondent. By Hedrick Smith N POLICY TERMS, TIME IS GETTING short for Ronald Reagan. For as 1983 draws toward a close, he is set to tell us if he intends to seek re-election. But whether he runs or not, he is already framing the 1984 campaign by the decisions he has been making lately about Lebanon, Central America, the economy and arms control, and by the way he is dealing with the Soviet Union, China and the Middle East. If history is any guide, the latter part of Mr. Reagan's third year is a time of telltale choices: whether to seek compromise or risk confrontation, whether to hang tough or ease off, whether to try something new or stand pat.

title: THE PROSPECTS FOR JOBS IN NEW YORK CITY AREA
description: FOLLOWING a year of several major plant closings in 1982, Connecticut moved into an overall economic upswing. Its unemployment rate is the lowest in two years and several foreign companies and small, high-technology companies have announced plans to set up shop in the state. And job prospects look good in the health and services industries.

title: ILLINOIS RALLIES TO STUN OHIO STATE, 17-13
description: Thomas Rooks ran 21 yards for a touchdown with 66 seconds left to help give Illinois a 17-13 upset victory over Ohio State in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: BUSINESS SCHOOL DEAN OFFERS SOME ADVICE
description: LEARNING the culture of the work force is a process that begins in high school, if not earlier. Yet most college graduates enter the work force lacking skills necessary for long-term survival and success. They are too fact-oriented, accumulating solutions to yesterday's problems, and employers must invest time and effort in training them for their first position.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Angela DeMeo, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Angela M. DeMeo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo G. DeMeo of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to John H. Works Jr., son of Mr. Works of Denver and Ellen Johnson Works of Shawnee Mission, Kan. The Rev. Andrew J. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Elizabeth Charles A Newport Bride
description: Elizabeth Charles, daughter of Robert H. Charles of Washington and Newport, R.I., and the late Mrs. Charles, was married yesterday to William Bryson Walton, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Walton of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. John Beaven, pastor of the Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. Luke in Portland, Me., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father in Newport.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BETHEL
description: BACK in the early 1970's, Robert M. Gilchrest used to tell potential newcomers that Bethel had features some of its neighboring Connecticut towns lacked, such as municipal sewers and water, a full-time police force and downtown shopping.

title: U.S. PANEL AND NICARAGUA MEET AT CLOSE OF LATIN TOUR
description: Henry A. Kissinger, closing a week- long visit of President Reagan's commission on Central America to the region, said tonight that ''we should not have to choose between peace and democracy'' in Nicaragua.

title: No Headline
description: Achilles

title: Move to Jersey Was Justified
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE HAZARDS OF LAISSER FAIRE
description: DISMANTLING AMERICA

title: STRATEGIES ARE EMERGING IN SUFFOLK RACE
description: AS the Suffolk County Executive's race moves into its final weeks, the candidates' strategies are emerging, more clearly defined.

title: OBLIGATIONS OF MAN IN CARE OF ANIMALS IN CARE OF ANIMALS
description: Despite the lateness, I wish to commend Tom Garry for his fine article (''The Obligations of Keeping a Pet'') on the Aug. 28 Opinion Page.

title: IN NEW YORK, AN ECONOMIC TESTING, AND HOPE
description: FOR the last 15 years especially, New York City's economy has been powered by an engine based in Manhattan and fueled with ever greater numbers of financial, service and white-collar jobs. But two years ago the city's economy began to flatten, after four years of solid growth, leading one observer, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, to ask, ''What's happened to the locomotive - has the engine run out of steam?''

title: 'CEASE-FIRE' TAKES ITS TOLL OF AMERICANS
description: A cease-fire appeared to be holding in Beirut last week but what lapses there were had devastating effects on Americans. A sniper's bullet killed a marine as his jeep crossed a Shiite slum neighborhood near the airport. Another marine was wounded nearby and a third was slightly hurt by a grenade tossed from a car as he guarded the American embassy's offices.

title: Karen C. O'Brien, U.N. Aide, Weds
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., Karen Cassard O'Brien and William Arthur Dreher of New York and East Hampton were married yesterday by the Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr.

title: Reasons Behind Suffolk Bus Audit
description: ''Suffolk Buses Under Scrutiny'' (Sept. 11) was erroneous in its implications concerning the reasons cited for the audit being performed by Comptroller Joseph Caputo.

title: OLD SPORT FLOURISHES ANEW
description: BICYCLE racing, which has been called the sport of the 80's, is booming in Connecticut, where the number of people competing has doubled in the past 10 years to about 500, according to the United States Cycling Federation.

title: IF BETTER EDUCATION IS A FAD, IT IS ABOUT TIME
description: PUBLIC education is a hot topic. Seemingly, out of nowhere politicians are issuing pronouncements, educators are discussing a variety of alternatives, foundations are conducting studies and magazines are featuring cover stories.

title: PLUMBING: THE DEPTHS
description: Time was when one thought of Switzerland as the land of cheese, watches and chocolate. Lately one tends to associate it with gnomes and the numbered account. Never with plumbing fixtures. America, in the popular mind, has always been the land where the plumbing works. For generations of American travelers a yearning for the comforts and dependability of American plumbing has eventually overshadowed the delights of French cooking and the esthetic pleasures of the Sistine Chapel.

title: Mary Womrath Is Wilton Bride
description: Mary Womrath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Womrath of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Douglas L. Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walton Olson of Madison, Wis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stephen Parker at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: LONGEVITY--THE REAL JAMES BOND MYSTERY
description: One of the earliest and staunchest supporters of the James Bond films was Bosley Crowther, the late film critic of The New York Times, but by 1967 even he was beginning to suspect that enough was enough. Writing about ''You Only Live Twice,'' the fifth of the phenomenal series started in 1963 with ''Dr. No,'' Mr. Crowther said sadly, ''The sex is minimal. But, then, Bond is getting old.''

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: ''Sometimes there along the way

title:
STAMPS;
A RAPHAEL AND A SANTA ON TWO CHRISTMAS ISSUES
description: Americans will have a choice of two Christmas stamps this year: one a Madonna and Child by Raphael, and the other Santa Claus - who is back on a stamp after an absence of some years.

title: TENSION GROWS OVER IRAQ PLANES
description: Whatever their value under combat conditions, the five Super Etendard jets France has promised to Iraq have already served as a reminder of the potential dangers of the three- year-old Iran-Iraq war. Officials in Washington confirmed French news reports that the planes were delivered last weekend. As launchers for French-built Exocet missiles already on hand, the planes were expected to give Iraq the potential to knock out Iranian oil-loading facilities and shipping. But Saddem Hussein, the Iraqi leader, said with a show of impatience that the planes still hadn't arrived.

title: FLYERS TOP SLUGGISH ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders this season begin most of their Saturday home games at 7 P.M., one hour ahead of their normal routine at Nassau Coliseum. The four-time Stanley Cup champions tonight showed up on time for the first of those early games 60 minutes ahead of time but neglected to arrive with 60 minutes of hockey.

title: BITING INTO SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: COME Jan. 1, when the new Social Security law goes into effect, relatively affluent taxpayers will see their Social Security benefits taxed for the first time. For many, this will come as a real shock - but that's only part of it: The formula used to determine whether their benefits are subject to tax will include all or part of their income from municipal bonds. Until now, that had been free of Federal income tax.

title:
ABOUT MEN ;
VIDEO PHOTOGRAPHY
description: LAST YEAR THE television screen replaced the roll-up screen as America's chosen backdrop for the display of homemade movies, as electronic photography superseded the chemical kind and home-video color cameras outsold super-8 film cameras by almost three to one. Babies born in this decade are more likely to have their birthdays memorialized on tape than on film.

title: RESORT PONDERS BOOKINGS
description: ATLANTIC CITY UNDER a new marketing plan being considered by the casino-dominated Convention Bureau here, Atlantic City's hotel rooms will never again be completely sold out to conventions.

title: BERMUDA BOWL DRAMA
description: Although the world championship final in Stockholm eight days ago missed, by a hair, being the closest such event ever played, there is not the slightest doubt that it was the most exciting and dramatic. In 176 deals, spread over three days, neither Italy nor the the United States was able to establish a clear ascendancy. The lead changed hands no fewer than 16 times, raising the tension in the small playing rooms and the large Vugraph theater to fever pitch.

title: YOUNG AMERICA AS SEEN IN ITS ART
description: BOSTON

title: FILMING 'NEVER CRY WOLF'
description: Bruce Brown is the author of ''Mountain in the Clouds: A Search for the Wild Salmon,'' which was released last month in paperback.

title: WHY I WON'T BE AT THE YALE-HARVARD GAME
description: TWENTY dollars is not a lot to spend on entertainment today. Concert tickets are in that price range and a decent meal plus a movie (including transportation, soda and popcorn) will eat up most of an Andrew Jackson. A double album by a hot rock group, such as the Stoned Gerbils, costs $19.99.

title: INTEREST GROUPS ARE GOING CORPORATE FOR ADVICE
description: WASHINGTON

title: 1-78 NEARS END, BUT ISSUES REMAIN
description: SUMMIT IN 1957, shortly after passage of

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
FOREIGN SECRECY: A KEY TO THE LOCK
description: IN 1981, the Securities and Exchange Commission sued ''unknown purchasers'' who bought Santa Fe International securities just before the announcement of its merger with Kuwait Petroleum. The unknown investors, purchasing through Swiss banks, made over $6 million in a few days. Insider trading was charged, but for two years this litigation has stalled while the S.E.C. attempts to identify the purchasers whose names are shielded by Swiss secrecy laws.

title: NOTE FORM LIMBO ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: Though its legal authority expired last month, the United States Commission on Civil Rights is still at it. According to an account in The New York Times last week, the commission reported that the Reagan White House's parsimony and lack of interest had meant a sharp reduction in attempts by Washington to enforce civil rights laws.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN WELL, at least one of them still needs me - I think. Proudly, I attended open-school night at Herricks High School the other evening to check on the progress of Mark, the sophomore.

title: 200 Extremists Attack The Jerusalem Mayor
description: About 200 Orthodox Jewish extremists assaulted Jerusalem's Mayor, Teddy Kollek, with sticks and bottles today, knocking him down in a street brawl.

title: RUTGERS RALLIES TO DOWN COLGATE, 29-26
description: It has been a stormy football season for Coach Frank Burns of Rutgers. After winning its opening game, his team went on to lose four straight for its worst start in more than a decade. But on a cool and breezy afternoon at Rutgers Stadium today, the Scarlet Knights staged a comeback to post a 29-26 victory over Colgate.

title: WINTERIZE YOUR MOWER WELL SO IT WILL PURR IN THE SPRING
description: OWNERS of power lawn mowers in this area will soon be cutting their grass for the last time, and shortly after that the mower will be put away until next spring. To make certain that the mower will start up easily and be ready to go when spring rolls around, and to prolong the life of the mower by preventing corrosion and unnecessary wear, the mower must be properly winterized before it is put into storage. More damage can be done by improper care during the months of idleness each winter than by all the months of use in summer.

title: Part of Bourbon St. Closed After a Major Nightclub Fire
description: Officials closed one block of Bourbon Street Friday because of fear that the front wall of a fire-damaged building in the French Quarter might collapse.

title: HUMANITIES COUNCIL AWARDED
description: FOR its program of ''overall excellence,'' the Connecticut Humanities Council has been awarded a special $75,000 grant by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: CHICAGO TAKES UP TEACHING SLACK OF SCHOOL STRIKE
description: R. SHIPP

title: 3 Food Outlets Listed by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited three food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: NEW NAME AND SCHEDULE FOR EGLEVSKY BALLET
description: When the Eglevsky Ballet opens its new season with ''Nutcracker'' at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., Dec. 4, it will have a new name and will be trying out a new approach to scheduling its activities.

title: DUST HEAPS OF HISTORY

Aikens and his teammates Willie Wilson and Jerry Martin entered an agreement with the Government to make the guilty plea to a charge of attempted possession of cocaine.

description: THROUGH the years few workers have been so maligned, so caricatured in their occupations, as auto salesmen. And there has been a grain of truth in that view of the fast-talking, somewhat shady inheritor of the horse trader's mantle.

title: THE SCIENCE CORPS WANTS A FEW MORE GOOD HERETICS
description: The award of a Nobel Prize last week to Dr. Barbara McClintock for biological work once regarded as heretical spotlighted not only a gifted researcher but also the tension underlying all scientific progress. Since the days of Galileo and Newton, science has forged ahead largely because its ranks include both researchers who uphold the status quo and those who rebel against it.

description: Dorothy Parker once said that there were two things she could never figure out: the theory of the zipper and the precise function of Bernard M. Baruch. title: NEW BIBLE TRANSLATION WINS MIXED REACTION

description: For Wally Muller, the head football coach at Boys High School in Brooklyn from 1923 to 1958, the greatest legacy of his career is that 25 years after his retirement players not only remember, but care.

title: THEATER: BERTRAM ROSS
description: Bertram Ross has long been known as a leading dancer with the Martha Graham Dance Company, with which he performed for some 20 years. Thursday, in the Theater of the Riverside Church, he continued his exploration of a comparatively new world for him with monologues in which he played a number of characters. If Mr. Ross doesn't watch it, he may soon be thought of as simply a consummate actor.

title: OFFICES TO RISE ON 13 PRIME ACRES IN GLEN COVE
description: For seven years, the heart of Glen Cove's business district has been dominated by a 13-acre weed-filled lot. But in the corner of the city-owned site, a three-story office building - the beginning of a major redevelopment project here - is rising.

title: WIDOW, MOTHER, DAUGHTER, WRITER
description: THE LETTERS OF MARY WOLLSTONECRAFT SHELLEY

title: INTERMARRIAGE: JEWISH CHILDREN SUBJECT OF STUDY
description: What happens to the beliefs, practices and relationships of children born to Jews married to non-Jews? According to a study issued last week by the American Jewish Committee, they tend to define their Judaism as a belief in a religion but do not feel strongly linked to other Jews in ethnic or cultural ways. Although they may identify themselves as Jews, according to the study made public at a news conference, they rarely if ever attend synagogue services and are not distressed by the prospect that their own children may marry non-Jews.

title: POETRY AND MUSIC
description: As Dante rises through Paradise in the ''Divine Comedy,'' he keeps hearing saints and choirs of angels singing songs, some of which he says he will remember till he dies, but he does not give us the songs. At the same time he is involved in an intricate theological discourse in language so melodious one cannot forget the sound of it. The reader comes away from the great poem imagining that he too has heard what Dante would always remember. Music may never have been given greater tribute. But, then, Dante was a musician and never feared music might leave him speechless.

title: THE REGIONAL OUTLOOK ON EMPLOYMENT
description: HIGH TECHNOLOGY and military spending are providing new jobs in the New England states, but some other industries have yet to experience a recovery, according to economic experts.

title: A ROTHSCHILD STORY WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: ''IHAD thought a lot on the subject,'' said Anka Muhlstein of New York City and Sagaponack, ''so I had a rather clear idea of what I was really interested in, which was the character of James de Rothschild.''

title: WINTERIZE YOUR MOWER WELL SO T WILL PURR IN THE SPRING
description: OWNERS of power lawn mowers in this area will soon be cutting their grass for the last time, and shortly after that the mower will be put away until next spring. To make certain that the mower will start up easily and be ready to go when spring rolls around, and to prolong the life of the mower by preventing corrosion and unnecessary wear, the mower must be properly winterized before it is put into storage. More damage can be done by improper care during the months of idleness each winter than by all the months of use in summer.

title: Case of Soviet Activist Brings U.S. Questions
description: The State Department said today that the sentence imposed on a Jewish activist by a Soviet court, coupled with an increase of ''officially sanctioned'' anti-Semitism, had called into question Moscow's commitment to human rights.

title: FARE OF THE SEA IN NORWALK
description: OUR latest odyssey for seafood took us to downtown Norwalk to The Lighthouse. Inside, a dimly lighted hallway leads past a darkened bar on the right to a less dark dining room on two levels. Wood siding and brick walls with ''portholes'' of a colored-glass design, tanks of tropical fish and lobsters and overhead lanterns are the main concessions to nautical decor. Tiffany-type lampshades add an eclectic touch, and small vases of fresh flowers on each table complete the scene. Service combined friendliness with professionalism.

title: COSTLIER, BUT NOT YET BETTER TRANSIT SERVICE
description: Running New York's public transit systems means always having to say you're sorry. Even though Robert R. Kiley, the chairman-designate of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had yet to be confirmed by the State Senate, he was already warning subway riders last week that they would have to lower their expectations. ''They're going to have to put up with rebuilding the system,'' Mr. Kiley said in an interview four days after being selected by Governor Cuomo to succeed Richard Ravitch as chairman. ''It's going to be a frustrating two or three years.''

title: WORKSHOP SLATED FOR OVER-40 JOBLESS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK BEING out of work is rarely fun for anyone. But unemployment is usually harder on the older worker, who is less likely to find another job and more likely to leave the labor force in discouragement.

title: FINLAND'S HERITAGE ON PARADE
description: On the landing between the first and second floors of the Mannerheim Museum in Helsinki a visitor hearkens to the muffled clip-clop of . . . could it be a herd of reindeer from a nearby forest? The sound deepens to a steady rumble until the felt-slippered feet of a sturdy group of elderly Finnish women come into view, maybe 50 of them, paying homage to the man they revere as the father of Finland: Field Marshal Carl Gustav Mannerheim.

description: Four people have been charged after the police confiscated 673 pounds of cocaine while conducting a fire investigation at a cattle ranch in Lassen County.

When the bouzouki music begins its slow, siren sound and he starts to dance, it is as if the mountain itself had begun to move. He is old and grizzled, and his belly sags; but he is sinuous and feather-light on his feet, and he commands authority like no one else on stage.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE ;
 ON A STRING
description: As far as some connoisseurs of music are concerned, the only thing that could possibly be better than one mandolin is 30 mandolins - which is why the Long Island Mandolin and Guitar Society, one of the few remaining mandolin orchestras in the metropolitan New York area, has built up a devoted following. Today, doubters and devotees alike can judge for themselves when the society performs at the Levittown Public Library. Joined by Sally Ventriglia, soprano, and Joseph Mazzelo, tenor, the 30 instrumentalists will offer a program that encompasses both classical and contemporary music. The concert is at 3 P.M. at the library, 1 Bluegrass Lane, and is free. BAROQUE MUSIC

description: The Kitchen's ongoing survey of Russian Constructivist music and performance from the 1920's continued Thursday night when the pianist Sarah Rothenberg, the mezzo-soprano Cynthia Rose and the cellist Jerry Grossman presented music by Alexander Mossolov (1900-1973).

title: Sally Ann Montan Is Bride

The Rev. Park Dickerson performed the ceremony.

title: CHINESE ASSURANCES DO LITTLE TO SOOTHE HONG KONG'S JITTERS
description: When China and Britain began formal discussions on the future of Hong Kong last fall, they agreed not to divulge any details. The British have remained generally tight-lipped but the normally secretive Chinese have become almost voluble about their side of the issue. ''The Chinese leaders and the Chinese press have every right to explain and publicize to the Chinese people, including the compatriots in Hong Kong, the basic stand of the Chinese Government,'' the People's Daily said this month. ''How can this be interpreted as 'negotiating in public?' ''

title: POLISH PARTY WINDS UP 2-DAY IDEOLOGICAL SESSION
description: The Polish Communist Party's Central Committee today ended a two-day meeting with a call for increased struggle against deviant ideologies.

title: TENNESSEE, TRAILING BY 27-17, UPSETS ALABAMA, 41-34
description: Alan Cockrell passed long for three touchdowns and ran for another score, and Johnnie Jones sprinted 66 yards for the deciding score with 3 minutes to play as Tennessee upset Alabama, 41-34, today.

title: MARATHON STORY: FAMINE TO FEAST
description: In 1970, when Fred Lebow staged the first New York City Marathon, the race budget was so tight that he bought soda for the 126 runners in Greenwich Village, where it was a few cents cheaper, and dragged it to the race site in Central Park.

description: Mental as Anything made despair sound like fun Thursday at the Ritz. The five-piece Australian band played good-timey songs that tapped rockabilly, British music-hall, country-rock and Beatles-style pop, slipping in extra chords here and there.

title: PHYSICAL REHABILITATION MARKET IN FINE SHAPE
description: WHEN it comes to a growth industry in jobs, hardly any positions fare as well as those of physical and occupational therapists, people who work with the physically disabled and elderly and prepare them to return to a career or to domestic life.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Phillies vs. Baltimore Orioles, Game Five of the World Series, at Philadelphia. Only six American black pitchers have ever won World Series games: Joe Black with the 1952 Brooklyn Dodgers, John (Blue Moon) Odom with the 1974 Oakland A's, Jim (Mudcat) Grant with the 1965 Twins, John Wyatt with the 1967 Red Sox, Grant Jackson with the 1979 Pirates and Bob Gibson with the Cardinals in 1964, 1967 and 1968. Charles Hudson of the Phillies, the loser in Game Two, gets another chance to become the seventh one. Scott McGregor is scheduled to be the Oriole starter. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 4:20 P.M.). Football Jets vs. Miami Dolphins, at Shea Stadium, 1:05 P.M. This is the first meeting of the season between the Jets and the team that kept them from going to the Super Bowl last season. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880 1 P.M. P.M.).

title: Shoemaker Goes North
description: Willie Shoemaker, the world's leading jockey, has won a lot of races in his day, including 215 in Canada, but he's never won a Canadian race worth more than $100,000. Now, at the age of 52, Shoemaker thinks it's time to try again. Today he'll make his third attempt at the $500,000 Rothmans International turf race in Toronto aboard a 5-year-old French horse named Palikaraki.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: The boy was born by Caesarean section last March 26, nine weeks after his mother had been declared ''brain dead.''

title: Oregon Upsets Arizona, 19-10
description: Doug Judge's 91-yard kickoff return helped give Oregon a 19-10 upset victory over previously unbeaten Arizona tonight in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: RUSSIA: A PEOPLE WITHOUT HEROES
description: AUTUMN IS THE SADDEST season in Moscow. It comes too soon, furtively, dissolving the fleeting summer warmth in a haze of gray and rain. In the collective farmers' markets the crude wooden counters begin to lose their splashes of bright greens and reds, shifting into somber shades as squashes and nuts and potatoes appear, heaped in front of peasant men and women who have come on crowded trains and buses in the aching hours before dawn. In coarse padded jackets they stoop over their wares, their faces the color of burlap. Occasionally a gold tooth flashes in a clucking, coaxing smile of salesmanship, like the glint of gilt on a church's onion dome against the sunless city. The smells of the aging summer turn musty.

title: INQUIRY BY SEOUL BLAMES NORTH FOR BOMBING
description: A South Korean investigating team says North Korean agents used a bomb filled with about 700 small ball bearings and an incendiary device in the explosion last Sunday that killed 17 South Koreans, including 4 Cabinet members.

description: Before today's teen-agers finish college, computers will interpret changes in tax law and plan tax strategies for business. Robots will replace humans in radioactive nuclear plants. Underlying these statistics - a mirror of the American economy itself - is the fact that the United States is a big, richly endowed, affluent nation.
