title: RELIGIOUS GROUPS PLAN MORE SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS
description: With another winter approaching, representatives from churches, synagogues and private assistance groups gathered yesterday to consider ways to help New York City's growing homeless population - a group that city officials have acknowledged may pose an overwhelming problem.

title: No Headline
description: Amy McKeon Is a Bride

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
THE POSSIBLITIES ARE ETERNAL
description: The identity of God as a father may or may not affect the heavenly disposal of saints and sinners, but some believers feel it strongly affects everyone's attitude on earth. Last week, the National Council of Churches took a bold step toward textual equality of the sexes.

title: MIDDLE EAST PROSPECTS: ROOM FOR SPECIALISTS
description: CAIRO FOR decades, the Middle East has held a special allure for Westerners, with visions of Arabian sands, colorful Bedouins and romantic desert oases. But in the last 10 years, the nature of the enticement has been replaced by prospects of easy money in sheikdoms swimming in oil. Tens of thousands of Americans have come to the Arab world to work since 1973, when the price of oil began skyrocketing.

title: CASHING IN ON THE NEW BUSINESS OF BANKING
description: WEARING a bright red dress and fingering a long string of beads, Elaine R. Bond is not the typical banker. But what makes her different is not the brightness of her dress nor her sex, but what she does. For she neither makes loans nor takes deposits. She is an expert in computerization and communications. Her jargon is not that of a banker. It is that of a wizard in electronic communications.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDAL MARKS METROPOLITAN OPERA'S CENTENNIAL
description: The Metropolitan Opera is celebrating its 100th anniversary this week, and to help underscore the importance of the occasion a special commemorative medal has been struck with the opera company's formal imprimatur. This ''centennial medallion,'' commissioned by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, is the first official medal ever offered to the public by the Met.

title: Dublin
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR HIGH SCHOOL GRADS, A WIDE JOB RANGE
description: THOUGH the importance of career training and education cannot be denied, hundreds of thousands of people with only a high-school diploma and no training can still qualify for steady, well-paying jobs. Special training or skills help, but the job market, despite high youth unemployment, has plenty to offer in a variety of fields, such as the airline industry, the brokerage business and the growing world of computers.

title: BASIC HACKING, FROM DATA BASE TO PORT
description: TO hundreds of thousands of users

title: Earthquake in the Pacific
description: An earthquake early this morning near the Solomon Islands in the southwestern Pacific Ocean measured 6.7 on the Richter scale, the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center reported. The earthquake's epicenter was about 1,400 miles north of Brisbane, Australia, the center said.

title: FIRST-STRIKE CAPABILITIES IN THE WAR FOR OPINION
description: Soviet-American arms negotiations have long had a fair quotient of posturing and maneuvering but never more so than in the talks on European nuclear forces. In two years, the exchanges have produced more thunder than diplomacy, more public relations ploys than private give-and-take. Driven by Moscow's hopes of splitting the Atlantic Alliance and Washington's determination to hold it together, the negotiations have seemed less an exercise in balancing the nuclear equation than a drama staged to sway Western European opinion. Now, with the initial deployment of American medium-range missiles in West Germany, Britain and Italy going ahead in December, both sides seem mainly preoccupied with scoring tactical points. However, their roles have switched: President Reagan has turned to offering concessions and preaching flexibility; the Kremlin has dug in its heels.

title: Bringing More Power
description: To the Island

title: DOES MONDALE HAVE IT MADE IN NEW YORK?
description: Beyond a shot at a few seconds on the evening news, one politician's ceremonial embrace of another usually doesn't count for much. Last week's announcement by New York Governor Cuomo that he would back Walter F. Mondale, a Presidential hopeful who has been on a roll lately, might be a different matter.

title: COWARD WILT ENLIVENS STAGE
description: SOME 25 years ago, the plays of Sir No"el Coward were out of fashion and even out of print. When Edward Albee, the playwright who has a home in Montauk, was asked to write an introduction to the volume ''Three Plays by No"el Coward'' in 1964, he was astonished to discover that none of the 27 works Coward wrote for the stage were available in the United States.

title: Article 229531 -- No Title
description: THE county's Department of Planning has parceled out this year's $3.9 million in Federal Community Development funds among 20 communities and 11 nonprofit organizations, for projects ranging from $7,700 in improvements at the Ossining Historical Society's headquarters to $400,000 for the reconstruction of streets and housing in Port Chester.

title: MARKET IS WIDE OPEN FOR MARKETING EXPERTS
description: IF the measure of the status of a profession is the fee a practitioner can command, then marketing has come of

title: Census
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SEARCH OF SEAFOOD
description: LOOK for a seafood restaurant on the Island, and you may find that the Galley in Lindenhurst is typical. It is an unfortunate fact of dining out on the Island that the preparation of seafood (as in the case of duck, the other highly esteemed local product) is often mediocre.

title: 1980'S GRADS: BABY BOOM TO JOB BUST
description: WHEN David Rivers graduated from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst nine months ago, he moved to New York City full of enthusiasm and optimism about starting a career in advertising. But despite a model job campaign and impressive credentials, including a high grade-point average and summer and part-time work experience, Mr. Rivers has been unable to break into advertising or even land an entry-level job in a related field.

title: First Apartment
description: To the Editor:

ANTIQUES;

description: IT is, in many ways, the gift of a

title: CAMPUS NEWSPAPER DEBATED
description: WHAT's in a name? That seems to be the question of the moment at the State University of New York at Purchase. In the case of the campus newspaper, the answer has involved weeks of heated controversy marked by charges and countercharges, editorial dismissals and resignations, broken friendships and threats of legal action.

title: CONCERT: VIENNA CHAMBER PERFORMS BISCHOF PREMIERE
description: The Vienna Chamber Orchestra under Philippe Entremont paid a visit to Carnegie Hall Friday night, and their program offered listeners a vivid contrast between the wildly popular and the barely known.

title: MARBLE HALLS EMERGE FROM GREEN PLANT
description: THE United States Navy has been gone from Hempstead House for 16 years. But a group of Nassau County people interested in renovating the mansion are still trying to restore its Jacobean and Tudor opulence after the Navy turned it from a virtual palace into the ultimate in military drabness.

title: PRINCETON HOUSING OPPOSED
description: PRINCETON APLAN by the Institute for Advanced Study to allow real- estate development on farmland that it owns is being opposed by local citizens' groups concerned over the possible effect on nearby historical landmarks and local wildlife.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Smart Money Evelyn E. Handler isn't exactly planning to put Brandeis University admissions on sale at cut rates, but as the new president of the institution, she has a cost-conscious approach. Mrs. Handler, who was inaugurated last week, says a major problem facing private universities is ''the possibility of pricing themselves out of the market.''

title: AT TIFFANY, A TROUBLED TRANSITION
description: THE store sits like a crown jewel on Fifth Avenue. Tiffany & Company, which made its name catering to the carriage trade, is a storehouse of luxe. Its cavernous main floor - with imposing teak and marble walls - is filled with precious gems and ornate gold jewelry. And its upper floors carry even more riches for the rich - exquisite crystal, delicate china and sterling silver flatware.

title: FROM FOOD STREET TO STREET FOOD
description: -FEI LO, author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes from the Chinese Teahouse'' (Crown), teaches regional Chinese cooking at the China Institute in America in New York, and in Montclair, N.J.

title: Crisis Procedure Tested
description: Key officials were reached within 16 minutes in a test Saturday night of Rockland County's emergency alert system, to be used in the event of an accident at the Indian Point nuclear facility, according to Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello.

title: THE ISRAELI MILITARY'S POLITICAL INTERFERENCE
description: The new Israeli Government led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir faces a severe economic crisis and a stalemate in Lebanon. Yet, there is another little talked about issue that may, in the long run, emerge as one of the country's most intractable challenges - the growing conflict between the military and the political establishments.

title: FOR MATT DILLON'S BREED, PURPOSE BEATS ADULATION
description: Pink and turquoise flags whip smartly in the ocean breeze, the sky is a brilliant blue and the bright sun glistens on the well-oiled bodies lounging beside the pool. The men are wearing such outfits as matching cabana sets; the women, in extravagantly teased hairdos with perky bows perched atop bouffant swirls and poofs, sport old-fashioned two- piece bathing suits with lots of ruffles or short shorts and high heels. Through the crowd strolls an extraordinarily good-looking young man with sultry eyes, a long, slow smile and a vintage flat-top haircut.

title: BUSINESS CHAOS IN ARGENTINA
description: Daghe S.A., a computer dealership, had a plan of expansion that was supposed to be completed in 45 days. But 45 days turned out to be a bit too long- range for doing business in Argentina's chaotic economy.

title: Abigail Petersen Weds Daniel Reingold

Reingold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Reingold of New York. Rabbis Marcus Kramer and Milton D. Rosenfeld officiated at Temple Israel in West Brighton.

title: No Headline
description: International The threat to oil supplies posed by the Iran-Iraq war is serious, especially in light of Iran's repeated assertion that it may close the Strait of Hormuz. But oil traders and industry analysts say the world could cope with a loss of the six million barrels of oil a day that pass through the strait. (Page D1.)

title: TENNESSEE G.O.P. FEARS LOSING BAKER'S SEAT TO ALBERT GORE JR.
description: ''I don't know where people get the idea that Al Gore is a shoo-in as the next Senator from Tennessee,'' said Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., who touched off a campaign for his seat by announcing that he would retire next year.

description: Lisa Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Perry of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. David J. Hellerstein, son of Drs. Herman and Mary Hellerstein of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: MCENROE TAKES FINAL, IS SUSPENDED 21 DAYS
description: John McEnroe received an automatic 21-day suspension today when he was fined for abusing the let-cord judge during his 6-1, 6-4, 7-5 victory over Henri Leconte in the final of the $255,000 Australian Indoor tennis championships.

title: CROWD IS ORDERLY, CRITICISM IS MILD
description: If booing can be scaled from 1 to 10, the crowd at Shea Stadium yesterday hit a 3 once at halftime and then a 5 after Richard Todd's fifth intercepted pass in the third period.

title: A STEADFAST LIFE
description: Esta Cameron Wicker was 89 years old when they buried her beneath the long-leaf pines in Mary Love Cemetery. She had lived, it was commonly said of her, a long, good, full life in which she had exemplified the words of the hymn they sang at her funeral:

description: Sheryl Rina Levin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Levin of Larchmont, N.Y., was married at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday to Scott Edward Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Thompson of Albany. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Abner Weiss, assisted by Rabbi Hershel Portnoy and Cantor Lawrence Avery.

title: IRAN-IRAQ OIL THREAT MINIMIZED
description: The three-year-old war between Iran and Iraq, neighboring nations that sit on top of some of the world's largest oil reserves, is posing the most serious threat of disrupting international oil supplies since the Iranian revolution in 1979. But, for now, the oil market is stable, and many experts are saying that industrial nations could take such a disruption in stride.

title: Marcos Calls Advisers To Confer on Crisis
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has called a meeting of his top advisers and allies at a party caucus to discuss ways to halt the slide of the Philippines into political and economic anarchy, the Government said today.

description: Wanda Rivera and Nilsa Velasquez, seniors at Washington Irving High School, were trying to convince an eighth grader that their school was the best.

description: WASHINGTON WHAT the Supreme Court has called ''the regulatory equivalent of war'' - the Government vs. Detroit over airbags - enters another phase this week. It is unlikely, however, that this engagement in a struggle that has been going on for 14 years is going to be decisive.

description: The Long Island Lighting Company could be bankrupted if it were forced to absorb as much as $1 billion of the $3.5 billion estimated cost of its Shoreham nuclear plant, according to the draft report by the staff of Governor Cuomo's special commission on Shoreham.

description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, Italy's first Socialist head of government, will arrive in the United States Tuesday for talks with President Reagan and top American officials that are expected to center on economic and arms issues.

title: No Headline
description: Beware the Dairy Skim Even a part of the dairy industry acknowledges that something has to be done about its price supports. They are costing the taxpayers close to $3 billion a year, and Government warehouses are bulging with billions of pounds of surplus cheese, butter and powdered milk. The question is whether Congress will simply reduce support levels or let the industry saddle the public with a ''compromise'' that merely papers over the problem.

title: MACLEAN HUNTER SCORES WHERE TIME INC. DIDN'T
description: Maclean Hunter Ltd., the Canadian publishing and communications company, is apparently succeeding where Time Inc. failed.

title: THE STAGE: 'ZORBA' AND QUINN
description: MAYBE a few diehards still picture the Parthenon when thinking of Greece, but most everyone else conjures up the sight of Anthony Quinn lifting his arms to a broad sky and dancing to the ever- quickening pulse of the bouzouki. When Mr. Quinn first played Zorba the Greek two decades ago, in the film version of the Nikos Kazantzakis novel, he created a movie image as durable as the M-G-M lion. Now the actor has returned to the part - playing it on stage for the first time in the revival of the musical ''Zorba'' - and you might say he is tempting the fates. One exaggerated move, and Mr. Quinn would lose the spontaneity that made the image of Zorba first grab us. The yeasty old Greek who still lives on film would be replaced by a plaster icon, a self-parody, a cliche.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Is it true that left-handers are not allowed to play jai-alai? If so, is there any other sport that restricts left-handers?

title: DANCE: AT RIVERSIDE, JOAN LOMBARDI GROUP
description: JOAN LOMBARDI devised pictorially effective choreographic images and set them moving in witty and poignant ways at Wednesday night's performance by the Joan Lombardi Dance Company at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Careless Smoking Suspected in Fire
description: Careless smoking may have caused a fire Friday night in which a woman, her two sons and a visiting child died when smoke and toxic gases from a smoldering couch filled a house while they slept, officials said.

title: PRETORIA REPORTS MOZAMBIQUE RAID
description: South African defense forces said today that a ''small task force'' of troops attacked buildings used by members of the exiled African National Congress in Maputo, the capital of neighboring Mozambique.

title: STATE ELECTION FEATURES COUNTY EXECUTIVE RACES
description: Contests for County Executive, a position of growing importance, in three of the most populous counties in New York State highlight the elections for town, city and county offices throughout the state next month.

title: ILLINOIS LOOKS LIKE A ROSE BOWL TEAM
description: Illinois has not played in a Rose Bowl since Jan. 1, 1964, when the Illini beat Washington, 17-7. But Illinois showed last Saturday that it was capable of going back to Pasadena, Calif., Jan. 2 as the Big Ten Conference representative. Not only did the Illini upset Ohio State, 17-13, but the way they came from behind in the closing moments marked them as a team of poise and power, not just a team of throwing and hoping.

description: * Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, Hanover, N.J., to Robert A. Becker Inc. for its Hydergne, Mellaril, Parlodel, Pamelor, Restoril products and yet to be introduced Clozaril.

title: KEY COURT RULING DUE ON HYDROELECTRIC PLANT
description: The proposal to build an electrical generating plant at Dog Hill here, after seven years of debate in the courts and before Federal and state agencies, is nearing a critical decision in the New York State Court of Appeals.

title: No Headline
description: Redecorating Apartheid Outwardly, it may look as if South Africa's white masters are creeping into the present century. They are offering a new charter, extending some rights to some nonwhites, for a referendum Nov. 2. Prime Minister P. W. Botha promotes it as a bold reform. Scenting heresy and fearing a dilution of white supremacy, a hard-line minority has seceded from his Nationalist Party and campaigns furiously against the new constitution.

description: Economists have been accused of predicting nine of the last five recessions, but that overzealous record does not seem any worse than that of traders of Treasury securities, who have a habit of predicting many more changes in Federal Reserve monetary policy than actually occurr.

title: SHIPPING RIFT WITH PHILIPPINES
description: A Federal regulatory agency has proposed rules that could bar Philippine cargo ships from American ports. The move would be in retaliation to Philippine procedures that, according to American exporters, cause shipping delays and excess charges.

title: WHITE'S PASSING LEADS COWBOYS
description: Danny White completed 24 of 37 passes for 266 yards and 2 touchdowns as the unbeaten Dallas Cowboys rolled to their seventh straight comeback victory, 37-7, today over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Nuclear Shipments Begin
description: The first of 114 shipments of spent nuclear fuel rods through Ohio to Wisconsin was moved Oct. 4, according to Philip G. Woods, a spokesman for the West Valley Nuclear Services Company in New York, the company that stored the radioactive wastes. In addition, 206 rods are to be sent in 30 shipments through Ohio to Commonwealth Edison in Illinois, he said Friday.

title: ISLANDERS' HRUDEY WINS IN FIRST START
description: No one noticed it more than Kelly Hrudey, the Islanders' rookie goaltender. With him in the net, the Islanders played their best game of the season tonight for a 3-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres at Memorial Auditorium. Hrudey, making his first start in the National Hockey League, benefited from a rejuvenated defense that had allowed 25 goals in the first five games.

title: Zia Reportedly Seeks Advice From Adversary
description: President Mohammad Zia ul- Haq sent an aide today to ask an opposition leader under house arrest about his views regarding a return to civilian rule, opposition sources said.

description: Denis Savard, Behn Wilson and Bill Gardner scored second-period goals to lead Chicago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: DOODLING AND CROSSING OUT Alfred Lord Tennyson doodled profiles, Walt Whitman crossed out a lot and Emily Dickinson printed oddly in pencil. The ways of nearly 50 American and English poets can be seen starting today in ''Exaltation of Poetry,'' an exhibition of rarely displayed manuscripts at the Central Research Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: M'FARLANE CALLED CHOICE OF REAGAN FOR SECURITY POST
description: President Reagan has chosen Robert C. McFarlane as his national security adviser, a White House official said today. The selection was reported to have angered Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, and to have persuaded her to reject any offer of another post in the Administration when she leaves the United Nations position this year.

description: THE deer hunting season in southern New York State opened quietly last Friday for New Yorkers with bows and arrows.

description: On Madison Avenue, Andre O. Backar, a financier, savored the glint of fall sunlight on his Rolls-Royce.

description: Some of the young computer enthusiasts under investigation by the Federal authorities say they were able to rummage through the electronic mail of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

description: The Giants went from bad to worse today. They lost their third straight game when the Kansas City Chiefs scored four straight second-half touchdowns for a 38-17 victory.

description: The weeklong Frankfurt Book Fair still has another day to run, but joy over the brisk business already conducted has given way to anguish and astonishment over the scheduling of next year's fair.

title: COMMON TRAUMA OF MOVING
description: WHILE tales of ''the old neighborhood'' tend to be bathed in a warm glow of nostalgia, little of the same glory is ever heaped upon the ''new'' neighborhood. For most people, the discomfort of settling in is something they would rather not talk about at all.

title: 'A BLOODY JOKE'
description: ''The Reagan Administration complains about the death squads in El Salvador. But its policy is for military victory, with negotiations only as window-dressing, and that doesn't give any chance to human rights. It just encourages the far right. And the policy isn't working. The 'military progress' is fading away. So there will be more escalation, more American involvement.''

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 17, 1983 International
description: Robert C. McFarlane has been chosen by President Reagan to be his national security adviser, a White House official said. The selection was said to have angered Jeane J. Kirkpatrick and persuaded her to reject any offer of another position in the Administration after she departs later this year as chief United States representative at the United Nations. (Page A1, Column 6.) An American marine was killed and three were wounded as unidentified snipers fired at the Marine contingent in Beirut for the third consecutive day, a Marine spokesman announced. Hours earlier, a man was killed and at least seven were wounded in a clash between Israeli troops and Moslem worshipers in the southern Lebanese town of Nabatiye. (A1:1.)

description: James W. Lewis goes on trial Monday on charges of extortion linked to the deaths of seven people who died last fall after swallowing Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules tainted with cyanide. Investigators have said they have no motive and no suspects in the killings.

title: MURRAY EMERGES TO SHATTER PHILLIES
description: When Eddie Murray was growing up on 108th Street in Los Angeles, his father recalled today, he broke an automobile windshield now and then. Not with a thrown rock but with a batted ball.

title: 2 Officers Cited In AIDS Incident
description: Two city patrolmen have been suspended and face departmental charges for disobeying orders for refusing to drive two prisoners - one of them ill with acquired immune deficiency syndrome - to a hospital, according to the police.

title: BILLS DEFEAT COLTS AND TAKE THE LEAD
description: The Buffalo Bills, a team lightly regarded in the division before the season, moved into sole possession of first place in the American Conference East today. They defeated the Baltimore Colts, 30-7, to raise their record to 5-2 and drop the Colts to 4-3.

description: Union officials rejected as ''totally unacceptable'' a wage offer from the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation, paving the way for a strike at midnight tonight by 6,300 aerospace workers in three states.

title: Nurse, and Dr. Jack Troper Marry
description: Leslie Gail Bennett, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Edwin J. Bennett of Woodside, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Jack Troper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Troper of Forest Hills, Queens. title: RANGERS WIN, 5-4 ENDING FLYER STREAK
description: When they skated onto the Madison Square Garden ice last night, the Philadelphia Flyers were one of two unbeaten teams in the National Hockey League. When they left, a loss had been pasted onto their record and they had been knocked down a notch in the standing.

title: Austria Bank Seeks New Role
description: The appointment three years ago of Hannes Androsch, the enfant terrible of the Austrian financial world, to head Creditanstalt-Bankverein, the nation's biggest bank, shook the venerable institution to its foundations.

title: TV: BBC SHAKESPEARE SERIES TURNS TO 'MACBETH'
description: GOING into its final seasons a bit behind schedule because of the usual money problems that afflict the arts internationally on television, the mammoth BBC project devoted to ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' all 37 of them, has finally come around to ''Macbeth.'' On WNET/Channel 13 at 8 this evening, the handsomely lean and compelling production stars Nichol Williamson and Jane Lapotaire.

title: Chaminade 18-16 Victor
description: Tim McDevitt ran 8 yards for the touchdown that gave Chaminade an 18-16 victory over Mount St. Michael's yesterday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. But while the 3-1 Flyers kept pace with undefeated St. Francis Prep in the Island Division of the Catholic High Schools Football League, they lost their star running back.

title: DEMPSEY LOOKS BACK
description: PHILADELPHIA HE didn't like it when he was traded to the Baltimore Orioles. He liked it where he was, working behind Thurman Munson, learning more about catching, watching the Yankees build toward a championship team.

title: HOLIDAY FOR KING: AN EXPRESSION OF PRINCIPLE
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Oct. 11 on ''A Day For Martin Luther King'' is a fair and balanced judgment, but you were far too easy on Jesse Helms in calling him ''simply wrong'' when he accused the late Dr. King of ''action- oriented Marxism . . . not compat

title: Lisa Baker Is Married To Robert Brill, Editor
description: Elizabeth Jane Baker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Laurence S. Baker of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Michael Brill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Brill of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Baker home.

title: MUSIC/NOTES IN BRIEF;
description: Jonathan Richman Sings at Bottom Line

title: DEVILS BEATEN, 4-1
description: The Devils were so ineffective in their 4-1 loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight that many fans headed for the Byrne Meadowlands Arena exits midway through the last period.

title: LOS ANGELES COMPANY IS ACCUSED OF DUMPING WASTES INTO SEWERS
description: An East Los Angeles steel processing concern, Precision Specialty Metals Inc., has been charged with using an illegal dumping system that channeled thousands of gallons of toxic wastes daily into city and county sewers.

title: WHAT IF LAND WAR CAME TO EUROPE?
description: Military Analysis

title: VIDEO GAMES INDUSTRY COMES DOWN TO EARTH
description: The boom is over for the once high- flying world of video games.

title: No Headline
description: Two Strikes Against the Crime Bill Dangerous Reform for Dangerous Offenders

title: Chicago Teachers' Strike Enters Third Week
description: Negotiators for striking teachers and the Chicago Board of Education faced each other today in another round of talks aimed at ending a two-week-old walkout.

title: Michael Pariser Wed To Andrea Hollander
description: At Congregation Kneseth Israel in Far Rockaway, Queens, yesterday Andrea Hollander, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Haskell Hollander of Pittsburgh, was married to Michael Pariser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Pariser of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel Bick, assisted by Rabbi Moshe Morduchowitz.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.67

title: Forecasters ExpectStorm to Bypass Hawaii
description: The tropical storm code-named Raymond raised surf that closed a coastal road on the island of Hawaii today but would arc past the Hawaiian Islands well out at sea, weather forecasters said.

title: Required Reading Lesson in Tolerance
description: Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York, on the recent speaking appearance of Senator Edward M. Kennedy at Liberty Baptist College, Congressional Record, Oct. 6, 1983:

title: Swiss Trade Deficit Cut
description: Switzerland's trade deficit narrowed by 62 percent in September from August and was down 54.6 percent from September 1982, the federal Customs Office said. September's deficit totaled 404 million francs, or about $190 million, compared with 1.075 billion francs in August and 890 million francs in September 1982, the Customs Office said Friday.

title: Fred Schwartz Is Married To Miss Berry, a Student
description: The marriage of Michelle Berry, daughter of Rachelle Sara Berry of Storrs, Conn., and the late Dr. John Edwin Berry, to Fred Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Asher W. Schwartz of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday. Walter Lawton, the leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale Golf Club in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Keep Supplying Continental, Judge Orders 200 Companies
description: More than 200 suppliers have been ordered to continue providing goods and services to Continental Airlines while the troubled carrier reorganizes under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: LONG, TROUBLED ODYSSEY OF A CHILD OF BUREAUCRACY
description: Twenty-two years ago, Dwayne Lee Gosso was born into the custody of New York State, the son of a prison inmate who did not want him. For two decades he was a child of the state bureaucracy, living in foundling and foster homes, mental hospitals and rehabilitation centers.

title: LandlordsMustProve Their Boilers Operate
description: The owners of 194 apartment buildings with poor records of providing heat and hot water will be ordered to prove in Housing Court next week that boilers in their buildings are working, city housing officials announced yesterday.

title: FOR THE DEATH PENALTY
description: Henry Lee Lucas will soon be tried in Montague, Tex. He has confessed to murdering about 150 women in 16 states. If found guilty in New York State, he would be able to peacefully live out his life in prison. In Texas, he may be executed - although undoubtedly his lawyers would stress that he is the product of a deprived childhood.

title: OUSTER OF GRENADA'S LEADER IS INDICATED BY ARMY CHIEF
description: The head of Grenada's army has indicated that Prime Minister Maurice Bishop has been deposed and that the army has taken control of the small island nation.

title: No Headline
description: Freshmen Vote Possible

title: OPERA: FIRST 'CANDIDE' OF YEAR BY CITY TROUPE
description: THERE is a belief popular in music circles that ethnic differences matter little anymore. The Japanese, for example, often seem to be playing Haydn as well as the Viennese, and bel canto tradition rests certainly as much with the Australians and the Americans as in Italy.

title: CANADIANS SIGN PACT WITH U.S. ON GREAT LAKES
description: The United States and Canada signed a new agreement today to cleanse the Great Lakes further of phosphorus pollutants.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: 20th-Century Program By English Guitarist

title: No Headline
description: BUSINESS PEOPLE

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Liner's Safe Still Unopened

title: AUDEN BEING HONORED THIS WEEK
description: The work of the English poet W. H. Auden, who died 10 years ago last month, will be celebrated today through Friday with poetry readings, symposiums and literary tributes around the city.

title: WHISTLEBLOWER FIGHTS BACK
description: On Feb. 11, 1982, George R. Spanton, a Defense Department auditor assigned to Pratt & Whitney's huge plant here, sent his boss a memorandum that accused the jet-engine manufacturer of entertaining several high-ranking officials from the Air Force and the Navy in violation of Pentagon standards of conduct.

title: APPLAUSE IN PARIS FOR LAGERFELD AND MIYAKE
description: Two moving collections have been shown here since the wave of Japanese designers roiled the fashion waters late last week. Karl Lagerfeld, who told everyone he was making ''the last collection for Chloe under my old contract,'' tried to stretch modern dressmaking into new directions. Issey Miyake, who has been bringing his clothes here from Tokyo for 11 years and is a regular part of the Paris scene, presented a collection of stunning beauty and received an ovation.

title: Advertising; Movies Magazine Halted
description: AFTER three years of effort and five issues of his magazine, Joe Armstrong suspended publication of The Movies on Friday. His Texas angel and partner, Neil C. Morgan, declined to put up any more than his original $2.5 million investment.

title: KOCH, IN VISIT, PLEDGES TO AID SANTO DOMINGO
description: Mayor Koch concluded a two-day visit here today with a promise to Mayor Jose Francisco Pena Gomez that New York City would step up its efforts to sell used sanitation trucks and other municipal equipment to this struggling, sprawling city.

title: ORIOLES DEFEAT PHILLIES, 5-0, AND WIN SERIES
description: The Baltimore Orioles won their fourth consecutive game and the World Series today when they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-0, with an early burst of home runs and the precision pitching of Scott McGregor.

title: No Headline
description: Yale Hamsters Injected WithVirusAre Missing

title: SORRY STATE OF THE WORLD, AS TOLD IN 151 SPEECHES
description: During the three weeks of debate that have now ended in the General Assembly, 151 countries expressed their views from the podium. While few of the speeches contained surprises, taken together they made up a kind of straw poll revealing official opinion among virtually all the nations of the world on various crises and controversies.

title: Architectural Digest Appoints a Publisher
description: G. Robert Griswold, 54 years old and with 29 years at McGraw-Hill behind him, has been named publisher of Architectural Digest, which has one of the nation's most elite magazine audiences - and is $4.50 a copy.

title: DOLING OUT THE PERQUISITES OF POWER
description: Like the President he works for, John F. W. Rogers is an affable man of boundless self-confidence whose age is a sensitive subject and who has long craved tenancy at the White House. Like Ronald Reagan, Mr. Rogers has also devoted the last decade to winning the chance to wield power there.

title: DOLPHINS BEAT JETS
description: After suffering six interceptions, a blocked punt, a safety and the reaction of fans who treated them as if they already were an out-of-town team, the Jets lost to the Miami Dolphins, 32-14, yesterday.

title: Spanish Advertising Merging With Robles
description: Spanish Advertising and Marketing Services is becoming independent once again and, since it is also merging with Frank Robles Communications, will be known as Robles Rodriguez/Spanish American Marketing Systems.

title: 2 Bell Units Elect Boards
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Southwestern Bell Corporation, two of the seven regional holding companies to be created from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, held their first board meetings on Friday.

title: 'NEANDERTHAL' OPPOSITION TO GAS DECONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: SCORE OF COMPLAINTS FILED ON LOUD RING OF CORDLESS PHONE
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission says it has received more than 20 complaints about the ring of cordless telephones, including a few asserting permanent hearing loss.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Outlook For Crop Demand
description: sown grains and soybeans proceeding at a rapid pace under ideal weather conditions, and with the Government's latest crop estimates, issued Tuesday, producing no surprises, the major questions now facing the trade are: How much demand will there be for the crops, which were sharply cut back this year by the drought and Government acreage reduction programs? Will the higher prices caused by the smaller harvests reduce demand by in effect rationing supplies?

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Music of the Caucasus Performed by Kavkazi

title: 2-YEAR NOTES TO BE SOLD THIS WEEK
description: The first sale of Treasury notes in three weeks is scheduled for Wednesday, when $8 billion of new two-year notes are to be auctioned.

title: No Headline
description: Kenyan First In Chicago

title: MusicNoted in Brief; Sergei Edelmann In Piano Recital
description: There was much to admire in the recital given by the Soviet emigre pianist Sergei Edelmann at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday afternoon. Aside from a few technical slips, Mr. Edelmann's digital accomplishments were considerable, whether in the swirls of Bach's Chromatic Fantasy or in the furious articulations of Schubert's ''Wanderer'' Fantasy.

title: SHULA SOLID IN MIAMI
description: SOME coaches prefer to stand on ceremony, or at least on a carpet. But after the Miami Dolphins stunned the Jets, 32-14, yesterday, Don Shula stood on the tile floor of the visiting team's bathroom at Shea Stadium as he discussed his future, his team and his rookie quarterback, Dan Marino - all three of which are connected. On Feb. 28, his current contract with the Dolphins will expire. As a result, Don Shula has been openly coveted by Donald Trump, the new owner of the New Jersey Generals, as the next coach of that United States Football League franchise.

title: DANCE: BERND DOES 'LOST AND FOUND'
description: JOHN BERND'S new ''Lost and Found (scenes from a life),'' performed at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater on Tuesday, opens with a tableau that could have been painted by Thomas Eakins in a fairly distant mood. Mr. Bernd sits front-stage in a chair, reminiscing in an elliptical fashion that has the ring of spare, lean verse. Behind him lies a slight young man, nude in the dim light.

title: Diane Steinberg Is Married
description: Diane Bryna Steinberg, daughter of Max Steinberg of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Shirley Steinberg, was married yesterday to Dr. Edwin Michael Schottenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Schottenstein of Columbus, Ohio, and Hallandale, Fla.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Different Look

title: JESSE JACKSON SEEKS WIDER AUDIENCE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is seeking a broader audience, fueling speculation that he will announce his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination within weeks.

title: Bahamian Crew Is Rescued From Blazing Ship Off France
description: French frogmen and naval helicopters rescued 29 crewmen from a burning Bahamian freighter off the coast of northwest France today, the maritime police said.

title: GERMAN SAYS ARMS TALKS MAY CONTINUE
description: West Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, said today that the Soviet leadership was considering remaining at the Geneva arms limitation talks even after the projected deployment of American medium-range missiles in Western Europe.

title: BOTTLE LAW A BONANZA FOR YOUNG
description: Nine-year-old Raymond Martinez brought 49 cans to his local A.&P. yesterday and left with $2.45. David Greengrass, 7, and his brother Andrew, 11, brought 18 cans and bottles to the Red Apple supermarket down the street and took home 90 cents.

title: INTERNATIONAL REPORT B.A.T's Setbacks in Tobacco
description: Despite its moves toward diversification, including the purchase of Marshall Field & Company and Gimbel Brothers Inc., two big American retailing chains, B.A.T Industries of London is still very much a tobacco company. And tobacco has become a nagging headache for it, especially in the United States.

title: A COURT OFFICIAL WILL LEAD PANEL ON SENTENCING
description: Joseph W. Bellacosa, chief clerk of the State Court of Appeals since 1975, will head New York State's 14-member committee to recommend guidelines for determinate sentencing of criminals, Governor Cuomo has announced.

title: CLOSE RYDER VICTORY FOR U.S.
description: Europe's team of 12 professional golfers, far behind in power and depth of talent, came close to tying or beating the United States in the finale of the Ryder Cup matches today.

title: BRIBERY TRIAL BEGINS FOR OFFICAL IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Lieut. Gov. James C. Green goes on trial here Monday on charges of participating in a bribery and conspiracy scheme involving an undercover Federal agent who posed as a man with underworld connections trying to open a bar.

title: TWO WHITE HOUSE AIDES AFFIRM REAGAN WILL RUN FOR RE-ELECTION
description: Two of President Reagan's top political operatives said today they were sure he would run for re-election in 1984.

title: OPERA: 'BUTTERFLY' CHANGES A SINGER
description: THE tenor Robert Grayson joined the cast of the New York City Opera's production of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' Saturday afternoon, the second performance of the season. Mr. Grayson made a sophisticated Lieutenant Pinkerton.

title: Germans Continue Protests Against Missile Deployment
description: Church organizations held nationwide services and marches for peace today as West Germany's 10-day campaign of mass protest against the planned deployment of new United States missiles in Europe moved into its fourth day.

title: SNIPERS IN BEIRUT KILL A U.S. MARINE AND HIT 3 OTHERS
description: Snipers opened fire on the American Marine contingent in Beirut for the third day in a row, killing one marine and wounding three others, a Marine spokesman said tonight.

title: JOURNALISTS DEBATE GUILD'S ENDORSEMENT
description: The Newspaper Guild's endorsement of Walter F. Mondale's Presidential aspirations has raised anew the issue of whether journalists lose credibility if they and their organizations take partisan political positions.

title: RACE NARROWS TO 2 FOR HORSE OF THE YEAR
description: Who will be the horse of the year? In the wake of the stakes-record victories by Slew o' Gold in the Jockey Club Gold Cup and Devil's Bag in the Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park Saturday, that will depend on how the voters answer another question: What is a horse of the year?

title: TOMBS TO REOPEN WITH A NEW LOOK
description: Nine years after a court closed the Manhattan House of Detention for conditions so bad that they violated the Constitution, the jail - known as the Tombs - is about to reopen.

title: No Headline
description: Lazio, an Italian First Division team, beat the Cosmos today, 3-1, in a farewell exhibition for Giorgio Chinaglia.

title: Autopsy Discloses Drowning Caused Death of Boston Boy
description: A 5-year- old boy whose body was found in a neighbor youth's closet after a two-day search by the police, volunteers and the National Guard died by drowning, an autopsy showed.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Green Bay Packers vs. Washington Redskins , at Green Bay, Wis. These teams have met once previously on Monday night, with the Redskins winning, 10-9, at home in 1977.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIME
description: THE COURTING OF MARCUS DUPREE. By Willie Morris. 452 pages. Doubleday. $15.95.

title: CAROL C. SMITH JR.
description: Vice Adm. Carol C. Smith Jr., commander of the Navy's air forces in the Atlantic, died of a heart attack Friday after jogging.

title: Peter Sawczynec Marries Hilary D. Marsh in Jersey
description: Hilary D. Marsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zane Marsh of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter P. Sawczynec, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Sawczynec of the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The Magic Ends

title: SEAHAWKS UPSET RAIDERS
description: Paul Johns scored on a 75-yard punt return and the Seattle Seahawks took advantage of eight Los Angeles Raider turnovers for several other scores to defeat the Raiders, 38-36, today.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Brazil-Japan Steel Debt
description: Japanese industry sources said today that a joint Brazilian-Japanese steel mill had suspended repayment since last July of export credits supplied by Japan for equipment imports.

title: KEARNEY NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1983
description: International

title: STRUTHERS SCIENTIFIC & INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $36,077. c-After an extraordinary loss of $92,841 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $40,210 for the 9 months. Struthers Scientific & International Corp. is an 80.1 percent-owned subsidiary of Struthers Wells Corp.

title: WESTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,700,000 from a pension plan termination.

title: B.B.D.& O. Is Chosen For HBO Account
description: Home Box Office Inc., it was learned late yesterday, has selected Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as its new ad agency for HBO, which had been at Ted Bates for four years.

title: BARNES TESTIFIES ABOUT 'COUNCIL' OF DRUG DEALERS
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, serving a life term in prison as a major heroin dealer, identified five defendants in a Manhattan trial yesterday as his former associates on a ''council'' of high-level narcotics traffickers.

title: DILLON STEPS DOWN AT MET MUSEUM
description: Douglas Dillon, who guided the Metropolitan Museum of Art through a period of its largest growth and public success, stepped down yesterday after 14 years as chairman of the board.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROCHESTER TELEPHONE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VALID LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $230,000 for the quarter and $412,000 for the 9 months. c-Year ago comparable figures were not available because the company completed its initial public offering on Oct. 4.

title: Biochem Sale Off
description: Biochem International said that it would not be acquired by Medtronic Inc., which held an option to acquire a controlling interest in the manufacturer of blood chemistry monitoring equipment at $17.50 a share.

title: ON COVERING THE MARATHON
description: The black limousine weaved its way comfortably through the traffic on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge last Wednesday, but rain, fog and mist obliterated any picturesque view of Manhattan.

title: COMET FOUND IRREGULARLY SHAPED
description: Radar echoes from the core of the comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock during its close passage by Earth last May imply that the comet has an irregular shape ''more like a cardboard cake box than a uniform sphere,'' it was reported here today.

title: Falcon's Streak Ends
description: Alfred Jenkins of the Atlanta Falcons had gone eight years and 103 games with at least one pass reception in each game, the longest receiving streak among active National Football League players. But that streak ended Sunday in the Falcons' 27-21 loss to the Los Angeles Rams.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shares outstanding are 203,049,000 versus 191,891,000

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I only wish the election were really next Tuesday rather than a year from now.'' - Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada. (A22:3.)

title: EL NINO JUST WON'T GO AWAY
description: A MASSIVE body of warm water that meteorologists say upset worldwide weather last winter is, although diminished, still lying off the coast of South America. Scientists are uncertain what effects it could have on this winter's weather; last winter it destroyed billions of dollars worth of property and took thousands of lives.

title: ARE 16 BITS VALUABLE?
description: THE magical buzzwords ''8-bit'' and ''16-bit'' keep creeping into the conversation of the salesmen in computer stores, much as ''V-8'' and ''straight six'' were once used in automobile showrooms.

title: UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lakers Sign Scott
description: Byron Scott, who was obtained from the San Diego Clippers in a multi-player trade last week, has signed a long-term contract with the Los Angeles Lakers. The Lakers got Scott, a guard, and Swen Nater, a center, in return for two guards, Norm Nixon and Eddie Jordan, and a future draft choice. Terms of the contract were not revealed by the Lakers, but Scott had said earlier that his contract would be for four years and ''about the same'' as that of Steve Stipanovich, which was a $1.2 million deal with Indiana.

title: URGENT CARE CENTERS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-There are no comparable results for the year-ago quarter or 6 months because the company was organized in September 1982.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARARA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $513,000 for prepayment penalty for early payment of debt. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $4,532,000 on the repurchase of mortgage-backed bonds.

title: Japan-U.S. Trade
description: The Japanese Ambassador to the United States today called on his Government to find ways of solving trade friction between the two nations before President Reagan visits Tokyo next month, Foreign Ministry sources said. Ambassador Yoshio Okawara, who returned to Tokyo to prepare for the visit, made the appeal when he met Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, they said. He was quoted as saying United States criticism of trade friction was growing because there was little sign of correcting the imbalance, although the United States had appreciated a series of measures Japan had taken to open its markets.

title: EL PASO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., has appointed Edward N. Patrone executive vice president-corporate development; John H. Kennedy senior vice president and chief financial officer, and Hugh G. Moulton senior vice president-administration and general counsel.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The American Home Finance Corporation, an affiliate of the American Continental Corporation, announced yesterday that it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a $150 million issue of G.N.M.A.-CXL collateralized bonds. Proceeds from the sale will be used to buy Government National Mortgage Association pass-through certificates from the American Continental Mortgage Company, the mortgage banking arm of the American Continental Corporation. Stifel, Nicolaus & Company and Continental American Securities Inc. were named as exclusive underwriters for the securities.

title: VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,126,000 in settlement payments from Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing.

title: FROSTY FREEZE AND KID SMOOTH BREAK FOR FAME AT ROXY DISCO
description: It is Friday night at the Roxy Disco, a hot and crowded pantheon of hip-hop music and dance. The line at the front door snakes its way down West 18th Street toward the river. In the glass- enclosed V.I.P. lounge, some in the crowd keep cool sipping drinks. Below, on a vast wooden floor, amid the dancing masses, only Frosty Freeze seems in a melancholy mood.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Rises by 5.18; Volume Picks Up
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in more active trading with some of the transportation issues posting the largest gains.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Companions in Misery
description: Subway delays are common now while trains are diverted and slowed to accommodate crews making repairs that have been put off for years. The delays frustrate riders, especially when routes are changed abruptly and trains stalled for minutes that sometimes stretch longer than an hour.

title: Capitol Air Recruits Air Florida Executives
description: The new owners of Capitol Air, a financially struggling airline, have recruited a new management team from Air Florida.

title: Officer Badly Hurt In Park Robbery
description: An off-duty police officer, wearing civilian clothes, was severely beaten and robbed early yesterday in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company began operations in November 1982.

title: Double Coverage Is Frustrating Jets
description: Keeping a straight face, Richard Todd explained as follows today what his five interceptions on Sunday had in common:

title: Funding Raising in Reverse
description: Washington traditionally exports politicians to New York in search of contributions.

title: XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOWARD BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FETAL DEFECTS DISCOVERED EARLY BY NEW METHOD
description: DETECTION of many fetal defects as early as the 10th week of pregnancy may soon become practicle because of a new technique that some experts expect to replace most uses of amniocentesis, currently the standard test for such conditions, within the next several years.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
READING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $12,830,000 from the recapitalization of an affiliate. c-Net loss after extraordinary credits of $31,000 for the quarter and $283,000 for the 9 months, and losses from discontinued operations of $227,000 for the quarter and $333,000 for the 9 months.

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Music/Noted in Brief; Flute and Guitar Duo At Goodman House
description: Janet Ketchum and Peter Segal, who together make up the flute and guitar duo of Ketchum and Segal, are both gifted and sensitive artists. But spending two hours at their Sunday afternoon concert at the Abraham Goodman House was a little like trying to make a substantial meal out of nothing but airy desserts.

title: Top Official Quits Church's Position
description: Roger A. Harvin, chairman and president of Church's Fried Chicken Inc., has elected to take early retirment and has resigned as an officer and director, the company announced yesterday.

title: Toshiba Shares
description: The General Electric Company has sold 60 million shares in the Toshiba Corporation to undisclosed Japanese companies, mostly insurance concerns and banks, Toshiba said. The selling price was not disclosed. G.E. would remain Toshiba's biggest shareholder, with 6 percent of Toshiba's total issued capital now, compared with 8.3 percent at the end of last March.

title: Arg"uello Makes Offer
description: Alexis Arg"uello offered to join the guerrillas fighting to overthrow the leftist Sandinista Government in his native Nicaragua, but was told he could help in other ways, a rebel leader says. Eden Pastora, the former Sandinista leader who is now fighting the regime, was quoted in The Miami Herald yesterday as saying that Arg"uello, his manager and a Miami journalist, Tomas Regalado, slipped into southern Nicaragua, a rebel stronghold, last week.

title: DEBREU RECOGNIZED FOR PURE RESEARCH
description: When Gerard Debreu strolls with close friends and colleagues through a wildlife preserve above the shore of the Pacific Ocean north of San Francisco, the conversation often weaves through the work of Marcel Proust and the music of Saint-Saens.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: The creative heart of French fashion is still beating here. Forget that the French papers declared the Japanese designers the victors of the shows that have been held thus far at the Louvre, and that French fashion editors and American buyers found many of the major designers here uninspiring. There was still praise for the smaller, middle-of-the-road houses that specialize in medium- priced coats and suits that are normally sold in junior departments in the United States.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shares outstanding for the latest quarter are 176,233,000 versus 165,114,000 for year-earlier period.

title: Addendum
description: * Newsweek magazine increasing its advertising rates 5.5 percent, starting with the Jan. 2 issue.

title: HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Magazine Conference Opens
description: Controversy marked the opening here today of the 64th annual American Magazine Conference. While it did not interrupt a single golf game, tennis match or briny dip, it did extend beyond the luxurious precincts of the Southampton Princess Hotel and into the local press.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are the gliding and landing capabilities of a commercial jet airliner that has lost all engines, compared with a small two- or four-passenger aircraft?

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income.

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jersey Calls Halt To Disability Cuts
description: Governor Kean has imposed a moratorium on the case review process that has cut off Social Security disability benefits to thousands of New Jersey residents.

title: PICKENS GROUP GETS GULF STAKE
description: The long-expected battle to revamp the giant Gulf Oil Corporation of Pittsburgh erupted yesterday with the disclosure by T. Boone Pickens Jr., the Texas oilman, that a multimillionaire group he headed had spent $630 million for 8.75 percent of Gulf's stock and was committed to raising its purchases to $1.1 billion - a stake of nearly 15 percent.

title: TV: QUEST IN THE ORIENT WITH GEORGE C. SCOTT
description: IF the prospect of having Ali MacGraw perform as a Chinese translator for George C. Scott amuses you, turn to a made-for-television movie called ''China Rose'' on Channel 2 at 9 tonight. Mr. Scott plays a recently widowed American businessman, Burton Allen, visiting China and Hong Kong in search of his son, who disappeared in the area 16 years ago.

title: Fights Bring N.B.A. Inquiry
description: The National Basketball Association is investigating violence that led to the ejection of three players Sunday night in the Celtics' 99-86 exhibition victory over the Philadelphia 76ers at Boston Garden.

title: Celanese Back To Profitability
description: The Celanese Corporation yesterday reported third-quarter earnings of $33 million, or $2.03 a share, in contrast to an $18 million loss a year before. Sales grew 13.6 percent, to $811 million, from $714 million.

title: SCIENCE NOBELS' DO THEY ALWAYS GO TO THE BEST?
description: THE three Nobel Prizes in science and medicine have long been the most prestigious of awards. Each year scientists throughout the world compete desperately for them; universities scramble to hire the winners; nations routinely count them up as measures of scientific prowess, and the Nobel laureates become instant celebrities whose advice is sought on everything from research to war and peace.

title: Giants Place Reece On the Waiver List;  Club Agrees To Request
description: The Giants placed Beasley Reece on waivers today, acceding to a request by the veteran player, who had lost his starting position at free safety to the rookie Terry Kinard. ''We let him go because he asked to be let go,'' said Bill Parcells, the head coach.

title: No. 30 for Bass
description: Randy Bass, formerly with the Texas Rangers, hit two home runs, lifting the Hanshin Tigers to a 7-0 Japanese League victory over the Hiroshima Toyo Carp tonight. Bass has 33 homers for the season.

title: PEERLESS TUBE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings were adjusted.

title: THOSE COLLEGIAL BONDS WITH SCHOOLTEACHERS
description: COLLEGE professors are coming to the aid of the public schools. University faculty members are climbing down from their ivory towers to establish collegial bonds with schoolteachers. The college-school connection many experts consider crucial to school reform is turning into a movement. The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching has reported the movement's growth but has asked for more action.

title: Boat Explodes in Harbor
description: A 26-foot cabin cruiser, believed stolen from her Staten Island berth, exploded and burned to the waterline in Lower New York Bay last night. It was not known whether anyone was aboard when the boat ignited shortly after 8 P.M. The Coast Guard said that the owner had been unaware the boat was missing. She erupted into a ball of flame a half mile off Coney Island and the blaze was seen by many people on Staten Island and in Brooklyn.

title: Stage Fright Workshop
description: The pianist Richard Goode will be the guest speaker at a workshop on stage fright, Oct. 31 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the quarter and $259,000 for the 9 months.

title: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $929,000, or 9 cents a share, from an exchange of property.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected March 14, 1983.

title: Columbia Gas Sells Affiliate
description: Columbia Gas System Inc. said it had accepted an offer to sell its West Virginia natural gas distribution affiliate for about $60 million to the Allegheny and Western Energy Corporation.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 17, 1983.

title: Nets Set Back 76ers by 112-105
description: Darryl Dawkins scored a game-high 24 points to lead the New Jersey Nets to a 112-105 preseason victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: DANCE: BETH SOLL PRESENTS 'PARADISE'
description: MIDWAY through Beth Soll's ''Dances of Paradise and Everyday Life,'' the members of Beth Soll and Company sang a song by Dave Stringham with words taken from the biblical book of Ecclesiastes. On the one hand, the lyrics urged, ''Drink wine with a merry heart.'' But on the other hand, they warned, ''In the house of mirth resides the heart of fools.''

title: Eagle Computer
description: Eagle Computer Inc. introduced a hard disk portable computer, the Eagle Spirit XL, as part of its line of desktop microcomputer products. The 16-bit model,which is compatible with the I.B.M. PC XT,will retail for $4,795 and will be available this month.

title: Charlotte Curtis Love Affair With the City
description: AFTER several years of thinking about it, 46-year-old Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the high-powered Boston real estate tycoon who swooped in to save The Atlantic magazine from extinction, has finally moved to New York. As a commuter, he established himself as a lunch-time regular at the Four Seasons and the magazine's scout on the literary circuit. He became the sort of extra man knowing hostesses kept at the top of their A-lists. Yet there was a lot more to his move than that.

title: Coleco's Adam To Be Shipped
description: Coleco Industries said it would probably begin shipping its Adam home computer Tuesday.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEMORIES FROM WITHIN THE EGG
description: ANNE BEKOFF, a biologist at the University of Colorado, may not be ready to tackle the old conundrum - which came first, the chicken or the egg? - but she has come up with revealing observations about the development of coordinated movement in chick embryos that enable them to kick and peck their way out of their shell. She discovered that a newly hatched chick, if stuffed back into an egg- shaped container, remembers how to repeat its escape act.

title: BUCYRUS-ERIE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net charge of $80 million from consolidations of certain operations and writedown of an investment. c-Net income.

title: Costly Oversight
description: Because an ineligible defensive back played in the games, the University of Puget Sound has decided to forfeit three football victories and then appeal the penalty. Officials said that Mike Moore, a substitute back, unwittingly violated a residency rule by transferring to a community college and then back to Puget Sound. Puget Sound officials said they were not aware of a 16-week residency requirement by the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics when Moore switched there from the jurisdiction of the N.C.A.A.

title: 4 ATTACKS WERE IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A 23-year-old man whom the police described as a drifter was arrested last night and charged with two recent rapes in Riverside Park. The police also believe the suspect is the same man who raped four women in Central Park last summer.

title: AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
At an Impasse
description: Ricky Davis and the Cosmos have reached an impasse in their contract negotiations and, according to Davis's agent, the 24-year-old midfielder may sign this week with a Major Indoor Soccer League club. ''Right now it looks like Rick will be leaving the Cosmos,'' said the agent, George Kalafatis of the International Management Group.

title: 12.63% Avco Note
description: Avco Financial Services Inc.'s $75 million of 12 1/2 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1993 are being offered at 99 1/4 to yield 12.63 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes were rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Ex-Im Bank Reduces Rates
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that it had reduced interest rates on medium- and long-term loans that finance American exports.

title: HOAXER STAYED IN MANHATTAN HOMES AS 'STUDENT'
description: By convincing at least four New York couples recently that he was a friend of one of their children, a young man who said he was both a Harvard student and the son of the actor Sidney Poitier gained entrance to their homes, dined with them, borrowed money, stayed overnight and walked out.

title: CONTINENTAL TELECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A GOLDEN-THROATED MET OPERA GALA
description: With any luck, the Metropolitan Opera's Centennial Gala this Saturday will behave like one of those big people on the dance floor who amaze everyone for their lightness of foot. The celebration will be huge - with big arias, duets, trios, big audiences, big stars, big egos - all of which are going to have to maneuver delicately within one opera house and a finite amount of time.

title: F.B.I. Expands Sports Program
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has expanded to the National Football League a program designed to make professional athletes aware of the threats of bribery, wagering on sports contests and illegal drug transactions.

title: WEST GERMAN TAKES FIRST IN THE KAVKASIAN TOURNEY
description: Eric Lobron's 9 1/2-4 1/2 score held up to gain him the $1,800 first prize in the Kavkasian International Tournament in New York. The 23-year-old West German grandmaster had finished his play ahead of schedule so he could take part in another event, and no one succeeded in overtaking him.

title: USE OF CAPACITY UTILIZATION TO 78.1% IN SEPTEMBER
description: American industry operated at 78.1 percent of production capacity last month, an increase of a percentage point from August's level, the Government reported today.

title: INCUMBENCY IS THE BASIS OF O'ROURKE CAMPAIGN
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, was at a candidates forum sponsored by the Ludlow Park Homeowners Association in Yonkers one night last week, waiting for the four mayoral aspirants to finish.

title: Bridge: Victory in Stockholm Brings Double Title in a Single Year
description: It is now a century and a half since Alexandre Deschapelles of France was simultaneously the leading figure in whist and chess. Whist has become bridge, and vastly more competitive, while chess at the top level has become a game for full-time professionals. The Deschapelles double is therefore inconceivable today, but a similar double has been achieved in the last few months.

title: IC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and $1.7 million for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $8.6 million for the quarter and $12.6 million for the 9 months.

title: ADAMS-MILLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $33,000 for the quarter and $92,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,377,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CBS SEEKS RECORD COMPANIES
description: CBS is actively seeking to acquire ''one or more major record companies,'' the company announced yesterday.

title: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED TECHNOLOGIES REPORTS 6.9% INCREASE
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter rose 6.9 percent, to $121 million, reflecting strength in its helicopter and air- conditioning businesses.

title: KILEY THINKS M.T.A. NEEDS $10 BILLION IN NEW REBUILDING
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will need $10 billion more than it is now spending to rebuild the subways and renovate commuter rail lines, the chairman-designate of the M.T.A. said yesterday.

title: Export Curbs Are Extended
description: Declaring that a national economic emergency exists, President Reagan signed an executive order last week that indefinitely extends export controls and other provisions of the Export Administration Act.

title: 2 Chinese Films of 1937 To Be Seen at Collective
description: ''Street Angel'' and ''Crossroads,'' two Chinese films made in Shanghai in 1937 just before the Japanese occupation, will be shown for the first time in New York City on Oct. 25 at 8 P.M. at the Collective, at 52 White Street.

title: LOCKHEED CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shipping Bill Cleared By House
description: The House of Representatives approved by unanimous voice vote today a bill that would grant American shipping companies broader immunity from United States antitrust laws as a means of competing more effectively with foreign shipping.

title: Market Place; Bank Stocks And Bad Loans
description: ONE reason bank stocks typically sell at lower price/earnings multiples than the average equity is the potential exposure of bank portfolios to bad loans and the burden of ''nonperforming assets.'' As a rule, bank stocks now trade at slightly under 8 times their trailing 12-month earnings, compared with a multiple of just below 12 for the average stock. Loan-loss problems at several Texas banks underscore this fact.

title: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 18, 1983
description: Companies

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Operating earnings. c-Net income and includes a tax credit. d-After a tax credit.

title: Query of the Times
description: Amother was overheard greeting her teen-age daughter at a recent East Side community meeting: ''Did you remember to turn off the computer?''

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
The Power That Wasn't
description: The trailers at the foot of West Street that serve as Battery Park City Authority headquarters were without electricity or telephone service yesterday.

title: Jerome Hickey
description: The Northern Trust Corporation said it had signed an agreement to purchase all of the outstanding shares of stock in Jerome Hickey Associates Inc., a discount brokerage house based in Chicago. After regulatory approval, Jerome Hickey will become a subsidiary of Northern Trust, which runs the Northern Trust Company bank in Chicago. Northern Trust said it was the first Chicago bank holding company to purchase an established discount brokerage rather than create a new one.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHITTENDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $424,000 for the quarter and $1,152,000 for the 9 months.

title: AMERICAN INCOME LIFE & INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rush to Victory
description: On Sunday, the Seattle Seahawks scored 38 points in upsetting the Los Angeles Raiders, 38-36, and passing had nothing to do with any of the Seattle points. Jim Zorn attempted 16 passes and completed only four for 13 net yards gained.

title: RIBI IMMUNOCHEM RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EL PASO NATURAL GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: El Paso Natural Gas is a subsidiary of El Paso Co.

title: BLUE PLEADS GUILTY TO COCAINE CHARGE
description: Vida Blue, one of baseball's most successful pitchers of the 1970's, pleaded guilty today to a Federal misdemeanor charge of possessing three grams, about a tenth of an ounce, of cocaine. A short time later, he appeared before a Federal grand jury hearing evidence in a six-month-old narcotics investigation here.

title: MOBOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORPAC EXPLORATION SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.
