description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $27.8 million for the quarter and $33.6 million for the 9 months. Year-ago 9 months results reflect a gain equal to about 11 cents a share from the retirement of debt.

title: President Is Appointed At Burgess & Leith Inc.
description: James M. Oates, a 37-year-old bank president in St. Louis, has been named president and chief operating officer of Burgess & Leith Inc., a New England investment bank bent on expansion.

title: TRANSAMERICA INCOME SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
10.6% AMERICAN EXPRESS RISE
description: The American Express Company, despite a slump in its insurance business, reported yesterday that net income rose 10.6 percent in the third quarter, to $180.2 million.

title: AMERICAN CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRABENDER'S LAW WORKS AGAIN
description: This was the year when Koppett's Law did not hold up but Brabender's Law worked out to stinging perfection in the postseason frolics known as the league championships and the World Series. And because Brabender's Law held up, a lot of people are visiting the dry cleaners this week. Does champagne come out of a knit tie?

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LANDMARK BANKING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $133,599. The year-earlier quarter and 9 months per share earnings were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 4.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMSOUTH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Regan Charges 'Risks' in Prisons
description: Some prisoners have been assigned to less secure New York State prisons than their records warrant, posing ''unnecessary safety risks'' to fellow inmates and the public, State Comptroller Edward Regan said today.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.C.A.A. Plea in High Court; Controling TV Football At Stake
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the National Collegiate Athletic Association's appeal from a lower court ruling that its exclusive control over the televising of college football games violates Federal antitrust law.

title: Yields Off on Treasury Issues
description: Interest rates for Treasury bills fell by a tenth of a percentage point or more yesterday, while other short- and long-term rates were unchanged to barely lower.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,671,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Bank in Texas Is Open Again
description: A major west Texas bank reopened its doors today after losses on energy loans caused it to fail. The First National Bank of Midland reopened as Republicbank First National Midland.

title: U.S. AGRICULTURAL SHOW OPENS IN MOSCOW PARK
description: An exhibition of American agricultural and food- processing equipment, the first American trade show in the Soviet Union since 1977, opened in a Moscow park today with 105 companies displaying everything from giant combines to fast blini makers.

title: SOUTHERN BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEMORIES FOR JAVITS AS ARCHIVE IS DEDICATED
description: As his health has worsened, he has been toasted and feted so many times. But this one, the official dedication of his own archive, meant more than all the rest to former Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: CITY OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'CARMEN'
description: THE New York City Opera is currently offering performances of Bizet's ''Carmen,'' and Saturday night there were some major changes in the cast.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains of $810,000 for the quarter and $947,000 for the 9 months from the repurchase of debentures. c-Including a gain of $223,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: U.S.F.L. Eyes 8 Players
description: Howard Slusher, the player agent, says he is discussing with officials of the United States Football League a possible plan to bring eight National Football League players into the new league.

title: Nissan View on Quota
description: Takashi Ishihara, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said today that Japan should not agree to limit its auto exports to the United States next year until it received assurance that the curbs would be removed in 1985. The two countries are expected to agree on increasing the Japanese auto export quota to more than 2 million units from 1.68 million, according to some governmental sources.

title: TYLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a provision of $737,000 for possible losses and an extraordinary credit of $1,277,000 attributable to the forgiveness of the remaining obligations to lending banks, less related expenses.

title: DANCING ON ICE TOGETHER, AS ONE
description: Unheated rinks, hot coffee in paper cups and stifled yawns are as common to stories about figure skaters as lightning and thunder are to horror films and pea-soup fog to spy novels. Long before the house lights are dimmed and the performers glide across the ice wearing glittering outfits and toothpaste smiles, there are all those mornings that must be spent practicing, mornings like the one Michael Seibert and Judy Blumberg spent yesterday at Ice World in Totowa, N.J.

title: Knight-Ridder
description: The Federal Communications Commission has granted Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. permission to purchase a 50 percent interest in a specialized mobile radio service system in Miami, part of a broad diversification effort by the newspaper holding company.

title: FIRST CHICAGO UP 50.2%
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that third-quarter net income declined 11.5 percent from the same period a year ago. The company said that the decline in earnings from levels a year earlier was primarily attributable to a lower level of nonfee-based income and higher operating expenses.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $8,400,000 from the sale of securities.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rhode Island Industry Plan
description: A state panel today urged a $750 million cooperative effort by business, labor, government and academia to create 60,000 new jobs by 1990.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings figures represent earnings per sub-share.

title: Seafirst Predicts Loss
description: The Seafirst Corporation, which has lost $291 million already this year, will report another large loss for the third quarter, its chairman, Richard P. Cooley, predicted today. Exact figures are to be released later this week, but Mr. Cooley said the loss, although significant, would be less than the $158 million loss reported in the second quarter. He said the bank holding corporation, parent company of Seattle-First National Bank, could return to profitability next year.

title: Business and the Law; Unitary Tax Scope Widens
description: AS states find themselves increasingly hard- pressed for revenues, more and more are converting to the so-called unitary worldwide method of figuring corporate income taxes.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Rose 8% in September
description: One indication that things are looking up in the magazine business is that the Publishers Information Bureau now lists ad pages before ad revenues without embarrassment in its monthly advertising report.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dollar General
description: The Dollar General Corporation said it had agreed to buy about 275 retail stores in 11 Middle Western and Southern states from Interco Inc., a St. Louis-based merchandiser.

title: Output in Italy Drops
description: Italian industrial output, seasonally adjusted, fell by 8.7 percent in August after rising by six-tenths of 1 percent in July, according to Government figures released today.

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $126,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss.

title: GEORGE LIBERACE, 71, VIOLINIST
description: George Liberace, a bandleader and violinist who for years was the silent straight man for his flamboyant piano- playing younger brother, Liberace, died at his home here Sunday. He was 71 years old and his death was attributed to heart disease complicated by leukemia.

title: Galaxy Oil Debt
description: The Galaxy Oil Company of Wichita Falls, Tex., said it had amended its agreements with its bank lenders, restructuring some $31 million in loans, and that it was no longer under default on the debt. Under the agreement, the company's existing $31 million debt to the banks was restructured into three credits, and a new $3.5 million line of credit was made available. A minimum of $3 million in additional funds was made available for development drilling on the San Pedro Ranch, which is Galaxy's principal oil and gas property in southwest Texas.

title: John Carter Quintet In Carnegie Jazz Series
description: The clarinetist John Carter's music for quintet aimed for the clarity and structural variety of chamber music in a concert Saturday as part of Carnegie Recital Hall's jazz series.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Heinsohn is following Bill Russell as the lead television analyst for CBS Sports in its coverage of National Basketball Association games. . . . Steve Yeager, the Dodgers' veteran catcher, has signed a two-year contract with the club.

title: Jacob Lateiner, Pianist, With Musica Aeterna
description: Jacob Lateiner's performances of two Mozart piano concertos were curiously unsatisfying at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday night. Playing with the Musica Aeterna Orchestra, led by Frederic Waldman, the Cuban-born pianist seemed uncomfortable, losing his place several times, remaining on the surface of the keys, even allowing tempos to drift.

title: INTEGRATED SOFTWARE SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUBLICITY MAN NAMED TO HEAD ADIRONDACK AGENCY
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday announced the appointment of a former minister and public-relations director for a ski resort to head the Adirondack Park Agency.

title: Dolphin End Strikes Twice
description: In football regalia, from the bottom of his cleats to the tip of his helmet, Doug Betters measures 7 feet. And when he is waving those huge arms - well, the sky's the limit.

title: Jacob Scholer Is Dead at 96; Helped to Found a Law Firm
description: Jacob Scholer, a founding partner of the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96 years old.

title: RAMYMOND ARON, FRENCH POLITICAL THINKER, IS DEAD
description: Raymond Aron, France's leading conservative political thinker, collapsed and died of a heart attack here today at the age of 78.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Frederick Peterson, 80; Was U.S. Ambassador
description: Frederick Valdemar (Val) Peterson, a former Governor of Nebraska and Ambassador to Denmark and Finland, died Sunday at Memorial Hospital of Dodge County. He was 80 years old.

title: A Bright Future
description: ''I've really enjoyed watching Mike Boddicker pitching in the playoffs and in the World Series,'' said Al Ashmont, a senior at Union Catholic High School in Scotch Plains, N.J., last week. ''For a rookie, he's showed he can handle pressure real well.''

title: 2 Officers Restored In AIDS Incident
description: Two police officers suspended after refusing to transport prisoners they thought had been exposed to AIDS were reinstated today.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are restated to give effect to a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: PACKERS TO REDSKINS, 48-47
description: Jan Stenerud kicked a 20-yard field goal with 54 seconds to play tonight to give the Green Bay Packers a 48-47 victory over the Washington Redskins.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1982 per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend effective May 3, 1983.

title: S. & P. Says Harris Bid Hurt Debt Ratings
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, the rating agency, says in the latest issue of its Creditweek publication that the proposed acquisition of Harris Bancorp Inc. by the Bank of Montreal has negative implications for the long-term debt ratings of both companies. The Montreal bank recently reached an agreement to buy the Chicago-based Harris in a transaction valued at $547 million.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect a $4,265,000 writedown of certain assets. Results are for 13 and 39 weeks for the latest periods and 16 and 40 weeks for the year-ago periods.

title: JANE FONDA CHIDES THE WHITE HOUSE
description: JANE FONDA, the actress and political activist, said yesterday that she felt the White House and the space agency had overreacted in their criticism of her presence as an honored guest at a space shuttle launching last June. She said the space program is ''for everyone'' and should be bipartisan.

title: MANVILLE'S FILING IS DELAYED FOR 10 DAYS
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland, saying that the filing of a reorganization plan now would be considered ''hostile,'' yesterday gave the Manville Corporation 10 more days to try to agree with creditors on how the company should handle its millions of dollars of debt and thousands of asbestos-related legal claims.

title: ISLANDER DEFENSE NOT YET CONSISTENT
description: The Islanders showed two faces over the weekend. They displayed their worst defensive capabilities and their best tight-checking skills.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $7,885,000. Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change.

title: Pfizer Net Up 51.7%
description: Pfizer Inc. yesterday reported net income of $110.1 million, or 68 cents a share, up 51.7 percent over the third quarter last year, when earnings totaled $72.6 million, or 45 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter rose 2.8 percent, to $945.8 million, from $920.2 million a year earlier.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMONWEALTH FEDL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no comparable per share figures because the company went public in April. c-After tax credits of $459,000 for the quarter and $1,126,000 for the 6 months. Operating income in both the second quarter and 6 months of 1983 includes a nonrecurring gain of $643,000 from the sale of mortgage-backed certificates acquired as a result of a merger.

title: Investors Buy Condec StakeStates News Service
description: Three investors have acquired 9 percent of the common stock of the Condec Corporation with the possibility of gaining control of the Greenwich, Conn., heavy machinery manufacturer. The investors, Farley Metals Inc. of Chicago; William F. Farley, director and president of Farley Metals Inc., and the Farley Metals Inc. Employee Benefit Master Trust, were earlier rejected in an attempt to seek a leveraged buyout of Condec.

title: Drop in Rating Concerns ABC
description: Lower prime-time television ratings this year for ''Monday Night Football'' and baseball's postseason league championship games and World Series are causing concern at the network level.

title: KELSO DIES OF COLIC AT 26
description: Kelso, having heard the cheers of the race track one final time last Saturday afternoon, died of colic Sunday night at Woodstock Farm in Chesapeake City, Md. The popular thoroughbred gelding was 26 years old.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW ENTRIES IN A COOKIE RACE
description: A multimillion- dollar introduction of new products by three of the nation's biggest marketing guns, the Procter & Gamble Company, Nabisco Brands and Frito- Lay Inc., is trying to stir up the stagnant grocery store cookie market.

title: Brooklyn Children Find Box of Skulls
description: A carton containing seven skulls and various bones was found yesterday by children rummaging in a vacant lot in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

description: Asset figures are net assets.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTION
description: Because of a printing error, part of a column on page C6 in SportsMonday yesterday about Coach Don Shula was obliterated. Any reader wishing a corrected copy may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: CITY SCHOOL TOUGHENS CURRICULUM
description: IT is one thing for Harvard or

title: Advertising; People
description: * Robert H. Schirmer named executive vice president and elected to the board of the Campbell-Ewald Co., Warren, Mich.

title: Toyota Sports Car
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation will display a new luxury sports car later this month at the Tokyo Motor Show and could start selling the mid-engine auto next year, a report from Japan said.

title: Court to Rule on Pension Retroactivity
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Congress had the right to impose retroactive liability on companies that withdrew from pension plans in 1980 in expectation of stiffened Federal pension regulations.

title: MUSIC: THE AMERICAN BEGINS ITS 21ST SEASON
description: THE American Symphony Orchestra, which began its 21st season Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, is somewhat out of the ordinary as far as most major American orchestras are concerned. Its distinction, though, is less musical than organizational. It is a freelance orchestra with what it calls a ''unique form of participatory government'' - the musicians work with the board of trustees and the staff in running the orchestra and in hiring its music director. This cooperative arrangement would presumably lead to amiable music making, and last year the orchestra named Moshe Atzmon a principal conductor of the orchestra along with Giuseppe Patane.

title: Sharks and Cancer
description: Shark fin soup aside, sharks have been variously described as the total eating machine; as one big tooth (their skin has the same composition as their teeth); as the waste disposal units of the sea, and as generally unsavory. But research by Anne Lee and Robert Langer of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge and Children's Hospital and Medical Center in Boston may make this sea-creature desirable for medical reasons. An extract derived from shark fin cartilage contains a substance that inhibits the growth of new blood vessels. By inhibiting vascularization of a tumor, the extract could slow or prevent the growth of cancerous material.

title: ANTA NATIONAL THEATER AT KENNEDY

title: IN PARIS, NEW FASHIONS REFLECT OPPOSITE MOODS
description: At 2 A.M. Sunday, the Champs-Elysees was one long black limousine inching its way from the Arc de Triomphe to the Place de la Concorde. Groups of young men in leather jackets stood on street corners. Young women in tight skirts looked for taxis. Romantic couples walked head to shoulder. It did not matter that it was raining or that the leaves on the sidewalk were being blown into little tornadoes. Paris was awake. It was going to have a good time. And nothing - not the weather, the Government, the rate of exchange, the taxes, and certainly not the triumph of the Japanese at the current spring fashion shows - was going to stop it.

title: MIXING MEMOIRS WITH LORE OF COOKING
description: ''TELL me what you eat and I will tell you what you are.'' Brillat-Savarin's aphorism recognizes the menu as anthropology, cultural history and biography. Some new cookbooks also take this approach. How certain foods, styles of cooking and habits of dining evolve is a subject for scholars in two of the books, and in two others, on a highly personal level, it is the stuff of memoirs. These books are enjoyable to read and interesting, if not always easy to use in the kitchen. ''Irish Traditional Food'' by Theodora Fitzgibbon (St. Martin's Press, $14.95) is a well-researched volume that examines the origins and traditions of Irish cooking with

title: ASSASSIN RE-ENACTS HIS STEPS BEFORE '81 SHOOTING OF POPE ROME, Oct. 18 (AP) - Mehmet Ali Agca re-enacted for Bulgarian prosecutors today his movements before he shot and wounded Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981.
description: The reconstruction was directed by an Italian judge, Ilario Martella, who has been investigating Mr. Agca and a Bulgarian, Sergei Ivanov Antontov, who is charged with complicity in the shooting.

title: RETURN OF THE BUDGET-BUSTER MOVIE

GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: FILMS ON WOMEN Samuel Goldwyn, the giant independent Hollywood producer, contended that he had no use for socially conscious movies. He is supposed to have declared: ''If you want to deliver a message, call Western Union.'' Catalyst, a national organization working for women's ''full participation in business and professions,'' takes a different view. On Wednesdays through Nov. 16 the organization is sponsoring: ''Women's Achievements: A Catalyst Film Festival'' and all the films have messages.

title: JET AND GIANT PROBLEMS
description: With the season nearly half over, both the Jets and the Giants are nearly half-buried. To qualify for the playoffs as a wild card, the Jets, with a 3-4 record, must jump over four teams in the American Conference; the Giants, at 2-5, must leap over five in the National Conference. That's not impossible, but, unless each team suddenly produces an extended winning streak, it is improbable.

Mark Moseley of the Redskins missed a 39-yard field-goal attempt with 3 seconds remaining, and the Packers won, 48-47.

title: FEW GO TO STUDY INTELLIGENCE REPORTS

title: THREAT TO PERSIAN GULF: THE CHOICES FOR IRAN
description: Tension has reportedly increased in the Persian Gulf region after a warning from the United States against any Iranian move to close the gulf and reports from Britain and Turkey that five French Super Etendard fighters have arrived in Iraq. The planes, which were falsely rumored to have arrived last week, are now reported to be stationed at an air base in northern Iraq. They were said to have been refueled in the air after Turkey refused to allow them to land for refueling.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1983 International
description: Sniper attacks on American marines in Beirut over the last four days have underscored how exposed they and the Beirut International Airport are to hostile fire. Two marines were killed by the sniper fire. Near the airport early yesterday there was a shootout between Lebanese Government forces and unidentified gunmen in which four people were reported killed. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) The Marines may be taking on an additional security role tomorrow. The Lebanese Government announced that the long-delayed national reconciliation conference of Christian and Moslem leaders would open then at the Beirut International Airport. But whether the meeting will take place on schedule, if at all, remained in doubt. No sooner had the Beirut radio announced that the airport had been chosen as the conference site than it was rejected by an aide to the Druse leader. (A7:1.)

title: PHONE FEE CHANGES DELAYED TILL APRIL 3 FOR STUDY BY F.C.C.

Hollings, one of seven candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, called yesterday for the United States to start importing from Latin America some of the things it now buys from the Far East. title: WINE TALK
description: YOU will recall that Mayor Koch blacked out briefly in an East Side restaurant the Sunday before last after some rather pricey wines and what he described as a particularly heavy meal. The medical implications are slight: the Mayor returned to full power in a matter of minutes. It's the political side that is interesting. What does it mean for a tight-budget city when the Mayor drinks elegant wine? Does it signal a general upturn?

title: No Headline
description: What New York Now Owes Itself With no resources except New York City's tax revenues and New York State's credibility, Big Mac, headed by Felix Rohatyn, was able in seven short years to allay the suspicions of investors. Gingerly at first, but later with enthusiasm, they came to agree that though bankrupt, New York City was not necessarily poor. Indeed, the bond market now judges the city to be independently wealthy, capable of selling its bonds without the M.A.C. Mr. Rohatyn should therefore recommend, in his new term, what ought to be done with his magic instrument.

SKIER LOOKS AHEAD IN COMEBACK YEAR
description: Most of the men and women who spend their youth hurtling down the sides of snow- packed mountains on a pair of thin flat boards are resigned to the fact that the time will come when they will be fitted for a plaster-of-paris cast and have various parts of their bodies held together with items that can be purchased in a hardware store. For instance, there is a screw holding her ankle together, Christin Cooper said matter-of-factly about a broken ankle she suffered earlier in her skiing career. As for her most recent injury, which sidelined her at a time when she was reaching her own summit as an Alpine skier, Miss Cooper brushed off any talk of disappointment like so many flakes of snow.

description: Washington will not allow Syria, ''aided and abetted by 7,000 Soviet advisers and technicians,'' to destroy the chances for stability in Lebanon, President Reagan said. The President declined to say what actions might be taken if the Iranians closed the key waterway at the mouth of the Persian Gulf. (Page A1, Column 6.) title: FILM: SAURA'S FLAMENCO 'CARMEN'
description: AS saucy, wanton, inexhaustible femme fatales go, Carmen, the Spanish gypsy who first appeared in Prosper Merimee's 1845 novel, must be one of the most popular and long-lived. Principally responsible, I suppose, is the continuing popularity of Bizet's 1874 opera. That ''Carmen'' goes on and on and on, whether conventionally performed, as it's done in most of the world's opera houses, or whether ''adapted,'' as in Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Carmen Jones'' and in Peter Brooks's production ''Carmen,'' which will open shortly in the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1983
description: Companies A.T.& T. plans to charge off $5.2 billion against 1983 earnings as part of its transformation from protected monopoly to competitive enterprise. It would be the largest such charge-off in corporate history. The move could make A.T.& .T. a more attractive investment, experts said, because it would be earning the same amount of money on what will appear to be a smaller asset base. (Page A1.) The F.C.C. said tariff charges proposed by A.T.& T. could lead to significant increases in long-distance rates for business. (D5.) Two of the nation's 10 largest banks reported sharp declines in earnings after a number of others had posted healthy gains. BankA merica's third-quarter earnings declined 29.1 percent, while those of Continental Illinois fell 38.9 percent. (D1.) American Airlines and Piedmont Aviation reported higher earnings. (D6.) Time Inc.'s net income fell 13.9 percent. (D6.) Earnings rose 34.2 percent for RCA and 71.6 percent for Weyerhaeuser. (D6.)

BRAZIL ANTICIPATES EMERGENCY
description: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo invoked emergency powers tonight to calm a tumultuous debate over his Government's attempt to force down Brazilian wages. The action came on the eve of a scheduled congressional vote on the wage legislation.

title: RERUNS AVAILABLE OF THE MARATHON
description: The burgeoning phenomenon of the New York Marathon, which has attracted 17,000 runners to its 14th annual running Sunday, has reached the point where runners can savor their individual finishes through the wonders of videotape cassettes. A runner, whether he finished in the top 100 or in the middle of the pack, will be able to sit back in midwinter and watch himself struggle across the finish line.

title: A CONSERVATIVE REWPUBLICBANK
description: James D. Berry, the chairman of the Republicbank Corporation, remembers only too well that day early last year. Republic, then the third-largest bank holding company in Texas, by assets, was not getting its share of the boom in energy lending that was still sweeping the nation's oil-producing heartland.

title: POLITICAL ACTIVISM IN TENNESSEE BY A NISSAN SUBSIDIARY IS STOKING CRITICISM
description: The American executives of a Japanese- owned automobile company here have become increasingly involved in local politics, focusing on an issue of overriding concern to both their employer and themselves. On Friday the company is to dedicate a $660 million factory manufacturing pickup trucks that began production in June.

title: Jury Finds 'Evils' In Lottery Deals
description: A state grand jury that indicted Lottery Commissioner Reese Palley last April on charges of falsifying documents relating to a state ethics investigation of his business dealings has found no other evidence of criminal wrongdoing involving the lottery, it was announced today.

title: ISRAELI COALITION DEFEATS OPPOSITION CHALLENGE
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's nine-day-old coalition Government easily defeated three opposition motions of no confidence today on its ability to manage Israel's economy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: -year-old, Oklahoma-born painter now living in New York. He received grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Phillips Petroleum Company. These grants supported him in an endeavor probably never undertaken before in this country. He became an artist-in-residence in two Oklahoma prisons. For three years he went in and out of the penitentiaries and produced paintings reflecting prison life in Conner Correctional Center in Hominy and McAlester Correctional Center, McAlester.

title: U.N. SAYS D'AMATO PUSHED FUGAZY'S BID FOR TRAVEL CONTRACT

LIE TESTS BACKED BY JUSTICE DEPT.
description: A Justice Department official said today that it would be appropriate for Federal agencies to require polygraph, or lie-detector, examinations of ''randomly selected employees'' as a condition of access to certain kinds of sensitive classified information, even if there was no evidence of a breach in security.

title: Japanese Car Spending
description: Major Japanese auto manufacturers are reducing their capital investment this year, reflecting a leveling off of exports and the completion of recent engine developments, company spokesmen said. Those who said they would cut spending included the Nissan Motor Company, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MIDDLE OF MY TETHER: Familiar Essays. By Joseph Epstein. 250pages. W. W. Norton. $14.95. I GOT so much pleasure out of Joseph Epstein's collection of essays, ''The Middle of My Tether,'' that I fell to wondering why such collections are not more popular, why it should be a maxim among publishers that most collections won't sell. It seems to me that form for people who buy ''collectibles,'' who read more magazines than anybody else in the world and who have fallen in love with the boutique. After all, what is a good collection but a boutique of ideas, collectible ideas or a superior kind of magazine?

description: An emboldened magazine editor who condemned the military Government in an editorial last month is the latest casualty of President Augusto Pinochet's uneasy relationship with the press.

title: Sears and MCI In Joint Venture
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it had reached an agreement with Sears, Roebuck & Company to provide 3.5 million Sears credit customers an opportunity to subscribe to MCI's long-distance telephone service.

title: Conrail Climbs 44.3%
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said today that its net income rose by 44.3 percent, to $85.6 million, or $3.21 a share, in the third quarter, from $59.3 million, or $2.34 a share, a year earlier. Revenue declined, however, to $760.2 million, from $860.7 million, because the company, known as Conrail, no longer offers passenger traffic. The company attributed the profit gain to tighter cost controls and an upturn in traffic.

title: MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Losing Syndrome
description: Can the pressure on a college football coach make his wife sick? Jerry Stovall , the Louisiana State coach, isn't sure, but his wife, Judy , has been suffering from a mysterious malady that flares up during L.S.U. losing streaks. If her doctors decide there is a link between her illness and his job, Stovall said, he will quit coaching. He said the illness was characterized by nausea, fainting spells and dizziness.

title: U.S. WILL CREATE HOLIDAY TO MARK DR. KING'S BIRTH
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a bill to create a Federal holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., and President Reagan said he would sign it because of its symbolic importance.

Washington Post Gains
description: The Washington Post Company said today that its net income for the third quarter rose 44.7 percent, to $12.3 million, or 86 cents a share, from $8.5 million, or 60 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 9.3 percent, to $202.9 million, from $185.7 million.

title: CUSTOM ENGRAVERS IN METAL AND GLASS
description: JEWELRY or glass engraved with a name or monogram is always a popular gift. Many department stores and places such as Tiffany and Cartier offer engraving services for in-store purchases. Sometimes, however, you need an inscription done in a hurry (some department stores require up to four weeks, particularly during the holidays) or want to monogram a piece bought from a shop that doesn't have an engraver. For fast service or odd engraving jobs there are a number of independent engravers to turn to.

title: Researchers Reporting U.S.-Haitian AIDS Tie
description: A study of Haitians suspected of suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, reported today that many lived in a Haitian prostitution center and several reported they had had homosexual relations with Americans, providing a ''link'' in the spread of the disease.

McEnroe Sued
description: On the first day of the United States Open last August, John McEnroe was fined $1,000 for throwing sawdust and cursing at a fan. Chris Schneider of Floral Park, L.I., the fan, said he had been cheering for McEnroe's opponent, Trey Waltke , and ''I guess McEnroe found this upsetting.'' On Monday, Mr. Schneider filed a suit against McEnroe in state Supreme Court in Mineola, L.I. John McEnroe Sr., the tennis player's father and attorney, refused to return telephone calls seeking comment. Mr. Schneider teaches social studies at St. Mary's High School in Manhasset and coaches varsity basketball at Sewanhaka in Floral Park.

title: SCIENTISTS ISOLATE GENE LINKED TO TOXIC SHOCK
description: Scientists have isolated the gene for the bacterial poison believed to cause toxic shock syndrome. The accomplishment, they believe, will lead to a test to identify those most susceptible to the dangerous disease and perhaps will make possible a vaccine to protect against it.

title: No Headline
description: No, Again, to Mr. Reagan's War For the United States to underwrite an armed rebellion in Nicaragua offends law, decency and sense. The non-intervention that President Reagan preaches to the Sandinista regime is mocked by his practice. From its inception two years ago, Mr. Reagan's war has been dishonestly defended as an attempt to halt Nicaragua's arms aid to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. That aim cannot be reconciled with sabotage raids against Nicaragua's oil refineries and airfields, all apparently carried out with the C.I.A.'s assistance.

title: Knicks' Brown Hospitalized
description: Coach Hubie Brown of the Knicks was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital late yesterday after complaining of chest pains.

title: F.C.C. RULE CHALLENGED IN SENATE
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee approved an amendment today that would delay for six months a proposed Federal Communications Commission order permitting television networks to own programs and control their syndication.

SEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LACK OF ALTERNATIVES BRINGS A PRISON TERM FOR A RETARDED MAN
description: A 21-year-old man who has been diagnosed as mildly retarded was sentenced in Queens yesterday to one and a half to four years in prison for burglary after state officials were unable to find another place in which to rehabilitate him.

title: No Headline

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: $200 Million Bond Sale By Alaska Housing Unit

title: Arguments Open in Case Of Tylenol Extortion
description: The attorney for James Lewis acknowledged today that his client had written a letter demanding $1 million to ''stop the killing'' of Chicago area residents by cyanide-laced Tylenol, but he denied that Mr. Lewis intended to carry out an extortion threat.

title: BRIEFS
description: Apache Petroleum Co. registered an exchange offer that will result in the acquisition of $218 million of oil and gas properties if 100 percent of investors' interests are exchanged.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC (AT&T) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $286.8 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: FOUR MARINES WOUNDED BY A CAR BOMB IN BEIRUT
description: Four United States marines were slightly wounded today by the explosion of a car bomb as a convoy of four American military vehicles moved along a road near Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut's southern suburbs.

title: TRUCK PURCHASE PROPOSAL DRAWS FIRE
description: To the outspoken dismay of legislators from upstate, the Koch administration wants to buy more than $41 million in new garbage-collection trucks from a company in Oklahoma instead of from a competitor in Elmira, N.Y.

title: BISHOPS' TALK ON PENANCE TURN TO SOCIAL SINS
description: Roman Catholic bishops prepared today for a final week of discussion on the meaning of penance, after broadening their talks to include appeals for more vigorous church action on social justice.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July.

title: POP: SHOW BY WONDER
description: MANY performers use popular music to evoke a feeling of communal solidarity, but that sense of togetherness is almost always superficial. Stevie Wonder is an exception. Mr. Wonder has always been an inspirational performer, but within the last seven years he has emerged as something of a spiritual leader, singing and talking of peace and interracial love and of a humanist philosophy that he calls L.L.M.O., which stands for Letting Life Move On.

title: I.B.M. Expanding Australian Unit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it is expanding its manufacturing operations in Australia to produce personal computers for the Asian market.

title: STAGE: 'SECOND PRIZE' AT PERRY STREET
description: ANY play that opens with a recording of the Beatles singing ''Back in the U.S.S.R.'' can't be a total loss, but certainly the new comedy by Trish Johnson at the Perry Street Theater puts this theory to a tough test. Miss Johnson's play, an account of Georgetown University students on a summer study outing in the Soviet Union, is called ''Second Prize: Two Months in Leningrad,'' and it is just as laborious as its title.

title: Gamble of Yankees Joins Free Agents;  Stearns Signs Again
description: Oscar Gamble formally entered the free-agent market yesterday for the second time. He joined an equally disenchanted Yankee teammate, Dale Murray, and four other players in declaring themselves free agents.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Thursday about the failure of some hospitals in New York State to report misconduct by physicians misstated the status of charges against Dr. Mitchel S. Fagin. In describing complaints against Dr. Fagin, the State Health Department failed to report that it had dropped a charge that he had endangered the life of a surgical patient.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DUN & BRADSTREET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective in May.

title: CHARGES AGAINST A WOMAN IN WELLS FARGO CASE HALTED
description: Five weeks after a $7 million robbery at a Wells Fargo depot here, charges were dropped today against the only person who had been arrested in the investigation.

title: Chock Full Threat
description: A 15-member group that owns 21.7 percent of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said it was ''giving serious consideration'' to conducting a proxy contest for the election of directors, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The group, which includes Jerry Finkelstein, Norman Elowitz and the Gladieux Corporation, said it might call for a proxy contest if discussions to iron out differences between it and the company's management do not result in a ''satisfactory'' agreement.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES ;

title: A.T.&T.'S EARNINGS WILL BE REDUCED $5.2 BILLION IN '83
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that as part of its transformation from a protected monopoly into a competitive company, it would subtract $5.2 billion from its 1983 earnings. That would be the largest such reduction in earnings in corporate history.

title: U.S. Experts Doubtful Of Soviet Space Plight
description: American space experts said yesterday that, contrary to one news report from London, they knew of no reason to believe that two Soviet astronauts are stranded in their orbiting Salyut 7 spacecraft.

title: A LEVY TO EASE FUTURE DEFICITS
description: A little logic and thought on the question of closing the Federal budget deficit leads to an inexorable conclusion: We should join virtually all of our European allies and institute a value-added tax.

title: 40 Executed in China In an Anticrime Drive
description: Red checkmarks on new posters outside the Peking High People's Court today showed that 40 more people had been executed in a crackdown on crime.

title: 18 Die in Thai Floods
description: Floods that hit 16 of Thailand's 73 provinces have killed 18 people and devastated this city of 6 million, the Public Welfare Department said today.

title: French Trade Surplus
description: France posted a trade surplus of 323 million francs, or about $34 million, in September, its first such surplus in two years, the Foreign Trade Ministry said today. France had posted a trade deficit of 389 million francs, which is about $41 million, in August. The Mitterrand Government imposed a stiff austerity program last March in an attempt to cure France's chronic trade deficit.

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Founder, 82, Becomes Franklin Electric Chief
description: Edward J. Schaefer was a founder of the Franklin Electric Company of Bluffton, Ind., in 1944 and headed the company until 1981, when he became chairman of the board's executive committee at the age of 80.

title: SAINT LAURENT: ELEGANT SENSUOUS
description: Yves Saint Laurent wrapped up the Paris spring and summer collections like a candy box today. He bounded down the runway in his navy blue suit surrounded by mannequins wearing bright cotton bras with a bow in the back and another bow wrapped around their hips, and the current opening season was unofficially over. Other showings will continue through Thursday, and Kenzo was to present his collection somewhat exotically in the ch^ateau at Maisons-Laffitte outside Paris late tonight.

title: ONLY 7 SOVIET SHIPS STILL TRAPPED IN ICE
description: A strike force of icebreakers led by the nuclear-powered Leonid Brezhnev is being prepared to rescue the last seven ships still locked in Arctic ice north of the Soviet Far East.

title: RANGERS LIFT MARK TO 7-1
description: There were many moments last night the game could have veered in another direction. As time ticked away to the final minutes, the Rangers were still guarding the 2-1 lead they took in the first period.

title: MUSIC: SEIJI OZAWA CONDUCTS BERLIOZ AND BRAHAMS
description: PERHAPS it should not be surprising at all, but I am often struck by how closely the New York audiences for out- of-town orchestras resemble those in the visitors' home city. Last night, for instance, the Boston Symphony gave a concert at Carnegie Hall under the direction of its music director, Seiji Ozawa, that drew exactly the sort of restrained, undemonstrative response that it might in its own Symphony Hall. The Boston audience, at home or abroad, is a knowledgeable one (no untoward applause between numbers of a song cycle, thank you very much) but it does not excite easily or without cause.

title: COMPUTERS A BOON TO LAWYERS
description: Richard Tufaro was sure that the uncooperative witness had changed his story. Mr. Tufaro was questioning the man in Los Angeles in a bankruptcy case, and knew the witness had contradicted himself in a deposition several weeks before.

title: 13 Bombay Cotton Mills Seized by New Delhi
description: The Indian Government took control today of 13 privately owned cotton mills in Bombay, saying its action was aimed at generating employment for thousands of unemployed workers and ending the factories' financial troubles.

title: CROSS, A T, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Growth for E.E.C.
description: The European Commission forecast growth of 1.5 percent in the 10-nation European Economic Community in 1984 after a growth of five-tenths of 1 percent this year as the ''hesitant and patchy recovery'' continues. In its annual economic report to member governments today, the commission said recovery remains slow and is vulnerable to any renewed turbulence in the international environment.

title: NEO-CLASSICAL LOOK: A FRESH APPEAL
description: WHEN styles change in architecture and interior design, fashions in antiques collecting change as well. Recently many architects and designers have begun to use European neo-classical furniture in the interiors they are designing. The architectural and often severe lines of the period's furniture and its references to Greek, Roman and Egyptian antiquities in details such as obelisks and columns seem to suit many classically detailed rooms.

title: C.D. Rates Are Lower
description: The rate war between New York banks over newly deregulated certificates of deposit slacked off last week, and there were few signs of renewed competition over the C.D.'s in other parts of the country, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

description: The gene that controls the production of the soft fatty material surrounding nerve fibers has been reported isolated from rats by biologists at the California Institute of Technology and the University of California at San Francisco.

title: STARTS ON HOUSING DROP 13.5%
description: New housing starts dropped 13.5 percent in September, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,652,000 units, the Government reported today. The sharp decline was the result of high mortgage interest rates, economists said.

title: ADVERRTISING ; Chairman Is Named At a Ted Bates Unit
description: William D. Dunlap, the 45-year-old president and chief executive officer of Campbell-Mithun Inc. of Minneapolis, a subsidiary of Ted Bates, has been elected Campbell's chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee. Also announced was the election of the vice chairman, William E. Stein, 43, as president and chief operating officer.

IONESCO WILL BE GUEST IN CAST OF WOOLF PLAY AT N.Y.U.
description: Eugene Ionesco will make his American acting debut as Alfred Tennyson in a production of Virginia Woolf's ''Freshwater,'' in a cast of French artists and intellectuals that also includes the novelist Alain Robbe-Grillet and the novelist and philosopher Nathalie Sarraute. The comedy will be presented in French for two performances, at 8:30 P.M. today and tomorrow in the New York University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street. The production is under the auspices of the university's Center for Contemporary French Civilization and Culture.

title: F.C.C. BACKS STATION
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a decision that could encourage more editorializing by broadcasters, ruled today that a Miami radio station did not violate the fairness doctrine when it began a major campaign to block a utility's request for a rate increase.

The company said it earned $55.6 million, or 88 cents a share, up from $39.8 million, or 64 cents, a year before. Revenue advanced 9.8 percent, to $1.23 billion, from $1.12 billion.

title: GIVING SUN TO PLANTS INDOORS
description: POTS make plants mobile, a good thing when a change in exposure is needed. But when a plant is moved, be sure the new location is right by looking for a specific response: a new leaf. As long as new leaves form, the basic light need has been met.

title: CHEMISTRY NOEL WON BY COAST MAN
description: Calling him ''one of the most creative contemporary workers in inorganic chemistry,'' the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry yesterday to a Stanford University professor, Dr. Henry Taube, for discovering the basic mechanism of chemical reactions ranging from enzymes to batteries.

title: A DIFFERENT AMERICA
description: Imagine a government in which all the significant officials dealing with foreign policy and defense - many thousands of them - are subject to random polygraph tests at all times. The same officials must sign an intimidating document binding them to submit virtually everything they write on those subjects to official censors for the rest of their lives, even after they leave the government.

title: DEVELOPERS PLAY DRESS UP WITH ART
description: -estate developers discovered - oh, a decade or two ago - that they could pretty up their buildings and shopping centers with art to attract more customers for rental space, a trend was born. And today it is burgeoning.

It maintained that the eight constituencies where the special elections are to be held were peaceful and stable.

TV: REMEMBERING JOHN F. KENNEDY
description: ''AMERICA REMEMBERS JOHN F. KENNEDY'' is not so much a recollection as a celebration. In this documentary, the late President is called, among other things, ''inspiring,'' ''incandescent'' and a ''figure from the bright days of our beginning.'' Moreover, it offers a good deal to substantiate this, and virtually nothing to dispute it. The approach, in its way, is refreshing. The two-hour documentary will be seen on Channel 9 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Comeback Abandoned

''I knew in the first half,'' he said.

title: KING HOLIDAY: BALKY MINORITY IN G.O.P.
description: The Senate debate over the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday demonstrates how attempts by Republican leaders to enhance their party's credibility among blacks can be undermined by a vocal minority of conservative Republicans who are prepared to ignore the black vote in next year's elections. Most Republican leaders on Capitol Hill strongly believe that if they are to retain control of the Senate and develop a long-range base as a majority party, they must attract more black voters. And they saw their vigorous support of the King bill as a way of enhancing their support among blacks.

title: No Headline
description: Storm Batters Texas and Oklahoma An Oklahoma City fireman carrying a woman from her flooded home. A state of emergency was declared in Oklahoma as 10 inches of rain drenched parts of the state. About 200 people were forced from their homes and at least three deaths in Texas and Oklahoma have been attributed to storm.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''UNTIL I went to work on 'The Right Stuff,' '' says Scott Glenn, ''I'd never been in a film where there was another person named Scott. On 'The Right Stuff,' there's Scott Wilson, Scott Paulin, Scott Beach and me. It was the most pervasive name on the set.''

title: THREE DOCTORS TELL HOUSE PANEL OF NEW MEDICAL DATA ON HUNGER
description: Three doctors testifying before a Congressional subcommittee today presented new medical evidence of hunger and malnutrition in America.

description: Governor Kean announced today that more than $154 million in state-backed home mortgages at an interest rate of 10.55 percent would be available beginning Monday to people who have already shopped for houses.

description: The defense ministers of the Warsaw Pact met here today, and diplomats said they probably worked on a response to the planned NATO deployment of medium-range missiles in Western Europe.

Comings and Goings
description: The Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League reacquired their former defenseman Jerry Korab on waivers a week after Korab, a free agent who had played three seasons with the Los Angeles Kings, had been signed by the Minnesota North Stars without first clearing waivers, as N.H.L. rules require. . . . Chuck Armstrong , a California lawyer and real estate executive with no previous experience in professional baseball, was named president of the SeattleMariners, succeeding Dan O'Brien , who was dismissed after five years with the club. . . . Al Rosen signed a three-year contract to remain as president and general manager of the Houston Astros ending speculation that he would succeed Lee MacPhail as president of the American League.

title: REYNOLDS AND 3M ARE HIGHER
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries reported yesterday that improved food and beverage sales contributed to a 21.3 percent increase in third-quarter net income, to $251 million, up from $207 million in the 1982 period.

title: IN HEAVILY BURDENED BRAZIL, BUOYANCY YIELDS TO DESPAIR
description: One recent morning while joggers passed by on the shore-front pavement and rush-hour traffic began to back up, a fully dressed man walked purposefully onto the beach in Rio's wealthy Leblon neighborhood. He placed a small Bible at the water's edge, dove into the breakers and swam out to sea until he disappeared.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The Euromissile Sadness Throngs of Western Europeans, mostly Germans and Britons, are now staging their long- planned marches against nuclear missiles. They blame mostly America for having to live with new variants of The Bomb in their midst, not even crediting America, or The Bomb, for their right to march. They want the sympathy and support of the many Americans who are equally dismayed by the nuclear arms race and by an American Government that has been less than vigorous in pursuing arms control. The marchers deserve some sympathy, but not much support.

title: Nissan Prices Rise
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation said it would raise prices on its 1984 cars and trucks by $399, or an average 4.2 percent, from 1983 levels. It also said it should complete changing the name of its vehicles and dealers from Datsun to Nissan by the end of 1985.

title: FILM: 'ALL THE RIGHT MOVES' IN FOOTBALL
description: TODAY'S version of the Horatio Alger story doesn't necessarily involve hard work. It may center on sheer ambition, which is shown to lead inexorably, even automatically, to glory. The latest example of this is ''All the Right Moves,'' a well-made but sugar-coated working-class fable about a football star. It concerns a nice boy who wants to ''be somebody,'' the athletic career that he hopes will bring him a college scholarship and the Pennsylvania steel- mill town from which he's determined to escape. The bluer the collar of such a young man, the more miraculous the payoff he will eventually receive - or at least that's the current Hollywood logic.

THE EVENING HOURS

Yes, it was the annual Scottish Ball, but this year it had something a bit different. There was a ''Texas table'' reserved for Americans of Scottish descent who either live in Texas or once did.

title: ART: WHEN AMERICANS WERE PAINTING IN VENICE
description: Ahigh spot on the Grand Tour at the turn of the century was Venice, jewel of the Adriatic, a particular haven for American artists and writers. For artists, it didn't have the heavyweight appeal of Paris or Munich, but there were seductive visual riches: its shimmering light, its rich architectural fantasies and its busy boulevards of water.

title: C-COR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Friday A 65-SEAT PRODUCTION
description: Brian Friel's ''Faith Healer'' won acclaim recently in Dublin and London, but it didn't fare well in a 1979 Broadway production that starred James Mason. Mr. Friel now feels the play should never have been on Broadway because it needs an intimate site. Intimacy is unmistakable at the 65-seat Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street, where previews of ''Faith Healer'' start tonight at 8. J. T. Walsh, whose Broadway credits include ''Rose'' with Glenda Jackson and ''Richard III'' with Al Pacino, plays the title character, who seems to have lost his touch. Also in the cast are Kathleen Chalfant and Martin Shakar, who was John Travolta's brother in ''Saturday Night Fever.'' Tickets are $8. For reservations call 683-0696. RARE BOOKS TO BUY

title: SCREEN: 'AMERICANA'
description: -GO-ROUND provides the overworked central metaphor for David Carradine's ''Americana,'' a film that seems to have emerged from a time warp very much the worse for wear. Shot in the mid- 1970's, written by Richard Carr from a novel by Henry Morton Robinson, it features Mr. Carradine as a soldier who arrives in Kansas with his Vietnam experience fresh in his mind. He is, in the words of one of the film's few characters to do much talking, ''one weird dude.''

Boone Pickens Jr., the Texas oilman and stock speculator, said he had bought 8.75 percent of the Gulf Oil Corporation to produce ''a significant appreciation'' of Gulf's stock through a revamping of the company. title: GEN. F.F. EVEREST DIES AT 79 - COMMANDED KOREA FLIERS -

After an overly cautious rendition of Busoni's achingly beautiful ''Berceuse Elegiaque,'' in Arnold Schoenberg's transcription, the ensemble was joined by the soprano Margaret Chalker for a shimmering performance of Anton Webern's ''Four Songs'' (Op. 19).

title: Davis Joining M.I.S.L.
description: The Cosmos have lost the best- known and perhaps best American soccer player, Rick Davis, whose signing with the St. Louis Steamers of the Major Indoor Soccer League is expected to be announced today. Davis's agent, George Kalafatis, said late yesterday that he and the Cosmos had been unable to come to terms on a contract to replace the one that expired Sept. 30, and that Davis had committed himself to a new team.

title: NOT A CHANCE FOR ROLE IN 'ZORBA,' SO HE GOT IT

title: ART: ASSESSING GUSTON BY HIS LATE PAINTINGS
description: THREE years after Philip Guston died, the shock of the quirky figurative images he painted during the last decade of his life has largely worn off. Current expressionist painting, partly fostered by the violent, funny, always idiosyncratic imagery of Guston's late work, has made his oversized and improbable clocks, fists, eyes and heads more familiar. The issue now is less where Guston's paintings came from, or what they should or should not have been, than what they are.

MARATHONS, AT THE MET AND ON FOOT
description: -distance events in New York are being covered by television, live and in their entirety. On Oct. 22, 1883, the Metropolitan Opera opened with a performance of Gounod's ''Faust.'' Tomorrow, the centennial celebration being mounted at Lincoln Center will begin at 2 P.M. and run, with a break at 6 for dinner, for about eight hours. The entire event will be carried on WNET-TV, Channel 13. In addition to featuring virtually every star in the opera galaxy, the broadcast will offer special essays on the history of the Met.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: ''LET'S do a little striding,'' Joe Turner says, leaning into the Cookery's grand piano. And without ceremony - well, maybe a trace of a smile - the 75-year old pianist does what he's been doing since the 1920's. He takes a tune like ''Dinah,'' or James P. Johnson's wrist-twisting ''Harlem Shout,'' or something by his friend Fats Waller and scatters it gleefully across the keyboard.

title: SYDNOR B. PENICK JR.
description: Sydnor Barksdale Penick Jr., retired chairman of the S. B. Penick Company, a manufacturer of pharmaceuticals, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Newark Airport. He was 78 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: HOSPITAL'S STAFF OPPOSES SALE
description: A new poll of doctors at the nonprofit McLean psychiatric hospital shows that a large majority of them oppose its proposed sale to a commercial hospital company. Some of the physicians have appealed to the Harvard Medical School to block the deal, which is intended to relieve financial problems at McLean and its parent hospital, Massachusetts General.

title: CONCERT: PHILARMONIC
description: ANEW concerto for any instrument is odd enough in our day, when a composer is likely to give his work almost any name but that traditional title. We have lived, after all, through a time when pieces went under such banners as ''Parameters II'' or ''Embolisms IV.'' However, oddity was compounded last night when the New York Philharmonic gave the world premiere of a concerto for the most overlooked and patronized instrument of the orchestra. The piece was Gian Carlo Menotti's Concerto for Double Bass and Orchestra, performed by James VanDemark, one of the few bass players who make a habit of appearing as soloists in public.

title: 2 BUYERS PICKED IN PLAN TO LEASE CONVENTION CENTER
description: Two financial companies were selected yesterday to purchase New York City's Convention Center for about $600 million under a plan that would allow the state to cover cost overruns and complete the center's construction.

title: TOP OF THE GATE IS RENAMED, FOR LAUGHS
description: ''I'm juggling, always juggling,'' said Art D'Lugoff, which is why he is celebrating the 25th birthday of his club, the Village Gate, by changing the name of one of its three components, the Top of the Gate, to Bananas at the Gate, and its identity from jazz room to comedy club. And so, as much to ''give myself a birthday present'' as to kick off the city's newest comedy club, Mr. D'Lugoff has booked the comedian Robert Klein in for this first weekend of Bananas at the Gate.

title: G.M. SETTLEMENT AND REAGAN TENETS
description: The negotiated settlement of a Federal job discrimination complaint against the General Motors Corporation directly contradicts a key tenet of the Reagan Administration's civil rights policy, which strongly opposes the use of numerical hiring goals.

Dow Rises By 4.77; Volume Off
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in slower trading on favorable economic news after dropping sharply in the previous two sessions.

title: Breton-Scottish Concert
description: Kornog, a folk quartet from Brittany, will perform Breton and Scottish music tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street near Avenue of the Americas. Tickets are $8.

THINGS ARE LOOKING UP AGAIN FOR PHOEBE SNOW
description: FROM the moment she achieved stardom early in 1975 singing her original folk- jazz ballad ''Poetry Man,'' Phoebe Snow was hailed as one of the two or three most gifted female pop singers of her generation. Miss Snow, who was born Phoebe Laub 31 years ago in Teaneck, N.J., boasts a mammoth, darkly hued alto that is so richly colored it is innately expressive in the manner of the greatest blues and jazz voices.

title: POP: MAX MORATH AND BAND
description: INTRODUCING Irving Berlin's ''Blue Skies'' as belonging to a genre of American pop he labels ''happy songs,'' Max Morath comments on how atypical it is because the song is slow and in a minor key and uses the color blue. But he quickly adds, ''Mr. Berlin gets to break the rules, because after all he made most of them.''

title: VITTORIO NOVARESE
description: Vittorio Novarese, the costume designer whose historical creations won acclaim in such films as ''Cleopatra'' and ''The Greatest Story Ever Told,'' died here Monday at the age of 76. He is survived by his wife, Giuliana Gianni, of West Los Angeles, a daughter, Letizia Gelles, of Beverly Hills, and a grandson, Oliver Gelles.

title: Marty Cook Leads Quintet
description: The trombonist Marty Cook will lead a quintet tonight and tomorrow at the Manhattan Healing Arts Center (431-1372), 386 Broadway. Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., and admission is $5.

description: b-Net loss.

title: BRIEFING
description: Aid to Zimbabwe

title: DEPLOY MISSILES; CUT ARMS
description: Unless a superpower arms control agreement makes deployment unnecessary, in December the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will begin to base 41 of its new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. Prospects for such an agreement look dim, and Western European governments will be under increasingly strong pressure from antinuclear demonstrators. If there is no quick way out through an agreement in Geneva, what steps could NATO take to try to neutralize the turmoil that seems to lie ahead?

title: BOARD CHAIRMAN RESIGNS AT GHH
description: Manfred Lennings, the management board chairman of Gutehoffnungsh"utte, or GHH, Europe's biggest machine-building group, will step down next month, company officials said yesterday.

title: 'HUMANIZING' CORPORATIONS
description: When Procter & Gamble was accused of promoting Satanism, the company turned to its consumer center, which took more than 100,000 calls on the company's 800 number, to make its case. ''It also helped us track how the rumor was going day by day and hour by hour,'' a company spokesman said. P.& G. later successfully sued several individuals for spreading the false rumor that the company's moon and stars trademark was a sign of loyalty to Satan.

title: AGREES TO TREATMENT
description: Eugene Gold, the former Brooklyn District Attorney, admitted today that he had fondled the 10-year-old daughter of an Alabama prosecutor and agreed to undergo psychiatric treatment to avoid prosecution.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ART: THE BIG PICTURE IN HUNTING AND STILL LIFE
description: ONE of the things I have sometimes missed in Manhattan is a dealers' gallery in which gigantic Old Master paintings are regularly on public exhibition. Old Master paintings large and small may come and go more or less in secret among private dealers, but to see them on public exhibition is both a delight and an education - and all the more so if some of them are markedly better than others.

title: STAGE: TWO-MAN 'SHADES OF BROWN'
description: -CALLED colored psychologist, living illegally in a Johannesburg township, is fearfully awaiting a visit from a Special Branch policeman who is known for brutalizing nonwhites. To the psychologist's surprise, when the official arrives he brings with him a personal problem and a need for counseling. Five years ago, his apparently faithful wife gave birth to a nonwhite child. That fact, the supposed ''taint'' in their bloodline and the abandonment of the baby have acted to shatter their marriage and the wife's emotional stability.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1983 International
description: Aid for Nicaraguan rebels was opposed by the House for the second time. The vote was 227 to 194, an identical 33-vote margin to the House action on July 28. The aid cutoff measure was attached to the House intelligence authorization bill. The Senate has not yet taken up its version of the measure. (Page A1, Column 6.) Brazil's deeply troubled economy has generated an uncharacteristic national mood of despair. Major companies are declaring bankruptcy almost daily, overpasses and bridges have become homes for the dispossessed, and mobs of poor people are looting food stores. (A1:2-3.)

title: DECINCIES SHUNS FREE AGENCY
description: Doug DeCinces, California's productive third baseman, did not even wait to be classified officially as a Type A free agent. In fact, before he could be listed as a free agent of any kind DeCinces reached agreement on a new contract with the Angels.

title: HOUSE AGAIN VOTES AGAINST FINANCING NICARAGUA REBELS
description: The House of Representatives brushed aside appeals from the Reagan Administration today and voted for a second time to cut off United States support for Nicaraguan rebels.

IT'S A BIRD, A PLANE- NO, KISSINGER'S TEAM
description: Henry A. Kissinger and his fellow missionaries have carried out their mission to six Central American countries in six days - or was it seven? They went by so fast. And now, we are told, they will spend something like 90 days writing their report. Perhaps, as one who once undertook a somewhat similar mission, I may be permitted to say that this is a lot of nonsense.

title: ECONOMY EXPANDS AT 7.9% RATE
description: The nation's economy expanded at a strong 7.9 percent annual rate in the third quarter, as the total output of goods and services expanded well beyond the record levels of 1981, the Government reported today.

title: Raphael Celebrated
description: ''Homage to Raphael,'' a celebration of the Italian painter on the 500th anniversary of his birth, is being held today and tomorrow at Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street. The event, devised by Prof. James Beck of Columbia, includes 12 papers on Raphael that will be read by historians. They can be heard today from 3 to 5:30 P.M., and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. The talks, in the Wood Auditorium of Avery Hall at Columbia, are free.

title: Riggins Status Doubtful
description: John Riggins , the Washington Redskins' star running back, was listed as a doubtful starter for Sunday's game against the Detroit Lions after doctors decided to extend his hospital treatment for an inflamed sciatic nerve in his right hip. Riggins, who suffered the injury in practice last week and then aggravated it during Monday night's loss to the Green Bay Packers, entered the hospital and was placed in traction Tuesday, but he had been expected to be back on the practice field yesterday and able to play Sunday. Bubba Tyer , the Redskin trainer, said the decision to keep Riggins in traction an extra day was a precautionary measure and did not mean that the injury, similar to a pinched nerve, was more serious than had originally been thought.

title: Guerrillas Said to Kill 32 in Nicaragua Town
description: Three hundred rebels seized a town 100 miles north of Managua, killing 32 civilians and soldiers, the Government said today.

title: JERUSALEM MAYOR, 72, STILL BRAVES HASIDIC STONES
description: Mayor Teddy Kollek wades into a mixed crowd of Arab and Jewish factory workers, pumping hands, signing autographs, parrying accusatory questions about poor city services and urging everybody to come out and vote next Tuesday for the sake of ''the character of Jerusalem.''

description: New York City is continuously renewing itself. Old buildings and neighborhoods change irrevocably. Sometimes the new co-exists with the old companionably; sometimes the juxtaposition is startling. A punk boutique replaces a shoe factory that itself replaced the lobby of a fashionable emporium. A bodega sprouts on the ground floor of a 100-year-old frame house that was once a farm.

title: SEAPORT NEIGHBORS AREN'T SHARING IN BOOM
description: Four years ago, John and Elio Agnese opened a gift shop on Fulton Street in lower Manhattan. As neighborhoods go, it was a pretty dead place, but big plans were in the offing. The South Street Seaport, a $350-million, 11-block complex of restaurants, specialty shops, pedestrian malls and restored 19th-century houses, was to be built across the street. Estimates were that it would attract 50,000 people a day - most of whom would have to walk right by the Agneses' door.

FILM: 'DEAD ZONE,' FROM KING NOVEL
description: THE combined talents of the novelist Stephen King, the director David Cronenberg (''Scanners'') and the producer Debra Hill (who has the second and third ''Halloween'' films to her credit) would seem to suggest something much scarier than ''The Dead Zone,'' a well-acted drama more eerie than terrifying, more rooted in the occult than in sheer horror. It's a sad, sympathetic and unsettling movie, quietly forceful but in no way geared to the cheap scream.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT CONVICTED OF ATTEMPTED MURDER
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, was convicted last night of attempting to murder two prosecutors and six witnesses.

title: CITY, UNDER PRESSURE, TO BUY MORE TRUCKS MADE UPSTATE
description: The Koch administration, responding to what it said were pressures from Governor Cuomo's office and members of the Board of Estimate, decided yesterday to increase its purchase of garbage-collection trucks from an upstate company and reduce its order from a competitor in Oklahoma.

title: AUCTIONS
description: The star attraction, the last offering in a furnishings and folk art auction taking place today and tomorrow at 2 P.M., is a block-and-shell kneehole dressing table carved around 1760 in the Chippendale style in the Goddard-Townsend Newport workshop. The dressing table, originally owned by William Ellery, a signer of the Declaration of Independence who was a Rhode Island merchant and shipowner, is a three-shell version similar to two four-shell Newport desk-dressing tables that were auctioned earlier this year - Sotheby's sold one in January for $687,500, the highest price ever paid at auction for American furniture, and Christie's followed with another, which sold in June for $627,000.

description: The Senate passed a two-year $6.4 billion State Department authorization bill tonight that includes a $500 million cut in funds for the United Nations, roughly half the United States contributions.

title: Pet Sematary
description: SOMEWHERE, around the time in 1980 when his novel ''Firestarter'' was published, it was written (I think), or said, that Stephen King was at work on a book that was frightening even to him. This was a fairly intriguing rumor, because since 1974, when his first novel, ''Carrie,'' came out, this prolific genius of horror had produced some fairly scary books, among the best of which were ''The Shining'' (1977) and ''The Stand'' (1978).

title: Spain Will Buttress Police in Basque Region
description: The Government announced plans today to increase the police presence in the Basque region and to consider tougher penalties for guerrilla activities after an army captain was kidnapped and killed by Basque guerrillas.

title: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1983
description: Companies Several large brokerage firms agreed to refund about $30 million to purchasers in New York of unlicensed Baldwin-United retirement investments, according to Governor Cuomo. The announcement raised the question whether the firms had knowingly violated state regulations in selling the investments or whether they had done so inadvertently, as they maintain. The firms that are to share in the refund are Merrill Lynch, E. F. Hutton, Shearson/American Express, Prudential-Bache and Smith Barney. (Page A1.) International Harvester said it had reached an agreement with major creditors to restructure $3.5 billion of its debt. (D1.)

CLARENDON TELLS COURT OF ASSETS
description: Clarendon Ltd., a spinoff of Marc Rich & Company A.G., has at least $100 million, and possibly as much as $200 million, in Switzerland, beyond the reach of a freeze on assets by the Internal Revenue Service, the company's chief financial officer disclosed yesterday.

title: THE WORM AND THE APPPLE Cheap Medicine / Costly Odds Blood Bucks
description: We recently awarded worms to New York City's Departments of Consumer Affairs and Health for their indifference to the sidewalk trade in blood pressure tests. For the modest price of a white lab coat and a device called a sphygmomanometer, untrained entrepreneurs sell blood pressure readings for $2 a shot.

title: No Headline
description: Chaplins in Pantomine Tramp to a Musical Tryout Derby hats and baggy pants, flowers in their buttonholes, walking sticks and outsized shoes, all in a wistful line waiting to perform. Chaplinesque was the style as actors awaited their turn to audition for a chance at understudy in the role of Charlie Chaplin in a musical review titled, ''Hooray for Hollywood'' at the St. Regis Hotel. Before his turn, Daniel Freedman, left, added some color to his guise while Dianna West reattached her mustache.

title: REAGAN AND AIDES DISCUSS TV RULE
description: President Reagan met with Cabinet members and advisers today on a proposed Federal Communications Commission order that would let television networks own programs and control their syndication, but the White House said it had reached no decision about its position on the matter.

title: NICARAGUAN PRESENTS STATE DEPT. WITH 4 TREATIES ON LATIN AMERICA
description: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister presented the Reagan Administration today with four draft agreements that he said were ''concrete and detailed proposals for the guaranteeing of the international peace and security of all the Central American states.''

title: Rose Unlikely as Red
description: Will Pete Rose be returning to the Cincinnati Reds, where he spent 16 seasons before joining the Philadelphia Phillies four years ago? Probably not, according to the Reds' president, Bob Howsam , who acknowledged that the club had expressed an interest in talking to Rose, a Cincinnati native who lives there during the off-season. Howsam said the Reds were not prepared to meet Rose's terms, especially his insistence on playing regularly.

description: Harvest of Failure in Grenada However bad the situation in Grenada before last week, it is now decidedly worse. The leftist regime that seized power on that small island in 1979 has itself fallen victim to violence. And the United States' undifferentiated hostility to leftists in this hemisphere has been rewarded with a hard lurch to the dogmatic and pro-Soviet left.

Stock prices declined in reaction to apparently unfounded rumors that Argentina would default on its foreign loans. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.64 points, to 1,248.88. (37.)
