title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1983 International
description: The U. S. has secretly trained a Jordanian strike force for the Persian Gulf, American officials said. The strike force, for which the Reagan Administration is seeking $220 million in secretly financed aid, has already been trained for two and a half years by American Special Forces units, the officials said. The officials said that in case of an emergency, the Jordanians would be airlifted not only by their own planes but also by United States transports that would go to the region. Initially, officials said the Administration was seeking $220 million for military equipment to start up the Jordanian force and there was no mention of any United States Air Force involvement. (Page 1, Col. 6.) A warning about Central America was voiced by Henry A. Kissinger, chairman of the President's commission on the region, who said that the situation there was ''graver than most of us had expected.'' His comments came after President Reagan met with the commission. (1:5.)

title: Indonesia Warns Iranians
description: Foreign Minister Mochtar Kusumaatmadja said today that his ministry had delivered a strong warning to the Iranian Embassy in Jakarta to stop spreading ''hostile'' propaganda in Indonesia. title: UNSCHEDULED AIRLINE STOP HAS PIPE SMOKER FUMING
description: A passenger who refused to put out his pipe on a Northwest Airlines flight was ''deplaned'' at an unscheduled stop in Fargo, then found himself stranded when two other airlines refused to let him board.

description: Japan's only remaining whaling mother ship left Yokosuka near Tokyo today en route to the Antarctic Ocean, maritime officials said.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY SHAKE-UP HINTED
description: Along with commuter trains, buses and subways, it seems likely heads will roll under Robert R. Kiley, Governor Cuomo's choice to run the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. At a confirmation hearing last week before the Transportation Committee of the State Senate, Mr. Kiley said he would overhaul the authority's management and added that a restructuring of the Transit Authority, the M.T.A. subsidiary that runs the city's mass transit system, would be the ''absolute top priority'' of whoever is chosen as its new president. ''The track situation that popped up last summer,'' he said, referring to a rash of subway derailments and delays, ''is a symptom of a problem that could suggest the need for greater depth and breadth of management.''

description: The songwriter Eugene McDaniels made his name in the late 1960's with such tough, roots-inflected songs as ''Reverend Lee'' and ''Compared to What.'' He derived considerably more in royalties from the reassuring ''Feel Like Making Love,'' a hit for Roberta Flack.

title: A NATIONAL DAY FOR DR. KING
description: Fifteen years after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., black Americans have come to carry considerable sway at the ballot box. It was surely not the only factor, but the possibility of retribution on Election Day appeared to have strengthened the Senate's resolve last week to approve a national holiday honoring the civil rights leader's birthday.

title: WHEN A DANCE IS AN ESTHETIC ARGUMENT
description: Even the slightest exposure to Senta Driver shows that this modernist choreographer takes an almost ornery delight in being different. For starters, there is the intriguingly indeterminate name she chose for the dance company she founded in 1975 - ''Harry.'' Her explanations have a habit of changing from interview to interview, but most have to do with the desire to alert her audiences not to expect a typical evening of modern dance.

The reasons for these enterprises are the inevitable certainty that Manhattan Island, upon which is located New York City, will soon be entirely inadequate to provide homes for its increasing population.''

title: Ford Revolution

title: A ROSY OUTLOOK FOR ELECTION '84
description: -year-old Wall Street economist, was calculating the Misery Index last week, examining movements in the economic barometer used occasionally by Presidential challengers to embarrass White House incumbents. Adding the level of unemployment to the inflation rate, the director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company figured the index stood at 20.5 percent just before the 1980 elections that brought Ronald Reagan to Washington. Currently the index is hovering at 13.6 percent, and based on Mr. Wenglowski's forecast, it will creep up to only 14.5 percent by Election Day 1984 as inflation rises faster than unemployment drops. ''These numbers say that Reagan makes it - things will be looking good for him on the economic front by Election Day,'' he said.

title: DANCE: KAREN MALPEDE
description: Who was Sappho? That she was a Greek poet of the sixth century B.C., inhabiting the island of Lesbos, is sure. What has kept her legend fresh is the question of whether she was a prostitute or the lesbian headmistress of one of the popular institutions designed to train young women in the arts and cult service of the gods. The fragments of her poetry that have survived, particularly in Mary Barnard's translation, are direct, spare and stylishly colloquial; lyrical and often funny, they are informed by a strong and vivid personality.

title: SURVIVAL FOR BOTTLERS IS A WAR ON 2 FRONTS
description: WHEN Pop Shoppe Beverages went out of business in Manchester last month, it might have taken a few customers by surprise, but, for the independent bottlers left in Connecticut, closings are becoming routine.

title: THE SOUNDS OF SILENCE
description: The Reagan Administration wants Federal employees to keep their mouths shut, and favors one particular way of making sure they do. Last week, the Justice Department backed random lie detector tests for screening officials with access to especially sensitive information. But in a rebuff of another part of the President's plan - lifelong censorship - the Senate voted 56 to 34 for a delay pending Congressional hearings.

title: MONDALE TRADES BARBS WITH GLENN
description: In speeches to the Florida Democratic convention here, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio exchanged criticisms on the subject of party loyalty and campaign tactics.

Passidomo, the Democratic Supervisor/Mayor of Harrison, was appointed State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles by Governor Cuomo last February, Republicans in the coterminous town and village were presented with one of their strongest opportunities to capture a position that Mr. Passidomo had held for 19 years.

title: SUSAN ROSE IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Rose of Rumson, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Anne Rose, to Bentley Atwood Howe Merrick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bentley A. Merrick of Chatham, N.J. Miss Rose and her fiance, graduates of Middlebury College, plan a June wedding.

title: Stony Brook Rift: Zionism and Racism
description: The article ''The Stony Brook Rift: Racism and Zionism'' (Long Island Weekly, Oct. 2), missed the mark in an essential aspect. This is embodied in the statement by Robert Goldsmith, a student of Professor Dube, as he recounted the professor's remarks during a class discussion on Israel: ''He screamed at me.

title: A TAX FOR THE WEALTHY: EASING ITS BITE
description: ONE of the thorniest financial problems that many well-to-do taxpayers may face in the next few weeks is how they can avoid being subject to the new alternative minimum tax. The intent of the tax, which was revised and expanded for years beginning with 1983, is to make sure that everyone with a substantial income pays at least some tax to the Government.

title: RUCKELSHAUS PUTS OFF PLAN TO CURB ACID RAIN
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has put off indefinitely a recommendation to President Reagan on a plan to control acid rain because of opposition from high-level members of the Administration.

title: BEARING WITNESS
description: THE DOORMAN LEAPS back as the 11-year- old boy takes the lobby of his apartment building at a gallop, legs kicking out almost sideways. Halfway down the street in Manhattan's West 80's, he pauses to look back and sees his father emerge from the building, walking with an even gait, arms drawn behind him. The boy runs on. Soon he is outside the pizza parlor that has his favorite video games and he waits for the man with the quarters, his father, Elie Wiesel.

title: SCHOOLS CAUTIONED ON 180-DAY STATUTE

title: IRAQ,IRAN,WATER, OIL
description: Iraq, Iran, Water, Oil It is disagreeably conceivable that an enraged Iran, threatened with humiliation in its three-year war with Iraq, might strike back by closing the Persian Gulf to oil tankers. Ayatollah Khomeini threatens no less if the Iraqis turn French missiles against Iran's refineries and tankers. It is unimaginable that the non-Communist world, which obtains a fourth of its oil from Gulf producers, would limply acquiesce.

title: A DELAYED FUSE ON KOHL'S MISSILE CRISIS
description: Helmut Kohl's friends like to say that, whatever his shortcomings, the Chancellor's nerves are good. He should have ample occasion to display steadiness and tenacity in the unsettled months ahead. For now, he seems firmly in control. A 10-day street campaign against American missiles, which climaxed yesterday with close to a million people attending rallies in five cities, failed to shake the country's foundations. Barring a surprise Soviet-American arms compromise in Geneva, Parliament is expected to approve the stationing of new American medium-range missiles on Nov. 21. In the next few weeks, nine Pershing 2 missiles are expected to arrive at American Army bases in southern Germany and become operational by Dec. 15.

description: eter the Great, Czar of All Russia, loved Cahors, and you really can't blame him. Cahors, a stick-to-your-ribs kind of red wine from the southwestern part of France, is just the thing for a cold winter's night on the steppes, even if you're not a czar.

title: GRENADA TORN BY A DEADLY DISAGREEMENT
description: There are many larger and more important Caribbean islands than Grenada, but few have been so much a part of the world's recent political preoccupations as this 133-square- mile speck in the Windward chain near Venezuela. Grenada distracted the great powers more than usual last week as Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, who seized power in 1979 and was on Washington's blacklist for his close relations with the Soviet Union and Cuba, became the victim of a coup that left him and at least three of his ministers dead.

title: STUDY FINDS CHILD ABDUCTION BY PARENTS EXCEEDS ESTIMATES
description: A new national study of the parental kidnapping of children has found that there are many more such abductions than previously believed. The study, which experts say is the THE FAMILYmost ambitious yet attempted, estimates that there at least 313,000 incidents a year and possibly as many as 626,000.

title: Escaping Inmate Killed
description: Six prisoners who commandeered a garbage truck today ran into a hail of gunfire as they crashed through the fence of the Federal penitentiary here, leaving one inmate dead and two others injured, officials said. The three inmates who were not injured were apprehended within a half mile of the prison. Joseph Owens, 40 years old, who was serving a 21-year sentence for armed bank robbery and escape, died of a gunshot wound to the neck.

title: Hicks in Dispute
description: They have an important game with the Los Angeles Rams today, but it looks as if the San Francisco 49ers will have to play without one of their best defensive backs, the safety Dwight Hicks , who left the team Friday as a result of a contract dispute with the club. The move apparently came as a surprise to the team.

title: CONCERT: 3 WORKS BY CLAUDE BOLLING

Feiner, son of Frieda Feiner of Providence, R.I., and the late Leonard A. Feiner. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at 1A East 77th Street in New York.

title: THE SONG OF HIGH WATT
description: ''Buy the shores of Gitche Gumee, Buy the shining offshore leases, Buy the shining mining leases, Giving me the credit due me, And you'll be as rich as Croesus, Richer far than old King Croesus. Though the Congress may beshrew me, Pick my policies to pieces, Reagan's will is working through me, Not to mention Edwin Meese's.'' Thus spake Watt in his ascendence, Pillar of Conservatism, Glowing with a great resplendence, Til he brewed a mess of potage That created massive schism, Dimmed his incandescent wattage Even in the Great White Cottage, Spreading through the Great White Cottage, Instant Oval Roomatism. Thereupon Watt drew dismissal, Drew dismissal unexpected When the Wise Men blew the whistle: Reagan must be re-elected. Overnight, in public parklands, James G. Watt was superceded; Parks became the William Clark lands. Though Ron's Confidential Clark stands Unequipped, no whit impeded By experience . . . none's needed. He can do as he indeed did In the job where he's been working: Just keep Reagan's kettle perking. Faced with need to find replacement, Fill the chair Clark sat so still in, Reagan, standing at his casement, Sought a substitute to fill in, One less prone to lead than follow, One his Cabinet could swallow. Jeane Kirkpatrick, willing, eager, And prepared to wear the garland As a Reagan major leaguer Found that gratitude was meager When the garland was MacFarlaned. Having pulled this double shuffle, Reagan, ever tender-hearted, May think back to where it started, Back to Watt and how it started, Feel with guilt he cannot muffle That Watt suffered in the scuffle - Conscience bears such heavy duffle! Doubtless Reagan soon will see a Tidy and uncomplicated And befitting panacea That would leave Watt's pride placated: Choose Jim Watt, with flatt'ring unction, For the Mideast envoy function That MacFarlane has vacated.

title: TWO DEMOCRATS IN SEARCH OF A SOUTHERN STRATEGY
description: The political setting here last week was one in which former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is at his best. The hand-picked audience of 200 ardent Democrats, most of them New South progressives who had been associated with former President Carter, represented the Southern Democratic Party's loftiest instincts if not its usual voting patterns. The discussion, by a panel that included Mr. Mondale, Mr. Carter, and former Secretary of State Dean Rusk, was high-toned and enlightened. As in other such gatherings of his party's elite, Mr. Mondale demonstrated the easy wit, detailed knowledge and political acumen that often seem lacking in the public performances of his nearest competitor in the opinion polls, Senator John Glenn.

That particular holiday is becoming more of an embarrassment as we continue to learn of groups that came to this continent before him. Perhaps ''Discovery Day'' could be combined with Independence Day, and we could celebrate both for the price of one. GLENN MALLISON Watertown, N.Y., Oct. 10, 1983

title: THE THEORISTS: 11 AMERICAN LAUREATES
description: Below are the American winners of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, the year they won and a look at their current activities. 1970 - Paul A. Samuelson, now 68, is Institute Professor of Economics at M.I.T. He was awarded the prize for his influential and widely read works, which raised the level of scientific analysis in economic theory. Having completed a revised volume of ''Foundations of Economic Analysis,'' he is working on the 12th edition of his classic beginning textbook, ''Economics''; a fifth volume of his lectures will appear next year. 1971 - Simon S. Kuznets, 82, is professor emeritus of economics at Harvard University. He was honored for his contributions to national income accounting that made possible quantitative studies of the comparative growth of nations. He retired from active teaching in 1971. His most recent research and writing has been in the field of income inequalities. 1972 - Kenneth J. Arrow, 62, is Joan Kenney Professor of Economics at Stanford University. He won the Nobel award, with Sir John R. Hicks of Britain, for work in the abstract field of equilibrium theory. (See article above.) He is now studying the role of small companies in the innovative process and, separately, developing a theory to account for information transfer problems within organizations. 1973 - Wassily W. Leontief, 77, is director of the Institute for Economic Analysis at New York University. His prize was for his ''input-output'' technique for quantifying and studying specific interdependencies in an economy, and using it to predict major trends.

title: MASSAPEQUA UPSETS FARMINGDALE Mike Napoli scored two touchdowns yesterday, helping Massapequa upset Farmingdale, 20-8. Farmingdale, ranked No. 1 one in New York State in a sportswriter's poll, lost to Lawrence in last year's Conference A county championship. This year, the team has given up only 14 points and was undefeated. Massapequa is 3-2, Farmingdale 3-1.
description: The Chiefs scored twice in the second quarter. The first touchdown followed a 14-play, 80-yard drive that was led by an 11-yard screen pass to Craig Zimmer. This set up a 1-yard touchdown run by Napoli. With one minute remaining in the half, Tom DeLucie intercepted a Farmingdale pass, and on the next play, Jim Pierzza, the quarterback, threw a 20-yard touchdown pass to Chris Kastl.

description: Representative Ted Weiss, chairman of a House subcommittee investigating the Westway project, has asked the New York State Transportation Department to surrender more than 100 documents related to the project. The department has refused, contending that the documents are privileged.

title: PICKENS RATTLES GULF MANAGEMENT
description: What Gulf Oil feared most happened last week. T. Boone Pickens Jr., dubbed the ''wolf'' of Wall Street by a Gulf spokesman, said that he and a group of investors had bought 14.5 million Gulf shares, or 8.75 percent of the company, and that they had commitments to buy up to 15 percent of the company's shares for a total investment of $1.1 billion. The Pickens group, which includes the Belzberg family from Canada, told the S.E.C. that its purpose was to increase the value of Gulf stock. It recommended the company either split into a number of parts or, particularly, place its key oil and gas properties in a royalty trust, which would give shareholders a direct interest in the assets and avoid double taxation. Gulf has reportedly lined up $4 billion in bank credits and is expected to fight Mr. Pickens fiercely. Mr. Pickens, likewise, has substantial funding, but apparently the waters were a little too hot for the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh - Gulf's home town - and three other banks, which withdrew their lines of credit to Mr. Pickens.

title: PUSHING THE NICARAGUAN PRESSURE POINTS
description: The actions and words of the past two weeks here and in Washington have persuaded many officials in both countries that the United States, in effect if not in fact, is at war with Nicaragua. In Managua, the sense of siege is pervasive - in headlines denouncing the Central Intelligence Agency and the ''contras,'' or counterrevolutionary rebels, it supports; in Sandinista speeches, and in the accelerating mobilization of loyalists to fight in the north. ''Nearly everyone has a brother or a cousin or a son fighting up there,'' said a college student from Matagalpa, north of the capital.

For the first time since its heavy steel doors were slammed shut nine years ago, the jail, better known as the Tombs, was back in business.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Shauna Rolston, 16, One of Two Cellists And a Pianist Heard
description: Shauna Rolston is a 16-year-old Canadian cellist who made her debut in Town Hall Tuesday evening. Like all child prodigies (Miss Rolston began playing at the age of 2), her relationship with the instrument was completely natural; no physical movement was alien, and her own breathing was intimately related to the music's. Vibrato was not an ''expressive'' or ''vocal'' touch added to something already existing; rather, it was part of the music's respiration, the source of its tempo.

title: BLACK FIREFIGHTERS PRESS FOR ACTION ON JOBS GOALS
description: WHITE PLAINS THREE years ago, the county's four largest cities agreed to increase minority representation at all levels within the fire departments of each city. The agreement settled a 1978 suit filed by the Vulcan Society of Westchester County, a group of black firefighters who charged the fire departments of Yonkers, New Rochelle, White Plains and Mount Vernon with discriminating against blacks in hiring, promotion and testing procedures.

title: LINCOLN THEATER GETS NEW LIFE
description: NEW HAVEN THE roof does not leak and the projector does not break down during the movie. The floor does not dip in the middle, so you do not have to sit in the back row anymore to see the full screen.

title: Zimbabwe Said to Bar Entry of Israelis
description: Zimbabwe has restricted the entry of Israelis into the country, officials said today.

title: THE ICY GRIP OF INCOMPETENCE
description: A bone-chilling battle against 12- foot-thick Arctic pack ice provided Soviet newspaper readers with a dramatic diversion from everyday drabness last week. But after all the rhapsodies on maritime heroism, Pravda announced that bureaucrats, not ice floes, were the true villains.

title: 3 Win Columbia Prize For Research on Nerves
description: Three scientists who have conducted research on cell development have been awarded Columbia University's 1983 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize.

title: PAY CABLE CONFRONTS THE FORCES OF THE MARKETPLACE
description: We all know by now, presumably, that pay cable organizations, faced with a shortage of theatrical-release movies to fill their daily schedules, are moving into the making of original productions. Obviously, these programs will have to appeal to viewers who are being asked to pay a premium for the supposed privilege of watching them. What we don't know, though, is what kinds of productions pay TV will eventually find most compatible with its bottom-line profit ambitions. Will they be merely a bit less cheap than theatrical films and a bit more ''adult'' than TV movies? Will they cover many areas of the arts and entertainment, or will they settle on a few most popular formulas? The possibilities are wide-ranging, as illustrated in two current extremes being provided by major pay TV channels: ''Eddie Murphy . . . Delirious'' on Home Box Office, and ''A Case of Libel'' on Showtime/Movie Channel.

title: Article 249456 -- No Title
description: Three armed robbers broke into a Manhattan jewelry factory yesterday morning by climbing down a rope from the roof, handcuffed the owner and 13 of his employees as they arrived for work and escaped with what was estimated at $1 million in gold and jewels, the police said.

description: A Phenomenon ran a phenomenally fast seven furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday to win the $115,000 Vosburgh Stakes and probably earn an Eclipse Award as the champion sprinter in the country.

Clark, to the suddenly vacant post of Interior Secretary. The President stressed, and aides confirmed, that his friend and adviser had requested the transfer from his august position at the White House.

title: NURSING HOMES OFFER STRONG ARGUMENT FOR RE-REGULATION
description: In a review of its first 30 months, the Administration boasted that it had ''revised or eliminated hundreds of unjustifiable inherited rules'' and slashed the publication of new ones in the Federal Register by one-fourth. It thus saved, it asserted, $150 billion for consumers, businesses and state and local governments over the next decade. The White House's experience with the nursing home industry, however, provides a textbook example of the way the Reagan challenge to the status quo can force Congress and the public to define the minimum role of Government. In the instance of nursing homes the minimum demanded proved substantially larger than President Reagan thought appropriate.

title: 2 LIVES, 2 BUILDINGS: A STUDY IN PARADOX
description: TIME has a curious way of altering perspectives and fostering peculiar ironies. The life stories of Joseph Philo Bradley and Paul Robeson provide a case in point.Their biographies are bound together in odd ways, but that there are buildings named for them on the Rutgers-Newark campus may present the strangest paradox of all.

description: Thousands of Americans took to streets and parks yesterday in demonstrations protesting the proposed deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Europe.

title: SCOTISH TRADITION
description: he cup of fellowship is one to be sipped slowly. There are, after all, enough gulps in our lives. But there are those special times, with workaday storms stilled, when men do assemble in elegant celebration of friendship, and of themselves. Which brings us to a dozen members of the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York, their shared Scottish heritage and their talent for sipping slowly from the cup of friendship.

Nowhere does this seem more evident than among Jews, whose votes in a referendum next month are conspicuously up for grabs.

title: SUBTITLES WIN AT CITY OPERA
description: Encouraged by an overwhelmingly favorable public and critical response to the use of English-language subtitles in this season's production of Massenet's ''Cendrillon,'' Beverly Sills of the New York City Opera now plans to subtitle 12 foreign-language operas for the company's 1984 season. The only opera not sung in English that will be presented without the subtitles will be Philip Glass's ''Akhnaten,'' which incorporates a narrator as part of the staging.

title: LINES STILL VEX, BUT AIR IS CLEANER
description: CONNECTICUT'S program to inspect the emissions of motor vehicles started last Jan. 4 with considerable confusion, two-hour lines at inspection stations and 500 calls a day to special number for questions and complaints.

description: HOW could anyone with the uncomplicated name of Tom Brown Jr. turn out to be as charismatic a figure as the 33-year-old author by that name?

title: YOHJI YAMAMOTO DEFINES HIS FASHION FASHION PHILOSOPHY
description: Yohji Yamamoto may stand barely five feet tall, but his effect on world fashion in the last two years has been enormous. Many people at the recent Paris showings said he is the best of the new Japanese designers - a distinguished group that includes Rei Kawakubo for Comme des Gar,cons, Issey Miyake and Kansai Yamamoto (no relation). Some say he is the best anywhere. His fans use his first name when they discuss his clothes, a sure sign that a designer has arrived. Fashion experts and retailers are often inclined to exaggerate, but Mr. Yamamoto's influence is hard to dispute.

title: Hofstra Downs Fordham, 14-0
description: Tim Feldman of Hofstra intercepted a Dan McCain pass and sprinted 45 yards for a touchdown with 3 minutes 31 seconds remaining to break a scoreless tie, and the Flying Dutchmen went on to register a 14-0 victory over Fordham yesterday afternoon at Jack Coffey Field.

title: J. L. Kempner, Investment Banker, Is Married to Cynthia Anne Hayden

Hayden of Newton, Mass., and Lauretta Mae Hayden of Hingham, Mass., was married yesterday to James Lindsey Kempner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Kempner of New York and Purchase, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gerard Beausoleil at the Chapel of the Most Blessed Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Newton.

title: ROBUST REPASTS
description: n the brisk days of fall and winter, appetites tend to be heightened. This is particularly true if the day is spent outdoors, skiing, perhaps, or in the stands at a football game, or even tacking into a stiff autumn wind. But it is equally true if it is spent in a more leisurely way, indoors, out of the weather, watching a football game on television with friends or entertaining by a warming fire.

title: WARMING CONCOCTIONS
description: hite wine seems to be the all-purpose drink these days and, let's face it, in most cases it neatly fills the bill. There are times, however, when it simply won't do. In a tough waterfront bar, for example, or at a formal dinner at Chateau Latour. Or almost any occasion when it's cold. The weather, not the wine. Think of striding into the lodge after a day of skiing Aspen, your face red from the frigid wind and your hands numb with cold, to ask for a little glass of white wine.

title: 2 STAMFORD COACHES PROTEST LOSS OF JOBS
description: FOR many years, Phil Ragozzino, the basketball coach at Rippowam, and Charlie Pike, the baseball coach at Stamford High, have been regarded as two of the state's most successful high school coaches.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: -dotted skyline of Atlantic City and Absecon, northwest of it, are thousands of acres of wetlands and a network of back bays that serve in the fall as resting and feeding stations for migrating birds.

title: THIS WAY OUT
description: State officials also found a solution last week to cost overruns on the West Side's other major development project, the Convention Center. They selected two companies to whom they will sell the center, now at least two years behind schedule and $125 million over budget, according to state officials.

title: STONY BROOK RIFT: ZIONISM AND RACISM
description: In the controversy about Professor Dube's course in The Politics of Racism, academic freedom is a false issue; and the faculty committee that dismissed without investigation the allegations of impropriety on the part of Professor Dube came to an irrelevant and short-sighted conclusion in declaring that the professor was within the bounds of academic freedom.

title: HOUSTON SCORES 3
description: Ken Houston scored 3 goals and 2 assists tonight to lead the Los Angeles Kings to an 8-3 victory over the New Jersey Devils.

title: ; RUTH PRAWER JHABVALA'S WRITING
THE PROPER QUESTION IN ADJUDICIATING A MERGER
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Oct. 2 about corporate sponsorship of rock groups misidentified the lead singer of The Who. He is Roger Daltrey.

title: Lebanese Leaders Meet To lan Geneva arley
description: President Amin Gemayel, Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan and Foreign Minister Elie Salem met here today to review efforts to convene a Lebanese conference in Geneva.

title: MARITIME TRUSTEES AGREE TO CHALLENGE
description: The trustees of the foundation that backed Dennis Conner and Liberty, the yacht that lost the America's Cup to Australia II last month, have agreed to field a challenge to win the cup back in 1987, and it is expected that Conner will be at the helm.

title: SUSPECT HAD RECENTLY LOST HIS JOB AND HIS FATHER
description: Charles R. Harris, suspected of taking five hostages in the Augusta National Golf Course pro shop and demanding to speak with President Reagan, was ''not at all'' a loner and ''had a certain amount of popularity'' among co-workers at a paper mill where he worked until recently, according to a mill official.

title: 'BEYOND THERAPY' SPOOFS INTIMACY
description: CHRISTOPHER DURANG's ''Beyond Therapy'' is a series of vignettes covering the relationship of Bruce and Prudence and their relationships with their respective psychiatrists. In a large Broadway house, Durang's satire seemed fatuous. In a small, intimate theater, such as the Arena Players Repertory, where it is currently playing, it is howlingly funny.

title: WHEN FORDHAM BEAT ALABAMA
description: TO the current generation of

title: 11 Lifters Banned From Olympics
description: The 11 weight lifters, including an American, who were disqualified from the Pan American Games for using banned drugs are ineligible for the 1984 Olympics because of a two-year suspension imposed by the International Weightlifting Federation.

title: No Headline
description: Joanne Busel Affianced

title: CENTRAL AMERICA: U.S. ON A 'DISASTER COURSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN TUNE UP (OR TRY TO) FOR FIRST TIME
description: THE sounds of autumn are heard upon the land. From the concert hall to the football field, the music begins anew, as sure a sign of fall as changing leaves and fashion shows. The haunting cry of geese flying across the sunset sends shivers up the spine - but wait. That is not the sound of a lonely goose separated from its flock. That is the neighbor's child, practicing his new oboe.

title: NEW HOPE 'SCHOOL' AIDS MUSEUM
description: TRENTON FOR SOME young people, ''antique'' may mean anyone over the age of 30, but for James Gregory, the rule of thumb is that the objects in any antiques show should be at least 100 years old.

title: Facts Available On Hazardous Wastes
description: I write to thank you for the splendid treatment you have afforded Karl J. Wagener, director of the Connecticut Audubon Society's Environmental Center, in the ''Secret Polluters: Homeowners'' article (Oct. 2). The graphic was especially appropriate.

title: NEW HAND AT RENT REGULATING HELM
description: NEW YORK STATE is beginning to assemble the elements needed to take over the complicated system of apartment rent regulation in New York City.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE 13TH VALLEY. By John M. Del Vecchio. (Bantam, $3.95.) Set in Vietnam in 1970, when the antiwar movement in the United States had reached its peak, troop withdrawals were under way and the soldiers still fighting knew there was no light at the end of the tunnel, John M. Del Vecchio's powerful first novel depicts sensitive, complex individuals waging an apocalyptic battle. Our critic, Joe Klein, found ''The 13th Valley'' remarkable for its ability to communicate ''the day-to-day pain, discomfort, frustration and exhilaration of the American military experience in Vietnam.''

title: A CINDERELLA TOUCH TO A MODEL'S STORY
description: MOST weekdays when the clock strikes 1:48 P.M., a 15-year-old Babylon girl undergoes a transformation.

title: RARITIES FROM SPAIN
description: What is the relationship of rarity to monetary value in antiques? Collectors quickly learn that the rarity of period objects does not always guarantee high prices or even saleability in what they buy and sell. Sometimes, in fact, when costly wares become scarce, they may prove to be less interesting to collectors, causing prices to plateau or even plummet. When vintage material goes out of fashion, it may remain so, never returning to the price levels it once enjoyed. Those who fancy antiques of slight monetary value, are the lucky ones - as long as they remain realistic about what they buy, the prices they pay and the expectations they harbor.

title: FICTION
description: 118 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 2318 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 327

title: FROM THE SEA, WITH A SPLASH OF VENICE
description: ONE of the many wonderful sites in Venice is the food market near the Rialto Bridge. Early one morning a couple of weeks ago, the light was pale and slightly misty, making the colors of the fruits, vegetables and fish even more pronounced. There were all kinds of eggplant - white, purple and thin, pale mauve - ivory cauliflower, piles of funghi porcini, freshly picked young salad greens and zucchini with their flowers still intact, piled next to boxes of peaches and green figs.

title: Warsaw Pact Meeting Is Reportedly Planned
description: Eastern European sources said today that there were reports of preparations for a meeting of the seven heads of state of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact.

title: PREMIER FOR A MOVIE COMPLEX
description: RESIDENTS in the Commack Road area of Commack are so pleased at the closing of a motorcycle run that the potential of traffic congestion caused by its replacement, a movie complex, does not dismay them.

title: REUSING A CHURCH
description: Two years ago the parishioners of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Roman Catholic Church moved from their Norman-style home in Yorktown in Westchester to a larger church in Shrub Oak and the abandoned church was put up for sale. But existing zoning limited use to such functions as a community center, a day-care facility or a social club.

title:
ANTIQUES;
INSURING YOUR VALUED POSSESSIONS
description: WHEN several residents of a small, suburban town in New Jersey were invited by the local police to view a display of antiques and other household items recently, they were being called on to identify their own stolen property.

title: Miss Blanchard Weds M. K. Langstaff
description: Michele Marie Blanchard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Harris Blanchard of Devon, Pa., was married yesterday to Maxim Kennedy Langstaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Kennedy Langstaff of Stamford and Mystic, Conn. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College in New London, Conn.

title: 2 EX-FIREFIGHTERS AWAIT JOB RULING
description: A Federal judge is to decide soon whether to reinstate as firefighters two women who contend that their dismissal from the New York City Fire Department last month was based on sexual discrimination and not on their inability to do the job.

title: Mother's Birth Weight Linked to Baby Health
description: Women who weighed less than five pounds at birth are more likely than others to have babies needing neonatal intensive care, according to researchers at the University of Washington at Seattle.

title: Lisa A. Alter, Lawyer, Married to a Physician
description: Lisa Ann Alter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Alter of New York and Fire Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Joel Confino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Confino of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Irving J. Block performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre.

title: THE WIRING OF WALL STREET
description: STANDING WITH HIS BACK TO THE WINDOWS of his 44th-floor corner office, Peter J. Solomon - former United States Treasury official, former deputy mayor of New York City, current managing director of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb - ignores the magnificent view over the waterfront. Not many years ago, that panorama would have been chockablock with freighters and tankers, but time and technology have passed the port of New York by. Today, the harbor is all but empty.

title: SECURITY IS STRICT ON CITY COMPUTERS
description: It is an unusual scene for a city agency.

title: THEATER: HOLLAND'S 'JOHNSON'
description: Fred Holland's performance piece, ''Jack Johnson,'' seen Thursday night at the Franklin Furnace, was a well- meaning, ambitious, diffuse multimedia attempt to examine the significance of the first black heavyweight boxing champion.

title: SO FAR, GREENHOUSE EFFECT HEATS ONLY DEBATE
description: ''The ice caps are melting! The ice caps are melting! The oceans are rising and we'll all be drowned for our sins,'' sang the shrill-voiced Tiny Tim some 20 years ago.

title: HOLMES, IN LAST YEAR WITH JETS, FORSAKES CAUTION
description: Jerry Holmes is happy that he still gets sick before a game. Holmes expects to be sick at Shea Stadium today and not simply because the top-rated passer in pro football, the Atlanta Falcons' Steve Bartkowski, will be throwing into the Jets' secondary.

title:
DINING OUT;
BRANCH MOVES UP FROM THE U.N.
description: AFTER operating his Manhattan restaurant Hsin Yu (near the United Nations Building) for nine years, Fred Sye has opened a second eating establishment, this time in White Plains's sprawling Cross Roads Shopping Center on Route 119. Having a preference for the county life, Mr. Sye has stood in constant attendance at Bamboo Garden since its opening in February.

title: Navy Goes Overboard With Softball Order
description: The Navy ordered so many softballs at the end of the spending year that a Congressman has suggested that sailors must be playing games aboard carriers where ''it's difficult to retrieve home run balls.''

title: 2 JEWISH DOCTORS SUE TO JOIN SAUDI PROGRAM
description: A Federal District Court here is soon expected to take up a suit in which two doctors charge that the Baylor College of Medicine denied them lucrative employment at the King Faisal Specialist Hospital in Saudi Arabia because they are Jewish.

title: PANEL CITES LOSSES AT 2 STATE-RUN SKI AREAS
description: A state legislative commission reported this week that two state-owned skiing centers, one at Belleayre Mountain in the Catskills and the other at Gore Mountain in the Adirondacks, had lost $2.9 million over the last three years.

title: THE BEST-LAID PLANS
description: o you're going to have a party and the food is going to be irresistible and the guests fascinating. What could go wrong? Plenty. To start with, you could be cut dead by a lot of nice people who were invited last year, and the year before, but who didn't make this year's list. The guest list, especially for annual parties that have become almost traditional, is a veritable minefield in the best-laid plans of hosts and hostesses. The obvious question, of course, is why someone who merited an invitation in years past doesn't still merit one. And the first thing to clear up is that merit has nothing to do with it. The individual who has been crossed off the list hasn't changed from friend to enemy, or from a pleasant human being into a miserable wretch. What usually happens is that this nice person is simply less relevant to the host than he or she once was. It is, perhaps, a sad commentary on life today, and particularly on life in a big city, that people who once had a good deal in common drift apart, both personally and professionally.

title: Deer Park Triumphs, 13-0
description: Mike Koerner caught a screen pass for a touchdown, had 10 quarterback sacks and deflected a punt, giving Deer Park a 13-0 victory over William Floyd yesterday.

title: GEORGIA RALLY TOPS KENTUCKY BY 47-21
description: Georgia capitalized on four turnovers for 23 third-quarter points en route to a 47-21 victory over Kentucky in a Southeastern Conference game today.

title: WE MUST CHANGE THE JOBLESS-BENEFIT PLAN
description: NEW JERSEY'S unemployed citizens are returning to work. The construction business is booming. Earnings for the average factory worker are up. Unemployment claims are down.

title: FOR A YOUNG CARDIOLOGIST, AN ESSENTIAL RX IS COMPASSION
description: ''HOW are you feeling - any pain today?'' the cardiologist on morning rounds in the coronary-care unit asked. ''I feel pretty good - no pain, no nothing. The worst pain is when I get blood drawn,'' said Vincent Voltaggio of Rockville Centre, grimacing at the thought.

title: TOGUE TIED AT THE BAZAAR
description: WILLIAM FINNEGAN, a writer who lives in San Francisco, is writing a book about South Africa, to be published by Harper and Row.

title: SECURITY TEAMS SEEK WEAPONS IN DETROIT SCHOOL
description: Responding to rising violence, two five-member teams using hand-held metal detectors began checking students, their belongings and their lockers for weapons at high schools and some grade schools here this week.

title: Miss Bassett, W. H. Derby Are Married
description: Suzanne Sherman Bassett, daughter of Thomas A. Bassett of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., and the late Irene Sherman McCallum, was married yesterday to William Harlan Derby, son of Roger A. Derby Jr. of New York and Millbrook and the late Laurie Derby. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: ABOUT CARSMarshall Schuon
description: THE first time I saw the Dodge, it was

title: THE BUILD-DOWN BUILDUP
description: A new arms-control plan has been proposed: to destroy two old land-based missiles for every new one deployed. This idea, when originally put forward by Senator William Cohen of Maine, was dubbed a

title: FIGURING THE MORTGAGE COSTS A FAMILY'S INCOME CAN CARRY
description: WITH two young children and a third on the way, Kevin and Mary Ellen Adams decided it was time to move out of their two- bedroom apartment in Morris Plains, N.J., and into a house that could accommodate their growing family. A year ago, they started scanning the papers to check prices. Eventually, they went to a real-estate broker and decided on a house they felt they could afford.

title: Future Events
description: Parties and Sales

title: INDUSTRIAL 'POLICY'
description: There is a lot of argument these days about whether or not the United States should experiment with a national industrial policy. In fact, we already have such a policy - and have had one for most of the nation's life. Why not, then, have a coherent and competitive one? As a businessman, I feel that business and labor must do more to participate with the Government in developing such a policy.

title: REAGAN UNHURT AS ARMED MAN TAKES HOSTAGES
description: An armed man crashed through the gates of the Augusta National Golf Course today, took hostages and demanded to speak to President Reagan, who was playing the 16th hole at the time.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE PRIME EVIL OF THE FOREST PRIMEVAL
description: ''NOTHING is all bad,'' my grandmother used to tell me. Grandma was a direct descendant of Pollyanna. She wore blinders - and not just in memory of her horse. She departed these parts at the age of 100, mercifully missing at least one modern mess: roadway strew.

title: MODERN R.F.C.
description: To the Business Editor:

title: LAMENT IN LAS VEGAS
description: THE DESERT ROSE

title: A G.E. ALUMNUS SHAKES UP RUBBERMAID
description: WOOSTER, OHIO

title: Latin American Group Ends Talks in Panama
description: The Contadora group ended its meeting here today expressing profound concern over an increase in Central American violence.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TOUR OF 1692 TAVERN

title: WHO MAKES FOREIGN POLICY? --
description: If Zbigniew Brzezinski had served as Secretary of State instead of national security adviser, his reflections might have taken a different turn. For example, he might be struck by the fact that the Secretary of State has the constitutional responsibility (with the President) for foreign policy.

title: PEDROZA IS WINNER
description: Eusebio Pedroza of Panama retained his World Boxing Association featherweight title tonight with a unanimous 15-round decision over Jose Caba of the Dominican Republic.

title: PEACEKEEPERS BECOME ANOTHER WARRING FACTION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon WITHOUT anyone really noticing it at first, the Marines here have been transformed during the last month of fighting from a largely symbolic peacekeeping force - welcomed by all - to just one more faction in the internal Lebanese conflict. Between September 1982 and July 1983, one marine was killed and 10 wounded in Beirut clashes. In the last two months six American servicemen have died in action and 50 have been wounded - including one killed and nine injured last week.

title: Strike Threat at Greyhound
description: Unionized workers of the Greyhound Lines Inc. are being asked to authorize a strike if a new contract is not reached by Oct. 31, when the current agreement expires, union officials say.

title: JOBS PROGRAM EMPLOYED 2,500 YOUTHS
description: DESCRIBING this year's effort as a success, Dr. Charles E. Ziegler, chairman of the Summer Jobs for Youth program this year, has reported that more than 2,500 youths received summer employment through the project's direct placement and referral service.

title: CONCERT: SOLOS IN ELECTRONICS
description: The Public Access Synthesizer Studio in lower Manhattan produces a concert series in addition to providing instruction in electronic music, and on Thursday night, Elodie Lauten and Boris Policeband each offered some recent solo compositions.

title: Translation Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 23, 1983;  International
description: Opposition to new American missiles scheduled to be deployed in Europe at the end of the year drew protests across Western Europe. The peaceful protests in five West German cities were the biggest show of support to date for a loose antimissile coalition. Antimissile demonstrations were also held in London, Rome, Stockholm, Paris and Vienna. (Page 1, Col. 1.)

title: HOW TO LIVE IN A GREENHOUSE
description: Two rather different reports on the ''greenhouse effect'' were released in Washington last week. One holds that the process leading to a serious warming of the earth's atmosphere is already so firmly set in motion that nothing short of a ban on coal could prevent it. The other concludes it lies so far ahead that no preventive steps are even worth attempting for the next 20 years. Which group of scientists should be believed?

title: Olivia McElroy Becomes a Bride
description: Olivia McElroy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. McElroy of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. David Bruce DeLeo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arch A. DeLeo of Wilton, Conn. Judge James P. Connors Jr. of the Town Court of Eastchester, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Siwanoy Country Club.

title:
GARDENING;
BEHIND THE COLORS OF AUTUMN LEAVES
description: THE northeastern United States is recognized as one of the premier areas of the world for fall color. Its sugar and red maples and sweet and sour gums are among the outstanding trees for panoramas of gold, orange and scarlet foliage.

title: OFFICIALS SAY PRESIDENT IS UNLIKELY TO SEEK BIG DOMESTIC BUDGET CUTS
description: President Reagan, while continuing to blame Democrats for the Federal budget deficit, is viewed by senior aides as increasingly unlikely to seek major new cuts in domestic spending when he submits his election-year budget in January.

title: DARIEN IS BEATEN, 21-12
description: A large crowd gathered at Stamford Catholic's field yesterday to watch Catholic (5-0) take on Darien, the team leading the Eastern division of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference.

title: Rebels in Peru Launch Bomb Attacks in Lima
description: Leftist guerrillas detonated more than a dozen bombs in Lima tonight, killing at least 2 people and wounding more than 20 in attacks on an office of the ruling Popular Action Party, a police station and a bank, officials reported.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My son is 14 and they want to sell him drugs. It's a shame.'' - Ethel Kriss of Manhattan. (40:1.)

title: A CHANGE FOR THE BETTER
description: RISTORANTE SAN GIORGIO in Westbury changed ownership several months ago with notably good results. It was always an attractive place, with an understated formality that was not overbearing, but, despite the appeal of the setting, the food sampled on numerous occasions was inconsistent. When the restaurant was last reviewed about a year ago, the service had become quite careless.

title: MISSILE PROTESTERS JAM CENTRAL LONDON
description: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators jammed central London today in the largest protest against nuclear weapons in British history. The protest came only 10 days before the first American cruise missiles are reportedly due to arrive here.

title: CONCERT: SEQUOIA QUARTET
description: The Sequoia String Quartet's Friday evening performance at the Metropolitan Museum offered a varied sampling of the diverse talents of the violinists Yoko Matsuda and Miwako Watanabe, the violist James Dunham and the cellist Robert Martin.

title: PAPANDREOU KEEPS LEFT OF NATO
description: While other European governments struggle to control people demonstrating against weapons, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has serenely assumed the leadership of Greece's antinuclear movement. As the only NATO leader supporting the international campaign, he has urged a six-month delay in deploying American cruise and Pershing 2 missiles in Europe and has talked of forcing the removal of American nuclear weapons stockpiled in Greece. ''When they try to corner us and ask whether we are with the West or the East, our reply is: 'We are for peace,' '' Mr. Papandreou said last week at second anniversary celebrations of his electoral victory.

title: REPORTER GUILTY OF IMPERSONATING A GOVERNMENT OFFICIAL IN JERSEY
description: A 29-year-old reporter in Morris County, N.J., has been convicted of impersonating a government official.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE CHILDREN OF THE SUN

title: Miss Platt, A Writer, Is Married
description: Helen Hartley Platt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian T. Platt of Madison, N.J., was married there yesterday to Eleuth ere Paul duPont 3d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. E. Paul duPont Jr. The Rev. Hayward Levy performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: MUSIC: EASTMAN PIANO PIECE
description: The composer Julius Eastman has been concentrating on vocal works recently. He didn't sing a note during the 40-minute piano piece, ''His Most Qualityless Majesty,'' that he played Thursday at Roulette, but the music was thoroughly vocalistic.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DEAR MR. HENSHAW

title: FALL: WHEN PARENTS GO BACK TO SCHOOL
description: IF you have a batch of kids in

title: A WAR STORY THAT IS BETTER READ
description: ''THEY danced, they loved, they sang their way through World War II.'' So reads the advertising copy for the late C. P. Taylor's ''And a Nightingale Sang,'' presented by the Hartford Stage Company. It reflects just what the late British playwright must have had in mind, except that they bickered a lot, too.

title: Ellen Ameling Watts Is Married in Boston
description: Ellen Ameling Watts and Daniel Steven Bernstein, architects in Boston, were married at their home there yesterday by Justice of the Peace Judith Craven.

title: ; OFFER THE CONDEMNED A 'FATAL DRAUGHT'z
description: To the Editor:

title: FORGING A COED TRADITION AT CLINTON
description: A student at DeWitt Clinton had a button pinned to her gray sweater, the sort of button that booster clubs sell to raise funds and school spirit. ''Clinton Has Tradition,'' the red circle proclaimed. But just a year ago, tradition at Clinton meant all male.

title: ARIZONA STATE IS UPSET, 31-21
description: Kerry Porter scored two second-half touchdowns to help Washington State upset Arizona State, 31-21, in a Pacific-10 Conference game tonight.

title: Farmer's Body Exhumed In Slaying Investigation
description: The body of a man who the authorities said committed suicide while being sought in the slaying of two Minnesota bankers has been exhumed from a grave in western Texas at the request of investigators.

title: Margaret T. Corbin and Brian J. McNally Marry
description: At St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday, Margaret Talcott Corbin, daughter of the late Marion T. Francis and the late William H. Corbin, both of Morristown, N.J., was married to Brian John McNally, son of Genevieve McNally of Loudonville, N.Y., and the late Josph P. McNally. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James H. Purdy.

title:
HOME DESIGN;
A STEP BACK
description: ONG REVILED AS A SEAson when the ugly interior reigned supreme, the Victorian era has recently emerged as a source of inspiration to decorators. Fashion is not the omnivorous consumer it often seems. Though admittedly styles have a way of plummeting to their nadir scant minutes after having reached their zenith, the discards of the past are constantly up for review, and the canny eye has a way of retrieving a recyclable essence, even as it filters out the unredeemable.

title: POLY PREP (6-0) DEFEATS MCBURNEY, 42-14
description: Poly Prep, which had an unusual losing season last year with a 2-6 record, has got back on the winning track. The Brooklyn school brought its record to 6-0 yesterday by rolling over McBurney, 42-14, in front of a Parents Day crowd on its home field.

title: CITY PONDERS FUTURE COURSE ON ZONING
description: AT the very time that a mayoral commission is studying the process by which

title: ARSENIC LIMITS NEAR TACOMA SMELTER SOUGHT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's proposal for reducing emissions of arsenic from a copper smelter here does not go far enough, regional officials say.

title: MODERN ARRANGEMENTS
description: AMERICAN COUPLES

title: SNYDER DEFEATS NORTH BERGEN, 13-6
description: Larry Rodgers ran for 2 touchdowns in the second half as Snyder of Jersey City (6-0) beat North Bergen, 13-6, for the first time since 1966, at North Hudson Park in North Bergen.

title: CELEBRITIES IN COMPOSED DISARRAY
description: There is something about Annie Leibovitz that inspires people to reveal themselves. Since 1970, when her photographs first started appearing in Rolling Stone, hordes of celebrities have disported themselves before her camera in wry, often semi-clad, usually uncharacteristic poses. In her first published collection, ANNIE LEIBOVITZ: PHOTOGRAPHS (Pantheon/Rolling Stone Press, $35), Miss Leibovitz shows us the likes of Steve Martin, Bob Dylan, Bette Midler, Robert Redford and John Irving in various stages of composed disarray: 69 portraits of movie stars, athletes, singers and writers in terms alternately mundane, whimsical, self-parodying. We see through the traditional celebrity shots to what Tom Wolfe, in his splendid introduction, calls the ''raw vital proles'' beneath.

title: CAVEATS IN HIRING A CONTRACTOR
description: MORE householders hire remodeling contractors during this final quarter of the year than in any other season, according to the National Association of Home Builders. And the value of the work they are doing is soaring. Census figures show that expenditures on remodeling and improvements done by professionals have increased fivefold in a decade, from $5.9 billion in 1972 to $30.4 billion last year.

title: Liberian Official Is Dismissed For Setting Conditions on Job
description: The newly appointed secretary general of Liberia's ruling People's Redemption Council has been relieved of the job and dismissed from the army for setting conditions on his appointment, the Monrovia radio reported today.

title: Golf Honor to Sutton
description: Hal Sutton was on the course playing in the second round of the $400,000 Walt Disney World Golf Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., when he got the news on Friday that he had become the Professional Golf Association's player of the year. Sutton, the tour's top money-winner ($425,148) who won the P.G.A. and the Tournament Players titles this year, clinched the award when Calvin Peete , the only one with a chance of overtaking him in the point standing, withdrew from the Disney after an opening 73.

title: PORTRAIT OF A PHOTOGRAPHER AS A YOUNG ARTIST
description: Vicki Goldberg is writing a biography of Margaret Bourke-White.

title: Christina Dunbar Wed To a Transit Official
description: Christina Marie Dunbar, daughter of Eustace Charles Dunbar and Gwendolyn Russell Dunbar, both of New York, was married yesterday to Burtel Darryl Batson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burtel Joseph Batson of Brooklyn. Canon Charles A. Carter performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Chapel of St. James at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: CRAFT OR ART? THE BLURRY LINE IS EVEN BLURRIER
description: NEWARK THE blurring of distinctions between ''art'' and ''craft'' is commonly acknowledged on both sides of the vacillating line that keeps them in separate camps - and galleries.

title: SKIING TO A WINTER PICNIC
description: Picnicking, some would contend, is more a state of mind than of location. A sandwich next to a corporate fountain downtown or a cup of yogurt in a museum courtyard qualifies if one carries to them the right spirit. Similarly, a few notches on the thermometer - give or take, say, 50 degrees - should not necessarily nullify this most elemental dining pleasure.

title: AN ANCHORING DEVICE THAT WORKS IN HOLLOW OR SOLID WALLS
description: -it-yourselfers are familiar with conventional metal expansion anchors and toggle bolts that are used for hanging or mounting things on hollow walls and ceilings of plaster or drywall. But many are not familiar with a newer type of plastic anchor that combines the advantages of both types - and can also be used in solid walls of brick, concrete or cement block.

title: W.P.A. Guides
description: To the Editor:

title: VAST CROWDS HOLD RALLIES IN EUROPE AGAINST U.S. ARMS
description: In a day of protests across Western Europe, hundreds of thousands of people demonstrated against the deployment of new American medium-range missiles at the end of this year.

title: THE CHURCH IN BRAZIL
description: The shantytowns of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo don't see many international bankers but last week their influence was being felt by millions of normally ebullient Brazilians who despairingly contemplated austerity in the midst of 200 percent inflation.

title: BITTER AFTERTASTES OF THE COLUMBUS SAGA
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN APPLE PICKERS STIR WEST VIRGINIA DISPUTE
description: In another sign of autumn in West Virginia's Eastern Panhandle, the apples are ripe and ready to pick and the pickers and the growers are back in court fighting over the hiring of foreign migrant labor.

title:
THE WORLD;
JORDANIANS TO THE RESCUE?
description: The Reagan Administration's secret plan to prepare a strike force of Jordanians, revealed in part two weeks ago in Israel, lost more of its cover last week. Government officials said training had been under way for 30 months without Congressional authorization.

description: Saudis and foreigners alike flocked recently to Redec Plaza, one of the city's shopping malls, to say farewell to Joe Horton, an artist who had decided after seven years in Saudi Arabia to return to New York City to study art.

description: An inmate has confessed abducting and killing 6-year-old Adam Walsh in 1981, according to the police here. His parents' efforts to help other families with missing children led to enactment of a Federal law and a television movie about their ordeal.

title: SAILOR'S TREASURE
description: he Eastern Shore of Maryland is traditionally capitalized for a reason, for it is a land unto itself. Only since 1952, when the Bay Bridge was built, has it been connected, tenuously, to the mainland of the state. On a map, it resembles a giant crab claw reaching down southward into the Chesapeake Bay. From a plane, it looks more like a big, lacy green leaf. Its edge is serrated into a labyrinthian pattern of points and coves; a network of backwaters, rivers and creeks intrudes far inland; everywhere land and water intertwine. With thousands of miles of shoreline, it is no wonder that the life of the Eastern Shore is focused intensely around the Bay. Houses - stately old colonial manors, farmhouses and shacks - are set at water's edge. Travel is often conducted by water. Docks are as commonplace as picket fences. And at the end of almost every dock is a dinghy, sailboat or log canoe, along with a stash of crab pots.

title: Driving Abroad

title: ; RUTH PRAWER JHABVALA'S WRITING
description: Bernard Weinraub quotes Ruth Prawer Jhabvala as saying that Indians have tended to ignore or criticize her because her work depicts Indian society as less than a paradise on earth (''The Artistry of Ruth Prawer Jhabvala,'' Sept. 11).

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times Double-Ring Ceremony
description: AS the Baltimore Orioles' owner, Edward Bennett Williams now has earned a World Series ring to accompany his Super Bowl XVII ring as the Washington Redskins' president. But this is an unprecedented double-ring ceremony that will not occur.

title: HarlemandNewHavenLines Snarled by Bronx Derailment
description: A southbound Metro-North Commuter Railroad train on the Harlem line derailed yesterday at 10:20 A.M. near the Melrose station in the Bronx, halting all traffic on the Harlem and New Haven lines for more than an hour. There was no local service in the Bronx by southbound Harlem line trains from the time of the accident until 7:30 P.M.

title: HEARTY SOUPS

Give me a bowl of hot soup made with beans or bones, fish or fowl, meat or game, and I find it time to cry comfort and peace on earth where the appetite is concerned.

description: Music like John Driscoll's ''Pieces of Second Mesa,'' at Roulette Friday night, fills and decorates a given space much as an architect furnishes a room. Mr. Driscoll's taped effects reached out from stationary loudspeakers at different ends of Roulette's performing space and continuously altered it with changing configurations of sound.

title: CONSUMER RATES
ADVOCATE: PRAISE, CRITICISM
description: WHEN R. William Potter, assistant commissioner of the state's Department of the Public Advocate, announced that he could not stay for dinner at the annual meeting of the New Jersey Utilities Association last June, there were, he said, cheers among the diners.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: For the traveler, dropping temperatures mean lower air fares to Europe. Generally speaking, summertime fares are the highest of the year; fall and winter fares - except at Christmastime - the lowest of the year. This year, because of inflationary pressures, many winter fares will rise after the year-end holiday, and they most likely will rise again in late spring. So, with the dollar strong abroad, the incentive to visit the Continent now - with opera, ballet, concerts and theater abounding - becomes even greater than in some past years. (Remember that fares, as one airline official said, ''run up and down like a window blind'' and may change without notice.)

title: G.O.P. FLEXING ITS MUSCLES WITH KEAN
description: On his television commercials, Robert Brennan of First Jersey Securities Inc. boasts that he is always on the lookout for growth companies. Even in his spare time, the financier appears to be attuned to organizations with potential. One of his recent leisure-time investments is the New Jersey Republican Party.

title: MET SERENADES ITSELF FOR 100TH BIRTHDAY
description: The Metropolitan Opera gave itself the grandest of parties yesterday - a two-part, daylong concert with a heady assortment of the world's most famous opera singers, all in celebration of the 100th birthday to the day of the company's first performance.

GARDENING;
BEHIND THE COLORS OF AUTUMN LEAVES
description: THE northeastern United States is recognized as one of the premier areas of the world for fall color. Its sugar and red maples and sweet and sour gums are among the outstanding trees for panoramas of gold, orange and scarlet foliage.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Extortion Defense James Lewis wrote a letter to Johnson & Johnson demanding $1 million in the Tylenol murder case last year, but he didn't really want the money, his attorney said last week. Mr. Lewis, who is on trial for extortion in Chicago but has not been implicated in the murders, contended he wrote the letter only to get even with his wife's former employer, a travel agent who paid workers off with bad checks before going out of business. His letter instructed the Tylenol manufacturer to deposit the money in a certain bank account, which, it developed, belonged to the travel agency.

Vincent Sordillo of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Dr. Sordillo, and Roger Niles Pearse Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pearse of Concord, Mass., and Hancock, Me., were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Neil Connolly, Vicar of the South Bronx, performed the ceremony at the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: TOURING THE COUNTY FROM PALACES TO PUBS
description: JAMES MILDREN reports for The Western Morning News, the regional daily newspaper in the west of England. Getting There T he county of Dorset in England's West Country is easily accessible by car, rail or express bus. From London the M3 motorway siphons its traffic into the A30 trunk road north of Winchester and, once past the spire of Salisbury Cathedral, the driver sees the rolling hills of Dorset stretching southward to the English Channel. Dorchester, the center of Thomas Hardy's literary landscape, is 122 miles from London; the coast, at Weymouth, is another eight miles to the south. Trains run frequently between London's Waterloo Station and Weymouth (round-trip fare, $70, first class; $39, second class); the National Express bus service from London's Victoria Coach Station to Weymouth costs $18 round trip. The journey by train, bus or car will take about 2 hours and 45 minutes. Sherborne Of all Dorset towns, Sherborne has survived as the least spoiled and it makes a good center from which to tour the county. It has a variety of accommodations, from the 60- room Post House Hotel (phone, 093581-3191), priced at $66 for a double room, and breakfast, to the homey comfort of the Riverside Guest House (093581-2046), $15 a person for bed and breakfast. The town's 12th-century fortified palace, now a romantic ruin, is open year round on weekdays (admission 45 cents). It is separated by a lake from Sir Walter Raleigh's mansion of the late 16th century (open daily June to September, 2 to 6 P.M; $1.50).

title: Rosalie Ripley to Wed R. H. Reventlow
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Louis R. Ripley of Litchfield, Conn., of the engagement of her daughter, Rosalie Wagstaff Ripley, to Richard Haugwitz Hardenberg-Reventlow, son of Mrs. Stanford Brent of Litchfield and New York and the late Count Court Haugwitz Hardenberg-Reventlow. The wedding is to be Dec. 10.

title: REDFORD'S FILM LAB IN THE ROCKIES
description: None of the staff members at Robert Redford's Sundance Institute, near Provo, Utah, remember who first began calling the boss Ordinary Bob. Some say it must have been the comedian Cheech, of Cheech and Chong. Others think it was a famous film actor, who no longer comes around. Sterling VanWagenen, a Redford in-law and Sundance's executive director, guesses it was a kind of spontaneous communal joke, born one purple and gold afternoon when Redford, returning from a flying business trip to Los Angeles, descended in his helicopter toward the lower slopes of Mt. Timpanogos, the sun gilding the famous red-blond hair, a dozen earnest film makers gathered in discussion groups on the beautiful meadow, a de facto audience . . . .

title: Elissa Gretz To Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Gretz Jr. of Schenectady, N.Y., and Dennisport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elissa Margaret Gretz, to Robert James Friedman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Friedman of New York and Waccabuc, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: FISHERMEN SEEK CLEARER PCB RULES
description: ALONG with New Jersey's other charter boat captains, Howard Bogen of Brielle still marvels with more than mild expletive at the decision of the state's Department of Environmental Protection to announce an advisory on the consumption of bluefish.

title:
ART;
SOME METICULOUS STEICHEN IN HARTSDALE
description: -FIVE photographs by Edward Steichen from a new, posthumously printed edition of his works are on view through Oct. 29 at the Alan Brown Gallery in Hartsdale.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PARIS
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: Shoplifters to Get Tickets
description: Shoplifters in Cleveland will no longer be arrested for first offenses but will instead receive a citation similar to a traffic ticket, officials say. Police Chief William Hanton said Thursday that the procedure would free officers for more serious crimes. Under the old system all shoplifters were arrested, jailed and released after posting bail.

title: PENN HANDS YALE 6TH LOSS IN ROW, 17-0
description: Pennsylvania registered a 17-0 victory over Yale today that accomplished at least two things: It was the first triumph for a Penn team at Yale Bowl since 1962 and it left the Red and Blue half a game behind first-place Dartmouth, the season's final opponent, in the Ivy League standing.

title: REAGAN STEPS CLOSER TO '84
description: Ronald Reagan made it legal last week but still not official. Signing two letters, one authorizing his friend Senator Paul Laxalt to establish a campaign committee and the other informing the Federal Election Committee that the Laxalt committee is indeed ''my principle campaign committee'' made the President a candidate for re-election by the letter of the law.

title: 48-POINT QUARTER BY NEBRASKA
description: Top-ranked Nebraska scored 28 points in the first 5 minutes 30 seconds of the third quarter and finished with 48 points in that period to rout Colorado, 69-19, in a Big Eight Conference game today.

title: SOME LOSERS IN SILICON VALLEY SAID TO FIND WEALTH IN SPYING
description: In what used to be a lush agricultural valley, where specks of sand started a new California gold rush in which it seemed almost anyone could become a millionaire, James Durward Harper Jr. and William Bell Hugle were among the losers.

title: BOARD RACES ARE EXPECTED TO FAVOR THE G.O.P.
description: WESTCHESTER voters, electing a new County Legislature this year, will be dealing with new districts, redrawn to conform to the 1980 population census, and new faces, but they may produce a political lineup much like the old one.

title: RURAL EXCLUSIVITY ON STATEN ISLAND
description: Within the confines of a 12-acre parcel of land defined by an imposing 5-foot brick wall, a Staten Island developer is erecting 30 custom- built homes in a wooded area in the Princess Bay section of the borough just off Seguine Avenue between Amboy Road and Hylan Boulevard.

title: REACTION IS SLIGHT TO SABBATH RULING
description: SIX weeks ago the State Supreme Court overturned a law giving workers the right to a day of rest, but other than a boycott by a minister against the retailer whose lawsuit sparked the decision, the response from the religious community has been subdued.

title: COMPUTER LISTS HEALTH HAZARDS
description: APHYSICIAN who sees a lot of travelers in his practice near the University of Connecticut at Storrs has put a computer to work to help protect his patients against tropical diseases.

title: Miss Bricker Is Affianced

title: Leslie Ann Moraller Wed To Neil Krauter in Jersey

Winant 3d of Manhattan. The Rev. David Watermulder performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: STATE'S HOUSING GROWTH CITED
description: SPURRED largely by money from financial institutions in the state, New Jersey's residential real-estate activity has experienced a healthy growth in the last several years with the construction of condominiums and single-family homes.

title: A VISIT TO THE PERIGORD COUNTRY
description: This is cassoulet country, the land of truffle oaks and walnuts, wild cepe mushrooms and the golden, French fatted goose. The table that Marie Paule Malaurie has set in her stone house in the hilly village of St. Cyprien typifies the cuisine of the Perigord in France's southwest: rich, hearty, robust and copious. The cassoulet, a warming blend of white beans, pork sausages and preserved goose, has been gently simmering near the open fire for hours. Fat black truffles are about to be swaddled in barding fat, then paper or foil, ready for tucking into the hot, gray cinders. Mrs Malaurie, an elegant, white-haired, natural-born cook, is about to begin the day's soup, a simple but full-flavored tourain,, a peasant's blend of onions and garlic, tomatoes, eggs and vinegar. Visitors help by slicing the fole gras, then the thick, four-pound loaf of country bread, and soon the house will be alive with sounds and aromas of the southwestern feast.

title: FEMALE CANDIDATES LAG IN NUMBERS
description: FEWER women are running in the Nov. 8 municipal elections than had been anticipated, according to state political leaders. A recent listing of candidates running for Mayor or First Selectman shows that fewer than 20 percent are women.

title: N. ROCKLAND CELEBRATES
description: As members of the very first North Rockland team watched, the current team continued to overpower its opponents, shutting out Spring Valley yesterday, 21-0, for its 24th straight victory.

title: DANCE IS THRIVING IN FRANCE THESE DAYS
description: Like the Sleeping Beauty, herself the heroine of a 17th-century French fairy tale, dance in France has awakened after 100 years. On a brief trip to Paris this month, I found the burgeoning dance activity so strong that it was not unusual to hear remarks such as ''I have the impression that dance is stagnating in the United States. France is the center now.'' The first statement is dubious. But the second assumption - and one that came from a manager very sympathetic to American dance and whose firm presents American dancers - is one to bear in mind for the 1980's.

title: '84 Wedding Set By Miss Franklin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Franklin of Garrett Park, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Franklin, to George William Van Tassel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Tassel of Cold Spring, N.Y.

description: -RANGING study of the state government that Governor Kean has received from business leaders could become the basis for important changes in government operations or the blueprint for further political battling between the Kean administration and Democratic legislative leaders.

description: At a ceremony honoring Lech Walesa at the Waldorf Astoria Friday night, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said American foreign policy was harmed by an ''intellectual confusion'' about the nature of the Soviet Union.

description: For those who like good food in hearty portions, it is time to enjoy. The cold soups and salads of summertime have vanished, or at least been reduced to the rank of side dishes, and on come the roasts and the casseroles and their weighty peers.
