description: Union, behind a stubborn defense and the passing of Guido Petruzzelli, handed Edison a 14-0 shutout yesterday in Union in a match between two of the strongest football teams in the state.

title: SOVIET SEEKS TO LAY BLAME FOR ICE CRISIS
description: With a two-week struggle to save more than 40 Soviet ships trapped in Arctic ice nearing an end, the Communist Party daily Pravda has set aside the drama and heroics of earlier accounts and turned to apportioning blame for the crisis among Government bureaucracies.

title: TOWNS PREPARE BRIDGE CLAIMS
description: THE rumbling trucks of last summer, diverted around a bridge collapse on Interstate 95, no longer clog the streets in Greenwich or across the state line in Port Chester, N.Y. But they left wear on local pavements and stress on municipal budgets that both communities want help to fix.

title: GUATEMALAN OUSTS HIS MILITARY CHIEF
description: Guatemala's leader, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, has dismissed the chief of his armed forces, according to an army communique.

title: DIAMOND JUBILEE FOR TWAIN LIBRARY
description: ''SEVENTY-FIVE years young,'' the Mark Twain Library calls itself, and in celebration of its diamond jubilee, the institution in Redding has invited the public to an open house this afternoon, from 4 to 6.

title:
THE REGION;
COMPLEX CASE OF BABY JANE DOE
description: Doctors, lawyers, judges and next of kin have sometimes found themselves at odds over whether or when medical equipment artificially sustaining terminally ill patients should be withdrawn. Last week on Long Island, the issue seemed even more difficult: Should surgeons intervene to prolong the life of a severely deformed infant?

title: 'ZORBA' IS NO CLASSIC, BUT QUINN MAY BE
description: Not long ago I saw a revival of ''Hair,'' and could not believe it was the same show that had sent me skipping into the street back in 1968. What had felt so liberating suddenly seemed puny, sniveling and worse: an infantile celebration of a ''now'' generation which time had mercifully relegated to the ranks of the thens, a tawdry paean to stoned simpletons. ''Hair,'' like many another acclaimed musical, had not weathered well. Nor, for that matter, had the 1960's.

title: CRIME
description: Let's take a look at some private eyes, and we'll start with THE GLASS HIGHWAY by Loren D. Estleman (Houghton Mifflin, $13.95). This is the fourth in the series featuring Amos Walker, the Detroit operative. He is hired by a television anchorman to find a missing (adult) son. Walker promptly finds him, but the case does not end there. A girl who is a drug addict enters the picture, there is a murder, and Walker finds himself helping the murder suspect. Knighthood is still in flower.

title: THE HUNTER'S BOUNTY
description: n heaven,'' John Donne said, ''it is alwaies Autumne.'' Conversely, there is probably nothing on earth that discloses the season's celestial side better than a hunt with good friends. Crisp fall breezes waft away cares, the rays of the southering sun bathe everyone in flattering sidelight, and patience replaces rush as the order of the day. True enough, some hunters tire of tramping sooner than others and not all are equally good shots. But such inequities seldom spoil the sport: With any luck at all, there is always the hunt dinner to make up for them.

title: PRESSURES BUILD ON TEEN-AGE SKATING RIVALS
description: THEY may nod, even smile, when they

title: Modern R.F.C.
description: To the Business Editor:

title: OH, THE JOYS OF BEING A SENIOR CITIZEN
description: IT is simply greed that makes me

title: SCARSDALE SOCCER FITNESS ROUTINE PAYS OFF IN AN 83-GAME STREAK
description: There are no practices this fall for the girls' soccer team at Scarsdale, but that is not because Coach Art Resnick is feeling smug about his team's 83-game winning streak. Girls' soccer is played in the spring at Scarsdale, and the fall is a season of hard work of a different type.

title: Mother Gets Death Penalty
description: A 23-year-old woman convicted of burning her two young sons to death to collect $10,000 in insurance has been sentenced to die by electrocution. Judge Peter Economus of Mahoning County Common Pleas Court ordered Rosalie Grant to be transported to the Marysville Reception Center in Columbus to face electrocution by Dec. 21.

title: PEACE AND PROMISE FOR 42ND STREET
description: After a stormy honeymoon, the state-city marriage to redevelop Manhattan's 42d Street seems to be going smoothly. The head of the City Planning Commission, Herbert Sturz, and of the state's Urban Development Corporation, William Stern, deserve credit for overcoming their early difficulties and agreeing on a development team for the major elements in the plan.

title: YOU ARE YOUR NUMBER
description: When the credit-card company sent a bill of several thousand dollars for first- class airline tickets I was naturally offended. I respected my credit-card company so much that I never left home without its card. I wanted my credit-card company to respect me and thought it did. But now - this monstrous allegation. So that was what my credit-card company really thought of me, was it?

title: GEORGE VECSEYSports of The Times No. 303 for Marathon Man
description: SY MAH runs in marathons the way some people go to the movies: maybe once a weekend, maybe twice, sometimes even three if there are good ones nearby. The 57-year-old man has run 302 marathons going into today's New York City Marathon, more than 100 more than anybody else, according to Fred Lebow of the New York Road Runners Club.

title: REPORT CALLS FOR BETTER PROCEDURES IN THE TESTING OF ANTICANCER DRUGS
description: The Food and Drug Administration needs to improve procedures for protecting patients in the testing of anticancer drugs, Congressional investigators have reported.

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY TO SELL DOCUMENTS
description: DRAWINGS of Robert Fulton's ingenious submarines and naval armaments, autographs of all the signers of the Declaration of Independence and letters of Abraham Lincoln are some of the items being sold by the New Jersey Historical Society.

title: TRAINING MUSICAL ENGINEERS
description: Musicians and engineers, met at recording sessions, sometimes confront each other like alien tribes, different in thought and language. Especially in recording classical music, their mutual incomprehension often gets in the way of good results.

title: WHO DECIDES ON WAR?
description: Jacob K. Javits, former United States Senator from New York, is of counsel to Trubin, Sillcocks, Edelman & Knapp, a New York law firm. This article was written with the assistance of Don Kellerman, Mr. Javits's former administrative assistant, who lives and works in Washington.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: CAUTION and precision were top priorities when Westchester and Bronx teen-agers participated in the 15th yearly high school driver-safety motorama, which was held last Sunday at Yonkers High School. The event, designed and coordinated by Brother George L. Mathews , chairman of the driver-education department of the Mount St. Michael Academy in the Bronx, tested the skills students had learned in driver-education courses.

title: SKEPTICISM LINGERS ON EFFECT OF CHANGE IN AUTO INSURANCE
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH Governor Kean hailed it as a ''victory for the common good,'' skepticism persists over the Legislature's passage early this month of a package of automobile-insurance bills.

title: 'EXPERT' DEFENSE WITNESS ADMITS LYING TO JURY ABOUT CREDENTIALS
description: A 69-year-old man who posed as an expert defense witness in more than 50 criminal trials around the country has pleaded guilty to lying about his academic credentials before four Brooklyn trial juries from 1979 to 1982. He was promised probation at his sentencing next month.

title: FOR CONGRESS, PRIORITIES SHIFT AS TIME FLIES
description: In a speech to stockbrokers last week, Representative Barber B. Conable, ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, propounded the conventional wisdom on budget discipline. ''Congress is a crisis-activated institution,'' he said, and ''we need to have a greater consensus of crisis before we can expect action.'' Conventionally was just how Congress was behaving. Racing toward the end of this year's legislating session so they can get home again to campaign for next year's elections, the lawmakers were more eager to spend than tax, and notably reluctant to challenge the White House.

title: HOLLAND TUNNEL REPAIRS SET
description: JERSEY CITY WORK on replacing and repairing the Holland Tunnel's 57-year-old concrete ceiling will begin in late November or early December and force the closing of one of its two tubes, administrators of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said last week.

title: House Votes Vietnam Medal
description: The House has unanimously approved legislation directing the Treasury to design and sell at cost medals honoring American troops who served in the Vietnam war. Under the bill, which the House sent to the Senate Tuesday, the design of the gold, silver, and bronze medals would be chosen in consultation with recognized organizations representing Vietnam veterans and would have to be approved by the National Commission on Fine Arts.

title: U.S. Agency Will Investigate Safety of Metal Chimneys
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission plans to investigate factory-built metal chimneys, saying they have been associated with 21,500 home fires in 1981.

title: COMPUTER ENTRIES INDENTIFIED BY F.B.I.
description: The Federal authorities engaged in a nationwide investigation of unauthorized entry into computers say that intruders have tampered with the electronic mail of about 18 corporations and Government agencies that subscribe to the same communications service.

title: LITERARY VIGILANTES
description: The Folger Shakespeare Library bookstore in Washington recently exhibited dozens of titles from ''King Lear'' to ''Gulliver's Travels'' under the heading ''500 Years of Banned Books.'' And the New York University bookstore displayed life- size cutouts of literary characters standing behind prison bars to remind people of books that have been challenged by censorship groups in this country. The ''guilty'' included Mary Poppins, Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Dolittle, Wilbur and Charlotte from ''Charlotte's Web,'' Dorothy from ''The Wizard of Oz'' and, appropriately, Alice in Wonderland.

title: MICHIGAN ACTS TO PREVENT DIVERSION OF WATER
description: Michigan officials have begun a major effort to block diversion of water from the Great Lakes to the Sun Belt or anywhere else.

title: No Headline
description: ROBERT SWEENY

title: A FINAL GOODBYE TO A FRIEND
description: AWEEK ago, while more than 32,000 racing fans journeyed to Belmont Park to watch Slew o' Gold and Devil's Bag wrap up some Eclipse awards, I tagged along, more than anything else, to seek out some old friends.

title: AMERICAN ENVOYS GOING TO GRENADA
description: Two United States diplomats left Barbados today to visit Grenada at the invitation of the Government to look into the safety of United States nationals living on the island.

title: MUSICAL: ROCK-AND-ROLL 'DEMENTOS' AT GUINEVERE
description: The Hotel Del Rio, a seedy midtown welfare hotel, is the setting for ''Dementos,'' a lively new rock-and-roll musical at Theater Guinevere. Some of its residents, like Charles, a pimp, and his prostitute Precious, plan to move up in the world - to the nearest motel. Ruby, an over-the-hill male hustler, nourishes various money- making schemes, while the Cuban transvestite Maria is saving her pennies for a sex-change operation. Spike, a would-be rock singer turned prostitute, contents herself with writing poems with titles like ''I Saw God.''

title: RUNNING A BOOT CAMP FOR WRITING
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY typed standing up at a counter that overlooked the ocean. Balzac wrote at night, gulping one cup of coffee after another. Gogol kept a basket of spoiled apples on his desk while he worked. Despite their oddities, all these writers had one thing in common: they wanted to get a lot of words on paper.

title: CHOOSING A PERONIST REVIVAL OR MIDDLE-CLASS POLICIES
description: After seven years of military rule, Argentina is to hold its first elections in a decade next Sunday. According to polls, two presidential candidates, Raul Alfonsin and Italo A. Luder, are likely to split most of the vote in a close race. Either will inherit a nation in such turmoil that last week the beleaguered Government of President Reynaldo B. Bignone raised the possibility of moving up the inauguration of the new Government from Jan. 30 to late December.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DALI DESIGNS 1984 OLYMPIC MEDALS
description: World-famous artist Salvador Dali has designed a series of gold, silver and platinum medals to commemorate the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. The medals carry the official endorsement of the United States Olympic Committee and part of the proceeds from their sale will go to that organization.

title: PLAN TO COMPUTERIZE COURTS PROPOSED BY KEAN FOR JERSEY
description: Governor Kean and Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court have outlined a plan to save New Jersey an estimated $54 million over the next nine years by fully computerizing the court system.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  2 Royals Explain Plea
description: Lawyers representing Willie Aikens and Willie Wilson said that the two Kansas City Royals, to avoid protracted publicity and the uncertainties of a trial on more serious charges, had pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges of attempting to posesss cocaine. ''You could spend a year fighting this, and in the meantime, what's going to happen to your career and reputation,'' James Kelly , who represented Aikens, and David Russell , who represented Wilson, told The Kansas City Times. Authorities have said that Aikens, Wilson and Jerry Martin , a Royal outfielder who has been released, were overheard on wiretapped phone conversations ordering cocaine from a man who has been indicted on charges of conspiring to sell the drug.

title: LEHIGH UPSETS ARMY, 13-12
description: An Army gamble with a 2-point conversion that failed came back to haunt the Cadets today as they lost to Lehigh, 13-12, for the first time since 1893.

title: Tar Heels on a Roll
description: Dean Smith , the North Carolina basketball coach, says it must be a record: His Tar Heels won 3 games in 50 hours. The victories, one on Wednesday and two on Thursday, took place in Salonica, Greece, where the team has been taking part in an international tournament.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture on page 36 of The Times Magazine today, showing Elie Wiesel at the 92d Street Y, carries an incorrect credit. It is by William Coupon.

title: A LIFE AHEAD OF ITS TIME
description: LAURA Z

title: 'JEWISH TERRORISM' A NEW ISSUE FOR ISRAEL
description: In recent months Israeli authorities have started investigating what they describe as the possibility that a small group of ''Jewish terrorists'' has operated against Arabs in the occupied West Bank.

title: CHILD-ABUSE STUDY IS CRITICAL OF CITY
description: A two-year study of violent and suspicious childhood deaths suggests that two to three children under 6 years of age are dying each week in New York City as a result of parental abuse or chronic neglect and the failure of private and city agencies to intervene.

title: THE DEADLY MYTHS ABOUT COCAINE
description: JUSTIFIED as is public preoccupation with AIDS, the national alarm over that ailment has overshadowed the fact that another ominous epidemic is sweeping the country, one that is much more widespread than AIDS and which devastates not only its victims but their families as well.

title: A GLITTERING SUCCESS
description: Beads and sequins have become best Beads and sequins have become best sellers this fall at all price from $250 separates to designer gowns costing thousands of dollars. Left: Ellin Saltzman, Saks Fifth Avenue executive, in a beaded dress loaded with sewn- on pearl necklaces. Right: Vogue's fashion editor, Polly Mellen, in a short pailletted dress by Geoffrey Beene. In front of her, another woman sparkles in black sequins.

title: HOCK IS TIED WITH STEWART
description: Scott Hoch made his seventh birdie of the round in a driving rain, completed a 6-under-par 66 and tied Payne Stewart for the third-round lead today in the $400,000 Walt Disney World golf tournament.

title: Loud Swearing Ruled Constitutional Right
description: The First Amendment protects a person's right to use loud and obscene language as long as it is not aimed at provoking trouble, the Missouri Supreme Court has ruled.

title: TOP LEGISLATORS FROM 27 STATES GET A TOUCH OF BOSTON POLITICS
description: At the end of the first day of classes on Monday night, when William M. (Billy) Bulger, president of the Massachusetts Senate, raised his baritone at dinner in the lilting strains of an Irish song, the new leaders of half the legislatures in the United States smiled, enjoying it.

title: ...AND SMALL HOTELS OF CHARACTER
description: PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Rome.

title: Data Bank; October 23, 1983
Laura M. E. McGinty Weds
description: Laura Maria Elsa McGinty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard McGinty of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., was married yesterday to Frank David Kobola, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Kobola of Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: SUFFOLK G.O.P. FIGHTS TO RETAIN ITS EDGE
description: ALTHOUGH usually strong at the town level in Suffolk County, Republicans have only a 6-to-4 edge in town supervisors and even that slight advantage is in jeopardy in the Nov. 8 election, politicians of both parties agree.

title:
STAMPS;
OMNIBUS PAYS TRIBUTE TO RAPHAEL
description: Collectors have an opportunity to acquire a priceless collection of art on stamps in the ongoing omnibus issue marking the 500th anniversary of the birth of Raphael, one of the great painters of the 16th century. There has not been anything like it since the big omnibus issue of 1981 for the 100th anniversary of the birth of Pablo Picasso, the giant of modern art.

title: TEXAS TRIUMPS, 15-12, ENDING S.M.U.'S STREAK
description: Despite six turnovers and a poor performance by Rob Moerschell, their starting quarterback, the Texas Longhorns defeated Southern Methodist, 15-12, today and remained undefeated.

title: Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $87,500 *2*65 Idolstone Lane, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*19-year-old ranch; 1-car attached garage, central *2*air-onditioning; taxes $2,345. Cranford $128,000 *2*11 Hemlock Circle, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*16-year-old colonial; fireplace, beamed ceilings; *2*taxes $2,874. Livingston $180,000 *2*74 North Hillside Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; full basement, rec room, *2*attic; taxes $3,968. Morris Plains $117,000 *2*16 Foxwood Drive, 2-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*3-year-old town-house condominium; stone fireplace, *2*balcony, $139 common charges; taxes $1,788. title: ABOUT LOND ISLAND
description: IM storing bile, stoking spleen

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE ROOTS OF SOUTHERN POPULISM

title: HERE'S TO THE GOLDEN T!
description: SILICON VALLEY! The Golden Triangle! Mellon Square! Route 128! The nationally acknowledged success stories of California, North Carolina, Pittsburgh and Boston are introduced into virtually any discussion of strong economic areas, particularly in the high-tech field. These areas are often raised as ideals for Long Island to emulate in our pursuit of a stable, sound and promising economic future.

title: PACINO RETURNS TO A FAVORITE ROLE
description: In a startling burst of energy, he detonated

title: Syosset-Hicksville Canceled
description: Two Nassau county football games scheduled for Friday were canceled by school officials who feared there would be crowd violence. The cancellations came after custodians in the school districts involved discovered racist grafitti during the morning.

title: Michael A. W. Evans, Photographer, And Story Shem Wed in Washington
description: The marriage of Judith Story Shem, president of Arrive Unlimited, a public relations concern in Washington, and Michael Arthur Worden Evans, personal photographer to President Reagan, took place in Washington yesterday. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square.

title: No Headline
description: Hilary A. Winter To Marry in May

title: CRACKDOWN TARGETS SCOFFLAW
description: IN the last five years, scofflaws

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: NEW JERSEY scored a ''first'' last week: It was chosen as the kickoff state for a series of nationwide conferences for women business owners, a program called for by President Reagan.

title: 5 Food Outlets Listed by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited five food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: Feminist to Seek Presidency
description: Sonia Johnson, a Mormon feminist excommunicated for supporting the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, said Friday that she would announce her candidacy for President on Monday. The 47-year-old feminist said she would seek the nomination of the Citizens Party ''to bring a feminist perspective to the campaign dialogue.''

title: WHO MAKES FOREIGN POLICY?
description: The proposals of Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser, make a lot of sense, particularly his suggestion that this post be subject to Senate confirmation (''Deciding Who Makes Foreign Policy,'' Sept. 18). This would provide the opportunity (now lacking) to examine the background and ideology of this very important Presidential appointee.

title: BROWN IS OUT OF HOSPITAL
description: Coach Hubie Brown was released from Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday, and hours later under Brown's two assistants, the Knicks ended their exhibition season by losing to the Nets, 106-100, in the second game of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: FARE OF THE COUNTRY
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of The New York Times bureau in Athens.

title: PICTORIALISM DEFINES THE RUSSIAN WAY WITH A MELODY
description: Perhaps it's the tenacity of Russian culture and the deep-rootedness of its traditional music, or perhaps it's the extreme climate of musical conservatism in official circles; but for some combination of reasons, an unusually consistent stylistic thread runs through the music of the great Russian symphonists, from Tchaikovsky to Shostakovich. On the surface, this may seem obvious - it shouldn't be surprising that Russian music sounds peculiarly Russian. But think about it in more global terms: In Germany and France, for instance, musical language has changed so radically that mid-20th-century German and French works have precious little in common with their late 19th-century predecessors. With Russian music, by contrast, once you look beyond certain superficial harmonic developments, you can't help but notice that the qualities that make Shostakovich's music sound Russian are the same as those that make Tchaikovsky's sound Russian.

title: Patricia Haran Is Married
description: At the Fordham University Chapel in the Bronx yesterday, Patricia Haran, daughter of Elizabeth Haran of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Patrick Haran, was married to Denis M. Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Sullivan of Whitestone, Queens. The Rev. Raymond Rafferty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. The bride is a registered nurse at Lenox Hill Hospital and Mr. Sullivan is an audit manager for Lazar, Levine & Company, certified public accountants.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: -BACK TERRAPIN Malaclemys terrapin

title: Nicaraguan Guerrillas Attack Power Plant
description: Rebel saboteurs attacked Nicaragua's only geothermal power plant today, but the gunfire apparently missed and the new installation was not damaged, the authorities said.

title: Patricia Clark Is Wed to Stephen Quincy Adams
description: Patricia Mary Clark, daughter of Mary Higgins Clark Ploetz of Washington Township, N.J., and Delano, Minn., and the late Warren F. Clark, was married yesterday to Stephen Quincy Adams, son of Suzanne Adams of Ramsey, N.J., and the late John F. Adams. The Rev. Charles Cushing performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Washington Township.

title: LAND PLAN GAINS IN SOUTHOLD
description: SOUTHOLD TOWN, which hopes to

title: DEPRIVATION
description: Crumbling Cookies

title: Q AND A
description: Therapy in a Co-op Question:

title: HOUSE AGAIN DEFIES REAGAN ON NICARAGUA
description: Congressional Democrats last week tried anew to dismantle Administration support for the anti-Sandinista war in Nicaragua. The House dismissed President Reagan's news conference assertion that covert actions have always been ''a part of Government's responsibilities'' and voted, 227 to 194, to halt aid to the insurgents. It authorized instead $50 million to help nearby countries intercept weapons the Administration says Nicaragua is supplying to subversives in El Salvador.

title: Bilbao Marchers Protest E.T.A. Terrorism
description: Crowds estimated at up to 250,000 marched in silence today through Bilbao, the Basque capital, in one of the biggest protests against terrorism the region has had, the police said.

title: IMMOLATION DAY IN WARSAW
description: A MINOR APOCALYPSE

title: A TALE OF TWO B-MOVIES: ONE'S PLAIN, THE OTHER FANCY
description: ''Rumble Fish,'' a teen-age gang film with aspirations to create its own mythology, set in what may be Tulsa, Okla., is Francis Coppola's second attempt within the year to make a mountain of a movie out of a molehill of a young-adult novel by S. E. Hinton. Like ''The Outsiders,'' which was released in March, ''Rumble Fish'' is full of unintentional giggles but, unlike that earlier film, ''Rumble Fish'' has a feverish, partially redeeming, cockeyed grandeur to it. Probably no one else but Mr. Coppola would have the nerve to attempt such a mixed-up film, the ability to obtain the financing for it, or the talent to make it as interesting as it is in spite of its comically inflated pretensions.

title: A FAMILY STORE TAKES STOCK
description: Roy Reed, a former reporter for The New York Times, teaches journalism at the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville. HE SCENE WAS WHAT PASSES FOR bus tling in Fayetteville, Ark. Shoppers and office workers strolled in the shade of the old post office square. Near the middle, as from a concert stage, a woman named Free serenaded the flowers with a violin.

title: CORPORATE GIANT MOVES, AND A TOWN REAPS THE BENEFITS
description: WHEN Elena Quintana moved back to her parents' home in Middletown six months ago, she sought employment with ''a financially sound company.'' The 27- year-old accountant's most recent employer had just gone bankrupt, and she wanted job security.

title: MILLER TRIES A NEW FORM FOR AN OLD PLAY
description: Last November, after his two latest plays had failed to impress critics, just as others had failed in the preceding 15 years, Arthur Miller got a letter from Tennessee Williams. Mr. Miller can no longer find the letter - it was misplaced in the frantic clean- up after a fire at his home in May - but the sentiment was not one easily forgotten.

title: A KEYBOARD LIFE PLAYED ON STAGE
description: -casting. And she isn't, she said, suffering from an identity crisis. Yet, when the concert pianist from Shoreham takes to the stage at Dowling College on Friday to perform ''Clara Schumann,'' a one-woman musical drama by Ned Bobkoff that is being given its world premiere on the Oakdale campus, there will be more involved than mere play-acting or piano-playing.

title: Rev. Andrew Hamza, Leader In the Hungarian Community
description: The Rev. Andrew Hamza, a leader in the Hungarian Reformed Church and several cultural organizations serving the Hungarian community in the Northeast, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manville, N.J. He was 63 years old.

title: Mary-Christy Fisher to Marry Feb. 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Fisher Jr. of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary- Christy Fisher, to Harold Hongju Koh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kwang Lim Koh of New Haven. A Feb. 19 wedding is planned.

title: JAZZ: TOSHINORI KONDO GROUP
description: Miles Davis's albums from the early 1970's, like ''On the Corner'' and ''Pangaea,'' made a major impact on Japanese jazz musicians. Among those who have decided to extend the edgy, percussive Davis style is the trumpeter Toshinori Kondo, who brought his Tibetan Blue Air Liquid Band to 55 Grand Street on Wednesday.

title: NOT-SO-OLD AID THE ELDERLY
description: IT WAS in 1981 that Pat Gerber,

title: Linda Henigson, J. T. Stanley Wed
description: Linda G. Henigson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Henigson of Larchmont, N.Y., and J. Thomas Stanley, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Pearson Stanley of Grosse Pointe, Mich., were married yesterday in Larchmont. The Rev. George Zabriskie 2d performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Gerard DiSenso, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: YOUNGER GROUP REPORTS MORE MENTAL WOES
description: Americans 25 to 45 years old report a much higher number of psychiatric disorders occurred at some point in life than older people report, according to preliminary findings of a broad study being sponsored by the National Institute of Mental Health.

title: HOW THAT CLOSET DOTH RUNNETH OVER
description: THE Removal Association of the Property of Adult Children (RATPAC) met recently in another attempt to decided how to cope with the problem that is strangling suburbia. The president explained that the group's purpose is to figure out what to do with what is left by grown-up children who move their bodies out of parents' homes but leave behind more treasures than were found in King Tut's tomb. The problem is particularly serious on Long Island, which had always considered itself a bedroom community, but has suddenly discovered that it's really one large storeroom.

title: Doreen Ma Becomes the Bride of Kenneth Wang
description: Doreen Ma, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Ma of Bangkok, Thailand, was married yesterday to Kenneth Wang, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. C. Wang of Manhattan and Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. John Olafson of the First Methodist Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Wang home in Pound Ridge.

title: HOLY CROSS, BY 31-10, GOES 7-0
description: Chuck Doyle, a sophomore fullback, scored three touchdowns to lead Holy Cross to a 31-10 victory over Brown today, giving the Crusaders their best start since the 1945 season.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of Peter Carlson's ''Roughneck: The Life and Times of Big Bill Haywood'' (Sept. 4) misidentified the union with which Haywood was associated. It was the Industrial Workers of the World.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Helms 'Exonerated'As Director of Central Intelligence in the mid-1970's, Richard Helms knew how to keep a secret.

title: Isolated Boy Reported Well After Operation
description: David, the 12-year-old boy who has spent his life in a plastic bubble boy because his body cannot fight germs, was reported in good spirits and excellent condition today after an experimental bone marrow transplant that doctors hope will enable him to walk into the world for the first time.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TWO black women from Amityville and an angel from Massapequa are combining their talents to publish The Long Island Black Advocate, the Island's first general newspaper intended primarily for blacks. Sharon Davis and Debbie Tekosky, longtime friends with no journalistic backgrounds, decided there was a need for strengthening communication among Long Island blacks, who number close to 200,000.

title: Driving Abroad
description: To the Editor: John Brannon Al

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS, 3-2
description: This is unfamiliar ground for the Rangers. They left Nassau Coliseum tonight with a 3-2 victory over the Islanders, only their 10th regular-season victory ever here, and a firm grasp on first place in the Patrick Division with an 8-1 record.

title: A NOBEL QUEST FOR THE INVISIBLE HAND
description: THE award of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to Gerard Debreu of the University of California at Berkeley was a welcome affirmation of the value of basic research in that subject. Professor Debreu is the purest of pure economists. He has left it to others to deal with the pressing problems of inflation, poverty, developing less-developed countries, and the rest. Instead, he has devoted his career to the enduring problems at the foundations of economics.

title: MONDALE IN THE MIDDLE IN CHICAGO CITY HALL FUED
description: Mayor Harold Washington and Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak have fought each other on just about every issue that has arisen since Mr. Washington took office last April, from who will control key committees on the City Council to how a vacant room at City Hall would be used.

title: HENRY JAMES
description: To the Editor:

title: PORT CHESTER ITEMIZES BRIDGE CLAIM
description: PORT CHESTER THE rumbling trucks of last summer, diverted around a bridge that collapsed on Interstate 95, no longer clog the streets here or in Greenwich across the state line in Connecticut. But they left wear on local pavements and stress on municipal budgets, which both communities want help in fixing.

title: VARYING LINKS TO TRADITION
description: WE use tradition in various ways, frequently seeking it out - consciously or unconsciously - because it reinforces values we have acquired. Even the most inventive artist borrows from earlier art sources, and this can be an asset in creating an initial rapport with the viewer and a useful guide when it comes to measuring originality.

title: JOB BANK TO SERVE DISABLED
description: CONVINCING an employer to hire the emotionally disabled may not be easy, but 29 Westchester industries have joined the first countywide job bank to make positions available to them.

title: NATIVITY SCENE BEGETS A CONSTITIUTIONAL DEBATE
description: Among the items on the Reagan Administration's ''social issues'' agenda only one, the effort to promote religion in American life, has made headway at the Supreme Court.

title: ROGERS SCORES 30 POINTS
description: The Greg Rogers Show went on the road yesterday and was a smash success. The star halfback passed for one touchdown and rushed for four more, kicked two extra-points and carried two 2-point conversions as visiting Byram Hills crushed Peekskill, 42-8.

title: CONCERT: SHANKAR AND RAKHA
description: For sheer percussive momentum, few duos in any kind of music can match Ravi Shankar on sitar with Alla Rakha on tabla drums. The two master north Indian musicians played their annual concert Friday in Carnegie Hall.

title: SHOREHAM TO AFFECT DEMAND AND RATES
description: EVERY time the numbers are revised, they seem to get larger. By 1981, the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, built to cut the Long Island Lighting Company's electric rates, was estimated to be likely to cause an increase of 16 percent.

title: No Headline
description: Colleen Bohan to Marry

title: FORDHAM IS PLANNING TOBUILD 2 DORMITORIES IN NEXT 2 YEARS
description: Fordham University has decided to build two 400-student dormitories over the next two years - its largest financial undertaking since construction of its Lincoln Center campus in 1969.

title: KISSINGER UNIT TALKS WITH REBEL LEADERS OF 2 KEY COUNTRIES
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and members of his Central American study commission have met privately here with opposition leaders from El Salvador and Nicaragua, spokesmen for the commission and the rebel groups said today.

title: HANNA SCHYGULLA CHARTS A FRESH COURSE
description: Among the day's major European film stars, the German actress Hanna Schygulla, long associated with the films of the late director Rainer Werner Fassbinder, has emerged as one of the most visible and luminous figures in international cinema. In the recent years, her cool, enigmatic beauty and her fluid, subtly modulated acting have prompted a wide variety of well- known directors to cast her in their films, usually to stunning effect.

title: Judge Blocks Airing Of DeLorean Tapes
description: A Federal district judge today blocked CBS and its local affiliate from airing undercover videotapes showing the surveillance and arrest of John Z. DeLorean, the former car manufacturer accused of cocaine trafficking.

title: Coretta King Says Candidacy Of Jackson Could Be Harmful
description: Coretta Scott King says it would harm both blacks and Democrats if the Rev. Jesse Jackson ran for President, creating a ''backlash'' that could help re-elect President Reagan.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: When Albany State College, a predominantly black school in Albany, Ga., appointed Dr. Vuela Rhodes chairman of its history department, Dr. John Moore, one of two whites passed over for the job, filed a complaint with the Georgia Office of Fair Employment Practices, charging racial discrimination. He argued that he, not the black woman, merited the appointment.

title: MARKETING EMOTION
description: THE MANAGED HEART

title: STAGE: 'BIG AND LITTLE/SCENES' BY BOTHO STRAUSS
description: Botho Strauss's ''Big and Little/ Scenes,'' presented in an uncut three- hour version at the C.S.C., is a nonlinear but consequential tour of present- day alienation. Our guide is a lonely woman named Lotte who is a kind of contemporary Candide. The play is theoretically tantalizing, more interesting to contemplate than to experience and less adventurous than works by Mr. Strauss's peers such as Peter Handke and Franz Xaver Kroetz.

title: Inanna
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: photo of Susan Geise, her horse Magic

title: THE YEAR OF THE SOUFFLE
description: TO> urmudgeon that I am, I can safely distance myself from most food fashions. I have lived through the winter of the ubiquitous kiwi and the summer of the cold-pasta picnic, and stayed aloof from the fad for chicken cooked with 40 cloves of garlic. But I have a surround of gourmands who are not immune to the silken words of food writers. And while neither of them cooks, they are fiendish about eating well. Or encouraging those who don't mind cooking for their pleasure. This was never more apparent than last year, which, because of personal overinvolvement, I have named The Year of the Souffle.

title: INFIGHTING SHAKES BIG HOSPITAL UNION
description: A trade union fight is disrupting the New York-based National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, the country's leading organizer of hospital workers.

title: 10-SCREEN CINEMA
description: When the Whitestone Drive-In opened in the Bronx in 1949, some regarded outdoor movies as a godsend for an industry threatened by the growing appeal of televison. While many of the city's movie theaters and drive-ins have closed since then, the Whitestone remained open until last year, when construction began on an indoor, multiscreen complex, an industry innovation to compete with the home screen.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Jets vs. Atlanta Falcons at Shea Stadium, 1 P.M. The Falcon staff should be well prepared for the Jets. Dan Henning, the head coach, and two of his assistants, the offensive coordinator Bob Fry and the defensive coach Dan Sekanovich, were all assistant coaches for the Jets under Walt Michaels. In addition, Garry Puetz, the Falcons' assistant offensive line coach, is a former Jet player. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880 1 P.M.).

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 FOR A SONG
description: Convinced that Long Island harbors legions of unsung songwriters just waiting for their big chance to be heard, the Babylon Citizens Council on the Arts has moved into the vacuum with a song-writing contest. And today at 8 P.M., after a committee sifted through 80 entries by 40 different tunesmiths, 24 finalists will get the exposure they've dreamed of when the council stages the contest at the North Babylon High School. Drawn from all walks of life - ''We've got businessmen as well as musicians,'' said Mike Kenny, executive director of the council - the finalists offer songs that run the gamut from country-western to pop to soft rock music. In addition to having their work performed in public, the songwriters are vying for prizes that will be awarded by seven judges. The high school is on Phelps Lane, and tickets are $3 or $2 for students and the elderly. TIMERMAN ON L.I.

title: PROTESTERS FORM CHAIN OF 60 MILES
description: -ULM, West Germany, Oct. 22 - The four tall birch trees along the road through Urspring, population 900, had probably never been surrounded by so many people.

title: Martial Law to Remain In Turkey After Election
description: President Kenan Evren said today that martial law in Turkey would remain in force after the Nov. 6 parliamentary elections because of a threat of terrorism.

title: DONNING COSTUMES, HINTING AT ROLES
description: ACTING in the school play, trying on old clothes from a trunk in the attic and participating in a local theater group are various ways in which ordinary people step outside their own skins and take on alternative personalities. Even dressing up for a costume party can induce feelings of release and transformation, but with the realization that the role is temporary and fictional.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: WHERE BRIBES DON'T SMELL
description: To the Editor:

title: JUAN GRIS: THE OTHER CUBIST
description: Among the progenitors of Cubism, Juan Gris has never had the kind of universal constituency that has for many years attached itself both to Picasso and (to a lesser but still considerable extent), to Braque. He is known to have made a contribution to Cubism that, from 1913 to 1915 in particular, was equal to theirs. In the great Cubist exhibition that was held at the Tate Gallery in London last summer, there was a long wall of paintings by Gris that came as a revelation to people who had previously seen his paintings only in ones and twos.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Time-TestedInsights WinNobel AwardsIf some scientists see farther than others, Isaac Newton modestly said, it is by standing on the shoulders of giants. Just who the giants are, however, is not always immediately clear, as last week's Nobel Prizes in Physics and Chemistry showed.

title: HEDLINERS
description: Isherwood HonoredThere was a new honor in the picture last week for the author whose best-known line begins ''I am a camera.''

title: No Headline
description: Joffrey Executive Named

title: No Headline
description: A Modest Heave on Ocean Shipping Representative Mario Biaggi called it ''an important step in the process of revitalizing our merchant marine.'' Actually, the maritime bill that slipped through the House without dissent last week probably won't change much of anything. And since many shippers had been pushing for significant new protection against competition, the bill is really a modest victory for free enterprise. Or it will be, if the House defends its version against the better deal the industry won from the Senate.

title: Nets Triumph And Finish 3-4
description: Buck Williams scored 16 points to lead the New Jersey Nets to a 103-95 victory over Utah in an exhibition game tonight.

title: Burnett Creates Posts In International Unit
description: The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, some 38 percent of whose $1.48 billion in billings in 1982 were on the international scene, has set up an office of the chairman-international.

title: CAMP LEJEUNE MARINES ARE IRATE AND UNCERTAIN
description: Marines and residents of this town outside Camp Lejeune reacted with anger and uncertainty today to the killings in the terrorist bombing in Lebanon. Most of those interviewed said that if the marines were not allowed to protect themselves better, President Reagan should bring them home.

title: SALVADOR: 'ROUTINE' POLITICAL KILLINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR CITY AND STATE LOBBYISTS, BOTH BOSSES AND GOALS DIFFER
description: Judy L. Chesser, the New York City lobbyist here, met with the staff of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato recently to describe the bounty that would flow to the city if the New York Republican voted in favor of a $26 million amendment.

title: Soviet Ships Freed From Ice
description: A group of Soviet ships freed from Arctic ice off the coast of northeast Siberia reached Murmansk on the Bering Sea in northern European Russia today. The official Soviet press agency Tass also said the Kolya Myagotin, which was in danger of sinking when its hull was punctured by ice, had cleared the Bering Strait between the Soviet Union and Alaska.

title: Penguins' Sutter Traded to Flyers
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins traded a rookie right wing, Rich Sutter, to the Philadelphia Flyers today for the centers Ron Flockhart and Mark Taylor, and the left wing Andy Brickley.

title: LEGILATORS SAY REAGAN MUST REASSESS U.S. ROLE
description: In the aftermath of the attack on the American marines in Beirut, legislators from both parties said today that the Reagan Administration must redefine and clarify the role of its troops and their long- range mission in the Middle East.

title: ; FRENCH CASUALTIES RISE IN BOMBINGS;; REAGAN INSISTS MARINES WILL REMAIN; BUILDINGS BLASTED
description: A suicide terrorist driving a truck loaded with TNT blew up an American Marine headquarters at the Beirut airport today, killing at least 161 marines and sailors and wounding 75.

title: STRIKE BY TEACHERS IN CHICAGO SEEMS AT END AFTER 3 WEEKS
description: A tentative agreement today ended a three- week strike in the nation's third-largest district. Officials said 436,000 students might return to the classroom by Tuesday.

title: Randall D. Holmes Weds Susan Goldberg, an Editor
description: Susan Goldberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barnett Goldberg of New York, was married yesterday to Randall D. Holmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rufus D. Holmes of Pampa, Tex.

title: Bonn's Steel Bid Is Denied
description: West Germany's demand for a cut in its quota of European Economic Community steel imports has been rejected by the Common Market's president, Gaston Thorn.

title: ; TO CUT BOTTLE LAWS' COST TO CONSUMERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockwell Closings
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said it might close plants in Battle Creek, Mich., and Wellington, Ohio, because of declining production.

title: FRANCE HAS NO PLANS TO PULL TROOPS OUT
description: Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy, condemning today's bomb attacks on French and American troops in Beirut, indicated tonight that France would maintain its forces in Lebanon for the time being.

title: Prison Population Up As Crime Rate Drops
description: The nation's prison population set another record in the first six months of 1983 while reported crime dropped by 5 percent over the same period, the Justice Department reported today.

title: LOCKHEED BACKED IN A BRIBERY CASE
description: No evidence exists that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation bribed foreign officials with Government money beginning in 1965 to facilitate secret spy missions into North Vietnam, a member of the House intelligence committee, Albert Gore Jr., said yesterday.

title: RANGERS TOP ISLANDERS AGAIN
description: Don Maloney is not best known for scoring goals, and Peter Sundstrom is a rookie not known for anything yet. But under the pressure of overtime last night, those two came through and rescued the Rangers' weekend sweep of the Islanders.

title: MONDALE'S TIGHTROPE ACT ON THE CARTER PROBLEM
description: To Walter F. Mondale's surprise, a key problem that has suddenly intensified in his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination is his role in the Carter Administration and to what degree he wants to be identified with it.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.68

title: 200 MUSICIANS TAKE ON NUCLEAR ARMS TONIGHT
description: The violinist Itzhak Perlman and the sopranos Jessye Norman and Kathleen Battle will band together tonight at Avery Fisher Hall with 200 players and singers from the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera, the City Opera, the American Symphony and a score of smaller groups as Musicians Against Nuclear Arms. Presiding will be Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic.

title: No Headline
description: America Held Hostage Once again America is held hostage by a Middle East circumstance beyond its control. And this time there's no escape through daring rescue missions or ransom negotiations. Honor and prestige are again on the line, but the marines who claim them are dead, victims of a murky diplomatic cause that the President feels bound to reaffirm but still cannot fully define.

title: Gasoline Prices Decline
description: The average price of gasoline nationwide fell nearly one cent during the past two weeks and was expected to continue declining, Dan Lundberg, oil industry analyst, said today. Mr. Lundberg's biweekly survey of more than 17,000 service stations in 50 states found the average price of gasoline, including tax, stood at $1.2285 a gallon, down 0.94 cent over two weeks. The wholesale price, with no taxes, was 90.77 cents a gallon, down 1.4 cents. Mr. Lundberg said that the wholesale price was the lowest since January 1980 and that the retail price was 3.3 cents lower than a year earlier.

title: REAGAN BID FOR I.M.F. BILL DUE
description: President Reagan will try this week to break the logjam over the bill authorizing an increase in the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund, Administration officials reported over the weekend.

title: BALLET: ARPINO'S 'MR. .B'
description: -Tones for Mr. B.,'' a world premiere that the Joffrey Ballet presented Saturday night at the City Center, poses some problems.

title: 'DON'T LEAVE US' TRAPPED MEN CRY
description: Gunnery Sgt. Herman Lange was one of the first marines to get down to the bombed Marine headquarters from a nearby barracks.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Routs Jo Durie, 6-1, 6-1
description: Chris Evert Lloyd won her first tournament since the French Open in June by routing Joe Durie, 6-1, 6-1, in the final of the Daihatsu Challenge today.

title: U.S. Team to Study 'Yellow Rain' Reports
description: The United States has formed a team to investigate the reported use of chemical weapons in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan by the Soviet Union and its allies, a United States Embassy spokesman said Saturday.

title: FOREIGN COMPANIES IN BRAZIL
description: Robert M. Gerrity, president of Ford Brazil, was hurrying through a day of meetings in the showroom of his newly renovated plant here, amid new Ford Escorts that the plant began making last summer for the Latin American market and Europe. He had been summoned back to Detroit to try to explain, once again, the condition of the Brazilian economy.

title: A Tale of Good Will
description: In his work as a freelance sound engineer, Bob Moscowitz gets around to concerts, street fairs and festivals all over the city. Recently he had a job in East Harlem.

title: MORTGAGE SECURITIES POPULAR
description: Corporations are reluctant to sell long-term bonds and the Treasury's borrowing needs are declining, but the issuance of mortgage-backed securities is setting records and attracting new investors.

title: Bus Driver Shot to Death
description: A 62-year-old Greyhound bus driver was fatally shot as he drove down an interstate highway Saturday by a passenger described as ''mentally deranged,'' the authorities said.

title: Helen P. Rosenberg Wed To Willy Waks in Dallas
description: Helen Pappenheim Rosenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Rosenberg of Dallas, and Willy Waks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Waks of Nancy, France, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents by Rabbi Isadore Garsek.

title: ANGLICANS LOSING GROUND IN BRITAIN
description: Jutting out on a hillside overlooking the fields of Cheshire, St. John's is a simple Anglican parish church.

title: Stewart Winner In Disney
description: Payne Stewart pulled away with an eagle-birdie burst en route to a 67 and a two-stroke victory today in the Walt Disney World golf classic.

title: SHAMIR LAYS BLAME FOR BLASTS ON THOSE OPPOSED TO PEACE
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, said in a statement today on the attacks in Lebanon, ''There is no doubt that this crime was perpetrated by those who want to prevent a peaceful solution in Lebanon and to increase bloodshed.''

title: JETS FALL BY 27-21 AFTER A 21-0 LEAD
description: The Jets lost their third consecutive game yesterday, 27-21, this time collapsing under a 20-point final period by the Atlanta Falcons. The Jets had been ahead in the third quarter by 21- 0 but seemed to lose their concentration, their intensity and whatever support remained from their Shea Stadium fans.

title: AFTER THE RACE IS OVER
description: THEY are the celebrities of the

title: Spellman Routs Mt. St. Michael
description: Marcus Gonzalez scored three touchdowns and Kevin Hellman threw for a fourth score as undefeated Cardinal Spellman routed Mount St. Michael, 30-0, in the Catholic High Schools Football League yesterday.

title: Madera Is Victor, Retaining Title
description: Lupe Madera of Mexico, fighting aggressively, retained his World Boxing Association junior flyweight title tonight with a 15-round unanimous decision over Katsuo Tokashiki of Japan.

title: STEPFAMILIES SHARE THEIR JOYS AND WOES
description: Is America becoming a nation of stepfamilies? ''By 1990, the number of stepfamilies and single-parent households will be greater than the number of traditional families,'' said Emily Visher, president of the Stepfamily Association of America, at a conference that ended here Sunday.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Lear Siegler Inc.'s debt rating has been raised by Standard & Poor's to A-, from BBBx. The company's commercial paper rating goes to A-, from A-2, and its preferred stock to A, from A-.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Lag in Profits Hurting Stocks
description: INVESTORS can tell when a bull market is in

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week. Monday

title: HEARINGS DUE NEXT MONTH ON CARTER'S DEBATE BRIEFING BOOK
description: A four- month Congressional investigation of the conduct of the 1980 Presidential campaign is expected to result in public hearings by mid-November that will focus on how the Reagan campaign obtained copies of briefing papers prepared for President Carter in his showdown television debate with Mr. Reagan.

title: China's Unions Reported To Win Right to Strike
description: A Chinese labor convention adopted a new trade union constitution today. The official New China News Agency said it gave workers a limited right to strike against unsafe working conditions,

title: GRETE WAITZ WINS AGAIN
description: Racing more against the elements than against her competition, Grete Waitz of Norway strengthened her status as the world's top female long- distance runner yesterday by winning her fifth New York City Marathon in six years. She finished in 2 hours 27 minutes, almost 5 minutes ahead of the second woman, Laura Fogli of Italy.

title: AMERICANS REACT TO ATTACK WITH FRUSTRATION AND DOUBT
description: Americans reacted to the terrorist attack upon United States marines in Beirut yesterday with sorrow, shock, outrage and expressions of growing doubt about the nation's involvement in Lebanon.

title: DIXON AND MRS. WAITZ WIN IN NEW YORK MARATHON
description: New Yorkers braved a steady rain to cheer 15,193 runners in the 14th New York City Marathon yesterday, and Rod Dixon of New Zealand returned the enthusiasm with a courageous victory, the first by a foreign man in this 26-mile-385-yard race.

title: No Headline
description: Housing's Best Hope New York City's need for decent moderate-income housing far exceeds any effort to promote it. The City Council can keep alive some hope by renewing the J-51 law that stimulates housing rehabilitation.

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 24, 1983 Bombings in Beirut
description: At least 161 American marines and sailors were killed and 75 were injured when suicide terrorists driving a truck loaded with TNT blew up a Marine headquarters at Beirut International Airport. A Pentagon spokesman said the truck broke through a series of steel fences and sandbag barricades and exploded in the heart of the headquarters shortly before dawn. Two miles away, another bomb-laden truck crashed into a French barracks, killing at least 12 French paratroopers and wounding 13. Fifty-three paratroopers were missing and believed buried in the rubble. (Page A1, Column 6.) The explosion at the Marines' headquarters building was so massive it dug a crater in the heart of the structure 30 feet deep and 40 feet wide. ''Bodies were lying around all over,'' said a rescuer. ''Other people were trapped under the concrete. I could hear them screaming: 'Get us out. Don't leave us.' I just started digging, picking men out.'' (A1:5.)

title: BUY THE KID A MEAL
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

title: MARINES' SECURITY RAISES QUESTIONS
description: After a car bomb blew up the United States Embassy in Beirut on April 18, killing 63 people, the Marine force at the Beirut airport took steps to strengthen security measures against a similar incident, Marine Corps officers said today.

title: NEW YORK AREA OFFICIALS URGE MARINE PULLOUT
description: Several officials from the New York metropolitan area, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Mayor Koch, said today that the Reagan Administration should remove the Marines from Lebanon.

description: Pacer Promotion

description: '76 Glenn Speech Flap

title: Steven Weisman Weds Miss Bumiller
description: Elisabeth Bumiller, a reporter for the Style section of The Washington Post, and Steven R. Weisman, White House correspondent of The New York Times, were married in Washington yesterday. Rabbi Harold White and the Rev. William Bumiller, an Episcopal priest and uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the couple's Georgetown home.

description: One Move Solves Two Problems

description: Unusual Spotlight For Clarendon Aide

title: MONDALE EMBRACES NO PROTECTIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: 4,000 Recent Arrests Detailed by Pakistanis
description: The Pakistani Government said today that more than 4,000 people had been arrested across the country in 10 weeks of political agitation against martial law and that 2,527 were still in jail.

title: BRINGING BARD DOWN TO EARTH ON WEST SIDE
description: They came, a thousand thespians, to learn to speak Shakespeare trippingly on the tongue. And when they stumbled - sawed the air too much, tore a passion to tatters and, all in all, out- Heroded Herod - some of the finer English classical actors tried to help.

title: TROOPERS FACING ALLEGATIONS OF BRUTALITY AT UPSTATE FAIR
description: For many New York State troopers, it is a sought-after assignment - almost a brief summer vacation. In exchange for 10 days of patrol duty at the New York State Fair in Syracuse, there is free lodging at a motel and the off- duty attractions of the fair's midway, theaters and restaurants.

title: DISRUPTION OF PEACE PARLEY IS TERMED TERRORISTS' GOAL
description: Some Lebanese officials asserted today that the terrorist explosions here that killed scores of United States marines and French paratroopers this morning were aimed at undermining the planned peace conference of the country's religious and political factions.

title: No Headline
description: Quotation of the Day

title: EAGLE COMPUTER STAYS IN THE RACE
description: Despite the death of the company's first president in an auto accident on the day it went public last June, many analysts say tiny Eagle Computer Inc. has not faltered so far.

title: YEARS OF DELAYS SEEN FOR MOTORISTS AT LINCOLN AND HOLLAND TUNNELS
description: Motorists who use the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels can expect to encounter construction delays for the rest of the decade, according to Port Authority officials.

title: Pamela Gruninger Marries Charles Heard Perkins
description: Pamela Elizabeth Gruninger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew F. Gruninger Jr. of Florham Park, N.J., was married there yesterday to Charles Heard Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Perkins of Cambridge and Nonquitt, Mass. The Rev. Richard Raum performed the ceremony at Calvary Presbyterian Church.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: In spite of the attack Sunday on United States Marines in Beirut, President Reagan plans to keep to his schedule today and meet with President Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo and have lunch with regional editors and broadcasters.

title: TREASURY PLANS $15 BILLION PACKAGE
description: The lull in Treasury note and bond financings is about to end, as securities dealers expect the Treasury to announce on Wednesday plans to sell a package of 3- , 10- and 30-year securities totaling about $15 billion. The actual auctions are not expected until the week of Oct. 31.

title: HAITIANS IN CITY TO STUDY CREOLE AS LITERACY AID
description: Illiterate Haitian adults living in New York will be taught to read and write the only language most of them understand, Creole, in an experiment being conducted with the Ford Foundation's assistance.

title: Advertising; Santa Sponsor Sought
description: A PAIR of local professional Santa's helpers are involved in one of the biggest Santa capers of their careers.

title: T.W.A. Accused of Bias In 150 Dismissals
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has filed a complaint against Trans World Airlines, charging that discrimination prompted the carrier's decision to lay off 150 black baggage carriers.

title: Patriots Surprise Bills by 31-0
description: Steve Grogan threw two touchdown passes to Derrick Ramsey to help give the New England Patriots a 31-0 victory over the Buffalo Bills today.

title: ONE FALCON FINDS SEVERAL WAYS TO DEFEAT THE JETS
description: Although 89 players were in action at Shea Stadum yesterday, one made the difference. That was Billy (White Shoes) Johnson, a wide receiver and punt returner extraordinaire of the Atlanta Falcons who worked his magic on the Jets within 12 minutes of the third and fourth quarters.

title: A RUSH TO LICENSE BERENSTAIN BEARS
description: Lederle Laboratories has them pushing vaccinations. Texas Instruments is using them for talking books. Hallmark is trying them on cards and puzzles. Coleco is weaving them into video games. Mattel is making stuffed copies of them. Which is not to forget the embroidery kits, scribble pads and socks.

title: QUESTIONS ON MISSION
description: NewsAnalysis

title: One Killed and Two Wounded I
description: Three people were shot, one fatally, yesterday inside a bar in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: 'NEOLIBERALS' IN NEED OF CONSTITUENTS
description: They call themselves ''neoliberals'' and admit, as one of their founders put it, that it is a ''terrible name for an important movement.''

title: CENTER INCREASES JOB SERVICES
description: Founded 21 years ago as a nonprofit organization that promotes the full participation of women in the work force, the Catalyst organization has increased the range of its services. It now not only publishes books and pamphlets on careers for women, but also collects and analyzes information on women in the corporate world, rents out videotapes and filmstrips about women and employment and is studying the needs of dual-career families.

title: GERMAN MISSILE PROTESTS: MIXED SIGNALS FOR KOHL
description: NewsAnalysis

title: PAYTON WINS SMILE, AND BURR OAK LOSES SYMBOL
description: Chicagoans, it sometimes seems, can agree to disagree on just about anything.

title: Teltscher in Final
description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador and Eliot Teltscher advanced to the final of the $175,000 hard-court Japan Open today.

title: A.M.I. TO BUY LIFEMARK FOR $1 BILLION
description: American Medical International Inc. has agreed to acquire the Lifemark Corporation in a deal valued at $1 billion, the hospital management companies announced yesterday.

title: People
description: * Robert E. Weekes promoted to executive vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: Addendum
description: * Discover magazine increasing its circulation rate base to 875,000, from 850,000, and its advertising rates 2.9 percent, with the January issue.

title: Gottfried Wins
description: Brian Gottfried beat Mel Purcell, 6-2, 6-3, 7-5, today and won the Fischer Grand Prix tournament for the fourth time.

title: No Headline
description: Getty Oil Pact With Shareholders The Getty Oil Company and its two controlling shareholders announced yesterday an agreement not to alter their relationship for a period of one year.

title: I.M.F.-AS IN 'MIFFED'
description: Today, in the midst of the worst international recession since the 1930's, many Latin American countries are having difficulty repaying bank loans. To prevent a default, the International Monetary Fund often steps into the breech, lending debtor nations some of the cash they need to make interest payments and, in return, insisting that they slash spending on social programs, abolish cost-of-living adjustments, raise taxes and restrict imports.

title: 3D-QUARTER PROFITS UP SHARPLY
description: Powered by the economy's zesty third-quarter performance, corporate earnings jumped sharply from a year earlier.

title: THE DANCE: 'Swim Ride'
description: ADANCEGOER interested in abstraction who attended the program that Kathy Duncan gave on Saturday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater might conclude that Miss Duncan likes to devise patterns of assembling and dispersing. However, a dancegoer interested in dramatic values who attended the program by Miss Duncan's company, Kathy Duncan/ Transition, would say that she is concerned with mutual support.

title: Julia T. Schuster, A.D. Klingenstein Marry in Capital
description: The marriage of Julia Temple Schuster, daughter of Virginia G. Schuster of Reisterstown, Md., and the late John Schuster, to Andrew Davis Klingenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Klingenstein of Greenwich, Conn., took place in Washington yesterday. The Rev. H. Richard Harp, pastor of the National Memorial Church of God in Washington, performed the ceremony at the Vista International Hotel.

title: ANGUISH, RELIEF AND JOY FOR THE FAMILY
description: They often provide a psychological lift, and sometimes a lift to the starting line. Along the way, they offer services ranging from encouragement to oranges, fruit juice and a clean pair of sweat socks. And even if they think running is closer to a form of torture than exercise, it is inevitable that the members of a marathoner's family usually feel as physically and emotionally drained as those who have completed the race.

title: TRADITION SUSTAINS ACADEMY
description: St. Vincent's Academy, a private Roman Catholic high school, is an anomaly. The neighborhood around it has decayed over the years, into vacant lots and crumbling, abandoned buildings, but the school has remained at the same location, in the heart of the city.

title: Korean Jet to Be Topic At Aviation Parley
description: The annual conference of the International Air Transport Association opening here Monday plans to discuss ways to protect civilian aircraft from military action, conference sources said today.

title: NATIONAL NEWS COUNCIL SEEKS SURVIVAL AND MEDIA BACKING
description: The National News Council, set up a decade ago as an independent forum for complaints of unfair or inaccurate news reporting and a voice for press freedom, is struggling to stay alive.

title: ASKEW WINS FLORIDA STRAW POLL BUT NOT A MAJORITY
description: Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida placed first in a straw poll at the Florida Democratic convention today, but fell short of a majority because of a strong push from labor groups for former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: 49ers Defeat Rams With 3 Late Scores
description: Joe Montana threw three touchdown passes, and Dwaine Board recovered a fumble in the end zone with 6 minutes 40 seconds left in the game as the San Francisco 49ers scored a 45-35 victory over the Los Angeles Rams today.

description: Several waterfront companies regulated by New York City's Commissioner of Ports and Terminals are clients of a marine company owned by the Commissioner's family, according to officials of the companies.

title: 6 Months Ago, Blast Ripped U.S. Embassy
description: The explosion at the United States Marine headquarters in Beirut yesterday came six months after a bomb was detonated at the United States Embassy in the Lebanese capital, killing 63 people, including 17 Americans, and wounding more than 80 people.

title: Jill Nightingale Becomes Bride of Daniel Burstein
description: Jill Diane Nightingale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Nightingale of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married in Rye yesterday to Daniel Burstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Burstein of Larchmont. N.Y., and Tunbridge, Vt. Judge Sondra Miller of the Family Court of Westchester performed the ceremony at the Manursing Island Club.

title: CBS NEWS SHOWS FILM OF DELOREAN PREPARED AS EVIDENCE IN TRIAL
description: A Government videotape showing the automobile maker John Z. DeLorean examining the contents of a suitcase purportedly containing cocaine was broadcast nationally last night by CBS News, which had its right to air the tape affirmed in court earlier in the day.

title: LED IN HEATLH CARE FOR YOUNG
description: Dr. Edward T. Wilkes, a leader in health care for children and the author of several books on pediatrics, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: BREAKING THE DEADLOCK
description: Demonstrati ons against the deployment of American medium-range missiles in Europe have so far changed nothing, and the Soviet- American negotiations in Geneva remain deadlocked; so the superpowers are at an impasse that if not broken will result in a new and unnecessary round of nuclear escalation.

title: Nissan's British Plans Said to Gain
description: Senior executives of the Nissan Motor Company, ending more than a year of internal disagreement, have agreed on a plan to produce cars in Britain, a company official confirmed here today.

title: Massachusetts Reaps Money in Tax Amnesty
description: As Massachusetts' three-month amnesty for tax evaders took effect last week, two nuns admitted that they had not been paying state taxes on meals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Memorizing the 'Iliad'

title: MET GIVES GALA HUG TO ITSELF
description: -tiered gala in honor of its 100th birthday reminded me of the old song about a fellow determined to get his arms around a very large lady. He hugs a bit, makes a chalk mark, hugs some more, chalks some more and goes on working away in sections, a-huggin' and a-chalkin', until the embrace is accomplished. Over a span of 11 hours, with time out for dinner, the company did a magnificent job of hugging itself on Saturday. There were many thrilling moments, both in the afternoon and evening sessions, though not until almost the 11th hour, literally, were sentiment and drama allowed to take over the proceedings.

title: THE VIEW FROM THE TOP AND THE VIEW AT THE FINISH
description: Viewed from a helicopter 500 feet above the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the New York City Marathon quickly divided itself into three distinct races. Before a single runner had set foot in Brooklyn, the leaders separated themselves from the pack, the hardy recreational runners were massed across six lanes of freshly- patched pavement and the bravest of all, the elderly and infirm, were straggling behind with a gait all their own.

title: FLORIDA TRYING TO AVOID S.E.C. PITFALL
description: Florida has had such a frustrating recent football history that fans of the Gators might be excused if they had given up on the team. Many Florida teams have started well only to slip when least expected. That is one reason why Florida has never won the Southeastern Conference championship since that league was organized in 1933.

title: Commoner Denounces U.S. Cold War Policies
description: Barry Commoner, a peace activist, today told a crowd of about 2,000 people on the Boston Common that President Reagan is ''carrying out a proxy war in the Soviet Union.'' Speaking at a rally to protest the planned deployment of Cruise and Pershing 2 missiles in Europe, Mr. Commoner also denounced the Reagan Administration's policies in Lebanon and Nicaragua.

title: RUTTLEDGE'S PATIENCE FINALLY REWARDED
description: Jeff Rutledge was 6 years old when he started playing organized football in a Pop Warner League in Birmingham, Ala.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rooney-Hanover Deal
description: The Rooney, Pace Group Inc. and the Hanover Square Securities Group Inc. announced jointly yesterday that Rooney would acquire Hanover, a stock brokerage that has nine seats on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED AGAIN ON REAGAN'S LIMITS UNDER WAR POWERS ACT
description: With the ink barely dry on compromise legislation giving President Reagan carefully limited authority to keep marines in Lebanon for 18 months, today's bombings in Beirut raised anew the question of what military steps Mr. Reagan could legally take.

title: 3 Lebanese Villagers Killed In Clash With Israeli Troops
description: Three Lebanese were killed today and injuries among both Israelis and Lebanese were reported when Israeli troops clashed with rioting residents of this village in southern Lebanon.

title: Bulgarian Lifter Sets World Mark
description: A Bulgarian weight lifter, Naim Suleimanov, snatched 130 kilograms today for a world record in the weight class up to 56 kilograms, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said.

title: 2 AVENUES ARE FACING U.S. FORCE
description: Military Analysis

title: TENACITY IS A NEW CHARACTERISTIC OF THE KNICKS
description: After nearly a decade of frivolous front-office decisions and inept performances on the court, the Knicks set a dangerous precedent during the second half of last season: They won. And they did it in stirring fashion, rebounding from an atrocious 0-7 start to capture 22 victories in 26 games in February and March - 8 in a row during one juncture - and charge into the playoffs.

title: CITY U. SEEKING $889 MILLION BUDGET
description: The Chancellor of the City University of New York will propose an $889.3 million budget for the 1984-85 school year that would allow the hiring of 335 new teachers at the four-year senior colleges and 179 teachers at the two-year community colleges.

title: No Headline
description: Giants vs. Cardinals , at St. Louis. The Cardinals beat the Giants on a Monday night in 1977, and since then the Eastern Division rivals have split 10 games.

title: U.S. SAYS SLOPPY DRUG TESTS AT LABORATORY IN SOUTH PROMPT WIDE REVIEW
description: A Louisiana laboratory was sloppy and inept in testing the safety of a chemical used to remove caffeine from coffee, Federal scientists say, prompting them to begin an intensive review of the laboratory's studies of 25 other chemicals now in the marketplace and the workplace.

title: GOVERNOR-ELECT EDWARDS PLEDGES HIGHER TAXES AND TEACHERS' SALARIES IN LOUISIANA
description: Edwin W. Edwards, fresh from a landslide victory that made him the first man elected governor of Louisiana three times, said today that he would take steps to see that his actions in office did not carry even the appearance of wrongdoing.

description: Forty-five years ago members of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion stood on the parade ground in Barcelona listening to La Pasionaria, the fiery, inspirational speaker of the Spanish civil war.

description: For Spain's fishing fleet, the largest in Europe and the supplier of one of the most fervent fish-eating populations anywhere, the world is getting painfully smaller.

description: Accounts

title: Beth Wilansky Weds Dr. Harold Goldstein
description: Beth Ann Wilansky, daughter of Lieut. Col. Nathan L. Wilansky, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Wilansky of Silver Spring, Md., and Dr. Harold A. Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Goldstein of Great Neck, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert S. Widom performed the ceremony in Columbia, Md.

title: COWBOYS' STREAK ENDED BY RAIDERS
description: The Los Angeles Raiders ended the Dallas Cowboys' seven-game winning streak tonight by defeating them, 40-38, on a 26-yard field goal by Chris Bahr with 20 seconds left in the game.

title: REAGAN INCIDENT FIGURE IS SAID TO BE 'TOUBLED'
description: Charles R. Harris, who was arrested Saturday after ramming a pickup truck through a gate of the Augusta National Golf Club, taking hostages and demanding to talk with President Reagan, may have been drinking at the time of the incident.
