title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: John Cleese of Monty Python can be seen as a sleazy salesman in an advertisement for Sony, and the actor Dudley Moore, in spiked hair, chains and leather, is a punk-rocker in an ad for Barclays Bank. An Orson Welles lookalike and soundalike parodies ''Citizen Kane'' in a commercial for The Observer and, in a film promoting P. G. Tips Tea, costumed chimpanzees appear as eccentric English mountain climbers.

title: THE REAL REAGAN
description: For all his years in the spotlight, Ronald Reagan is a puzzle to most of us. What goes on under that genial surface? We got a rare insight at his press conference last week when the President spoke about Martin Luther King Jr. It was a moment of chilling self-revelation.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a runner on first base and one out, the batter hits a line drive that is caught by the left fielder. The runner, off with the swing, must return to first base. The left fielder throws there in an attempt to double him up, but the ball is too high and goes into the dugout before the runner can tag up. What is the ruling? Is it the same in softball?

title: Auto Race Put Off
description: Lingering showers forced a one-week postponement of today's 500-mile Grand National stock car race at North Carolina Motor Speedway. The $248,000 race was rescheduled to start at 12:05 P.M. Sunday.

title: HEARTLIGHT CAPTURES MISS GRILLO STAKES
description: Heartlight easily handled a soft course and a mediocre field to score a seven-length victory yesterday in the $56,300 Miss Grillo Stakes for 2-year- old fillies on the grass at Aqueduct.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg New Batch Of Options Expected
description: A PAUSE in the proliferation of new futures and options products is at hand. But as welcome at this is to Federal regulators and the weary brokerage houses, it will only be a brief respite before the next wave of new products arrives.

title: KNICKS AND NETS: THE RIVALRY HEATS UP
description: FOR a long time, it was easy for the

title: THE RACE WITHIN
description: FOR more than two hours, the umbrellas had been up near the finish line. Under the red, white and blue New York City Marathon banner, two men held a thick white tape. When policemen on motorcycles, their red lights flashing, rumbled along the Central Park roadway, the people knew the winner would soon arrive. Moments later, Rod Dixon of New Zealand, wet from the rain and perspiration, appeared, and the applause began. After breaking the tape, he raised his arms high, then he knelt as if in prayer and bowed. Soon he was up, thrusting his right arm in the air and wobbling slightly.

title: Jacob G. Goldenberg Weds Deborah Lurie
description: Deborah Ruth Lurie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Lurie of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Jacob George Goldenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Goldenberg of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel, performed the ceremony at Temple Israel of Great Neck.

title: DON'T CERTIFY ARGENTINA
description: Less than two weeks before the Argentine national elections, scheduled for Oct. 30, the Reagan Administration has already insulted the not-yet-elected civilian government and signaled, once again, Washington's contempt for human rights in Latin America.

title: NETS TRY TO SHAKE OFF BAD DECISIONS
description: Decisions. Decisions. Perhaps more than in any other sport, basketball decisions are critical to a team's immediate success or failure. To sign? To waive? To trade? To draft? A management gaffe, and it might take a team several years to recover.

title: Tulane Reveals $1 Million Debit
description: Tulane University's intercollegiate sports program lost $1 million last year, school officials have confirmed.

title: STAGE: 3 STORIES IN 'SAND DANCING'
description: DO I detect a trend? The worst play of last week began with a recording of the Beatles singing ''Back in the U.S.S.R.'' Now we have Kenneth Pressman's ''Sand Dancing,'' a formidable contender for this week's worst-play honors, and it ends with the Beatles singing ''Hey Jude.'' Though there's some solace to be had in encountering beloved songs in trying circumstances, it's also possible that a conspiratorial exercise in mass aversion therapy is afoot. Let the Beatles turn up in a few more such dramatic clinkers, and even the most Beatlemaniacal theatergoers may soon switch their allegiance to the Lennon Sisters.

title: No Headline
description: Different Directions for 2 Teams Nov. 10, 1982 - Knicks lose to Nets and fall to 0-7; Nets (5-3) trade their ineffective point guard, Phil Ford, to Milwaukee for a forward, Mickey Johnson. Nov. 12 - Knicks win first game. Nov. 26 - Nets fall to 7-9, losing to Phoenix; one day later, Knicks fall to 3-11, losing to the Bucks. Dec. 8 - Nets win fifth in row, defeating Bullets to become, 12-9. Dec. 26 - Knicks lose to Indiana, fall 10 games below .500 - 9-19. Jan. 8, 1983 - Knicks lose to Los Angeles, fall to 12-22; three days later, Nets (23-13) win 10th straight, beating the Lakers. Jan. 14 - Knicks lose to Atlanta, fall to 13-24 and lose Edmond Sherod and Bernard King to injuries; Nets' victory string ends at 11. Jan. 15 - Teams meet and Knicks lose, falling 11 games below .500 (13-24); Nets are 25-14. Feb. 4 - Nets defeat Chicago to go 14 games over .500, 31-17. Feb. 6 - Nets obtain Michael Ray Richardson from Golden State in exchange for Mickey Johnson and Eric (Sleepy) Floyd. March 8 - Knicks defeat Seattle to reach .500 (30-30) for the first time.

title: ON STAGE AND ON TELEVISION TWO VIEWS OF GALA
description: SATURDAY'S Metropolitan Opera Gala was carried, all eight and a half hours of it, on public television's WNET/ Channel 13 as a ''Live From the Met'' presentation. As has been noted countless times before, there are considerable differences between going to an event and watching that same event on television. Exploring some of those differences, I attended the first part of the occasion, from 2 to 5:30 in the afternoon, at the theater in Lincoln Center, and watched the evening portion, from 8 to about 1 A.M., on a television set at home.

title: EXPLOSION HORRIFIES POPE
description: Pope John Paul II, shocked by the massacre of American and French soldiers in Beirut today, said this ''new act of war'' filled his soul with ''a feeling of great pain, of horror and of execration.''At his regular Sunday noon prayer appearance in St. Peter's Square, the Pope said: ''A feeling of great pain, of horror and of execration surges in the soul.

title: PENTAGON SAYS MARINES WILL IMPROVE DEFENSES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the bombing attack on the United States Marine force in Lebanon would not cause it to abandon its mission but would require it to find better ways to protect itself.

title: TV: ITALIAN 'LIFE OF VERDI' IN 6 PARTS
description: APPROPRIATELY coming on the heels of Saturday's Metropolitan Opera Gala, ''The Life of Verdi,'' a six- part weekly series, gets under way tonight at 8 on WNET/Channel 13. (It has already been shown on cable.) The composer's music was liberally represented at the Met's 100th birthday party.

description: As United States diplomats consulted with American citizens on Grenada, the 16 military officers who seized power warned the nation that they expected an invasion by forces from neighboring Caribbean states.

title: Charlotte Curtis Black-Tie in SoHo; 'That,' explained Ahmet Ertegun, is a rare dance called the fox trot.'
description: THE rich and the powerful slipped their uptown moorings for a few hours the other night to drink, dine and dance away a convivial evening for the Archives of American Art in beautiful downtown SoHo. They came in black- tie and evening gown to the Puck Building, a newly gentrified condominium on Lafayette Street across from a gas station in a neighborhood unaccustomed to an invasion of limousines. Their arrival was noted by passing denizens including curious middle-class residents, a drunk or two and a bag lady. A doorman escorted the swells to and from their cars.

title: Advertising; Chairman Of A.T.W. Sentenced
description: JOHN L. ERNST, the chairman of the Advertising to Women agency who pleaded guilty in a Federal court in August on two charges arising from income tax returns, was sentenced yesterday to 26 weekends in custody, and the maximum fine of $10,000 on each count. Additionally he will be required to create and teach a program intended to prepare ex-offenders for employment in the advertising business.

description: Following are excerpts from an opinion issued today by Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise in Federal District Court that found unconstitutional a law, Assembly Bill 1064, requiring a minute of silence in New Jersey public schools:

title: TV: 'BAY CITY BLUES' BEGINS ON NBC
description: THERE is nothing in television quite so persistent as the lure of imitation. Producers even imitate themselves. A couple of years ago, Steven Bochco and Michael Kozol ''created'' the award- winning series ''Hill Street Blues,'' constructed around a group of policemen and a couple of policewomen headed by a tough but fair, taciturn but sensitive leader played by Daniel J. Travanti. Now, in collaboration with Jeffrey Lewis, Mr. Bochco is bringing forth ''Bay City Blues,'' which begins its weekly run tonight at 10 on NBC.

title: No Headline
description: Ducking the Airbag Again Why won't Washington require the auto industry to use a relatively inexpensive, decades-old technology that could save 10,000 lives a year? Only because the inflating cushion restraint, popularly known as the airbag, has become a symbol of Big Brother for those who want less government. And the latest word from Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole suggests that she is reluctant to challenge conservative gospel.

title: THE KEY TO REFORM: FINDING THE TEACHERS
description: RACINE, Wis. white s THERE is no lack of generals who are calling for a campaign to improve the public schools. But what is lacking is an army of teachers trained to fight the battle for reforms. The nation's major universities, by largely abandoning teacher training, have done little to provide those important troops. The research universities haven't had teacher education on their agenda," J. Myron Atkin, dean of the School of Education at Stanford University, complained last week at a gathering of the deans of education of 17 leading universities. The meeting, held at the Johnson Foundation's Wingspread Conference Center here, was called to discuss how to build up a teaching force without which all the calls for better schools will fizzle. And while the deans agreed on the need to join forces to improve teacher education, they seemed less certain about how to do it. Although they never admitted it in so many words, they left little doubt that teacher education is in chaos. Schools of education attached to major universities today train fewer classroom teachers than in the past, and some have gone out of the teacher training business altogether. They prefer to do research, leaving the crucial task of teacher training to lesser institutions. Research is more glamorous than service in the trenches. Dealing with bright Ph.D. candidates, as one dean admitted, is more exciting than preparing teachers for the first grade. Although there was no formal agreement on the issue, the sense of the meeting was that leading universities must once again make teacher training first in priority. But what kind of training? The profession is seriously split. One faction would follow the medical model, with its internship and residency; another faction charges that such "apprenticeship" fails to imbue future teachers with fundamental philosophies of education. Most of the deans seemed to feel that reliance on apprenticeship limits the apprentice too narrowly to one model. "The public needs to make the decision - do we really want somebody teaching the children who is merely an apprentice?" asked Robert H. Koff, dean of the school of education at the State University of New York at Albany. Others view apprenticeship as an essential but currently missing, ingredient that should be added to, rather than replace, theoretical training. They consider current reliance on once-over-lightly student teaching insufficient to prepare future teachers for the classroom. Most new teachers face their first assignment with a sense of inadequacy, if not outright terror. Some observers critical of this way of teacher education say it is as if physicians got only their theoretical training in medical school and came face to face with real patients only after being licensed. Despite disagreement on such crucial questions, the deans unanimously insisted on the need for solid grounding in the subjects the trainees would be teaching: teachers must know what to teach before learning how to teach it. In fact, most of these prominent educators recommended that all future high school teachers at least major in the academic subject they want to teach during their four undergraduate years. This would be followed by a one-year master's program in education. The educators worried about a new trend: As critics of the schools, and particularly legislators, impose tough requirements for licensing teachers, local schools that are unable to find enough teachers, particularly in mathematics and science, are given waivers to permit unqualified people to teach. This is new, but the deans find the situation getting worse. They see a rash of quick-fix retraining. "You go into a six-week summer course as a social studies teacher, and come out as a math teacher," one of them said. The trend is dangerous because it creates the impression that children are taught more science, mathematics or whatever other subjects the reform proposals call for; but the added subjects appear only on the students' records, not in their minds. The deans were not overly optimistic about prospects for a dramatic rise in the number of high-ranking high school students who want to become teachers. "We are crazy to think we are going to get the best and the brightest," said one of the educators, who did not want to be identified. "We need to do a better job of training that middle third from whom most of our teachers will come." Until pay and conditions improve greatly, the the best students will shun teaching. Does this mean that the schools will have to give up all hope of drawing outstanding young people into teaching? Not, said the deans, if high-quality colleges and universities refrain from abandoning their teacher training function, as some have already done or are contemplating. Instead, the deans agreed, these schools should be trying to seduce some outstanding students into teaching. This can only happen, however, if the universities as a whole, not just their schools or departments of education, take an interest in the needs of the public schools. What emerged was an admission that the generals would have to spend more time with their troops. Painful as it may seem to many university- based teacher education people, status-rich research may have to take a back seat to activism in the field. One dean put it bluntly: "We can't blame the politicians who are pushing in all directions, if we don't tell them where we want to go." - ABOUT EDUCATION

title: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1983 Bombings in Beirut
description: Keeping the Marines in Lebanon is central to United States credibility on a global scale, President Reagan said. He denounced the Soviet Union's presence in the Middle East, but cautioned that reacting to the destruction of the Marine Corps headquarters in Beirut by applying increased military force in Lebanon would risk ''the start of overall conflict and world war.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Several House Democrats rebelled against their party's leadership and said they would offer a proposal to halt funds for the Marine contingent in Lebanon and to force President Reagan to bring the troops home. Congressional leaders said they expect the plan to fail. (A16:1.)

title: Roughnecks Set Back
description: The chances of saving the Tulsa Roughneck franchise by a public stock offering are dead, according to a co-owner of the North American Soccer League champions. Carl Moore said that hopes of putting the stock on the market by Nov. 1, at the latest, had vanished and that the offering could not be made before Jan. 1. He said that unless more investors were found, ''it's dead,'' and added, ''I think there will be a change of ownership in the next two weeks.''

title: Sharon Sees Soviet Role

''One of the mistakes of the free world has been to prevent Israel from ridding Beirut of the remnants of terrorism.''

Rivera has been charged by the police in Ross Township, a suburb of Pittsburgh, with drunken and reckless driving.

Philip was an all- American boy who loved baseball. He's very funny, a keen sense of humor. You get him in a room and you'll have a very good time. Growing up, he was just like any other all- American boy. Any other ethnic boy, that is.''

title: VIEW OF HIGH COURT ON SCHOOL PRAYER IS AWAITED
description: If it looks like prayer, seems like prayer, feels like prayer and promotes religion like prayer, then it is prayer, even if it's called a ''moment of silence.'' And if the state stands behind the practice, then it's unconstitutional. This, in essence, is what Judge Dickenson R. Debevoise of Federal District Court in Newark ruled Monday when he invalidated a New Jersey statute requiring children to observe one minute of ''quiet and private contemplation or introspection'' at the beginning of every school day.

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1983 Invasion of Grenada
description: An assault force of U.S. marines and Army rangers and soldiers from seven small Caribbean nations invaded Grenada before dawn and easily seized both airfields in the small island country. But the invaders' advance was reportedly slowed in the afternoon by heavy fire in the capital. (Page A1, Column 5.) President Reagan announced he had ordered the invasion of Grenada by nearly 1,900 Marines and Army airborne troops to protect United States citizens and to help restore democratic institutions in the Caribbean island. The casualties were said to be low. Mr. Reagan said the operation was launched in response to an urgent request from countries close to Grenada, some of which provided 300 troops for the assault. The United States, he said, ''had no choice but to act strongly'' to oppose ''a brutal gang of leftist thugs'' that violently seized power on Oct. 12 and later executed the ousted Prime Minister and other Cabinet members. (A1:6.)

title: HOLD FIRM ON LEBANON
description: In the wake of the savage and senseless murder of American and French forces in Lebanon, we face a question that goes to the heart of our purposes as a nation: Do we have the will and the resources to be a steady, consistent and persevering force for peace in Lebanon and the Middle East? I believe strongly that we should never send our troops to a place where our nation cannot sustain them. We now have committed our Marines to a delicate and dangerous task in Lebanon and we must sustain them there to provide time for political negotiations.

title: Atomic Research Ban Is Opposed by Bok
description: The president of Harvard University, Derek Bok, announced Monday his opposition to the proposed Nuclear-Free Cambridge Act, which would make research involving nuclear weapons illegal in this city, and called it ''intolerably vague for a criminal statute'' and ''a dangerous precedent.'' A referendum on the act will be held Nov. 8.

title: Clayton Season Ends
description: The board of education in Clayton, a small community in southern New Jersey, has canceled the rest of Clayton High School's varsity football season, but has voted to continue a junior varsity program. The nine-member board acted Monday night after school officials called off a varsity game last Friday because Clayton, which suffered a series of injuries in its first four games, had only 14 healthy players left, including only 5 with varsity experience. Joe Mucci, the athletic director, said he had hoped the board would allow the school to continue its varsity program on a week-to-week basis, but Coach Nick Russo called the board's action ''the only alternative.''

title: THEATER: 'KNUCKLEMEN,' CONTEST IN THE OUTBACK
description: ''THE Last of the Knucklemen,'' an Australian western by John Powers, is a knockabout adventure about wildcat miners betting, boasting and competing for power in the outback. In its original showcase production, the play began tamely but eventually became two-fisted. For the Off Broadway version, opening last night on the same stage at the American Theater of Actors, the director, Peter Masterson, has tightened and somewhat recast the production. Added punch is delivered by the evening's two new leading actors, Kevin O'Connor and Dennis Quaid.

title: Soviet Atom Blast Detected

title: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1983 Invasion in Grenada
description: The invasion of Grenada is advancing ''extremely well'' and only one major area of resistance remains, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said. He said that American losses stood at six killed, eight missing and 33 wounded. Mr. Weinberger said he was unable to provide any casualty figures for Grenadian and Cuban forces and had no word of any civilian casualties. He reported, however, that about 600 Cubans had been captured. (Page A1, Column 6.) Cuban resistance in Grenada reportedly ended, but American troops battled Grenadian soldiers and militiamen in crowded areas of the capital. The United States flew in hundreds of paratroopers to bolster the force of 1,900 marines and Army Rangers that invaded the island early Tuesday with soldiers from seven Caribbean island countries. (A1:5.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1983

The company, which had a 13.8 percent increase in sales, said about half its profit came from tax-loss carryforwards. It also said it might revalue its holding of 1.8 million shares of stock in the French auto maker Peugeot. (Page D1.) More oil companies showed improved third-quarter earnings as a result of cost-cutting programs and higher earnings from foreign operations. Among those reporting, Mobil was up 42.3 percent, Texaco 9.2 percent, Gulf 73.6 percent and Shell 1.6 percent. Occidental's net rose six-fold. (D1.)

In a televised interview in Columbus, Ohio, Schlichter, who was suspended from the National Football League indefinitely in May after he disclosed that he had run up almost $400,000 in gambling debts, acknowledged that his battle against compulsive gambling would be a lifelong struggle, but said he had not yielded to it.

title: DOOMING ARMS CONTROL

title: Fugitive Caught by F.B.I.

Mr. Watson, 37 years old, escaped June 22, 1982, from Patuxent Correctional Institution, where he was serving 95 years in connection with the murder of a Maryland state trooper. The bureau said he was arrested as he left his residence in Slatington.

title: ACHIEVING A FRESH LOOK: THE DETAILS THAT COUNT

Others think of the uncluttered open spaces of a newly renovated loft. Yet both have their limitations. The traditional space can be gloomy and rigid in its layout, while the clean modern interior can be unfocused, cool and off- putting.

title: 'MIMIC' FUNGUS SUSPECTED BY AIDS EXPERTS

title: ART: THE DRAWINGS OF CARLO CARRA
description: THE heavy Italian presence on today's art scene most noticeably that of the ''Neo-Expressionist'' painters Sandro Chia, Francesco Clemente and Enzo Cucchi - has inevitably rekindled interest in the older 20th-century Italian art from which they've borrowed so much. This, and the growing art- historical fix on the ''isms'' of the early 20th century, may account for the fact that now (and through Nov. 12), at the Rachel Adler Gallery, 58 East 79th Street, we're being treated to a show of drawings by Carlo Carr a (1881-1966). A founder of Futurism, the Italian homage to speed and movement, Carr a went on to join with Giorgio de Chirico in the ''metaphysical'' school of painting, winding up as a slightly revisionist Renaissance old master. But he must be one of the few European ''movement'' artists who until now hasn't had a solo exhibition in this country.

title: MUSIC: HOLST'S 'PLANETS' BY BALTIMORE

It was also a nice tribute to Sergiu Comissiona's work with this orchestra in this, his last concert in New York as the Baltimore's music director.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Yacullo , a linebacker, has been dropped from the University of Iowa's football team after his third arrest in two years. He was charged by the Iowa City police with drunken driving, possession of marijuana and interference with official acts. . . . Dan Hampton, defensive tackle for the Chicago Bears, has decided to ignore the advice of a team physician that he undergo surgery on his injured right knee. ''I know my body better than anybody else,'' said Hampton after Dr. Clarence Fossier recommended arthroscopic surgery on his knee, which was injured last Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles. . . . Mike Woodson , the sixth man last season for the Kansas City Kings, has undergone arthroscopic surgery and will be lost out about four weeks. . . . Coach Joe B. Hall of Kentucky said it was likely but not definite that his 7-1 center, Sam Bowie, would return after a two-year absence with injuries for the Wildcats' opener against Louisville Nov. 26. . . . Bruce Affleck and Gord Dineen , both defensemen, were sent back to Indianapolis of the Central Hockey League by the Islanders after being called up for Tuesday game against Winnipeg.

title: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1983 Invasion in Grenada
description: President Reagan termed Grenada ''a Soviet-Cuban colony being readied'' to export terrorism. In a televised speech, Mr. Reagan declared that the American invasion had prevented a planned ''Cuban occupation of the island.'' ''We got there just in time,'' he said. (Page A1, Column 6.) American forces captured the final major stronghold of Grenada's defenders at the edge of the capital, but the country's Marxist leader was reportedly holding out with hostages in the southern part of the island. Barbadians and the Pentagon said the attacking troops overran a prison, where Cubans and Grenadians had repulsed earlier assaults. (A1:5.)

title: DU PONT DE NEMOURS ,E I, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Transactions BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Jim Palmer, three times a winner of the Cy Young Award, filed for free agency. He has spent his entire major league career with the Orioles, starting in 1965. CLEVELAND (AL) - Gorman Thomas, outfielder formerly with Milwaukee, said he would invoke his right to be traded, preferably back to the Brewers. If he is not traded by March 15, his contract provides that he will become a free agent. DETROIT (AL) - Purchased contracts of Bob Melvin, catcher, Scotty Earl and Pedro Chavez, infielders, Nelson Simmons, outfielder, and Roger Mason and Bryan Kelly, pitchers. All except Chavez played last season with Birmingham, Class AA farm, and Evansville, Class AAA farm. Chavez played for Birmingham and San Jose of the Class AA California League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Purchased contracts of Matt Nokes, catcher, and C. L. Penigar, outfielder, from Fresno of Class A California League. Waived Chris Smith, infielder-outfielder. title: THEATER: AL PACINO, 'AMERICAN BUFFALO'
description: AL PACINO now has his performance down to a science in ''American Buffalo.'' In the new Broadway revival of David Mamet's play - a recycling of the deservedly successful Off Broadway revival of 1981 - the actor seems to have precisely thought out every move and line. A charismatic fellow under any circumstances, Mr. Pacino may not disappoint his fans with the energetic, fastidious star turn he is serving up at the Booth. Theatergoers hoping to see Mr. Mamet's crackling drama, however, will find that Mr. Pacino's calculated display of technique has doused much of its fire.

title: AT JEWISH MUSEUM, A DRAMATIC RESCUE STORY FROM DEMARK
description: Word spread rapidly through Copenhagen that the Nazis were preparing to round up Denmark's Jews. But when the German force struck, the Jews were hidden away in the attics and basements of their Danish neighbors. Over the next few days, in what amounted to a national effort by the Danish people, more than 7,000 Jews were spirited out of Denmark in a makeshift fleet of fishing boats and rowboats to sanctuary in Sweden.

No Headline
description: The Politics of the English-Speaking Caribbean Nations Grenada Barbados Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1966. Prime Minister: J. M. G. Adams, who belongs to Barbados Labor Party and was elected in 1976. Major opposition party is Democratic Labor Party. There is also a small black nationalist group called People's Progressive Movement. Jamaica Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1962. Prime Minister: Edward P. G. Seaga, who was elected in 1980, ending eight years of socialist rule under Government of Michael Manley. Mr. Manley, first elected in 1974, established close links with Cuba and Soviet Union, which were loosened with his defeat. Dominica Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1978. Prime Minister: Eugenia Charles, member of Dominica Labor Party, elected in 1980 after internal dissent led to resignation of Prime Minister Patrick John. Two attempted coups in 1981, both unsuccessful. St.Kitts-Nevis Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since September 1983. Prime Minister: Dr. Kennedy A. Simmonds, elected in 1980, is leader of People's Action Movement, in coalition with Nevis Reformation Party. One major opposition movement: the Labor Party. St. Vincent and the Grenadines Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1979, when current . Prime Minister,: Milton Cato, who had been serving as Premier, was elected. to current position in 1979. Frequent social strife since then, including general strike in 1981. Fragmented political opposition in the past but Progressive Democratic Party emerged as important opposition force to Mr. Cato's St. Vincent Labor Party.

title: No Headline
description: Grenada - and Mount Suribachi No one was surprised last month when the Soviet Government refused to let reporters near the place where Korean Flight 007 had been shot down: everybody knows how open the Russians are to public scrutiny. But there's plenty of reason for surprise now, in Grenada, for this time it's the United States Government that has been trying to keep the public in the dark.

title: No Headline
description: Doctors' Care for Medicare People who look forward to Medicare as a cushion in old age typically are dismayed to find that it doesn't cover all their medical costs. One reason is that the law permits doctors, unlike hospitals, to charge the Medicare patient more than Medicare will reimburse. An amendment favorably reported by the House Ways and Means Committee would change that, protecting both patients and the Medicare program's solvency. Despite predictable objections from doctors, the plan is worth trying.

title: QUEENS AT 300, STILL GROWING AND FULL OF SURPRISES
description: F OR many New Yorkers, Queens is a place to go through to get somewhere else, like the airport, for instance, to go to another country. But in this, the county's 300th anniversary year, Queens would like you to know that not only is it home to the Mets and Jets, but also to the only Dravidian-style Hindu temple in North America, perhaps the best Greek cooking outside of Athens, the birthplace of Quakerism in America, a scale model of New York City that includes 835,000 buildings and every street in the five boroughs, a collection of Chinese art in the only Peking- style building in the city, the heart of the city's growing Korean community, Civil War fortifications, a weeping beech tree that is an official city landmark, a protected wildlife preserve filled with herons, geese and migrating ducks, 16,000 acres of parkland and a major museum, not to mention Governor Cuomo's brick house.

title: GRENADA PROVES WE'LL FIGHT
description: ''Will America ever fight?'' That was the stark question posed by the British writer Henry Fairlie four years ago. He reasoned that if the world were to conclude that no reliable response to events could be expected from the United States, its friends and enemies would go on to make their own arrangements in ways that would make the world a more dangerous place than it would be if American power were still something to be reckoned with. The United States' intervention in Grenada gives a clear if not resounding answer, and it is an answer that should make the world a less rather than more dangerous place.

title: No Bonus for M.V.P.

''Given the odds against that happening, they would've given it to me,'' said Dempsey, a .231 hitter during the season who rapped out four doubles and a home run while batting .385 during the Series.

title: OPERA: 'LA TRAVIATA'
description: THE role of Violetta in ''La Traviata'' is for a soprano what Hamlet is for an actor or Giselle is for a ballerina: a part that cuts across the range of human emotions and allows inexhaustible opportunities for a talented artist. Whether Verdi planned it that way or not - and I think he did - in each act his consumptive heroine moves back and forth with giddy suddenness through a spectrum that runs from buoyant joy to the deepest and darkest anguish. Is it any wonder that sopranos of all sizes, shapes and degrees of talent lust after such a part?

title: FILM: 'RICHARD PRYOR HERE AND NOW'
description: DURING the concert performance that is recorded in ''Richard Pryor Here and Now,'' Mr. Pryor is presented with a live crab by someone in the audience. He makes a few jokes about this, of course, but he also does much more: He talks to the crab, talks about it, even imagines how it must feel about being in the limelight. Letting it creep around the seat of a stool, for instance, he supposes that the crab must be discovering that the world is round.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DISTURBANCES IN THE FIELD. By Lynne Sharon Schwartz. 371 pages.Harper & Row. $15.95. IT takes a long time to get to the good part in Lynne Sharon Schwartz's third novel, ''Disturbances in the Field.'' One has to slog through a lot of adolescent talk, which led me to wonder whether anyone but the parents or peers of adolescents could find them consistently interesting. They try so very hard: even their ideas seem to be choked with hormonal changes, to have poor complexions.

In a statement, William R. Rhodes, chairman of the committee, added that the banks are also being asked to extend until the same date the deadline on a $350 million repayment on a $1.1 billion bridging loan signed last December. The advisory committee requested that banks respond to the recommendations by Nov. 15.

title: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1983 Invasion in Grenada
description: Fighting reportedly dwindled in southern Grenada, but United States military officials said it appeared that some Cuban and Grenadian troops had taken positions in the mountainous central and northern parts of the island. Fears were expressed that protracted fighting was still in prospect to eliminate the remaining pockets of resistance. The Defense Department said in Washington that 300 Cubans had retreated into the central and northern areas ''where militia camps were known to exist.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. criticized the Reagan Administration's foreign policy, calling it ''frightening.'' The House Speaker's comments came as the Senate adopted an amendment declaring that the War Powers Resolution now applied to the fighting in Grenada. (1:3-4.)

description: W. J. Usery, a labor consultant hired by Eastern Airlines, said yesterday that three major unions and management had agreed on the results of an independent audit that showed the carrier had serious financial problems. Both sides pledged to work for a solution, he said.

title: KLOSS VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Keeping in Touch
description: The New Jersey Generals said goodbye and hello yesterday to Chuck Fairbanks , their president and head coach until Donald J. Trump purchased the United States Football League team two months ago. Trump said what everyone had expected, that Fairbanks would not remain as a coach or as president. However, he said Fairbanks would remain as a consultant during the ownership transition period.

title: Loss for Bank In Oklahoma
description: The First Oklahoma Bancorporation said yesterday that it posted a loss of $58.3 million in the third quarter, primarily because of problem energy loans. The company earned $8.63 million, or 75 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1982.

title: Secret Service Men See Slaying but Do Not Act
description: A police detective today said two United States Secret Service agents witnessed the slaying of a doorman at a condominium, but he said the Police Department could not comment on why the two had made no attempt to arrest the suspect.

description: A senior Administration intelligence official today dismissed as unfounded a report from Ankara, Turkey, that a Soviet general had defected through Turkey in September, saying there was ''nothing to it.''

title: JOHN CANDY IN 'BERSERK'
description: John Candy is easily the funniest thing in ''Going Berserk,'' an affably stupid comedy that's saddled with too much plot and that hasn't nearly enough energy to go with it. Mr. Candy plays John Bourgignon, a tubby limousine driver whose exploits are much too numerous to chronicle in detail. He's involved in an assassination plot and a jailbreak, among other things, with a good cast that includes Pat Hingle, Richard Libertini, Alley Mills, Paul Dooley, Eugene Levy and Joe Flaherty.

title: BAXTER SILENT ON REPORTS HE'LL QUIT ANTITRUST POST
description: William F. Baxter, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division since 1981, will resign to return to the Stanford University law faculty, friends and Government officials reported today.

description: In Washington there was a crisis of respect. Men who thought of themselves as men deserving respect met at the White House. ''We are men of respect, yet we get no respect,'' they acknowledged.

description: Workers covered by union contracts negotiated in the first nine months of 1983 accepted first-year pay increases averaging 1.7 percent, less than half the current rate of price increases, the Labor Department reported today.

title: NO WORD ON FATE OF SHIP OFF CHINA

title:
PATENTS;
Method to Test Drugs For Chemotherapy
description: A method of testing drugs to determine which are preferable for cancer chemotherapy has been developed at the University of Arizona Cancer Center in Tucson. Dr. Sydney E. Salmon, director of the center, and Anne W. Hamburger, a cell biologist, were granted Patent 4,411,990 this week and assigned it to University Patents Inc. of Norwalk, Conn.

title: TEACHER CONVICTED IN SLAYING
description: A high school English teacher was convicted on three counts of first-degree murder today on charges of plotting the killings of a fellow teacher and her two children to collect a $900,000 inheritance.

title: AFGHANS' FIGHT IS ALSO AMERICA'S FIGHT
description: War in Afghanistan. Almost four years of it. We don't think about it. There is little news. There is war and death enough in Lebanon, in Grenada, in Central America, in Chad. But in all its terror it is there, in Afghanistan, too, as surely as you hold this newspaper.

title: Letter: On Food Aid Audit the Free (School) Lunch To the Editor:
description: You are correct that for most of its 37 years, all that America's school lunch program asked of its participants was self-declaration of household income. You are misleading the public, though, by saying ''Two years ago, however, an Agriculture Department impelled by suspicion of fraud and pressure to cut costs asked that parents list their Social Security numbers on the applications'' (editorial Oct. 1, ''An Expensive Way to Save on Lunch'').

title: Two Soviet Diplomats Are Expelled by Belgium
description: The Belgian Government said today that it had expelled two Soviet diplomats for spying, the second Eastern-bloc espionage scandal in Belgium in recent months.

title: Increase in Caesarean Births Is Linked to Added Survivals
description: A dramatic increase in births by Caesarean section in the United States may be partly responsible for improved survival rates among some high-risk infants, a doctor said Wednesday.

title: WHITE HOUSE INSISTS; MILITARY IS DOUBTFUL
description: Americans back the invasion of Grenada and marines in Lebanon but are uneasy with President Reagan in a crisis, a poll shows. Page 9.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Mystery of the List

title: CAROLINA OFFICIAL ACQUITTED OF BRIBERY
description: Lieut. Gov. James C. Green was acquitted today of four charges that he agreed to take a bribe. The jury took about two hours to reach its decision.

title: MIDWEST FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. SAID TO THINK IRAN HAD KEY ROLE IN BEIRUT ATTACKS
description: The Reagan Administration is now assuming that the Iranian Government played the key role in the bombing attacks on the American marines and French troops last Sunday and will retaliate once conclusive information is collected, Administration officials said today.

title: WRIGLEY, WILLIAM JR, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; A Special Name at Illinois
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.

title: HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TODAY'S ARTISTS ARE IN LOVE WITH THE STAGE
description: It is a perennial dream that one day the fine

title: ABOUT MEN
description: BASIS FOR COMFORT BY RALPH DIGENNARO Ralph DiGennaro writes regularly about men's style for The New York Times Magazine. KEIJI OBATA

title: CARNAGE IN BEIRUT ONLY STIFFENS THE WILL OF THE FRENCH TO STAY
description: On the covers of magazines, in newspapers, on the state television networks, one photograph from Beirut appeared again and again here this week: It showed a buried soldier's hand reaching out from underneath the rubble of the devastated French billet, and another soldier, a rescuer, grasping it, holding it as if he would never let go.

title: MESSINEO PACES EDISON IN 30-6 ROUT
description: J. R. Messineo caught three touchdown passes from Craig McCoy to lead Edison (4-2) past Madison Central of Old Bridge, 30-6, yesterday in Edison.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS AGENCY LOOKS FOR A CONGRESSIONAL RESUSCITATION
description: Congress created the United States Commission on Civil Rights at the request of President Eisenhower, who said he wanted a ''real investigative body'' to look into persistent reports of discrimination against blacks. He said he hoped the nation would solve its civil rights problems ''by reason, by education, by tolerance of the other fellow's views.''

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
HOW DOES A MOZART HAPPEN?
description: The mystery of where extraordinarily gifted musicians come from has never been solved and, I must warn you, it will not be solved in this space today. However, it is an enigma that must tease the imagination of anyone who considers the periodic arrival of these star-kissed individuals in our midst to be a blessing, on balance.

title: 12 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY FOR VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 12 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: EARLY CASUALTIES IN DEMOCRATIC CAMPAIGN
description: While news from abroad dominated the front pages, Democratic contenders for the White House were mostly preoccupied with squabbling among their field commanders.

title: THE CONTROL OF INFORMATION
The Mystery Of Existence
description: My heart goes out to Sondra W. Baron after reading her article (''Give Me One More Ride,'' Oct. 9).

title: Teacher Held on Charge Of Murder of Woman, 21
description: A former anatomy professor at Tufts University has been arrested and charged with first-degree murder in the disappearance of a 21-year-old artist.

title:
CAMERA;
DRAMATIC EFFECTS POSSIBLE WITH SILHOUETTES
description: Stan Godlewski is a freelance photojournalist.

title: 'Frivolous' Cases
description: To the Business Editor:

title: LIONS, TREATED LIKE 'FAMILY,' MAUL OREGON MAN TO DEATH
description: A woman who owned three African lions and treated them like family had them shot to death after the mauled remains of a man believed to be her husband were found in the animals' fenced compound.

title: DARTMOUTH RALLIES TO TOP YALE, 24-21
description: Yale surprised Dartmouth by scoring three touchdowns in the first 21 minutes of play today and then tried to sustain its diminishing lead through the third and fourth quarters. But the Elis could not stop the Green's final offensive drive, and Dartmouth won, 24-21, on a 22-yard touchdown pass with 47 seconds to play.

title: THE CONTROL OF INFORMATION
TENNESSEE OVERCOMES RUTGERS
description: Johnnie Jones, who began the season as perhaps Tennessee's fourth-best running back, broke two school records for rushing today in providing the only excitement during the Volunteers' 7-0 victory over surprisingly tough Rutgers.

title: THE JOFFREY BALLET IS IN TOP FORM
description: Everything seems to be going right for the Joffrey Ballet. It has acquired a new base at the Los Angeles Music Center, and therefore a new source of financial backing from a California board of trustees that recently merged with its New York directors. Much more visibly, its current New York season at the City Center has been launched with an exemplary renewal of artistic standards. Perhaps this is most evident in the company premieres of ballets tranferred from elsewhere.

title: SQUARING INTERNATIONAL LAW WITH POLITICAL IMPERATIVES
description: WASHINGTON DOES anything that deserves the name ''international law'' govern the use of military force? Last week's invasion of Grenada raised the question anew, as Reagan Administration lawyers and critics fenced with citations of treaties and charters, a familiar exchange in any shooting war.

title: GROUP PLUGS IN COMPUTERS TO HELP DISABLED
description: A home builder in Alabama wanted floor plans for a house equipped for a resident in a wheelchair. A motorist in Ohio whose right leg had been amputated wanted to find a company that made gas pedals for the left foot. A Washington resident requested the names of local support groups that could help her son, who has a permanent spinal injury but wants to live alone.

title: DANCE: KEITH LEE TROUPE AND A SOLO FOR A TEACHER
description: The stage crackled with excitement for a few minutes the other night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, in a performance by the Keith Lee Ballet of Contemporary Arts. The occasion was ''Mama Rose,'' dedicated to the late Thelma Hill, a much-loved New York dance teacher. Set to nervily intense jazz and poetry by Archie Shepp, the solo hinted poignantly at the disparate black American cultures of the days before and after the struggle for racial equality of the 1960's, all in one smoothly blended whole.

title: Co-op Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: HOPES of finding the cockpit voice recorder of Korean Airlines' Flight 007 have all but vanished, but the families in the downing of the 747 over the Sea of Japan last month do not plan to let the matter rest.

title: 166 YARDS FOR RORKE OF BROOKS
description: Matt Rorke, at 5 feet 9 inches, may be considered small for a running back by some large football colleges. But as far as Bill Poirot is concerned, ''he is one heck of a football player.''

title: A Setback For Connors
description: Jimmy Connors was upset by unseeded Scott Davis in the semifinals of the $375,000 Seiko Super Tennis tournament today.

title: REPRISE FOR VAUDEVILLE HOUSE
description: As Marvin Ravikoff tells it, when he bought the decrepit Capitol Theater at 149 Westchester Avenue in Port Chester, N.Y., earlier this year, the ground floor was filled with water and there were ''about 20 million pigeons in residence.'' Since then he has begun rehabilitating the 2,000-seat theater, which had been closed for seven years.

title: No Headline
description: Best Re-Release?

title: N. ROCKLAND SQUEAKS BY
description: A single point stretched North Rockland's winning streak to 25 games yesterday as the Red Raiders defeated host Clarkstown South, 7-6. North Rockland, the defending champions in the county and the ninth- ranked team in the state, were unable to score until the fourth quarter.

title: THE QUESTION: TO SKI OR APR ES SKI?
description: ENID NEMY is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times.

title: FAST-FOOD OUTLETS: FAST GROWING, TOO
description: IN the last few years, fast-food places have flocked to Long Island, bringing with them attractive prices and an appealing variety of foods. For the most part, these chain-franchise outlets have met with success, and the reasons for that have a lot to do with the nature of the Island's economy and life style. In a way, the Island was just what the fast-food industry ordered, and fast food was just what Long Islanders ordered.

title: Generosity Repaid
description: Dan Issel became the eighth player in professional basketball history to score more than 25,000 points Friday night after getting a little incentive in the afternoon from the Denver Nuggets.

title: COURT INVALIDATES BERKELEY RENT CONTROL LAW
description: A three-judge panel of the State Court of Appeal has declared this city's stringent rent control law unconstitutional. If the ruling stands, according to lawyers in the case, an equally stringent law in Santa Monica in southern California might also be struck down.

title: NATURE WATCH ATLANTIC COD Gadus morhua
description: Size: Average caught by anglers, three to 25 pounds. Record, six feet and 211 pounds, caught by trawler in 1895.

title: Spellman Clinches
description: Cardinal Spellman clinched first place in the City Division of the Catholic High Schools' Football league yesterday when it beat Farrell, 14-6.

title: JUST WHEN IS PRETRIAL PUBLICITY UNFAIR?
description: Was it truly asking too much, in view of an individual's right to a fair trial, to pause - a moral pause - to respectfully withhold the disclosure for just a week?'' said Federal District Court Judge Robert M. Takasugi.

title: IMPASSE IN SENATE IS THREATENING TO DELAY ACTION ON DEBT CEILING
description: The Senate faced new obstacles today in its effort to raise the nation's debt limit. The impasse could prevent Congress from acting before Monday night's deadline, forcing the Government to postpone plans for borrowing.

title: FLORIDA IS BEATEN BY AUBURN, 28-21
description: Bo Jackson ran 55 and 80 yards for touchdowns, the latter after a controversial turnover, to help Auburn defeat Florida, 28-21, in a Southeastern Conference game today.

title: New Towns From Old Change Census Figures
description: That ''five towns were smaller in the last census than in the one of 1800'' (''Population Nears Its Peak,'' Oct. 9) might be explained by boundary changes in the intervening years.

title: MOVIE 'SCARFACE' RECEIVES X RATING
description: ''Scarface,'' Universal's $23.5 million Christmas movie, was given an X rating this afternoon by the rating board of the Motion Picture Association of America.

title:
GARDENING;
A MATTER OF IMPROVING YOUR GARDEN SOIL
description: THE nature of the soil has a greater influence on success with plants than any factor other than climate. Fall is an ideal time to work heavy clay soils.

title: MENNINGER, AT 90, STILL WORRIES ABOUT WORLD
description: At the age of 90, Dr. Karl Menninger, regarded by many as the dean of American psychiatry, is still trying to jolt people into dealing with the fact that ''the world is in a nervous, unsettled state in which terrible things can happen.''

title: BOSTON COLLEGE TOPS PENN ST.
description: The thought, Doug Flutie said, never crossed his mind. Even though Boston College was only seven minutes away from winning a game that the players thought would give the school inmeasurable prestige and national recognition, the offense was not going to allow caution to become a last- minute addition to the game plan. So on first down from his 18-yard line and facing a team popularly known as the Beast in the East, Flutie took the snap from center and once again dropped back to pass.

title: SPECIALIZED NORDIC GEAR
description: RUTH ROBINSON is an editor in the Style section of The New York Times.

title: BRIDGE IN MARSH IS CONTESTED
description: A 20-FOOT-LONG footbridge has become the latest focal point in a decade-long fight over property rights and environmental protection in a Clinton salt marsh.

title: THE WITCH WHO FOUND NEW HAUNTS
description: FOR 364 days a year, her neighbors liked Betty. For one day a year, they could have done without her. On Halloween, of course.

title: BANKAMERICA IN SEARCH OF ITSELF
description: SAN FRANCISCO IT WAS a sunny day here two weeks ago - and from

title: DEMOCRATS SHARPLY CRITICAL AT NEW HAMPSHIRE FORUM
description: The appearance of seven Democratic Presidential aspirants at the state party convention here today was marked by sharp criticism of President Reagan's foreign policy and even sharper criticism of the two apparent front-runners by their opponents.

title: KEAN STILL TRYING ON HOBOKEN PLAN
description: HOBOKEN IF THIS city's $500 million waterfront project falls by the riverside, it certainly will not be Governor Kean's fault.

title:
ON AND OFF THE SLOPES;
ROCKIES SKIING: NOTHING TO FEAR BUT FEAR ITSELF
description: NORMAN ZOLLINGER, a novelist who lives in Albuquerque, is the author of ''Corey Lane'' and ''Riders to Cibola.''

title: IN AUTUMN, ONE TURNS TO HEARTY SOUPS
description: THE taste for soup changes according to the seasons. Like the landscape, even the colors change. Light, pale herb-scented soups of spring give way to summer's smooth chilled purees of scarlet tomato and green cucumber. In autumn and winter hearty soups thickened with dry beans, enriched with meat and winey mushrooms whet the appetite. It becomes a season for large helpings of soups that are fortifying enough to be one-dish meals.

title: A DESIGNER BIDS TIFFANY GOODBYE
description: She is small and soft-spoken, and tough is about the last word that would be used to describe her, but Angela Cummings, one of the foremost jewelry designers in the country, agrees that her appearance is deceptive.

title: PLAINEDGE MOVES INTO FIRST
description: Alex Coules scored a touchdown and caught an interception yesterday, helping Plainedge defeat Plainview, 12-0, and move into first place in Conference B Division B.

title: COMPOSERS' FORUM IS INTERNATIONAL NOW
description: Linda Sanders is the music critic of Saturday Review.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: ''Sadat,'' which will be broadcast in two parts on Monday and on Nov. 7 on Channel 11, ''marks the first time that U.S. television has presented the crisis in the Middle East from the viewpoint of an Arab nation,'' Columbia Pictures says of its four- hour television movie. The film covers about 40 years in the life of Anwar el- Sadat, the late Egyptian president and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize who was assassinated two years ago. Operation Prime Time is syndicating ''Sadat'' as it did ''A Woman Named Golda,'' about Golda Meir, the former Israeli prime minister. Ingrid Bergman won an Emmy award, posthumously, for her portrayal of Mrs. Meir.

title: CHICAGO GOES BACK TO SCHOOL
description: Chicago teachers, who stayed off the job more than three weeks demanding a 10 percent salary increase, were back in the classroom last week after getting ''what we wanted all along,'' according to their leader, a 5 percent increase.

title: HOUSING ACT AIDS ELDERLY
description: THE Town of Huntington has became the first municipality in Suffolk County to enact a law protecting elderly and handicapped tenants during conversions of rental apartments to cooperatives or condominiums.

title: BAY STATE FEE FILLS IN FOR U.S. LEGAL AID CUTS
description: Local and statewide legal aid programs are beginning to benefit from a new Massachusetts court fee designed to compensate for Federal cutbacks.

title: Susan Patel Weds R. M. Furlaud Jr.
description: Susan V. Patel and Richard Mortimer Furlaud Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Stephen Garmey at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jamshed R. Patel of Summit, N.J. Her husband is the son of Richard M. Furlaud of Princeton, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., and Elspeth Banks Furlaud of New York and Edgartown, Mass.

title: PARALYTIC CHOOSING DEATH OVER A LIFE OF PAIN
description: Tired of being in constant pain and dependent upon others for her survival, Elizabeth Bouvia is fighting for the right to die.

title: No Headline
description: Investigators Report Air Traffic Problems

title: WASTE-STUDY CENTER PLANNED
description: WITH an $18,000 planning grant from the National Science Foundation, New Jersey's major institutions of higher education are laying the groundwork for what is expected to become the nation's first research center for developing technologies to detoxify or otherwise deal with hazardous waste.

title: OPERA: DEBUT BY BARITONE
description: There were wholesale cast changes in Verdi's ''Forza del Destino'' at the Metropolitan Opera Friday night. Most notable was the Met debut of the Italian baritone Silvano Carroli as Don Carlo.

title: Before Leap, Suicide Set Up Meeting With Line's Officials
description: A man who leaped from a commuter airplane had, only hours before, resigned from a job at the airline, a company official said today.

title: DOROTHY LAMOUR'S RUBBER FEET, ETC.
description: RITA The Life of Rita Hayworth. By Joe Morella and Edward Z. Epstein. Illustrated. 261 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95. JOAN CRAWFORD The Ultimate Star. By Alexander Walker. Authorized by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. Illustrated. 192 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $29.95. JAZZ BABY By David Houston. Illustrated. 203 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95. BABY DOLL By Carroll Baker. Illustrated. 305 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.95. PRETTY BABIES An Insider's Look at the World of the Hollywood Child Star. By Andrea Darvi. Illustrated. 210 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $14.95. EDITH HEAD'S HOLLYWOOD By Edith Head and Paddy Calistro. With a Foreword by Bette Davis. Illustrated. 240 pp.

title: A GUIDE TO WINE TASTINGS
description: WINE bars and formal wine tastings, where people can sample a variety of vintages in an afternoon or evening, have become quite popular. Because it is illegal for stores selling licensed beverages in the state to allow open bottles on the premises, a place to evaluate wine is important for those interested in buying cases for their cellars.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT BULLETS, 100-97
description: SAM GOLDAPER

title: U.S. TO STUDY POLLUTION IN HIGH-TECHNOLOGY AREA
description: California's area of high- technology and electronics industries, once thought to be free of pollution, has been chosen as the site for a $500,000 study by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: ILLINOIS DEFEATS MICHIGAN, 16-6
description: J. D. Gross led a blitzing Maryland defense that broke up a 2-point conversion attempt with 22 seconds left today and preserved a 28-26 upset over previously undefeated North Carolina.

title: Newsweek Is Dropped From Grenada Visits
description: Newsweek magazine was barred from further participation in press pool trips to Grenada after a photographer working for the magazine failed to return Friday with 23 others.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY:SWAMP ADVENTURES, SKI HOLIDAYS SEA VOYAGES
description: Hot-air balloon.

title: O'ROURKE AND REID OUTLINE VIEWS ON WIDE RANGE OF ISSUES
description: WITH the campaign for County Executive drawing to a close, the two major candidates have been outlining their positions on a wide range of issues, including housing, the environment and county government. Some of the areas in which they disagree were explored last week when Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican-Conservative incumbent, and Ogden R. Reid, the Democrat-Liberal, met in a 90-minute debate at The New York Times.

title: North Korea Says U.S. Violated Its Airspace
description: The official North Korean press agency said today that a United States Air Force SR-71 reconnaissance plane had violated North Korean airspace twice in a ''high-handed encroachment'' on North Korea's sovereignty.

title: Jody Robinson Married to Bronson Hart Fargo Jr.
description: The marriage of Joanne Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Robinson of Hillsdale, N.J., to Bronson Hart Fargo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fargo of Grafton, Mass., and Little Compton, R.I., took place yesterday. Msgr. Thomas Guinan performed the ceremony at Our Lady Mother of the Church Roman Catholic Church in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. George Holland.

title: USING TAX REFUNDS TO 'DO SOMETHING WILD'
description: When Peter and Judy van der Linden calculated their Iowa state taxes last spring, they found they had a modest refund coming. They never received it. That's because the van der Lindens used the ''Chickadee Checkoff,'' a new line on the tax form that lets Iowans, like taxpayers in many other states, direct some or all of their refunds into a state conservation fund to benefit native nongame animals that are endangered.

title: RECITAL: ANTONINO MENESES
description: Antonio Meneses, a deft and skillful young cellist from Brazil, played Beethoven, Debussy, Schubert and Brahms at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night. Mr. Meneses was inhibited somewhat by the faceless collaborations of his partner at the piano, Franz Massinger, but in all this music he showed a delicacy of phrase, a fine sense of intonation and, in general, a very impressive control of his instrument.

title: DANCE: TRADITION AND INNOVATION
description: -84 dance season enters its first quarter with modern, jazz and ballet companies staging revivals of old favorites, as well as experimental pieces, and promises to be marked by tradition and innovation.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT DEVILS, 5-3
description: Caution. The following synopsis could be misleading:

title:
GARDENING;
A MATTER OF IMPROVING YOUR GARDEN SOIL
description: THE nature of the soil has a greater influence on success with plants than any factor other than climate. Fall is an ideal time to work heavy clay soils.

title: PUMPKIN TIME
description: EFORE THE tin can stripped the pumpkin of its own natural container and reduced its flesh to a mere pulp, the fruit was an example of Yankee thrift and wit. How many foods, after all, come in their own pots? And how often does the price of a vegetable include a lidded tureen or casserole as chic in color and shape as a piece of French Le Creuset?

title: WHEN IS A BOND MORE THAN A BOND?
description: IN their pristine state, bonds are relatively

title: U.S. CONSIDERING COURT'S RULING FOR FARMERS
description: The Agriculture Department is considering whether to appeal a Federal District Court ruling that extends to 43 other states a suit by North Dakota farmers seeking a halt in foreclosures and accelerated loan payments to the Farmers Home Administration.

title: Alcoholism's Cost Is Put In Billions
description: The economic cost of alcohol abuse may be as high as $120 billion in the United States each year, and treating alcoholism may cost less than not treating it, according to a Congressional report.

title:
TELEVISION;
PRESERVING THE BEST OF TODAY'S PROGRAMMING FOR TOMORROW'S VIEWERS
description: While working on the PBS documentary series ''Vietnam: A Television History,'' Kenn Rabin, whose job was to dig up historic footage, couldn't locate one of the most famous broadcast reports of the war. In August of 1965, CBS News cameras had shown American marines setting fire to the straw huts of Vietnamese villages with cigarette lighters, and the story had caused an uproar.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Dripping blood, spinning eyeballs, shrieking mouths and miscellaneous other graphic elements that book designers use to telegraph

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
MONEY MAN FOR PUBLIC RADIO
description: Douglas J. Bennet won't bring any broadcasting experience to the presidency of National Public Radio, the job to which he was named last week, but that doesn't seem to matter much. Something in far shorter supply at NPR is the ability to part politicians from public funds, which happens to be Mr. Bennet's long suit.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MAJO CHANGES LIKELY IN U.S. PAPER MONEY
description: United States paper money is likely to undergo a number of important changes within the next few years. Some will probably be subtle and chiefly of interest to collectors, but others might well be dramatic enough to catch the eye of everyone who handles ''folding money.''

title: Celine Stahl, Doctor, Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn., yesterday, Dr. Celine Marie Stahl, daughter of Gloria Kloos Stahl of San Diego and the late James Edward Stahl of Cincinnati, was married to Eugene Ransom Bayliss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayliss of Westport. The Rev. Robert Sproule, who teaches at Fairfield College Preparatory School, of which the bridegroom is a graduate, performed the ceremony.

title: MARY D. LAVELLE, A NURSE, TO WED
description: Mary D. Lavelle, a registered nurse, and Dr. Michael L. Spear, a pediatrician, both at The Children's Hospital in Philadelphia, planned to be married in March 10.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: HALLOWEEN gives children a chance to dress up like ''scary'' creatures, such as monsters, witches, rats and bats. But at the Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, it's the grownups who are dressing up for Rat and Bat Weekend, which began yesterday and continues through tomorrow. Vincent Sharp , the zoo's education director, wears a bat's outfit and Barbara Dyer , its project director, dresses to match the weekend's guest of honor - Zilda , the office rat.

title: PROPOSED TRANSIT BOND CONTAINS $100 MILLION IN PROJECTS FOR COUNTY
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO, standing near an aging bridge in the City of Rye while campaigning recently in the county for the proposed new state transportation bond issue, was quietly buttonholed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: ; WHAT'S WRONG WITH NATO?
description: What's Wrong With NATO?

title: Susan Sillcox Marries William Clarke Repko
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday Susan Sillcox, director of treasury operations of the Continental Group in Stamford, Conn., was married to William Clarke Repko, a vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York. The Rev. Philip Perkins performed the ceremony.

title: YALE TO CELEBRATE WEILL ACQUISITION
description: THE Yale University Music Library has acquired the complete works of the composer Kurt Weill, bringing to 35 the number of comprehensive collections in the library's Archive of 20th Century American Music.

title: LAW TO SITE WASTE PLANTS REMAINS AT STANDSTILL
description: A TWO-YEAR-OLD state law designed to help solve New Jersey's growing hazardous-waste disposal problem and actively encourage new means of safely getting rid of the wastes has done neither, according to state officials, environmentalists and corporate spokesmen.

title: HELPFUL 'HOTLINE' FOR RUNAWAYS
description: The first night, when it starts getting dark, their dreams of making it on their own begin to shatter and they often panic, realizing how vulnerable they really are.'' That, said the head of the Victim Services Agency, is the reason for the New York City Runaway Hotline.

title: Sheriff's Aide Admits Charge
description: Floyd Baker, a former San Jacinto deputy arrested with Sheriff James C. (Humpy) Parker and two other deputies on charges of abusing prisoners, has pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to violate the civil rights of inmates. Five other counts against Mr. Baker, 40 years old, of depriving inmates of liberty by subjecting them to water torture were dropped Friday by Federal District Judge James DeAnda.

title:
STAMPS;
THE NATIONAL STAMP SHOW OPENS NOV. 17
description: No matter what the calendar says, collectors know that fall does not arrive until the National Stamp Show opens. This year the show will be held at the Madison Square Garden Rotunda from Nov. 17 through Nov. 20, marking the start of a new philatelic season.

title: NEW YORK'S SPIRIT
description: UST AS THERE IS USUALLY SOME SHIFTing about of silhouettes in fashionable clothes from season to season, so too there will be a bit of change for next spring from America's designers. Much longer hemlines, for instance, are being suggested for daytime, some dipping as low as the ankle. And while the shape of clothes in general, as in Paris, is still broadish of shoulder, it is now more often languid and narrow of silhouette rather than agressively curvy.

title: MORE SUPPORT FOR IMMIGRANTS URGED AFTER BROOKLYN SURVEY
description: A community group set up to investigate the status of refugees and other immigrants, particularly Asians, who have resettled in the Flatbush area of Brooklyn has concluded that efforts to help them are overwhelmed by growing demands.

title: MAKE THEM RESENT YOUR SPLENDOR
description: LEILA

title: 'A SILLY LIFE...I MISS IT'
description: THE CRAZY YEARS

title: JESUITS RENEW THEIR MISSION OF SOCIAL JUSTICE
description: The Society of Jesus ended its 33rd General Congregation here this week by reaffirming the order's joint mission of faith and social justice, a policy that has led to some Jesuit practices that have been assailed by Pope John Paul II.

title: BROKERS MONOPOLIZE RENTAL VACANCIES
description: IT IS possible to find an apartment in

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE William L. Hutcheson Memorial Forest, a nature preserve and field-research area in the Somerset County community of Franklin Township, is growing in more ways that one.

title: CANARSIE FINALLY BEATS JEFFERSON, 14-6
description: It was a habit that Canarsie had had for too long, agreed team members. And yesterday, the Chiefs broke a 16-year pattern of losing to Jefferson with a 14-6 victory over their Brooklyn rival. Maurice Jones threw a 25-yard pass to George Pajonas for Canarsie's first touchdown in the first quarter. In the third quarter, Steve Rashkin had a 6-yard touchdown run Jefferson's only score came in the fourth quarter off a 6-yard run by Ricky Johnson.

title: MUSIC: TRIO AT FOLK CITY
description: Martin Carthy, John Kirkpatrick and Howard Evans sounded as if they'd just strolled off some mythic village green to play at Folk City on Thursday.

title: Bomb Kills 2 Lebanese
description: Two Lebanese were killed when a bomb they were making went off by the coast road near the Lebanese port of Tyre, the military command said today. The Israeli radio quoted Lebanese radio reports as saying Israeli troops had made several arrests after the bomb blew up Friday night.

title: Lauren D. Talner To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman S. Talner of Orange, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Diane Talner, to Nicholas J. Spiliotes, son of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Spiliotes of Blue Point, L.I.

title: HIS ART BLENDS THE BEST OF TWO CULTURES ON STAGE
description: Don Shewey is a regular contributor to Arts and Leisure.

title: Laurance Rockefeller Wins Suit Over $220 in Back Rent
description: Laurance S. Rockefeller has won $220 in back rent and $10 for court costs in a lawsuit against a woodcutter.

title: No Headline
description: Pitt Triumphs In Last :007 PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (AP)

title: FURNISHING THE SENATE
description: ABC television recently did an elegant job of refurnishing in the United States Senate. The Senate can now return the favor.

title: 'BORN' AT 19

title: SOBS AND CEREMONY GREET 16 COFFINS FROM OVERSEAS
description: At precisely 7 A.M. today, a Marine honor guard and a color guard in ceremonial dress uniforms marched into a huge hangar at the Dover Air Force Base and stood facing 16 coffins. Behind them, suspended from the beams of the hangar, was a 38-foot American flag.

title: Counterfeit $5 Million Seized by Coast Agents
description: Secret Service agents have arrested three men in California and Nevada and seized $5 million in fake money. In its announcement today, the agency called it one of the nation's biggest counterfeiting cases.

title: BOXING: SO BASIC, HUMAN NATURE IS ITS BEST DEFENSE
description: MANY millions around the world believe that the fight game is so far from being a legitimate sport that it should be disowned by every civilized society. As someone who not only finds the greatest performers in boxing irresistibly thrilling, but also has been writing about them for more than 20 years, I am bound to challenge that view. However, I have too much respect for the abolitionists' argument to try to ignore or belittle them.

title: PROPER USES OF POWER
description: Suddenly, within a single week, and for the first time in years, the United States has been engaged in military actions of two different kinds and in two widely distant countries. Is this, then, the resurgence of American power that some of us have been hoping for since the election of Ronald Reagan?

title: Michele Lippa to Wed K. L. Gartner in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Simon Lippa of East Meadow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Beth Lippa, to Kenneth Lawrence Gartner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gartner of Elmont, L.I. The wedding is to be in April.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER REMODELS ITS SKYSCRAPER
description: AFTER 18 months of work and expenditures of more than $75 million, Manufacturers Hanover Trust has nearly completed the remodeling of the former Union Carbide building at 270 Park Avenue into its world headquarters. The 52-story building, which covers the block between 47th and 48th Streets, is the tallest on the avenue.

title: ARGENTINES VOTE TODAY IN TWILIGHT OF ARMY RULE
description: Argentines are scheduled to vote Sunday in national elections that will end nearly eight years of military rule.

title: Killing Suspect Called Sane
description: Michael David Miller, the son of President Reagan's personal attorney, Roy Miller, is mentally fit to stand trial on charges that he raped and murdered his mother, according to psychiatrists. Michael Miller, 20 years old, was arrested March 25, a day after his mother, Marguerite, 52, was found dead by her husband. After the psychiatrists' findings were announced Friday, Judge Thomas Fredericks scheduled a Dec. 13 hearing in Superior Court to decide if the trial should proceed.

title: INTERVENTION IN GRENADA: RIGHT OR WRONG
description: * To the Editor: Bravo to President Reagan for taking prompt action against the Communists in Grenada! If President Eisenhower had done the same in Cuba when Castro expropriated American property, we would have been spared 20 years of trouble. Now we should stop being coy about our efforts to bring democracy back to Nicaragua and mount a full-scale effort to oust the Sandinistas and the Cubans from that beleagered country.

title: DAYLIGHT PARADIGM;  For the last five weeks, there's been a four-hour instead of a five- hour time difference between the Eastern United States and most of Europe. The gap narrowed because many Europeans end daylight-saving time on the last Sunday in September. But that's only a small piece of the confusion. Russia and Albania ended it on Sept. 30. Britain and Ireland ended it only a week ago. We ended it, at least those of us who remembered, last night.

title: WHITE HOUSE TACTICS COULD BE COSTLY NEXT YEAR
description: WASHINGTON RONALD REAGAN began his political life almost two decades ago, rising from the ashes of the Goldwater Presidential candidacy and slowly building a constituency around a glowing core of anti-Communist rhetoric that powered him ultimately to the White House. And leaning on that basic theme he'll survive politically, if he can, as the incumbent accountable no longer just for stump rhetoric but for actions with mortal implications against a force he measured in global proportions.

title: PAUL SIMON USES ROCK AS A SPRINGBOARD FOR THE MATURE ACT
description: Paul Simon's intellectually ambitious pop music has always thrived on an attempt to reconcile opposing forces. Using rock and roll's simple harmonic vocabulary and casual lyric tone, he has tried to fashion the pop equivalents of short stories and paintings, in which each word, image and nuance is carefully weighed. If the rock genre was invented by unsophisticated people as a mode of spontaneous self-expression, Mr. Simon has used it to analyze his own very literary kind of angst in albums that want to be both commercially successsful and critically recognized art works. These contradictions run to the core of Mr. Simon's latest album, ''Hearts and Bones'' (Warner Bros. 23924-1), his first studio album since the soundtrack for his movie ''One Trick Pony.'' Of all of Mr. Simon's albums, the new record makes by far the most convincing case for using rock and roll as the basis of mature artistic expression.

title: AUTO MAKERS HEAD FOR A RECORD YEAR
description: The Big Three auto makers are heading for their most profitable year ever. All reported substantial earnings for the third quarter - normally the industry's low point. Yet the weak sister, American Motors continues to struggle, reporting its 15th consecutive quarterly loss. G.M. posted record third-quarter earnings of $737 million, a fivefold increase from 1982. Ford recovered from a $325 million loss last year and earn $333 million, while Chrysler's earnings rose tenfold to $100 million. Analysts predict that the money will continue to pour into the auto makers' coffers during the fourth quarter. They add, however, that the Big Three can expect the unions soon to begin claiming a portion of those profits for themselves in the form of higher wages. And the industry strength continued into October. Domestic car sales rose 41 percent in the mid-October period to an annual selling rate of 7.6 million cars, somewhat higher than the 7 million rate during September. Meanwhile, Japan appears to have decided to take a bigger slice of the market. Its new trade minister told the White House that Japan would not go along with the requested import quotas of 1.8 million cars in 1984. Rather the Tokyo Government would volunarily hold shipments to 1.9 million, up from 1983's 1.68 million level.

A worthy sequel to Isaac Asimov's ''Foundation Trilogy,'' which won a Hugo award in 1966 as the best science-fiction series of all time, the best-selling ''Foundation's Edge'' is ''future history portrayed as a great game,'' according to our reviewer, Gerald Jonas. Once again, the fate of all humanity is at stake as the First Foundation - wielding ''the power of the physical sciences and technology'' - clashes with the Second Foundation - which can ''cloud men's minds and predict mass behavior through the statistical insights of psychohistory.''
