'BEFORE' AND AFTER' LOOK FROM THE COAST
description: NEW YORK CITY is the art capital of the world, and any artist seeking worldly success must have dealings with the capital. The drive behind ''Shift: LA/NY'' at the Neuberger Museum, State University of New York at Purchase, is the demonstration of an eastward migration. The exhibition shows the ''before'' and ''after'' work of 17 contemporary artists who quit life under the palm trees of Los Angeles to ripen in the canyons of Manhattan.

title: YOUNGSTERS LEARN HOW TO BE VERY CORRECT
description: ''WHEN children are told to behave themselves, we give them the tools of the trade,'' said Betty Lou Graffagnino, who with two partners runs ''Conn-Etiquette - A State of Good Manners,'' a West Hartford-based manners and etiquette business.

title: DINING OUT ; COUSCOUS, FOR SOMETHING UNUSUAL
description: LA BARAKA in Little Neck, Queens, is a small restaurant owned and run by a family that came to the United States from Tunesia in 1962. The family members take great pride in serving couscous, a uniquely North African specialty that is not available at any other restaurant on the Island.

title: THEY'RE A DUO THROUGH MARRIAGE
description: IT happened recently in Dubuque. Invited to ask the pianist Ian Shapinsky and the cellist Aaron Shapinsky anything at all about themselves or about the concert they had just given, a young man wanted to know: ''How did you guys meet?''

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The violist Paul Coletti, 23 years old, is already a remarkable musician. In his Town Hall debut concert, at twilight Tuesday, Mr. Coletti, who studied with Yehudi Menuhin and at the Royal Scottish Academy of Music, combined a selfless service to his chosen composers - Schubert, Martinu, Brahms and Dejan Despic - with a distinct artistic personality that is entirely his own. Although Mr. Coletti has an impeccable technique, there is nothing ostentatious about his playing; the mastery is there and needs no promotional fanfare. He is an elegant artist who enhances all he plays.

title: INVINCIBLE SOMERVILLE
description: Somerville extended its unusual streak when it defeated Piscataway, 7-0, yesterday in Piscataway and remained unbeaten, untied and unscored upon after the first six games of the season.

title: NEW CANAAN TOPS LUDLOWE
description: Floats, bands, and crowds of students joined the New Canaan Rams at their homecoming game and, not to disappoint, New Canaan beat Roger Ludlowe yesterday, 34-6.

title: Union Wins, 31-14, For 13th in a Row
description: Union (7-0) scored 31 first- half points and extended its winning streak to 13 games, the third longest in the nation behind Nebraska (19) and Mississippi College (14), with a 31-14 victory over Williams today.

title: DANCE: SENTA DRIVER TROUPE EXPLORES EMOTIONS
description: Senta Driver is a thinking choreographer and, judging from the dances she presented on Thursday night at the Space at City Center, one of the things on her mind these days is emotion. The program - the second in the season that her company, Harry, is offering at the Space - contained several interesting works that examined highly emotional situations.

title: ANOTHER MYTH CRUMBLES: CRIME IS MARCHING IN
description: ONCE, in the not-so-distant past, I was preparing to leave Long Island for a year of travel and study abroad. On the eve of my departure, mother insisted that my prized possession - a gold charm bracelet hung with sentimental treasures - should remain safely ensconced at home.

title: LIST OF CASUALTIES IN GRENADA
description: The Defense Department has identified these additional United States servicemen killed or wounded in the fighting in Grenada: Killed BUTCHER, Machinists Mate 1st Class Kenneth J., West Islip, L.I. Wounded CAMPBELL, Sgt. S. M., Jacksonville, N.C. HARTER, Lance Cpl. K. D., West Unity,

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Powerboat Mark Set
description: Driving the 38-foot aluminum catamaran Peter Stuyvesant, Ted Tolman of England has set an offshore powerboat world-straightaway record of 120.951 miles per hour.

title: Schlichter on Court?
description: Art Schlichter , the Baltimore Colt quarterback who was suspended indefinitely by the National Football League for gambling on games, may stay in shape until his possible reinstatement by playing college basketball this season. Schlichter, who attended Ohio State but needs 70 more hours of credits to get his college degree, practiced last week with the Ohio University-Chillicothe basketball team.

title: ; MAKING THE CUT
description: John Tarkov's ''Making the Cut'' (About Men, Sept. 25) was a thought-provoking piece on the experience of being judged as ''good enough'' by one's peers and one's superiors, an experience, incidentally, which is certainly not confined to men.

title: GENTLE PERSISTENCE PAYS OFF IN THE SEARCH FOR EXECUTIVES
description: AFEW years ago, Peter Ueberroth

title: SHOW JUMPING'S NEW LOOK
description: THIS TUESDAY, ON ITS 100TH ANNIVERsary, the National Horse Show WILL open at Madison Square Garden. Like the Metropolitan Opera and the Brooklyn Bridge, the National is a New York institution. And like them, it is substantially the same in form as it was 100 years ago. Horses still take part in competitions called ''classes.'' The sidesaddle classes feature impeccably turned-out women wearing long wool skirts and, sometimes, veils appropriate to a 19th-century hunting field. The harness classes pit one jaunty carriage against another, the judges taking into account the horses' gaits, the way they're matched to each other and the neatness of the entry. And, as has been the case since the show opened in 1883, various levels of jumping classes provide the most spectacular performances of the show.

title: Nassau's Budget And the Sales Tax
description: The recent story entitled ''Nassau's Penny Tax Story: To Be Continued'' discussed Nassau's continuing financial problems, along with the creation of a citizens' budget commission to study the question of whether to continue the recently enacted 8.25 percent sales tax rate.

title: CLOSING THE BREACH BETWEEN HARTFORD AND FAIRFIELD COUNTY
description: LIKE necessity, adversity and disaster sometimes make strange bedfellows. Or they may make natural bedfellows take another step toward togetherness.

title: COWARD 'MARQUISE' RETAINS FROTHINESS
description: THE Nassau Repertory Theater, which has just settled into its new home in Molloy College's Hays Theater, has a special affinity for No"el Coward, and it is appropriate that they have chosen to open their new season in their newly acquired space with a Coward comedy.

title: Tokyo
description: To the Editor:

title: THE KING'S GAMBIT: SHADOW OR SUBSTANCE?
description: The King's Gambit, once the noble trigger of glorious, scintillating attacking play, hardly appears anymore in tournament practice; and when it does, nostalgia or reckless suprise is its motive.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: On First Anniversary, A Sale on Furniture

title: REACTOR DIES BEFORE IT CAN BREED
description: WASHINGTON

title: Helen Huber Is Wed To Scott Jay Curtiss
description: Helen Graham Huber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold John Huber of Summit, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Scott Jay Curtiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutledge Curtiss of New Milford, Conn. The Rev. William H. Strain performed the ceremony at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit.

title: FUJI'S JOUST WITH 'KODAK-SAN'
description: TOKYO WHEN Minoru Ohnishi talks about Eastman Kodak, the Goliath of the photographic industry, he respectfully applies the Japanese honorific form, calling it ''Kodak-san.''

title: Dr. Catherine C. Hart Plans to Wed Dr. Mark Y. Stoeckle in December
description: Dr. Catherine Carlisle Hart and Dr. Mark Young Stoeckle, clinical fellows in infectious disease at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, plan to be married early in December.

title: EX-POLICE CHIEF RECALLS STORMS
description: LONGPORT THIS town at the southern tip of Absecon Island - Atlantic City is at the northern end - is bounded by the ocean on one side and an inlet and bay on the other, making it highly vulnerable in storms.

title: PHILIPPINE COURT STANDS UP
description: Twice last week, President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the Philippines' faltering strongman, was challenged by his own Supreme Court.

title: CRIME
description: When Aaron J. Elkins's ''Fellowship of Fear'' came out earlier this year, it was happily greeted in this corner. There was something infectious about the character of Gideon Oliver, the young anthropologist who could look at an old bone fragment and give the owner's age, sex and just about everything else except name, rank and serial number. Now there arrives Mr. Elkins's THE DARK PLACE (Walker, $12.95) and, alas, it is not as good as its predecessor.

title: CASUALTY LIST IN LEBANON ATTACK
description: The Defense Department today identified these additional United States marines killed or missing in the attack Sunday in Beirut.

title: Columbia Soccer Team Beats Hartwick by 2-1
description: Columbia defeated Hartwick, 2-1, seriously dampening Hartwick's drive for a playoff position and pushing the Lions' record to 11-0-0 for the season.

title: ELECTION NEARING FOR SAN FRANCISCO
description: Except for some scattered eruptions of passion over a few of the 16 ballot measures, it would be possible for a visitor to come and go without realizing that San Francisco is a little more than week away from an election where the city's most important offices are to be filled.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Sunday night is the last chance to catch a view of ''The Green Table,'' before the Joffrey Ballet puts this amazing masterpiece away for the rest of its season at the City Center.

title: WHY REVERSE THE BENEFITS OF DECONTROL?
description: DEREGULATION of the airlines had essentially one purpose - to improve the industry's productivity by lowering costs and fares. Such reform is not always kind to every subgroup of an industry. Instead, improved productivity means that the noncompetitive companies or labor arrangements will have to undergo a painful adjustment.

title: END OF TITAN 2 MISSILES SPURS LOCAL CONCERN
description: While people favoring a nuclear freeze march through the cities of Europe and America hoping to stop a new generation of missiles, the end of an old generation of missiles, the Titan 2, is causing some economic worries here.

title: DELAYS GIVE SHOREHAM A BREATHER
description: SOMETHING there is that doesn't love a deadline, especially where Shoreham is concerned. The reactor is so far behind schedule that indeed it no longer has a schedule. The Long Island Lighting Company has declined to make a prediction since the crankshaft of an emergency diesel generator broke last summer; the last date mentioned for commercial operation of the reactor was Jan. 1, 1985. That would make Shoreham a 20-year job, which is to say twice as long as it took to build the Suez Canal, and about the same as for the Pyramid of Cheops.

title: BRINGING DECENRALIZATION TO THE RESERVATION
description: On the walls of the Hopi tribal chairman's office hang pictures of President Reagan and Arizona Senator Barry M. Goldwater, two exponents of Federal minimalism whose likenesses might seem out of place here at one of the more government-dependent institutions in America, an Indian reservation.

title: PROJECTS LISTED BY STATE
description: The following is a list of projects state officials say they have proposed to be undertaken in the county over a five-year period if voters approve passage of the $1.25 billion ''Rebuild New York'' bond issue. The list is based on information supplied by the state's Department of Transportation. Agency officials said the cost of the projects would be met not only from bond revenues but also from regular state appropriations and Federal aid.

title: STEPS TO THE INVASION: NO MORE 'PAPER TIGER'
description: The Reagan Administration's overriding reason for invading Grenada was to keep the United States from being perceived as a ''paper tiger'' in the eyes of both friendly and hostile Latin American nations, Administration officials said today.

title: Ronald David Reading Is Married to Diane Flynn
description: Diane Patricia Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Flynn of Brightwaters and Fire Island, L.I., and Amelia Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Ronald David Reading, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Reading of North Hollywood, Calif. The Rev. Peter Dillon performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: A COZY SEAFOOD SPOT
description: WHY is it, we wonder, that so many restaurants seem to believe that fresh seafood, especially shellfish, requires heavy breading and deep frying? Do they have something to hide or is it merely a custom held over from times when that might have been the case?

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE PEKING MANDATE

title: PENTAGON SUPPLIER ASSAILS REPORTS ON PRICES
description: The Defense Department can make changes to get a better deal on spare jet engine parts, but many reports of soaring prices are inaccurate and sensationalized, the president of the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group says.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The contemporary German painter Marcus L"upertz is best known for big forthright paintings that are long on rhetoric. Images that have to do with power, authority and violence move in and out of them, and they sometimes have a hectoring quality that does not go down too well in this country.

title: U.S. REPLACES PART OF FORCE; SENATE CHIEFS URGE INQUIRY
description: United States forces using helicopters searched today for up to 600 Cuban soldiers thought to be hiding in the heavily wooded hills of Grenada, military officials said.

title: WAS LIFE BETTER BEFORE MAO'S REVOLUTION
description: BROKEN EARTH

title: CHAMBER: QUARTET
description: Ralph Towner, Paul McCandless, Collin Walcott and Glen Moore, who make up the chamber quartet Oregon, possess an instrumental versatility that gives their impressionistic compositions a geographical scope that warrants the label ''world music.''

title: INVENTORS GATHER ON L.I. TO HELP MAKE IDEAS PAY
description: Like thousands of other owners of backyard swimming pools, Dr. Richard Kravath found that building his pool was only the first problem - he then had to keep it clean.

title: World Series And Surfing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JAZZ: VALERY PONOMAROV
description: The trumpeter Valery Ponomarov's tenure with Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers served him well. Universal Language, the quintet he led Tuesday and Wednesday at Lush Life, recalled the Messengers in the way it yoked a hard-charging rhythm section to expansive solos.

title: TEXAS OVERCOMES TEXAS TECH, 20-3
description: Todd Dodge substituted today for the second consecutive week and rallied Texas to a 20-3 victory over Texas Tech in a Southwest Conference game. The Longhorns (7-0, 4-0) trailed the Red Raiders (3-4, 3-1) at halftime by 3-0. Dodge, who replaced Rob Moerschell last week and led Texas to a 15-12 victory over Southern Methodist, took Texas on a 72-yard scoring drive in the third period.

title: PENTAGON ORDERS BEIRUT INQUIRY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger announced today that a formal inquiry would be held into the bombing of the marine barracks in Beirut last Sunday.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION 119 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 2219 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 338 CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. 4413

title: Q AND A
description: Trees Grow in Brooklyn Question:

title: Data Bank;October 30, 1983
COACHLIGHT'S 'DOLLY' LACKS A CENTER
description: ''HELLO, DOLLY!'' took the charm right out of Thornton Wilder's ''The Matchmaker,'' its source, and substituted elaborate productions, musical momentum, elegant style and a star - star after star after star.

title: A TASTE OF EARLY LIFE IN BROOKLYN
description: THIS past spring, with pageants, exhibits, fireworks and much popular enthusiasm, New Yorkers celebrated the centenary of one of the most inspiring events in civic history: the opening, on May 24, 1883, of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: I'M DREAMING OF TRADING MOTHERHOOD FOR A POLAR CAREER
description: MAGAZINE articles are now saying that it is very difficult for a woman to have both a family and a career. It's too late to tell me that. I just signed on as a microbiologist with an Arctic expedition.

title: COMPANY THRIVES ON TOXIC WASTES
description: THE thought of Love Canal or Times Beach might bring shudders to environmentalists and to owners of companies that produce hazardous wastes, but it has created a bonanza for one new Connecticut company.

title: Where to Write
description: To the Editor:

title: THERE'S A KNACK TO FIXING THE JOINTS OF A WOBBLY CHAIR
description: WHEN a chair becomes loose or wobbly, one of the first things to do is see if there are any wood corner blocks or metal braces on the underside of the seat that can be tightened. Often these have screws or bolts that help make the framework rigid, so simply tightening these will do the trick.

title: Guild Unit Dissociates Itself From Mondale Endorsement
description: A local of the Newpaper Guild representing workers at United Press International and The Associated Press has dissociated itself from the guild's support of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Uruguay General Says Vote Is On Despite Political Fight
description: Uruguay's military rulers are to conduct a plebiscite and hold elections even if they cannot agree with political parties on a proposed overhaul of the Constitution, a top general was quoted Friday as saying.

title: No Headline
description: For the People

title: FROM A GRENADIAN DIPLOMAT: HOW PARTY WRANGLE LED TO PREMIER'S DEATH
description: A Grenadian Embassy official here says the events that led to the death of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop on Oct. 19 began at a secret meeting in Grenada the month before when the Central Committee of Mr. Bishop's party told him he would have to share leadership of the country with his Deputy Prime Minister, Bernard Coard.

title: RETURNING TO A BELOVED LAND
description: E. J. MUDD is a writer who lives in McLean, Va.

title: 500,000 JOIN DUTCH ANTIMISSILE RALLY
description: An estimated 500,000 people turned out here today for a peaceful mass rally to protest NATO's scheduled deployment of intermediate-range missiles.

title: A BIG BANK SERIES OFFER THE UNUSUAL
description: Nostalgia for various periods of recent American history has been a thriving part of the record industry for years, and the 30's and 40's have been a major part of that glance backward. In a new look at that era, Time-Life Music is issuing a series of big band recordings offering some unusual attractions for fanciers of the music of that time. The series includes, at the moment, 12 albums, each devoted to one band: Glenn Miller, Benny Goodman, Jimmy Dorsey, Tommy Dorsey, Gene Krupa, Harry James, Duke Ellington, Artie Shaw, Woody Herman, Count Basie, Charlie Barnet and Les Brown.

title: SUPERVISORS PRESS LIBEL SUIT AGAINST 3 UNIONISTS
description: Three employees at a Kenosha, Wis., plant of the American Motors Corporation are to go to trial Monday over allegations that they libeled their supervisors in a dissident union newsletter. The case, in Circuit Court in Racine, Wis., is believed to be the first such civil suit to go to trial since a May 1983 Supreme Court decision gave employers much broader grounds for bringing libel suits against employees.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE VERSATILE TABLE
description: OF all the different forms of furniture, tables have an almost magical ability that no other furniture has - that is, to be transformed into different shapes and sizes and uses. True, bedsteads can be taken apart and their posts and rails stacked but the result no longer is usable as a bed. Chair legs can be cut down to make a smaller size, but the result is still a chair.

title: TILLING THE SOIL OF SUBURBAN FARMETTES
description: -gold soybean plants, ready

title: HOFSTRA TOPPLES ST. JOHN'S
description: Todd Jamison, the St. John's quarterback, completed 15 of 34 passes for 205 yards against Hofstra yesterday in a showdown of unbeaten Division III teams. His counterpart, Rich Codella, completed just 2 of 10 for 70 yards.

title: NEW YORK COLLEGES AREN'T SO COLLEGIAL
description: When the annual meeting of the Association of Colleges and Universities of the State of New York got under way earlier this month in Ithaca, representatives of 80 private schools were marked absent. They stayed away in protest, accusing the state's two huge public universities of reneging on a promise to agree on a joint legislative agenda for the coming year. Officials of the State University of New York and the City University of New York denied the charge, but the incident was another example of increasingly strained relations as public and private colleges compete for students and money, both of which are getting harder to come by.

title: FATHER AND SON AND THE RUSSIAN EARTH
description: THE MEMOIRS OF LEONID PASTERNAK

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BROADWOOD BY APPOINTMENT

title: NEW ACCOUNTING RULES: STILL A TANGLE
description: New accounting standards governing the reporting of foreign currency transactions may be more of a headache than a remedy, according to two Stanford educators.

title: No Headline
description: Black Dance Events

title: MILLER PLACE TAILBACK THROWS 2 SCORES
description: Jim Whitney threw two touchdowns passes and scored on an 80-yard run as Miller Place trounced Mercy, 33-0, and tied for first place with Babylon (4-1) in League VI. Whitney started the season as a quarterback but was moved to the tailback position two weeks ago. He threw an 18-yard pass to Chris Daly in the second quarter and an 8-yard pass to John Martirano in the third. Dan Jones, the current quarterback, ran 31 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A HOUSE WARMING'' is what Thomas C. Timmons called the reception scheduled last Thursday to introduce the Westchester School for Special Students officially to its new neighbors in Harrison's Louis M. Klein Middle School.

title: WHY ROBERT MOTHERWELL PROVOKES DIVERSE OPINIONS
description: As much as any living artist, Robert Motherwell divides the art community into two camps. For some he is a modernist master, a major figure of Abstract Expressionism, someone whose bulbous, suspended, splattered forms have expanded the possibilities of abstraction and art in general. For the pro-Motherwell camp he is also a voice, perhaps the most eloquent spokesman for a heroic approach to art that was mocked and repudiated by post-Abstract Expressionist generations.

title: FROM BEIRUT TO GRENADA, THE PRICE OF POWER RISES
description: WASHINGTON IF one central principle has animated President Reagan's foreign policy, it has been the urge to confront

title: POLITICAL AND LEGAL RECOURSE
description: ONE of the most shocking experiences life can hold for a homeowner is the condemnation of his house for such public needs as the widening of a road, the extension of a sewer or subway line or the clearing of a plot of land for redevelopment as a solid waste plant. When such public needs are judged to override the private needs of the homeowner, government authorities may legally seize the private property, provided they give the owner fair compensation.

title: Sittler and Clarke Lead Flyer Victory
description: Darryl Sittler and Bobby Clarke scored third-period goals to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Golden Gate Bridge To Get Deck Repair
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 (UPI)

title: BOEHM ADDING FACTORIES AND NEW PRODUCTS
description: -based Boehm porcelain studios are increasing their British operations. In July, Edward Marshall Boehm Inc. bought a bronze foundry and studio in Cowbridge, Wales, 100 miles southwest of the 12-year-old Boehm studios in Malvern, England.

title: STUDY DISPUTES ACCUSATIONS OF POLICE BRUTALITY
description: Study DisputesAccusations ofPolice BrutalityNew York City Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire mustered a platoon of statistics last week against those who have accused white officers of brutality against minority citizens. Mr. McGuire said a department analysis of 98 allegations of racially motivated police misconduct raised at a Congressional hearing last month provided ''no indication'' of pervasive police bigotry or brutality. ''A fair-minded appraisal of even this limited sample of incidents,'' the commissioner said, ''suggests that in these cases the officers involved acted properly and professionally.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A WAY WITH WILL

title: EYES AND EARS OF ROME Enough complaints from the flock can raise questions about the shepherd. So it was with
description: Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen , whose opposition to nuclear weapons and relatively tolerant view of homosexuality have prompted a rising number of complaints from Catholics in his western Washington State Archdiocese. Last week Pope John Paul II asked Archbishop James A. Hickey of Washington D.C. to visit Archbishop Hunthausen to examine ''criticism regarding his pastoral ministry.'' A Vatican spokesman said such a visitation was not necessarily designed to ''punish a bishop,'' but to ''clarify matters'' when there is ''conflicting information.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is the Bonn bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: STOCKHOLM SCENARIOS
description: Aknowledgeable Swedish audience greatly enjoyed watching the recent world team championships at the Hotel Anglais in Stockholm. As is normal nowadays, they were not allowed in the playing rooms, which were barely large enough for a table, four players and an official or two, but they could see much more on the Vugraph show.

title: Wife-Beating Held An 'Acting-Out'
description: Sandra Gardner's Sept. 25 article on family violence is indicative of the increasing attention given to this problem.

title: Inter-American Press Group Sights Attacks on All Sides
description: Press freedom in the Americas is ''under attack from all directions,'' the Inter- American Press Association said in a final report adopted Friday in Lima by 250 publishers, editors and news executives at the association's annual convention.

title: BERNSTEIN'S 'TRISTAN' HIGHLIGHTS THE NEW OPERA RELEASES
description: Perhaps the most eagerly awaited of the fall opera releases is Leonard Bernstein's account of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' (Philips 6769 091, five disks). Mr. Bernstein probably counts as our most overtly Romantic international- circuit conductor, the man with the most tangible links to the great Romantic conductors and composers of the past. He has proved his affinity for such repertory with his long-admired Mahler interpretations. But partly because of a lack of opportunity (the American concentration on symphonic rather than operatic repertory), and possibly from a lack of personal sympathy, Mr. Bernstein has not given us much of the great, complete Wagner operas.

title: WHEN--AND HOW--UNCLE SAM CAN HELP
description: Contrary to what seems to be popular opinion, American embassies and consulates are not travel agencies, law offices, Red Cross stations, banks or hostels for the weary of foot and empty of pocket. Their staffs will not change hotel reservations, post bail, tend the sick, lend money or provide sleeping bags to ease the discomfort of sleeping on their foyer floors.

title: 2 ARE NAMED BY KOCH TO MUNICIPAL POSITIONS
description: Claudia Wagner was appointed Friday by Mayor Koch as the city's legislative representative in Albany, and John Gilbert was named the Mayor's representative on the Board of Estimate.

title: STATE AGENCIES GET A CHEAPER PHONE SYSTEM
description: A state employee assigned to the State Fair in Syracuse last month tried to call a relative in Rochester using her office phone. But the only place she could reach by long distance was Albany.

title: FEWER BILLBOARD PAINTERS PRODUCE THE BIG PICTURE
description: Far below Paul Chan, the pigeons circled and swooped. A taxicab honked, a jackhammer pounded, a band played and an ambulance with its siren screaming rushed by. Sounds of New York's streets drifted up to Mr. Chan, who stood high above Times Square, barely taking notice.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
THE FINE FUNITURE OF IOWA'S AMANAS
description: GLORIA LEVITAS is an anthropologist and writer who lives in New York. Most visitors to the seven Amana colonies - 100 miles east of Des Moines - go primarily for a glimpse into the past. They go to admire the neat gardens, sunlit stone buildings and communal kitchens, built by a group of German, Swiss and Alsatian Protestants in 1854, that made up the collective enterprise which persisted until 1932. Others go to the Amanas to shop for handmade furniture and clocks, brooms and baskets, dolls, gifts and woolens. Old styles seem fresh, and the workmanship is evidence that the skill and caring of the past have been preserved.

title: Indoor Soccer Is Optimistic
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League will open its sixth season Friday night with 14 teams and with enough in its favor to overshadow its problems. A promising new franchise in the state of Washington and the presence of Rick Davis should help overcome the loss of three franchises that are now part of the North American Soccer League.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Today Ruth Orkin is best known for her romantic color photographs of New York City as seen across Central Park from a vantage point high above ground level. Her current exhibition at Rizzoli Gallery, 712 Fifth Avenue through Nov. 7, includes many of these, some from the recently published book, ''More Pictures From My Window'' (Rizzoli, $17.50 in paperback), others from her earlier book, ''Pictures From My Window.'' But it also includes a number of black-and-white photographs from the 1940's and 1950's when Miss Orkin was a photojournalist. It is in effect an informal retrospective, and it says a lot about the photographer's artistic attitude toward life.

title: Economics and Race
description: To the Editor:

title: French Rider Takes Jumper Match Race
description: Herve Godignon of France won the $7,500 international open jumper match race tonight at the Washington International horse show.

title:
GARDENING;
A MATTER OF IMPROVING YOUR GARDEN SOIL
description: THE nature of the soil has a greater influence on success with plants than any factor other than climate. Fall is an ideal time to work heavy clay soils.

title: MUNCH EXHIBITION BENUSES AND FASCINATES THE CHINESE
description: The brooding world of Edvard Munch, the Norwegian artist who was a forerunner of Expressionism, has been luring crowds into the Peking Fine Arts Museum this month.

title: NEGLECTED SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINTMAKERS AT NEW BRITAIN
description: LIKE the short man who yearns to play big league basketball, print fanciers would like to have their speciality ranked with painting and sculpture. That it has not been is a result of prejudice and ignorance. Or so contends Jeffrey Wechsler, the curator of the Zimmerli Museum at Rutgers University, in his catalogue introduction to a recent show inaugurating the museum's print archives.

title: WASHINGTON ; WHAT WENT WRONG?
description: One of the odd things about the conduct of U.S. foreign and military policy in the last 50 years is why we are so often taken by surprise.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH NATO?
ON REFLECTION, IT'S STILL 'NO'
description: Lawmakers in New Jersey argued that a statute requiring a moment of silence in public schools was designed to foster order, not religion, but last week a Federal judge wasn't sitting still for it. Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise struck down the law as an ''obvious attempt to cross the forbidden line'' separating church and state.

title: POSTINGS;
description: While some Brooklyn neighborhoods like Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens, Boerum Hill and Park Slope stand as shining examples of the borough's recent rebirth, the immediate vicinity around the Brooklyn Academy of Music has continued to deteriorate.

title: TRANQUILLITY ELUDES MANORVILLE PROJECT
description: WHEN Vincent J. Tirado moved into Greenwood Village in Manorville, he thought he was buying his ideal retirement home. Brochures promised leisure living in affordable modular houses. But for Mr. Tirado and many other residents, living in Greenwood Village has been anything but relaxing.

title: POTOS I, BOLIVIA S CITY OF SILVER
description: PETER J. McFARREN is a journalist who lives in La Paz, Bolivia. In the late 16th century the great Inca

title: PLEAS AND DECISIONS
description: LAUGHING WHITEFISH

title: WHAT SIDELINED THE N.B.A.'S REFEREES
description: THE National Basketball Association began Friday night what

title: Wightman Cup Debut
description: Chris Evert Lloyd will be missing from the United States Wightman Cup squad, but Martina Navratilova will be in the lineup when the 60th competition against the leading British players starts Thursday at Williamsburg, Va. This will be the first Wightman appearance for Miss Navratilova, the world's leading female tennis player. Mrs. Lloyd, who has appeared in 14 cup matches, will play instead in a mixed doubles tournament in Houston.

title: REVELING IN MILITARY POWER
description: Bot h the tragedy at Beirut airport and the American invasion of Grenada offer dramatic insight into the Reagan Administration's foreign policy, one whose true objectives are often obscured by its rhetorical bows to public opinion. These events reveal a militarized Administration, obsessed with force and more than a little trigger-happy, an Administration that has never learned that being strong is not the same as looking tough.

title: BROOKLYN RENTS LURE ARTISTS
description: WHEN Andrea M. Biggs, a painter, and her husband, Timothy, an anthropologist, arrived in New York from Massachusetts last year, they were hoping to rent an inexpensive but spacious apartment in lower Manhattan.

title: Double Trouble
description: The University of Virginia basketball team has been dealt a double blow at center, the position Ralph Sampson played the last four seasons. Wingo Smith , one of the logical successors to Sampson, has left school for personal reasons, and Kenton Edelin , who was expected to start in Sampson's place, suffered a face injury in practice and will be out from four to six weeks.

title: TO TREAT HAZARDOUS WASTES, WE MUST FIND THE RIGHT SITES
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency recently reported that our nation generated four times as much hazardous waste annually - about 150 million metric tons, or 40 billion gallons - than had been estimated originally.

title: NUCLEAR SWORD OF DAMOCLES: FINGER OVER THE BUTTON
description: IT was a sunny late summer Saturday, only a bit warmer in this northeastern corner of the Western Hemisphere known as New York State than average: 93 degrees, the weather forecaster announced with exclamation points. On this beautifully clear day, I was at work, engaged in a regional ritual, a convocation that marks the formal opening of the academic year. This entails the sitting through a required number of speeches revolving around current key words in education: ''mission,'' ''goals,'' ''evaluation.''

title: BLACK-DUCK HUNTING LIMITED IN ATTEMPT TO RESTOCK SPECIES
description: As ducks and geese begin their annual migration south, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation has imposed restrictions on hunting black ducks in New York State in hopes of stemming a decline in their population.

title: RARE CHINESE MURALS GET A FACELIFT IN TORONTO
description: Audrey Topping is the author of ''The Splendors of Tibet.''

title: BREAKING THE NEWS ON CASUALTIES
description: TELLING a family that their son has died in some faraway place is never an easy task, and for Connecticut's two Marine Corps casualty assistance officers, the notifications they had to make last week were the toughest.

title: POETRY READINGS AT LIBRARIES
description: THE seventh season of The Poet's Voice, a series of free poetry readings, will begin today at the Darien Library when Alan Dugan, a winner of a Pulitzer Prize for Poetry and the National Book Award, will read from his work.

title: MARCOS WARNS OF STIFF PENALTIES FOR HOARDING
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that Filipinos found hoarding gas and basic food items would be given stiff penalties.

title: Elizabeth VanT. Weisbecker Is a Bride
description: Elizabeth VanTassel Weisbecker, daughter of Franklin Weisbecker and Elizabeth Dannehower Weisbecker, both of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Townsend Claghorn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Claghorn Jr., also of Princeton. The Rev. Edward Morgan performed the ceremony at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: HAMPTONS INSPIRE A JAZZ FUSION
description: ONCE it was a quiet retreat from the city's oppressive heat. Now the Hampton setting has acquired a reputation for satisfying almost any desired pleasure; it is even serving as the theme for an exhibition of avant- garde wall constructions in a SoHo gallery.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: One of the most appealing of New York's instrumental groups, the Jupiter Symphony, begins its fifth season Sunday afternoon with a special concert in Harlem. The Jupiter, conducted by Jens Nygaard, the group's music director and one of its founders, will appear at St. Martin's Church at Lenox Avenue and 122d Street in Harlem.

title: Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STATE GIVES HOUSING A HAND
description: It was worth spending a night in the rain, many New Jersey residents decided last week, to finance the roof over their heads with low-cost mortgages from the state. When 63 lending institutions began offering the 10.55 percent, 30-year home loans Monday morning, the lines lasted longer than the money.

title: GOLIATH IN GRENADA
description: If there is an argument at all for the way the United States invaded Grenada, President Reagan has been clumsy in making it. The rescue of medical students was, almost by his own admission, only a pretext. Their evacuation, if necessary, could have been accomplished by lesser means. The legal justifications were a sham. Such breaches of treaties and sovereignty can only be rationalized by the aggressions of others.

title: DOWNEY SETS SIGHTS ON STATEWIDE RACE
description: REPRESENTATIVE Thomas J. Downey has been a behind-the-scenes adviser to his friend and political ally, Assemblyman Patrick J. Halpin, the Democratic candidate for Suffolk County Executive. Indeed, it was he who helped persuade Mr. Halpin to run after briefly raising and then sinking the possibility that he himself might be a candidate.

title: Belfast Butcher Shot Dead
description: Two gunmen killed a butcher as he washed a window in front of his shop in Belfast today, and a young girl inside the shop was slightly grazed by a bullet.

title: All Along Captures Turf Classic Easily
description: All Along, the 4-year old filly who won the Prix de l' Arc de Triomphe Oct. 2 in France, ran away from nine male rivals for an easy victory in the $585,700 Turf Classic yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: ; THE CONTROL OF INFORMATION
description: Regarding Floyd Abrams's article ''The New Effort to Control Information'' (Sept. 25): Outrage at such efforts goes beyond the press box or any academic hall: We are all in this one together.

title: IN KYOTO, CEREMONIAL AND SUBTLE SWEETS
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM is a writer who divides her time between New York and Japan.

title: Miss Nedeau Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Melinda Ann Nedeau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Nedeau of North Muskegon, Mich., to Donald James Shea Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shea of Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. William Zink performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Muskegon, Mich.

title: HOMES EMPTIED IN GAS LEAK
description: About 500 homes were evacuated for eight hours today after a gas main ruptured, sparking a brief fire and sending natural gas into sewer lines, officials said.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE sound track from the movie ''Flashdance'' is reverberating throughout the cavernous gymnasium and a strikingly muscled young man is barking directions at five rows of dancers. ''One two three,'' he shouts, a grin on his face but unmistakable authority in his voice. ''Right arm up, left arm up, four, five, six. Step out, step together, and pivot.''

title: Joan Kamin Becomes Bride
description: Joan Elizabeth Kamin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Kamin of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Erik Hedegarard-Schou of Houston, son of Erna LaBombarda of Phoenix and Ib Schou of Brooklyn. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church. The bride's father is a vice president of Shearson- American Express in Greenwich, Conn.

title: TOPICS
description: I wake up in the morning. I sit up in bed. I look at my husband and I hate him.

title: THE CONTROL OF INFORMATION --
description: The irony of the situation is that the Reagan Administration is violating the most basic tenet of classical conservative ideology.

title: 49ERS ARE ROLLING AGAIN AFTER COLLAPSING IN 1982
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDENTS AID PEERS
description: -Hartridge School have begun an experiment in communication, hoping to make the transition into adolescence a little easier for freshmen at the school's campuses in Plainfield and Edison.

title: No Headline
description: * To

title: Plaints From Artist And Gallery Owners
description: As the owners of Hopoghan, a photography gallery in Hoboken, we would like to reaffirm our commitment to contemporary artists. To put it in perspective, our goals are:

title: BUDDY RICH TO PERFORM
description: Buddy Rich, the jazz drummer and ultimate showman, will appear with his band next Sunday night at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange. The performance will feature Steve Marcus on tenor saxophone and Andy Fusco on alto sax.

title: Michael L. Goldman Wed To Bonnie Klein in Jersey
description: Bonnie Mara Klein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Klein of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Lee Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Goldman of Ridgewood, N.J., and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: KEAN PRESENTS A PLAN TO EXPAND AID TO HOMELESS
description: Governor Kean has endorsed a multimillion-dollar program to improve emergency shelters for homeless people in New Jersey and to assist residents who would lose their homes because they cannot pay their rent.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Faster Track
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Tickets To Yale-Harvard Game
description: An article by David Holahan gave reasons why he will not be at the Yale-Harvard game this year (''Why I Won't Be at the Yale-Harvard Game,'' Oct. 16). Among them is the ticket price of $20, and he leaves his readers with the incorrect impression that all seats are so priced.

title: Ann Howard Weds Douglas W. Bray
description: Ann Howard and Douglas W. Bray, both industrial psychologists with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Basking Ridge, N.J., were married yesterday in Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. John P. Croneberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BICYCLE RIDER

title: Hotel Fire Loss $5 Million
description: Property losses reached about $5 million from a smoky fire at the Diplomat Hotel here, according to the Fire Department, As a result of the fire Thursday, two complexes of the oceanfront hotel as well as a center that was the site of the Florida Democratic State Convention last weekend will probably be closed for weeks, said Robin Gutmann, a fire inspector. Fifteen people, including firefighters, were treated for smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion.

title: INTERNECINE INCIVILITY
description: In a recent political tirade, I wrote that the willingness of Speaker Tip O'Neill to dismiss the charges of Carter briefing-book pilferage by the 1980 Reagan operatives made me suspicious: Could Tip's unaccustomed nonpartisanship mean, I slyly innuendoed, that the ''mole'' in the Carter White House was a Kennedyite and that ''internecine Democratic warfare may have kept on going through the 1980 campaign''?

title: JERSEY MAY ADD 11 ANIMALS TO ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST
description: State wildlife officials, concerned that development could mean the extinction of the corn snake and 10 types of birds, are seeking the first additions to New Jersey's list of endangered species since 1979.

title: Amy E. Boyle Is the Bride of Scott D. Vandersall
description: Amy Elizabeth Boyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmet J. Boyle of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday to to Scott David Vandersall, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thornton A. Vandersall of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Donald Bouressa performed the ceremony at St. Mary Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Narragansett, R.I. The Rev. Vernon Vandersall, a retired Presbyterian minister and grandfather of the bridegroom, assisted.

title: POSTINGS;
description: It is no suprise that a full- floor apartment in the vicinity of Lincoln Center would command a fairly dear price. And perhaps the $1 million asking price that Herbert Handman, a real estate developer, has put on the 2,300-square-foot floor- through units in the apartment tower he is building on West 66th Street demonstrate to what heights residential property values in that West Side neighborhood have soared.

title: ONE ON ONE IN THE SCHOOLS
description: Wherever he goes these days, New York City's Schools Chancellor, Anthony Alvarado, has one special plea: ''I need 275,000 people to give me an hour a week to do some mentoring with young people.'' He wants business and professional people to lay aside their attache cases for that hour and deal personally with 275,000 high school students, giving them special help and inspiration.

title: LENDING AN EAR TO NOISE POLLUTION
description: LONG ISLAND'S development over the last century brought a side effect that until the 1950's was largely ignored: noise pollution. Some towns on the western end were the island's first to enact noise-control laws. The Town of Brookhaven recently revised a six- year-old noise-control ordinance that had proved difficult to enforce. And now, with development continuing to spread, officials from some more- rural eastern towns, like Riverhead, Southold and East Hampton, are thinking it might be necessary to legislate noise restrictions.

title: State Players In the Majors
description: As a loyal and faithful New York Yankees fan, I was pleased to see a Connecticut resident, Brian Dayett, recognized for his promising performance as a future Yankee in John Cavanaugh's article ''Deep River Hails Its Major-League Hero'' (Oct. 16).

title: 'BACK IN JUNGLE': EX-PRISONER DESCRIBES EVENTS BEFORE INVASION
description: A Grenadian journalist who had been interned on Grenada until the American-led invasion said today that ''we need some authority to maintain order,'' but said he hoped it would include Caribbean forces only.

title: All-Day Kindergarten: Another View
description: As a preschool teacher, I would like to comment on the article by Gary Kriss (''All-Day Kindergarten Gaining Acceptance in County,'' Oct. 9). At the outset, let me state that I am not against all-day kindergarten; especially for those children who have attended nursery school. I do, however, take exception to some aspects of this article.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
MERCK FINDS A FORMULA FOR SUCCESS
description: MERCK & COMPANY is completing the acquisition of a majority interest in two Japanese drug companies - Banyu Pharamceutical and Torii Pharmaceutical. Not only is the acquisition of Banyu the first by a foreign company of a Japanese company listed on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, but the Torii deal makes Merck the first American concern to hold a majority interest in two Japanese companies.

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times
description: The Resurrection of Roberto Duran

title: CHILEAN LAND AGAIN SEIZED BY HOMELESS
description: For the last three years, Carlos Rodriguez and his young wife had been sleeping on the floor of a friend's kitchen. So when they heard several weeks ago that a group of homeless families was planning to take over a plot of public land and set up homesteads there, Mr. and Mrs. Rodriguez eagerly joined them.

title: TALENTS TRIED AND NEW ARE FOCUS OF THE FORENIGHT
description: ARE you a musical gambler, or do you go for the sure thing? Do you enjoy taking a chance on new but basically unproved talent, or would you rather stick with artists of major reputation? Piano recitals and ensemble concerts over the next fortnight will provide the opportunity to indulge either preference.

title: I.M.F. Optimism
description: To the Business Editor:

title: PLAINTS FROM ARTIST AND GALLERY OWNERS
description: Artists working and exhibiting in New Jersey hope to be noticed but expect to be ignored by New York Times critics.

title: 'CARMEN' IS EVERYWHERE
description: Annette Insdorf, an Associate Professor at Yale and Columbia, is the author of ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I felt their spirit and I saw their pride. They did not doubt their vital role in bringing a war-torn Lebanon to its feet.''

title: Barbara M. Burg, Officer of a Bank, Weds H.S. Miller
description: Barbara Marianne Burg, daughter of Robert J. Burg of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Dorothy M. Burg of New York, was married yesterday to Henry Stephen Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Miller of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Mark Shapiro performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: STUDENTS AT WESLEYAN TAKE FRISBEE TO THE 'ULTIMATE'
description: On a divot-covered field, 29 students stand in loose array tossing Frisbees - backhanded, forehanded, overhanded and between the legs. They are Wesleyan University's Ultimate Frisbee players, a team called the Nietzsch Factor.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHEN THE DARK COMES DANCING

title: MANUFACTURING ACADEMIC RENAISSANCE
description: PALO ALTO, CALIF. For years, manufacturing has been the ugly duckling of the business school curriculum. Professors lacked the interest to teach it. Students found it too boring - compared with the more heady vistas of finance and marketing - to study. And placement officers considered it the least lucrative management task.

title: ISSUES RAISED BY 'UNDER FIRE'
description: Richard Bernstein is United Nations bureau chief for The New York Times and is a former foreign correspondent.

title: 'THE GLASS MENAGERIE': AN IRRESISTIBLE DARE FOR ACTRESSES
description: Of the season's promised and rumored treasures, which are

title: A SCHOOL FOR RACING FANS
description: MOST mornings Brian Peck travels to his office in Waterbury, dons a white laboratory smock and ministers to the needs of his patients.

title:
ART VIEW;
A SHOW ON CUBISM STRESSES AFFINITIES WITH WRITERS
description: ''Cubism is a necessary reaction (to impressionism) that will give rise to great works, whether people like it or not,'' wrote Guillaume Apollinaire in 1911, complaining about the hostility with which the new movement had been greeted in Paris. ''I will go even further, and say that Cubism is the most noble undertaking in French art today.''

title: TARGETS OF TERRORISM
description: * To the Editor: All across the country, Americans are today expressing their justifiable outrage at the heinous terrorist act committed in Beirut. We are shocked that such a senseless, brutal act could be committed against sleeping, defenseless human beings.

title: WATT MAY JOIN HERITAGE GROUP
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt will go to work for the conservative Heritage Foundation when he leaves his Cabinet post next month, a foundation spokesman said today.

title: SOVIET-CHINA TALKS END WITH LITTLE PROGRESS
description: A Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Leonid F. Ilyichev, left here today after a third round of talks that failed to resolve any of the issues dividing Moscow and Peking.

title: PUPILS IN STAMFORD FIND MOON ROCKS ARE 'NEAT'
description: After traveling a quarter-million miles through space and spending a decade in storage vaults filled with pure nitrogen, rocks and soil from the moon arrived this month in Jean Richen's fourth- grade class.

title: 90 Hurt in South Africa Riot
description: Ninety people were wounded today, two critically, as students and members of a political group engaged in clashes at the black university of Zululand, a local hospital official said.

title: REJECTED NEARBY HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: NEBRASKA GETS 19TH CONSECUTIVE VICTORY
description: Mike Rozier rushed for a season- high 227 yards and three touchdowns to help Nebraska extend the longest current winning streak in the nation to 19 games with a 51-25 Big Eight Conference victory over Kansas State today.

title: BEIRUT: 'THERE IS NO PLACE FOR A FOREIGN PEACE FORCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: A BITTER PEACE LIFE IN VIETNAM
description: Craig R. Whitney, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, was a foreign correspondent from 1971 to 1980, stationed in Saigon, Bonn and Moscow. He was in Vietnam from 1971 to 1973. S OUR THAI AIRWAYS jet came in for a landing at Hanoi, skimming bomb craters that had become circular rice paddies, I felt again the cold fear that had been a fairly constant companion during my two years as a war correspondent in Vietnam. Now, it was not so much fear of danger as fear of the unknown, of what I might learn about the fate of the people since American troops left after the defeat of South Vietnam almost 10 years ago and the country was reunified under Communist rule.

title: Secret Service Comments On Killing Agents Saw
description: In the wake of a Houston killing witnessed by Secret Service agents who the police say did not try to arrest the assailant, a spokesman for the service stated the agency's policy on firearms use today and said the agency would look into the case.

title: CONERN GROWS OVER SAFETY
description: In less than two weeks, New York's State's oldest high school football rivalry will be renewed when St. Paul's School of Garden City, L.I., is host to Poly Prep of Brooklyn. The series began in 1884 but was suspended in 1981.

title: AID FOR HEATING BILLS
description: THE state will begin to distribute on Tuesday an estimated $40.5 million in Federal funds intended to help low-income residents with the cost of heating their homes this winter.

title: Victoria McNeil Marries D. C. LeVine
description: Mary Victoria McNeil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lincoln McNeil Jr. of Wyndmoor, Pa., was married yesterday to D. Christopher LeVine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Caldwell LeVine of Philadelphia and Ocean City, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. C. Vincent Wilson at the Presbyterian Church of Chestnut Hill in Philadelphia.

title: FARMERS RALLYING TO UPHOLD L.I. DUCK HERITAGE
description: THE Long Island duck industry is going through changes intended to help it remain competitive in the national market. More and more ducks are being raised off the water in totally enclosed facilities, rather than in the fresh-water estuaries of the East End.

title: DOBBS FERRY TRIUMPHS
description: On Friday night, each town held huge bonfires and pep rallies. The taverns set up betting pools on the rivalry, with bets reaching $500. Almost 4,000 people attended the game. And on Saturday night, the players and fans from Dobbs Ferry drove their cars through Hastings, honking their horns to proclaim the 21-15 victory.

title: BALLET: THE JOFFREY TROUPE REVIVES 'PARADE'
description: Robert Joffrey is a master archivist. And ''Parade,'' revived this year and performed by the Joffrey Ballet Thursday in the City Center, is one of his greatest triumphs. There is nothing quite like this chic and witty survivor of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, and the performance that the Joffrey dancers give it belies its 66 years.

title: 'FREEZE' LEADERS SEE ONGOING MOVEMENT
description: WHEN County nuclear freeze advocates staged a rally last weekend in downtown White Plains to protest the planned deployment of American medium-range missiles in Europe by the end of the year, it seemed to some that there was a resurgence of a movement that had lost momentum, after the massive Central Park gathering of June last year. But local freeze leaders disagree, contending that the movement has been steadily working toward a bilaterial, verifiable halt to the nuclear arms race and a reduction in existing nuclear arsenals.

title: THE FAMILY THAT FEEDS NEW YORK
description: SIX years ago, there was a little

title: A GHOST THAT STAYS QUIETLY AT HOME
description: ON HALLOWEEN, when most spirits go forth to haunt our public places, one kind of spirit remains quietly at home. This spirit even has a name; it is called a

title: No Headline
description: Lafayette Fate Undecided

title: LONG DAY'S JOURNEY TO MARATHON NIGHT
description: HAVING been told that it takes two years of training to run in a marathon, I nevertheless began to prepare for New York City's 14th with only five months remaining.

title: DINING OUT
description: THOSE with a taste for the good life often look with genuine regret on the closing of a dependable superior restaurant. Such a one was Damiano's. However, spirits and appetites should brighten at the news that the new owner is Maxime Ribera, a chef dedicated to the preparation of fine French cuisine. Having sold his restaurant interests in Florida, this culinary Odysseus has returned to his Westchester hearth ready, he vows, to settle down.

title: Morris Hancock, Miss Peyton Wed
description: The Rev. Linda Peyton of Narberth, Pa., daughter of Mrs. Robert W. Tilney of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Bernard Peyton Jr., was married yesterday to Morris C. Hancock of Berwyn, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Woodson Hancock Jr. of Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. John A. Smart, assisted by the Rev. Timothy Pickering, performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Radnor, Pa.

title: TECHNOLOGY TACKLES THE INTRICACIES OF TAPE REVERSAL
description: Maybe they are too lazy or too busy, but lots of listeners are loath to flip over their cassettes. They are prone to the lure of automation and partial to so-called auto-reverse cassette decks. With these decks, you don't have to turn over the cassette at the end of the first side. The machine automatically puts the tape in reverse motion so that the second side is played after the first.

title: TWO MARINES HURT IN BEIRUT ATTACK
description: Two United States marines were slightly wounded today in a 10-minute exchange of shooting with unidentified gunmen, Marine spokesmen said.

title: A TURBULENT WEEK
description: Sunday, Oct. 23

title: Searchers Off China Spot Life Jacket From Ship
description: Searchers spotted a life jacket from a missing United States oil-drilling ship in the South China Sea, a rescue official said today, but there were no signs that any of the 81 crew members had survived after a typhoon hit the vessel.

title: HERE'S TO HOLLYWOOD'S DOWNTRODDEN WRITERS
description: In the beginning there was not the word but a succession of images. Stuck in, here and there, on cards

title: MUST OPERA ALSO BE GOOD THEATER?
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,200 MARINES TO QUIT ISLAND FOR BEIRUT DUTY
description: Defense Department officials said today that most of the 1,200 United States marines in the 6,000-member Grenada invasion force had been replaced by Army troops and would head for Lebanon in the ''next few days'' to relieve the Marine force stationed there.

title: A CASE AGAINST RUSHING TINTO BYPASS SURGERY
description: Coronary bypass surgery is a major medical industry, accounting for a majority of heart surgery in the United States. But a 10-year national study released last week suggested that a substantial number of patients could safely postpone the operation and perhaps avoid it entirely.

title: THE ETIQUETTE OF RECRUITING
description: In the real world, the scouts who seek out new executive material for their companies face few guidelines when hiring. But on the campus, recruiters who set out to hire M.B.A. students often must follow the rules set by business schools.

title: Lisa Weiss Is Married On L.I. to Pediatrician
description: Lisa Dawn Weiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Weiss of Oceanside, L.I., and Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. David William Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weiss of Lincolnwood, Ill. Rabbi Nathan Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Oceanside Jewish Center.

title: Of Old Verandahs And Life Styles
description: In reply to Richard A. Rauch's essay on improving the quality of life on Long Island (Opinion Page, Oct. 9), I agree that smaller groups will make possible greater concentration on the issues. But I feel one factor is never touched upon and it involves the subject of housing.

title: SENATORS SUGGEST ADMINISTRATION EXAGGERATED ITS CUBA ASSESSMENT
description: Democratic and Republican members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that the Reagan Administration had exaggerated Cuba's role in Grenada.

title: No Headline
description: Lakers 120, Jazz 115

title: No Headline
description: Ellen Gorman to Marry

title: U.S. Warns Unesco Over Role of the Press
description: The United States said today that it would oppose any attempts within Unesco to redefine the role of a free press and might withhold its budget contribution to the United Nations body if that principle were threatened.

title: No Ruling on Stenmark
description: The president of the International Ski Federation said yesterday that no definite decision had been made on Ingemar Stenmark 's Olympic eligibility despite comments from other officials who said the Swedish star would not compete at the 1984 Winter Games in Yugoslavia next February. Marc Hodler , president of the federation, said at a news conference that Stenmark's status for the Games would be discussed by the group's council next Sunday in Bern, Switzerland.

title: THEATER: 'THE ALTO PART' BY BARBARA GILSTRAP
description: The WPA Theater has introduced many worthy new American plays, but Barbara Gilstrap's ''Alto Part'' is not one of them. It is a hand-me- down, composed of spare and familiar parts worn out through overuse.

title: INFLATION: WHY SOME WORRY
description: ''Keeping inflation under control,'' White House spokesman Larry Speakes said last week, ''requires constant vigilance.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE HUMAN BODY

title: JAZZ: BYARD-KLOSS QUARTET
description: The Jaki Byard-Eric Kloss quartet romped through jazz history Thursday at Lush Life, where they are appearing through today. Like Kurt Vonnegut characters who had come ''unstuck in time,'' they played tunes and solos that leaped without warning from modal jazz to ragtime to be-bop to free jazz.

title: Cynthia Conner to Marry Richard Marshall Zwirn
description: Announcement has been made by William B. Conner of Erie, Pa., and Barbara Conner of North East, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia B. Conner, to Richard Marshall Zwirn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard P. Zwirn of Manhattan.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A PLAN TO SET A MINIMUM FARE
description: EVEN a partisan supporter of airline deregulation would have to

title: IRELAND AND ITS DISCONTENTS
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF SEAN O'FAOLAIN

title: RABBIT IN THE ROUGH
description: Ignorant of its extreme demands and sublime satisfactions, many consider golf just another game. But John Updike has given golf literary respectability. Many writers have found a metaphor for the human condition in sports, especially in baseball, but Updike has discovered that golf ''is like life in that its performance cannot be forced and its underlying principle shies from being permanently named.'' Over the years, he has been producing, in bits and pieces and often quite incidentally, some of the best golf writing ever.

title: Poland Offers to Free 11 If West Will Take Them
description: Poland has offered freedom to 11 jailed dissidents if Western governments will give them asylum. All 11 were accused of plotting to overthrow Communist rule during the Solidarity crisis.

title: A LOUISIANA PAGENT OF CALAMITY

title: CARTOONS OR COMMERCIALS?
description: Cartoons on television are once again an issue, the wonder being that they are not an issue more often. American children grow up surfeited with cartoons, although usually cartoons become controversial only when someone pronounces them too violent. The new issue, however, has to do with merchandising. When is a cartoon only a 30-minute commercial?

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Giants vs. Dallas Cowboys, at Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 1 P.M.) Jets vs. 49ers, at San Francisco. The Jets have not beaten San Francisco in three previous meetings. The 49ers won the last game, 37-27, in 1980. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 4 P.M.).

title: IN EUROPE, AMMUNITION FOR ANTI-AMERICANISM
description: PARIS OVERNIGHT last week, every West European who sees the United States as an unreliable, bellicose, immoral ally had found seemingly perfect justification in the United States invasion of Grenada. Overnight too, every West European who regards American missiles less as protection than as a threat to his safety considered his arguments had been bolstered.

description: ELLIOTT AVENUE in Yonkers has just the kind of houses that people like to renovate - and that is what worries the people who live there now.

title: POETRY PRIZE AWARDED
description: George Starbuck has been named winner of the 1983 Lenore Marshall- Nation Magazine Prize for Poetry. The $5,000 prize, supported by the New Hope Foundation, is given annually for the outstanding book of poems published in the United States the previous year. Mr. Starbuck's book is ''The Argot Merchant Disaster: Poems New and Selected,'' published by Atlantic Monthly Press/Little, Brown. The author is a professor of English at Boston University.

title: IS FLORIDA TAXING AWAY BUSINESS?
description: The Florida Legislature last summer came up with what seemed to be a nifty way to pay for education improvements. By last week, however, it looked as though the state was in danger of losing the very businesses it hoped to tap as a source of funds.

title: ARGENTINA VOTES FOR A CIVILIAN
description: Under the shadow of a dictator who has been dead for nine years, Argentina is making another stab at democratic civilian rule today with its first presidential election in a decade. The movement established by Juan Domingo Peron, which has provoked two military coups in the past 28 years, is alive and well and its latest leader, Italo Luder, stands a good chance of being elected.

title: FOR ITS SIZE, DEFICIT GETS LITTLE WEIGHT
description: Last spring, Congress adopted a budget with a simple promise. Before the end of July, by cutting spending and increasing taxes, the lawmakers would reduce the Federal deficit by $85 billion over three years.

title: WHEN THE FAMILIES' LONG WAIT ENDS
description: Bruce and Joyce Hastings had been bitterly opposed to the intervention of American troops in the ancient hatreds of Lebanon. Last week two marines in fatigues, accompanied by a local police officer, knocked on the door of their home in Seaford, Del., and confirmed their worst fears.

title: LOW-COST MORTGAGES GO QUICKLY
description: LUCKILY for Robert Stern and his wife, Cheryl,

title: DUAL FAILURE IN KIDNEY MACHINE BLAMED FOR 3 DEATHS IN DALLAS
description: A double failure in a machine that automatically prepares chemicals for kidney dialysis caused three patients here to suffer heart failure within minutes of one another Friday, the medical director of the Dallas Kidney Disease Center said today.

title: THE OLD KIT BAG
description: When I was a child I always had to eat everything on my plate, unpleasant though it might be. If I balked, some adult was always ready to say, ''Think of all the hungry people in the world who'd love to have those boiled rutabagas.''

title: BRADLEY AIRPORT SEEKS NEW IMAGE
description: EVEN though the official name of Connecticut's major airport has been Bradley International Airport for more than a decade, many travelers still refer to it as Bradley Field.

title: NEW FACE ON 59TH
description: Until the end of August the building with the dramatic dark glass facade at 5 East 59th Street, just off Fifth Avenue, was the site of the New York Playboy Club. But last year the publishing and entertainment empire sold the building to the Hong Kong and Shanghi Banking Corporation, which will establish its United States headquarters there.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 1 in some issues last Sunday misidentified a discount clothing store. The photo was taken in Marshalls in Carle Place, L.I.

title: CASEY SEES A SOVIET CHALLENGE
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the United States had failed to properly confront the challenge of the Soviet Union in developing countries and now must adopt ''a realistic counterstrategy.''

title: HOUSE FRESHMEN TAKE THE MONEY TO RUN
description: In December, when they gathered at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government for orientation seminars, many of the newly elected members of Congress found considerable disagreement on Social Security, the arms race, the Middle East and the economy. But one topic that found agreement was the need to curb the influence of political action committees.

title: A PIONEER OF GLASS AT A SHOW IN TENAFLY
description: TENAFLY AN ARTICLE in Craft Horizons magazine 30 years ago referred to Maurice Heaton's ''wizardry with glass.'' Seen against the extraordinary blown glass now being made by younger artists, it is hard to realize how original it was, in 1947, to sprinkle crushed crystals of enamel on window glass and fire it in a kiln.

title: POPE ISSUES ARMS APPEAL TO REAGAN AND ANDROPOV
description: Pope John Paul II told a final session of the Synod of Bishops today that he had personally appealed to President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, to press for an end to the arms race.

title: Writer Engaged To Spencer Boyd
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Boyd Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Spencer Boyd, to George Crawford Bradley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradley of Sagaponack, L.I.

description: New Jersey is losing its ''brightest young people'' to other states, according to an analysis of the 1980 census by a Princeton University study group.

title: THE REACTOR THAT MAY BREAK THE BANK
description: It is 10 times over budget and six years behind schedule. It was built to cut electricity rates, but the power it generates will cost almost twice as much as power from conventional plants.

title: TEACHERS TO MEET ON AN UPBEAT NOTE
description: ''LET'S Celebrate Public Education'' is the theme of this year's convention of the New Jersey Education Association.

description: Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello, unhappy with the property-tax assessment on his Westchester County home, has taken the matter to court.

description: NELSON BRYANT writes the Outdoors column for the Sports section of The Times. umn for the Sports section of The Times.

description: I would like to compliment your reporter for a fine job in capturing the essense of a rather complex subject: charter revision in the Town of Greenwich (''Greenwich Reassessing Its Form of Government,'' Oct.16).

description: To the Editor:

title:
ON AND OFF THE SLOPES;
AN ALPINE AND NORDIC GUIDE
description: There are ski resorts with Alpine (or downhill) skiing that is good - and with Nordic (or cross- country) skiing that is its equal. Such resorts are ideal for people sharing a vacation but not sharing a passion for the same form of skiing, as well as for Alpine aficionados who would like the cross- country option for variety or in case of severe cold or low visibility. (Last season, in the East, moderate temperatures and sparse snow left many of the cross-country centers with more peace and quiet than the owners would have wished for. Snowmaking equipment, an aid that few cross-country places have, enabled the downhill facilities to keep going.)

title: PEACE GAINS 218 YEARS AS UNION ROMPS
description: Keith Peace came up with the finest rushing performance of his career when he ran for 218 yards on 24 carries and scored three touchdowns in Union's 28-0 shutout of Westfield yesterday in Union.

title: THE ARTFUL CAREER OF A BUSINESSMAN
description: WHEN Alexis Gregory was a young man, he went to Harvard and studied the history of art. ''I had traveled around Europe quite a lot, seen an awful lot of museums, painting, art, sculpture,'' he said. ''At that point I thought I would go, basically, into the museum business - curating.''

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRA FROM IRELAND
description: Youth orchestras can be effective training grounds for instrumentalists, chiefly through the instruction and direction they get in rehearsal. Some of them, however, seem to be placing increased emphasis on public performance, even touring, these days.

title: A PLAN TO MAKE JERSEY JUST A LITTLE GREENER
description: Listening to New Jersey's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, Robert E. Hughey, over the past few weeks, it's easy to get the impression that the environmental bond issues on next week's ballot are in trouble. The commissioner and his aides have been trying to persuade voters that the Green Acres program needs another $135 million to purchase more land for open space and parks and that $50 million in bonds is necessary to protect the shoreline from erosion.

title: TOPICS
description: I recently surrendered to technology and purchased a telephone answering machine. For years I had resisted, believing that the machines were frivolous novelties for those who had grown tired of their Walkman cassettes, video tennis games, musical calendar-alarm-multifunction watches and Cuisinarts. Far be it from me, I thought, to fall prey to the latest technological toy.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: NO MAN'S LAND

title:
THE REGION;
BAR DISAGREES ON JUDGE SELECTIONS
description: The City Bar Association turned thumbs down on a black and a Hispanic candidate for State Supreme Court in the Bronx last week, adding to the turmoil of a judicial race that already had politicians and judges pointing accusatory fingers at one another.

title:
GARDENING;
A MATTER OF IMPROVING YOUR GARDEN SOIL
description: THE nature of the soil has a greater influence on success with plants than any factor other than climate. Fall is an ideal time to work heavy clay soils.

title: Cynthia White Is the Bride Of Advertising Copywriter
description: Cynthia White, daughter of Edgar P. E. White of New York and Mantoloking, N.J., and Daphne Landon White of Venice, Fla., was married yesterday to Edwin W. Cobb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cobb of Narragansett, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Hugh D. McCandless, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Ernest E. Hunt, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in New York.

title: Janet G. McCabe to Wed Jon Laramore
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aloysius B. McCabe of Bethesda, Md., and Wellfleet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Garvin McCabe, to Jon Bosworth Laramore, son Mr. and Mrs. William F. Laramore of Plymouth, Ind.
