title: SOVIET SEIZES THE MOMENT TO MAKE A MISSILE OFFER
description: In the midst of division among the Western allies over last week's invasion of Grenada, Moscow renewed its campaign to block deployment of new American missiles in Europe.

title: Miss Whitlock Plans Wedding For Late Spring
description: Mr. and Emmet Whitlock of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Valantina Welch Whitlock, to Marcus Albert Forsell, son of Uran Forsell of Stockholm and Charlotte Bonnier of New York. The wedding is to be in the late spring.

title: STATE AGENCIES INCUR EXTRA COSTS FOR LATE PAYMENT OF UTILITY BILLS
description: Many state agencies are costing the state hundreds of thousands of dollars because they are failing to pay their light and heating bills promptly, according to the State Comptroller's office.

title: TAXABLE PROPERTY VALUE ROSE IN MOST JERSEY COUNTIES IN '82
description: The value of taxable property rose last year in 20 of New Jersey's 21 counties. The only decline was in Atlantic County, where land prices that climbed sharply with the introduction of casino gambling in Atlantic City have been stabilizing, according to state officials.

title: THE BUSINESS OF KEEPING UP TO DATE
description: Information is money, or so goes one of the axioms of Wall Street. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, after years as a commodity and stock trader, has found that in Washington information is power as well.

title: 25 Wounded on Island Awarded Decorations
description: Twenty-five American servicemen wounded in Grenada received Purple Hearts and four others received the first Combat Infantry Badges given since the Vietnam War.

title: More Chinese Oil Contracts
description: Five more foreign oil companies have signed contracts to explore and develop China's offshore oil reserves, the New China News Agency said during the weekend.

title: CHAMBER OPERA BENEFIT TO HAVE NICOLAI GEDDA
description: It sounds like a good plot for an inspirational film: a worthy smaller opera company, financially strapped and forced to indefinitely postpone the opening of its season, is suddenly rescued by the intervention of two great artists who donate their services for a benefit concert to bail out the plucky troupe.

title: PUBLIC POWER TO THE PEOPLE OF NEW YORK STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: IS NICARAGUA NEXT?
description: Was Ronald Reagan's invasion of Grenada a trial run for an invasion of Nicaragua? Even if that was intended, the results ought to disabuse Mr. Reagan of the notion.

title: COSTA RICANS BEING VISITED BY VIOLENCE
description: Surrounded by swamps and cacao groves, and well beyond the reach of paved roads and telephone lines, this small town just 10 miles from the border with Nicaragua was a place to which outsiders rarely gave a thought.

title: PERU ECONOMY: HIDDEN CASH
description: The average Peruvian, enriched by a vast underground economy, is about 50 percent more wealthy than official statistics indicate, according to preliminary results of a major social science study here that were issued here today.

title: Washington WatchClyde H. Farnsworth Reshuffling Of Analysts WASHINGTON THE Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, is quietly strengthening the Commerce
description: Department's International Trade Administration with industry analysts from another corner of his department, the Bureau of Industrial Economics. The transfer involves more than 100 economists who analyze specific industries, from steel and autos to telecommunications and microprocessors.

title: RATE FEARS PERSIST DESPITE RECOVERY
description: Interest rates and Federal budget deficits are at levels that were unthinkable during the 1970's, yet the nation's economy is growing at a healthy pace and confounding forecasts of an anemic recovery from the 1981-82 recession.

title: PERONIST'S RIVAL TAKES STRONG LEAD IN ARGENTINE VOTE
description: The presidential candidate of the Radical Civic Union took a strong lead this morning over his Peronist rival in Argentine elections intended to end nearly eight years of military rule.

description: Art Schlichter, the Baltimore Colts quarterback who has been suspended for betting on National Football League games, said today he would like to return to school but had not decided where.

description: President Reagan has scheduled few meetings this week, so he can have time to monitor developments in Lebanon and Grenada.

title: APARTHEID, NOT WITHOUT ANOMALY, FACES BIG TEST
description: There are, by the racial laws that prevail in South Africa, only white people living in the Johannesburg suburb of Mayfair, a place by the tracks where small villas with roofs of corrugated tin provide home to the less affluent. But the law, unusually, has been bypassed, and so the reality is different.

title: BRITONS SHYING AWAY FROM MISSILES
description: On the eve of a scheduled parliamentary debate on the stationing of cruise missiles, there are signs that the Government's plans for deploying some of the American missiles have become extremely unpopular after the invasion of Grenada.

title: MOTHER OF THE 39TH PRESIDENT
description: Lillian Carter, the 85-year-old mother of former President Jimmy Carter, died of cancer yesterday in Americus- Sumter County Hospital in Americus, Ga., where she had been hospitalized since Tuesday.

description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel today accused Syria of bombing the United States Marine headquarters in Beirut and attacked the Syrians as a group with ''subhuman moral standards.''

description: Breathless Chronicles

title: KUNG PREACHES IN GREENWICH AT A FESTIVAL HAILING LUTHER
description: Today, on the Sunday when Protestants traditionally commemorate the beginning of the Reformation, a Swiss Roman Catholic priest stood in the pulpit of the First Presbyterian Church here and spoke of the message of Martin Luther, ''that it is God's grace, not human endeavor, that brings about salvation.''

title: HUSH DEAR WINS AT AQUEDUCT
description: A month ago, the Long Island Handicap looked like a good spot for Hush Dear to sew up an Eclipse Award as the best grass filly or mare in the country. She won the race with authority yesterday at Aqueduct, carrying 125 pounds to a stirring victory over a mile and half, but it probably had no championship implications.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope we will succeed in saving our country, which we have always compared to Switzerland and always called the Switzerland of the Orient.'' - Pierre Gemayel, founder of Lebanon's Christian Phalangist Party and militia. (A1:4.)

title: Zia Will Revive Political Discussions
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, faced with an 11-week-old opposition campaign against his military Government, will resume discussions with politicians early next month, officials said today.

title: LEBANESE AWAIT GENEVA TALKS
description: The leaders of Lebanon's main religious and political factions gathered here today in preparation for their long-awaited peace talks.

title: SECRETARY'S CHANGING OFFICE ROLE
description: office wife, that is.

title: A SPORTING EVENT WITH SOCIAL TIES
description: THE National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden may have a certain mystique, but it is a mystique of high society, not of athletes and horses. The image regularly associated with the annual show is of silver-haired, hawk-nosed gentlemen in tuxedos and elegant, diamond-decorated women in expensive furs, offering polite applause from ringside boxes as the polished horseflesh parades before them.

title: STAGE: 'TALLULAH,' REVUE
description: -comedy performers like Helen Gallagher anymore. Now in the fourth decade of her career, this song-and- dance woman can still belt out a number with the brash, unmiked clout that has all but vanished since the heyday of Ethel Merman. But if Miss Gallagher is a rarity these days, so are new musicals suitable to her robust professionalism. She must settle instead for a vehicle like ''Tallulah,'' which is wasting both her time and ours at the Westside Arts Center.

description: Airport and hotel video-game rooms are where Len (Truck) Robinson, the Knicks' power forward, can often be found blasting alien vessels off computer screens.

description: A Roman Catholic priest defended the Solidarity union activists today in an indirect attack on the Government's attempt to persuade its opponents to emigrate.

title: Suriname Reported to Order 100 Cubans to Leave Country
description: Suriname has ordered more than 100 Cubans to leave the country, according to a Dutch news agency report.

title: U.S. REDUCES FORCES IN GRENADA BY 700
description: The American force on Grenada has been reduced from 6,000 to about 5,300, a Defense Department spokesman said today.

description: Paul Foley, retired chairman and chief executive of the Interpublic Group of Companies, an advertising holding company, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The issue of what happened to the thousands of Argentines who vanished after being kidnapped by armed men during the late 1970's, long discussed in private, came to the surface during the election campaign here.

description: The military commander of the American task force in Grenada has been fighting two battles, one with the resistance on the island and another with the international press trying to cover the invasion.

description: A new magazine, with pages designed to look like wanted posters, promises cash for information that leads to the capture of accused criminals who have jumped bail.

title: Marsh Takes Golf
description: Graham Marsh, trailing his Australian countryman, Terry Gale, by three shots with nine holes to play, shot a five-under-par 67 today to win the $18,000 first prize in a $100,000 golf tournament at the Coolangatta course. Marsh shot a 12-under-par 276 for a one-shot victory over Gale, who shot 71.

title: GRIMMER VIEW IS GIVEN OF NUCLEAR WAR EFFECTS
description: The long- term environmental impact of a major nuclear exchange would make life tenuous, perhaps impossible, for survivors of the initial blasts because the world's climate would be drastically altered, according to a scientific study.

title: E.E.C. GETS U.S. OFFER ON STEEL
description: The United States has agreed in principle to compensate Common Market countries for injuries caused by Washington's restrictions on specialty steel imports.

title: DEVILS LOSE EIGHTH STRAIGHT
description: Coach Billy MacMillan said he was running out of answers to explain the ineffectiveness of the Devils, who lost their 10th game of the season tonight, 5-3, to the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: DANCE: SATIRE OF CLUMSINESS
description: DITHER and fuss. Fuss and dither. Dither and fuss. That's what Stephanie Skura did throughout ''It's Either Now or Later,'' a choreographic work that she presented Saturday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater.

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH OVER FLYERS BY 6-2
description: The Islanders continued to emerge from their early-season slump when they defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-2, tonight at the Spectrum.

title: Florida Paint Factory Burns
description: A fire at the United Solvents of America paint factory early Saturday set off explosions that sent up 200-foot flames and launched 55- gallon drums of toxic liquids ''like solid rocket boosters,'' fire officials said. Residents of more than 100 homes near the plant, north of Orlando, were evacuated.

title: MOTIVE SOUGHT IN THE SLAYING OF HAITIAN EMIGRE PUBLISHER
description: Firmin Joseph, the owner of a weekly newspaper published in New York City for Haitians, was shot to death outside his home in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn on Sept. 21. Detective Ray Apo, who was assigned to the investigation, said at the time, ''Right now it's 50-50 whether this is a political assassination or a robbery that went sour.''

title: A YIDDISH READING REVIVES A WORLD
description: A collection of smugglers, prostitutes, actors and poets who only recently had taken the familiar trip from the streets of Jewish Warsaw in the 30's to the imagination of Isaac Bashevis Singer made their way to the YIVO Institute yesterday. Once there, they charmed, tickled and touched 150 lovers of the Yiddish language.

title: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, has called for an early solution to bilateral trade disputes with Japan prior to President Reagan's visit to Tokyo Nov. 9, Foreign Ministry officials said during the weekend.

title: TAX REVOLT LEADERS RETURN TO BATTLE
description: Paul Gann and Howard Jarvis, the two businessmen who emerged from obscurity five years ago to lead California's taxpayer revolt, are trying once again to shake up government in this state.

description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Dumont, N.J., yesterday, Toni-Ann Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Smith of Dumont, was married to Paul J. Pieschl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil F. Pieschl of Bergenfield, N.J. Msgr.

title: CHRISTIANS START TO GIVE UP ON BEIRUT
description: Adnan Kassar has replaced the windows of his home six times. Mr. Kassar, a wealthy banker and president of the Chamber of Commerce here, vows to go on replacing the glass until the fighting here stops and peace is restored to his country.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Chargers vs. Washington Redskins , at San Diego. The Redskins lost twice on Monday nights this season by a total of 2 points - 31-30 to the Dallas Cowboys in the season opener and 48-47 to the Green Bay Packers two weeks ago in the highest scoring Monday night game ever.

title: Bomb at Turkish Consulate
description: A bomb exploded early today at the entrance to the Turkish consulate, causing light damage but no injuries, officials said. The officials said they suspected the bomb was planted by West Germans angry over the 1.2 million Turks working in the country.

title: WHEN PARENTS WORK ON DIFFERENT SHIFTS
description: Patricia Cremer, a reservations agent for Delta Air Lines, finished work at 2:30 P.M. Her husband, Richard, a mechanic with the airline, was due on the job at 2:50 P.M. On weekdays, the Cremers used to drive their cars to a point midway between the airport and their home in Jonesboro, Ga., for the changing of the guard: He would hand her the baby.

title: A STATE PANEL CITES ABUSES IN SECURITY-GUARD INDUSTRY
description: New York State's Commission of Investigation, citing what it said were widespread abuses in the private security-guard industry, has urged the Legislature to require the licensing of all guards in the state.

title: Ex-Teacher Gets Life In Pennsylvania Killings
description: Rejecting arguments that a former schoolteacher should die in the electric chair, a judge sentenced him to three life terms in prison for the murders of a fellow teacher and her two children.

title: Champagne Harvest Is 'Crop of Century'
description: Despite the ravages of hailstorms, the 1983 harvest of 869 million gallons of grapes in the Champagne region has been termed the ''crop of the century.''

title: Miami-Nebraska Orange Bowl Prospect
description: The University of Miami football team may not attract many out-of- town spenders into town if it plays in the Orange Bowl game Jan. 2. That is because the school is situated in the city that hosts the Orange Bowl game and most of its fans live in that region. Inviting a local team is not a way to fill hotels, restaurants and shops with tourists.

title: U.S. TROOPS PATROL AS GRENADA EDGES CLOSER TO NORMAL
description: United States forces patrolled here today amid signs that this Caribbean island capital was approaching near normal life.

title: ; LET TRANSIT FARES LURE, NOT DETER, RIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS SELF-HELP PLAN FIGHTING FOR ITS LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Meeting Called On Referee Rift
description: The National Basketball Association, in an effort to settle the labor dispute with its referees, called last night for a joint meeting of its Labor Relations Committee and negotiating team in Manhattan tomorrow.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Lawyer for Bowery In Private Practice

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch in the Company News column in Business Day last Wednesday incorrectly reported Mattel Inc.'s financial results for the six months ended July 31, 1982. The company earned $31.2 million.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Uncertainty Causes Selling
description: STOCK market activity last week was a classic example of how the market can buckle in the face of surprising, albeit scanty, news developments.

title: Pirelli Realignment
description: The Pirelli group has put its American and Canadian subsidiaries under the same senior managers, the company announced over the weekend. Marcello DeGiorgis, chairman and chief executive of Pirelli Cables Inc., Montreal, will hold the same offices at the Pirelli Cable Corporation, Union City, N.J. James E. Arnold, president and former chief executive of the New Jersey company, will become president and chief operating officer of both subsidiaries. Operations of the two companies were merged Oct. 24.

title: WHITE CALLS HIS 5 TOUCHDOWN PASSES MORE OR LESS ROUTINE
description: In passing for five touchdowns against the Giants today, Danny White tied a Dallas Cowboy record achieved by three distinguished predecessors, Eddie LeBaron, Don Meredith and Craig Morton, but not by Roger Staubach, the most immediate and most distinguished predecessor.

title: Topics In Living Color
description: Late, Lazy Leaves

title: VOTERS TO WEIGH CHANGES IN CITY CHARTER AND STATE CONSTITUTION
description: Voters will be asked to consider three proposed amendments to the New York City Charter and seven proposed changes in the New York State Constitution when they go to the polls in the Nov. 8 election.

title: INSURANCE INDUSTRY FACES TAX CHANGES
description: For more than 60 years, largely because of difficulties in measuring its profits, the life insurance industry has been governed by a special set of Federal tax laws.

title: Iran Reported to Execute 9
description: Iran has executed nine people convicted by a revolutionary court of trafficking in opium and heroin, Iran's state- run radio reported today. In a broadcast monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation in London, Iran said all nine were put to death Saturday night and this morning.

title: SPAIN'S FOREIGN-BANK GRIP
description: Times are getting harder for Spain's once-flourishing foreign banking community.

title: COWBOYS BEAT GIANTS, 38-20
description: The Jets showed today why they are one of the National Football League's most enigmatic teams. After losses in three previous games, they defeated one of the best teams in the league, the San Francisco 49ers, 27-13.

title: U.S. Team Abandons Nepal Climbing Bid
description: Bad weather has forced a Colorado team to abandon its attempt to make the first American conquest of Mount Ganesh Himal IV, the Ministry of Tourism said today.

title: Dr. Barbara Engelson Marries Marc Klee on L.I.
description: Dr. Barbara Engelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Engelson of Woodmere, L.I., and Marc H. Klee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Klee of Kew Garden Hills, Queens, were married yesterday. Rabbi Barry Dov Lerner performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

title: Stepinac Defeats Mount St. Michael
description: Kevin Chamberlain rushed for 312 yards and scored four times in the first half yesterday to lead Archbishop Stepinac to a 43-34 victory over Mount Saint Michael in a Catholic High Schools' Football League game.

title: 9 WOMEN WHO EXCELLED ARE HONORED BY RADCLIFFE
description: When Dr. Mary S. Calderone said, ''Life isn't easy at all - there are hard, hard things you have to solve along the way,'' she might have been speaking not just for herself but for all nine of the distinguished American women honored by Radcliffe College for their lifetime achievements.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS' PULLOUT
description: Texas Instruments' move out of the home computer business may be of little help to its competitors, except for I.B.M. Page D4.

title: 'REAR WINDOW' SUCCESS INSPIRES OTHER REISSUES
description: Spurred by the successful returns of Alfred Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' and Luchino Visconti's ''Leopard'' to some big-city art theaters, classics divisions at several Hollywood studios are looking into re-releasing other old films.

title: ISLANDERS 'TICKLED PINK' AT INVADERS, A WOUNDED MARINE SAYS
description: A Marine helicopter pilot wounded in the crash of his gunship on Grenada said today that local citizens ''waved to us and were tickled pink to see us'' when United States forces invaded the Caribbean island.

title: I.R.S. REJECTED IN HUNT FOR ESTIMATED INCOME LISTS
description: The three companies that compile computerized lists of the estimated incomes of most American households have refused to give the Internal Revenue Service access to their lists so it can test-use the information to track down tax evaders.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Papering the Streets

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1983

title: BEIRUT TRUCE HOLDS AS WARNING GROUPS PREPARE FOR PARLEY
description: Guns fell silent today in Beirut as leaders of the warring factions gathered in Switzerland to open talks on a national reconciliation.

title: POLL ON WOMAN ON '84 TICKET
description: If a woman ran for Vice President on the Democratic ticket next year, it would not affect the voting choice of more than half the American public, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week. Monday

title: U.S. EASES RESTRICTIONS ON COVERAGE
description: The Defense Department eased restrictions on news coverage in Grenada today by increasing the number of reporters and camera crews allowed there and permitting them overnight or even indefinite stays.

title: SATELLITE SEES SOLAR DUST RING
description: Scanning the heavens with the Infrared Astronomy Satellite has shown that the plane of the ecliptic, the flattened region in which the planets orbit the sun, is glowing brilliantly with sources of infrared emission, it was reported last night. Their distance from the sun, however, remains uncertain, according to participants in the project.

title: A Strike Is Authorized O
description: Bus drivers and mechanics yesterday authorized their union leadership to call a strike for tomorrow morning against Liberty Lines in Westchester County.

title: PANEL CALLS CITY'S SCHOOL HEALTH PROGRAMS GROSSLY INADEQUATE
description: Health programs for New York City's 1.1 million public and parochial school students are ''grossly inadequate,'' the Citizens Committee for the Children of New York said yesterday.

title: Gulf of Tonkin Searched For Signs of Ship
description: Rescue operations continued today as ships and planes from China, the United States and Vietnam searched the Gulf of Tonkin for an American drilling ship that was reported sunk with 79 American and Chinese oil workers on board.

title: Bozell or Needham For Satellite TV Corp.
description: Sometime this week the Satellite Television Corporation, a new subsidiary of the Comsat Corporation, should decide whether Bozell & Jacobs or Needham, Harper & Steers will be its agency.

title: Military Official in Bahrain
description: Richard L. Armitage, Assistant Defense Secretary for international security affairs, met the Emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa, here today.

title: No Headline
description: A HORSE SHOW GLOSSARY COMPETITION HUNTERS: Their name comes from fox-hunting, and many of the horses competing are also used for that sport. In the show ring, obstacles similar to those encountered on a real fox-hunt - fences, chicken coops or stone walls - are placed around the ring in a prescribed order, and as horse and rider complete that course, the judges look for an even pace, calm behavior and good form while jumping.

title: No Headline
description: Vote for Independence in the Bronx Once upon a time defenders of the process for picking New York's Supreme Court judges could claim that honor tempered politics. Since political leaders choose the candidates for apathetic voters to ratify at election time, only party loyalists have a chance to get on the bench. But once there, supporters of the system have long argued, staying there requires only decent performance, not continued kowtowing to the pols.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Regulating Bullion Dealers
description: HOW can investors in precious metals be protected from unethical or even criminal bullion dealers before their savings are lost through mismangement or fraud?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Chelsea Lives

title: Ester Fuchs Is Wed To Daniel J. Victor
description: Ester Rachel Fuchs, daughter of Cantor and Mrs. Max Fuchs of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Daniel J. Victor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Victor of Centerville, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla. The bride's father and Rabbi William Orentlicher performed the ceremony at the Bayside Jewish Center, where the bride's father has served as cantor for 35 years.

title: BRAZILIAN TURMOIL ON COFFEE
description: The rainy season has begun on the Sao Joao do Atibaia plantation in Campinas, the center of Brazil's most productive coffee-growing region. Next June, at the start of the Brazilian winter, the skies will clear and the leaves will have fallen from the plants, leaving behind branches of bright red berries, each pod containing two beans that a cooperative will sell to roasters, processors and trading companies.

title: Iran Says It Downed An Iraqi Warplane
description: Iran said its forces shot down an Iraqi warplane on Saturday during air raids in the northern sector of the Iran-Iraq battlefront.

title: No Headline
description: The Real Shame in Foreign Aid Something remarkable is going on in Washington. Congress will probably finish 12 of its 13 annual appropriations bills for fiscal 1984 before this year's session ends. Compare that with the customary budget logjams, which in the last two years required dumping most funding into one big ''continuing resolution'' so the members could go home. But if they can pass 12 bills this year, why not 13? Because the 13th is foreign aid. And thereby hangs a disgraceful tale.

title: POPE TELLS U.S. BISHOPS: FIGHT DISSENT ON SEXUALITY
description: Pope John Paul II has been talking to a steady stream of Roman Catholic bishops from the United States since late summer, and his principal message has been unmistakable: The bishops must more effectively proclaim church teachings on sexuality that American Catholics have increasingly rejected.

title: Laker Said to Plan Sale of Business
description: Sir Freddie Laker, whose cut-rate trans- Atlantic airline collapsed last year, is putting his Skytrain Holidays travel company up for sale after less than a year in business, company sources said during the weekend.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:At Stockholm, a Part-Score Made a World of Difference

title: SCHOOL WILL GET ANNENBERG GIFT OF $12 MILLION
description: Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher, has pledged $12 million to the Peddie School in Hightstown, N.J., which he attended as a teen-ager in the 1920's in what he called ''the happiest school years'' of his life.

title: No Headline
description: Maritime Plans Of U.S. Faulted WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)

title: PERFECTION OF 1,000 CHRYSANTHEMUMS REVEALS JAPANESE SPIRIT IN ; THE BRONX
description: It is a small and beautiful world, the island of Japan revealed in the middle of the Bronx, in a greenhouse of a thousand chrysanthemums. Some are carefully shaped like waterfalls, others like miniature and ancient pine trees, still others like sailboats before the wind. The flowers bloom in ivory and in shades of red, yellow and purple, each in a way a painting that renders the world of a humble perfectionist named Isao Adachi.

title: Flynt Says He'll Defy U.S. on DeLorean Tape
description: The publisher Larry Flynt said today he would not comply with a Federal court order to turn over Monday a tape he says records a Government informer threatening the life of the automaker John DeLorean for trying to back out of a $24 million cocaine deal.

title: 22 Marines and G.I.'s Honored at Ceremony
description: Twenty-two coffins were draped with flags and placed in a row today on the second day of ceremonies honoring United States marines and soldiers killed in Lebanon and Grenada.

title: Advertising; Executive Change at Rosenfeld
description: STEPHEN E. HUMPHREY, whose father, Champ Humphrey, was once chairman of Gardner Advertising, St. Louis, is the new president of the New York office of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson and the chief operating officer of the whole organization.

title: No Headline
description: Beyond the Police Brutality Report

title: No Headline
description: Officers Picked For I.D.S. Unit The American Express Company announced yesterday that

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed John D. Williamson Jr. president of the Transport Life Insurance Co., an Associated Madison subsidiary.

title: ANTITRUST FIGHT ON FILM SHOWS
description: What Bernard Goldberg and Jeffrey Deneroff want to know is why ''Return of the Jedi,'' ''Octopussy,'' ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and ''Superman II'' opened in more than 1,000 movie theaters around the country - but not in Greenwich Village.

title: No Headline
description: Milton Blackstone, 77;Was a Publicity Agent

title: BRIEFING
description: Hostile Activity

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Golfers A and B are each lying 3 on the fringe of a par-5 green. Golfer A mistakenly chips B's ball into the cup. What is the ruling?

title: HAGLER, HIS DUES PAID, FINALLY TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass.

title: TREASURY SALES TIED TO DEBT ACTION
description: Treasury auctions will dominate credit market activity this week, assuming that Congress reaches a compromise on increasing the national debt ceiling above the current maximum of $1,389 billion.

title: INQUIRIES STIRRED BY STOCKLENDING
description: The rapid growth in Wall Street's lending of stock shares has led to an increase in investigations of alleged fraud, bribery and other abuses in the stock loan departments of brokerage firms.

title: BUILDERS AND PRESERVERS BATTLE FOR HISTORIC TRACT
description: It would seem a natural progression. A metropolitan area grows. Farmland turns commercial, industrial. An old woman dies. Her farm goes up for sale. A corporation buys it, and the horse farm becomes an office park.

title: No Headline
description: 2 Jersey Policemen Are Shot While Trying to Make Arrest

title: Holiday Inns Chairman Retiring at End of Year
description: Roy E. Winegardner, who first opened a franchised Holiday Inn in Kentucky in 1958, has announced his retirement as chairman of Holiday Inns Inc.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Trampolines Out

title: MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1983 International
description: Services are being restored in Grenada, less than a week after American marines landed as part of a multinational Caribbean incursion. American forces guarded checkpoints and patrolled the capital, but Grenadians were also out in force, walking the hilly streets and crowding the seafront. Sniping continued from the hills around the city, but Sir Paul Scoon, the Governor General, has asked Grenadians to open their shops, return to work and send their children to school today. (Page A1, Column 6.) A cut in the American force in Grenada to about 5,300 troopers from 6,000 was announced by a Pentagon spokesman. He said that 700 Army Rangers were returning to bases in the United States. (A1:5.)

title: FIRST OF THE CUBAN CASUALTIES DUE TO LEAVE GRENADA BY AIR
description: The first group of Cubans killed or wounded in the United States-led invasion of Grenada may return home Monday on a flight arranged with the help of Spain, Colombia and the International Committee of the Red Cross, authorities here said today.

title: AT ATTICA
description: At a barred gate at the maximum-security state prison here, a young guard looked on as 18 inmates silently formed a column along the wall of a corridor. In the guard's hand was a two-foot-long club.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Michigan General Corp. has extended its exchange offer to holders of its 10 7/8 percent senior sinking fund debentures due 1992 and its 14 percent senior sinking fund debentures due 1992.

title: PROPOSED FOOD STAMP RULES MAY CUT BENEFITS FOR MANY
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted a comprehensive set of rules that would make it easier for the Government to reduce or eliminate food stamp benefits for many households.

title: Cindy Marderstein Is Wed to Dr. Alan Lichtbroun
description: Cindy Marderstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Marderstein of East Northport, L.I., and Dr. Alan Sheldon Lichtbroun, son of the Rev. William Lichtbroun of North Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Faye Krichmar Lichtbroun, were married yesterday. Rabbi Stanley Wernick performed the ceremony at the East Northport Jewish Center, assisted by the bridegroom's father.

title: Man Linked to Deaths Of 19 in Middle West
description: A house painter charged with stabbing a man to death is a suspect in the slayings of 18 other men in three states, according to the authorities.

title: NEIGHBORS SAY TWO 'SLAVES' WERE FRIENDLY BUT HELPLESS
description: Some Chelsea residents say that two apparently mentally retarded men, who the Federal Government says were kept for more than 10 years as slaves on a farm near here, were familiar figures in the community and did not appear to have been physically restrained. But others say they believe the men were held in at least psychological bondage.

title: HOW TO MAKE THE INSANITY PLEA ABUSE-PROOF
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH KOREA'S PRIORITY NEED IS DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Required Reading Tribute to Colleague
description: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of the House, in eulogy at funeral mass for former Representative James A. Burke, Democrat of Massachusetts, Oct. 17, 1983:

title: FIVE FIELD GOALS WIN FOR COLTS, 22-21
description: Raul Allegre's fifth field goal of the game, a 30-yarder with 2 minutes 7 seconds left, carried the Baltimore Colts to a 22-21 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in the National Football League today.

title: DOLPHINS TRIUMPH ON MARINO'S PASSES
description: Dan Marino, the Dolphins' rookie quarterback, ran for one touchdown and passed for two others as Miami scored a 30-14 victory over the Los Angeles Rams today.

title: SAROYAN AND HIS PLAYS ARE RECALLED AT TRIBUTE
description: ''Every playwright,'' the late William Saroyan once said, ''creates a human race.''

title: A POLITICAL CLIMATE FOR DETERRENCE
description: As almost two million European citizens have taken to the streets to protest the imminent deployment of American medium- range missiles, the Soviet Union has made it amply clear that it wants to maintain its monopoly on such weapons. Agreement in the Geneva arms control negotiations is now virtually excluded. The deadlock seems complete. The only way to overcome it and to regain public support for nuclear deterrence will be to provide a political - as distinct from military - incentive to reach an agreement. Western leaders seem to have forgotten a fundamental precept of arms control - that a compromise agreement makes sense only as part of a comprehensive relationship between the superpowers.

title: Turkish Newspapers Banned
description: Turkey's martial law authorities banned the daily newspapers Gunaydin and Tan today for an indefinite period, newspaper officials said. No reason was given for the ban, but newspaper sources said they believed it was imposed because the papers did not carry a portrait of the founder of the Turkish republic, Kemal Ataturk, on their front pages Saturday, the 60th anniversary of the republic.

title: No Headline
description: Patricia F. Peate, 72, Dead;Director of Theater Off Park

title: TWO-WAY DATA SETUP OPERATING
description: The nation's first two-way home electronic information system started formal operations here today, backed by a $1.5 million advertising campaign.

title: Revamped Pinkerton's Adds Flexi-Van Officer
description: Pinkerton's Inc., the big security and investigative company, has made further rearrangements of its management as it awaits its new chairman and chief executive, New York City Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, who is joining the company Jan. 1.

title: TOOL ORDERS SURGE, BUT STAY LOW
description: Machine tool orders, which plunged precipitously during the recent recession, rose 80 percent in September over the 1982 month, according to the industry's trade association.

title: Soldiers in Zimbabwe Evict Squatters From the Capital
description: Soldiers and policemen armed with submachine guns evicted hundreds of squatters Saturday and bulldozed their shacks made of plastic, wood and metal on the outskirts of Harare.

title: No Headline
description: Robert Thomsen, 70, Author,Stage Actor and Playwright

title: Man Suffocated by Potatoes
description: A man was killed and another injured Saturday after support beams in a farm warehouse gave way and a cascade of potatoes buried the men. Scott Tidemann, 32 years old, of Wiggins, was rescued but Henry Ruppel Jr., 39, of Fort Morgan, suffocated under five feet of potatoes, officials said. F. D. Jolliffe, the Morgan County coroner, said the men were trying to shore up some weakened aluminum crossbeams that held back tons of potatoes at a warehouse in Wiggins, a farming community 60 miles northeast of Denver.

title: I.B.M. MAY BENEFIT
description: Texas Instruments' decision to pull out of the home computer market will probably be welcomed by the stock market, but it may provide little help for the companies that were its chief competitors, analysts said yesterday.

title: PARIS SEES MISSILE ISSUE TIED TO GERMANY'S FUTURE
description: News Analysis

title: 200 CHILDREN TRY OUT FOR 'NUTCRACKER'
description: With expressions ranging from concentration to panic, 200 potential mice, candy canes, toy soldiers, angels and other small inhabitants of ''The Nutcracker'' ballet took turns raising their arms just so in a studio at the Juilliard School and essaying the steps: ''Echappe,'' a man enjoined, ''changement'' or ''pas de chat,'' while in a hallway outside mothers and a few fathers waited it out.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS TAKE TOWN
description: Left-wing rebels seized a small town northeast of the capital Sunday and assaulted army positions at a bridge and power station south of the town, civilian and military sources said.

title: NAME WINNERS, LOSERS OF INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: With the search for a national industrial policy in full swing, Congress faces a political dilemma. While the intent of industrial policy - creating jobs and expanding industrial development - is laudable, it is difficult to forget that previous Government tinkering with the economy is responsible for some of our current problems. And history has a way of repeating itself.

title: HOPES OF U.S. PULLOUT SAID TO IMPROVE
description: Military Analysis

title: Vermont Ski Resort Selects Atlanta Agency
description: At first blush, retaining an Atlanta ad agency to promote a Vermont ski resort may seem to border on the weird, but consider the fact that Austin Kelley Advertising down Georgia way has a fine track record in resort promotion.

title: No Headline
description: Australian Crew Honored

title: OILERS TOP RANGERS IN OVERTIME, 5 TO 4
description: Pat Conacher, his sweater switched to the blue and orange of the Edmonton Oilers, returned to Madison Square Garden last night and set up Pat Hughes's goal 78 seconds into overtime to defeat the Rangers, 5-4.

title: WHAT WAS HE HIDING?
description: A man who strains to conceal what he is doing must fear the consequences if the truth is discovered. What feared knowledge was President Reagan trying to keep from the American public on Grenada? Why did he bar the press from the invasion of that small island as General Eisenhower did not feel it necessary to do when his forces challenged the might of the Nazis?

title: McCumber's 65-266 Wins Tour Finale
description: Mark McCumber finished off a six- under-par 65 with birdies on the last three holes and scored a four-stroke victory today in the Pensacola Open, the final individual event on the 10- month PGA Tour.

title: IN TRINIDAD, GRENADA'S NEIGHBOR IN CARIBBEAN, BUSINESS AS USUAL PREVAILS
description: While Grenada simmers in the aftermath of an invasion, it's business as usual for its closest neighbor, Trinidad, where residents are divided on what has become an international controversy

title: U.S. CASUALITES IN BEIRUT
description: The Marine Corps today identified these additional marines as killed or missing in the attack Oct. 23 in Beirut.

title: OUTDOORS: CHILLY FINALE TO SEASON
description: WENTWORTH LOCATION, N.H.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Oct. 31, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: For 50/, Precise Time From 900-410-TIME
description: Starting Friday, it became easier to find out what time it is from the nation's official timekeeper.

title: SALARY A FACTOR IN REPLACING WALKER
description: Just when he thought he would have a respite from player personnel moves, Lewis Schaffel, the chief operating officer of the Nets, was back on the telephone yesterday atempting to replace the team's first injured player of this regular season, Foots Walker, the reserve point guard.

title: Dr. Arlene Friedman, Optometrist, Marries
description: At Temple Torah in Little Neck, Queens, yesterday Dr. Arlene Edith Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Friedman of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married to Ira Minkoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Minkoff of Los Angeles. Rabbi Alvin Poplack performed the ceremony.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: HALLOWEEN HOUSE Witches and vampires will preside throughout the Theater for the New City tonight and into the morning hours as the performance center at 162 Second Avenue near 10th Street goes all out for Halloween.

title: THEATER: 'MUSIC MAN'
description: THE Equity Library Theater has dusted off ''The Music Man,'' with all its small-town charms intact. In Worth Howe's straightforward, good- hearted production, the musical seems to play itself, and Meredith Willson's songs and repartee sound absolutely surefire.

title: CAUALTIES IN GRENADA
description: The Defense Department has identified these additional United States servicemen killed or wounded in the fighting in Grenada: Killed SLATER, Sgt. Stephen E., Lacey, Wash. Wounded CAMPBELL, Staff Sgt. Richard J., Fort
